description:
I stopped by on a Friday night around 8:30 pm and there were about 20 people in front of me in line. They do not take reservations and the seating inside is limited to about 25-30 and it is also communal seating. Since I came by myself, the server was able to offer me a single seat at the bar after waiting about 30 minutes. The bar seating overlooks the kitchen. 

After being seated the server came over quickly and I went ahead and ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen with a soft boil egg. The service was very efficient and friendly. The ramen was also brought out quickly. The broth was very rich and flavorful and the meat was tender. However, the egg was sweeter than I expected and closer to hard boiled than soft.    

They also charge a mandatory 15% service fee into the bill and they don't have any take out containers but you can bring your own. I would not recommend coming with a large group of friends and be expected to wait no matter when you come.
author: Dave S.

description:
Came here after a weeknight concert - luckily there was a minimal line, but the restaurant was packed even at 10PM, and people were showing up after us!

Seating is tight - they will likely put you at a table with other people which is great and makes for a very communal experience.

We split the spicy pork ramen and the vegan ramen. And listen - the vegan ramen is incredible. The pork ramen was great, don't get me wrong - flavorful broth, tender cuts of meat, textured veggies, etc. But for those who don't eat meat, the vegan ramen is honestly on par if not better than the pork ramen in flavor. It's incredibly rich and nutty (there are literal nuts at the bottom from making the broth!) and honestly tastes like the real thing.
author: Angela Z.

description:
I showed up on Sunday with a few friends for dinner. We got there at around 5:40 and we're sitting inside the restaurant at about 7:15PM. I would really call this an absurd wait, but the line lived long and even got longer as we inched along. 
Why? 
I wish this would be followed with "BECAUSE THIS WAS THE BEST EVER". But no. My why wasn't answered in that way. Why would you stand the chill of night to cram into a tiny restaurant for some just good ramen? The answer remains elusive to me. 
So here are the details- remember, I didn't say this place wasn't good, I am coming from the point of view of how worthy it was of an extended and cold wait. 

We had the cream based ramen with duck and pork and the heavily advertised A5 wagyu beef ramen. The cream based ramen had dense soup that though thick didn't leave the oily residue you might think it will. It sticks nicely to the noodles and gets soaked up by the kale in the bowl. The bits of duck and pork were good, and soft. And the onion shavings kept things interesting. Thing is, I didn't really get awe struck with the little differences. The duck was new, and delicious but not extraordinary. The broth was simply broth, yes with a new twist but still- broth. 
The A5 expensive ramen bowl was ok. It was advertised as only 10 served a day, but our party had two bowls (we weren't first in line by any means...) and they were still offering it after we left. I guess it's not the main reason folks come here. The beef was scrumptious but the broth was a bit of a letdown. It was light but at the same time it was super oily. The noodles were great... but really it was just a big slab of beef (delicious) on top of noodles. I guess wagyu is expensive... but I wouldn't run to get it again. 
Overall, would I go back or recommend this place? 
Very likely, I won't go back. If someone else were to ask me, I would probably encourage them to go during a weekday to possibly avoid the extended wait. In any case, if you're already in line- you might as well.
author: Nadia H.

description:
TL;DR: Broths are rich and creamy, yet light--wolrds better than your average joint. Not worth waiting almost 2 hours for.

This place is super tiny so you better be prepared to wait up to 2 hours before  being seated. Decor is very clean and service is good. 

Enoki Chips:
You ever go to a Chinese restaurant and order that deep fries prawns that have that tasty outer batter? Yeah, picture that but flavor enhanced by 1000x times. The enoki was so crispy and had me foodgasming with every bite. Make sure you save some to dip in your ramen. 5/5!!!

A5 Wagyu Ramen:
This is where they lost major points with me. When the bowl first came to me, my mouth was salivating like Beethoven slobbering all over the bed. Even the first sip of broth was beefy heaven in a bowl and the meat itself was tender, but there was still some chewing involved. My complaint about this dish was the fact that they had put way too much garlic, onion, and ginger in this dish that it  took all the broth and beefy essence away from the experience. The beef and the broth are the stars of this dish. Why ruin the flavor by muddling it with random ingredients? I would have much preferred if they only gave me beef and broth and call it a day. Even the noodles themselves were a bit undercooked for my standard. For $50, I was underwhelmed. 3/5.

Matcha Ramen:
The broth was so creamy, but so light. The chashu was very soft and the matcha powder actually accentuated the flavors of this dish. A much better experience than the A5. 5/5.

This is one of those places where you just have to try once and never have to go back again. Albeit their quality and variety stand out from the rest of the crowd, it's probably not somewhere you want to wait hours in line for more than once.
author: Jonathan K.

description:
For my 700th review, I'm giving this 4.5 stars. I'm knocking off half a star. Why? The wait. Yelpers said they waited at least 30 minutes to an hour. We waited over an hour and half. And we got there when they opened at 5. I think the best thing is to start queueing up at 4:15, that way you will be the first or second seating. For us we were the third seating and I was pretty tired by the time I got into the restaurant. It's not like Marufuku in Japantown where you can actually go and look at different shops so the time passes by quickly. Lesson learned. 

I came with my friend and thank goodness we were not that hungry because by the time we got seated, we were starving. Inside there are long tables that are meant to be shared.  We ordered Oysters in Shoyu and dare oil as a starter. 

I ordered the Spicy Tori Paitan (chicken soup, pork chashu, menma, spicy jalapeno miso, cabbage, fried burdock and green onion) $17: I've been looking for a ramen place with thick egg noodles in SF and I've finally found it! The ramen was al dente and the spicy jalapeno miso added just enough kick to it. The chicken soup was very thick, almost to the point of being viscous, and was very flavorful. I loved the crunchy fried burdock root and perfectly cooked soft boiled egg. I liked that the pork chasu was not too fatty and was able to eat most of the meat. 

Service was quick and our server moved quickly in between tables and taking orders. 

I'll definitely come back here but now I know to come extra early to be in the first seating of the night.
author: Nette T.

description:
We've been back from Japan about six months now.  Upon our return we stated we planned to try local ramen places.  So far this is just our 2nd place.  But definitely a winner!!!

We knew to come early before the restaurant opened at 5pm to secure first seating.  We arrived around 4:30pm on a Friday night, and already six people in line.  

Being our initial visit, the four of us agreed to go with the Tori Paitan ramen noodle soup.  Three of us went with the original, while my hubby had the spicy version.  We ordered imported Japanese beer to pair with our noodles.

The chicken soup broth was very flavorful.  That was the essence of our Tori Paitan.  Thick ramen noodles and great presentation.  Just the right amount of toppings.

We got the only 4 seats with chair backing.  Else you sit at one of two communal tables on high bar stools.

Service was quick and efficient.  We were in & out within the hour.

We've only been to two ramen shops in six months; however this one will be hard to beat.
author: Shirley N.

description:
Here's the breakdown:

1. There will be a wait. You just stand outside in a single line waiting for people to finish. I don't think you can make reservations or be on a waitlist online. (if so, lmk) I went on a weekday around 5:30pm and waited about 20 minutes.

2. It's very small. You definitely will feel crowded but hey, many Japanese restaurants follow this trend.

3. The food is yum! We got 4 different ramens (Matcha Tori Paltan ($17), Spicy Tori Paltan ($17), Spicy lamb ($16), and the special limited beef ($39)) The beef ramen is $39 and only offers 10 per day. My friend got the limited beef and said it was okay. Still very good ramen but the meat wasn't amazing. I personally loved the Spicy Tori Paltan ramen here. The noodles are so tasty. Perfectly chewy and the soup is amazing! The rest enjoyed their Matcha and spicy lamb as well.

4. Service is nice but it's busy so you probably won't get the best service in town. They are kind and helpful but they did forget our drinks and didn't refill our waters when they were empty. 

5. It's located in a sketchy part of the neighborhood. It should be safe since there will probably be other people waiting in line for you but be careful.

6. The interior is nice though. Nicely decorated. They were playing Buzzfeed Tasty videos on the TV.

7. The price is a little high for a Japanese Ramen, but I personally think it's worth it. Starting price around $16 but add ons which cost more.

Overall, my favorite ramen place in SF. I only been to 2 places (read my review of Marufuku on my profile) but so far this place is #1. Would definitely recommend this place to anyone and everyone. Definitely will be back!
author: Shin L.

description:
Finally made it out to Mensho on a Wednesday evening and just missed the first wave to be seated.  The wait after that was about 40 minutes long as the restaurant is quite small. 

I ordered the tori paitan while my boyfriend ordered the shoyu. We also ordered the two appetizers: oysters and enoki chips. Both were tasty but the oysters were a bit too salty for me and so I enjoyed the enoki chips much more. I thought these were quite unique and tasted really good with a little lemon on top or even dipped into the ramen broth. As for the ramen, I found my tori paitan to be very flavorful and I loved the thick and toothsome noodles. While the frothy broth was interesting at first, I feel like this caused the ramen to cool down really quick, making it less tasty. My favorite part, however, was actually the duck chashu! Cooked perfectly- I wish I ordered more! The shoyu was quite good as well and I actually preferred the broth of the shoyu to the tori paitan. 

Overall it was a pretty good meal, a little pricey but not too extravagant. They do have quite a few other options such as vegan tantanmen as well as some soupless noodles that I can't wait to try next time!
author: Janice L.

description:
4.4 Stars if I could give. Also, not going to review anything about waiting in line only to the food and service.  The third thing you'll notice are the outstanding ramen noodles, very chewing and thick.  The first thing being presentation and second you'll probably take a sip of the soup.   Although those noodles are the star of the show IMO.  There is quite a bit of difference in flavor & saltiness depending on which type of soup you choose.  Ramen bowls rated:

Spicy Tori Paitan - 5 stars, great flavor and seasoned appropriately
Vegan Tantanmen - 5 stars, also excellent flavor and seasoning. 
Matcha Tori Paitan - 3.5, flavor wasn't as deep as the other two bowls and needed more salt to the broth, although the broth was rich.  

The table does have a pink salt grinder sitting there for anyone that would like to add more salt to their soup.  Their Shio ramen looks great as well as the fried enoki mushroom appetizer.   Will def. bring my dad here next time to try some other flavors.
author: Spencer W.

description:
Mensho, one of San Francisco's best spots to eat a bowl of ramen. Unfortunately when everyone knows this, you can also expect to wait in a sizable line. On a Sunday evening over Labor Day Weekend, we waited a little over an hour for 3 people. 

Mensho actually has a pretty decent ramen selection. There's the traditional options, there's chicken based broth, and a vegan broth. This is already 5/5 to me because I love being able to take all my friends with dietary restrictions to ramen. Also, they let me make a substitution to my order (of getting duck instead of pork). So service is definitely 5/5.

Moving on to the actual ramen. So I think the broth here is pretty stellar. Good texture, right amount of creaminess, and tastes savory. I actually wasn't the biggest fan of the noodles- they were a little too firm for me. Apparently the noodles differ between which ramen you order, so I guess maybe it's just the bowl I got. 

Overall, Mensho is absolutely delicious, don't get me wrong. The reason I have to boil it down to 4 stars is going to be a. the noodles and b. the wait. Even though other ramen places in the city are brutal with waits, the fact that you're just in the middle of the TL with nothing to do but starve in line with your dear ramen buddies makes it hard to justify coming to Mensho again and again. If the wait were to divide by two, I could make it a monthly visit.

Definitely a must-go if you love ramen and reside in the Bay!
author: Arezou A.

description:
Can here on a Friday night at around 6:20pm and waited about an hour in line. We sat right in front of the kitchen which was pretty cool! Definitely a small place and expect to wait in line. 

I ordered the Tori Paitain ($16.50) and added nori ($2) and an egg ($1.80), which is a bit pricey my opinion, but egg is a must. The broth was really rich and creamy and while it was super good it was too rich for me to finish. The noodles are on the thicker side, which is my preference, and cooked perfectly. The meat was tender and added good flavor. My friend ordered the $39 Waygu special, which she said the meat was tender, but probably wouldn't pay the $39 again. The base of that soup was shoyu, which was lighter than the Paitan.

I would definitely come back again!
author: April L.

description:
Great place awesome food - go late in night and satisfy your ramen cravings 
The lines are always long
author: Sameer B.

description:
Overall, I'm very whatever about ramen. But that was before I met Mensho. I love Mensho. I don't love the cramped seating but if I'm gonna sweat while I eat, it might as well be over a bowl of Mensho ramen. 

Friends and I came at 5:45 on a Friday night and waited around 30-45 mins. Not too bad and the good company made the wait seem shorter ;) 

We each ordered a different bowl with me being basic and getting the tori paitan and someone getting the matcha. Others ordered the vegan tantanmen and the spicy tori paitan. I added an egg to mine that honestly, you can probably skip. But that's only because I didn't like a cold egg. 

The matcha was weird, not gonna lie. Mine was my favorite but the vegan one was also really really good. I'd just order that for the tantanmen and add chashu because you know, meat. 

All in all, totally worth the wait and I can't wait to revisit.
author: Lucy Z.

description:
Crazy about the Abura Soba here. The richness of the flavor is definitely enhanced by making the noodles "dry". It kind of reminds me of the dry saucy noodles I have back home in Indonesia, called Bakmi Ayam (Chicken Noodle). They give you a bottle of chili oil and a bottle of vinegar so you're able to adjust the amount of chili oil and vinegar for your noodles yourself. The noodles here are thick and chewy, just the way I like them. 

I am just okay with their best seller, Tori Paitan ramen. It's a little too heavy for me, but a lot of people like it. 

The restaurant is pretty tiny, so always expect a line, even on a weekday. The line is worth the wait, but honestly, try coming at around 4.40 to get first seating. They don't have any to-go boxes, so bring your own if you think you're not gonna finish the whole bowl, but honestly, you wouldn't be able to resist finishing the whole thing!
author: Shannen B.

description:
Worth the wait, if it's an hour or less. We tried the chicken and spicy lamb ramen, which were good, but not as good as the Abura noodles, which make my mouth water now--two weeks later and full from another meal. 

It's definitely not healthy, but it is probably as close as you can get to experiencing pure umami. Soft small droplets of fat cling to each noodle, easing your slurping and coating your tongue with smooth rich flavor enhanced by garlic, pork, and glutamic acid which is brilliantly rebranded msg.
author: Kaison T.

description:
I think it's safe to say that Mensho is my favorite ramen place in San Francisco... but keep in mind that my opinion is solely based off of their Tori Paitan Ramen. I love my raMEN thiccc so... (:

I've been here a few different occasions at different times, 5:30PM, 8:00PM, 9:20PM on weekdays and I've always had to wait 45min to an hour. The wait isn't too bad if you're with good company...and there's almost always some ratchetass people around the area making a scene so fear not, time will go by quickly. 

Tori Paitan Ramen: MY FAVORITE (and also the only thing I've ever gotten lol). Thick, creamy soup with thick, al dente noodles OH MY GOD. Their meats are also amazing. Duck chashu is soft and cooked perfectly, pork chashu  just melts in your mouth. Menma and burdock root provides different textures. Kale...took that shit out because kale belongs in one place, and one place only. The trash. 

I always ask to add an egg because it doesn't come with one. It's always soft boiled and flavorful so I recommend getting it for the extra $1.80

Please give this place a try if you haven't already. If you like thick and flavorful soup, you'll love their tori paitan ramen! They also have other choices that are on the lighter end so there's something for everyone. Prices are on the higher side for ramen, but it's totally worth it (:
author: Jackie T.

description:
3.5 rounded down to 3. Came ~40 mins before they opened on a Saturday and there were already ~10 people on the line. They started taking orders from people on the line about 15 mins before opening time and they opened on time. We ordered:
- oyster appetizer(taste is good but the texture is similar to chicken heart)
- deep fried enoki mushroom(good, oily)
- a5 wagyu ramen(the a5 wagyu is reaalllyyy good, the broth is ok)
- spicy lamb ramen with duck chasu(the broth tastes like curry, duck chasu is really good)
- veggie tantanmen(if you like sesame you will like this)

I love the thick chewy ramen here, but I haven't found any broths I like. The duck chasu is also really good. The a5 wagyu ramen is limited to 10 per day. No to go boxes. There is a parking garage a couple of doors down for $4/hr. I prefer the new nagi ramen in Palo Alto compared to this one.
author: Prisilia P.

description:
So, I should preface this by saying I'm a bit of a ramen newbie. As in, prior to this experience, I had never really had ramen other than the individual pouches of Mr. Noodles with those nifty flavour packets.

I wanted my first ramen experience to be amazing, so I did my research and I came across Mensho Tokyo and decided it would be a great addition to my foodie adventures on my San Fran vacay. I was totally pumped and ready to love it.

To start, I went there prepared to wait in line. Reviews advised that the wait would be around 30 minutes, ours was a bit closer to 40 but we did go around 7:00pm, prime dinner time, I guess! Fortunately the wait time gave us time to peruse the menu and decide what to order. I am thankful that the menu is not overwhelmingly long, but there were several interesting options so I had to choose carefully.

Once we got in, we could tell that the space is small, fitting maybe 20-25 people, which does explain the lineup. It has a nice cozy charm to it though, with a type of communal seating, and wall decor. Somehow it made the experience feel more authentic and worth the wait. This might not be ideal for some people looking for an intimate or private meal.

We decided to try the Enoki mushroom chips to start. I have absolutely zero regrets here- they were freakin' delicious! In fact, I would have been perfectly satisfied with a bowl of these for dinner! They're kind of like crispy onion strings you can get on burgers, same texture... but the flavour is just yummy. Disclaimer: I am a bit of a mushroom fanatic, so if you don't like mushrooms, these might not be for you.

After much deliberation and recommendations from our server, I ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen (double chashu) which is what they are known for. I was given the heads up that this is not "typical" ramen as it has a creamier soup, but I thought I'd try it anyway. I'll start by saying- the pork and duck chashu were delicious. Super tender and packed full of flavour. I loved it. The noodles were also done well. Not too soft, but not too hard, just what I expected. Unfortunately that is where my enjoyment ends. 

I won't fault the restaurant for it, but apparently I am not much of a miso fan and maybe I'm just not that into ramen, even though I really wanted to be! I did enjoy the overall experience, and will say that even though there was a bit of a mishap with my soup- our server worked quickly with her manager to rectify the situation, which I always do appreciate.

Overall- if you like ramen, definitely come check it out. But if you aren't sure if ramen is your thing, keep in mind the wait time!
author: Samantha M.

description:
Mensho is a MUST TRY ramen place. I am so blown away by the quality of the food. I've been trying to go to this place for months but the lines are always sooo freaking long if you don't come right during opening.. But I understand why now!! Boyf and I got the Tori Paitan with double chashu and the Wagyu ramen. The Wagyu was amazing, it's $40 but totally worth. The Wagyu was like butter and just melts in your mouth and paired really well with the clear shoyu broth, everything balanced out. They only serve 10 bowls per day for the wagyu ramen so keep that in mind if you want to try it out! The chashu in the Tori Paitan was soo good! The duck chashu was my favorite, it was so tender yet meaty at the same time I swear I could just get a whole order of just that lol. The broth for the Tori Paitan was really flavorful and a thicker broth. The noodles here are cooked so well too! It had just the right amount of chew and not overcooked at all. 

The place itself is small and has limited seating, which also explains why there's always a line. Service was very efficient and food did not take long to come out. Highly recommend to at least try this place once!
author: Erica L.

description:
When I think of ramen, I immediately associate that with Mensho. I've been a couple times and I've always had to wait if it was dinner time. The line is usually because of the small dining area. There are only 2 rows of tables (communal style) with a row right in front of the kitchen. They're really utilizing all the space they can, and even with their effort, don't be surprised waiting at least half an hour to get in! 

Both times I've been, I've ordered the Spicy Pai Tan Ramen. Why ruin a good thing right? But the matcha definitely did catch my eye, I just wasn't sure if it would be appetizing in a savory type of food. The spicy is just so rich and creamy. It's not as spicy as I thought it would be but it's got a kick to it. Even when I think I'm super hungry, I've yet to finish a bowl of ramen and I think it's because I love slurping their soup, which is pretty filling itself. The ingredients are all fresh and just pretty typical of ramen shops. Obviously as you may have read, there are no take out boxes and that's most likely because reheating it would taint your taste buds from the ramen and also most likely because the soup would congeal from all the fats in the soup. Let's be honest, we aren't eating this to be healthy! Can't wait to come back, maybe I'll order the matcha next time!
author: Ada C.

description:
Phenomenal and unique! It's one thing to have well executed ramen; it's another to have ramen that introduces you to new flavors and combinations that I think really exemplifies what ramen is capable of. Got the Tori Paitan Ramen of course, and it was so delicious! Definitely in my top 2 ramen spots. The broth is thick, creamy, and complex; the noodles are thick (thicker than average) and bouncy; the meat is so tender; there's also some kind of potato topping (?!) that goes so well with everything. Also, if you care about this, the bamboo shoots are nice and soft, which is something my boyfriend I look out for.

My only real complaint about the experience is the wait...I waited an hour and while I don't regret it, it was not great. Would have been better if they at least had a separate line for solo diners to fully utilize the space, as many other ramen places do.
author: Hannah P.

description:
The Spicy Tori Paitan Ramen had flavorful broth. I loved that it had menma mushrooms because it added to the ramen flavor which is very different from other types of mushroom. The ramen noodles were not too soft and had the right amount of chew to it. This ramen is a bit on the pricey side but it's quality ramen and tastes amazing! Also love that their health score is 100! This place is dinner only (opens at 5pm) and one bowl will make me pretty darn full. I had no room for desert after though I wish I did. 

This place is small and there can be a long wait depending on when you go. But if there's a line outside waiting for food then it must be worth it. I didn't notice a bathroom for customers... so try to go beforehand!
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Disclaimer: My bf and I came to try the abura oil noodles, not the ramen with soup.

After visiting Japan earlier this year and discovering abura oil noodles, basically soupless ramen, but accompanied with chili oil and vinegar, we were mind blown at how delicious it was. Hence the visit here to satisfy the craving.

Line: we got there at 5pm and waited about 20 minutes. 

Inside: communal tables (no more than 30 seats) with high stools, storage baskets underneath, and numbered hooks for coats and jackets. Love the organization, just like in Japan.

Food: there's regular ramen, matcha ramen (interesting), vegan ramen, and then the abura noodles which we chose. 
-abura ramen: served with green onion, bamboo shoots, seaweed, chashu pork, and I ordered a boiled egg.
-fried mushroom: we ordered this as an appetizer. It was pretty goof, but would probably pass next time
- I ordered a sparking yuzu soda, and it was like a lighter Sprite

Service: Excellent. They auto charge a 15% service fee, but no additional tip needed.

Overall, the noodles did satisfy my craving, but it became a little too oily at the bottom. Not as amazing as Japan's Abura Soba, but still worth coming back for.
author: Corinna T.

description:
The HYPE exist! But be warned this is not your typical ramen spot. First of all there is a huge wait no matter what day you go on but it's definitely better on a weekday. They open pretty late so if you prefer not to wait as long I suggest going an hour before they close. Surprising they seated everyone who was waiting in line after closing. 

We ordered the deviled oysters, spicy lamb ramen (added duck chashu) and a spicy tori patina ramen (added duck chashu) The duck chashu was really GOOD but wish it came with more duck. The devil oysters were pretty good too but not amazing. Next came the ramen! Finally, the broth was creamy and the noodles were thick. Just how you would eat tsukenmen (dipping ramen) I felt like it was a similar concept without the separation of the dipping. I really love how the thickness of the sauce cling onto the ramen and the flavors were on point. If you want a lighter and not as creamy broth they do have other options, just because it can be pretty heavy at times.
author: Amy L.

description:
The wait is truly worth it. We were going to come before closing to prevent the long wait but since we were already close by, we decided to just start waiting. The wait took about an hour. Make sure you don't come on an empty stomach or else you'll be hangry for sure. Good luck to the person you're with. 

The restaurant only has 28 seats available. It's best to come in twos or just by yourself. It'll be a bit harder and larger parties may have to wait longer. 

Ramen is pricier than average but to be honest, it was really good so it made it sort of okay. 

The vegan ramen was probably one of the best creative ramens I've had thus far. I really liked the type of noodles they used. The soup was flavorful as well. VEGANS/VEGETARIANS, finally a really good restaurant for us to enjoy! 

Two ramens and two drinks came out to almost $70. 15% gratuity is already included and they do not accept more on top of that.

I would definitely come back and recommend this restaurant to dine in when you're in SF.
author: Debby S.

description:
This was my first time ever eating ramen, and that's because I'm a vegetarian. They serve a vegetarian ramen...wahoo!!!!  It was really good and really spicy. I wish that I can go back in time and rewind to the moment I was eating it. 

Tips. They don't provide to-go containers, but you are welcome to bring your own if you like. I'm so doing this. If requested at the beginning, you can pay with separate checks.

We waited over an hour to be seated, made the experience so worth it.
author: Michelle M.

description: Came here to eat ramen all the way from Sacramento and definitely was not disappointed!! Get the spicy lamb it's soooooo so filling especially on a cold sf night will def come again for a5 wagyu
author: Valerie D.

description: I've never had ramen as good as this. I went here last night with a few friends late around 10pm. There was a line out the door, but even with a long line we were seated relatively quick. I ordered the vegan ramen and it was to die for. I also recommend getting the fried shrooms, they were to die for. I will definitely be returning with my family. This is the best ramen I've ever had to date! Expect to walk out spending $20 and a 15% gratuity is automatically included in your bill which is something to keep in mind. Enjoy!
author: Jordan S.

description:
As much as I like the food here, I do not like being harassed by the homeless people in that area. As someone who was born and raised in SF, I felt like the people wandering around this place made not only visitors but also locals like myself feel uncomfortable.

Besides the location, the food here is great! I like getting the tori paitan and the fried enoki for appetizer. Soup and noodles are good, and the big spoon helps but is a bit heavy. The first time I had the tori paitan, I thought the soup was too thick but the second time I had it, it grew on me and I started to like it!
author: Andrea T.

description:
I waited ~30 minutes in a line that looked very long. Props to being able to turnover tables fairly quickly.

Came with the family for my birthday and no one was that impressed. The ramen was interesting and different and worth trying but not worth coming back for.
author: Sophia L.

description:
HYPE, HYPE, HYPE

Don't get me wrong, I'm all for the hype but sometimes too much of a good thing can be overkill. Take the hypebeasts rocking multiple hype brands in a fit worth more than your car payment, for example.

Mensho known as the first outpost of Tokyo's ramen chain, sets a high standard for ramen with its experimental flavor profiles, rich broth and modern approach. 

With a line forming outside the small shop in the Tenderloin, took a look over the menu and noticed the higher end of ingredients being used in the food they serve with of course an A5 Wagyu option for $39, limited to 10 bowls a day. Opted for the Tori Paitan Ramen; chicken soup, pork and duck charshu, menma, kale, burdock root chips and katsuobushi paste. The broth is thick, creamy and fatty. Paired with the slices of charshu adds more fattiness and savoriness to the bowl. The burdock was a nice textural component and had a nice toasted, nutty flavor. The kale and menma were overpowered by the richness of everything else in the bowl. Ramen was thick with a good chew, but a little too thick for my preference and I'm a huge fan of curly and thick ramen noodles! The dish is so unctuous I felt uneasy. The broth is nearly a sauce instead of a drinkable broth, thick noodles and fatty pork and duck made this bowl of ramen too much of a good thing. Some acidity or brightness from another ingredient such as scallions or a lighter green would've helped a great deal. Ate half of my bowl and was just overwhelmed by how excessively rich it was, it was crazy rich.

Small shop with really close quarters here, be forewarned. If you have social anxiety and/or have issues with people being in your personal bubble this is definitely not the place for you. You are literally elbow-to-elbow with people and yes, if your ramen slurp game is not on point you will get broth splattered on yourself as well as the guy next to you. Service wise the wait staff is attentive and quick. Food doesn't take too long to come out of the kitchen and you can keep yourself entertained watching their process on the TV or to look at their decor. You can keep your belongings in a basket on the ground.

Price point is high, which makes sense for the quality of ingredients used and the compositions of the ramen bowls. However, this isn't my cup of tea - I mean bowl of ramen.
author: Janet N.

description:
Overhyped for sure. 

I was craving something soupy like noodle soup so I suggest to my bf to come here one night while we were out in the city. Seeing the high rating on Yelp, I was excited to try Mensho. It's been a long while since I had ramen with the second to last time was in Japan. Prior to this visit, I had ramen for lunch with my sis at Kokoru Ramen in Milipitas which was yummy. 

Upon arriving, there was a line of about 12 people waiting. I think we waited about 30-35mins before we got in. The seating was communal so we were seated next to other people/elbow to elbow. We both got the Tori Paitan Ramen which was okay. I was disappointed to see that they didn't have corn as an add-on. I always get corn as an add-on at ramen places. So that was a bummer. The music was loud, and it was hip-hop. So I couldn't really hear my bf when we were trying to talk. They kept on replaying a video on the TV about mochi? I don't really remember exactly, but it was the same video playing over and over again. 

Would I come back? No. Cause there are better ramen places elsewhere such as Ramen Dojo, Kokoru Ramen, and etc.
author: Amy C.

description:
My friend took me here on a Friday 30 minutes before they opened. I wondered why, but I immediately understood once we got there. There was a line already formed waiting for the restaurant to open. Luckily, we got in with the first wave once they opened. The place was fairly small but it accommodates a moderate amount of people. The decor and atmosphere reminded me of Japan. There were baskets under or seats to put our bags, purses, backpacks. There were also big long tables to squeeze most of their customers inside.

Food:
I ordered the spicy lamb ramen and we decided to share the enoki mushroom chips. The enoki chips had an interesting texture. It reminded me of a potato chip and mushroom mixed together. It was tasty but I wouldn't say worth $6 for the portion size. The spicy lamb ramen was pretty good. The soup base reminded me a lot of Chinese lamb, with the tremendous amount of cumin they put. The soup is also very thick and heavy. I wasn't able to finish the soup. The noodles were delicious and pretty standard. The chasu was very tender and broke every time I tried to pick it up. 

Service:
Our server was very attentive and immediately gave us water when we sat down. She made sure all of our waters were filled and if we needed anything. There is an automatic 15% tip added to your bill, so you can tip more if you'd like but that's totally up to you.

Overall I give it a 4/5.

Pros:
-new twist to ramen
-flavorful broth
-tender and juicy chasu pork
-friendly and attentive servers

Cons:
-pricey for what you get
-long wait times if you don't get there before open
-automatic 15% tip
author: Danny T.

description:
If you want to treat yourself to something nice, then Mensho is the place to go. So far it's the closest thing I've had to the delicious, quality ramen in Japan. The tori paitan was amazing. I really want to try the matcha series next time! 
Note: I wouldn't recommend coming here for a catch up meal with friends.  Most people come to Mensho to enjoy the food and go, so please be considerate of the limited seating and long line.
author: Julie L.

description:
Gosh I feel bad I didn't brave the lines earlier for this place. I loved it. One of the best if not the best shoyu or paitan ramen in the SF area. 

We arrived at 8:30 Pm on a Friday night and the line was about 20 deep. Wait was around 40 minutes. Staff is super attentive collecting party numbers in the line and accommodated everyone on a first come first serve basis. We were waiting for a table for 4 and even as double seats showed up, and though smaller parties were behind us, they took care to seat us first.

The menu is clean and easy to read. We ordered:

Oysters in shoyu dare oil - doesn't look appetizing, tastes like canned oysters in oil (not a bad thing).

Organic shoyu ramen with double chasu - this was DELICIOUS. I was opting for a less-rich broth so went with the shoyu. Great choice. They double chasu is an extra slice, totally also worth it. The smoky flavor of the chasu pairs well with the clean shoyu based broth. The kale was so tender yet held texture in the bowl, and I adored the noodles. Tender, squiggly awesomeness. The duck chasu is new to me in ramen, and added depth to the bowl. 

Spicy tori paitan ramen with double chasu - spicy isn't too spicy, noodles were a little different than the shoyu ramen (closer to typical ramen noodles). Broth was super rich, creamy, heavy and delicious. Some with duck and pork chasu as well.

Although this ramen in general is much more rich than what I'm used to, it's GOOD. It's not exactly comparable but seems to me to stand In its own category - I've not had ramen like this before and it was so good.

Egg isn't included and it's a must add for $1. A whole egg, perfectly cooked. $1 is worth it.

Parking and neighborhood is kinda sketch... but I didn't feel unsafe dining here. The spoon provided is also way too large IMO, and made of heavy metal and my hand was tired after using it halfway through.

I'll be back!
author: Karen H.

description:
I recommend coming here by yourself, as I was able to skip half the line. I would say it's worth ditching your friends to shorten your wait, since this is in the Tenderloin after all. The sooner you get inside, the less likely you'll get stabbed by a needle.

This was my first time trying a tori paitan ramen, as I've always been more loyal to tonkotsu. I will break down each component of the ramen.

The broth was so rich and packed with umami; if I could, I would carry around a thermos full of it everyday and just drink it. It was hot, savoury, creamy, and really hits the spot, even in the summer. If ramen broth could give out warm hugs, this would be it.

The toppings... were a bit weird. I'm not sure why there were random vegetables. They didn't really taste like anything, and if anything actually distracted me from the part I really cared about (the ramen and the broth). They just tasted so drastically different and didn't pair well at all with the ramen, so that sorta killed it for me.

The noodles... were nice and thicc, just the way I like it. They paired really well with the broth, as the chewiness and thickness held up really well to the bold flavour of the broth.

It's not a perfect bowl of ramen, but it's still pretty good. If they ditched the weird vegetables, and added a bit more noodles, I'd be more willing to line up every week and risk my life for a bowl.
author: Calvin Z.

description:
Hubby & I came here around 8:15p on a Thurs night. We waited only ~45 mins before we were seated at the counter, by the kitchen. The line wasn't too long since it was later in the evening, I think. 

We both ordered the vegan ramen and the Enoki mushroom chips for appetizer. The app came out fairly quickly. I should have asked, but it was a decent size bowl of fried enoki mushrooms, served with a lemon wedge and chili seasoning on the side. We both enjoyed it, but I don't think I'd order it again simply because I try not to eat fried food. 

The ramen came out not long after we finish the app. I eat with my eyes first, and the presentation was nice and looked super delicious. The taste was not disappointing either. The broth was creamy, rich and FULL OF FLAVOR. There was some smoky topping in there which added a nice smokiness to the bowl. I didn't even look to see what else was in there, but I THOROUGHLY enjoyed every single slurp. It had enough kick to it, and it was spicy for me but I didn't care. The noodles were fat, chewy and perfect in my opinion. I loved it very much. I finished almost all the broth. If I hadn't been so full, I would have finished the entire thing. This was hands-down the best vegan ramen I have ever had, and I've eaten a lot of good ramen over the past 5 years. 

HEADS-UP: if you're the type who cannot finish a bowl of ramen in one seating, bring your own to-go container; they don't provide it here. I wish I had known about it.
author: Hanh N.

description:
First time having noodles of this texture and chewiness..& i liked it.. A LOT!

Im not a soup guy but i ended up cleaning house on that broth! Man was it delicious.

Ill be honest, Wait time here will be a pain in the ass, so definitely dont come here on an empty stomach. Give yourself an hour at least to be seated, but once your turn arrives you will not regret the wait, i promise.

Prices here will be high but you're paying for the quality and taste.

Two ramens & two drinks will set you back close to $60ish.

Just wish their wait time was shorter or a front of the line pass if you're dining alone, since there are some times single seats left unoccupied.
author: Steven H.

description:
This is definitely the best ramen in the Bay Area. First off, be prepared to wait! No reservations and the line can easily get 2 hours long. But at the end you are rewarded with the most delicious broth, chewy noodles, and melt in your mouth meat!

I had the spicy duck ramen. I found the broth amazingly savory. The spice was not overwhelming and worked well to compliment the fatty duck. 

I would not hesitate to come back. Pro tip: Show up by 4:30 to try to make the first seating. If you show up even at 5 you will end up waiting for an hour 1/2 or more. But hey, I don't know your life. You do you.
author: Aaron K.

description:
Mensho Tokyo is my favorite ramen place in the bay area. That rich and creamy broth in their Tori Paitan is so delightful. I was instantly in love with their ramen, completely satisfied after finishing, and left wanting to come back for more! I have no more words to say but to try it for yourself! All of my friends loved their dishes - the Tori Paitan Ramen,  the Vegan Tantanmen, Spicy Tori Paitan Ramen, Shoyu Ramen and A5 Wagyu. Delicious!!!

Please come between 4:00-4:30, so that you're in the first group of 28 that is served at 5 PM!  It feels so much better getting seated and served first, so you get to skip having to wait in line and watch people eat their food. 

Thank you to Yoshi for the delectable food! I will always recommend this place and their great service.
author: Katrine U.

description:
There's overrated ramen, and then there's Mensho, where the ramen literally just tastes bad. I was craving ramen today and since it was only ~630pm we were willing to try waiting in line today. We waited 30-40 min for a table of 2. If you're an SF resident, you'll know that Mensho is in the heart of Tenderloin, so waiting in line here is not a pleasant thing with all of the drugged up homeless passing by yelling uncontrollably. 

When we got seated, we sat down at the communal table squished in between two groups. We got the tori paitan and the shoyu. I had heard that the tori paitan had a rich broth but I didn't expect it to taste so thick and creamy. It was actually a bit disgusting. I really wanted to like it, but I just could not. It felt like they just threw a bunch of veggies that really didn't need to be there - the burdock root that they add really made the dish taste out of place - the texture was very similar to apple peels.. The noodles were thick and wrinkly and didn't really taste like ramen noodles - felt a lot more like instant noodles, which was pretty disappointing. I had a taste of the shoyu broth which was much lighter and edible than the tori paitan.

The best description of the tori paitan broth was a remark that I heard from the group beside me: "is this even soup? it looks like peanut sauce". 

So.. yes if you'd like a peanut sauce soup with instant noodles and a bunch of random vegetables, try Mensho. 

Aside from the food and wait, our service wasn't anything special. She asked whether my friend was done his meal pretty early in. The front door was also left open so there was a cold draft in the restaurant. 

Do yourself a favor and go to Iza Ramen or Hinodeya and you won't have to wait as long nor eat shitty ramen.
author: Elisa L.

description:
The American child of Tokyo's famed Mensho ramen bar, the minimalistic, no-frills joint serves up innovative spins on traditional thick tonkotsu broth - tasty and satisfying indeed, yet too hyped for my tastes. It is good, but not wait 1.5hours good. 

The decor is simple, modern, and scientific - the science of molecular ramen.  The space is cozy - sitting around 20 people in short segments of time. 

For the Macca Tori Paitan - The broth was too heavy for my palate.  The Macca powder dispersed on top the ramen was great for show, but did not add much to the culinary experience as I consumed chunks of Matcha powder here and there - it did not blend well in the soup.  The chewiness of the noodle was fine, but the noodle width was a bit on the thick side. 

For the Organic Shoyu Ramen - The broth was too salty. Again, the chewiness of noodles fine - the noodles were flat and thin like Chinese style Wonton noodles.  It was a good, but not an amazing bowl of ramen that dreams are made of. 

For the Vegan tantanmen, the broth was too salty for me to handle. The chef was incredibly liberal with the salt in this dish.  The dish was thick and lacked a balance of flavors. I appreciate the use of mame, pea shorts and cilantro, but the vegetables were very much overshadowed by the thickness and saltiness. 

For the Aburasoba, I was quite actually pleasantly surprised!  This was my favorite ramen dish here. Certainly not the signature thick tonkotsu broth, but most certainly more well balanced, with chewier noodles in a delectable lighter sauce with a mix of Chashu, menma, green onion, and daikon sporouts.
author: Vivienne K.

description:
Wow. The broth alone is worth 5 stars.

We arrived a bit after opening (5:15) to a healthy line. Luckily, the line moved at a reasonable pace (people are obviously lingering over their bowls, but not obnoxiously so), and we finally sat down around 6. If you're in a hurry, definitely come around 4:30 to make sure you're included in the first seating--everyone in our group seemed to have joined the line after 5.

Onto the food. I ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen, and the BF ordered the Spicy Tori Paitan with double pork chashu (note that this one doesn't come with duck!). Like I said, wow. The broth is viscous and rich, like chicken noodle soup living its very best, fattiest life. All of the toppings were delightful, from the burdock (a first for me) and the menma to the two chashus; the duck was the star, but I ended up sharing one of my two slices with the BF because his dish only came with pork. We didn't love the spicy miso paste in his bowl, but it has a nice jalapeño kick that I wouldn't mind trying in other dishes. Honestly, the broth just felt too perfect to mess with.

One last note: I wasn't a huge fan of the noodles, since I've been on a thin, firm noodle kick lately (ever since we binged on Ichiran in Shinjuku), but they did work nicely with the thickness of the broth.
author: Becca M.

description:
Ramen was good overall. The chicken broth was thick and flavorful. The chashu style charred duck was tender.  I was hesitant about the thicker noodles but they were nice and chewy. I wasn't prepared for an 1hr+ wait on a Tuesday night (6-7:15pm) but it's a tiny dining room. Overall it was a pleasant experience. Probably not worth the wait IMHO, but worth a try. 
For less lines and a simpler more traditional Hakata style ramen, head to Ippudo SF
author: Jason C.

description:
Mensho is the absolute best ramen restaurant in the city and I have been to many. Mensho is a tad different then most places, but extremely tasty. I like the creamier soup, I haven't tried the other ones yet but I plan to. 

It is totally worth the wait. Try to get there at 4:30 before the open. They have about 28-30 seats inside. Not sure how many.
author: Tina L.

description: Mensho offers a simple menu and straight forward ramen. There is always a huge line here though which takes 30-45 minutes to wait. There's no list so you have to wait in line. They also don't take reservations. For those who don't want rich or savory ramen they have a chicken-soup based and soba ramen -- a bit healthier for the SF organic crowd.
author: Thomas C.

description:
I came to Mensho Tokyo after being heavily referred to it. We arrived around 5:21PM on a Saturday afternoon, and had to wait around an hour before we were seated. There seems to always be a line no matter what, because the place is super small, and only has two rows of seats. The service is pretty quick though. They're quick to take your order, and quick to get your food out, so I recommend looking at the menu before you head inside. 

My party ordered 2 orders of Orangic Shoyu Ramen ($14.5) , and 1 Shio Ramen ($12). The Shoyu Ramen's broth tastes great at first, but after eating it for a while, it gets super salty, and makes you crave water. Their broth has a soy sauce like taste to it, while the Shio has a Fish Oil taste to their broth. I wish I ordered their Tori Paitan Ramen, which seems to be the highlight of their shop! I'll try it next time I come. Noodles seem to be handmade (?) because of their difference in length. 

Mensho Tokyo will always have a line, so I recommend getting here as early as possible, and waiting before opening. Prices are decent, but eating here made me feel really rushed since I felt like I didn't really get to sit and enjoy the place before finishing my food and getting out. The vibe here is very hipster with their white walls being decorated with chemistry ramen facts, and Drake being played in the background. 

This is not the place to go for authentic, whole in the wall ramen, but a place to go if you want simplistic, nice ramen (looks great in pictures!) I prefer more Japanese authenticity in my ramen, and a shorter wait time if possible personally, but this seems to be the place to try, for the moment.
author: Jessica H.

description:
I'm ready. 


Patience is a virtue. But, what is a 'virtue'? The dictionary describes a 'virtue' as "behavior showing high moral standards." The dictionary does not outline who's moral standards we follow and the bar for keeping ourselves high above those standards. I am only interested in high food standards. Waiting in line for 40+ minutes for 1 seat is definitely a high virtue. I only wished Mensho Tokyo positioned all of the seats to look outward into the salivating, longing eyes of hungry virtuous patrons. I've been on both sides of the glass and -- while one culminates in the other -- I would gladly pay more to watch someone upset with waiting watch me eat my super delicious food. 

In life, if you wait long enough, you might die waiting or you'll get what you were waiting for. There's only two options: wait or die waiting. I would willingly die a thousand times waiting for another bowl of Tori Paitan. The broth was so rich, so thick that after I finished all of the components, I looked deep into the remnants searching for answers to my deepest concerns. I was sure as the sky would be blue in the morning that in that broth I could find Waldo, Carmen San Diego, the President's tax returns, the fabled land of Atlantis, and my lucky sock. Alas, I only found satisfaction, tranquility, and a smile from heaven's door shining upon me welcoming a long lost stranger to nirvana. 

I then ordered another bowl so the hapless sacks in line would test their virtues.
author: Albert L.

description:
If I were to think about where I had the best ramen in SF, Mensho Tokyo would undoubtedly come up in my mind at the very top. It might even be more surprising that a vegetarian ramen convinced me that this was true. I came here with a friend on a Friday evening, waiting if I remember correctly at least an hour before we got to the front of the line. I knew I wanted to get the vegan tantanmen since I'm really a fan of really good vegetable ramen, and there are such few places that do a good job of bringing out the taste in vegan ramen.

The vegan tantanmen in my opinion is pretty rich in flavor, and the broth was very creamy. I really enjoyed the seven herbs that they had in the dish, and the noodles were pretty good as well. The dishes here are more expensive than your average SF ramen place, but if the prices reflect the quality of the ramen here, then the prices are well deserved.  

At the time of this writing, I would say that the vegan tantanmen here is the best ramen I've had in SF, and that isn't an exaggeration. It appears that the vegan tantanmen is one of their top selling dishes, which honestly doesn't come as a surprise to me since it's pretty flavorful. After tasting the ramen, I could see the reason why this place draws long lines even two years after it opened. What makes it even more amazing is that it's near the Tenderloin, and it's relatively out of the way for ramen. 

Mensho Tokyo is a solid five, and I hope they open up another store so there wouldn't be such long lines. I could see myself ordering the spicy lamb ramen or the clam ramen the next time I come back. Highly recommended to anyone who enjoys ramen and definitely worth the hour's wait in line.
author: Nelson X.

description:
Wow! I've walked past Mensho a dozen times and have always been too intimidated by the line to take the plunge. I'm glad that I found a time when there was no line and snuck in. 

The atmosphere is very clean and modern. The communal seating tables are very fun for anyone from groups to singles because you get to see all the interesting types of ramen people get. I didn't eat it, but the matcha ramen looked super cool!

The mushroom fries were fun, light, and tasteful. I've never had anything quite like it. 

The Spicy Tori Paitan Ramen was as advertised, thick chicken/pork broth soup with tender chashu that melts in your mouth. The spice was a lot so I only used about 2/3 of it to reach the perfect blend of heat and umami. The noodles made my face light up. Soooooo yum. 

The vegan ramen was very unique, almost nutty in a good way. I normally don't go for the vegan option but glad I tried it! 

I see why everyone says such good things about this place. Definitely will go back.
author: Barron C.

description: Love love love this place. It's extremely hard to get a seat (seems like it's always busy) but the couple of times we've been seated - it's been well worth it. My favorite dish is the lamb ramen. It's to die for! Honestly, I don't think I've ever had better ramen. Make sure you wait in the line because you will not be disappointed.
author: Zinia G.

description:
I've been here twice in one month, both times around opening on a weekday. I've been lucky enough to get the last few spots without waiting. The place is small and fills up quickly. Seating style is communal, so expect to sit closely and share long tables with fellow ramen lovers. 

The ramen here is different from any other ramen spot I've tried in San Francisco. The Tori Paitan was verrrrry thick and rich, almost like a gravy. I also had the Organic Shoyu, the broth was flavored just enough n much lighter that the others I've tried here. Both the Tori Paitan and Shoyu contained one piece of Chashu(option for double Chashu for 2$ more) and 2 slices of duck breast. The duck was soo tender and the Chashu was melt in your mouth. My friend had the Spicy Lamb...mmmm the lamb flavor was prominent and the combination of spices were just perfect. The noodles had a nice bite to 'em. Bouncy and cut on the thicker side, just how I like it.

Definitely worth the wait! Would recommend to give Mensho a try!
author: Mary R.

description:
I had passed by this place several times and each time there was a line out the door! I finally made plans to go on a weekend and arrive before opening to hopefully avoid any long wait times all together. Success. The inside is very tiny and clean. I can't imagine how a large party would come here, but I can't speak to that since I was just in a party of 2.

The ramen is delicious! A bit pricey of course, but well worth trying in my opinion. The bowl may seem small at first, but omg it is very very filling. The broth itself is a meal because it is so savory and meat-y tasting that I could easily have gotten full of drinking it alone. I think their broth and noodles are what sets this bowl of ramen apart from other ramen places.

My only tip is to plan ahead or come to wait in line when you aren't starving!
author: Erica C.

description:
My boyfriend and I just finished shopping around the union square, so we were starving. Since it was 10 pm, the food selection was limited. I noticed Mensho Tokyo and got very excited because they have vegan ramen!! So obviously I had to drag my boyfriend to this place LOL.
Off the bat, there was a long line. I believe we waited for 10-15 minutes, which isn't that bad. Also, I notice the restaurant is very small so that's probably why there is always a wait list. 
Anyways, we ordered their mushroom appetizer, spicy lamb ramen, and the vegan ramen (forgot the actual name lol). I absolutely LOVED the mushroom appetizer, it was 100% vegan but it reminded me of calamari. It was really good and crispy. 
Vegan ramen: I first noticed my ramen was really oily. So, it didn't really look that delicious to me lol. I wish they didn't put so many nuts because it was really nutty. Their noodles also tasted a little weird to me? Their seemed to be a weird after taste of some sort? I still enjoyed it tho. It's just not that good for $18. 
Spicy lamb ramen: My boyfriend said it was okay. He also said his was oily. Overall he enjoyed it but it's just a whatever ramen.
I've noticed that they don't have containers to go because I guess they believe that ramen is supposed to only be eaten when it's first served. 
It is also crucial to leave a 15% tip, which I found a little ridiculous because I saw the waitress like twice within a 5 second time span?
Anyways this place is okay. Maybe I'll try again in the future?
author: Tanya D.

description:
I cry. This place has magical ramen. 

It was a pretty cold and windy night out in San Fran. My hunger for a good ole bowl of ramen was stirring up in my tummy. I quickly filed into the line that had formed outside of the restaurant. I gleamed at the people with their steamy bowls through the window glass; I knew this wait would be worth it.It took about 20-30 mins to get seated. But, once I was inside, I ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen.

HOLY SCHNIKES.

I've watched foodie videos my entire life practically, and this bowl in front of me had ALL the aspects of a great bowl of ramen. The noodles weren't too soft and had enough chew. The broth was soulful and intense, but not too salty. The duck and pork chashu were treated so beautifully; I should've ordered double. They even paid attention to the bamboo shoots. You could tell that they either made their bamboo shoots in house or had some local shop bring them in. The ramen bowl in it's entirety was happiness itself. 

I'd wait in that line out in the cold time and time again for another bowl of their ramen. If shipping a bowl of ramen to Texas was a thing, I'd have way too many orders by now.
author: Mikayla R.

description:
I would recommend showing up at or before opening time, or you'll end up waiting 30-45 minutes!

This is a tiny place with seating for maybe 20-25. The Spicy Lamb Ramen was aight, but I think their Spicy Pai Tan Ramen is better. Loved the noodles and thick broth!
author: Michael K.

description:
Waited for 75 minutes on a Saturday night around 6 pm. There are only 28 seats in the restaurant. 

I got the Tori Paitan ramen. The food came out fairly quick after ordering. It was the creamiest broth I've ever tasted in ramen. The noodles were firm at first, but got softer as it soaked in the broth. It was a tad salty to me if I drank only the broth (but I am more sensitive to salt than others). This place has definitely ranked in my top 3 for ramen places! 

Tips:
-No leftover containers so finish your food !!! 
-There are only 10 bowls each day of the clam butter ramen and wagyu ramen so come early for that!
author: Maggie C.

description:
Michelin recommended, is Mensho the best ramen in SF? Probably....not? 2.5 stars for the ramen and .5 extra for their delicious egg and their enoki chips that topped your ramen. I've been getting mixed reviews about this place, some say it's good because it's so rich and some say it's bad because it's so rich. I really had to come and try it for myself. 

The line is a little intimidating but people don't really take that long when they're eating here, so it moves relatively fast if you're waiting for groups of 2-4. Can't tell you how long the wait is if you're waiting for anything larger.

I ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen which I believe is their signature. At $18, it's verrrryyyyy pricey and it didn't even come with an egg. I recommend adding the egg even though it's extra, it's quite tasty. The broth is thick and very salty, almost like gravy. It was rich but not the good kind of rich I was looking for. The noodles were not my favorite type of ramen noodles, they were kind of like egg noodles combined with udon noodles. Thicker and didn't help much with absorbing the soup flavor. I prefer the thinner and more supple Ichiran noodles because it makes for a much easier bite, while I found it difficult to pick up the noodles with the gravy like broth at Mensho.

Gratuity is already included, is that why they don't care to provide you any service at all? For three people after gratuity and adding an egg each, it came out to $25 a person. WHAT THE?!! I can understand the appeal if you're into thick gravy like ramen broth, but it's not what I'm used to and it's not what I enjoy. If you're looking for a very different type of ramen experience, then I say come thru, but whether it's worth $25 and waiting 30 minutes or more? Well that's for you to decide.
author: Nancy L.

description: What an experience! It was worth waiting every second once you get seated. The service is prompt and the food is delish. I opted for a spicy ramen with a creamy sauce. It was not like the miso based ramen I have been used to and I was pleasantly surprised! I hope to be back and take more people here as this is as it is definitely an experience.
author: Ashley L.

description:
Super delish ramen! Creamy soup like broth with lamb, pork, onion, spring onion, cress, boiled egg etc.. Would strongly advise you to starve the whole day and then hit this place as the portions are huge! Since it's a small place there is possibility of a huge queuing up. So be there at 5 on week days and maybe even before on weekends! 
We had the spicy lamb ramen and the vegan ramen. Both were super delish!
author: Riya S.

description:
My friend brought me to this restaurant.
Wait for 40 mins(it usually need to wait for 30min-1hour) but it worth the waiting.
The soup is very thick and very fresh.
I'll check it out again!!!
author: 语夷

description:
In all honesty I was not a fan of Mensho after my first visit - that first time I tried the Tori Paiten Ramen, Specialty Maccha Ramen, and the Shio Ramen. All of which were just A-OK in my opinion. After a mediocre first experience I was hesitant to wait in line and try this place again.

My friend invited me to try Mensho's 2nd Anniversary Specialty Ramen - A5 Wagyu Ramen and it was to. die. for. The wagyu was flown in from Miyasaki, Japan - fatty, flavorful and tender. Too bad it was only limited time and they only served 10 bowls/day over a span of a few days. 

Not only was the special bowl delicious, at this visit I also got a chance to try the Aburasoba which is a dry noodle served with pork chashu, green onion, menma, and the usual toppings. Top with as much chili oil and vinegar as your heart desires, and voila.... OISHI. I have officially had a change of heart regarding Mensho and I have to say that the Aburasoba makes the wait worth it.
author: Elaine N.

description: Heaven. Just heaven. The best ramen I've had ever. So much so that we went back twice with different friends during our conference. I miss it already.
author: Desa D.

description:
Move over, Nojo and Marafuku - I think I've found my new favorite ramen spot in the city.

I'll be real, I don't know if this review would be 5 stars if I had some ridiculous wait. By some miracle, I only waited 20 minutes to get seated for a table for two at 7:30pm on a Friday night, which was a great start.

My boyfriend and I shared a Tori Paitan ramen (extra chashu) and a Spicy Lamb ramen (also extra chashu - yeah, we're extra). Both were super flavorful but also very thick and creamy with thick noodles, so if that's really not your thing, I'd recommend ordering something else or going elsewhere for ramen. Ordering a Japanese beer with the bowl was the PERFECT way to cut the richness of it all, but if you don't, it'll definitely feel heavier than most ramen. 

Toppings wise, the best part was the meat. The lamb inside the spicy lamb ramen was super tender cumin lamb with just a hint of numbing spice (ugh, I LOVE cumin lamb). The duck chashu in the Tori Paitan was a unique touch that was perfectly cooked, and the pork chashu was so tender that it literally just broke into pieces at the touch of my chopsticks.

Price wasn't unreasonable for SF. The surrounding area isn't great, but if you go at a slower time it's not much of an issue.
author: Sara L.

description: The BEST vegan ramen I've ever had! Actually, all of their ramen is stellar. The quality of the food and service is consistently high. This spot is on the top of the list any time friends come to visit, or when I'm in a cozy mood. I prefer going during off-peak times when the line isn't crazy - but it's still worth the wait when it is long.
author: J N.

description:
With all of the hype, I was overall a little let down by the ramen at Mensho Tokyo.

Given the colder weather, I was looking forward to a nice bowl of hearty ramen to soothe the soul.  For months, I heard rave reviews of the ramen here so I was ready to be blown away.  I came on a Saturday around 6pm I saw the long line which built on the expectation that the ramen was so good that it was good enough to wait in line for.  And perhaps because the expectations were so high, it was set up to disappoint. 

TIP: The place does not have many seats.  Smaller parties have a better chance of being seated sooner than larger parties!

I ordered the tori pairan which is a milky broth from chicken bones filled with unique toppings like kale and duck chasu.  It was thick and hearty with everything one would expect from a good bowl of ramen but not to the point where I was trying to drink every last drop of broth.

Since everyone else also ordered the fried enokki, my friend and I suckered in and ordered it.  The enokki itself is small stranded and when fried, all one really tastes are fried bits.

The service though is very fast and efficient especially since they are mindful of the long line of customers.

Overall, Mensho has a solid broth ramen that is worth trying but may not be worth waiting for multiple trips.
author: Patrick S.

description: Dat shit right there.....is hella gooood. I couldn't understand for the life of me why people waited in a  line down the block to slurp noodles in a 4x4 restaurant that seat 10 ppl. Gawd I know why. I had the ground lamb in the creamy chicken and pork broth...damn who knew. To top it off I had an ice cold Sapporo Japanese beer. I am sooo fuqn with this place. I am sharing my experience but kind of don't want to because I don't want the line to get any longer.....at least not when I am trying to go....
author: Stacie J.

description:
Super limited seating- I think it's three long tables, with a capacity of about 26-28 people at a time? This may be from mental memory, but the wait was worth it.

I remember seeing "No take out or to-go boxes", which means: you better bring an appetite, or be okay with leaving leftovers there. Unless you have stomach capacity the size of their seating space, I'm sure you'll be able to enjoy and devour the ramen like my partner and I did.

We went with the Tori Paitan- regular for me, spicy for him. Both taste similar and are very creamy, but the spicy gets a little bit different (not just the spice, but maybe another ingredient?). Loved the noodle size- somewhat chunky, rich soup, two kinds of chashu (pork and duck), some kale, bamboo shoots, and katsuobushi sauce (dried, fermented skipjack tuna). The spicy doesn't have the sauce, and has nuts, jalapeno miso, and cabbage instead.

Very efficient seating and service, it really is all dependent on how quickly (or slowly) you eat! I'd return, but probably at a less busy time... who knows?
author: Mary F.

description: A little perplexed how to rate this restaurant....After seeing some amazing reviews and the picture of the Matcha Tori Paitan ramen i was totally sold that i had to try this place out and endure the line up! My group and i arrived to the restaurant around 6pm and there was about 30 people lining up. The wait wasn't too bad for a Michelin recommended restaurant. Waited for about an hour and we were in and seated together. I ordered the Matcha Tori Paitan and was pretty happy with the order! The broth was really really creamy and thick but i didn't taste much of the matcha.  It was really pretty and unique so worth a try for $17. When i went they also had a wagyu ramen as well for $39 and they only serve 10 of those a day. Didn't see anyone order wagyu ramen but it was neat to see them have specialty ramen every now and then. The experience did take a bit of turn when one of our friends chewed out out piece of thick string in their ramen. The server explained it was used for wrapping the chasu and apologized and replaced the bowl right away.  But it was very unfortunate that she found a small fly floating in the soup in her replacement bowl...it was a bit ironic to have this happen to a Michelin recommended restaurant but i guess these things can happen anywhere. The server was yet again very kind and apologetic and replaced it with a third bowl and comp the meal for her. Luckily no finding in the third bowl! It was unfortunate this happened but their service and taste definitely makes up for it. Hope this will be a good chance for them to be a bit more aware and reflect to be more attentive with their food preparation even when they are highlighted as Michelin recommended.
author: Paula C.

description:
A. MAZING. 

we were gonna go somewhere else since the line was outside, but a friendly chat with locals in line convinced us to stay. 

as a ramen lover I've never tasted anything like what I had. I had the spicy lamb ramen. it was curry-like. husband got the special of the day (SPECIAL: they only make 10 bowls of it a day--once they're out they're OUT). he LOVED it. 

just eat here. spend the money. Brave the line. 
DO IT.
author: Ashley M.

description:
Ramen is one of those foods I do not mess around with. In a way I'd say I'm a ramen snob but that's only because I've been to Japan and lived there for a while so I know a good bowl of ramen when I taste one! 
I wanted to try out Mensho because I LOVE MATCHA and I LOVE RAMEN. So I had to go there and try the Matcha Ramen. It was good, but if you are not into Matcha (green tea) you would not like this. My Mother got the normal version of this dish without Matcha and that was very savory and rich in taste.

The broth for the ramen is thick and good. The Matcha is over powering but I love it so I can't complain. The noodles were nice and thick in texture. The meat in the ramen was AMAZING. I believe it was that traditional cha-shu pork they use in many ramens. 
My mother and I got here right when they opened/even a few minutes earlier because I heard it is super busy. There was already a line when we got there and quickly filled up. I was not a fan of the community seating. It is a bit awkward when you want to enjoy your food without the judgment of strangers. But, besides that pretty enjoyable experience. Price was average for ramen in the US around 13-16 per bowl.
author: Shelby S.

description:
So we heard a lot about this place and happen to be in town so we were really excited to try it. When we got there at 7:30pm, already the line was out the door. We waited for an hour and our appetite was building by the time we got seated. Being ravenous, we ordered almost everything on the menu.. we ordered the shoyu oysters, fried enoki mushrooms, tori paiton spicy ramen, and tori paitan with extra chashu ramen along with their craft beer Coedo Shiro.

Here's the breakdown of the food:

Fried Enoki Mushrooms 5/5
The best thing we had here were definitely the fried enoki mushroom. They were meaty and has such great umami flavors and super crunchy. Yummmm

Shoyu Oysters 0/5
This definitely was not for me and it's really an acquired taste. The oysters seem to be cured in the shoyu leaving it in a kind of pasty and chalky kind of texture. It doesn't have that sort of plump texture that oysters have so that definitely kind of threw me off. Also, the brininess flavor was also lost and all you could taste was the soy sauce flavor. 

Tori Paitan Ramen 3/5
The ramen was a bit murky and grainy.. and I don't know.. a little flat without depth of flavor. Or maybe there was too much flavor everything was kind of fighting each other so it cancelled everything out, which made it just.. murky. The noodles had a good bite to it and the soup was able to hold on to the noodles. The chashu was good, the best thing about the bowl of noodles, it literally melts in your mouth. Overall, I thought the broth was just too murky and salty, it was hard to taste the broth altogether.  

Coedo Shiro 4/5
I like it, it's very light and refreshing but it wasn't cold which was kind of strange. Cold beer is a must, so I had to deduct a point there. 

All in all, our bill plus the mandatory tips came out to be $68 which is ridiculous for two bowls of ramen with appetizers and a bottle of beer. I mean yes I know this is SF prices but I wouldn't come here again to wait an hour for the food here.
author: Jean C.

description:
For the longest time, I had Mensho Tokyo bookmarked at the top of my list. With over 1k reviews, this place is regarded as one of the top ramen shops in San Francisco. After months of trying to find the best time to go, I finally had the chance to check Mensho out with my girlfriend last week.

To describe our experience, I need to use a basketball analogy. For many fans, LeBron James is considered the greatest player of all time. To me, I find this debatable (Kobe 5ever!). But just because I don't believe LeBron is the best doesn't mean I do not respect his greatness.

So what's this got to do with Mensho? Before y'all report this review as irrelevant, let me explain. First off, I understand the hype around this restaurant. Overall, the food was tasty, atmosphere felt chill, and service seemed efficient. But, just like how I feel about LeBron, I didn't think Mensho was the best ramen shop ever. Nevertheless, I have to admit that this place was legit!

Coming into Mensho, I had actually thought this restaurant would have a limited amount of choices. In my experience, well-established ramen joints usually specialize in only a few dishes. One look at their menu and it was clear that I was wrong. Mensho has at least 8 distinct kinds of ramen - each unique in its own way. The broth that immediately caught my attention was the Tori Paitan; although I usually don't care for a chicken-based broth, I've heard amazing things about Mensho's rendition. For those of ya'll who can eat a horse, this restaurant also serves two appetizers and double meat/extra toppings can be added to any ramen. Plus, the list of drinks is almost as large as the number of food items! In terms of pricing, Mensho is definitely on the higher end. Ramen here can cost anywhere from $14-$20 not including tax+tip. 

I ended up ordering the Spicy Tori Paitan and my girlfriend got the regular Tori Paitan. Here's what we thought: 

-- GOOD, BUT NOT FOR EVERYONE --
To put it bluntly, the ramen here was great but definitely not what we expected. For both our bowls, the sheer quality of our ingredients - the texture of the noodles, melt-in-your-mouth softness of the meat, and freshness of the toppings - was unrivaled. However, when it came to the broth we felt like it was WAY TOO CREAMY. I LOVE thick af soup, but the Paitain broth tasted more like a sauce than anything else. 

-Spicy Tori Paitan (8/10): Besides the consistency of the broth, I really enjoyed this bowl. The spicy miso definitely added some heat (was sweating!), the cabbage was fresh, and I felt like they gave a decent amount of noodles. On the other hand, I wished that I got more than 1-2 pieces of Chasu - especially if I'm paying $20 (including tax+tip).

-Tori Paitan (7/10): Protip for everyone...Tori Paitan is SLIGHTLY DIFFERENT compared to the spicy version. For example, the regular one has both pork and duck. On my girlfriend's end, she echoed the same sentiments I had about my Spicy Tori. Creamy soup aside, she really loved the Chasu (very soft and flavorful) as well as the noodles. 

-- SMALL, BUT HOSPITABLE ATMOSPHERE -- 
Although the size of Mensho was SUPER TINY (can only fit like 20 people max at one time?), the restaurant made up for this with a really welcoming environment. For instance, I loved the lighting, the decor was beautiful, and they even had coat hangers/boxes for bags that helped save space. Ironically, the bathroom was big too! My favorite part had to be the setup. Every table is essentially communal, and it may force you to interact with your neighbor; some may hate this, but I was all for it.
