-- FRIENDLY, EFFICIENT SERVICE -- 
Every employee was super kind and very quick to respond. Even with the large crowds, we were able to take as long as we needed to eat without ever feeling rushed. 

-- LONGER WAIT THAN THE DMV -- 
If you ever want to try this place you better get here BEFORE THEY OPEN (5pm Tuesday-Sunday). We stopped by around 5:10pm and still had to wait ~30 minutes to get in. Also, don't bother showing up with more than four people unless you have all night.

When planning a trip here, I encourage y'all to take advantage of San Francisco's public transportation system because parking/driving around this area SUCKS. The restaurant is half a mile from Powell St. BART, and there are plenty of bus lines along/near Geary. I will feel bad for you if you end up spending 30 minutes trying to find parking and then having to wait another hour to be seated.

All in all, I find that Mensho Tokyo is really for individuals who love a super thick broth in their ramen - at least when it comes to most of their options. For me personally, I enjoyed my first time here. Despite the wait, it was worth it to say that I finally had a chance to eat at Mensho. But for the price and some of the nitpicky things, I probably wouldn't come back often. I give Mensho Tokyo a "Nice-su, you can take your parents here and they'll be happy" rating. Itadakimasu!

Eat well and prosper,
author: Bryan W.

description:
Ramen is the new craze in San Fran....or well it has been for a year or two.

Mensho is actual pretty fantastic ( if you don't mind the line and wait).

I find their flavors spot on. Super flavorful broths, vegetables, and meats.

Plenty of ramen joints just toss in the veggies and meats and they really do not have much flavor. Mesho's Chashu is heavenly porky goodness. Mushrooms were delicate, woodsy, and added dimension to the broth. 

I would even suggest their vegan ramen...there are very few places that serve something like this....as the broth is usally made with bones and or meat.

Even if you don't feel like a bowl of ramen Mensho offers soba noodle plates that are incredibly tasty. Great thick noodles. Wonderful cooked pork and vegetables.

Nice beer and Sake options!

Writing this review makes me want to get back into line!

GO!!!!!!!!!
author: David G.

description:
I was here at a recommendation of a friend, and oh my, was it good!!! The Iine starts forming 40 min before the place actually opens. If you don't get there that early, you will have to wait until the second turn of the restaurant. The place is small so be prepared to wait.

Once you get in, the food is excellent, the Ramen Brothers is rich and creamy and the nodded is to die for. The consistency of the noodle is excellent and the bbq pork is fatty and succulent at the same time. I would definitely come back here again, but arrive between 4-4:30pm to get in and not have to wait too long.
author: Duncan H.

description:
Matcha Ramen and ALL THE (well-deserved) HYPE. 

I'd be lying if I said that wasn't the reason why my friends and I tried this ramen spot. Mensho Tokyo has had such a good reputation in terms of the quality of their food and the atmosphere of their restaurant. They have a very modern, communal design for their restaurant that gives off a very at-home vibe for their customers. They also have an automatic service charge since they are a gratuity free establishment!

We were able to try the Tori Paitan and of course the Matcha Tori Paitan. You can definitely tell why they're the crowd favorites. The broth was SO rich and creamy, the noodles were better than anything we've had anywhere else, and the meat was melt in your mouth good. 

We arrived an hour before closing on a Tuesday night and there was about a 10 min wait (which is not bad at all especially since were expecting a much longer wait). One thing to note is that it was a pretty cold night so my friends and I went inside to wait inside the restaurant for a little bit. A server acknowledged us and told us that it will be a couple of minutes and we should be seated soon. Before we got a chance to go back out, another server saw us and condescendingly told us to go outside since we weren't allowed to wait inside. Our apologies, we've never been there before and we were cold. 

Other than the weird customer service hiccup, highly recommend Mensho Tokyo!
author: Isabel C.

description:
Tips: Highly suggest coming early to start lining up.  There is no wait list so there is no wandering away.  There are also no takeout containers (but you can bring tupperware if you really must) so only order as much as you can eat!  

I tried the Matcha Ramen because I was super intrigued about the idea.  It was good ramen, and I could definitely taste the matcha but next time I will probably try something less gimmicky. I was also able to try the $40 ramen with wagyu.  Highly recommend getting it at least once (there's a limited amount sold each day!) - I absolutely loved it and the price is somewhat reasonable since the meat is so expensive!  

Overall, Mensho is a good place to come to treat yourself and also if you're not strapped for time.  Your tummy will definitely leave happy.
author: Shannon L.

description:
My new favorite ramen spot in the Bay Area! I heard a lot about Mensho and finally decided it was the perfect time to try it on a rainy day. My group got there at 4:30 and people were already standing in line. When 5pm finally came, we were able to get in as the first wave. 

It was their 2 year anniversary and they had a Miyazaki A5 wagyu special! Anytime I see Miyazaki A5 available, I get it. Great choice indeed. The meet was so tender that I was able to twirl my fork and break it apart. The juicy fatty contents the lingered with each bite. It was a generous amount of meat too! The noodles were different from the regular noodles. It was shorter and chunkier which wasn't of my preference at the time. Watched my friend slurped up his ramen, which was thin and long. I tried my friends broth and it was creamy but not to the point where it was overly milky. I might just try whatever he had next time. The duck chashu I did as an add on was tender. 

Service was impeccable. The girl with the nice wing liner, glasses and tattoos was awesome. Very nice and made sure we got everything. Can't wait to come back and try other items on the menu!
author: Ada H.

description:
RAMEN HEAD. I came here after watching Ramen Head and because it was supposedly the best in the SF area. I had the spicy ramen (the only spicy one on the menu) and to be honest, I found the broth to be too thick. Almost as if they added flour to it. 

The noodles were good. I judge a bowl of ramen by their noodles.

The price seemed a little far fetched. $17 for a bowl of ramen, when I can go to K-Town in LA and eat a bowl for $11-12.. I guess if you're in SF and don't mind waiting an hour in line then go ahead.
author: Stephanie G.

description:
Very solid ramen joint in SF. However, I don't really think the bowl is "line worthy" though, given that there was a decent line and wait for a Tuesday evening. Inside is pretty small and they really squeeze people in here, so can feel a bit cramped / claustrophobic. Staff is very quick and efficient, and can come off as a little brusque. 

They have a specific type of ramen, which is the paitan ramen which was mostly a very creamy, thick, milky chicken broth. The noodles are pretty thick and chewy, and have an eggy noodle taste to them, cooked very well although it does absorb the broth and get soggy somewhat quickly. Portion is pretty large and with how thick the soup is, it's a very filling meal. There are a multitude of toppings you can add on to your ramen in addition to what they come with, although they are a little pricey at $2 a pop for everything including cabbage and bean sprouts (seriously???).

They have other options on the menu including non-creamy ramen, as well as aburasoba which is kind of like yakisoba but not friend with the sauce. 

Overall a really good bowl, but I think a bit overhyped - I definitely would have loved it if I didn't wait 40 minutes for it, though.
author: Pam C.

description:
Mensho was one of those places that was so good, I had to come back the next day to have it again.

There is always a line. I heard it's super crazy when they first open, but I waited until after 8PM on both occasions and went by myself for easier seating. By doing this, the wait was always less than 15 minutes before I snagged a spot. If you go in a group of two, the wait wont be as bad, but if you try to come with more than that, then good luck - you might be there for a while.

Because the place is small, single eaters will be sat wherever there is space. That means if a party of five is having a dinner full of inside jokes, guess who's the creepy uncle in the corner quietly trying not to make eye contact. I didn't mind. Just buried my face into one of the best bowls of ramen I've ever had.

For food I went with the Spicy Tori Paitan Ramen with double chashu each time. The first round I forgot to order an egg, the second time I wasn't so careless. The broth had a good kick and it had an amazing creamy texture. The noodles were perfectly cooked and a little thicker than the traditional ramen that I was used to.

I wish you could order extra noodles, but they have the food coming out like a well oiled machine. One bowl is plenty and you'll be sweating out all those amazing spices for the next 24 hours. Worth it.

If you have some time to kill and you don't mind waiting for your food, I highly recommend Menhso.
author: Ryan C.

description:
2 of us waited for about 45-50 minutes to get seated. It was crazy because when we called the staff person said "45-50 min". He's obviously timed these lines perfectly! 

We ordered the tori paitan ramen and it was good. I never eat duck but it came with so I went for it. It was actually delicious and very tender. The broth was rich, but it was just that. It was extremely flavorful for the amount of richness that appears in the photos. The chives and cabbage were a great touch. The eggs was deliciously fermented but it was cooked all the way through. There's something oddly satisfying with that hot broth and partially runny egg but oh well.

Prices were steep. With the wait factored into it, the broth not being my #1, and not allowing to go containers for your leftovers, I give this 4 starts. I would not go again simply because of the way and can think of several other places I'd rather go to.
author: C T.

description:
Our friend living in SF brought my boyfriend and I here on a late Friday afternoon. We got here about 30 minutes before opening and there was already a decent number of people lined up outside the restaurant, a sign of the huge hype for this place. We were able to make it in the first wave right after opening and were seated at a shared table with several other people. The space inside is fairly small but it seats a decent number of people. The tables are also very similar to the restaurants in Japan, with small cubbies to store your bags and belongings.
We ordered the fried enoki chips to share and I ordered the Tori Paitan ramen with double chashu and a soft boiled egg. They brought us our appetizer first to start before then preparing our entrees. The enoki chips were crispy and were pleasant to snack on, however for the $6 price tag I wouldn't get it twice.
Once we worked our way through the chips, they brought out our ramen. Upon trying the broth, you're hit with a lot of flavors as well as the thick/creamy texture. It was also interesting to see a variety of vegetables including kale and cabbage included. The chashu was worth adding, falling apart immediately as you pick it up or bite into it. The egg was a bit of a disappointment. It was marinated in tea and the flavor permeated the egg, but the egg itself was more cooked than soft boiled, unfortunately. The same went for my 2 other friends that also ordered an egg. I wouldn't pay for the egg again.
Despite that, the overall dish was very filling and we all left in a food coma. Paying about $27 per person (15% tip is automatically added to your bill), it was definitely a hefty price tag as well as a very long wait if you don't come early enough, and for that I wouldn't come here often just to get my ramen fix. However, I wouldn't be averse to coming once or twice more to try some of the other options here.
author: Vivian Y.

description:
I had put off coming here for the longest time since they always had a line. But one Friday night around 10 pm, I decided to give it a try -- there couldn't possibly be a long line at 10:30 at night, right? Right? 

Wrong, we waited for over an hour for a table for 2, getting seated right before 11:30pm, their closing time. So I guess the lesson here is they have a pretty long line at any time of day, if you want to eat here, just accept that you will have to wait ;) 

The wait would've been okay if the food was good. But the ramen was disappointing -- it could just be my personal preference but my husband and I both didn't like it at all, and we LOVE ramen. 

We got the Tori Paitan. The soup was thick and salty. But everything else was not very flavorful. The pork chashu also didn't have a very good texture. The duck chashu was the only thing that was okay. 

To make it worse, the service was not attentive at all. We didn't get a glass water until 45 minutes after we arrived and asked for water twice. 

Not to mention the very noisy environment where the people who we sat right next to (big shares tables) were very drunk...
author: Iris H.

description:
The place that made me fall in love with vegan ramen. Their vegan broth is so creamy and tasty, that even though that's their only option - I keep going back for more. My husband loves the pork or lamb double chashu. 


Be prepared to wait no matter what time you go to, coz they are the best and everyone in the city loves mensho! 


Also come here very hungry coz it's a large portion and there's no to-go boxes.
author: Eshita S.

description:
I've been hearing so much about this place.  I've noticed that the inside is always packed and the line is outrageously long.  So, I decided to check this place out one Thursday evening.  I arrived at about 4:15pm and was the 3rd person in line.  As expected, a large crowd started filing in behind me.  As the doors opened, I was intrigued by the attentiveness and efficiency of the staff.  I got a seat at the counter looking into the kitchen which I thought was pretty cool.   I ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen which came pretty quickly.  The broth was rich.  The noodles and the other items tasted good as well.  I'd have to say I enjoyed having the duck included because I personally don't eat it often.  

It worked out well for a single diner.  But be aware, this is no place for a large group or an intimate dinner.  People are packed into this place and you might feel you are on your neighbors lap listening to their conversation.  

Overall, I really enjoyed this place.  I'm giving this place a 4+ because I can't say I am a Ramen connoisseur compared to some of my friends.
author: Mitch T.

description:
Been to this ramen joint five times and their tori pairan is consistent and flavorful. The broth is VERY rich which fills you up really fast. The noodles have a very good texture and their pork and duck chashu just melts in your mouth. You can add extras for a small charge. While the ramen is not cheap, I would definitely wait in line again for another bowl! 

Get their oyster appetizers! Salty and delish!
author: Sui N.

description:
The broth was creamy and the noodles were pretty chewy and tasty; however, I feel like I've tasted better ramen (overall) elsewhere, like in LA. The chashu pork was definitely not up to par for me - it had a very distinct smell and was a little too neukkihae for my taste (What's the correct word for this in English? Oily? Greasy?)

It's a very small joint where you'll be sharing a table with strangers. And oh yes, definitely expect to wait in line!

P.S. make sure to get their fried enoki mushroom tempura!
author: Angelina H.

description:
The HYPE is REAL!

Rich and creamy broth that packs a punch of flavor with tender pieces of pork and duck chashu and al dente noodles with the perfect bite? You bet the wait is worth it. And by wait, I mean there's a line outside before the restaurant even opens!
author: Lisa N.

description:
Yaas! Super creamy broth and thick noods are the way to go. I really liked their noodles because the noodles were a bit chewier and had a bounce/elasticity to them. 

I got the Matcha Tori Paitan, and I tried my friend's Spicy Tori Paitan, which I liked more (the kick is there!). When I took my first bite out of the Matcha Tori Paitan, I got a lot of pepper in that bite, which was not pleasant at all. LOL, so make sure you mix everything before consuming. Also, I could taste a bit of a bitter aftertaste from the matcha. Overall, the dish was an interesting try, but I'm not sure if the matcha such a good match. 

Do get their soft boiled egg! Ajitama comes in two flavors: soy sauce or miso. I got the miso flavored egg, and I was super impressed with how they got flavor in the yolk! So delish.

Came here at 5pm on Super Bowl day, so the line wasn't bad. My friend and I were seated when the restaurant opened, so there was minimal wait time. Good stuff. Super filling meal due to creamy broth. Service was decent. Gratuity is included.
author: Tiffany H.

description: Was visiting SF for a couple days and stayed downtown. This ramen joint was actually located around the corner of where our hotel was located. Our family waited about 3 hours, it was worth the wait.
author: Sheryll R.

description:
My girlfriend and I finally decided to give Mensho a try. We've heard many of our friends speak highly of this place. We got here at about 4:30 on a rainy day and were surprised that there were already people waiting in line. We got seated and was part of the first wave of people that got seated. 

We both ordered the Miyazaki A5 wagyu ramen. This is part of their anniversary special and they only make ten bowls of this a day, so if you want to try this, make sure to be here early. The wagyu was very tender. I was surprised at how generous the portion was. The broth was light yet flavorful. The only thing that was off about it were the noodles. It wasn't your traditional ramen noodles. The noodles were clumps and didn't withhold the flavors of the soup well.

There was a decent range of beers and sakes available. The lychee sake here was floral and refreshing.

The service here was impeccable. All the servers were quick on their feet and even though it was busy, each person took their time to make sure everything was good.
author: Timothy C.

description: Oh man this place still doesn't disappoint. Recently came here and had to opportunity to try their $40 Wagyu ramen with beef imported from Japan. One of the best ramens I ever had!!! This was only limited to 10 bowls a day, with a opening at 5pm, and we didn't even get seated till 6:30 when we arrived at 5pm. The beef was so soft and buttery, the soup was super flavorful and the temperature of the soup was perfectly hot. This place is still my favorite spot in the city and well worth the wait. Thanks to my best friend Yvonne for taking me on my birthday!
author: Nicholas k.

description:
So good!!! Love this ramen spot. A bit more pricey, but worth it! It's the most tastiest ramen in the area without a doubt. The ramen noodles have a nice texture and the soup base is thick and creamy.  

The entire bowl's ingredients and proportions compliment each other really well. Never felt that there was too much or too little of something.
They have a pretty unique menu to pick from, none seem to disappoint.
The restaurant is pretty small, seating wise. They have 2 long tables for people to sit across from each other and pretty much shoulder to shoulder with your neighbor lol. There are baskets under the table to put your bags in (and your feet I suppose). I've tried their tori paitan, matcha, and lamb ramens and they are all satisfying. 
Parking is hard in the area and there may be a wait outside, but just give yourself more time and strategize your dinner plans! Be patient, arrive a little earlier (they open at 5pm, so try and get there before 5:30), and enjoy your meal :).
author: Tiffany Z.

description: Mensho has a long wait outside but it's definitely worth it. My sister got the Matcha ramen and I got the vegetarian and we preferred the vegetarian.
author: Sydney G.

description:
Love the idea and execution of the ramen here.  One of the best ramen I've had in the Bay Area.  I got to try their signature, matcha, and the lamb.  While all of them were good in their own respect, I thought the lamb just leaps and bounds better. 
The cumin and lamb carry through the flavor from start to end.  It wasn't too gamey as most US lamb tends to be.  The signature ramen is crazy full of flavor for being chicken and the broth is a lot thicker than you'd expect.  The ramen itself has a great bite and chew.
Excellent!
author: Bobby L.

description:
'Whoa, look at that line! This place must be great!' - me, being misguided. Don't get me wrong, Tokyo Mensho isn't terrible. It's nothing to write home about though. And with that line and the prices, I expected more.

Got here with friends pretty late, think it was around 9:30pm. We still waited for about half an hour. Upon getting to the front of the line, we finally got to see a menu. Turns out after all that wait, there was only one dish on the menu that most people in our group could eat. If you're vegetarian or Kosher, I suggest skipping this place.

Most of us ordered the vegan ramen since that was all we could eat. Tbh it wasn't great. It got the job done but wasn't the best ramen I've had. And at $18 for a dish with zero meat, it should be great. 

Service was good but ambiance was a bit much. The music was fun but so loud we had to yell our conversation. The videos playing on the TV were also fun but definitely felt a bit inauthentic. 

Overall, eh. If it was a few dollars cheaper with less of a line, I would love this place. As is, probably won't return.
author: Audrey S.

description: 1st time. We showed up 10 min before it opened and it worked out perfectly because we were behind about 10 people and got seated. I ordered the vegan ramen and it was so flavorful. It was also a bit spicy. If you don't have a huge appetite then I'd suggest for you to share because they give you a nice portion of it. Also, you can't take leftovers home. So there's no to-go bowls which forced me to stuff my mouth because I was full haha.
author: Lani M.

description:
The best ramen I've ever had. The Spicy Lamb with its creamy miso soup had me helplessly 
 in its grasps instantly. Added some sliced duck (so tender!) along with a soft boiled egg -- perfection.
author: Rob K.

description:
OH MY LAWD. This unassuming ramen shop is realllly tasty. I got the Shio Ramen and it wasn't too salty nor was it too fatty. The noodles are spirally and wide enough to soak up the broth. In the future, I'd want the noodles a little harder, but overall an amazing dish and a cute place where you're knocking elbows with your neighbors.

I want to try their fried mushrooms next time, it looked really tasty and not oily.
author: Jenny Q.

description:
Despite the long wait, I would say the ramen here is some of the best there is in San Francisco. The place is rather small, so you may be sitting with some neighbors if you come with a small party, but it was an overall cozy and enjoyable atmosphere.

I had the Tori Paitan and it was delicious! Be aware that it is rather chickeny, especially the broth which at points did feel a bit too heavy and kind of felt like there was chicken blended into it.

That being said, it was still amazingly delicious, and the flavors, textures, and profile were all on point! I especially enjoyed the addition of the egg, which was soft-boiled just right and had the perfect amount of flavoring.

The foaminess of the ramen soup base was also quite excellent, and honestly, I'll probably have to come back to try the other ramen flavors cause this one was so delicious.
author: Tyler T.

description:
Tiny little shop which results in long lines but it has a nice atmosphere for dates. I came late at night on a random week day tho by myself so it wasnt too bad. 

I ordered the enoki mushroom chips and the tori paitan ramen. The enoki mushrooms were deep fried and very similar in taste and texture to hash browns so needless to say they were great. The tori paitan ramen had a creamy chicken soup broth, pork and duck chashu, kale, and burdock and I added a soft boiled dark soy egg. It was very filling and flavorful and among the best ramen iv had in the area.

In the running for the best ramen in the area the only downsides are the hot cramped location and they charged me a hidden 15% gratuity while dining alone at off peak hours. No one was able to explain to me why or what it was for but they ran my card without leaving me an option to tip on the receipt. I usually tip 20% minimum so financially it balanced out it just made no sense to me.
author: Sean G.

description:
By far my favorite ramen shop in SF! I'd dream about their tori paitan ramen sometimes cuz it's that unique (has chicken thick broth and duck breast) and good! 
We had the matcha tori ramen and the limited A5 wagyu ramen this time. The matcha taste is not that strong so it's similar to the regular tori paitan ramen. The wagyu ramen is flavorful. However I prefer the broth to be a little bit lighter so the wagyu can standout even more. 
Prepare for a super long wait (1-2 hours) and entertain yourself in line. Other than that everything else is fantastic! Staff is super friendly too! Will come back again, again and again...
author: Christy X.

description:
I took off a star because of the extremely long wait. The portion size is healthy and ramen is cooked to a nice texture. The broth is delish . Will be back again but definitely not during peak times.
Ordered two bowls of noodles and saw the expensive noodles and decided to snap a picture Incase if anyone trying to hunt down Kobe beef ramen.
author: Amy E.

description:
I waited 45 minutes in line at Mensho, then an hour a second time exactly  a week later. Both times were totally worth it.

The first time I got the spicy lamb ramen and it may have been the best ramen I've ever had. The ground lamb was moist and had a very strong, appetizing cumin flavor, the pork chashu was most and tender, and the thick noodles were delicious down to the last shreds hiding away at the bottom.

The broth was similarly fantastic. It was at that perfect spicy level where it feels good to eat, but didn't have me downing glass after glass of water. It was very rich and what I would call "dirty", but in a good way. There was a lot of flavor and texture going on, with each sip making me want to take the next. Overall masterfully executed, even better than most of the ramen I had in Tokyo.

The second time I got the spicy tori paitan, which wasn't as tasty. Still better than all the other ramen I've had in the Bay, I think, but the flavor was less interesting than the spicy lamb. It was less spicy and a good bit cleaner, with a less intricate flavor. It was still very thick though, and filled me up fast.

The ramen itself was easily five stars, but the line is awfully long and frequented by aggressive panhandlers. A system to allow customers to wait in a warmer, less-shifty place and be notified via text message would be greatly appreciated (Nowait, anyone?). Also, a bowl of ramen after tax and included 15% tip comes out to $20, which is a bit pricey for what is essentially Japanese fast food. But overall, the food outweighs the other stuff and it's overall definitely worth the wait and price to visit Mensho.
author: Shawn W.

description: Fire! This is a ridiculous ramen shop, has to be in the top ten in the nation. Everything has been studied meticulously and this place knows ramen, broth, and specially, umami. I got a duck ramen, and this is one of the most delicious dishes I have ever had, and I have eaten a lot of good stuff. Definitively a must stop if you like ramen. On the other hand, you can skip the apps. But get a beer.
author: Julio H.

description: The broth was my favorite part. It was very rich! Noodles were also fresh and higher in quality compared to most ramen places I have been to. Only thing was the wait to be seated. My friend and I waited for approximately 2 hours in line on a weekend. The place also is very small and can probably fit 20 people at a time. Expect to be sitting extremely close to other parties.
author: Justine T.

description:
Make sure to get there 30 minutes before it opens!! Otherwise the line is HELLA LONG. 

I've been here twice and ordered the same thing both times because it was that good.
I ordered:
* Fried enokki: SO GOOD! Crispy with that umani flavor
* Tori Paitan Ramen: DELICIOUS! omg my mouth is watering just thinking about it. What's special about this ramen is that it has chashu and duck! The broth is rich, flavorful, with that umani flavor as well. 
* plum wine: really sweet and good! Really small portions though 
* matcha ramen: pretty good, but not worth the extra couple dollars. The tori paitan is just as good! 

Really recommend, but make sure to go early!
author: Jamie N.

description:
I DID MY WAITING. TWO HOURS OF IT. Not in Azkaban, but outside Mensho near the Tenderloin.

My friend raved about this place and said the wait would be one hour. Instead, it was two. And it was good, but not worth the two hour wait. 

I got shio char siu ramen with an egg and it was really good, but felt overhyped. I got the egg as an extra and the egg was warm and had a strong soy-flavor. The broth was rich, warm, and savory, and the noodles had a good consistency. 

The restaurant is cramped and small and tea is not included and ramen portions aren't as big as Santa Ramen/Ramen Dojo/Ramen Bar in San Mateo. They also don't offer takeout boxes.
author: Lizzie S.

description:
For some strange reason, I crave Mensho almost exclusively on Mondays...the only day I can't have Mensho. Then I go through the test of patience and suffering until Tuesday. 

Needless to say Mensho is my favorite ramen spot in the city because of my love for. Thick. Rich. Ramen. 

My go tos are the Tori Paitan and the Spicy Lamb. Tori Paitan never disappoints on cold SF evenings with its thick rich flavorful broth, but spicy lamb can be a little too salty sometimes. Let's just say the spicy lamb is burst with flavors - sometimes your mouth gets confused and overwhelmed in a good way.

Enoki mushrooms? I could go either way , but get it only if you are ordering a beer :P 

I tried their other ramen choices , such as shio and clam ramen - however, wasn't too impressed. I think it's just personal preference/taste thing though because my other friends liked the shio. FYI: clam butter ramen is limited to 10 each day, and takes longer to make than other ramen.

I dare you to point out a rich thick ramen spot that's better than Mensho in SF.
author: Solongo B.

description:
Been seeing crazy lines and finally got a chance to check it out on a Saturday at 9:50 pm. The line was about 20 people and took half an hour. Not bad considering during prime time hours it could be a hour. 

The Tori Paitan is their most popular and I thought after reading other reviews that I wouldn't like it. But after a taste, my mind and taste buds changed. The broth is on the thicker and creamier side but I didn't think it was too much. It wasn't salty either but tasted like a richer tonkatsu. I had the extra chasu which was duck chashu and it was good.

Prices are a bit high and it's small inside with a long line but it's worth it.
author: James H.

description:
I don't like ramen.

I don't like ramen.

I don't like ramen.

Oh wait, wtf... I do.

Mensho has shaped the way I think about ramen and completely turned me on to my obsessive search for good ramen everywhere. I've eaten practically every item on their menu now and still love it. The lines, yes, are still ridiculously long unless you get there just before 5pm or after 11pm, but it's worth the wait.

My favorites are:
- Vegan Ramen: I love meat, but this vegan ramen is quite something. The flavors are not as "heavy" as the other favorite, the Tori Paitan, but yet it's still a filling meal here. It feels a little healthier too!
- Tori Paitan: Creamy, rich, delicious pork broth; this one is a classic. It's mouth-watering savory!
- Shio: If you're into fishy flavors, this lighter ramen for under $10 fills a lighter meal than the above two items and has a deep umami flavor. Not a fan of fishiness? Probably shouldn't choose this or the shoyu.

The only bad ramen I've had here was the worst ramen I've ever had in my life, but it was a temporary summer chicken and corn special that isn't a menu staple. I've tried some of the dry ramens too which are good as well, but not exactly my cup of tea (or soup for that matter).

Why Mensho stands out:
- Ramen: has a lot of chew, and are thicker noodles to my liking.
- Broth: deep, deep umami flavor that gives it the complexity many ramen places miss.
- Meat: by far the BEST meat on ramen I've ever had. It's seasoned well, isn't dry at all, and they have both duck and pork options (both which are amazing).

Basically, Mensho's ramen stands out in all regards.

Note: They do not do takeout, they do not let you box home food, everyone who comes in has to order their own bowl of ramen, and sometimes they play very hyped up music which doesn't really make sense for the environment... but for the amazing ramen that hits the spot every time, I will deal with these minor inconveniences.
author: Joanne Y.

description:
I've been dying to try this ramen place for the longest time, and the numerous number of rave reviews I have gotten from friends has definitely made the experience of trying Mensho Tokyo's ramen extra exciting. 

We came on a Thursday night at around 6pm, and the line was already fairly long. The restaurant holds only about 28 spots, so the lines and wait for ramen are crazy! We waited for about an hour, which I heard was better than most, since the average wait time is 1.5-2 hours. After getting seated on one of their bench seats, they had a place to hang coats and a cubby on the bottom of the table to hold purses. 

I decided to order their organic shoyu ramen with double chasiu. At first bite, the aroma of the broth was absolutely amazing. Since I enjoy more of a lighter broth, I loved the warm, meaty taste of the clear shoyu broth. The noodles were also very interesting, and they had a thick yet flattened texture. The duck chasiu was also very tender and the chasiu was flavorful with a good amount of meat to fat ratio. However, I do wish the chasiu was heated up, since it was cold on my plate. 

Overall, this is a great ramen place and I would love to come back (if I feel like waiting in that line again). This is definitely an experience that needs to be fulfilled when living in SF, and the aesthetics of each bowl will make the food all the more delicious.
author: Sandra S.

description: THE BEST ramen I've had thus far! They even have a vegan ramen which is super yummy. I also love that they use thick noodles here, not the thin stringy kind. The only downside to this place is the wait, but it is totally worth it!
author: Alice S.

description: Every time I go to menshu it's always packed but always worth it. As a newly vegetarian, I ordered the vegan ramen (with an egg). It was unreal! It has a great Smokey flavor to it and the egg was perfectly cooked. The noodles were cooked really well, and the nuts gave it an interesting crunch. I added fried garlic on top of my ramen which I highly recommend. I also got my ramen non spicy (which is why it looks a little different) but I sprinkled some flakes on top anyways. Just bring a snack while you wait in line.. def not a spot you would go if you were hangry and be prepared for over an hour wait. Bring good company too (makes the wait easier)
author: Michelle K.

description:
I'm not sure why ramen places in the Bay Area have to have long and arduous waits. It really doesn't add any extra flavor and with ramen as good as Mensho, adding more flavor would ruin the great taste.
The broth is rich and creamy. The multiple meats are tender. My only criticism is that I need more noodles for the leftover broth!
Verdict: Ah you got to Go you must
author: Sunder I.

description:
Usually when I see a line adjacent to a store, I usually think it's a bunch of hypebeasts waiting for some Supreme, Bape, Jordans, Yeezys, etc.  But when I found out it was a ramen joint, I was curious.  The hype is real.  

My average wait-time here ranges from 45 minutes to an hour, but there have been times (generally past dinner time) that I just walked in.  The staff is courteous enough to run down the line to count how many people are in your party, which sometimes serves as useful evidence for calculating how soon and by whom you'll be seated if you're peeping through the window to see those finishing their meals.  The restaurant is comprised of a few long tables, so you inevitably will sit next to a stranger (unless you get seated in the back counter that seats 4-6 people).  

There are a few ramen selections, but I've only ordered the paitan broth.  It is extremely rich and creamy!  There is a single or double cha-sew option, which is just how many slices of pork your order will come with.  I always order the double cha-sew and add duck and a miso egg.  The egg is a must.  The yolk is perfect, golden runny and never overcooked.  The noodles aren't the firm-textured noodles that I've seen in most ramen restaurants.  These noodles are on the thicker-end and have a bounce to them--much like how pasta is al dente.  You will be equipped with a metal spoon the size of which is probably meant for scooping rice out of a rice cooker.  

To my recollection, there are only two appetizers:  deep fried enoki mushrooms and mini oysters.  I'd pass on the oysters because they're overly saucy, but the enoki mushrooms are very tasty!  I mean, it's a vegetable, so it's healthy even if it's deep fried--right?

The servers are all friendly, especially Kelani (her Japanese is on point)!  They seem to deal with the crowd on a daily basis, so they are accustomed to answering questions such as "how much longer til we get seated?" and telling customers that there is no to-go option.
author: Bonnie T.

description:
Mensho's ramen is def very unique in it's own way by creating a flavor no one has reached. In my opinion, the broth was so thick it tasted closer to a tantanmen than a ramen. The wait was about 45 minutes on a sunday evening but that can't be helped bc the restaurant is pretty small and only couple of parties can sit at the same time. I got the 'spicy tori paiten ramen' and was $17 (not including tax or tip). Pretty pricy for a bowl of noodles.

The service is what honestly made this place a whole lot better as well. Despite everyone being agitated because they had to wait so long, the servers were very professional and kind. They were also very attentive when it came to refilling drinks and grabbing the check.

All in all, it was a memorable and a great experience. I gave it a 4 stars bc it just wasn't what I expected but still very delicious in it's way!  I would 100% recommend to a friend if they are in SF for vaca just for the experience.
author: Sindy C.

description:
Holynoodlers. Mensho have restore my faith in SF Ramen.

Prior to Mensho the best ramen I've tasted was Hinomaru's in Astoria, NY. I lived in Boston previously so Santouka had been our go to place and I never thought I could replace Santouka until now.

Mensho. Took me away from basic shoyu/miso broth and shove my face into tori paitan and changed my life. The creamy broth was incredible, rich, umami, warm, and comforting. Broth alone it got me. Noodle itself is normal nothing oomph. But the meat itself was equally lit. Duck + pork, tender, melt in your mouth kind of loving. Appetite for seduction...oh wait. It's good. Even the crunchy burdock part elevate the bowl to a whole nother level. Drink the entire soup, not a drop left. Amazingly not salty like other ramen place, though I do drink a whole cup of water.

Now is the wait worth it? It is and it isn't. Up to a point your hunger take over and if you're not a very patient and discipline person you'll give up and may or may not just go to Kim Thanh down the street which is also delicious, that may or may not happen with me on more than one occasion. 

But when I am a good girl and wait it's so worth it. It's so beautifully good that most of the time if I am waiting alone I can wait for it. Trying to go on off hours again is a better choice though now everyone will know the trick and go early so there is no way around the waiting. And it is infuriating when you're at the window and you see people finished their food, paid and proceed to sit their and chat for another 15 minutes and you are like "LEAVE GO OUTSIDE AND TALK OMB IM STAVING PLZZZ" but they must have waited in line for 30 minutes and think they deserve to make people wait more after that? Meh? 

Service is normal, you are expected to read the menu while waiting in line and just order asap so they can get you your food so you can eat and then gtfo for the next few customers. It's like literally going to war, delicious rameny war.
author: Quynh Nhu D.

description:
Came here on a weekday while visiting a friend in SF. 

The place was highly rated so we wanted to give it a try. When we got to the restaurant, there was a fairly sizeable line outside deep into dinner service. Expect to wait about 45min to an hour.

The spot is simple and really focuses on the food and service. Service was attentive yet not overbearing. As for the food, we got the mushroom chips, the Paitan Ramen and the Matcha Paitan Ramen. The mushroom chips were really tasty, I highly recommend adding the dashi dust on the table to really enhance the flavors!

As for the ramen, it was A-OK. The matcha broth was rich and had the nutty bitterness that comes with the matcha. The other Paitan was quite savory, however, both broths were too rich for our tastes. The first few bites of the ramen were really good, however, we felt the heaviness as we finished the ramen.

Overall a good experience, with good food.
author: Ryan C.

description: Amazing Ramen!!!  We waited for a hour and a half during a beautiful sunset on Friday evening and were not disappointed with the ramen dishes we had.  Both the Vegan and Spicy Chicken ramen were absolutely delicious!
author: Lauran H.

description:
Get here at least by 4:15 to be one of the first to sit down. Otherwise, one will have to wait.  I am a person that prefers to wait ahead of time to be the first one inside rather than waiting while a line has formed after opening.  

Ambiance
This is a very small Ramen place that holds around 40 people. Once inside, the place has a modern Japanese feel to it.  They have places to hang my coat and put my book bag. The space is quite narrow for seating. 

Food 
There is a nice variety of Ramen and the usually toppings. The Paitan Ramen is pretty impressive with the creamy broth sticking to the noodle.  The organic Shoyu is more of the traditional broth Ramen with a twist of the noodles.  The mushroom cups are worth a try if one is fine with the fried foods. Really nice twist to a traditional mushroom. 


Service
After getting into the restaurant, I think the service is very fast once I ordered.  My Ramen came out before the appetizers since Ramen broth is made well in advance.  The wait staff is very attentive.
author: Simon N.

description:
I was supersized for how tiny of this ramen place. Maybe that's the feeling of Tokyo, lol

I ordered the most popular ramen, called Tori Parian. It is creamy but not that creamy. I liked it. The noodle in it is thick one, but thin than udon. 

My friend ordered the special which is not on the menu. His soup base was way lighter than me, but he says it was salty. The noodle in his bowl was thin one. 

We also shared marinated oyster. It was impressive at first bit, then just ok ok. 

Overall, this is spot I would like recommend to friend, while I will warning them be patient for the line.
author: Silvia L.

description: I've heard about this place for a while and finally got to try it out. I got the Vegan Tantanmen and omg, the soup was amazing. The right amount of sesame/peanuty flavor with the right amount of chili oil flavor. I could not believe that this whole dish was vegan, it definitely made me feel a little better about putting on a couple pounds lol. I would definitely go back again.
author: Amanda C.

description:
Waited about an hour for seating on a Saturday around 5:30pm. There is no wait list, so you have to wait in line. I'd say the wait time isn't worth the meal but if there is a short line then it's ok trying this place out. The ramen is pricey for what it is. This place is popular for their Tori Paitan ramen which consists of a rich and creamy chicken broth and comes with lots (and lots) of noodles, a couple slices of cha su and duck, and vegetables (such as bamboo shoots, mmm). I assumed an egg came with it, but unfortunately it didn't- you have to order it as an add-on. While the cha su was standard the duck was quite tasty and didn't taste gamey. The noodles itself was thick and flat which I don't prefer for my ramen but it was ok, better than I expected. I was really full from the abundance of noodles so I couldn't imagine getting double cha su. I did try the fried enoki mushrooms which I would personally skip, it was just like eating fried batter.

Might I add the bar seating was really uncomfortable, my back started hurting.
author: Donna M.

description:
I don't normally go for chicken ramen, but I think Mensho's Tori Paitan ramen with double duck chashu might be my favorite ramen in the US right now. As a person who loves pork, I don't even know what I'm saying. But that tori paitan ramen broth made me feel like I was drinking a whole chicken--and yes, that tastes as amazing as it sounds.

My partner and I came on a weekday evening about half an hour after they opened. There was a line of ~6 people in front of us. We waited about a 30 minutes before being seated at one of the communal tables. I think some diners might be put off by this but in Japan, tiny, packed restaurants are pretty common. For me, it sort of added to the authenticity. The only thing missing was a vending machine taking my order instead of a cute, but edgy waitress.

I think some people don't like this ramen because they prefer a thinner broth. I, on the other hand, prefer a very thick broth (like tsukemen) to coat my noodles so this ramen aligns perfectly with my preferences. 
The chashu has that sort of complex, dark meat flavor that I love about duck. The broth was thick and very chicken-y while the noodles were the perfect width for holding broth. The texture of the noodles had a nice gentle chew to them.

The price and wait make expectations for this place super high. For me, it really surpassed my expectations so I definitely think it's worth the price. I haven't had ramen that was this good since Japan (travel not-so-humblebrag). 

TL;DR?
- With ~1400 reviews, is there anymore that needs to be said? Mensho is a popular ramen spot that will always have a wait.

- If you like thick noodles, thick broth, and juicy duck this meal will be heavenly for you.

- I've never seen matcha in ramen before! Looking forward to trying it next time I'm in the city.
author: Chesa C.

description: Third attempt to tackle their long line. Arrived around 530 on a Sunday evening. No seats to wait. No clip board to sign your name down. So we were forced to stand outside and wait for 1 hour. Inside is small & can feel overly crowded but the dining area was clean, so I give it that. Got seated @ the bar which was nice, & was able to overlook the cooking process in the kitchen. The cook and the employees in the back were working quickly. We got our order taken a few minutes after being seated, & got our food shortly after. The matcha ramen was good 4/5, the noodles were so soft & chewy but the broth could have used a bit more flavor. The spicy lamb ramen 5/5, broth was full of flavor, meat was tender, noodles were consistently soft & chewy. The staff was prompt and friendly. Overall this place was good, but next time I would avoid their long line & go somewhere else just as good for my ramen fix.
author: Mel B.

description:
The ramen at this place is on point, delicious pork Chashu, and excellent broth.
My partner and I ordered 2 different ramen dishes and the gyoza. All was excellent.Highly recommend this place if your feeling peckish, it's just a bit on the tight side. Such great things jammed in a small package
author: Macleod R.

description:
Man...the thickest and heaviest broth I've ever had.  I've heard so much good things about this place, but the long wait times always scared me and I never explicitly sought to come.  But things always work out and just happened to be in the neighborhood and a group of 6 of us decided to give it a try.  

Even an hour before opening, the line was packed and we had to wait about 40 minutes before getting seated.  I can see why the wait so darn long; they only have 15-20 seats inside!  The setting is mostly community format, so unless you have a large party, you're more than likely to be seated with other die-hard ramen lovers.  

I recall that on this particular day, I wasn't really hungry but ended up getting Tori Paitan (Double Chashu).  I know I know...no shame!  First sip of the broth....wow is it filling, rich, and creamy.  I don't know if I'm in the minority here, but wasn't that big a fan of the thickness of the broth.  The chashu however, was some of the best I've had compared to other ramen establishments.  I loved the texture of the noodles though!  We also had the oysters in shoyu dare oil to share, and those were incredible; highly recommend to order that to start off.

Maybe I'll come back and try this for a second go round in the near future, but my initial experience has me questioning if the richness of the broth is really my style or if I just didn't have the best appetite on my visit.
author: Kevin C.

description:
Sorry, but I really don't get the hype here.

Waited over an hour in line on Sunday at 5:15pm for a party of two.

I ordered the Tori Paitan ramen with double chashu (+egg 1.80) and my s/o got the shoyu with double chashu.

The shoyu broth was incredibly oily and fishy. The noodles were thin and flat, which was interesting and had a nice bite. But the fishiness of the broth was really overpowering and off putting, IMO.

The tori paitan was rich and creamy, but I was expecting a lot more depth in the broth. I really enjoyed the thick and chewy noodles, though. The chashu was nice and fatty and the duck chashu was a nice addition, as well. Due to the broth and the chashu, I was stuffed and tired of the flavors after a few bites. 

I went with the server's recommendation of the soy sauce egg, but wasn't a fan. The yolk was nice and soft boiled, but the egg didn't pair very nicely with the ramen, as it was like adding more salt to something already salty. 

Noodles were done very well, but both bowls of ramen were overall incredibly salty.

Service was decent. Note that tips are already included in your total bill. The servers repeatedly came by and tried to take our bowls away even though there was still food left, which got really annoying. I waited over an hour for this, at least let me finish it!!

Overall: I was honestly pretty disappointed after hearing nothing but great things about Mensho. The flavors are good, but it's just not my bowl of ramen :(
author: Shirley H.

description:
After having this place bookmarked for months, I finally decided to trek all the way to Mensho since the gloomy weather was perfect for ramen. As you all know this place is notorious for ALWAYS having a line. My coworkers and I came here just a little before 5 and we missed the first group by 5 people. :( We ended up waiting 1hr for our group of 4 to have to get seated. 

| AMBIANCE | 

When you enter you realize how small this place actually is. I think it seats only around 30ish people? The place is set up with long communal tables and some bar seats.I would recommend coming with groups 4 or less since a group of 6 came in and their group had to be separated between the bar and a communal table. There's also one bathroom so you have to keep an eye out. 

| FOOD | 

I was afraid that this place was going to be anti-climactic and that maybe my expectations were too hyped up from all my friends, but I'm glad to say that they were just right. We ordered the: 

- Fried Mushrooms: YUM! We saw everyone getting these so we asked the waitress to bring us some as well. It was a big enough size to share between 4 people. The mushrooms were coated in a light batter that wasn't too oily. Squeeze the lemon slice on top and add some of the spices and delish! 

- Tori Paitan: This is definitely a heavy bowl. I only ended up eating only half of my bowl since the broth was so rich and cream (not a bad thing though). My favorite part was a split between the chasu which was so tender and the noodles which were cooked perfeclty al dente. I will say that the noodle for this bowl are thicker than the shoyu but it's probably to fit the broth. 

- Shoyu Ramen: A lighter bowl than the tori paitan. The noodles in this dish are thinner since the broth isn't as creamy but it's still just as good. 

| SERVICE | 

I did feel that since there was such a long line outside the waiters rushed us as soon as they saw some of our bowls empty or us taking a break in between bites. I get it since they want to be able to serve everyone, but at the same time I felt like towards the end I didn't get to enjoy my meal as much. 

***They don't do take out or give you containers for leftovers so be sure to come hungry!

We left around 7PM and the line was even longer than when we first came. I would recommend coming before they open at 5 or a little bit before they close because any other time in between warrants a 1.5-2hr wait.
author: Keizzel C.

description:
Between the amazing ramen, unique atmosphere, and the Missy Elliott blasting on the speakers, I'd say this place is definitely worth 5 stars. 

For an appetizer, go for the enoki chips! Crispy and savory but light at the same time. In terms of main dishes, you honestly can't go wrong with any of them, although my favorites were the Tori Paiten and the Poki soba (Limited, only 10 a night! I think I got the first one). 

If you don't want to wait too long, I suggest lining up at least 30 min before it opens. The restaurant only seats about 25 so you wanna be part of the first wave.
author: Alexandra L.

description: The line for Mensho is visible from down the street and it's definitely worth lining up for at least once! The paitan ramen is one of their most popular ramens and it has a thick soup and fatter, chewy ramen noodles. The noodles make the dish! I would recommend coming on a weekday and lining up right before 5pm so that you don't have to wait too long. I came on a Saturday around 4:55pm and waited in line for about 50 minutes for a table of 4.
author: Jacqueline H.

description: The ramen is really worth the wait. Some of the best ramen I've EVER HAD. Waited about 45mins around 7pm on a TUESDAY. The place seats kinda cafeteria style where you sit across from your dinner date along a large table with other patrons. Tight fit and loud but you have plenty of room to enjoy. Just dont expect to be able to have intimate conversations here. You feel like you have to yell to be heard.
author: Leo J.

description:
Definitely get here earlier than opening time as there will likely be a line formed! We arrived at 4:45 but missed the first round of seats and ended up waiting about 45-50 min to be seated, which isn't too outrageous. Fortunately the food comes out very quickly.

I had the spicy tori paitan + soft shoyu egg. This bowl of ramen was very unique, unlike any kind of ramen I've ever had. SUPER creamy & rich broth. While the dish was definitely tasty, the thick consistency of the broth made it difficult to finish. I think it was too rich for me. The flavor is great  and the noodles are very good though, don't get me wrong! We also ordered a side of the enoki chips, which were such a yummy and fun twist to tempura. 

Our server was very nice and the workers were all quick to refill our waters. I'm not sure this place is worth waiting over an hour for but if you beat the line, I recommend trying it at least once.

[79/100]
author: Emily K.

description:
Rarely do I rave about places but this one is worthy of all the rave and more!

I've been going to this place for months and the thing that blows me away is how consistently good the experience has been. The menu has few items but each of them are distinctly delicious and they have something catering to nearly all dietary preferences(vegan, vegetarian, no pork etc) without compromising on the quality of the experience.
author: Nitin K.

description:
Ramen it up.

People, the seasons have turned. We've said goodbye to our Indian summer in SF, so that means, pull out the chunky sweaters and scarves and head over to Mensho Tokyo in the 'Loin to warm up your soul with some incredibly rich ramen.

This is the first Japanese outpost outside of Tokyo and I loved that the owners chose SF. (why should NYC get all the cool places all the time?!) Years ago, I used to whine to my friends that I'll have to drive to San Mateo to get some fantastic ramen. But, now that we actually have choices, I can happily stay in SF and my friends don't have to hear my whining. 

First: YES. There is always a line. Come right when they open at 5pm or maybe closer to 11:30pm (but what if the soup runs out?) chances are, your wait will be less than an hour. There were 3 of us who waited around 530pm and got sat down in 20 mins. 

Second: it's all communal seating. Most are high tops where you will uncomfortably balance yourself. So, leave the kids with a babysitter and don't bring big groups. You will rub elbows with your neighbors. You won't have much space for your said purse/jacket/scarves, but there are baskets on the floor where you can store them, just like in Tokyo!

Third: get the Tori Paitan. Everyone talks about it, right? it's their signature bowl. At $16, you get rich and creamy chicken soup, pork chashu, duck chashu, menma, Kale, Burdock and katsuobushi sauce. I love duck and I love that they give you duck here. Double up and pay the extra $2 for another slice of MMMeat. If you got vegan friends, say hello to their Vegan Tantanmen with made several types of mushrooms, nuts, chili oil, etc. in premium Japanese soy cream. You won't miss the real thing. Trust. 

Fourth: the broth is like GRAVY. Is that groovy? if you think so (I think so!) then you'll love this place. If you prefer a lighter, cleaner taste, you won't like Mensho and you'll be pissed that you waited an hour in line for this sh*t. 

Fifth: just like in Tokyo, eat your ramen, don't linger and leave. People got things to see and places to go. Rye is next door and they make killer basil gimlets. You're welcome!
author: Janice C.

description:
Not worth the hype nor the wait. I don't really understand the appeal.

The broth tastes like pure fat. It's overly thick to the point that it looks and tastes gross to me. Just think of your noodles dipped in gravy. 

Price wise and wait wise, it just doesn't make any sense why this place is popular. There is very limited seating, long wait, and slow service. Not a single redeeming quality for me. You're better yet going to Nojo ramen or Ramen Yamadaya.
author: Alicia L.

description:
I've never waited 2 hours in line for ramen but as soon as I had that first sip, it made the wait completely worth it. I wanted to run out after and scream "IT'S WORTH IT" to everyone still waiting in line because it really was worth every painstaking minute of waiting. 

I arrived around 4:45 pm on a freezing Sunday evening while wearing a short dress and sandals. There were already 50 people in line and I did not anticipate waiting 2 hours but I was hungry and determined to try this place. I've suffered far greater lengths for food so it wasn't the worst wait of my life. 
 
I ordered the the vegan tantanmen and it was the best bowl of ramen I've ever had, hands down. Unreal. My friend ordered the matcha ramen and it tasted like a matcha latte! The noodles were super thick and the broth, which was full of flavor, clinged to the noodles so well. I couldn't believe it was vegan! Aaa I can't wait to come back.

100000/10 best ramen would ramen again.
author: Nikki I.

description:
Mensho's always a good time! Most recently, I came because I had heard about their new matcha tori paitan ramen and wanted to give that a shot.

I came right before they opened, around 4:45 on Wednesday, and there was only a handful of people in line. To be fair, it was a hot day--maybe 80 degrees--and only the most dedicated Mensho fans would even attempt ramen in that weather. The heat was definitely a barrier to enjoying the ramen; let's just say that I've been to Mensho many times but the lack of AC has never bothered me until this meal...

But was the matcha tori paitan worth it? YES it was! At $17 a bowl, it definitely doesn't come cheap, but I appreciated the subtle addition of the matcha to the already fabulous tori paitan ramen. Both my friend and I thought that the matcha flavor was very subtle and you had to stop and think about the flavors in your mouth to really taste it. Other than that, everything else about this dish is the same. The soup is still deliciously rich and creamy, the noodles thick and satisfying to chew, and the duck and pork chashu slices were perfectly tender. 

Also, I want to call out that they offer soft boiled eggs now! Unfortunately it's not included in the base ramen, so you have to fork out another $1.80 to add it, but it is completely worth it. I'm just really grateful that they've started offering it here, since for the longest time they didn't. I've had a lot of good ramen eggs before, but even then I think the one at Mensho is one of my favorites. It comes as a whole egg instead of sliced in half, and when you bite into it, you can see the perfectly partially cooked egg yolk inside. Plus it's marinated perfectly and that first bite of the marinated egg white and half cooked york is really memorable.

My friend and I also shared the poke soba ($18) as we were intrigued by the 10 bowl limit per day, but I would recommend skipping this. Because it was called poke soba, I thought all the proteins in the dish would be seafood, but for some reason there was also chashu in there. It ended up being a weird combination of warm and cold ingredients (the soba was also warm). Also we underestimated how full we'd be from the ramen. By the time we both finished with our tori paitan and were ready to start on the poke soba, we were already feeling pretty stuffed...

Another friend ordered the vegan tantanmen as he is vegetarian, and he was blown away by how delicious and flavorful the ramen is. I tried a sip and would highly recommend this even for non-vegetarians!

I know $17 for a bowl of ramen is really pricy, but I always end up coming back to Mensho time and time again for ramen. Definitely my fav spot in the bay area!
author: Dianna H.

description: Quality ramen that's quite tasty. Absolutely worth repeat visits but not sure if it's "that" good to wait nor do I understand the hype though.
author: Yen C.

description: Some of the best ramen I've had. Small venue that can have quite a long line, so get here really early (opens at 5pm). Limited menu but everything looked amazing. Went with Spicy Tori Paitan ramen with egg. It was spectacular...the broth was insane. $19 + $1 egg so $20 bowl of ramen, but it was definitely worth it. 15% service fee included. Communal seating. Highly recommended.
author: Matthew M.

description:
Ya know the feeling of seeing your ex and wonder what was it that makes you go gaga for him/her in the first place?
I had that feeling when I came back to try Mensho again...
We were bringing an out of state guests, preparing to blow their ramen sense with a sip of rich umami from Mensho broth. 
Instead, it was our sense that got baffled. This was not the Mensho we remember. What used to be silky rich paitan was replaced by rough bubbly (yes, bubbly!) broth. It's still okay if it has that deep umami flavor. Umm, nope! It just taste rough and shallow now! There was no love in that broth of ramen there!
I noticed the chefs in the kitchen were different. Perhaps that's why?
As far as I'm concerned, this is no longer Mensho. Please bring the old Mensho back..
author: Jenny T.

description:
Been excited to try this place ever since I first saw that it came from Tokyo. 

That being said... here theres really only one soup base that they are popular for which is made from chicken (the tori patan). It is extremely rich and creamy, but I personally enjoy lighter soil bases. With that said, you can order it regular, spicy or with matcha. I personally thought the ramen was a bit salty for my liking as well, however the matcha one wasn't as salty and had more of a nutty flavor. The noodles itself were awesome as they are a thicker, chewier type of noodle.

Downside is that it's a small place so expect to wait. It's also a bit pricey... but so is most of the food in SF. 

Overall, tasty but not sure if I'd go back as I personally don't prefer this type of ramen.
author: Ashley W.

description:
Yes i waited in line.

Yes it took about 30 min on a thursday around 8pm.

Yes we were buzzed before we came in.

Ordered the tori with an egg. Soup was thick and flavorful! Ramen noodles thick as well. Although, eggs should be included in the bowl already......

My bf ordered the spicy lamb. It was super spicy. The broth was more thick than the tori. It was much too salty. Id say the need to cut the salt by a quarter, at least.

Tried the enoki chips. Salty. But an interesting way to turn a .50 cent mushroom you can get at an asian grocery. Definitely going to try at home. A couple next to us gave us theirs, they didnt like it much.

Overall, a pretty okay place. I may come back one time with my cousin, she loves ramen. But i cant justify paying a mandatory 18% service fee when i didnt feel like i was getting much service. Id rather go back to marufuku.
author: Lynn C.

description:
I've passed Mensho a dozen times. But I could never imagine waiting in line for what always looked like hours. I was given the best tip, just go early and get in line before they open. Sure enough, I got in line at 4:30. I waited till 5, opening and I was the first in group in. 

The restaurant is small but welcoming. Styled as long wooden shared tables.

Started off with some enoki mushroom chips which were soft but crispy. I choose the tori ramen. I immediately tasted the broth and I just lost it. It was the most delicious I've ever had. Followed by the noodles, reminded of almost a carbonara style.

There's also an automatic 15% gratuity added. It's reasonable and consistent.  

Hands down best ramen spot in SF. Truly worth the experience.
author: Nick F.

description: The ramen is good and when I have the patience to wait in line for an hour to get in, I'll be back. Otherwise, I'm happy with other options like Orenchi and Ramen Dojo.
author: Chi N.

description: Since most of the broth have fish in it(I am allergic), I was limited to a vegan ramen. It's so nutty, intense, very good. Chashu pork is absolutely delicious, melts in your mouth, has a smoky flavor.
author: Natasha R.

description:
Our first ramen joint in San Francisco! We hardcore lucked out on the wait. We arrived around 8pm on a Wednesday night and only had to wait 10 minutes or so. The couple ahead of us told us the average wait time was 40 to an hour, and the reviews and the restaurant itself can confirm that. Like damn, we buyin' the lotto TONIGHT!

But anyways, I've read around that this was supposedly the best in town and I can see why both visitors and local think that. I ordered their famous Tori Paitan and the boyfriend ordered the vegan tantanmen. The Tori Paitan was filled with an incredibly savory chicken-based broth. Your first bite will immediately hit you with a ton of harmonious flavors. Lots of umami going on here. Lots of toppings. Certainly a good bowl of ramen so I thought we were off to a good start. While delicious, have to be honest and admit we were underwhelmed. The broth was too creamy, too thick for my taste. And I know it's weird to complain about spoons but quite honestly, their spoon was excessively large and made the eating experience a little difficult. Imagine trying to eat soup but with a flat giant wooden paddle. I'm sure it was more so for a *wow/cool* factor. Minor detail though. I also wasn't feeling' the noodles either. It made everything feel so thick. However, I did think that both the pork and duck chashu were juicy, tender and generous in portion. Granted I ordered the double chashu, but hey, they delivered. The soft egg was perfect. And if you're fiending for savory, this will do the trick. As a broth fanatic, I had to try a few bites of the vegan one and tbh - it was bomb af. Nice spicy kick to it. I would actually recommend that over the Paitan, or if anything, perhaps the Spicy Tori Paitan would've been the better route.
author: Nikki M.

description: Excellent ramen. Had the Spicy Tori. Such a rich, layered, almost creamy broth. The fried enoki are also very nice. Communal seating may be a turn off to some diners. They should have someone rethink their seating plan, as the counter facing the kitchen where I was re-seated to accommodate a larger party (from the main communal table) is cramped and confined. Gratuity is included.
author: Ant C.

description:
My first meal in SF..... and it was worth the wait. This place makes ramen like no place I've been to before.  The broth is creamy and the noodles are just perfect.  The texture and wavy-ness of it was just superb. The tori paitan ramen is a definite must try. The broth is rich in flavor and the chasu melts in your mouth.  The spicy lamb ramen is also great.  The ground lamb with the spice... gives it a great kick. 

The place is pretty small... be prepared to wait 30-45 minutes.  It seems like there is always a line out front.  The place seats just under 30 ppl. The wait staff is super friendly and efficient with the orders. Definitely a must try place!
author: Charlie T.

description: Truly exquisite ramen. Layered flavors, delicious noodles, and many choices. I got the tori paitan flavor and my friend got the vegan and we were both impressed. I wanted to eat a second one. They're open late, their staff was friendly, and it had a warm, communal feel. Will definitely be back.
author: Colleen S.

description:
To eat at Mensho, you'll have to put in some effort and brave the elements in the Tenderloin while waiting in a long queue. As one of the most hyped ramen places in SF, Mensho serves traditional Tokyo style ramen with some modern twists. What sets Mensho apart from other places is the richness of its broth/flavor. The broth is extremely thick, hence the strong flavors. Personally I thought the ramen was solid, but not worth an hour and a half wait/high prices (20$).

Mensho can only fit about 20 people. Things move relatively fast because it's a ramen place, but there will usually be a long queue. Usual waiting times are in the hours.

I ordered:
Enoki Mushroom Chips - I enjoyed these chips. While deep fried and crispy, still has a bit of chewy and that subtle enoki flavor.
Tori Paitan Ramen (Double Chashu) - comes with pork and duck chashu as well as your run-of-the-mill toppings. Good thick broth, almost too rich for me. The duck chashu was the best, extremely flavorful and tender!
author: Sean W.

description:
So. Fucking. Pretentious. 

I'm sorry but waiting in line for an hour and a half for a 20$ bowl of ramen is where I draw the line. 

Yeah, they have Santori. Yeah, they have high quality dashi. Yeah, the noodles are good.

However, now that the field is opening up a bit I really don't see a purpose in going to this place anymore. I can get into plenty of other places faster and easier, pay less, and the broth is better.

They need to figure out a way to serve more customers faster, because as it stands, San Francisco's hipster population has ruined yet another simplistic small restaurant that would be ok if the price was lower, and they offered more seating.
author: John W.

description:
2.5 stars rounded up.

Wait time: 1 hour, starting at 5:15pm (they open at 5:00pm). Line moves VERY slowly.
Ramen: Not good, but the presentation was nice.
Atmosphere: Very rushed and cramped (the place is small, seats around 20 people at a time?)

I get it, but I don't get it. Mensho serves "artisanal" ramen, and I really wanted to like this place since it was recommended to us by our friends. We came as a party of 4, and one of our friends graciously waited in line for an entire hour. The tables are communal, and the servers very much expect you to know what you want to order the moment you sit down (they came by 3x before we finally ordered).

The lowdown:
I ordered the Spicy lamb ramen ($16) and my boyfriend got the Tori Paitan Ramen (Double Chashu) ($18.5). In short, my ramen was barely edible - the thick broth was so, SO SALTY (like the ocean)! I literally couldn't drink the soup (boyfriend can attest). The noodles were also a bit hard, but our friend who ordered the same thing said his was good (?!) so I just suffered silently and finished the noodles. The broth of the Tori Paitan ramen was a bit better - not as salty or thick - but the noodles were also a bit hard. My friend knew one of the servers, so they generously gave us free (soy saucey) oysters as an appetizer. My god, it was also incredibly salty! What is going on here?! I used to tell myself that if certain dishes weren't good, it's because I "ordered the wrong thing", but honestly, EVERY item on the menu should be good because restaurants have one chance to make a first impression - especially if you're highly rated like Mensho. Lastly, the bill came before we were even done and once we signed, the waitress stared us down until we left. 

Needless to say, I will not be coming back to Mensho.
author: Angela C.

description:
We came here on a Saturday night and I would advise to arrive at least 30 minutes before opening if you want a seat when they first open. Their menu is super extensive. We came on the night where they first introduced the Lobster ramen (only 10 per night!). It was good, but I prefer the Matcha Paitan Ramen. It was not as gimmicky as I thought it would be and the flavor was rich and delicious. We also got the poke bowl which I would skip, but the enoki mushroom chips were delicious!

I will come back, but not for a while because the wait is a bit too much for me. It is very worth the first try though!
author: Michael T.

description:
An excellent dinner for a straightforward bold flavored Ramen experience. 
The long wait is worth the bowl of super rich broth with great al dente ramen. 
Menu is short, as it should be, as sign of great care and excellence.
author: Bruno S.

description: I was so very impressed by Mensho Tokyo and Vegan Tantanmen that the first thing I decided to do after ravaging my bowl was open up this site and spread the word about its importance. I am impressed that they were able to craft up such a delicious meal thats consumable by both vegan and nonvegan people
author: Ricky M.

description:
Do NOT get the wagyu....... if you avoid the wagyu its probably probably pretty good. The Wagyu was tough and thus extremely overpriced.

Regardless, Ramen Nagi in Palo Alto is 10 times better.
author: J D.

description:
Absolutely LOVED this Japanese restaurant. If you aren't a fan of community tables, cozy small restaurants, or if you require back support while seating this is not the place for you. They do not support boxing up items ifyou do not finish your meal also, 15% is added for tips (regardless of party size)

Now as far as the waitstaff: they seat you to a cleaned, cleared table. Promptly provide menus and bring drinks in record time to take your order. It's a constant round robin between your party and others so do not get flustered by the constant movement. They are professional, prompt and attentive (in a quickened manner)

This is NOT your typical ramen !! It's traditional from a different prefecture of japan characterized by thicker noodles, a heartier broth. I was able to taste these fried mushrooms on the appetizer and they literally tasted like Lays Original Potato chips (important because i LOVE those chips). Wait time was not too bad, food was absolutely delicious (spicy noodles were amazing as was my friend's matchta broth noodles) 

Slurp up !!
author: Brittanie W.

description:
Every time I attempt to branch out and try a new ramen place I end up being disappointed. Why is that? Because Mensho Tokyo's ramen really is that good! 

There's so much attention to detail with every bite that I appreciate. You can tell that the chefs have carefully thought through every ingredient and then some. There is variety to be had here. If you are feeling like a hearty and thick soup is what you need, go for the tori paitan. If you're needing a lighter option, the shoyo ramen is great as well. All have unique flavors to them! 

It can be very loud inside the small space. I come here most often with just my fiancé, party of two, and it is almost impossible for us to have a conversation when we get seated across from each other and in between parties. 

Yes, this ramen shop is on Geary Street, but it really isn't in the heart of the tenderloin like others suggest. Sometimes there are homeless people asking for money but I have never had any issues or felt unsafe. 

Definitely come here, definitely try the ramen, it is delicious!
author: Stephanie E.

description:
Mensho Toyko's ramen is a definite must-try, without a doubt the best ramen you can get in San Francisco for the money. I cannot praise the ramen here enough, it has to be one of the best ramen I've had in the U.S.

Expect to pay around $20 - $25 per person. The price is quite amazing considering what you get. The creamy broth means that not only are you getting a delicious meal, you are also definitely leaving the restaurant with a full stomach.

The location is alright, quite easy to get to even on foot, in a sketchier part of the city but since there are so many people around, you should be fine. 

The service was very quick and efficient, they've exceeded my expectation for such a busy restaurant.

The wait on the other hand kills me. You can expect to wait anywhere from 30 minutes to 1+ hour in line, and while the ramen is good enough that I have stuck through the wait multiple times, I doubt it is an experience many want to have and it has definitely turned me away from the restaurants on some nights.
