TL;DR I recommend giving Mensho a try at least once, it is a unique experience, you won't regret it. It changed my expectation for what is good ramen and I'll definitely be coming back for more. That being said, I don't see myself becoming a regular anytime soon, the long wait means there won't be any spontaneous visits and I'll have to think twice before putting any of my friends through the experience.
author: Anh N.

description:
I know the wait here is a bit ridiculous, but in my opinion totally worth it!

I have tried to get dinner at Mensho Tokyo several times, but have not been successful until my most recent visit. The line is CRAZY. I think the only reason I made it this time was because I arrived at 5pm on a weekday, albeit still had to wait for an hour. How you would get in during normal dinner hours on a weekend I have no idea.

The menu here is pretty simple, but every single item is intriguing. I ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen and that did not disappoint! The broth here is a lot creamier than other ramen shops I have been. This is exactly to my liking, though has put off some of my friends. The girl sitting next to me ordered Matcha Tori Paitan Ramen, which is kind of a strange idea when you first hear it but the final product looks amazing! I would definitely try that if I manage to get myself back in here again :P
author: Angel C.

description:
This place essentially lives up to the hype. Walked past this area in the Tenderloin and there was a line at the door before it opened. If there is a line in must be good!

After reading the reviews online we made it our mission to try this place. Arrived early at 4:30pm to do the early bird dinner so we can the first group to eat. Drawbacks is if you come a little bit later expect to wait some more due to the restaurant being teeny tiny with communal seating

As for the ramen it was stellar. I chose to get the spicy Lamb ramen with the soy hard boiled egg. The broth was the creamiest/richest broth I've had. Definitely filling.  The noodles are the perfect texture of thickness and chewiness.  Each ramen dish also has different noodle type to compliment the individual dish.  Prices seem standard for San Francisco.  Would come if I stop by the bay area again
author: Kay T.

description:
If I'm comparing ramen places, I think it goes Ippudo then Mensho, then everywhere else... I loved the ramen here, definitely quality ramen... noodles were cooked to perfect chewiness and had great texture... the broth was great tasting although I have to admit, it was thicker than I am used to. 

We got the Tori Paitan and the Matcha. Both were excellent... The matcha was surprisingly flavorful... gotta admit tho that the matcha taste kinda wore me out after a while. The duck chasu on the Tori was a great addition... 

The only real downside is the wait and the small space...
author: Jonas E.

description:
Phenomenal, spectacular, I cannot even begin to describe how delicious the food here was. We waited 20 minutes on a Wednesday evening to get seated. The inside was quite small, the table was shared with two other parties. Now you can either make the most of it or not. 

However, it was totally completely worth it. We had the Mushroom chips and the Vegan Tantanmen. Let me tell you, I HATE mushrooms but these crisp chips got me. If you have ever ate Indian Pakore, they taste just like it, but healthier with lemon and seasoning! The Vegan Tantanmen was ever better! It was the best ramen I have ever had! Do yourself a favor and go try this place, you WILL NOT regret it!
author: Karan L.

description:
Worst ramen ive ever had in my life. And ive had a lot (including in Japan and Los Angeles). 

Noodles were only thing halfway decent. But only the springy, chewy texture. Color was gross brown since by arrival they already soaked up gross brown broth color. (Noodles should have just-thrown-in golden yellow color).

Broth? Horrible. Too thick, oily, and rich, tasted like a sauce or dip for thai chicken satay. Not for drinking like a soup (like a proper ramen broth should be) 

Meat? Horrible too. Pork chashu was overcooked and fell apart immediately into a mashed up gross mess, impossible to eat with chopsticks. They put "duck chashu" also in the "double chashu." (Maybe to be cool and hipster). Sorry, just doesnt work. Try getting one chashu right before throwing in another.

Veggies? Horrible #3. No seaweed. Kale! Nothing japanese about that! 

Temperature? Yea, it was NOT hot. Enough said. 

Other issues (which i was nice enough to not LEAD with in this review...out of pity i suppose): 
1 hour wait on a Sunday night at 8:30. Goes without saying def not worth it. 

10 min into waiting for our order we were told they RAN OUT of eggs. At a RAMEN place... 

2 parties after us got their food before ours. A bit irritating since our order was nothing special (apart from a request for eggs...which they were not providing anyway) 

"Double Chashu" ramen (their take on Tonkotsu ramen i guess) was $18.50. Wayy too expensive, even for SF, long line or not, Michelin or not.

They forcibly took 15% tip in the bill. We were 2 people. This should be illegal. Especially if they did nothing to deserve that extra 15%. 

In summary, perfect example of how a long line Michelin recommended big city restaurant can still be absolutely horrible. 

Next time you drive by this place, see the line, and tell yourself I should at least try that place once....do yourself a favor...just don't.
author: George T.

description: Tasty ramen, make sure to get here early to avoid a wait. I was able to get in line at ~4:40 on a Wednesday and was seated immediately as they opened at 5pm. I ordered the Tori Paitan which was great but the real surprise was adding a soft-boiled egg which was sweet and cooked perfectly.
author: Brandon L.

description:
edit: Not sure if this was intentional but they serve one of the cheapest  beers you can find in Japan (Suntory Premium Malts) at a premium price ($9). This is akin to opening an burger stand overseas and selling Budweiser as your only option.

The wait wasn't too terrible here. It was about a half hour to get seated for a group of three around 6pm on. Thursday.

The ramen here isn't anything special. It's good but not great. At the price point they're asking ($16-$18 a Bowl) you're not getting your money's worth. I had the Tori Paitan which is a heavier broth based ramen.

I would have given them 3 and am choosing to go down over their silly "gratuity-free" policy. They state they are a gratuity-free establishment but charge a mandatory 15% service charge. How does that make sense? I would be fine if they just charged a service charge and left out the gratuity-free part. Also, the service here is lacking. It's an environment where the waiters know they get paid regardless of the service they provide.
author: Danny N.

description:
The line is crazy and it's a tad higher than most ramen places in price but the quality is far better.

I've never had ramen in Japan to compare it to that.  I can't judge authenticity.

However, what went in my mouth was delicious.  It's was really heavy and like no ramen I've had before.  So much flavor.  Very rich.  Super satisfying.  I crave it sometimes but that line is horrible if you don't time it right so I've yet to go back.
author: Phillip N.

description:
Don't understand the hype, and this was the worst ramen I've ever had! 

I came here on a weekday night, there was a line but it wasn't crazy long. I ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen with the double cha siu. The noodles were good, the meat was melt in your mouth fall apart, and all the other toppings went nicely with the ramen, but my biggest issue was the broth. For me, the broth is the most important part of the ramen, and here I felt like the broth was overly rich, to the point it tasted like I was drinking chicken fat. I've had broths at other ramen places that had thick and rich broths but it never felt like I was just ingesting fat. 

Def would not come here again.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
This place is solid. I finally found ramen in the city that was not too salty! The downside of eating here is definitely the wait. We came the Wednesday before Thanksgiving, hoping most people would have left for the holidays, only to find out that its a prime ramen day... There is no sign-in clip board or anything - everyone has to wait in line. It took us roughly an hour to get to the front after starting to line up at 6pm. Luckily for us it was not too cold outside so the wait was bearable. Not sure I would wait a couple hours for this one bowl of ramen, but I have always wanted to try this place at least once.

The ramen was perfectly flavored - we ordered both the tori paitan and spicy tori paitan. The broth was very rich and filling, but not greasy to the point I didn't want to finish the broth. We also ordered shitake mushroom chips which were an interesting add to the mix. Everything meshed together - the chewy noodles, tasty broth, and fresh veggies. I wish it came with an egg though... 

Overall, ramen was bomb. Atmosphere was fun but seating/waiting in line were uncomfortable. I would come again only if I can find a way to not wait an hour for this ramen. They do not do take outs either.
author: Connie L.

description:
Long lines ALL the time. There was a line when we got there at 9 pm and there was line there when we left around 11 pm. So, is it worth the hype and wait?! Yes, it's worth at least trying once. No, I probably wouldn't come back to stand in line unless I'm ok with the potential 1.5+ hour wait. It definitely seemed like other people didn't mind the wait since the line was always consistently long. Mensho is pretty small with 2 rows of communal tables for seating. 

By the time we were ordering a little after 10pm, they had already run out of their soft boiled eggs (both miso and soy). Come early if you want to try their eggs! The add ons seemed to be a little pricy like an extra $2 for fried garlic or green onions. If you want additional toppings, your bowl of ramen can easily be $20+. 

The Tori Paitan ramen ($16.50) has a rich and creamy chicken soup base. The broth was much thicker than your average tonkotsu broth - almost like a curry consistency. The duck chashu was glorious - so tender and flavorful! It was a little weird to have kale in my ramen, but hey it's SF, so why not. It was strange that they give you such a huge spoon for your soup. It was as big as a serving spoon or rice scooper. The Organic Shoyu ramen ($14) was packed with flavor too. If you're looking for something tasty, but less heavy, this is the ramen for you. The noodles were thinner than the Tori Paitan ramen which went well with the lighter broth.

They don't have to go boxes and you can't order to go, so make sure to slurp up all your delicious ramen before you leave!
author: Susan D.

description:
How a small cozy place is taking people lining up to eat & wait in the line for about an hour or so is a mystery I got to solve recently!
Secret is Damn good  food! Absolutely amazing Vegan Tantanmen Ramen, in fact is the best seller!
Shared the bowl by two & was so full! Well complimented by Sapporo beer pint! 
Worth the hype, worth the wait & absolutely worth for having the best Ramen while in SF!  
Just like wow!
author: Tanmay G.

description:
I was craving for ramen this week and instead of going to my usual spot, I decided to try Mensho. My boyfriend insisted we go since he's been here before, and he said Mensho's ramen is much like the ones he had in Japan. In other words, authentic. We went on a Friday night at about 9:30 pm and there was a line outside. It was about a 30 minute wait, which I didn't mind. Plus, if it's Michelin-starred, it definitely has to be worth the wait. They also have some of their ingredients imported straight from Japan. The place is very small but its interior resembles an actual ramen shop from Japan. Seating is limited so it might not be good for groups or families. However, if you still choose to come in a large group, you most likely won't be seated all at once and eat at the same time. One thing to note is that in Japan, tipping isn't required and sometimes refused. Mensho doesn't take tips either so don't be offended if they don't accept yours! 
My boyfriend and I both ordered the spicy tori paitan ramen. I can truly say that it's the best and closest to authentic ramen I've had. The broth was thick and rich in flavor, which is exactly how ramen should be. The noodles were thicker than usual and much more chewy but I enjoyed it. The meat was tender and it was easier to pull apart in portions. Overall, the ramen was delicious and for sure worth the wait AND hype.
If you're looking to try ramen that is truly reminiscent of Japan, pay Mensho a visit. Your tastebuds will thank you.
author: Patricia B.

description:
This would probably be four stars purely for food, but the wait and service are definitely part of the experience. 

First, the food. The oyster appetizer was generous but over salted and over marinated - my friend and I could not finish it. The people next to us got the fried mushrooms and seemed to enjoy it a lot more. I ordered the spicy tori ramen, which was not spicy at all, even with the amount of chili flakes in there. The broth was very rich and clung to the noodles. The ramen itself was also very good; the dish overall was just a little too rich for me and a little pricey considering the toppings.

For us, the wait time was a little more than an hour, which was not too bad. However, our server was pretty bad - I understand that they're trying to hustle people in and out but having to ask three times for water in such a small restaurant space was kind of frustrating.

Probably will not be back, unless there's much less of a wait.
author: Hannah H.

description:
I really wanted to like this place, but sadly it was just all right.

My cousins and I got there around 6:30pm, and the line was already quite long. There were about 20-25 people ahead of us. We decided to wait since we all wanted to try it together for the first time. 

The place is quite small. 1 long communal table that seats about 18 people and 2 smaller ones that seat 7-8 people. 

The servers were very nice and knowledgeable. They worked very fast, so the wait was not as bad as I assumed it was going to be. I figured we would have to wait over an hour, but it was about 30-40 minutes. 

I usually already know what to order when I go eat, but I really had NO IDEA what I wanted because nothing stood out to me. I also had really high expectations because it was Michelin recommended!

We ordered:
Enoki Mushroom Chips- Good. I'm not even a fan of enoki, but I liked this appetizer. It was perfectly fried and salted. 

Organic shoyu- Probably the best of the 3 that we ordered. It was a clear broth, so easier to eat. It reminded me more of an udon broth. It just made me want udon and tempura. I did like this the best of the 3.

Spicy Tori Paitan- VERY RICH AND CREAMY! It was not spicy either. I ordered the habanero for $2 (not worth it), and it was still not spicy. I did not feel like I was eating ramen. I felt like I was eating pasta. The flavor was not bad, but after eating a few bites the creaminess became too much. I would definitely not be able to eat a whole bowl of this to myself. We couldn't even finish it!

Spicy Lamb- Also very rich and creamy. I felt that this was even thicker than the spicy tori. This was my least favorite of the 3, but then again it can be that I am not a lamb person. When I asked for their opinion, they also said they preferred the other 2 more.

Sad to say, but this place is not my cup of tea (or shall I say bowl of ramen?). I've already heard from other friends that it's over priced and that it's not great, but me being me I had to find out for myself. Unfortunately, I agree with them. At least I can say it from first hand experience and not just hearsay. Mensho is a no go for me.
author: Lily T.

description:
After coming here twice, I can say that this is a solid ramen joint. The first time I came was during primetime dinner on a Saturday evening - the wait time was roughly an hour and a half. The second time I came during the weekday right around opening time and there was no wait time. The place sits just a little over 20 seats and is communal tables so you get real close to your neighbors, but it's typical for a traditional ramen store so get use to shrinking your personal bubble.

I ordered their famous Tori paitan ramen with an added ajitama (seasoned egg), and as all the reviews say, the broth for this ramen is extremely hearty. It's not your typical smooth broth, but nonetheless I really enjoyed the depth of flavor. The meat pieces were very generous, it came with two cuts of duck chasu and two of pork chasu, and both were not majority fat, and if you're like me and don't like to eat the fatty parts of meat then this is a big plus! The ajitama was excellent - perfectly soft-boiled and great flavoring. One of the best I've had. The kale and cabbage toppings we're a bit questionable and felt a bit off from the rest of the dish, but it didn't bother me too much. 

Being a Michelin recommended restaurant, it's no surprise that the price reflects the accolade. After tax and tip (which they already include in the bill) it comes out around $22. So is this a place I'd come to on the daily? Definitely not. It's one of those special occasions or treat yoself places. I'd recommend going on a weekday if you can to avoid the long lines
author: Lisa T.

description:
Wow, wow, wow!! 

I had the best ramen I ever eaten here. The ramen is bouncy and chewy and the broth is deliciously creamy and frothy. Spicy here is not very spicy, but shichimi (japanese spicy seasoning) is available on the table.

The place is very small and the line get VERY long (my wait was about and 45min)... so don't come on an empty stomach. Unfortunately, if there isn't a table available for your party size (usually when the party is 3) they will seat the pair behind you first, which kinda sucks, especially when you already waited so and and are sooo close. The ramen is well worth the wait though!
author: Jennifer C.

description:
When I saw all my veggie Yelpies out there recommending this place I had to bite the bullet and give it a try.  I thought I would be saved from the crowds and lines as I arrived at the 9 pm hour on a weeknight but oh was I wrong.  The lines was about 10 deep and when I peeked in the window and saw all these relaxed patrons talking and chatting I knew my stomach was going to have to be patient.  Good news is the people in line were super friendly and made the time go by but it's still something to contend with.  The fact is the place is tiny and even when they make you share tables it's still is going to be slow.  I also noticed that the staff was slow to turn over the table once a party left.  They could do better but there is only like 3 staff having to handle everything so it's kind of expected.

While you wait in line you can look over the menu and so when you get a spot you pretty much can order right away.  In my case it's pretty easy as they serve one vegan ramen and that's why I'm there.  

So first off plan to spend a dime to get a basic ramen.  You are going to be out $20 without even making an additions.  They do provide extras also but they are pretty pricey at $2 a piece.  I decided to do a couple add-on's crushed habaenros and burdock since I've never seen that as an option before.

Once you get to your table they are quick to take your order which was nice after the long waiting.  Food came out 15 minutes later and I will say it's a beautiful looking bowl of ramen.  It looks very different than what you typically see at other places.  It's very creamy and white due to the fact that they use lots of nuts in making the broth.  They also drizzle chili
oil on top so it looks stunning.

Taste it's very flavorful and rich.  I wish there was more veggies in the bowl since you are getting no meat but having added the burdock was a plus.  If you get the habaneros just remember those suckers are hot.  I'm a hot head and I could not even use up half of the bowl so I handed it out to others who were no all that appreciative of the jester:)

Overall it's a fun place to try and I would say it's a good bowl of ramen but it is a little richer in taste than I am used to.  I wanted to actually take some home but they provide no to go options here.  I'm happy a finally got to see what all the hype is about and I was glad to be able to try out this unique bowl of vegan goodness.
author: Ron K.

description:
Not the best ramen spot, but good enough to visit at least once!  They do not accept reservations, so I would advise you to come early if you can.  

Shio Chashu Ramen with egg - underwhelming, clear broth was lacking flavor.  

Tori Paitan Ramen with egg - creamy and rich broth.  This bowl was full of flavors, my husband and I favored this one a hundred times more!  Noodles are served a little thicker than the previous bowl which complemented the soup just nicely.  Definitely something I would order again.

A few things to note, automatic 15% added to your bill for gratuity and they do not offer take out containers for you.  Their portion sizes are quite generous so if you know you wont be able to finish your bowl, you are allowed to bring your own.  Overall, delicious ramen but not delicious enough to wait 90 min in the cold delicious.  Would return again on the rare occasion that there isn't a line out the door.
author: Jann B.

description: Wish I could give more stars. With the line out the door I really had my hopes high. Sat down, place looks fine, sat next to some random people (space is very limited) but I dont mind that. The ramen came out and looked great. Right off the bat, the egg was not cut in half which was a little awkward to try and eat. The broth was a bit thick, still good. Not as spicy as I had hoped (I like my nose to run a little lol). The noodles threw me off. They were quite thick for ramen. Its not bad food, its just not the best and not worth the wait. But it was edible and I still left full. The service was really good.
author: Jay B.

description:
One of my favorite ramen places in the city ! 

Be ready for a LONG wait because the place is pretty small and always packed. Communal tables - sits around 25 people or so. Do not recommend large groups - anything over 4 people !! Went on Saturday awhile back around 430pm and there was already a line forming before they were open. All these dedicated ramen fans. We were able to be part of the first wave to eat ! Woohoo! Made the cut !

Ordered:
Clam butter ramen with added duck chashu 

The Clam Butter Ramen comes with clam, pork chashu, onions, and whipped butter. At first it sounded weird to me but decided to give it a try since they only sell 10 bowls a day!! Mix the whipped butter. The broth was very rich & creamy and flavorful ! The chewiness of the noodles was A+. The noodles are very fresh! OMG the duck chashu was fabulous ! It was so good! MUST ADD! Chasu very tender and delicious as well. 

Around $18 for a bowl of ramen. Kinda pricey but definitely must try! 

Definitely recommend this place. But I wouldn't wait an hour to eat. Try to get there EARLY! Have to be patient. While you are waiting browse through the menu so when you sit down you are ready to order. But if the menu will make you hungrier then maybe don't look at it. :p

Next I'll definitely try the Tori Paitan or the Spicy Lamb.
author: Karen L.

description:
Been here twice and had to wait over 45 minutes for a table each time but it's definitely worth the wait!

I ordered the Tori Paitan and it was one of the most different but best ramens I've ever had. The broth was thick and creamy and the noodles were cooked perfectly. Portion size left me full and satisfied. I also added one of their soft boiled eggs and it was delicious.

My boyfriend ordered Lamb Ramen and I was not really a fan. It had lots of flavors but it was a little gamey for me. I heard lots of other customers ordering the lamb so maybe it's just me!
author: Jane C.

description:
3.5/5...
DO come early! We got here 20 minutes past opening (5 pm) and the first wave of people just got seated before us. This means waiting at least 40 minutes until the second wave could get seated. 

This small ramen place has a hip, clean vibe to it, which probably adds to its attraction. It definitely is a place for a quick bite - once you are seated, they  ask if you are ready to order (assuming that you already decided while waiting in line, like most of us hangry people do).  

DO get the enoki chips! They are only chips in the sense that they are fried, but these babies are SO meaty! For $6, this dish is packin'.

I tried the shoyu ramen double chashu, and the broth was smooth and flavorful. The additions of kale were an interesting touch - perhaps to balance the meat (psychologically)? I wasn't thoroughly impressed though, given it was $16. I think it was the type of noodles, which didn't taste chewy enough like how I'm used to.

I'll have to come back here to re-evaluate the other options. Plus, I would pick a better day where I won't be waiting outside breathing in the smog/pollution, and inside where the shop closed its doors to prevent the pollution from coming in. I felt hot and bothered.
author: Vickie Z.

description:
Ramen is different, much thicker soup base than other places I have been. They also have vegetarian options which are not always true of ramen places. It's a tiny little shop off Geary that tends to be pretty packed. My co-workers and I waited a little under an hour for four on a Friday around 5pm.

I ordered the enoki mushroom fries and the standard ramen (double katsu!). Mushroom fries were delicious, thin and crispy . Ramen was flavroful, a little too creamy for me and the noodles are nice and tender. Two co-workers ordered the matcha ramen, which I tasted and looked more exotic than it actually tasted.

All in all a good meal, although small space and be prepared to wait.
author: Kevin Y.

description:
I had the spicy tori paitan ramen and the noodles were unlike any other ramen I've had before. It was in between a ramen and udon. The noodles were a little too al dente. 

The waitress was kind of rude when I was telling her my order. I told her I didn't want the cabbage, bamboo shoots or green onions. Her response was "okay so what do you want?". Uhm... not a side of 'tude.

Luckily I didn't have to wait because my friends and I arrived about half an hour before closing. Worst ramen experience of my life.
author: Sara J.

description:
Worth it if you're fine with waiting. I probably would not wait more than 10-20 minutes though. 

My boyfriend and I went on a Thursday evening around 9 30 and waited only ten minutes. Yay!

We both ordered the vegan tantanmen which had a great thick broth that also had a crunch to it. It didn't seem very Japanese, but I wasn't really expecting it to be. I was surprised that it didn't really have many vegetables, but it's not the end of the world. I would've added some if I had known though - and they give you this option (there's a list of add ins on the menu), so it's good to know for next time!

We ordered enoki mushrooms chips that were mehhhhh. I feel like they're so skinny that you can't really taste the mushroom, and you're just eating breading. 

If I could change anything, I'd want to turn the music down a bit. Don't get me wrong - they were playing slappers and all my fav rap music from the 2000s, but I literally could not hear my boyfriend - and most of the two person seats are facing each other because of the communal style. We ended up just not really talking because we didn't want to shout to have a conversation.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Unfortunately I did not think this place lived up to its hype and here's why:

The place is quite small so there's almost always a line out the door no matter when you come. (20-30min wait minimum) but perhaps lunch time would be better.

I was quite underwhelmed by the ramen. Noodles were a bit too soft/overcooked. Broth was too salty(and I like really heavy flavors). They definitely have a more modern take on the toppings, such as duck meat and kale. The duck meat was good but the portion was very small. Kale was good as well but I didn't think it particularly complimented the rest of the bowl. 

It wasn't a terrible bowl of ramen but it was definitely below my expectations and not worth the wait when there's better ramen spots in the city!
author: Mandy H.

description:
The A5 wagyu shoyu ramen was delicious (quickly eat the meat so that it does not start cooking). Not $39 delicious to be fair, but I would easily pay ~$25 to experience it again. The broth is clear and you can really taste the quality of the dashi base - the smokiness of the katsuobushi really stands out without being overwhelming. Great noodles.

Great minimalistic venue, always long lines - be prepared to wait outside in-line ~30 minutes on average.
author: Josh L.

description:
After an hour it was finally us! (And the line was still there when we left at 9...)
I got the matcha ramen with pork and duck meat - I really like their thick noodle. The soup base tastes very special and looks super attractive (for matcha lover)!! Duck meat is very special too, however I would say their soup base is kinda oily, and the noodle doesn't come with egg :( also they don't have dumplings/chicken wings (that my personal preference)

In addition it is not a good place for chatting since the music was super loud. 

This is a special place that I would go whenever my non-SF friend come visit, but I personally prefer other ramen places that with comfortable seats
author: Yuen Yung L.

description:
I am not one who usually likes different styles of ramen, heck I perfer for it to be traditionally made but Mensho Tokyo was really good. 
We came here after the Japanese Cherry Blossom festival in SF. It was around 5:30pm when we arrived and there was a decent size line outside the door. We waited about for 40 ish minutes on a Saturday to get seat with a table of 5. Note there is like 5 types of seating: Bar and 4 tables. So it make sense for the wait. 
The decor gives it such a modern feel. The decor is also educational of what makes a good ramen. Those 5 components are broth, tare (base), oil, noodles, and topping. I got the Tori Paitan Ramen with Extra charsu. The broth was a little bit more heavier than traditional ramens, I had but it was cream and flavorful. The noodles we're decent. My favorite topping was the duck charsu, if I can have all duck charsu. I would be sooooooo happy! So based on these categories, the ramen to me was a 4.5 out of 5. If you include the wait time. I would give this place a 4 out 5 stars. Worth the ramen if you are pacient.
author: Terri L.

description:
I'm going to put this average at 3. My fiancee had the vegan ramen, which was WAY too spicy. She didn't ask for it to be spicy either. I can handle spice, and this was near-inedible in terms of spice. Thus, she would probably grade hers at a 2.5 or so. I had the typical tori paitan and it was good, really thick and heavy. It could have used a hit of acid or spice though, but it still was tasty. 
Now, the line. We had somewhere to be at 6:30, so got there around 4:40. We weren't going to be the first seating and estimated we would get seated at 5:40. We made a decision to go to where we needed to go, and then go back afterwards. We got there around 8 and were seated around 9:15. Was it worth it?! I don't know. I really hate waiting in long lines for food. I think you can get better ramen in the Bay Area.
author: Samir K.

description:
The line is always so long but it's worth the wait! Pretty different / original types of ramen, but quality wise it's a bit better than the San Francisco Ippudo in my opinion, and on par with Ippudo in Singapore.


---- RAMEN ----

Spicy Tori Paitan Ramen: 5 stars
Tori Paitan: 5 stars
The creamy "paitan" broth is to die for. It's like the most flavourful gravy ever.

Organic Shoyu Ramen: 3 stars

Shio: 3 stars
Broth tastes of fried garlic and fishy bonito flakes, a bit salty.
author: Letitia L.

description: Wow. I've tried the spicy paitan, spicy lamb, and matcha ramen. They were all great but the spicy paitan was the best. The noodles are perfect, and are the main part of the bowl that puts all other ramen in the Bay Area to shame. I won't even bother eating ramen anywhere else unless something new and promising opens. Only place I've had better is Killer Noodle in LA, and they're really close anyways. This saves me a trip down to SoCal. Can't wait to try anything new that Mensho comes up with.
author: Kartik S.

description:
Been meaning to try mensho but the line has always thwarted me from doing so. Fast forward to the hottest day in San Francisco to date at 9:30pm we
Finally had our first mensho experience.

Service: fantastic, our waitress was really nice and came back to fill our waters several times

Noodles: perfect el denote consistency

Broth: paitan=great! Perfect amount of flavor, rich, creamy, flavorful
Organic shoyu: both bland and too salty at the same time

Ambiance: cramped seating, we were seated in between two couples flanked on each side. You really also can't linger as there is still a line at 10:30pm!

Value: pricey. We paid about $50 for 2 bowls inc. tax and tip which seems expensive for noodle soup

Final tip:
Vegetarians finally a ramen place you can eat at. The vegan ramen looked deelish! If I come back that's what I'll be ordering.
author: Betty C.

description: Ramen here was pretty legit. Only not legit part is having homeless people hassle you for money while you wait for your time to get let into the restaurant. Small spot with close quarters seating in communal tables. Food came out fast!
author: K D.

description:
I wanted to go here so badly on my family trip to San Fran that I went by myself.. and I'm SO glad that I did! I waited in line about 40 minutes at 10pm on a Saturday. The way their line works is you get in the back of the line and wait - no tickets, no lists or anything. Someone comes out to ask for your party size and that's it. They have very limited seating (like 25 seats) and just have big tables so you'll be eating with other folks, which was a fun experience for me! Service is quick and they have a really organized system to optimize their efficiency and get people in/out. Please do not be one of those groups who comes to a small place like this and sits for 45 minutes after finishing your foot to chat with your friends. This is a "get in, eat, leave" kind of spot.

Side note: Be warned that there are aggressive pan handlers that will come to the line. They even have a sign on their window where folks line up that warns you about it!

Now for the most important bit: the food. The Tori Paitan was the best ramen I have ever had hands down. The broth is so thick it's almost like chowder and the flavor has a lot of depth. I had eaten immediately before coming here and still finished my bowl - it was incredible. Would I wait two hours to eat here during peak hours? Yes. Yes I would.
author: Joan H.

description: Waited about 45 mins but was able to skip the line since I came alone. I ordered the Matcha Paitan with the Ajitama Soysauce (egg) and was quite disappointed. The broth was creamy and thick but was spoiled by the too sweet matcha. The chashu was salty and the duck fat was not rendered long enough. The Ajitama was surprisingly sweet but was cooked perfectly with the medium soft yolk. I would come again but will order the Tori Paitan or Shoyu. Stars for great service.
author: Kitty K.

description:
One and a half hour wait for ramen ? I can't believe I waited that long for ramen, but at least it did not disappoint. We were questioning our sanity for waiting during the cold sf night, but having heard such rave reviews on mensho, we braved through the chill. I probably would recommend coming in smaller groups, as they have limited seating in the restaurant. 

First, you must get the enoki mushroom chips! They were so addicting, but I also love enoki plus fried food so it was a win win for me. I ordered the tori paitan, and wow the broth was very rich and creamy. Almost gravy like, I actually which it wasn't as thick. But the flavors of the broth was intense and super flavorful. They also have the thicker tsukemen like noodles. My favorite part must be the chasu, super tender and melted in my mouth. I wish I got the double order. I also tried my friends matcha and vegan ramens, which were also very flavorful. Definitely, the ramen was different from other places I've tried, and overall had a great ramen experience.
author: Wendy L.

description:
Yuuummmmm Mensho! My favorite ramen spot in SF! Ahhh the chef's dedicate their everything in the ramens here at Mensho! It's so good. It takes 30-1:30 min to get your ramen but hands down its so worth it. I've been here like 15 times. I'm a fan. I honestly don't remember having eaten so good ramen outside of Japan! My favorite is the Ume-Shio ramen, and the enoki chips. You have to check this place out if you are visiting/living in SF. Put it on your bucket-list. Tip: only go if you are going alone, or with one more person; you will get seated faster if the table is for one or two ;)

...
author: Amy C.

description: Definitely the best place for Ramen in the city.  I have tried different dishes here and they are all good.
author: Manuel H.

description:
Got here when they opened, but the restaurant was already full and there was a line out the door. Ended up waiting an hour to get seated. 

Oysters in Shoyu Dare Oil - Looks like something you get out of a can. Smells and taste pungent but I liked it for some reason and goes pretty well with the ramen.

Shio Ramen with Double Chashu - Broth is supposed to be pork and chicken based with fried garlic, but I thought it was underwhelming and lacked flavor (pretty must just tasted like salt and oil). I thought the kale in ramen was a bit weird, it was bland and didn't do anything to enhance the ramen for me besides adding a bit of a crunchy texture which the menma is already supposed to do. Chashu was the only thing good, was flavorful, tender, fatty, and melt in your mouth.

Service was quick and prompt, but never felt rushed and 15% charge for gratuity is automatically added to your bill.

Maybe I chose the wrong broth or maybe they were having an off day, but I was not impressed. Cup noodles taste better.
author: Jenny L.

description: Best vegetarian tentanamen ramen in the world  hands down super like always had to wait 90 minutes in line before you get seats but believe me every minute waiting is worth once food arrives. Service is amazingly fast and waitresses are providing amazing service . I had mashroom fritters as starter and they were to die for mmmm
author: Hiten P.

description:
I honestly don't understand the hype about this place.

Food isn't bad, worth going once to try it. But they make you sit elbow to elbow with strangers in the crampest and smallest of tables that look like they were bought from IKEA... The whole place only fits about 25-30 people at once? So there's ALWAYS a line outside and if you miss the first wave when it opens, BE PREPARED TO WAIT. 

Service was oddly slow. I counted and there were 10+ people all sitting without food for 20 minutes. That's so weird considering everyone around me ordered the same thing...and isn't the kitchen used to "dinner rush" by now?

And the last thing that tipped me over the edge was the automatic 15% gratuity charge. Excuse me? All our server did was bring a bowl of noodles - didn't ask if we were okay, didn't refill our waters, didn't check-in, pretty much did nothing. Oh, except she brought us our checks at the very end if that's any justification. We were only a party of 2... makes no sense at all, at least earn your tip.
author: Vivian C.

description: BEST ramen I've had! It is worth the long wait. Spicy Tori Paitan, that's what you want to have
author: Rosalia M.

description: It is a very rich Ramen, super well done. Really recommend, if you in town put in your schedule.
author: Lois N.

description: Definitely has a really good option for vegetarians! I ordered the Vegan Tantanmen with an egg. One of the richest soup base I've had in ramens but awesome to try! The wait is quite long and felt slightly rushed when eating, but taste was great! Would recommend to other vegetarians!
author: MooMoo C.

description:
This bowl of ramen was total worth the hype! If you are wondering whether you should wait for at least an hour, or like me, stood outside thirty minute before they opened their door, you can stop wasting your time there and just line up.

This place was the first US outpost of that trendy Japanese ramen bar Mensho, so people get insane, I get it. Their menu was rather simple, if you enjoy a thick creamy broth that itself might serves as a standalone meal, go with the Tori Paitan, which was as fulfilling as you could imagine. If you are like me, prefer something that is slightly lighter and go well with the noodles, I would suggest Shio or Shoyu, both made with clear soup base. I went a step further by ordering the veggie Dandan ramen, which was recommended by the chef as their "best", while added the duck slices. 

Unfortunately they stopped supplying the soy-marinated eggs, and according to the chef, it was due to the concern of egg quality in US. Ok totally with him, I'd rather skip the whole thing if it was no good.

Lastly, noodles - this is the best part! Very different from the traditional instant noodle type, the noodles here were thick, chewy, and tasted hand-made! Felt to me that they had absorbed the broth so very flavorful as well! Heaven!

I guess starting from today I would ignore ramen in SF, as I have already experienced the best.
author: Elaine H.

description:
Best ramen in SF hands down. I've been to almost 10 or so ramen shops in SF and this one almost blows all the others out of the water. Went here with my friend during opening (around 530) I think and was suprised to see a huge line outside waiting right as they opened. However that did not deter us and we waited. 

The area outside isn't the best and smells of urine but nothing unusual for San Francisco. The restaurant is super small and compact but it really gives off that Japanese restaurant feel so the ambiance was perfect.

Me and my friend both ordered the duck ramen I think and it arrived in about 15 minutes. The ramen is amazing, you can taste the fresh noodles, meat, and toppings they have included. The warm broth has lots of flavor and was enjoyable to eat. The one thing I didn't like about the meal was that the broth was a bit too thick once you got to the end hence why I gave it four stars. I will definitely come back and I hope that they fix the broth soon so I can give them the 5 stars they deserve :)
author: Bhargava S.

description:
Came here for dinner on a weekday and the wait was about an hour. 

Due to the reviews on yelp I thought I was about to eat the most amazing bowl of ramen. I was wrong. I ordered the tori paitan. The noodle was cooked perfectly al dente but the broth was very thick and not that flavorful. I felt like I was drinking liquid fat. It was also missing some kind of punch. The duck was very rubbery which made it hard for me to bite a piece off. I had to put the entire big piece of duck in my mouth and chew and hope that it'll go down. 

My boyfriend ordered the clam ramen and one of the 4 clam was sandy. He also had to add more salt and pepper to his broth. 

For about $17 a bowl, this place is very expensive for mediocre ramen.
author: Michelle T.

description:
We enjoyed our ramen so much that we had to go back and try more!

FOOD:
Enoki Mushroom Chips - $5.00 
Yum, like mushroom tempura!  The squeeze of lemon and sprinkling of a red spicy-looking salt really weren't needed. 

Organic Shoyu Ramen - $14.00
I'm a shoyu broth fanatic so this was a must-try.  The broth had a strong smoky-bonito flavor which I loved.  Unfortunately they ran out of both miso & shoyu ajitamas 2 hours after opening, but I did get added bean sprouts and the included pork and duck chashu, bamboo, nori square and yucky kale, though the kale sprouts were good.  The noodles in this version were flat and wide, still cooked perfectly chewy and came out searing hot.  This ranks right up there for me with the version at Momofuku. 

Spicy Lamb Ramen - $16.00 
If you think the Tori Paitan is thick and rich, this sucker is beats it.  It's a miso broth topped with ground lamb, pork chashu, nira (Chinese leeks) bamboo and green onions.  No egg for my spouse either as they ran out, but he did receive burdock shavings.  The spoonful of broth I tasted was intense and a bit like curry.  Personally, I'd stick to the paitan for a rich broth, but he absolutely loved it. 

SERVICE:
Our female server was so friendly and patient with our amateur ramen friends.  My spouse and I on the other hand are pretty profesh, lol. 

TIP:
No sodas are sold here.  

OVERALL:
A joint with two bomb versions of ramen for me?  That's saying A LOT!
author: Vince N.

description:
Features:
-After waiting nearly one hour on a weekend, we were finally seated inside.  I had the chance to try the spicy tori paitan and the oysters in shoyu dare oil and the mushroom chip appetizers.  The spicy tori paitan came with pork chashu (yum!), spicy jalapeno miso, cabbage, burdock, and green onion.  The oysters were a bit herbal tasting to me and I didn't like it.  The mushrooms were good if you like fried food.  It was greasy and oily.  My ramen was good, rich, and very pungent tasting.  The soup base was very creamy but it went well with the thick noodles. It was not as spicy as I thought it would be.  Additionally, I tried the tori paitan (pork chashu, duck chashu, kale, burdock, and katsuobushi sauce) and it was flavorful, pungent and savory as well.  Note that although one was spicy and one was not, there were differences in ingredients.  I would come back here but I would not wait an hour again. 
-Good and fast customer service, you could place your belongings in a basket below the table. 

Tips:
-Come early so you don't have to wait so long, I would recommend coming half an hour before they open.
-Each table sits up to six so if you have a bigger party, the wait may be longer.  
-Credit Cards and Cash accepted.
author: Kristy L.

description:
BEST RAMEN EVER!

One of my closest friends introduced me to this place last year. Although I was skeptical about trying it, I now understand why this place is so popular.

Food:
I've tried the Tori Paitan Ramen and Spicy Lamb Ramen. The noodles are incredibly fresh and flavorful . The broth for the spicy lamb has a similarity with Indian curry. Another note is that the broth is very creamy and has amazing flavor! The spice level of the spicy lamb is very mild, so unless you have an extremely  low spice tolerance you'll love it.  I think I prefer the spicy lamb over the Tori Paitan but either one is a good choice! 

Service:
The waitresses are great at answering your questions and giving recommendations. But for some reason once I got my ramen I was never checked on or asked for water refills until the end but it wasn't a big deal for me. Today I got a seat that has the view of the kitchen. While I was waiting for my order I was watching the cooks work and it was amazing to see how a Michelin-starred restaurant operates in the kitchen. The way that the team in the kitchen works together and perfectly times everything is just outstanding. 

Wait times:
They open at 5pm so I suggest you get their at least a half hour before. For example I showed up at 4:25pm and was the fourth person in line. At 4:50pm there was about 20 people behind me. So, show up early to get into the first wave of seating. If you have a party, make sure everyone is there or else they won't seat you. But you can try your luck and ask the waitress if you can order for the people that aren't here yet. 

Price:
I paid somewhere between $19-$20 for Spicy Lamb Ramen. They already include 15% gratuity into your bill. This is very reasonable price for the quality that you get and the fact that it's a Michelin-starred restaurant.

Overall this place is amazing!
author: Sim T.

description: The long line was not worth it for me. I tried shio ramen. The broth was made from meat so the soup was oily and too salty for me. I could not drink most of the soup since it was too salty. The noodles were great though. It might have been better for me to have gotten the Tsukemen.
author: Sarah C.

description:
I recently embarked on a completely pointless quest to rank most of the Ramen Places in the Bay Bay Bay.

Ranking explained:  #1 (listed at the top)  is my favorite/ #?  (listed at the bottom) is my least favorite. Check out my latest reviews for my latest up to date Rankings. 

Rod Ramen Rating = (Taste of Broth / Taste of Noodles/Taste of other stuff in soup) on a Scale of 1 to 10 (10/10/10) being the best score possible

* Please note that I don't have a preference for thick or thin noodles or thick or clear broth I just call it like I feel it.
When I look at reviews sometimes just want to know where to go or how a user compares one venue against another to see if we have similar tastes. If you're curious, I have rankings for Boba, Bakeries and Ramen as well (random right?)  Follow my profile to see my most recent reviews.  I hope I can be helpful since so many Yelpers have helped me discover new places. 

# 1 Marufuku Ramen *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 9/8/8 *Rod's Yelp Rating *5 stars 
# 2 Mensho Tokyo *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 8/8/8 *Rod's Yelp Rating *4 stars 
# 3 Orenchi Ramen *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 8/8/7 *Rod's Yelp Rating *4 stars 
# 4 Orenchi Beyond  *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 7/8/7 *Rod's Yelp Rating *4 stars 
# 5 Ramen Parlor *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 7/6/7 *Rod's Yelp Rating *4 stars 
# 6 Ramen Dojo *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 7/6/7 *Rod's Yelp Rating *4 stars 
# 7 Iza Ramen *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 7/6/5 *Rod's Yelp Rating *4 stars 
# 8 Nojo Ramen Tavern *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 6/6/6 *Rod's Yelp Rating *4 stars 
# 9 Yokohama Lekei Ramen *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 6/5/6 *Rod's Yelp Rating *4 stars 
# 10 Ippudo *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 5/6/5 *Rod's Yelp Rating *3 stars 
# 11 Santa Ramen *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 5/5/5 *Rod's Yelp Rating *3 stars 
# 12 Ramen Yamadaya *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 5/5/5 *Rod's Yelp Rating *3 stars 
# 13 Sobo Ramen *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 4/4/5 *Rod's Yelp Rating *3 stars 
# 14 Ramen 101 *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 4/4/5 *Rod's Yelp Rating *3 stars 
# 15 Ramen Shu *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 4/5/4 *Rod's Yelp Rating *3 stars 
# 16 Suzu Noodle House *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 3/3/6 *Rod's Yelp Rating *2 stars 
# 17 Hinodeya Ramen *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 4/4/4 *Rod's Yelp Rating *2 stars 
# 18 Slurp Ramen *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 4/4/4 *Rod's Yelp Rating *2 stars 
# 19 Tadamasa *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 3/3/3 *Rod's Yelp Rating *2 stars
author: Rod M.

description:
I AM A HUGE FAN. 

Personally, I think this is probably the best ramen restaurant in SF I've had thus far. 

This was beyond my expectations despite the long wait. Actually I think the longest time I was waiting for was probably 30 minutes, but we went at around 5 - 6PM so maybe that's not dinner time yet for most people? 

Anyway, the first time I came in, I ordered Spicy Tori Paitan and it was AMAZEBALLSSS. It was so creamy and rich, almost weird to look at when they first place the bowl down. It looked as though you're eating ramen in a bowl of milk, but once you get a sip, you just want to keep on going! 

The second time, I ordered the same thing even though I was tempted to order the Vegan one. Finally, my third time, I went for it and got the Vegan one and man, I am coming back FOR SURE. To think the Spicy Tori Paitan was rich and creamy, the vegan was BEYOND what I could've imagined. I was having a mouth orgasm. It was DELIGHTFUL! The taste was exquisite and enticing. I've never had anything like it. Just one bowl itself was enough to fill me up. The noodles were cook perfectly as it's not super soft. I like my noodles on the more firmer side, ya know waaa I mean? 

If you're thinking of something else rather than the noodles....I got nothing to say to you, you DIRTY MINDED people!!

Anyhow, I am smitten with this place despite the small capacity and close proximity you have to be with people, but hey, you're in SF, get used to it!
author: Anna L.

description: I've had better ramen. Ramen was super bland and flavorless. The restaurant pretty much ran out of multiple items on menu so choices were limited.
author: Ally Q.

description:
Dinner with a lovely friend finally convinced me to wait out the 1+ hour line for Mensho Tokyo. We arrived at 7:45PM on a Wednesday and the line didn't look too bad, but the wait was still an hour. This line moves sloooow. Luckily I was with someone I enjoyed talking to past the time!
 
I tried three different broths - all in the creamy style. Mensho stands out for the thickness of their broth. It's not the thickest I've had - that was at Muteppou in Osaka (we are talking almost pudding), but it's the thickest I've tried in the states. 

I've come to realize thick broth is not my thing. I like rich flavors, but I don't want clam chowder texture when I'm eating noodles. Make sense?
 
Thickness aside, the broth flavors were great. My favorite was the Spicy Lamb, though it was way too salty and actually not that spicy. The flavor was unique for ramen - very peppery and heavily spiced.
 
The popular Tori Paitan was milder in flavor, with a very rich and creamy broth similar to Tonkatsu but not as 'meaty' in taste. If you like simplicity at its best, this is the way to go.
 
I usually stay away from veggie bases, but I was surprised at how much I liked the Vegan Tantanmen! The mushroom and kombu broth had so much umami, it was ridiculous. The chili oil and nuts added a nice dimension. This will be my next order if I revisit.
 
As for the meats, the pork chashu and duck chashu were tender, but forgettable for me. I did like the hearty portion of ground lamb. The noodles were good - nice chew and springy texture.
 
I enjoyed the Fried Enoki Mushroom appetizer. It's a heavier amount of batter, but it crunches so pleasingly. Enjoy with togarashi and lemon.
 
So was it worth the wait? I thought so, though I'm not sure I would be so eager to wait again having experienced it once.
author: Adrienne H.

description:
The. Best. Ramen. I've. Ever. Had. 
Maybe I starved whole day and waited about 1 hour to get in (even though I got there before 5pm), it was worth it. I had Paitan, which is super creamy and heart-warming  the pork and duck chashu were delicious. 

Pros: RAMEN
Cons: wait, you might sit with random strangers, and the seat is not that comfortable
author: April Y.

description: Thick noodles, thick broth and long lines. I'm really impressed that they still command an hour long line still. The ramen is really high quality including the duck chashu. The broth can be a little much so I can only handle it on occasion. Definitely work trying this place. Unique place but not a place I would frequent.
author: Young Y.

description:
This place is so worth the 1 hr wait standing outside in the cold... gotdam.

So of course I got the Matcha Paitan because I'm an insta ho but also because it intrigued me bc how often do you get matcha ramen... but I didn't know it came with duck!!! Well it comes with duck and pork but I asked if I could just get duck and they did the substitution for me. And holy shit. This is the most incredible ramen I've ever had... incredibly rich and bougie for sure, but... wow. The flavor in the paitan broth and the medium-rare duck breast that melted in my mouth... even the beautiful cut green onions added a nice contrast and I just.. wow. Wow. I get it. Get it.
author: Jenn L.

description:
4/5 for food
- shout out to the enoki mushroom fries
- oyster (appetizer) was too savory, flavor was too heavy. I would say it's not for everyone
- chicken Paitan ramen was very good. THINK AND HEAVY FLAVOR SOUP! but still, I would say it's not for everyone because if you finish the whole bowl you may feel a little bit greasy 

4/5 for service and environment 
- came here at 10pm and still a line there
- some private parking lot nearby ($4/hr)
- small and crowded spot yet very cozy
- service was quick and fast
- HOWEVER, this is not a good place for a after-meal chat. the wait outside was so long, the server actually told us to leave because we just sat there and keep talking and not leaving for like 20min. I totally feel sorry for doing that actually, not feeling mad or angry or what. Just FYI if need a place to hangout after this, go find somewhere else
author: Sunny L.

description:
Favorite ramen spot OF ALL TIME
Just be prepared to wait in line for an hour or so - 30 mins if you get lucky
Way worth it
The broth was creamy and flavorful!!!!!
No to go boxes and no take out available
This stuff is legit
author: Melodie L.

description:
I was on the fence between a 3 or a 4 but being one of those place with a 1-2 hour wait - you go in with a high expectation that this better be worth it. 

The ramen here is really good don't get me wrong but I'm not a person that enjoys waiting over an hour for food no matter how amazing it is. That said, the noodle quality here is probably the best I've had - great chewy texture and definitely handmade. 

The broth is very rich, creamy, and thick - I prefer a lighter and more soupier broth. My fiance got the lamb ramen ($16) - explosion of flavor but also very salty and heavy. I tried the vegan ramen ($18) which was a little lighter but still pretty thick as far as ramen broths go. The flavors were nice - peanut/ nuts and soy mixed in with a little kick of heat. I liked the toppings - edamame, kale sprouts, green onion, and mushrooms. The added poached egg is a must - cooked perfectly. Definitely one of the better vegan ramen's I've had. 

The space is pretty tight with communal tables and bench seating. The crowd usually lines up prior to opening at 5pm so get here early if you want to be part of the first wave. By the time I went (around 4:45) there was already a good amount of people and I ended up just missing the first seating and waiting a little over an hour to get seated. 

Maybe I'll come back to try the tori paitan ramen but it'll have to depend on the line which is pretty bad during prime dinner hours. The crazy part is that people choose to wait - by the time I finished and left - the outside line tripled. I don't think it's worth the 1.5-2 hour wait in my opinion - there's plenty of other good options for ramen in the city.
author: Brenda L.

description:
I almost gave up on ramen in San Francisco. As a vegan it can be hard to find good ramen. There's usually only one vegan ramen on the menu at most ramen shops and this place is no different. 

However the vegan ramen here is Grade-A amazing. It's all about the broth. I kept tasting the broth over and over. The noodles are good too and the vegan meat actually has me suspicious that it's real meat. That's how good it is. It has a real meat texture and aftertaste. The broth is also pretty spicy, too spicy for my gf to handle but I loved it. 

Six stars.
author: Dewayne P.

description:
I'm glad I got the heads up about the line. We arrived 30 minutes before they opened and there were already around 14 people ahead of us. Luckily we got in with the first round (It's a very small place). We ordered the Vegan Ramen (there's only one) I'm not vegan so I added ground lamb, the mushroom chips (So good) and the Shio with a miso egg added. Everything was delicious, filling, the service was quick and attentive but I felt like it was hard to hear talking across the table. 

Don't go if you're starving but do try it out. Best Ramen I've ever had!
author: kennice g.

description:
There was only one vegetarian option on the menu, which is the tan tan noodle.

While it started out really flavorful and delicious, it became far too rich and heavy halfway through the bowl. I also take offense to the fact that they can't seem to make a vegetarian broth, but can put in so much effort into this sesame sauce.

If I wanted saucy noodles, I'd just go to a better Chinese restaurant. I came for ramen -- the kind that comes with soup (miso, shoyu, shio, kombu...etc.) and noodles made from kansui (the yellow, wavy noodles that soup clings onto, not that white, flour/wheat noodle stuff).
author: Mel L.

description: So I think everyone is going to hate me but I think this place was just average. I'm sorry but I do. I got the vegetarian ramen with the duck because everyone on yelp raved about it and it was okay? I will say I hate the eggs here. They are a brown color and marinated in something maybe soy sauce? But usually the egg is my favorite part of ramen and I didn't eat this one. My co workers got the $40 beef ramen. I tried the broth and it was very tasty. I also like this broth because it wasn't very heavy like the broth in the vegetarian. We also got the two appetizers. The oysters were not good and I love oysters. Again something to do with the marinate. I really liked the mushroom appetizer though. Sooo I'm sorry to those who wait outside in line to get into this place but I'm rating it just ok :/ oh also this is important... they DO NOT have to go boxes. I pretty much wasted all mine because I didn't know this. You can bring your own Tupperware I was told. Not convenient
author: Sam P.

description:
I got the Tori Paitan Double Chashu Ramen. My takeaways:

PROS:
- Chashu is melt-in-your-chopsticks tender
- Noodles were thick, curly and had a nice bite to them
- Soup is like a chickeny-tonkotsu gravy. Rich and creamy, but you can still slurp a decent amount without feeling too gross. It has a well-rounded savoriness to it. One of the more unique ramen soups
- Smoked Oysters are a briny delight. Get them.

CONS:
- Got there at 4:30pm on a Saturday (30 minutes before they open!) but still had to wait TWO HOURS in line.
- The toppings and very top of the soup weren't steaming hot - just only warm. Only the noodles themselves were hot. I kinda wish the whole thing was hot.
- The lights in the restaurant are super bright and were making my face all red. Given how the restaurant is laid out, chances are the person across from you is going to be a complete stranger. Most of the seating is on stools. All of this led to an uncomfortable dining experience.

It's a good ramen shop. I like it better than Ippudo - I feel like this is actually worth the $18 price point.
author: Gabriel H.

description:
Okay let me preface by saying that we spent $120 here and I don't eat meat and the line was longAF. But I still gave this place five stars, and I don't normally give places five stars.

Okay moving forward, when we arrived there was already a long wait. But from the wait, we grabbed a bottle from the corner liquor store and drank in line like true BayDestrians. While we were getting "faded" and passing time the line started moving closer and closer toward the door. After about a 30 minute wait, we finally were seated and greeted by a friendly server. Not only did we jump on the order and get peach sale (see photos) my company ordered the last of the clam ramen.
 (Only 10 served per day, which worked perfectly because although I don't eat meat I'm a pescetarian so seafood is good for me all day.)

We were first ordered and served oysters and they were tiny as hell, but deliciousAF. The lychee sake came next and it paid perfectly with the small Japanese styled oysters.

When the ramen came out I was amazed by the quality, the smell, the presentation and the texture.

The broth was amazing and I was thoroughly impressed with the taste of the clams. I had an extra egg in my ramen and handed my chasu to my company, because I don't eat meat. 

They have a vegan option, which I have to try next time. Overall the experience the wait and the food was amazing and completely worth it. I definitely recommend this spot.

If anyone has any questions or concerns about this spot please message me. I'll be happy to answer anything that comes my way.
author: Jeremy Y.

description:
Second visit to this restaurant... we enjoyed it so much the first time we were definitely looking forward to revisiting, and didn't even mind the wait (a full 50 mins). Ramen was delicious as usual, but was totally thrown off by the rude waitress. 
When we paid for the check, she asked us if we wanted change, which we did. When she dropped off the change she made a point of reminding us that "the bill didn't include tip." We were a party of three, I think we knew that too was not included. 
Good food can't make up for bad service. Kinda left a bad taste in our mouth, not sure we will be back.

Update: 7/20/17
So, we did come back. We came back twice exactly. 15% mandatory tipping is now added to bill, which is a nice change.

More importantly, both subsequent visits we did not feel rushed. Ramen and dashi were both excellent, and service was much better! Both times we left fully satisfied and with happy tummies!

We also found out that coming later in the evening (after 10pm) the line was so much shorter!
author: Vanessa K.

description:
We got there at 515pm on a Thursday, and it was nearly an hour wait for 4 of us. 

They were out of the fried enoki, but we got the oysters. The oysters were good, but couldn't eat too much due to overuse of oil. 

The Tori Paitan was too thick. The duck was good. The noodles were perfectly cooked. It's creamy and has pretty good flavor, but too damn thick. 

The clam ramen is great for seafood broth lovers. The noodles are different than the TP's and were delicious. Noodles were so good. 

Overall experience was good with service, decent food and clean space. The wait would deter me from any future visits... food was good quality, but not my favorite ramen bowls.
author: Sau y.

description:
Is this place really worth the hype???

Sure Mensho is good, but is it really worth waiting. 30-60 mins in line?

I had the organic ramen here and it was really good, noodles were a bit overcooked in my opinion, the broth was rich and the meat was tasty. I've also had the oysters, fried enokis and they were both great.

I've come here twice and I've enjoyed it both times. I do think the wait is way too long and there's many other good options with less wait. 

Since I live so close, it's inevitable that I may stop by again.
author: Josh Giosue D.

description:
For the first review of the new year (2018) it has to be Mensho Tokyo...  The legend of this place extends far and wide and after hearing about this mythical place from the land of the rising sun where the ramen was magical and the lines were long. I had to have it. Now having tasted the fruit from said mythical place I can confirm that the journey, read wait, is worth the prize. 

This place changed my perspective of ramen and for that I will give this place 5 stars. I have become alot more choosy with my ratings and don't give 5 stars anymore. But, as you will read below this place deserves it. 

I am usually known to not like ramen, but that turned out to be due to the fact that I did not have the right ramen at the right place. It kinda scarred me for a long time and I shied away from trying any ramen for that reason. But, that all is behind me now after trying this place. 

After some merrymaking around town we stopped by here on the eve of Christmas eve and the line was only about 45mins-1 hour long. So, we decided that today it was finally in our destiny to have that bowl of awesomeness. And that we were served with a smile by the people at Mensho. Amongst me and my friends we tried 3 different types of the ramen:
- Spicy Tori Ramen: This is by far the most commonly ordered ramen here, and you realize that once you taste it. It has a smooth but very rich flavor profile. Once you mix everything it becomes pretty thick and tasty. If you have not been here before and want to try their most common signature dish then this should be your choice.
- Miso Chashu Ramen (Spicy lamb ramen): No one can fault you for ordering only the Tori Ramen every time you have been to this place but if you like to have something flavorful and filling then I would definitely recommend that you try the Spicy Lamb Ramen also. It is also very tasty and the flavor is very different but equally awesome as the Tori Ramen. I had this one and was very happy with my choice.
- Poke Soba: This is the Poke version of the ramen and is drier compared to the other ramen that are served in broth/soup. This had a very different flavor and the seafood was also very fresh and tasty. The thing that appealed the most to me here were the ramen. In India we get ramen like instant noodles called Maggi noodles. The company is owned by Nestle and is present in many countries in the world. The ramen in this one reminded me of those noodles that I used to have as a kid and brought back wonderful and fun memories. Apart from the taste, I might order this one purely for the awesome ramen that it has.

Appetizers: In all the haste to describe the food I forgot to mention the Oyster in Shoyu Dare Oil starter that we had. It was also amazing and I would recommend to try it if you like flavored oysters.

One thing to know, the serving size is huge. It does not look like when you get the food but there is a lot of food here and the bowl is deeper than it seems. I am a tall guy with an appetite but I could not finish what I ordered. They don't give to-go boxes, you have to have your own if you want to take it back home. When we were having so much awesome food for a second I thought if it was just us who were having such a good time as we don't have a very trained ramen palette. But, then if you looked around and saw all the people instagramming, checking in on Fb and taking pictures of the food from different angles, it made me feel assured that everyone was loving it.

This is an amazing place and I am looking forward to going back here.
Come hungry and leave happy and full. Definitely a must try!!..
author: Nipun S.

description: To me honest, I don't understand the hype when it comes to Mensho. First and foremost, the line to wait is absolute madness. When I finally able to get in, I was incredibly disappointed in the ramen. However, I love the thickness of the ramen noodles...but the broth was incredibly disappointing. I hate to leave a negative review, but Mensho definitely left a bad taste in my mouth. I will not be coming back.
author: Meesh L.

description:
Mensho Tokyo is my must have when I come up to catch the Giants in San Francisco. Almost a tradition that I come in for dinner after an afternoon game. The area is sketchy, I hate that you have to stand in line with all the locals of the Tenderloin coming up to you and asking for change and food. 

I think Mensho has the best ramen around. I also understand that there will always be a wait since the restaurant itself is small (fire marshal notice says 49 or so). So that's not the problem. 

I knocked off 1 start from their perfect rating because tonight's Shio ramen my friend ordered was pretty much bad. I always go with the flavorful Tori Paitan which is delicious but after trying my friend's Shio, Mensho dropped in ratings a bit. I also found out that they don't have togo boxes. My friend didn't finish the Shio but couldn't take it home. There was tons of ramen left! :(

Sorry...you were rated too honors in my books for a couple of years until tonight. I'd definitely be back to stand in line again for your Tori Paitan!
author: Ticha B.

description: This has been on my go-to list for awhile and I finally made the effort to wait in line for it! I got there around 4:30pm on a Saturday afternoon and there was a good amount of people in line already. As the doors opened at 5pm, they let people in and unfortunately, stopped at me and my boyfriend so we had to wait for the next batch to go in (they only have about 28 seats). By 5:30pm we were seated and I ordered the Spicy Lamb Chashu Ramen. It was a BURST of flavors in my mouth: the spicy, the lamb, the chashu and the thick broth. The ramen noodles was my favorite part as it was just perfect. It is the thicker ramen noodles, chewy with a bounce. My boyfriend ordered the Shio Chashu Ramen which includes clear chicken and pork Soup, shio dare, pork chashu, kale, menma, fried garlic, chives, and nori. We both enjoyed our ramen very much and left with happy full bellies!
author: Annie L.

description:
I've been here a few times now. The tori paitan is still my favorite. The broth is super rich and clings to the thick noodles really well. I'm not a huge fan of the spicy lamb. It tastes like something halfway between ramen and schezuan cuisine. I usually get my ramen spicy (or any food for that matter) so I recently tried it here. I thought the spice and extra flavorings took away from the deep chicken flavor. 

In short, stick with the regular tori paitan.
author: Huey N.

description:
Simply put. It's as overrated as SF. If you want to insult someone's taste, time and money, bring them here.

Comparing to various shops I have tried in the US and Asia, Mensho is disappointing to say the least. Overly salty soup and stale noodle with a piece of paper-thin chewy tasteless wagyu is what you get for $50 bowl of wagyu ramen. Ever get that annoying feeling when you undercook your noodles and it gets stuck in your teeth when you try chewing? Yep, that sums up what you get here for a week $ worth of Sprout groceries. 

The wait time in an urine-infested area is also ridiculous for the trash quality and pretentious atmosphere you get here. 

It's an utter rip off even by SF overrated standard. I will give a star at least for sanitary.
author: Derek P.

description: My second bowl of ramen in SF and all I can say is this was one of the best bowls/soup noodles I have add(ordered vegan tantanmen). Flavorful, thick creamy, spicy (ask for extra chili on the side) and firm al dente noodles. Enjoyed every bite n sip. Worth of every dime and second I spent over there. And by the way crushed the bowl :).
author: Prateek R.

description:
After hearing all my friends rave about this place, I had to go try it myself. Knowing that there was hardly any street parking and that the area around it was a little sketch, we decided to take an Uber there (good idea). 

Mensho Tokyo opened at 5pm, and we arrived there at 6pm on a Wednesday. Make sure to layer up, bring a warm coat, and be prepared to stand in the cold for an hour or two. The restaurant is very small and only seats 28 people. When we got there, the line (~50 people) was already extended two stores down from Mensho. I've never seen a line that long, but fortunately it moved more quickly than I expected. We were lucky that day and were seated after waiting for little more than an hour. I heard on some days, the wait time can be insane and can be 2+ hours. This gives you time to look over the menu and decide what you want to order ahead of time. When it was my turn to be seated, I walked inside, hung my coat up by the door, and made my way to the table. Seating is "communal style" so you'll most likely sit next to a stranger. The tables are high up and there are baskets underneath so you can temporarily store your personal belongings there. I also noticed they play fast paced music, such as EDM, but it didn't really suit the environment. It was odd, but after listening to the some Dillon Francis, I was even more excited to eat my ramen.

My two friends ordered the Shoyu ramen and I ordered the Shio ramen. The food arrived fairly quickly and all came out at the same time. 
SHIO RAMEN: It came with bamboo shoots, chashu, noodles, and kale. The kale was definitely an interesting addition to a bowl of ramen but none of the less, a great one because I like kale. The clear broth was delicious, which was perfect for me since I like it light. After one sip of the broth, I knew that it'd satisfy my ramen cravings. The flavors in the broth were distinct and I instantly knew that waiting in the cold was worth it since the broth was one of the best I've ever had. The noodles were interesting and different since it was kind of flat and thin. One thing that was a bit disappointing was the chashu. The chashu was barely warm and didn't complement the ramen since it wasn't the same temperature. It would have been better if the meat was heated up more and if it had more flavor. I also wish my bowl of ramen came with more broth because my bowl looked like it had less than my friends. I slurped all the noodles, devoured the bamboo shoots and chasu, and gulped all the broth. At the end, I was left staring at an empty white bowl hoping that more ramen would magically appear. 
All in all, Mensho Tokyo is worth lining up in for. I usually avoid restaurants that have long wait times since I tend to grow quite impatient, but I'm willing wait here again. Hit up some friends (to make time past by faster), bring some small snacks (so you don't starve while waiting), and stand in this crazy line for a bowl of delicious ramen. And yes, the hype is real!!
author: Michelle F.

description: This place is extremely overrated. The line was way too long for an $18 bowl of ramen that was drenched in fat and salt. Although we were lucky enough to be seated right when it was opened, the price and the taste of the food killed the excitement that was built up from waiting in line and reading other's reviews. We got the Spicy Tori Paitan, Oyster in Shoyu oil, and the soupless naked ramen. Both the paitan and naked ramed was distastefully thick and fatty. The taste was incredibly one dimensional in that I can only taste grease and salt. The oyster was also disappointing. The cooked oyster was shriveled up in the dark marinates on a tiny plate. It tasted extremely fishy and salty as if I was snorkeling and suddenly breathed in a surge of salt water combined with fossilized kelp.
author: Michelle C.

description:
Ramen quest achievement unlocked...finally made it to the elusive Mensho! Secret to my success? Came with 2 friends on a Tuesday evening around 5:20pm, and waited only about 35 minutes to be seated. Yay!

Once space is available, the waitress took us into the bar/counter table in the back. Seating is communal style here so be prepared to share some space. It did not feel crowded though. 

If you're in line for a bit, they do have a menu sign at front of line so you can browse the food and drink choices. I was anticipating my dinner here and spent the last half of my workday browsing their online menu. I debated between their infamous toripaitan or shoyu ramen. Instead I opted for SPICY LAMB MISO ramen, since it's very rare to get lamb ramen in the US! Both my friends got the toripaitan and I got to sample some. Both were excellent choices! Go for the lamb if you want a kick of spicy flavor and rich broth -- the thick miso soup had chili oil drizzled on top and lamb was well flavored with cumin. The TORIPAITAN'S broth was also rich and flavorful, and less thick/creamy than other reviewers make it seem. The chashu of both dishes were very tender and melted in your mouth.
