My favorite thing was the actual ramen noodles themselves -- thick but with a bouncy chew. 

Mensho was definitely comforting on a chilly SF evening. I have fallen for the hype and believe its impressive ingredients and flavor make the higher price tag worth it. Come here for a taste of Japan or your next yolo meal! I already have the toripaitan and clam ramen on my to-eat next list.
author: Bonnie Z.

description:
Most people complain about the wait time, but if you're not waiting before it opens, you're not dedicated enough!!!!! There's enough seating for about 30 people +/- a few (4) depending on how the party sizes work out and if you can extend to the ends of the table.

Between the three of us, we got the clam butter ramen ($18), tori paitan ramen ($16), and the shio chashyu ($13).

HOLY MOLY I had an out of body experience like I watching myself eat the ramen because simply eating it wouldn't do it justice.

Clam Butter - This was my favorite - the broth, the ramen, the swirl of pork, the clam, the butter 5/5 absolutely delicious. The only serve 10 of these a day, so be sure to get there early! We joked that we would just order 10 for the 3 of us in the future because that's how good it was.

Tori Paitan - The pork was delicious, and the broth was slightly sweeter than I anticipated. However, all good stuff!

Shio Chashyu - This broth was fantastic. It was thick, and rich, and everything I look for in .... but it was so delicious. It was like drinking liquid gold, and my mouth is watering just writing about it.

Bring your own container if you want to bring back leftovers!
author: Gina L.

description:
TLDR: WORTH THE WAIT !!!!!!

IT'S DEFINITELY NOT JUST A HYPE!  Mensho Tokyo is by far the best ramen I've tasted anywhere.  No wonder they have a line out the door a hour before they even open.  Trust me, it's worth it though.

I haven't been to Japan yet but Mensho is a franchise that started in Tokyo so that counts for something.  This is their first location in San Francisco and their ramen is clearly on another level.  Their infamous tori paitan was absolutely breathtaking. I literally had to pause a second just to admire it for all its glory.  (Mind that, I'm usually one to devour my food in seconds)  I added duck meat and a soy sauce egg for toppings and I would highly recommend you to as well! 

Their vegan tantanmen and matcha ramen is next on my radar to try!  I'll probably need to strategically pick a day where I won't freeze waiting in line for a hour though.
author: Derek L.

description:
The kids wanted noodles and I found this place with decent reviews on Yelp. I was lucky to get here right after they opened but wow there was already a long line and a crowd of people outside the store! While waiting in line I checked the menu and saw they were a Michelin guide restaurant. 

After waiting probably a good 30-40 mins we finally got our seats. The menu is quite simple, mainly ramen dishes that either comes regular or with extra chasu. Some are with broth and some without. For appetizers there were only 2 to choose from. I decided to order the enoki chips to start. I really wasn't sure what to expect and was hoping it wasn't something I had to end up finishing on my own. When it came out it smelled wonderful and believe it or not it was SOOOO good!! One way to know something weird is good is having young kids try them. My 11 year old and 5 year old both loved it just as much.

I also ordered the organic shoyu ramen and shio ramen. The noodles were tasty and both was very light without feeling too greasy or filling. I really liked the way everything tastes. The soft boiled eggs were perfectly cooked which was an add on.

Overall everything was great here and the staff were very attentive and accommodating with kids. I will definitely will come back again next time I'm in town!
author: Jenny K.

description:
Woah... that's some thick and flavorful broth served at Mensho. I made it to the restaurant at 5:07, just missed the first round of seating, waited about 40 minutes to get seated as I was just party of 1, shouldn't be as bad even if you're with party of 2. I'm not sure if it's so good that I would wait an hour+ for this. half an hour is ok, 

If you're not comfortable with sharing tables with strangers where your elbows might touch, this place isn't really for you. If you're extremely claustrophobic, I think you should be looking for a plan B dinner spot. 

I kept on seeing people raving about Tori Paitan, so gave that a go, add on ajitama and make it double chashu. Boom, here comes my $20 bowl of ramen. Ok, my $20 bowl was extremely filling, lots of flavors going on: my egg was marinated in miso, my soup was mainly chicken, I have pork chashu and duck chashu, got some fried burdock root with some earthy taste. So much stuff going on, I can't even put it in words. Duck chashu was amazing, it was so tender. Pork chashu was just alright, I've had better ones at Ramen Shop, it was a bit tough here compared to Ramen Shop's. Their noodles are pretty chewy, fun to chew but not fun to slurp. I made a huge mess on myself so had to eat more ladylike. That soup though, it wasn't drying out my mouth but it was just so flavorful, I couldn't stop. By the time I should stop, I felt sick, guess my stomach wasn't used to the thick broth. 

I read from some reviews that they do have lighter broth like shio. My other friend also suggested the vegan ramen and said it's the best thing he's ever had. Probably next time, if I made my way to that area before 5pm.
author: Connie C.

description:
Came here around 5:45 pm on a Sunday. The wait was probably about 45 minutes for a table of 2. 
Semi-long wait, but I was really excited to try their ramen.

The atmosphere was cool, once you get inside you'll see that it's quite small. You're seated at a communal table which seats 6 - but up to 7 cause you can add a chair to the side. 

Food: 
I ordered the Tori Paitan ($16.50). Took about 15-20 minutes to come out. Great, because I was really hungry waiting in that line.
The broth was really pretty thick - almost milky. It was pretty delicious. Noodles were a bit thick, and not quite like other many ramen noodles I've tried.
The meat for the ramen was actually "DUCK chashu" served in 2 different ways. First, they give you a large cooked piece of duck which really tastes like chashu! The other pieces of meat I think were slices of rare duck. I've never seen that it in a ramen nor have I ever even seen duck in ramen. It was really good though.

Service:
Friendly, decent.

Overall, the food didn't blow me away. I'm from SoCal and I'd still prefer my ramen spots here over this place. For the bay area, however, I think it was probably my favorite so far, though it was pricey. They also have plenty of options i.e., soupless ramen, extra toppings (I had habanero), side dishes, drinks and all that! Try this place out if you're tired of boring ramen!
author: Richie C.

description:
What I got:
Tori Paitan Ramen
Enoki Mushroom Chips

What I thought:
Mensho is based on an actual ramen restaurant in Tokyo with an American(Bay Area) twist to it. It's an incredibly popular place and typically has around a 45+ minute wait so be prepared to chill in line for a bit before you actually grub.

The ramen here is one of a kind. It's very different than most places that I've been to. The Tori Paitan hit the spot! The broth was rich and bursting with so much flavor. It's a bit on the thicker side than what I'm use to, but that's because of the the way they make their chicken broth. I think they blend like actual chicken into their broth to make the flavor pop. It's great! It also comes with pork chashu and duck chashu -- both were very tender and juicy. It even had kale in it (definitely a Bay Area thing).

The enoki mushrooms were fantastic as well. I've never had enoki deep fried before. It was a yummy snack to eat before our ramen bowls came out. Crispy and bomb.

Great place for a ramen fix. I usually don't finish all the broth when I eat ramen, but at Mensho I drank the bowl dry. It's the best ramen I've had in SF so far.
author: Tony V.

description: Delicious and worth the wait! Got here around 6:15pm on a Tuesday and waited about 25 min to get inside and then another 15 for food. The Tori Paitan is one of their most popular dishes and it was absolutely delicious! The broth is on the creamier side.
author: Sophia D.

description:
Wow. Ok, if you know me, you know I have a visceral reaction when it comes to ramen restaurants. It's not their fault, it's me. It has something to do with ramen being a cheap, last resort meal growing up, and I just get mad at the principle of paying more than like $1 for ramen. That said, I still waited for an hour with my friends to get ramen at this pricey ramen place.

And I loved it. Ramen is still just not up there in terms of my favorite foods, but for the ramen that I've tried (which is surprisingly a lot, despite my rant above), I enjoyed this the most! I got the spicy lamb ramen, which was FULL of flavor without being too salty. My friends got the clam ramen, which they said was amazing. We also tried the fried oysters. Delicious.

Overall, if you come knowing that you're gonna be waiting in line for an hour for a kinda pricey but delicious bowl of ramen, it's worth it :)
author: Alice L.

description: My cousin took me to this place while visiting SF and I'm very glad to experience this restaurant. We waited for about 20 minutes which is usual. I didn't mind to wait either way. The interior is small and you make sit next, or across from a stranger, so get comfy! Elbows may rub, but who really cares when you're enjoying ramen. I ordered the paitan ramen and it was thicc. Like suuuuper thicc like we're talking about thicker than a bowl of oatmeal. The broth was flavorful and packed with meaty essence. The tonkotsu was tender and really great. The duck breast had maybe a hit of citrus and was very delicious. My cousin ordered the $40 A5 wagyu ramen as of 5/12/2018. They may change up their current specials and that one was only able to be served 10 bowls a day! Enjoyed everything about this ramen, a little on the saltier side but I would definitely come back to try the miso or the shoyu brotha next time!
author: Alex L.

description:
One of the best Ramen I've ever had. It's heaven in a bowl!  the soup is ridiculously good, rich but light, very creamy but not too salty. 
One word: Perfection! The only thing was the line, it took us almost 2hrs to get seats. The delicious ramen bowl was still worth the wait. Definitely would come back and I highly recommend this place.
author: Vy N.

description: We took abt an hour to q n got our seats. The place was nicely done up. I ordered the spicy version with 'double' portion or chasiu or pork meat. The broth was thick and smooth. It was not as spicy as I expected. The noodle was thick and texture wise not as smooth. I add on a tamago egg which was pretty std compared to any other ramen joint. Overall feel was pretty average nothing to about abt. If u ask me: the most 15min-20min wait for this place. Abit over rated.
author: Jeremy K.

description:
One of the best places ever for ramen!!!!

Be prepared to wait to get in. If you make it an hour early you will be fine. If you come later expect a long line. There is no way around the wait but you will see it was well worth it!!!!

Came here with my brother.It was his first ramen experience ever and he was impressed!!!! I had the Tori Paitan ramen. I saw Cathy S. when we were waiting in line outside of restaurant. It was great to see her and chat for a while!!!! 

The restaurant is small and gets packed. If you don't like communal dining don't come here.

It's a nice looking restaurant!!!! Service is great!!!!

The ramen here is not cheap but it is truly exceptional!!!! The broth is truly exceptional and the noodles are superior!!!! The meat is perfectly cooked!!!! Make sure you order an extra portion of meat though!!!! They also serve great beer here. Not merely your average Asahi and Sapporo, etc.here.

What can I do without at Mensho Ramen?

The wait!!!!

What stands out at Mensho Ramen?

The exceptional quality of the bowl of ramen you get!!!!

Five stars!!!! Mensho Ramen is really, really ridiculously great!!!!
author: Miguel R.

description:
Been here twice now and both times we had to wait more than an hour in line but the ramen is definitely above par here! I recommend the tori paitan ramen (worth the $2 for double chashu) or add $1.50 for extra DUCK CHASHU. It's so good and melts in your mouth! I've also had the cold chicken ramen (refreshing broth but very bland), and arubasoba (nice first few bites, flavorful but super oily). Not sure if it's worth the wait to you, but I think every foodie/ramen lover must try this place at least once!!

TIP: 15% gratuity is already included in the tip, and all the servers share it at the end of the night--which creates a less competitive work environment for the servers but also allows them to slack off since they have guaranteed tips. Our server last night was slow, forgetful, and did not come back to refill waters or check on us even once, I would have chosen not to tip her if I could.
author: Cammy C.

description:
Has this restaurant really been open for over a year now?? Geez am I super late to the party! 

I live in the neighborhood and witnessed all the noise and hype when Mensho first opened. 2 hour long lines before the restaurant even opens is what I gathered from most. So I decided the best option was to wait for the initial excitement to die down before trying it for myself.

Well, I walk past it almost on a daily basis and I have never not seen a long line outside.
To be fair, the line isn't as crazy as before. I came on a Wednesday at 6:30 and waited about 40 minutes. 

What is there to be said that has not been said before?? Instead, I will address the haters that are giving out 1-star reviews.

THEY DIDN'T WANT TO ACCOMODATE MY PARTY THAT IS LARGER THAN 4! This restaurant has only 28 seats that are all on communal tables. That means that if you come here with 5 other people and get huffy that your 1-hour quote turned into a 2-hour wait, that is no one's fault but your own! They cannot guarantee that 5-6 seats next to each other will magically open up at once. Seriously, be smart.

THEY WOULDN'T LET ME SIT IN THE RESTAURANT AND NOT ORDER ANYTHING.
Yes, every person in every party must order something. Otherwise, you are just a useless paperweight taking up space in their tiny restaurant. The 60 people outside would agree with me.

THEY WOULDN'T LET ME TAKE MY FOOD TO-GO.
They clearly state that on the menu outside that you're staring at before you enter the restaurant. Many yelp reviews have stated this. The restaurant decided that this was a rule that was worth putting in place in order to maintain the quality of their food. If you want something to-go, Jack in the Box is just down the street.

THEY RUSHED ME.
There is a time limit they put on your party. 1 hour and you're gone. This is not the place for an anniversary date or to catch up with your bestie from high school. You come in, you eat, you leave. It's about respect for the restaurant asnd the people waiting outside. If you need to camp out somewhere, there's a nice bar across the street that is perfect for that!

I HAD TO SHARE MY TABLE WITH SOMEONE ELSE.
No one forced you to eat here, did they?

MY WAITER WAS RUDE TO ME.
In my opinion, I didn't see any rudeness, but I didn't see any incredible acts of service either. They are a tip-less restaurant-which is clearly advertised. The servers are there to take your order and give you what you need in a way that will keep their restaurant moving and turn tables quickly. They will get you what you need, just be patient. You already waited an hour for a table, you can wait another minute more.

THERE'S NO SUSHI!
*punches you in the face*

THE RAMEN SUCKED, I'VE HAD BETTER AT IPPUDO/JINYA/MCDONALDS.
Valid reason, you don't have to like it. But please continue telling me your engaging story I'm SOO interested. *sips tea*

I'M FROM JAPAN AND I'VE NEVER HEARD OF THIS PLACE.
Well aren't you such a special snowflake?

Extreme Sarcasm aside, I had an amazing experience. I didn't know Vegan ramen could taste like so. The broth was so creamy and rich, it was hard to believe it was made from nuts! The noodles were also so delicious and combined with all the veggies and mushrooms (those mushrooms! How!?), it made for 1 incredible slurptastic meal from the 1st bite to the last.

Also, if you haven't, try their draft beer! It is unique only to their restaurant and is extremely malty, yet still light & balance.

At $18 a bowl,  it is pricey for a bowl of noodles, but I say it was worth every penny. *burp*
author: Lanie L.

description:
I really enjoyed my ramen both times I came, but this place is 1) a hassle to frequent due to the location, wait, and seating, 2) overpriced (with mandatory gratuity, to boot! $56 for two bowls!), and 3) not as authentic as I expected. 

Pro tip: If you like very rich broth that's mildly spicy, go for the vegan. You can add eggs and your choice of meat. Yes, they now have eggs.
author: Paulina F.

description:
This place was okay.  They have a TON of broths, but the food did not live up to my expectations compared to other ramen places I've been to. 

Given the space issue, the restaurant addresses it greatly, storage baskets below the tables, extra utensils in a drawer of the table.  And the cool thing is you have to sit with other diners too, so it forces you to get out of your shell and talk to your neighbors.  Service was super fast, and they happily let me add another item last minute.  Their workers and processes are on point so no time is wasted.  

The broths were only okay and I feel their prices are only justified because it's a restaurant in SF.  Their cha sue was not for me, but the duck and miso egg were the all star of bowl.  

Some things did not sit well with me and I just had to take off stars.  

On the menu at the entrance there is a post where they charge a 15% service fee and tell you not to tip.  That is fine with me, but why?  What if I wanted to give the team an extra $20 if the meal was amazing? I would much rather them add the 15% charge in their menu prices and have a "tip not necessary."  It gives the customer more freedom.

I also don't think the fried enoki was worth it.  I did feel pressured into getting it but it's a $6 item.  Given that a thing of enoki is less than $1, and the item is just fried, it wasn't "amazing." And I wouldn't order it again.

They do not provide to go boxes, and that seems like a decision from the owners to increase efficiency speed and cut costs down.  Given the price point and wait time, not fond of that.

Advice:  Find another way to address the 15% service charge.  

Lower the price on the fried enoki, or at least don't have your employees pressure customers by saying it's the best thing ever and you're missing out.  

To go box...
author: Nathan S.

description:
Not a fan of their broth (texture was off putting) or noodles (too chewy). Marufuku is much better and more reasonably priced.
Also, you wait through the Yelp app at Marufuku, as opposed to waiting outside in the tenderloin for mensho.
author: Subrat M.

description:
Tried the famous tori paitan ramen here after waiting outside for 45 minutes on a Tuesday night at 6 PM. Overall, the dining experience seemed a bit rushed since you can see everyone waiting outside and start feeling guilty. The ramen itself was sub-par to me and not worth the 45 minute wait.

The plus side is that Mensho gives a good portion of meat to noodles and that the noodles were perfectly thick, curly and al dente. However, the broth wasn't hot (temperature-wise) enough for me and there wasn't enough broth. I think the noodles started to soak up the broth and it seemed like more of a noodle dish instead of a noodle soup. It seemed like a heavy bowl of ramen, with a very creamy broth, fatty meats, and thick noodles. Definitely a pricey, but filling bowl of ramen. Just wish it were hotter and more soupy!
author: Victoria L.

description:
Thank you Yelp for being my go-to when I'm traveling and looking for places to eat! This ramen place we visited during our SF trip definitely did not disappoint!
The first night we saw the line was almost a block down so we decided to try here another night. We made sure to get there early so we wouldn't have to wait in line as long. The wait was soooo worth it!!!
While in line I saw that the restaurant is Michelin rated and I perused the yelp photos and reviews on what would be the best thing to order.
I ordered oysters in shoyu dare oil as an appetizer, the tori paitan ramen, and the bf ordered the organic shoyu ramen.
First off, the oysters were already de-shelled, and on the drier side. But soooo good! I would definitely order these again and again! My tori paitan had such a rich and delicious broth. And besides the usual pork chashu, they also had duck chashu. Okay, I actually enjoyed the duck way more than the pork! Everything was so appealing to the eyes and stomach!
The bf also enjoyed his organic shoyu ramen. He said it was different from what he's usually used to eating but it was still good. I saw some reviews stating this was the best ramen ever, but that they've never been to Japan. I would say, for the category of atypical Japanese ramen, it's definitely very good. But it definitely cannot compare to traditional Japanese ramen in Japan.
If you're ever in SF, give this place a try! But be sure to get there early!
author: Cara Y.

description:
tl:dr the ramen is good, but definitely wouldn't say it's the best I've ever tried and it's not worth the wait or price.

Arrived at 4:45p on a Sunday and waited about an hour and 20 minutes to be seated. I've waited in longer lines for ramen so I was prepared to wait, however the ramen at Mensho did not live up to the hype for me. I ordered the Enoki Mushrooms Chips ($6) and Spicy Tori Paitan ($17) and the broth was TOO thiccc, a quality I've never complained about. The broth's flavor was good but it didn't amaze me. Additionally, the Spicy Tori Paitan only has 1 piece of pork chashu while the non-spicy Tori Paitan comes with duck chashu and pork chashu for a cheaper price ($16.5)... The noodles were okay, definitely fresh and the Enoki mushroom chips were great -- I'd recommend those! 

While I did appreciate the organic chemistry on the walls explaining their ramen's umami taste, the overall ambiance felt a bit disheveled. I understand space is limited in SF, but man you're really shoulder to shoulder with your fellow Mensho-goers once you're seated. I didn't know I could feel more claustrophobic inside a restaurant than waiting in line haha. Also, when I was getting seated throwback Pussycat dolls (Buttons) was playing and while it was humorous, it was not appetizing. My last comment is that the spoon that accompanies your ramen is yuuuge, but I digress. In fairness, I'd give Mensho 3.5 stars if it were possible on Yelp.
author: Sean D.

description:
Always wanted to try it, and it lived up to expectations for me. Came in on a Wednesday night around 6 PM, free parking across the street and was seated in about 15 minutes for 2 people.

You get seated at a table shared with other so the vibe here is extremely cozy. The waiters are friendly and the service was quick. We ordered the Tori Paitan (spicy) and a Matcha Tori Paitan, both of them super rich and creamy soups. The pork chashu falls apart when picked up and instantly melts in your melt. The matcha was something different and I would recommend it to anyone wanting to try something new.
author: Jason X.

description:
The interesting thing about mensho is that the ramen is delicious, but it never leaves me with a feeling of "hey, I want to come back any time soon". The cause of this dilemma is probably due to the overly heavy style of broth that mensho offers. 

While I love hearty broths, I found mensho's classic tori paitan too heavy. It's hearty to the point of being sickly. When you get through 2/3 of the bowl, it will feel like plowing through a bowl of cream of mushroom + noodles. It's a guaranteed food coma for days if you finish the entire bowl. 

It's funny because you can tell by watching the faces of the customers who finish their meal that they are done for the day by the time they finish. I know because I've closely observed the expressions of those who've finished their meals while waiting in the infamous 1-2 hour mensho ramen line. Their faces said "I'm so stuffed I could burst - time to continue with the rest of my day inebriated."

If you like thick ramen, definitely pay mensho a visit. If you need to stay awake for any physical or mentally intensive activity after the meal, stay away from this place. :)
author: Sherica L.

description:
Mensho's West Bay outlet is still going strong after 15 months of operations, if the perpetually long lines - even before each day's opening time - are any indication. While the wait might not be worth it if you're coming at peak periods and are already hungry, the experience here is definitely worth it if you can come about 15-30 minutes before opening, or later at night when things slow down a bit.

If you get here when they open, then go all out for one of their limited items, like their clam butter chashu ramen, which sells out fast. All the ingredients, whether the fresh clam, the butter, or the chashu are quite good on their own, but together they reach a whole new level. Similarly, the spicy lamb chashu ramen is quite delicious, with all the individual ingredients coming together to form a lovely, rich, and thick concoction. 

The only weak point here is the service, which skews towards the perfunctory and indifferent, which is all the more irksome given the mandatory service charge here. Nevertheless, if you can brave the crowds, you'll be rewarded with some delicious ramen, perhaps some of the best in the entire Bay Area.
author: Vincent L.

description: We arrived at 5:20pm and waited for 30 mins queue. Maybe you wanted to be there a bit before 5pm to avoid the queue time. I had a spicy lamb pork ramen. The portion was big. I was stuffed. It's not a bad experience to try. I mean it's worth trying.
author: Jasmine MengTing W.

description: O m g! Wow, ima say 4.5 stars round up to 5. Came on a Wednesday at 5:05pm and  waited in line til about 5:35. They only seat 25 people at a time. Got the spicy tori paitan! What a very unique and interesting soup/broth. Was almost like a thick gravy. I added duck chasu (interesting, can pass). Pork chasu was pretty tasty. I love the thickness and consistency of the noodles however. Would recommend to all!
author: JJ W.

description: Went to Mensho on a Saturday evening with my friend. We arrived just before 6pm to a long line. We waited just over an hour before being seated. While in line panhandlers approached several times, but overall I didn't feel unsafe while waiting even though during our drive in you go through a pretty sketchy looking area. We ordered the oysters and the mushroom chips to start. My friend got the last wagyu ramen left. It cost $39 and they only serve 10 bowls a day. I got the spicy tori. I personally did not like the oysters, but my friend who loves oysters really enjoyed them. I'm not a huge oyster fan to begin with though so if you're like me, maybe pass. The mushroom chips were yummy. We both enjoyed our ramen. Having spent significant time in Japan this was not the best ramen I've ever had but it was pretty solid. The noodles we quite delicious with a nice thickness and texture. I probably won't return as I didn't find it good enough to be worth the wait time, but definitely worth a try if you like Asian/Japanese/ramen food.
author: Kaitlyn W.

description:
This place has a waiting time of at least 60 mins outside the restaurant. 
My personal opinion - Food is not so delicious and this place is not worth waiting so long.
It's Over hyped..
author: Tejasai G.

description:
Thought Mensho would be overhyped, but the Tori Paitan is actually very good.  Thick, flavorful broth with a bit of grittiness that cuts against the fat.  

Wait is long and $$$ for ramen, but probably one of the better shops in the city.
author: Christine A.

description:
This place promised itself to be the best ramen in the city outside of Japan and I was so excited to try this place 

Personally, I was not impressed. The first couple bites of the ramen were good but after that, it was too 'heavy'. 

 Coming from the ramen heaven of LA, I'll have to keep my search for good ramen in the city. 

Please note that there is extremely long lines here! Be prepared
author: Natasha S.

description: I ordered the Spicy Tori Paitan with an add on of a soft boiled egg, which was medium to hard boiled in actuality. I enjoyed the noodles were thick and chewy, and the broth was tasty except that it contained fresh bamboo shoots which made it reek of a tap water-like smell. Be aware there's a mandatory 15% service fee.
author: Jessica T.

description:
One of the best ramen in SF! I'm not a huge ramen fan, but definitely appreciated the dishes here. Given the high anticipation of the grand opening of its first location outside of Japan, we decided to wait a few months before coming here. Even so, it's very crowded and there's always a wait. We arrived at 4:15 on a Sunday, before they opened at 5. Our wait was considered "short" compared to others who arrived after us.

Oysters in Shoyu Dare Oil - This is 1 of 2 appetizers that they offered. The other appetizer was enoki chips, which I wasn't interested in. This dish may not look pretty, but it tasted great and paired well with the ramen. The oysters were cooked and tasted salty and meaty.

Organic Shoyu - Ramen with a pork and chicken clear broth, seasoned with shoyu and topped with pork and duck chasu. The noodles were handmade, flat, thick and al dente. Everything married so well together and the chasu was so tender and flavorful. 

There's about 28 seats and the tables are communal style. Service was fast and efficient and turned seems high here. We were in and out in 30 minutes. Our waitress looked stressed, but totally understand given how hectic is gets here.
author: Helen C.

description:
Waiting in line for an hour for ramen? No problem! Especially, if it's Mensho, I'll wait even longer. This place is probably the best ramen SF has to offer. I mean, it made its way all the way from Japan afterall..

My go-to order is the spicy lamb, whoa! The broth is really rich and you can get an extra serving of lamb and a side of chopped habanero, too.

I'd skip the small plates and appetizers and go straight for the ramen! Be sure to line up with a friend so you don't get bored!
author: Nitar L.

description:
During my weekend getaway in SF I so badly craved ramen. I quickly yelped the nearest ramen joint and found Mensho Tokyo which was a near 0.3 miles away from my hotel. It was around 4pm and the place didn't open until 5pm, perfect!! I told my boyfriend to leave around 4:45pm to give us enough time to walk, find the place, and put our names down before opening. HUGE MISTAKE. Upon arriving, there were already at least 30 people in line and the restaurant didn't open yet! I was so confused. Apparently, this is a pretty popular ramen restaurant in SF?!! 

We waited exactly 1.5 hrs to be seated and served. Mind you, we never wait for anything but the yelp reviews convinced us to stay.. I was so excited and hyped but a bit nervous because I'm notorious for never finishing my food and the reviews mention not having to-go boxes for take out. I ordered the Tori Paitan ramen with the spices on the side based on yelp first-timers reviews. 

In my opinion, the ramen was delicious and definitely fulfilling but not overtly amazing. Because I waited almost 2 hours I definitely had some high expectations. The ramen was thick, almost gravy like. I felt like I was drinking fatty soup. The flavor was rich and creamy but not salty. The noodles were made hot and fresh - exactly how I like it. It's more on the pricier side of ramen, I paid almost $20 for the Tori Paitan Ramen (Double Chashu) and surprised to say that I actually finished my entire bowl! 

I'm glad I stumbled upon Mensho. I'd probably come back again if given the opportunity!
author: Jesse L.

description:
The ramen at this place is amazing, but be prepared to WAIT. I arrived 30 minutes before opening time on Christmas Eve and I was probably the 10th person in line, whew. They let in 30 people each HOUR so if you're the 31st person in line... be prepared to wait another hour. Once my family and I entered the restaurant, it was another 30 minutes before we got our food. So be prepared for the second round of waiting. By this point I was STARVING and was thinking I should've had a pre-dinner before the real dinner.

The tori paitan ramen definitely tasted sweeter than the ramen I've tried at Daikokuya (LA), Ippudo (NYC) and Totto (NYC). But it was GOOD and I'm craving some as I write this. I'm not really sure if it was worth the wait... but if you're a patient person (unlike me) then I say go for it! Also I wouldn't get the other ramen options... I thought they were mediocre in comparison to the tori paitan.
author: Lucy W.

description:
I've been demanded to change my rating...by Boyfriend. He's still adamant about Mensho being the best ramen, especially because of their thick creamy "chicken soup for rich people".

So, I went back. And I must admit - the experience was much better. The noodles were actually cooked through. I still love the duck chashu, the other one was too salty (even Boyfriend agreed). Maybe I should just ask to substitute the duck chashu for their regular chashu instead.

The service is always great. If you're an extrovert, or you can pull off being an extrovert (like Boyfriend), the community tables are cool. But DEFINITELY go later than earlier - I hate lines.
author: Athena C.

description: Every bowl is made with love, from scratch. The essence of authentic ramen, and probably the best food I've ever had. I hope they open up a location in San Jose!!!
author: Rafay C.

description:
I'd give this place a 3.5 stars. Close to a 4, but just not quite there for a 4 in my opinion. This isn't my favorite ramen broth. I prefer something with a lighter broth like Orenchi Ramen in Santa Clara, but the ramen broth is good. It's something new and different. As others stated, the broth is heavy and creamy. Very flavorful. A different taste from the traditional broth. Also ramen noodles are thick and good quality. 

Anyways, I got the spicy lamb ramen with double cha shu and my buddy got the matcha ramen. Spiciness =6.5/10. It's a little bit more spicy than mild, but nothing drastic. Leaves a little heat in your mouth as you're finishing up the bowl. Also lamb meat is grounded up like ground beef. 

As for the matcha ramen, it's good/ok and creamy but don't expect it to taste sweet like matcha green tea. It's a little bland and has somewhat like a dairy taste, but I doubt they use dairy. Matcha is heavy on creamy side but not bitter like the strong baking matcha. The matcha is more of a smooth powder rather than the grainy green tea matcha tea drinks. 

Overall I'd recommend it to try. But not sure if it's worth the 90 minute wait outside.
author: Danny H.

description:
Wow... what a genuine experience. Stepping into Mensho Tokyo will feel like you have been transported straight into a ramen shop in Japan! No matter which day you go, there will be a wait outside  Try to come early before it opens to avoid a long wait, but even then there might be people before you that are eagerly waiting for the place to open. But don't worry, the line goes quicker than you might think. Come with great company, and chatting while you wait really passes the time.

A must-try here is the Tori Paitan, which has duck chashu. It is slightly pink in the center, but it is simply amazing and just melts on your tongue as you chew. The ramen broth here is thick, frothy, and flavorful. It is so rich that it was border-lining too salty for me, but it is a perfect complement to their thick chewy noodles. If you aren't able to finish, it will be a sad day since you can't take it to-go with you. Try to finish every last bite, you won't regret it.
author: Lily C.

description:
Real Ramen- You can believe the hype of this place. Line is usually long for a seat at this small restaurant. Expect to wait over an hour or more during peak dining times. If you decide to wait it out, you'll be rewarded with one of the best ramen places around. It's as good as the ramen places we've tried in Japan. 

We had the spicy paitan ramen; one with the soy soft boiled egg and another with the miso egg. The ramen is rich and full of flavor. It's creamy as described. It's not spicy for us as the name implies as we're used to spicy food. It's hard to finish the bowl of ramen, but if you do, you'll be stuffed as it's heavy on your stomach. 

We also tried the fried mushrooms and it had a very good texture and flavor. 

If you like ramen and don't mind the wait, this is the place for you.
author: Michael D.

description:
Cold, rain and wind in SF equals ramen! This was definitely a spot we had bookmarked to try while in town. Be prepared to wait... outside and no leftovers are allowed to be taken home. Trust me it's all worth it. We ended up waiting a little over 30 mins to get in which wasn't bad just cold. 

When we showed up there was already a line outside with about 10 people ahead of us. It's a very small restaurant holding only 26 people in communal style seating. Yes you are elbow to elbow with strangers so don't be shy! They have baskets underneath the tables to store coats, bags or scarves. They also have coat hooks next to the front door. The stools are not great for purses ladies so you can use the notch at the edge of the table to slip your phone or purse into. Or just toss it into the baskets below your feet. Service was great and speedy! They have one vegan option here which I of course opted to get. My BF went with their Tori Paitan double cashu non spicy he didn't realize there was a spice option. It was made with a creamy chicken broth topped with duck and pork cashu. He really enjoyed the tenderness of the meat it was not overly cooked or dried out. The soup was creamy and smooth with huge flavors. He added a miso egg for extra. The miso egg is sweeter than the soy egg. If you are not familiar with these eggs they are soft boiled the center will be slightly undercooked and runny. My vegan ramen was amazing! It's truly difficult to find a good strong robust flavored vegan or vegetarian ramen. The thing that stood out about this vegan ramen was the 7 types of nuts added into the ramen. That was a first for me. It did add another dimension of texture, next to creamy rich thick broth and soft noodles. I love spice and the chili oil added a delicious kick of heat without killing my taste buds. I opted to add the soy sauce egg into my ramen. I liked both the miso and soy eggs. It wasn't packed with vegetables which is what I prefer. But that didn't stop me from loving this ramen. It was absolutely delicious! 

Defiantly worth coming to get again. Gratuity is included in your bill already. And no take out boxes here.
author: Karen H.

description:
Am I a maniacal gastronomical thrill seeker bent on waiting almost 1 hour just for an $18.00 bowl of ramen? If it's a highly acclaimed bowl of ramen, yee, you bet!

Were the Tori Paitan or Spicy Lamb bowls worth the wait and the price? No way. Overhyped? Frankly, yes.

The unpleasantly thick and overly creamy broth just wasn't for us. I noticed that the dude across from us took two slurps and abandoned the rest of the contents of his bowl. The broth just isn't for everyone. 

I tacked on an extra star because of all the high quality ingredients/toppings. The chashu Pork was beautifully tender and the noodles were springy.
author: Merica S.

description: Great ramen place!  I was surprised I liked it so much cause I'm not used to get broths that aren't just pork based.   The broth is very good and has variety of flavors with a nice level of spice.  The topping variety for the spicy tori paitan was really good in variety of taste and texture.   The pork chashu was also very tender, but it was lacking in flavor compared to the broth.  The wait is long but worthwhile if you have a friend!
author: Darren Y.

description: Ok, maybe it was an off night at Mensho but, I was so disappointed with my ramen and I am still dumbfounded. Came in on Wednesday night, it was super busy (in my mind, this is a great indicator that I am missing out on some good ramen) finally we were seated and I couldn't wait to try the ramen. I ordered the organic shoyu, in my opinion, it was too salty and the noodles were mediocre. I don't understand the hype. The ramen was overpriced and wasn't worth the splurge. Meh.
author: Minji K.

description:
Fantastic ramen here !!! I tried the Tori Paitan ($17.00 approx) and it was so so flavourful 10/10. It was creamy and had a very authentic flavour. The noodles have the right texture and all the ingredients go well together. The line outside is always long so I wasn't sure if I had the patience but it was worth it !!! Must visit this place for sure next time you crave ramen. 

The interior is very small with communal tables and the orders move quickly. 

Note : They have baskets below the tables for bags/ coats etc. 

I went back and tried the spicy ramen ($16.00)and that was super too 8/10. It is on the spicy side as the name suggests and has more of a curry feel to it so if you are looking for a light meal I recommend the clear broth. 

For me personally this place is super in terms of flavour, friendly staff, ingredients, etc and I recommend this place to everyone !!!
author: Shivani B.

description:
It's great that they are so busy but I feel the reason for the line is actually due to incredibly slow service. Ramen here is tasty and it's nice that the Ramen craze is finally hitting San Francisco albeit at this very slow pace - but Ramen in Japan is not something which is meant to take a long time. It's Ramen, you can bring the check with the bowl, OK? And if someone wants something else, you can just add it to the check. Let's do this people. Let's make it happen. As I stood there, I wondered why the people inside were sitting there so long. Were they being real cool, hanging out in the place to be? As I eventually sat there, I realized they were literally just waiting for the check. I realized the people were done with their food, waiting for their food or waiting for whatever. All of which, in a Ramen restaurant like this should be moving a lot faster. I know I wanted my Ramen, and then after my Ramen, was ready to bolt. Yet I sat there, looking at the line outside.

I don't want to sound like a bozo or another one of the 'I've been to Tokyo' crowd, but I've rarely seen a line for Ramen in Tokyo and on the two or three occasions I did you know that line went FAST. The Ramen came FAST and is equally as good if not better so let's speed it up here guys. I guess I just had to wonder if they were going slow here in order to have a line outside, thereby upping their status with the herd.

But then I saw another line last night at Ippudo. idk, either we need more ramen places or the herd has to stop twattergram trending about being real cool at every new place. But maybe I'm just old school like that and Ippudo is the new place to have a line? Is Mensho missing out on the line action these days? Someone should open a new Ramen spot with a baked in requisite wait of 'up to' 1 hour.
author: E C.

description: Best ramen hands down! Never had better. Vegan ramen is the best. Worth the lining up for.
author: Aisha V.

description: Came by because of yelp and its legit. Got the 2nd seating even though we got here at 430 but it was worth the wait. Wife had the spicy lamb and I got the spicy paitan and they were fabulous. The paitan was tastier than the lamb but you wont go wrong with either. Also had the mushroom chips as an appetizer that was amazing. Great food and outstanding service.
author: Jay H.

description:
One of San Franciso's premier ramen restaurants.

Mensho Tokyo ever since it's establishment has placed itself upon one of the more famous ramen restaurants in San Francisco. Known for its Tori Paiten(Chicken Stock Ramen), there is almost always a line at any given moment.

My friend and I came at around 6pm on a Thursday night. We expected the line to be a bit shorter since it wasn't the weekend, but lo and behold there was a line. We waited around 20-30 minutes for a table for two. Something to note here is that this restaurant is extremely small. There aren't very many tables, and the long tables often have parties unrelated sitting next to each other.

One note of the service here at this point: The waitress who served us would keep coming by asking if we were ready to order yet. I understand if it was every minute or so, but the waitress came so often it felt incessant, as if we needed to order as quickly as possible so we can leave as quickly as possible.

My friend and I ordered the Oysters in Shoyu Dare Oil, Tori Paiten Ramen With Double Chasu(Duck and pork chasu), and the Matcha Tori Paiten Ramen (Tori Paiten Ramen with Matcha all over).

The Oysters in Shoyu Dare Oil was unexpectedly very delicious. There was different layers of flavor but every flavor was deep and tasty. The price might have been a little much for this appetizer, but it is something that I can definitely recommend to others.
The Tori Paiten Ramen with Double Chasu was certainly an experience. In my opinion, they really try to showcase the chicken broth. The chicken broth to me was a turn off. It was certainly very rich and creamy, but maybe too much so. It was too rich, creamy, and frankly heavy & salty. I've had my fair share of rich and creamy broths, but this one felt a little excessive. The toppings were rather generic besides the duck chasu which I thought was very delicious. I've never had duck chasu before so when I had it here, it was a tasty surprise. Overall, I can understand why some people would enjoy this broth, but to me, it's a bit much.
The Matcha Paiten Ramen was really no different. I don't believe the Matcha added any type of flavor difference and it fact, if I had to choose whether or not it made the ramen better or worse, I think it made the ramen worse. The matcha certainly made the ramen look very novel however.

Overall I find myself difficult going to Mensho Tokyo again. The prices are pretty outrageous and if you're coming here to try the tori paiten ramen and you aren't a fan of heavy or thick broths, then this place is not the place to be. If you simply want to be part of the hype, then by all means, but I'd rather take my ramen hopes elsewhere.
author: Anthony Y.

description: This place was outstanding.  I had the ramen with the duck slices.  The broth was very flavorful and the noodles had a nice chew.  There was a line when I arrived around 9pm on a weekday night but turnover was quick.  Highly recommend this place.
author: Heath B.

description:
I found out about this place six months ago but I haven't got a chance to try it out until now.

I met up with a friend at 5:50, and by then, there was already a line forming outside. We waited outside for 50 minutes to get seated. The place is the Tenderloin so we got harassed by a couple of panhandlers and the smell wasn't so pleasant. 

On the inside, it's very small. There are four communal tables with very little walking room. It's very loud inside and the seats are high up. We got seated elbow to elbow next to strangers. Service was very prompt, we got our orders fairly quickly.

I ordered the Tori Paitan with a soft boiled egg. The broth was very rich and flavorful, a little too salty, but that didn't bother me too much. The noodles were perfectly cooked with just the right amount of chewiness. The pork and duck were nice additions to the dish. But there were vegetables that seemed out of place in the dish. wtf was kale doing in ramen? 

Overall, the ramen was pretty good. However, it comes at a steeper price point and a longer wait.
author: Donald C.

description:
I don't get it. 1.5 hour wait for a slightly above average bowl of ramen. Ramen is one food you'd expect to never have to wait this long for. If you've ever been to a ramen house in Japan, you know what I mean. You walk in, order, and almost immediately a enjoying a hot bowl, and walk out, it's a popular quick lunch option. My experience on a Sunday night was quite different. 

I can't say that the service was bad, because it wasn't. Once we sat down we almost immediately had our food. This huge wait to get in however is what makes me question the hype. We waited outside for probably 100 minutes. They don't rly have the best seating plan, so sometimes bigger groups at the front of the line end up waiting longer for space to clear up, than if there had been a space available for say 2 people in the middle of the line.  

All in all the food was pretty good. I really enjoyed the spicy lamb with double chashu I ordered. The broth was pretty thick and more like a curry and than a ramen soup base. Still flavors were great and plenty of noodles and meat to leave me satisfied. The whole umami thing i rly dont get. Maybe my taste buds are challenged or i lack culture to understand taste profiles, but jesus its a bowl of noodles ppl. Sure some ramen is better than others, but I don't think any bowl will ever be worth a 2 hour wait.... but that's me. 

Overall Mensho dishes up some great ramen that appeals more to the droves of hipsters than your typical joint. If they can save up and rent out a new spot with more seating I'd be back. I would not return for the sole reason that I'd rather not wait for over an hour for a bowl of noodles.
author: Giff D.

description:
This was my first time back since they first opened and the lineup was unfortunately just as long! My friends and I got there at 6pm on a Wednesday and waited for 45 minutes for 3 people. 

I got the tori paitan ramen for $16 and it was as creamy and delicious as expected. What I love most about their ramen is their noodles though. They're thicker than typical ramen noodles and just have the best consistency. I'm dreaming about them as I write this review! 

I tried my friend's shio broth and it was fantastic. My other friend's vegan broth wasn't bad either!
author: Emma W.

description:
I was looking for a place to grab a meal after walking around for a few hours.  Walking down various SF streets bouncing between food hunting and people watching I happen to follow a lady that was screaming profanities that I can only imagine she had invented as I have never known a sailor with the profanity skills running as deep as her.  Her walking common sense could have been a bit better as she was constantly causing traffic as she convulsed down Geary lap after lap. 

Well the intrigue of her drew me past a line that had built a length a good 20-25 people deep at 9:00pm.  Everyone in line was talking about the last time they were here, how long they had waited, the best way to eat your ramen (do you slurp, do you spoon it in, etc) and other general conversations trying to constantly prove they were the most intellectual of all their friend without saying it directly.

I hopped in line, popped open Netflix and watched just over an episode of Mindhunters while I was waiting ( amazing as well, if you're not watching you should be!). All of my friends have been talking about Mindhunters with much the same vigor as everyone in line talking about Mensho.

I was finally seated, quickly ordered a Tori Paitan which was served within about 10 minutes.  The broth was incredibly flavorful, when you are sitting you can read about their katsuobushi on the wall and where their two dashi's are derived from.  Really interesting to read. 

As a reference the Tori Paitan has a Rich and Creamy Chicken Soup, Pork Chashu, Duck Chashu, Menma, Kale, Burdock, Katsuobushi Sauce, it was fantastic.

I finished up, walked out, just in time for the lady that helped me find the place walk by on another swear-laden lap around Geary, I followed her down to Union Square, and left home for a good nights sleep.
author: Will N.

description:
I came here with my friends before opening and there was already a line out the front door.

We ended up waiting around 2 hours (on a Thursday night) to be seated for 7 people, however once you are seated and order the food arrives promptly.

I ordered the A5 Wagyu Ramen, which was the most expensive ramen on the menu. The meat melted in my mouth and the noodles were good as well.

If you plan on coming here make sure to arrive at least 30 minuets before they open, otherwise you will most likely find yourself waiting in line for a while.

I can definitely see myself coming here again in the future.
author: Draco L.

description:
TLDR: Fine, but doesn't live up to the hype/price

Shio Chashu (3/5)
- Broth was flavorful without being too salty
- Noodles were a little thin and soft for my taste

Tori Paitan (3/5)
- I substituted the meat with 2 soft-boiled eggs; the soy egg was better than the miso
- Broth was extremely rich and creamy almost to a fault
- Very sweet undertones and not as salty as i expect Ramen to usually be
- Noodles were bomb, definitely the star of the dish; they seemed homemade and each of our ramen came with a different noodle
- It came with a good amount of veggies; tasty mushrooms and kale

Ambiance/Service (4/5)
- Expect a long wait during dinner time (30min to 90min)
- Seating is limited and only at communal tables
- Service was friendly and quick
author: Nathan M.

description:
Got in line 20 minutes before they opened on a Tues.  About 15 people ahead of us but we were able to get seating once the doors opened.  Got the double chasiu on recommendation from the waitress after we mentioned it was our first time there.  

The broth was pretty good and the pork was more like a steamed pork intead of BBQ.  It was soft and crumbled if you really poked at it.  The serving size was pretty adequate and I was full afterwards.  Prob. stayed no more than 45 mins from being seated to paying for the bill.  

I'd rate Nojo maybe a couple points more as I prefer their broth more.
author: Kevin H.

description:
My friends and I were in the mood for Ramen and this seemed to be the most popular spot nearby. 

The wait was REALLY long. This isn't necessarily a gripe over the place, but be warned if you're really hungry (if I was). Once we finally got in, the menu was pretty simple and it was a pretty small cute place. The wait wasn't too long once we got in, and the Ramen was great! (I'm writing this review late so unfortunately I don't remember what I ordered).

Giving it a 4 because I think I've had Ramen this good for less before, but still worth checking out!!
author: Amolak N.

description:
This is probably the best ramen I've ever had in the states. I came during the last hour of serving and there was still a line! It's a michelin guide recommended spot. Cold outside in SF and ready to be seated. I was anxious to try this place out. Once we were seated I knew immediately to order the Tori Paitan ramen. A creamy chicken broth based ramen. Chewy thick noodles, hot piping broth, slices of duck and pork, kale, menya, and special sauce. It was a wonderful hit of umami. I couldn't believe ramen could taste this amazing. Blown away! 

Recommendation: Tori Paitan ramen
author: Andy N.

description: Best ramen we have had outside Japan and that includes all the LA all-stars. Go there, go early if you can, but worth even a little wait.
author: Brett R.

description:
I actually really like their yaki soba instead of the Tori paitan.  Been here twice and the first time i was jealous of the person sitting next to me at the shared table who got a big bowl of sauce drenched noodles.  This time I got the yaki soba after a few drinks at Redford across the street.  Great drunk food

Also, had previously tasted the shoyu broth.  I liked the flat noodles they use, but the broth was a little too sea weedy for me
author: Marshall Y.

description: Came across this place on Yelp! Had amazing reviews, and knew it was a must have while in SF! Let me just say...the line was pretty long, specially for it being like 9:30 on a Wednesday night. So took about 1 hour to get seated, they took our order right away and we had an amazing ramen 15-20 minutes later. Let me just say this is by far the best ramen I've had. And I've eaten a lot of ramen haha
author: Elley E.

description:
The four of us arrived at 10pm on a Thursday night when it was POURING rain, and the wait was ~40min. Spent the entire time in line cursing ourselves and the rain and willing the patrons inside to eat faster... honestly, I didn't think it'd be worth the hype. But honestly HONESTLY, it definitely was. 

Everything about the Tori Paitan was thick, rich, and delicious: from the handmade noodles to the chashu to the creamy broth. Amazinglyyy flavorful - I can't believe I guzzled down the entire bowl of broth and noodz.

Note: Ramen does not come with an egg, btw. For Tori Paitan, recommend going for the eggcellent and gooey Miso egg.

We also ordered the enoki chips, and seriously, why have I never had anything like this before?! So good and one-of-a-kind! Loved having this as a crunchy little fried side dish... 

Oh man, I drool as I write this... must. go. back.
author: Ashley S.

description:
This is a pretty small place and I think it holds about 25 people at a time. Line started forming around 4:15pm and I would say there was about 40 people in line when it opened at 5pm. I got the tori paitan ramen because everyone seemed to like it on yelp and I prefer more creamy tonkatsu broths. I really liked the noodles and the flavor was good, but I think the broth was too thick. The consistency was much like melted ice cream and I don't know how I feel about that. 

If I were to come back again, I would probably look to try the shio ramen.
author: Megan C.

description:
Came here Sunday night at around 9:30 and still had to wait 20 minutes! But it was well worth it. I'd stand another 20 if I had to. Make sure to bring a jacket though, it can get a little chilly outside.

Tori Paitan - A very rich creamy chicken broth based ramen, is a MUST HAVE. No other place in the Bay Area has a tori paitan style ramen as rich and delicious as Mensho. The meat in the ramen is cooked to perfection, both the duck and the pork chasu. The duck was perfectly cooked and tasted super juicy and flavorful. The pork chasu was so tender that my chopsticks would break apart the meat as I tried to grab it - absolutely amazing. Can't stress enough how incredible both the duck and chasu were, especially the duck.

If you want a lighter broth I'd recommend getting their Shoyu ramen - in my opinion it's just as good as the tori paitan but lighter in taste. Their Shoyu ramen is also one of the best I've had. Usually I hate ordering Shoyu based ramen because at most places it tastes like they just dumped soy sauce into water. At Mensho it's totally different and the Shoyu flavor is delicately finessed with all the other ingredients, creating a less punchy soy sauce taste. 

This is my favorite ramen spot in SF. I've come here multiples times now and I'll keep coming back. Only other place I like just as much is Ramen Dojo in San Mateo.
author: Jonathan C.

description:
Although we all had to wait for 2 hours and 30 minutes, I'm going to let you know, that this place was totally worth it. 

PROS
* simple place and straight to the point 
* best ramen I've had in SF Bay Area. The ramen didn't take that long to come out. Everything on the menu was appetizing
* the ratio of the noodles, veggies and pork was perfect 
* the chashu was extremely big. Bigger than what everyone thought it was going to be
* dishes compliment each other 
* this restaurant is a dine in exclusive. I love the fact that they don't do take outs or you can't take home any of your leftovers. It makes the place a lot more special, when you eat ramen you're supposed to enjoy and eat it all at once, rather than bringing it home and then enjoying it--you wouldn't really get the same experience as you would in Mensho Tokyo. This place is meant to be shared with others. 

CONS
* the selection on the menu was very small. There was only a few things that you can really order
* the wait LOL.
author: Melinda W.

description:
Considering how so many people rushed to check out Mensho when they first opened, this review is pretty late.  However, as much as I wanted to be part of that initial wave to check them out, I can't say I was willing to wait two and a half hours for that to happen.  My social calendar may not be as packed these days, but that's not exactly how I want to spend my time either!

Although the initial craze has died down a bit, the wait at Mensho can still approach two hours during peak times.  Thankfully, we were able to beat the rush and only had to wait about 25-30 minutes at 6:00pm on a Friday, but the line was pretty long by the time we left.  Sadly, our group was also forced to split in half, but it was understandable - with just a handful of communal tables and some counter seating, they can't easily accommodate large groups.

-- OYSTERS in Shoyu Dare Oil (3 Pieces)...$5
(https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/mensho-tokyo-san-francisco-2?select=dl2NqklWfTa36XWtThxdTw)
It may not have been the prettiest oyster dish to look at, but it tasted pretty good!  Being that it wasn't a raw dish, there wasn't much freshness or sweetness to the oysters.  However, I liked how the saltiness of the sauce complemented the oyster's meatiness so well.  Yum!

-- TORI PAITEN RAMEN (with Double Chashu) - Rich and Creamy Chicken Soup, Pork Chashu, Duck Chashu, Menma, Kale, Burdock, Katsuobushi Sauce...$18
(https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/mensho-tokyo-san-francisco-2?select=6oCdgfNJO79TLqfYAku5jQ)
While I still wish they had their tonkotsu ramen on the menu, this was great!  The kale was kind of odd, but I liked how well the noodles were cooked, how tasty the pork chashu was, and how tender the duck one was.  The broth was the star though - as advertised, it was super rich, creamy, deep, and very flavorful.

Beyond how good the food was, the service was just as awesome.  Orders came out very quickly and the workers were all super friendly, which was especially notable given how hectic this place can get.  If you want to avoid said lines, you can also try coming in for a late bite (they're open until 11:30pm, or so).  That is, if you're willing to gamble a bit, as they can run out of broths (and will shut down earlier than posted if they are completely out).

Though I'd certainly come back for the Tori Paiten Ramen again, I'd especially like to return to check out the additions they've made to their menu in the time since I came here (like their lamb ramen, which sounds very interesting).  Four stars for now (it's great, but $18 is still a little pricey), but I love how Mensho, Nojo Ramen Tavern, Marufuku, Hinodeya, and the upcoming Ippudo are making SF's ramen scene just that much better!
author: Mike L.

description:
Wow! Best Ramen I've had! Mensho's Tori Paitan Ramen (double chashu) ($18) was super amazing and full of delicious umami flavor! The broth was very rich and creamy, but the flavors were SO tasty, I could not stop drinking. The noodles were cooked to a perfect texture, the bamboo shoots and kale were a nice touch, but what was the crown on top was the EXTREMELY TENDER and flavorful chashu. Both the pork chashu and duck chashu were out-of-this-world amazing! Definitely the best I've had in any ramen bowl. I only wish there were more pieces.  

In addition to the tori paitan broth, Mensho also offers organic shoyu, shio, and a vegan tantanmen. The shoyu and shio broths are lighter and not as creamy, which might be good for those looking for something not as heavy. (But why come all the way out here, wait in an excruciatingly long line, and not get the best?) I also tried the oysters in shoyu dare oil ($5), which were not bad. The menu states 4 pieces...they gave us 6, but they were very small and not plated very nicely. 

Mensho Tokyo is one of Japan's most acclaimed ramen bars, and this very location in SF's Tenderloin district, is their first international shop outside of Japan. This location has been open for over a year now, but the long wait is still there. I came late Saturday evening (10:15pm) trying to avoid the long line, but it wasn't late enough. I still had to wait 45 minutes (only!?) and didn't get seated till just after 11:00pm. (They close at 11:30pm and there were people being seated all the way to the end.) I hate long waits, but the tori paitan ramen was well worth the travel out and 45 minute wait. On a positive side note, the restaurant was clean, the bathroom was clean, and their food safety score is 100.
author: Jean S.

description:
The food is about as amazing as the wait to get in isn't. 

It took 45 minutes to get in at dinner time, which was terrifying because I had tickets to see Aladdin at Orpheum (it was magical, by the way). Don't come here for a date, because the communal tables make way for unsolicited conversations with neighbors and a complete lack of personal space. 

But this is about ramen. And man oh man, while it is pricey for ramen, it was the best vegan/vegetarian ramen I've ever had. I didn't think Kayo Ramen Bar in Portland could be topped in that department. I'll be honest: in my veggie ramen dining experience, I've always just wanted a bowl of noodles, because the broth--the core of a ramen bowl--is never anything special. But this broth was rich. Flavorful. Fulfilling. If you're a vegetarian or vegan who wants a truly complete bowl of ramen, you're home.
author: Ashish B.

description:
When I saw the line at Mensho, I figured it would be a place I'd have to visit.  You don't often see a long line of people waiting for food in Nob Hill (especially in the rain), but I decided I would try to visit there during a different day; I hoped that if I arrived on the earlier side I could beat the mob.  

Fast forward to a subsequent Sunday-I arrive about 15 minutes prior to opening and the line was already massive.  After waiting about an hour, I finally got a seat (good thing I was only a party of one), and I was taken to a shared table setting.  If you are going to Mensho, you better be comfortable with sitting next to strangers, as you will be placed at a long table.  While the seating felt somewhat cramped, I did not mind the seating arrangement too much.  

I tried the Tori Paitan, which came with both duck and pork chashu in a rich broth.  This was my first time having duck chashu, and while I appreciated its tender texture, I think I prefer my ramen with just pork (I tend to find duck meat to be somewhat hit or miss).  Overall, I thought the ramen was good, but I did not think it was worth waiting on a long line for it.
author: Keith H.

description: We always get here before the opening time. The noodles are nice and chewy because they are freshly pulled. Their broth is savory and they have creative twists, such as using matcha. My wife brought my mother, who is very particular about noodles here and she gave it her seal of approval.
author: Gabriel M.

description: This has been on my to-try list forever. It's been touted as the best ramen in the city. The bf and I came around 5:40 on a weekday and still waited just under an hour to be seated. It's not a big place. They are actually pretty quick with the turnaround. Seats are not open for very long, which I appreciate as someone who's hungry and waiting for food. While in line, we were able to peruse the menu and decide beforehand so we were able to order right away. We got the tori paitan (with double chashu) and the organic shoyu ramen. I liked the tori paitan better with the thick broth and rich flavor. I'm not sure if the double chasui gets you more pork chasui or more of the duck chasui or both. But I really liked the duck chasui - it's very unique. The shoyu ramen had a thinner noodle than the paitan. The broth was good but got really salty the more you kept drinking it. Food came out quickly and service was fine, quick for the most part.
author: Alison W.

description:
If you're looking for rich, decadent dashi, Mensho is the place to go! I haven't been to a restaurant that does it better. It's pricey for ramen (expect to pay around $20) but it's delicious!! There's no reservations and no waitlist - you just line up in front of the restaurant. Expect at least an hour wait. We met around 8 on a Friday night and we didn't get in until 9:15. The restaurant is small with communal seating with raised chairs. Like most places in SF, parking is awful around this area. 

They have a small menu selection that's straight to the point. I got the Tori Paitan and it was AMAZING. The pork melts in your mouth, the noodles were perfect, and the broth was unlike any other. Another person got the spicy lamb, which was also very good but I preferred the Tori Paitan over it. 

If you're looking for a life-changing ramen experience, you have to go to Mensho!
author: Poy W.

description:
I don't understand why there is always a long line for this place? When we saw there was basically no line late on a Tuesday night, we figured we'd see what the hype was. It was decent, but we came away agreeing there was no way we'd actually wait in that line.

We got the Tori Paitan and the lamb. Their signature is too heavy - could basically feel my arteries clog. I thought the lamb was not harmonious, and it was super annoying trying to dig around for the little ground lamb bits. The space is small and a bit cramped. The wait staff are always hovering and try to rush you out. I get it, they want to serve more people, but jeez, let me finish my last bite and put my chopsticks down before you slip the bill on the table.

Also, it's super douchey that their website cover photo is of the line outside. C'mon Mensho, that's way too self-promotional.
author: Eva W.

description: I absolutely hate waiting in line and if I'm forced to, your food better justify my wait or else it's a 1 star! I was trying to treat my friend Nick to a birthday dinner and told him to choose somewhere and he picked Mensho out of all places. Now, my BF lives across the street and I've never tried it because of the lines, again I hate lines. I don't like over hyped hipster joints and waiting in line for ramen is absurd to me because it's just ramen. As good as it will be, it'll just always be ramen (haters are gonna hate on me for that one). Anyways, I sucked it up and decided to take him there along with my bf. We got into line before the restaurant opened and we still waited 1.5 hours on a Sunday! Anyways, I see a sign for the special and it looks like wagyu ramen and they only make 10 of the specials a day so when it's gone it's dunzo. We all were like OK it'll for sure be all gone by the time we get seated as there were at least 30 people who ate before us. We finally got seated and saw the ramen special menu on top of our actual menu. I quickly asked the server if this was still available. He said there were only 4 more (I guess the $40 price point scared patrons away - woo hoo SF pricing). I instantly said, we'll take 3 (me, bf, my friend Nick) and he hurried to put it in the system. The ramen came out moments later (actually almost instantly) the wagyu was HUGE! Like have you ever been to House of Prime rib and got the King's cut? Well yes, it was massive and filled to the brims on the bowl and they gave TWO huge slices, nowww that justified the price. If they were going to give me some sliced pieces in the ramen I'd be annoyed but Ok, I'm down to spend that much on good ass steak imported from Japan and all. Now, I see all these complaints by other Yelpers about the broth being too rich and yadiyadiya and how they've had ramen in Japan and this isn't shit. I TOO have had ramen in Japan and to be honest, I think this was better - oops :X Food in Japan is actually not as salty or "seasoned" as it is in the USA. My sister who lived abroad in Japan has said that as well. But to be honest I like my broth flavorful and rich and fatty. I don't want no clear soup with some winter melon AZN shizz. Anyways it's all preference and I can't say for the other ramen on the menu as I've only had the special but if you want to throw down on the $40 ramen (and if you get lucky to be 1/10) then I'd say it's totally worth the wait. I'm now a believer!
author: Yvonne L.

description:
I've heard rave reviews from friends, strangers and Uber drivers alike, but unfortunately, I didn't find the food nearly as appetizing. Mensho Tokyo is a cute little ramen shop that offers all communal and bar seating with a capacity of about 28. This place is extremely popular, so expect a wait of roughly 45 - 90 minutes, depending on when you go.

Of course, what we care about is the food, so let's get to it. I ate the Tori Paitain ramen. The smell and taste of the broth is extremely meaty. While I'm a huge fan of meat, I actually found it to be a bit too meaty for my tastes (which I didn't think was possible). The actual toppings - the pork chashu, duck chashu and veggies - were also pretty mediocre. What I found to be this establishment's saving grace were the noodles. These are some of the best noodles I've had. Cooked to perfection, these noodles are spring and soak up the broth like no other.

All in all, I didn't find the food to my taste so I won't be coming back for a second round. However, I believe other ramen shops in the city can learn a thing or two of how to prepare great noodles!
author: Tyler W.

description:
This review is an overall experience from Mensho Tokyo.

Wait 
I waited an hour just to get in.

Customer Service (1.5 stars)
When I reached the front of the line with my party, a podium, with the menu on top of it, was by the entrance. I was looking at the menu when the Japanese tapestry on a metal rod that was loosely hanging above the podium came off the hinges because of the wind and fell on top of my head. The hostess was busy inside and when she came back outside and I told her what occurred, she simply said, "oh okay, can you help me put this back up?" Wtf. No acknowledgement and no apology given. I currently have a bump on my head and mind you, am now experiencing a headache the night of which continued the following day(today). What irks me is that she had the audacity to actually ask ME to put it back up?!? I was mad and told her I will not put it back up, so she asked other people in line to put it back up - which they did eventually. 

Once seated, the waitresses were nice but still wasn't enough to compensate for that horrible experience with that hostess.

Facility (1 stars)
The place was tight and barely had any room for my arms. I felt quite uncomfortable while eating.
When I went to the bathroom, it was a simple design but expected it to be cleaner for a Michelin Restaurant. With the toilet paper on the floor, overflowing garbage container, graffiti (which could easily be fixed) you would think you are walking inside a bathroom at Walmart.

Food (5 stars)
The moment you sit down on the table, you are given a menu and laminated paper in regards of their A5 Wagyu Ramen that they "only make 10 bowls a day" A friend of mine who was with me told me what Wagyu and the ratings (A1-A5) meant so my expectation was quite high when I ordered the A5 Wagyu Ramen. When I ate it, it literally melted in your mouth. It was probably the best beef I ever tasted. It really was worth the price and actually went above my high expectations. The light and tasty broth slowly cooked the thinly sliced meat. The ramen noodles were cooked perfectly. This is the only saving grace of an otherwise horrible, horrible experience of this restaurant.
author: C C.

description: Amazing vegan ramen!! The noodles were incredible and the broth was very rich and tasty. Wish it was a tad less salty but I am extremely impressed  will be back for sure
author: Ali P.

description: This ramen place is a real deal. I'm a ramen fanatic and this place is one of the best, the most serious ramen so far. The broth is so rich, even the dry ramen is so intense in flavor. Would give them 5 stars if they improve the wait time. Definitely not a place when you're hungry and cannot stand waiting for at least 45 min.
author: Craig W.

description:
Finally tried the ramen place everyone in SF has been raving about.
The wait is definitely quite long - when we arrived at around 430 there were already around 22-24 people ahead of us. If you want to make it the first wave I would start waiting in line earlier to be safe since anyone after the cutoff would have basically been waiting since before store hours open and have to wait for people to finish. Luckily we made it! 

Interior is small and seats maybe 26 people. 

I got the most well-known speciality, the Tori Paitan.  The soup is a really creamy broth, for me too heavy too drink but because of its thickness it sticks to the noodles well. However I would say the soup doesn't really have too much to a flavor to it; I prefer broth more with a shoyu taste. This ramen comes with menma (marinated bamboo shoots), fried/dried burdock strips (SO delicious and fragrant, was one of my fav things about the ramen that made it even better) and kale (tender with flavor goes surprisingly well with everything else). The ramen also comes with a slice of pork chashu which is super soft & just melts in your mouth as well as a couple small slices of duck chashu equally as soft.

I recommend an add-on ajitama (egg) and they give you the option or soy or miso based.

I really liked the noodles -they're thick and chewy with that "Q" texture.
 
Overall very delicious and unique. Only downside is the steep price (but I guess this is the SF ramen price range) & long wait with fewer seats. I would say it's not better than all the LA ramen but definitely offers something different. Would definitely come again to try out the other menu items such as their soupless ramen!
author: Shirley L.

description:
I came here to catch up with a good friend of mine after a long day of interview at UCSF. He wanted to come here for a while, so we both decided to come with hearty appetites and waited about an hour before we were seated. 

The line was long on a Friday night, but the food was really worth it. I ordered the Tori Paitan, which was rich and creamy ramen that I needed to fuel up my belly! Although it's a little pricey for a bowl, the restaurant live up to its name for its Michelin star. The staff was swift and organized, which made my experience a good one for a LA native who went to SF for the first time. 

Overall, I highly recommend this place for good ramen in SF! There's other places to check out nearby, a good excuse to walk around after a full meal! :)
author: Jacklyn A.

description: Got the organic shoyu and it was just okay. Came here around 9pm for a late night meal so only had to wait maybe 40 minutes. I think this may be a personal preference but I find the broth here much too rich and heavy. The noodles had a great chewy texture but we all had such a difficult time finishing our bowls.
