I will say the staff here is super friendly and kind though - one person in my group got her bowl a lot later than the rest of us and they gave us a free appetizer.
author: Cheng X.

description:
I was adventurous and ordered the Matcha Tori Paitan Ramen. Given that I'm a fan of matcha everything, my opinion can be a little biased, but I found the matcha ramen very delicious! The matcha flavor offset the rich creaminess in the soup base somewhat, which tasted refreshing to me.

Getting there before the restaurant opens seems to help reduce the wait time - I was able to get in within about 35 minutes in line. Wish the would consider opening for lunch!
author: Iris K.

description:
Two words. VEGAN RAMEN. Three more words. GET IT NOW. 

But seriously, no joke, it's THE best vegan ramen. Ever. I've been a pescotarian for about 17yrs now, and have tried just about every version of vegan, vegetarian and pescotarian ramen available in the Bay Area...and this one here is by far the best. Even my meat-loving-eating friends agree! 

Let's get down to the nitty gritty. 

Wait times are long. If you hate waiting for dinner, this is not the best spot to hit up during a hangry spell. If you're down to wait a little bit, get here just before opening at 5pm. There's about 20ish seats available and they make their ramen pretty quickly. On the upside, their seat turnover is fairly efficient since the seating is open shared long tables (not a place to eat slowly and chill with your buds). 

Note that this isn't a write your name down and come back kind of spot. It's a stand in line like elementary school kids til you're called on kind of spot. The line starts to die down around 8:30-9ish. Basically, good for late night eating if that's your thing.  

WORTH IT. Five stars!
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Let me first preface my review by saying I really don't understand why this place forces you to wait outside its door in a line. Why not give out numbers? Customers literally cannot go do something else while waiting, and it's a big time waste. Why force wasting of (a LOT of people's) time? To prove what, exactly? I'm fine with waiting, but I'm not fine with a restaurant being so arrogant to force its customers to mandatorily wait in a line. The only reasons I can think of for this is: a) marketing - if there's a lot of people waiting, it must be good so let's convince even more people to waste their time to wait in line to eat at this place! and b) efficiency - if people are readily available, the restaurant can immediately seat people when a table clears out. Reason a is just selfish. Reason b can be solved by warning customers that if they're not there when they're called, they will be skipped over/crossed out. Or better yet, they can actually invest in a good technology system of calling/texting people. A bunch of restaurants have this, and I very much appreciate places that do. PLEASE change your must-wait-in-line policy. It's just selfish, arrogant, and wastes a LOT of people's time. Making people sign in on a sheet of paper or with one of the waiters/waitresses is fine; don't have to get all fancy with technology. But please think about your customers.
I waited in line for about 25 minutes on a Wednesday evening; I got into line at 5:45PM and got seated at 6:10PM. I was handed a menu and my order was taken shortly after. I got the spicy tori paitan ramen with the spicy stuff on the side - I wanted it on the side so I could taste the soup in its original form. I forgot to ask for no bamboo. The noodles also took their sweet time to come out, but I know they were getting freshly cooked since I had a seat that was right in front of the kitchen. They have timers to tell the noodle person when to take the noodles out! Amazing. I waited at least ten minutes for my noodles to get served, but it was piping hot when it did and the spicy chili flakes and the jalapeno miso sauces were on the side. The soup was quite thick but not overpowering, and it was pretty good. I REALLY liked the jalapeno miso sauce. It was very flavorful and had a nice kick. I ended up using most of it in my soup and the chili flakes were more for show than anything else; they didn't taste spicy. I also really enjoyed the noodles; they were really chewy and thick, and they're probably one of my personal favorite ramen noodles I've had. I ate my noodles in about ten minutes though I did try really hard not to eat them too fast so as to enjoy them. I ate everything in my bowl except the bamboo. Oh also the one thick slice of chasu I got: very flavorful and a good amount of meat (versus fat). There were also fried onions which added an extra fragrant flavor and pieces of cabbage which added texture and a break from the thick broth. 
At the high price of $20.99 including tax and mandatory 15% tip, I definitely expected more than one measly piece of meat. Also no egg?! The service was pretty good as the waitresses were all quite friendly (note: why is everyone serving the food a female and all the cooks male?). Good portion of noodles though.
Please get your wasting-time-in-mandatory-line policy changed.
author: Andrea W.

description:
The ramen was good.  I had the Tori Paitan, because that is supposed to be the best.  The broth was flavorful, creamy, and unique.  I enjoyed the bowl of soup and the noodles.

I thought the chashu was good, but not great.  The duck was super tender and not bad, but I'm not a huge fan of duck.

I probably wouldn't go back because of the typical 1 hour wait, the prices (which seemed high to me) and you basically have to sit down, eat and get out.

I know ramen can be expensive and that is probably why I don't go out to ramen that often.  It can easily run you over $20 for a bowl if you add an egg after tax and tip (15% service charge is included automatically (I kind of like this feature)).

The service was fast and sufficient.  Waters were filled regularly.

I also tried one of the other ramens (I forget the name, started with a S, so it is one of two different possibilities) and it was too salty and a little fishy for my taste.  I certainly wouldn't drop $20+ to have a bowl of that one.

If you are a ramen enthusiast, you will probably love this place, especially if price is no obstacle for you.  Either way, give them a try and see how you like it.
author: Ty C.

description:
Got referred here by a friend who now lives in the city.  I seen posts on her instagram that she has the UME Ramen.

When I read the description i was wondering how it would all taste together, but i figured give it a try since we dont have anything like it in hawaii.

surprisingly, all the flavors worked out! the ume didnt overpower or make the dish super sour.  it was just the right amount and cut into pieces that were managable.

The spoon.  Its a odd shaped spoon that is hard to fit in your mouth and doesnt pick up much soup.  but it'll do.

No take outs.  They do not let you take out food so if you dont finish, then its wasted.  I dont like that style, but to each its own.
author: Dayneen M.

description:
3.5 stars but I'm rounding up for the unique experience.

Get here at least 40 minutes early to get first round seating otherwise you'll wait 1 hour before you get seated. The staff was quick and efficient and the restaurant is fairly small. They offer a modern, trendy ambiance and play R&B music. 

We got the spicy Tori Paitan ramen which was good but a bit too rich/heavy and not what I expected. When they advertise rich and creamy broth that is what you get. The broth is thick like gravy so if you were expecting a cleaner broth you'll be disappointed. 

The meat was amazing and it melts in your mouth! We didn't realize the Spicy Tori Paitan didn't come with duck but I tried some from another friend's bowl. It was delicious and served medium rare. They do their meats right here! You can also order side meats for added protein. 

The enoki chips were yummy and perfectly crispy. The oysters on the other hand are too salty for my palate and 1 order was really enough but we ordered 2 for 5 people. 

Overall, I thought Mensho was good and offered a unique experience for your taste buds but I much prefer Ramen Parlor and Ramen Dojo but the ambiance at Mensho is so much cooler!
author: Jeanne L.

description: Spicy lamb was so good. The broth was probably the best I have ever had but I heard other people complaining they had another type and they didn't like it and it had a fishy flavor. So if you like spicy go for the spicy lamb that's all I can vouch for here. I woke up today I'm still craving that ramen.
author: Shannon B.

description: Turns out you can get any of their Ramen broths made to order without MSG! I ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen that way with a single Chashu and extra firm noodles. It was perfection! I really loved the duck and the kale in this Ramen. The only thing I wasn't a fan of was the crispy burdock root fries which quickly became soggy.
author: Khamis H.

description:
Haven't had a chance to try Mensho out yet since I was always a little concerned about how long the wait would be, but it actually wasn't terrible! Dropped by with a friend on a Wed night around 6:20pm and ended up waiting about half an hour. One of the workers initially quoted me 20 min, and it sounded too good to be true, but it ended up being a close estimate! 

Cute decor inside with a couple of high, communal tables and stools. You will definitely be getting cozy with your neighbors so don't expect to have any private conversations here =P. 

I liked that they had some wicker baskets below the tables where you could put your stuff, very female-friendly, I dig it. There's also a small shelf below the rim of each table where you can keep you phone handy to take pictures =). 

I ordered the Tori Paitan with an egg on top (the eggs come in your choice of miso or soy sauce flavor, which is unique!). I got the soy sauce flavor which basically reminded me of a tea egg. I wasn't sure what to expect, but I think it was worth the hype! I don't know if I'd wait an hour plus for it (I've gotten lazier as I've gotten older), but the ramen was delicious, with a creamy flavorful broth, pork and duck slices and even some surprisingly tasty and well-cooked kale. I slurped up every drop. 

Best ramen I've had in SF!
author: Vivian L.

description:
This place has hype and a line out the door to complement. The quality and craftsmanship of the ramen are top notch--- but you really need to know what you are getting yourself into.

First, expect to wait an hour, or more. People line up for this place, and I've seen lines most every day of the week.

Second, this is the thickest and creamiest ramen I've ever had. Think about eating light gravy. Even the lighter shoyu ramen is on the heavier side.

Each ingredient is prepped to perfection, with the chashu being one of the better ones I've had in the city. The broth had tons of flavor and the noodles were solid as well.

If you are looking for a gourmet ramen experience with a heavy tonkatsu prepared to perfection, this is the place for you. If you hate lines and/or want something on the lighter side, then skip this place.
author: James S.

description: The best Ramen I ever had. Waited an hour with 4 other friends. Don't think I would had waited alone. This Ramen was special. We ordered one vegan ramen, one clam, one lamb, one tonkatsu, one soy sauce ramen. We savored every bite while people in line were salivating watching us eat. Will come again.
author: Steve S.

description: Delicious broth, chewy noodles, it was a good bowl, but not the best I've had. Surprisingly, that award still goes to the Ramen Shop in Oakland. My friend ordered the matcha version thinking the noodles would be green, but no, they cover the top of the ramen in the powder, so beware.
author: Andrea Y.

description:
Tori paitan ramen - one of the best I've ever had. Worth the hour plus wait. 
RamenRating overall 5/5:

Noodles 4/5
Broth 5/5 - so creamy; so tasty, so perfect. This is not your mana's chicken broth
Chashu 4/5 - yummy duck
Toppings 5/5 - Egg with runny yolk, other good toppings
Spicyiness - not spicy and that's perfect for this bowl. Don't bother with spicy. 
Value 4/5 - $17 for a medium sized portion

Other mentions:
Lamb ramen is great.
Matcha (green tea) in tori paitan is interesting; Worth trying for novelty. 
Sushi bowls are forgettable.
author: Billy D.
Miko B.

description: I've been wanting to come here for a long time but the long line really put me off. The bf and I came here last night around 930pm and there were only a few people in line and we ended up waiting for about 20 minutes or so. I got the popular tai pan ramen and he got the vegan ramen. It was very rich, creamy and flavorful. The noodles were a bit thicker than other ramen places. The ramen was a little rich and heavy for my taste. The broth was also very salty. I felt extremely thirsty afterwards. I can see why people enjoy it because it was so flavorful. I doubt I'd wait 2 hours for this though. Didnt live up to its hype to me.
author: Linda P.

description: Straight outta Tokyo.  The depth and complexity of this broth you just can't get anywhere.  Holy moly.  It had layer upon layer of taste, the noodles were thick and so fresh, and I added toppings that were unique and delicious.  We waited about 50 minutes on a Sunday, but it was fine, and it was so worth it.
author: Susie D.

description:
I'm not a big ramen person, nor am I a fan for waiting in line to be seated for the newest "hotspot," but as per my brothers' nagging me that Mensho Tokyo might turn my opinion on ramen around, I may have been convinced.

On a cold January night in San Francisco, as the night was ending and people were getting off of work, I decided to give this place my 30-45 minutes of time in line to try and see why people are loving this place. (I heard the wait can be up to an hour, but we got lucky by coming in around 8pm.)

The Vegan Tantanmen Ramen, as highly raved about and sounding DELICIOUS, immediately caught my eye. A creamy, rich edamame and soy-based ramen using several types of nuts in its broth delivered a FLAVOR bomb in my mouth! I've never had ramen so thick and creamy, with a slight spice to taste, and authentic preparation of noodles.

I love the concept of Mensho putting care into their dishes to produce quality-tasting ramen prepared in a very traditional way. The $18 price tag for a bowl is definitely worth a try (can be higher if you add extras to your dish) as the flavors are incredible. Consider this an upscale ramen spot giving you quality ramen and flavors. I could barely finish my bowl but I don't think I've ever had ramen taste that creamy or rich in my LIFE... Definitely something I can't have everyday or on the regular.

Service was prompt and friendly. Got our meals out in a reasonable time as they are very efficient at trying to seat you and rotate customers around. Mensho, I've gotta give it to you for providing thick, creamy, flavor bombs of ramen. You made this non-ramen fan actually appreciate ramen, and I think that says a lot!
author: Rachel Ann C.

description:
Very good hearty ramen that delivers with consistency.  One of the best ramen I have ever had and super popular as you can tell from the lines and the reviews of this place. Is it worth it? Yes, if you don't have to wait that long. I jumped in line 30 minutes before it opened so I really didn't have to wait that long (on a weekday). The staff is definitely efficient and fast with a friendly attitude which is awesome. Make sure you know what's going on with the menu as they always have specials that run out daily with the first batch of patrons. I love the food !.  The broth is savory and consistent, though you know when you had enough of it as your palette can only take so much goodness. The noodles are delicious and have a nice bounce to it. Overall, it's almost to hipster-ish but good food. Is it worth the wait? Only if you have time. 
Pros: Food, staff
Cons: Lines, wait
Stars: 4.25
author: Sunny L.

description:
I don't see a lot of folks talking about it so I will: Try the Abura Soba - aka soupless ramen. 

For the uninitiated, this is basically a bowl with all the same stuff in ramen aside from the broth. At the very bottom are oil and seasonings, which you mix with the noodles and toppings in your bowl. Comes with vinegar and chili oil to customize to your preference. 

I fell in love with this stuff while I was in Japan last fall and have been looking for it in the Bay Area since. This is IT. 

I also ordered a small chashu rice bowl on the side, which might have been overkill, but considering that line was like 20 minutes long (to be fair, it moved a lot faster than it would seem looking at it from the outside), I wanted to make it worth my time.

Things to note:

- DO NOT TIP. (kinda like how they do it in Japan)
- THEY DO NOT GIVE TO GO BOXES OR DO TAKE-OUT (you can bring your own container)
- NO LARGE PARTIES. Everyone sits at communal tables and it's a small-ass place to begin with so take your 20 close friends elsewhere. This is best for date night, hanging out with your parents or grabbing a quick dinner by yourself.

Worth the hype!
author: Aivy C.

description: We ordered the vegan tantanmen, and it was downright delicious! Easily one of my favorite ramen spots in the city. We waited for about 35 min on a Friday night, but it was totally worth it.
author: Mansi D.

description:
Be prepared to wait 40 mins - an hour unless you come before they open or wayyyyy late at night. The wait is worth it! 

I've heard great reviews from friends about Mensho and finally had the opportunity to try myself. Everything on the menu sounded delicious and unique so it was a pretty difficult choice. I opted for the spicey lamb ramen  because I LOVE lamb (that's one way to choose, right!) My girlfriend and I also ordered the fried enoki (omg such a great decision) and we loved every single bite of it. 

Fried enoki ($5) - aroma was sensational. (Tho to be fair, fried things generally smell amazing!) the earthy taste, omg, and crunchy crisp texture were soooo perfect together. 

Ramen - Menaho is known for their ramen. I absolutely LOVED the noodles because they were chewy and thick. The spicey lamb ramen came with ground lamb, which I wish were thinly spiced lamb. I didn't love the ground lamb but did enjoy the how gamey lamb made everything else. (Am I weird for liking how gamey lamb is?) Soup was rich, creamy, spicey, and none of the tastes/texture were overpowering. If we were to put the spicey level on a scale of 10, I'd say it was a 4. The kick kept you wanting to eat more without stopping, because the instant you stop your tongue stings. I loved it! The soup base was the heaviest out of all the items on the menu and I am so glad to have tried it. I didn't realize how full I was from the noodles (carbs, yay!) and thick creamy soup base until I stood up!  needless to say I was ready to go back home and food coma 

Next time I want to go back and try the dry mixed noodles and will circle back with an updated review. 

P.S. 
- There are about 28-30 seats in the small space, split into for communal tables and one bar table area. Be prepared to sit next to randos, which could be a lot of fun! 
-They also play pretty up beat music which in a way makes you eat faster. 
- 15% gratuity will be automatically added to your bill.
author: Dana Z.

description:
Very good ramen. The broth and the texture of the noodles are exceptionally good. This place is really popular so if you're planning on coming here then plan ahead and go early because even if you arrive before opening time (5 pm), a line surely is will have already formed. On a Sunday, we arrived there at 4:50ish and we couldn't believe the long line that was already there. Good thing, my husband and I are always willing to wait for good food. Yes, we are those types of people. 

Overall, it was worth the wait!!! We were all very happy. I recommend the creamy ramens and the fried enoki mushroom appetizers are a must!!!
author: elizabeth t.

description:
My tip to everyone one that would wait in line for this place, take note of the last person in line then head down to Rye and grab a quick drink. When we did that the line was gone and we were the next person in line.

The Japanese herb ale was light and refreshing. It complimented the ramen considering the ramen I choose was really rich.

We order the oyster which was briney and fishy however it more marinated and surprising to the Bite.

The tori Panitan was super rich. It felt like the broth was just straight up duck fat. I like the ramen however this isn't a place I would die for.
author: Jackie N.

description:
Worth. The. Wait. 

Now, it might depend exactly how long that wait is, the weather, how fun your company is, and your level of hangry, but me and my boo got there at 4:10 on a cold but dry Sunday to be first in line and I'd take that any day. Note by 4:40 first seating (28 people) was filled, and by 5:00 so was second seating. 

I've had good vegan ramen before but this was out of this world. Frankly, I can't imagine finding better. Creamy, nutty, with a hint of barbecue flavor, there was the perfect amount of everything and the noodles were perfectly cooked. I don't think any meat eaters would feel they're missing out with that broth. Now, excuse me while I replay those flavorful bites in my head.
author: Cristina S.

description:
The GOOD: Mensho was mind-blowing and totally worth the 25-30 minute wait (despite it being a Sunday evening)

The BAD: This was my first time eating ramen at a restaurant (EVER. I know...)

The AMAZING: The Tori Paitan. I didn't order it myself but I fell in love with how creamy, rich, and smooth this broth was. I was having dinner with a ramen afficinado who claimed this was Top 3 best bowl of ramen he's ever had. I thoroughly enjoyed my own shoyu ramen with duck but next time I'm coming for this. 

The FUNNY: There's a lot to do once you've conquered the line and are ushered in. You can read about the molecular chemistry of key ramen glutamates which is painted onto the wall. You can watch the TV screen which plays Twitch-style food videos of other people eating ramen...or you can just watch other patrons slurping away from their bowls of umami goodness. Note: Aforementioned options are all equally agonizing.
author: Arushi S.

description: Not as good as expected. Maybe Chicken Paitan is not for me. Will try shio ramen next time. The oyster tasted like too much.
author: Xiaoshi Y.

description: To be honest, I don't really buy into the hype. I got the Tori Paitan as that's the one everyone raves about, and as someone who is 100% a fan of a proper soup/broth, I was stoked for it to come. But I found that the broth was like a gravy. It was SO THICK. It's not rich in a way that makes me think deep extract if bones or a ton of flavor - it's the kind of rich that makes me think they must have added cuts of pure fat to the broth. Besides the broth, everything else was good - I just wasn't able to get over the soup.
author: Jessie Y.

description: I seem to be the only person who thought the ramen was overhyped. The broth was too thick, rich, and oily for my tastes - could barely finish my bowl which never happens to me with ramen. Noodles were thick and the right texture. Meat was also good. Unfortunately, I don't think it was worth the wait and even without a wait, I'd go elsewhere.
author: Leslie C.

description:
Loved their ramen
Loved their oysters 
Did not love waiting an hour in line
Did not love that there is no take out
Did not love that I couldn't take food to go
Although I do love the idea of bringing your own Tupperware if you want to take it to go. 

Next time I will bring my own Tupperware because I can not eat a whole bowl to myself and I love leftovers and I love their ramen! Thick broth yummy meat and delicious noodles.
author: Maria K.

description:
My cousin recommended this place, said this place was better than many famous ramen restaurants. I was hyped about it as I loveeeeee ramen! I was warned to arrive early as this place always have a line out the door. But since my friend and my schedule didn't permit us to get there early, we got there around 5:30pm. Looking at the line, I thought to myself that this place must be good if all these people are willing to stand around in this neighborhood. As we got to the front of the line, we looked through the menu and saw a selection of different flavored ramen. Everything on the menu sounded interesting so we decided to each get a different flavor ramen to share. We also noticed a tip disclaimer by their menu posted outside that there is a 15% mandatory service fee added to each bill. 

We got seated and decided to order four different ramens: Maccha Tori Paitan, Spicy Lamb, Shio, and Clam Butter Chashu Ramen. We placed our order with our waitress and as she was about to walk away I asked if they have Pepsi or Coke for my boyfriend. Instead of being polite and professional, she gave my boyfriend and I a snooty response, "UH NO". Okay?!?!?! Wouldn't be more professional to say something like, "I apologize but our restaurant does not carry sodas"??? But how dare you respond to us in that tone, those words, and in such a disapproved expression? Who are you to disapprove what he likes to drink? If you don't have it, it's fine but don't disrespect us like that! Is this what your mandatory service fee includes, being rude???

Ramen arrived! Each bowl was presented beautifully! We were excited to dig in! We each took a spoonful of broth to try. I had the Spicy Lamb, OMG the broth is not broth, it's gravy! It's thicker than gravy and I cannot taste miso. Isn't this supposed to be MISO? The chashu was not bad, it was tender but lacks flavor. I do like the little kick in spiciness but I wish it was spicier. Overall, I would not recommend this ramen as I like broth type ramen with flavors! My boyfriend got the Shio and yes it came in a broth but it was way too salty and again lack flavor! Where are the chicken and pork flavors in this broth? Was this just salt water with soy sauce for coloring??? And then guess what happened? The same snooty waitress came by with a pitcher of water and asked to refill our waters. She was pleasant when she filled my glass but when she got to my boyfriend, she didn't say anything and just reach between my boyfriend's face and his ramen with her pitcher and dripped water into the ramen. How rude can you be? Didn't even acknowledged what she did and just went off. I mean the water helped a little in diluting the broth but really?!?! Anyway, my cousin got the Matcha and it was matcha flavored! YAY! But that was it! The taste of Matcha powder sprinkled on the ramen! My bestie got the Clam Butter Chashu ramen. We all tasted the broth and we all agreed that the broth tasted the best out of ours.  It has a scoop of butter, we assumed, on top of the ramen but turns out my bestie said it tasted like sour cream. She didn't think that will mix well with her ramen so she decided to remove it. She did the right thing or her ramen will be ruined. At lease she got the best one out of all the ones we ordered. 

Overall, I was not impressed this place and definitely not going there ever again. Every one has different preference in food so I'm not going to say don't try it as I'm sure this type of ramens suit other people's taste.
author: kaY C.

description:
Mensho is by far my favorite ramen place in town. I've been here five times in the past few months and I've always experienced great food, friendly and efficient service, and of course... long line. Expect to wait for at least 40 minutes for a smaller party size (2-4 people), and probably longer for bigger groups. 

If you hate waiting in line and don't mind eating late at night, consider going after 9pm on a weekday. I went there for a Wednesday evening ramen run at 10 and waited only 15 minutes to be seated. The only downside is that they might run out of eggs by then. (This might potentially be a deal breaker, I know.)

The best part about their ramen for me has to be the broth. If you love creamy thick broth, either the spicy tori paitan or spicy lamb ramen will be a great choice!

Definitely order some oysters to start! Coming there on an empty stomach is recommended, they don't do takeout. Though if you like it as much as I do, you won't ever need one -- it's so good I always finish it all, even when I'm already so full I could barely walk.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
I had their vegan ramen! It's to die for. The line is pretty long and you have to wait about 30-45 minutes, but it's definitely am worth the wait.

The ramen itself is flavorful, a little spicy and has a nutty flavor (probably because they use 7 different nuts for their base). The toppings are fresh and the service is good.
author: Briggs S.

description:
LOVE: The long and chewy noodles!
HATE: Your stupid ridiculous lines
LOVE: The creamy and thick broth
HATE: Why is your shop so small?!?
LOVE: The Vegan Tantanmen deserves an award!
HATE: Do you only open at night time to torture us?
LOVE: Can I have your miso egg recipe, please?
HATE: Your location sucks. 
LOVE: Once seated, food comes out quick
LOVE: The portion is enough to make me satisfied
LOVE: You close midnight, but you STILL have a line -_____-

Mensho easily takes the bronze for ramen in Fiona's Ramen Olympics along with Wasabi. 

Gold = Daikokuya Little Tokyo (LA)
Silver = Shin Sen Gumi (LA)
Bronze = Mensho / Wasabi (IL)
author: Fiona L.

description: Finally got around to trying Mensho now that the hype has kind of died down, and was not disappointed! Their signature dish is the tori Paitan with duck and pork chashu and is a must try for any ramen fan (just remember to order an egg separately). Got there around 6p on a Friday and the wait was about 30 min, not bad for SF. The shio ramen is pretty good too.
author: EJ A.

description:
We walked to this place after a thrilling escape room experience.  This place opens at 5pm and we got in line around 5:20pm. Parking, like most of SF, seemed about impossible so try to utilize a ride share company or public transit to get here. 

The restaurant is tiny and tables are kind of communal, so you'll be sitting at a table with other customers. We were lucky and sat next to a nice repeat customer. After our 30-45 min wait in line, we wanted to try the store's specialty, the Tori Paitan. 

The Tori Paitan was super rich, but I actually want to say it was too rich. This reminded me of Tsujita's tsukemen in LA, but as a broth rather than a tsukemen dipping sauce. It was rich, and almost greasy like a pasta sauce. Weird description, but I am not sure how else to describe it. The thing is, part way through, I started to have trouble finishing it. The noodles were a great texture, and the meat toppings were amazingly tender, but the soup really needed something to lighten it.

By the end, the soup itself also started to taste and feel gritty. I thought I was imagining it, but my friend agreed with me. Tsujita in LA provides a lime wedge with their tsukemen and it makes all the difference. The nice repeat customer sitting at our table suggested trying the soy sauce flavor ramen, as it is a less rich broth. If I come back, I'll probably do that, or try the shio.

Bottom line: if you've never had super rich ramen broth this is something to try, but shio may be a better option than the Tori Paitan. If the Tori Paitan was a tsukemen or had some acidity we could add to the broth, I'd give it 5 stars.
author: Kathy O.

description: Awesome. Worth the wait once every 6 months. I'd still say the broth isn't as sophisticated as the broths in Nojo's dishes, but these are the only two ramen spots worth frequenting. The noodles make the restaurant. Order the clam if it ever returns to the menu.
author: JWest M.

description:
I'm 100% sure this place gave me the food poisoning but ... maybe it was worth it (?) Now that speaks volumes about the broth ... or my standard.

The Tori Paitan was incredible - with a rich, creamy chicken soup, pork chashu, duck chashu, menma, kale, burdock, katsuobushi sauce. Everything about this ramen was standout but the soup blew it out of the park. I've always believed the magic lies in the broth and the broth had a wonderfully aromatic umami flavor. Chashu was great too.

Of course, don't forget that touch of kale because... well it's SF.

Skip the enoki chips or use it as tempura. It definitely gets soggy fast. Maybe that's what gave me the food poisoning. 

Line was maybe 30 minutes long starting at 6pm on a Thursday night. Not bad.
author: Cindy W.

description: Great spot!! The wait is long but it is definitely worth it. The soup is creamy and rich.
author: Bo S.

description:
I came here with a friend around 8:30pm on a Friday and finally got seated at around 9:25pm. Yep, a pretty long wait. We both ordered the tori paitan ramen, which costs $16 per bowl. While that may seem pretty expensive for ramen, I feel that it's justified. You get a pretty big serving of chewy noodles, a heap of burdock roots, and some slices of chashu and duck.

Mensho is so different from other ramen joints because they specialize in a very thick chicken based broth. While everyone raves about it, I couldn't find myself enjoying it that much. It left a very grainy texture in my mouth. The chashu, noodles, and burdock were much more enjoyable. Ramen restaurants rely mostly on their broth so while Mensho's broth is super unique, it didn't have enough of an interesting flavor to amaze me.
author: Trang T.

description: Solid food. Had the tori paitan and vegan tantanmen and mushroom chips. Delicious! Very limited seating and the wait was very long. Very cool space though and it has a communal feel.
author: Shalini C.

description:
Mensho Tokyo... my oh my, you are a lost love on new year's day!

I decided to surprise the guy I was seeing at the time, aka my preseny boyfriend , to some nice ramen in SF. & apparently Mensho was a handful of ramen spots in SF that was rather hot, popular & trendy. 

With that in mind, I decided to try out Mensho because it wasn't too far from the Regency Ballroom, and I was surprising him with tickets. It is such a horror, to find a parking spot in this part of town i.e. downtown SF. Always think ahead and plan for the traffic and tourists. 

I am so happy to have found parking about 2 blocks away, and luckily Mensho opened only 40-1 hr before we lined up. The line barely moved, because this place was so popular, it was first come first serve and no reservations. While in line, the guy after us decided to tell us his verdict on Mensho Tokyo, and proclaimed they made the best ramen. He was very specific on the duck ramen, and seemed very drunk lol. At that point we just exchanged a few words and were pretty excited to try Mensho, since we were considered "out of towners," but Bay Area natives (from San Jose/ South Bay).

We finally were able to be seated after 45 min have passed, and the restaurant is very simple and minimalist. If you know how San Francisco and Japan is similar, over populated and save on space. The style of seating arrangements was similar to cafeteria bar tables, where there are several high-bar tables and even amount of stools per table. Many pairs, like ourselfs, are seated across from each other, with barely enough room to stretch. If you are used to having your own space and bubble, be warned, you'll feel how close everyone is while eating here.

The food:

We started off with cooked oysters and they tasted very salty. Kind of how you would eat it out of a can. This wasn't that great as an appetizer, I would have fore gone this altogether. 

We decided to get 2 different types of ramen broths, because why not? So, we could taste and share our meals together, a win-win situation 

OH MY LORDDDD. My ramen was definately delicious. I am a very inquisitive person, and my ramen came in a black bowl while my guy had his ramen in a white bowl. I asked the waitress what the difference meant:

Black bowl: Creamy broth
White bowl: Not creamy broth

1 star: Great variety of ramen
1 star: Delicious broth
1 star: A+ Customer service
1 star: Nicely decorated, interior and thought into seating arrangement
1 star: I would bring my friends

Not your typical or average ramen!!!
author: Vivian V.

description:
I can see why San Francisco would be going crazy for this place.  Coming from Hawaii, I've had a variety of ramen styles, but the Bay Area seems mostly dominated by Tonkatsu style ramen.  This is where Mensho Tokyo comes in with their Tori Paitan ramen, which had an incredibly rich and thicker broth than most of what you'd find in the Bay.  It's very good and I was impressed.  I also enjoyed the noodles here, they were pretty al dente which I usually prefer.  The toppings were also great.  While there wasn't much of it, the duck is worth a try!  Also be sure to get the enoki mushroom chips if you're a fan of the stuff.  They're really good with the chili flakes and the lemon, perfect appetizer.  

As for the wait, we got there around 5pm on a Saturday and ended up making it in the second rotation.  It took under an hour.  The restaurant itself is small so you'll be sitting on communal tables here, just fyi.
author: Bryson L.

description:
Found this place after going to a concert in SF. It was near by and we decide to try it. There wasn't a line just 1 party ahead of us. Apparently during the day there's a long line.

Tried the Tori Paitan Ramen.... Flavorful and creamy broth. The combo with the pork and duck chashu was so good! The Duck chashu has a citrus and tangy hint to it and it tasted delicious with the broth. 

Service was good! It's a small place and seating is communal. The tables have a little area where you can place small belongings. Underneath there are baskets where you can place larger items like purses and backpacks.
author: Hiedie S.

description:
The ramen here is good. Now is it worth the wait which typically is at least an hour or the price? Absolutely not, you can go to plenty of other places in town and get ramen thats decent for no wait and a more reasonable price. 
There is almost always a line here as it is IMO way too over hyped. The place is very small only 4 communal tables so expect to sit close to other people. The service here is meh, not great but not bad. The biggest problem here is the people who come to eat here and honestly I think its more a cultural thing. In asian culture when you go to a ramen shop, you sit, you order, you eat, you pay, and then you leave. There is no time wasted talking and hanging out which american culture expects for any meal which is why this place typically has a terribly long wait. Come here a few hours before they close or right when they open to miss the larger crowds and have a shorter wait, otherwise be prepared mentally and with your stomach to wait. 
The ramen itself it wasn't that bad. Got the Tori Paitan: rich & creamy chicken soup with pork and duck chashu, menma, kale, burdock, and katsuobushi sauce. The soup is very rich and creamy, its a little more overwhelming in flavor then I prefer but good. Its so rich it tastes a little grainy but it works. The noodles are well cooked and the right amount of chewy. The duck and pork chashu were flavorful and a nice addition. I didn't really care for the kale but its SF so not surprising to see it in there. 
The ramen here was good but not worth the long waits or the prices they charge. If you don't mind waiting and want to try something a little different, then i'd say its worth checking out.
author: Peter P.

description: It's just noodles and broth. It's not worth an hour wait, or overcrowded tables, or all the annoying people talking about authenticity and experiences in travel they obviously never had.
author: Stevie D.

description: There was a line we had to stand in. Waited about 30 min which wasn't too bad. The place was pretty small and a little crowded. I liked the design of the place but it could get hot in there also. I tried the Matcha and it was good but not as tasty as the others. Also tried the mushroom chips which were pretty delicious! I would definitely suggest this as a place to try.
author: Yonelle A.

description:
Wow I had high expectations coming in. And I can honestly say it lives up to the hype! I've been wanting to try Mensho since they opened early 2016 but I was too afraid of the long lines and 1+ hour waits. 

Visited on a Wednesday (1/25/17) evening around 5:30pm and got in line. It was about 14-15 people ahead of me. The line moved in batches, 2 or 3 parties at a time. The outfit is small with communal seating for no more than 30. While you're waiting a worker will step out occasionally to get a head count and party size. I was the only one there for my party of four. And I reached the front by 5:50pm. I was worried I wouldn't be seated since no one in my party was there yet. Luckily two more arrived before our seats were available. We were let in by 6:10pm so total wait was about 40 minutes. I was still missing one person. But Mensho didn't trip about it. That was cool of them.  

Onto the food... we ordered the lychee nigori sake and enoki chips to start. Ramen we had the tori pantai x3 and the organic shiyo. The tori was amazing! The broth was so rich and creamy. It reminded me of cream of mushroom. The duck chashu was a treat. You don't see that too often. The noodles were chewy and plenty. Not al dente like many other ramen joints. But it still kept a good texture. The pork chashu was super tender and melts in your mouth. The broth was the biggest winner for me. It was unlike any other ramen I've had in the bay area. 

Final thought: don't let the line detour you from trying Mensho. It's well worth the wait. And it moves relatively fast. Most diners don't sit idle after their meals so turnover is fair. Prices are bit high (ramen + sake + shared appetizer + tax/tips = $30pp). 15% service fee is included automatically on all bills regardless of party size.
author: Stephen Y.

description: This is the best ramen place my bf and I have been to and we come here quite often. The broth is perfect having a rich and creamy taste with melt in your mouth chasu. I'd highly recommend it to anyone but remember that the line usually forms quickly so get there as soon as it opens!
author: Sarah C.

description:
The best ramen I've ever had but it came at the cost of pushy service and a 2 hour wait in line.

FIRST IMPRESSIONS: We got there about 15 minutes after opening and ended up waiting close to 2 hours for a table, even with their communal seating system. It's very well lit inside and there's a decent buzz of conversation.

FOOD: SO GOOD! I'm the type of person who's willing to wait hours for good food so my wait definitely felt justified. I got the Lamb ramen and could barely finish it all in one sitting. Heads up, there aren't any takeout containers so unless you can finish a whole bowl, bring your own container or arrive with an empty stomach.

SERVICE: I understand that there needs to be high table turnover for a restaurant as busy as this so I totally didn't mind when the waiter dropped off our check while we were finishing up. But about 2 minutes later, he came back to check on it despite it being pretty clear we still weren't done and slammed the book cover when he saw I hadn't put my card inside yet.

OVERALL: Honestly, besides the service, it was a really good experience and I'll chalk up the weird service for how busy it was. Definitely recommend!
author: Xin Yi C.

description: Came here on a Sunday evening (5pm) with a friend; waited about 40 minutes before being seated. The space inside is modern but pretty narrow. I got the Spicy Tori Paitan, and the broth was exceptionally rich. I ended up finishing the broth and not the noodles; would come again!
author: Kailin L.

description: Not sure what the hype is for this place. The line was super long and the food wasn't that great. I got the clam ramen. The broth was super salty and tasted like chicken stock from the grocery store. The meet was not dry but was not tender either. The noodles were spectacular. Those noodles were so good that they will upgrade the quality of any ramen. Its unfortunate that the rest of the ramen was subpar. Very dissapointed after a 40min wait.
author: Diane Z.

description:
After seeing the long line outside of this place for over a year, I decided to try it out on a weekend. We got there right when it opened (5pm) and waited for an hour.

I got the Spicy Tori Paitan ramen. The flavor is just okay - the broth is super thick and the noodles are also super thick. I guess I'm just not a fan of this style of ramen and I will not be back. Orenchi still remains my favorite ramen in the bay area.
author: Jenann P.

description: Came here by myself, craving a bowl of ramen.   35 min wait in line at 8:30 pm on a dirty street in one of the more run down areas of SF.   Finally was seated in a cramped side bar facing the kitchen, so I could at least watch the chefs in action.   Ordered the spicy lamb ramen.   The broth was way too thick and murky, supposed to be miso based, but had the texture of a peanut sauce.   Too many things going on in the bowl, and the thick broth just muddied it all up, in the end I couldn't really taste anything except the cumin in the lamb.   Even the egg was covered up.  Very small portion of noodles.   I really wanted to like this, but ended up not being able to finish the bowl...it was mostly thick porridge with a bit of noodles.   And very expensive.
author: Dean W.

description:
The line is the reason I take away 2 stars from this place. Whyyy would anyone want to stand in a 2 hour line in the rain for a bowl of ramen? Could it possibly be worth 2 hours of your life (standing in the cold)? No. 

Nothing is worth that! Not even the best bowl of ramen in your life. Which, to be honest, this wasn't. I went very simple with my order, since this was my first time here. I got the organic shoyu ramen. It came with kale, duck chashu and pork chashu. Surprisingly, I enjoyed the pork much more than the duck. It was the most tender piece of pork I've ever had in ramen. The noodles were also a stand out for me, since they were thicker than usual. The kale was a nice addition as well.

However, I don't think this was the tastiest bowl of ramen I've had. It was clean, simple, and minimal. However, I was really missing the egg! For $14, I've gotten lobster broth, soft shell crab, and quail eggs at Ramen Parlor in San Mateo. I just don't think this $14 bowl of ramen here really compared. 

In addition, the vicinity is tiny, claustrophobic and not that comfortable. I was not a fan of the communal style tables and did not like how close I was to the people next to me. They also don't allow take out--so if you can't finish your ramen there, too bad. There's no way to take it home.

Maybe I would come back here one day, to try some of the more complex menu items. However, if I'm in the mood for ramen, I'll probably go somewhere else. There are plenty of great ramen spots in the bay area where you can skip the line, sit at your own table, and enjoy a variety of delicious menu options for a better price.
author: Sara S.

description:
COME EARLY!!! If you plan to come here for a dinner, just know that you're going to be waiting for a very very very very very long time. This place has a capacity of only probably 35 people max and the wait to be seated takes over an hour, at least that's how it was like for us. When we left, the line was even longer and that was about 9:30pm!

We found this place based on the yelp reviews and after walking around San Francisco especially in the Golden Gate Park with temperatures in the lower 60s, we needed some hot Ramen to end our day. 

First impression upon arriving was the fact that there was a long line with approximately 25 people. The place itself is tricky to find because they don't have very many signs or indications that there is an actual restaurant. Like I mentioned previously we waited over an hour and the line was even longer when we left.

My fiancée and I both ordered the tori paitan because we were looking for a more creamier/heavier broth. I added habaneros, chives, chili oil, and garlic flakes. At $2 each addon, my bowl of ramen became pretty pricey. Between the two of us, our total was about $67. Overall, I think the ramen was pretty good. Portion was very generous and I was struggling to finish. They also give a generous amount of noodles which is awesome because a lot of ramen places I've been to short you on the noodles requiring you to order more at an extra charge.

Would We go back? Eh... We can't really justify waiting for over an hour again... maybe We would try to go right when they open to eat sooner. Regardless we liked it and would recommend this place to people looking for some good ramen!
author: Brian J.

description:
Best. Ramen. Ever!!

My friends and I went to go try this place on a Friday night, and they insisted that they had heard so many things about this tiny ramen shop. The wait was about an hour, and there was no wait list, just a line. The place is very tiny with communal style seating. But despite the wait and the awkward seating, it was absolutely worth it! 

We ended up ordering the Tori Paitan, which is what they're known for! The first sip of my broth had me in nirvana. I was pretty shocked at how rich and thick the broth was. I've had ramen in Japan, and don't get me wrong! Ramen in Japan was incredible, but this place definitely is my new #1 favorite. Anyways, the noodles were chewy and the meat was tender and delicious. It was a bit pricey for ramen, $16 for the bowl, but it was well worth it. 

I absolutely need to go back, I'm already drooling at the thought of our next trip!
author: Veronica D.

description: Poor taste, overhyped and overrated. Noodles do not have a good taste in the mouth and soup also doesn't taste good. Ramen is too whitewashed and tastes like spaghetti. Space is too cramped, price is not justifiable. Would not recommend.
author: Kevin R.

description:
Tori paiten (reg and spicy) 2/5. When it arrived, it was very appealing. It had all the appeal of what the ramen was supposed to be that so many people lined up for...but then i soon realized...for this particular ramen (creamy kind) it could be more hyped up. I mean, if you wait so long, you kind of psych yourself into thinking "this is gonna be worth it" but for us, we only waited 22 minutes, it was only worth the wait to experience the hype. 

Now for the taste review: the first thing that stood out to me was the fact that the broth wasnt soup. At all. It had the consistency of pasta alfredo so needless to say, it wasn't a ramen you could slurp up. The noodles were of the curly type and compared to all the ramen I've had, it was thicker. The egg was cold when it arrived so if u like cold soft boiled egg (one that the yolk isnt runny but like pudding consistency), then this is for you. It was not for me. I had the shoyu version of it. The broth was very thick (frothy from being whisked before delivered to client), again, reminiscent if eating saucy pasta but the broth taste wasnt bad at all. The umami was there. It wasnt too porky because of the other proteins mixed with it. The chasu was soft (especially the fat) and they give u a big piece along with a slither of duck. Overall, 2/5. 

My husband had the oysters and the lamb. I liked his better. It tasted like something reminiscent of gyro meat. Similar seasoning i guess?

If you like waiting in line and catching up with friends,  and eating closely with strangers, this is your place! I will check out the other ramen spot in Japan town next.
author: Mong Chong E.

description: Amazing food, great customer service, they even put on Too Short and Mac Dre for a bit! Lol. Line can get lengthy, but it's worth it.
author: Norman W.

description:
Wow. I think I might have found it - my favorite ramen spot. Only it's a 6 hour drive away from where I live and around $20 including tip... but I guess that's a blessing in disguise or else I'd be having this ramen once a week and ending up with a thick waistline and thin wallet.

Really, this ramen is something else. It's incredibly thick and hearty - not your average tonkotsu. The consistency is like half&half and the flavorful is unbelievable. I got the spicy lamb ramen and it blew my mind!! First of all, lamb in ramen??? Say no more. The lamb came in the form of ground lamb, along with the most tender pork chashu in the world (literally could not pick it up without it falling apart) and two slices of duck meat that I added. The duck meat was so chewy and tender while the lamb added a dimension of aroma and flavor that really changed the entire bowl of ramen. And don't even get me started on the noodles!! Absolutely the thickest, chewiest ramen noodles I have ever tried! These noodles are almost in the realm of udon noodles with how thick they are and I LOVED it. The ramen also came with bean sprouts and mushroom. My only wish is that the ramen could have been a lot more spicier but still, BEST RAMEN I've had. 

Our party of three got there about ten minutes before opening and waited about 30 min to be seated, which wasn't too bad. The store is small but clean and they have baskets under the table for you to put your belongings in so they don't touch the floor - gotta love the Japanese and their inclination for cleanliness and etiquette. 

Counting the days until I can come back to SF for this ramen!
author: Ellen J.

description:
Okay so many of the reviews say it but I want to reiterate, the vegan ramen is crack. Literally. It's dangerous. I don't want to even think about how bad it probably it is for me to consume this bowl of crack bc I plan to treat myself to it once in a while.

Yes, the lines are long , the place is tiny and the service is more likely than not the best but I don't really expect it. 

I absolutely love Nojo and I don't think I could pick between the two bc they're very different. 

Mensho is a real treat and not something you will find anywhere else in the Bay Area. If you love ramen it's a must!!
author: Hetal P.

description: Mediocre Raman. I had high expectations because of the line and the nice reviews. It was a bit disappointing. We arrived at around 5:30 and there were about 8 people in front of us in the line. We waited for about 25 mins and got seated. The inside is very small and most of the seats are high chairs which are not very comfortable. We ordered soy base and the chicken soup base. The soy base was standard and the Chicken soup base was too creamy and salty. The only highlight were the chashus where melt in my mouth. The Ramen was also a bit overpriced if you ask me. I  am here for vacation but from my experiences from where I live, which is Los Angeles,  a good Raman without any additional toppings costs $12 top. Here, it's from $14-$17.
author: Yiqiong Z.

description:
I personally think this place is overrated. I guess the idea of this place is to be much like ramen shops in Japan. The plus was no tipping (which is offensive to do so in Japan), especially when it's is one of the more expensive ramen places in SF. 
I got the tori paitan ramen because it was the closest thing to my traditional creamy ramen I would always get in Tokyo. The broth was good, but a tad too salty for what I am used to. If you want your egg it is an up charge. The noodle was what ruined the experience. All the ramen place I had in Japan had this soft yet bouncy texture to their noodles which were all made from scratch. Here I got this thick and undercooked doughy noodle, nothing that reminded me of Japan. 
My friend got the shio ramen and didn't feel it was any more special than other ramen places around.
We won't be making our way back considering the price, and the not so great area that it located in as well.
author: Diana N.

description:
Long wait.
Hyped ramen. Good, but hyped.
Any good Japanese restaurant touting they are from Japan better remind me of Japan if I dine. Mensho did not remind me of Japan. It reminds me of a really good Americanize Japanese restaurant at best due to the lack of attention to details and service. 

Why do I say hyped, while it did taste good, there was just no umami, no depth to the broth. the broth was savory and heavy, but in a 1-dimensional manner. chasu was tender. the toppings in the ramen just looked like it was tossed into it without much thought or care.

service and ambiance was also lacking. while the place looked fine, it just felt sterile. we came on a rainy day, and there wasnt much are put into where to place umbrellas. seats were not the most comfortable. Servers just served the food then disappeared. No attention paid to us. Mensho might be from Japan, but the quality of service and attention to details relating to the customer surely wasn't.  All these things are part of an excellent Japanese dining experience. 

so close, but no cigar.
author: Jason C.

description:
BEST!
If you like duck, if you like creamy broth, if you like fresh chewy noodles then believe you me this is the best damn ramen in NorCal.
It's no wonder why some top chefs claim Ramen as their all time favorite food to eat.
author: Paul C.

description:
On Friday, 12/22, I got in line at 420p and there were already 20+ people in line for 31 seats (4+12+7+8).  I got in the 1st wave of seating with 2 seats to spare which they never filled up for some unknown reason.  At 5p, the line was about 100+ people long (half block).

Tori Paitan Ramen soup was rich and creamy.  Noodles were soft and tender, but they weren't made onsite.  Duck and pork charsu were succulent and not super fatty.  Dried mushrooms and seaweed were standard ramen items.   Kale in the ramen is an odd combination and just added color.  Golden egg (miso flavored) add on was spot on.  

Overall, the ramen was tasty, but it is not worth the 1+ hour wait unless you have never been there.  There are numerous places like Mensho that are all over Tokyo.
author: Elmo ..

description: Awesome Ramen! I had the Tori Paitan...Had 1/2 the bowl and then asked for the chili spice to add a little zing to the 2nd half. Next time I would go for the spicy version. I typically think the pork is going to be chewy and hard to with chopsticks and soup spoon...But this was so well cooked that it broke off into bite size pieces just with the chopsticks. Have to bring the family here since my daughter just loves Ramen!
author: Ravinder S.

description:
Three words.... OMG! 

This place is like the best ramen I ever had in my life so far! I came here with my friend around 5:30pm and the line was crazy long. If your from San Francisco you know there's like a long line for every restaurant that's really delicious. Well I can tell you that this place is definitely worth the wait and price for the quality of the food.

I ordered the Organic Shoyu and my friend ordered Tori Paitan. Both of them were delicious but I loved the rich and creamy soup way more, and I know some of you are thinking, it's richer and creamy but more fat but hey majority of the best and delicious food are fat. You know what that means? Time to go gym and workout to lose all the fat and calories and eat more again! The ramen was honestly the best, I think it's handmade on the spot. And OMG their duck and chasu is litty! The organic shoyu was around $14 and the tori paitan was $16 just like it says on the menu on yelp. 

Overall it was a great experience just come early to avoid being the last one. And for those of you hesitating to come, just come or you miss out on the best ramen in San Francisco. Definitely one of those spots that I will be coming back again!
author: Christopher G.

description: Delicious broth!! I'm very particular about my broth. I like it thick with a lot of flavor. This was awesome, and the noodles were perfect. There was only a small line and the wait was brief. I got the spicy ramen. The guy next to me had the clam with butter. Cute small space. Excellent service. The only bummer is there are no to go containers  I hate wasting food. I'm bringing a glass container next time
author: Cecilia D.

description: Went there 30 mins before closing on a Thursday night. Short line outside. Got seated fast. My daughter and I ordered a spicy Tori paitan ramen and agreed it was good in broth and noodle texture. Although we prefer the ingredients in the regular Tori paitan with kale and duck chashu. Ours only came with cabbage, pork chashu and bamboo shoots. That's the only downside to our dish. Spice is just right not too spicy. Will definitely be back to try other stuff like the oysters and clam ramen!  We got our food pretty fast too. People are friendly enough to talk to one another at our shared table. Overall legit ramen spot in SF!
author: Corinne Z.

description:
This place was overhyped, overrated, and caused an upset stomach. The ramen was too salty and too rich, and the service was rushed and unfriendly. I'm not leaving 1-Star because I wish to impact the review aggregate, but because this place actually deserved 1 star. I ordered the Wagyu beef dish and was completely unimpressed, for any price.

Stay away. I'm not going back.
author: Benjamin S.

description: My favorite ramen place. Worth every wait. Loved it every time I went there! It is the kind of I-can-go-there-with-my-luggage-directly-off-the-flight place. Now I have moved out of San Fran, I will miss it really badly. It was a special spot for me and for my entire stay of 2 years at San Fran!
author: Jie X.

description: Oyster was a little salty. Mushroom chips were good. We like the ramens! It's really delicious! We ordered limited ramen. But it turns out it does not worth so much. I still prefer the normal ones.
author: Yiqiong Z.

description: Great ramen concept. Although the venue was on the smaller scale and there was a wait, all my expectations of good ramen were fulfilled and more. We ordered a regular as well as a Matcha Tori Paitan. The latter was surprisingly tasty and unique to try. The oyster appetizer is also a great opener with its light umami flavor.
author: Regina L.

description: They have delicious vegan ramen, but you have to wait in line for over an hour for it. Honestly, I don't think this ramen is delicious enough to wait that long (after trying it once), nor does my bf think that it's worth it to wait that long for the non-vegan ramen. Nonetheless, the broth was creamy and well-flavored and the noodles were cooked perfectly and were of perfect thickness. I'd dine here more often if there wasn't such a long wait.
author: Christina M.

description: It was definitely worth the wait! Make sure to get there before they open so that you are able to get first seating like others mentioned. I ordered the Spicy Tori Paitan. The broth was really rich but delicious. I loved all the different textures found in the ramen.
author: Yi L.

description: Been here twice and both times were amazing! Before coming here I did not like Ramen at all. Finally, after everyone talking about how life changing Mensho's Ramen was, we decided to give it a try. They were not wrong! The Ramen was delicious!!! I don't think I could go to any other Ramen place except here. Did not disappoint. Full of flavor and tasted very fresh. I think I've tasted 3-4 different broths and all of them were good. Don't think you can go wrong with anything on the menu. They also have enoki chips which I really enjoyed. Staff was super friendly and helpful. Place is small but nice. Parking is tough, just like anywhere in SF. Definitely recommend! A must try!
author: Christian N.

description: Hands down the best ramen I have ever eaten, and likely in the top 20 best tasting things I have ever eaten. Tori paitan was rich and creamy with thick noodles and a good sized portion. Well worth the wait and trip to SF.
author: Naomi S.

description:
The hype is real! We came around 745pm on a Saturday and there was a 40 min wait even in the rain! But I didn't mind too much since I wasn't too hungry. The interior is small but service is quick once you're seated.

We ordered:
-shoyu oysters ($5 for 4) -very just okay to me. A little in the fishy side, would skip!
-chasu bowl-4.5/5-yum!!! Had 3 huge fatty pieces of chasu with rice ! So delicious and tender ! 
-double chasu tori paitan ramen ($18) -4/5. I really enjoyed the broth, it was very flavorful and still somewhat light, but toward the end of my meal it did get a little heavy. Still I enjoyed the noodle texture a lot too. The chasu pieces were just okay 

Overall it was pretty good ! A little on the pricey side, but a solid choice in sf!
author: Isabel L.

description:
Yes I am here again. 10 min before the restaurant opened there are like 50 people waiting. The wait really worthwhile it.

I ordered tori taipan double chashu and the maresobs spicy. Again the soup is very flavourful and creamy. Noodle was thick and I like the way the soup was creamy and attach to the noodle.maresoba was a new item to me. It does not have soup and it was like mix noodle. As u can tell from the picture there are many ingredients that add spicy and nutty flavor for the meal. The spice does not kick in until later. I was glad that I did not order that spicy. It was very good as well. I really like both of them.

Yes the restaurant holds around 30 per time but average customer takes 30-35min. So if you came at a right time maybe the wait won't be too long
author: Stephanie H.

description: I think this ramen shop is the best in San Francisco. I mean their ramen has a similar taste to Japanese recent popular one (It named ie-kei ramen). Their price is pretty expensive as a ramen nearly $20, but other ramen places have almost the same price range. If you want to try Japanese ramen these days, it's a good place to go. A big disadvantage that this restaurant is always very packed. Usually, you need to wait in line around 60min. Therefore, I recommend to go there around 5pm or after 10pm on weekdays. Also, rainy day doesn't have many people. My favorite one is chicken paitan!! New matcha paitan is also good!
author: Yumiko H.

description: For the price and the wait in line (~1 hour), I have to say that it was quite underwhelming. I had the Tori Paitan and while the noodles were enjoyable, the broth was overly rich and creamy from the gelatin. It becomes overwhelming after a few spoons. The chashu was good, but nothing spectacular. For almost $30 I would try my luck somewhere else.
author: Harrison T.

description:
I don't think Mensho is worth the hype for an overpriced bowl of ramen. Like any other typical ramen place, the place is small = long wait in line. Another attribution is how people tend to come in groups, which slows down the line because they tend to chit chat than enjoy their meal. I've seen many people in groups who haven't ate a bite in 10 minutes because they were busy talking.. made me pretty hangry in line. 

I really wanted to like this place for their proclaimed authenticity but would it cost that much in Japan too? Maybe half their price. I had the creamy ramen broth and it was way too creamy/rich for me. It kind of had a grainy consistency of those small bits you find in chicken/pork bones. Like when you bite into a bone, it kind of has a grainy texture. The duck slices were great but I would prefer the standard chashu pork. Overall, my tastebuds didn't sit well with me here so I don't think I would come back unless my friends drag me here.
author: Sarah F.

description: This used to be one of my favorite spots for Ramen but the quality and taste has changed significantly for the worse. The flavor had a lot of depth and used to be very creamy. It was a unique spot with Ramen flavors unlike any other spots in SF. However, I tried it again today and it was watered down with an overpowering smokiness flavor and cilantro stems. I got whole stems of cilantro in my bowl of ramen which were displeasing to the palette. Drastic change in quality seems to indicate a change in kitchen. Overall it was a really disappointing experience.
author: Zeba K.

description: Mensho is so good that you can reach meditative zones while devouring their ramen with those big spoons. The crowded lil joint ends up becoming you and the bowl.
author: Yarrow S.

description:
Like all other reviewers before me said, the wait is long! My friend and I came in around 7 on a Tuesday night, and got in approximately an hour later. We luckily managed to snag two spots at the bar, which was more personable than the other tables, and the place was small. Also asked the waitress if there was a time limit we could dine in and she said no. 

I ordered the Tori Paitan ramen. Now I've never, ever been too picky with my ramen. I would be perfectly content with instant noodles,  obviously preferring dine in when occasions rose for it. But I think this spot definitely changed my idea of what GREAT ramen is. The broth was thick, creamy, and rich. And all the elements combined made for an enriching experience, from the soft, chewy noodles to the tender chashu pork, to the burdock root which added a very nice texture. 

My friend had ordered the organic shoyu ramen,  which tasted a lot lighter. Probably the healthier alternative, if you're looking for one. Although we agreed all the elements of it didn't match as well as the Tori Paitan.

I was also very impressed by our appetizer, oysters in shoyu dare oil. The plate was small with only a few pieces. However, from the very first bite, your taste buds just get sent through the roof. I don't know how else to explain it, but I was hooked. 

The whole meal was very filling, the service was good, and I would happily wait in line again for this place.
author: Sarah L.

description:
I really wanted to like this place but I just don't prefer it to others but keep in mind I don't have a very refined ramen palate. 

I've tried three of the ramens: tori paitan, shoyu, and shio. If you like creamy go for the tori paitan if not the shoyu or shio will better suit you. I preferred the shoyu over the shio just based on the soup and would come back for the shoyu or the clam ramen but that's never available when I get here anyways. 

The reason I don't like this place..... honestly there's a certain and smell and flavor to the ramen I just didn't like it kinda just reminded me of an Asian market but in my mouth... this could be just me but my boyfriend felt the same way. Just my two cents, still a nice place for ramen but definitely many worthy competitors out there!
author: Jenny E.

description:
Hands down
Best Japanese ramen I've ever had. 
This place has their own philosophy and tradition and makes authentic ramen that you probably could only find in Japan. 
The broth, spices, noodles, meat all blended in a perfect harmony.
You just cannot treat this noteworthy ramen like a msg overloaded fast food ramen. 
The best in San Francisco and the best I've ever had!!
author: Jason B.

description:
I can be very particular about my ramen, and overall, the ramen in the bay isn't as good as it is in LA. Fortunately, this place can stack up to the ramen in LA. There is only street parking here, and more then likely you will be waiting outside for while. The dining area is very small, and you will be siting very close to strangers. The restroom is unisex and is well maintained. The place is very bright and there is a TV on the side.

I usually get the Tori Paitan ramen with double chashu. I recommend getting the double chashu as it is the perfect amount of meat for the ramen. When you see it at first, the bowl appears to be a little on the small side; however, as you eat, you begin to wonder how you're not finished with your bowl. The broth is very thick and flavorful, with the chashu complimenting the broth. The one thing that I thought would take it over the top would be an egg. Sadly, I did not see that add-on option on the menu.

The service is pretty fast once you get seated. The people working here are kind and respectful. Overall, I would have to say that this is my go to ramen spot in the city. I will be definitely be coming back here many more times. 4.5 stars.
author: Jason P.

description:
This is my new favorite ramen restaurant in the bay area. I've heard the wait can be ridiculous so I came at night at 10 p.m. on a Saturday and waited only 10-15 minutes. It was also raining so there weren't very many people in line ahead of us.  

Tori Paitan- mmmm the broth is very rich and creamy and oh so delicious. It's very flavorful and fatty in all the good ways. It's a bit thick though so if you like a lighter broth I would recommend the shio ramen. The noodles were also cooked perfectly. 

Shio Ramen- the shio ramen was also really really really good! It's lighter but still super flavorful and yummy. 

By far the best ramen in the bay! I think it beats Ramen Dojo and Orenchi.
author: Mai Y.

description:
Worth the wait!!! Such a small place, and they seat you at tables where ever your party can fit. So there's a big chance you get seated at the same table with other patrons. That doesn't really bother me because people usually keep to themselves. 

Now, I'm not a fan of duck. But the duck chashu was legit. Trust me! It's good. The regular chashu was also nice and tender. 

The broth took the ramen to a whole 'nother level. The flavor profile was nice and porky, and it had a lot of body. So it was a lot more rich and creamy compared to other ramen spots I've been to. I think it's what sets it apart from all other places. It's their own style and it really works for them. 

The enoki chips were a great addition to the ramen. Delicious to eat by themselves, but also just as good if you throw them in your soup as well.
author: Cheryl E.

description:
This was my second time at Mensho trying the Vegan Tantanmen. The wait on a Tuesday night was ~45 minutes, but totally worth the wait! This is definitely one of the best vegan ramen dishes I have tried. With an incredibly creamy broth and a blend of seven types of nuts, the flavor is unique to any other ramen I've had. Perfect level of spice to complement the richness of the soup. The toppings it came with were edamame, mushroom and bamboo shoots, which were delicious. The noodles soaked in the flavor of the soup well and were tastier than noodles of other vegan ramen dishes I've had. 

I also tried the fried mushroom chips which were delicious as well! Highly recommend to meat-lovers and vegetarians alike!
author: Nidhi M.

description:
Definitely my favorite ramen in San Francisco. Way better than Marufuku Ramen in my opinion. I recommend getting the Tori Paitan. It has really thick, chewy noodles and a creamy, flavorful broth. The meat was also melt-in-your-mouth tender.

Admittedly the wait is very long (upwards of 30min-1hr) and the restaurant is small with a communal seating arrangement. Though, the service is very fast and food comes out quickly.
author: Danielle C.

description: Stood in line for 25 minutes (came around 7PM on a Friday) definitely worth all the hype. Best ramen in town, TRY IT! Place is super small so I wouldn't recommend coming in parties bigger than 4. This is not the place for you if you don't enjoy sitting next to strangers! Staff was super nice & the people sitting next to me on both sides were all really friendly. Will definitely return!
author: Aryana D.

description: This is probably the best ramen joint I have been to! Heads up: they open at 5 but the queue starts at roughly around 4:30ish, I came at around 4:40 and I was still the second batch. Their ramen is superb! I ordered the Fried mushroom appetizer, Lamb ramen, matcha and the spicy paitan and everything was 10/10. The appetizer was really good and I enjoyed it! For the matcha ramen, you can't really taste most of the matcha (they only have a subtle hint of it) but the broth was gooodddd that I finished most of it. The chasu is melt in your mouth as well. My boyfriend enjoyed the spicy ramen and he told me this is better than Tsujita LA. For those who can't stand pungent smelling food, I wouldn't recommend ordering the lamb as it has a unique aftertaste which some wouldn't enjoy but I love love the thickness of the lamb's broth. Overall, I would come back again when I'm in town!
author: Koyuki S.

description:
The ultimate question: Is it worth the wait? If you are starving, the answer is no. I would likely never bring most of my family here as we get HANGRY, and waiting is not something we would like to do as a group for dinner.

After a late meeting at work I decided to trek over to Mensho Tokyo after having read about it a while ago. As I approached, I immediately knew I had arrived because of the line outside. I hopped in and was surprised that the line never really got shorter. The line was as expected in the wait was about 45 minutes to an hour.

When I was finally seated the service was quick, attentive, and friendly enough. I ordered the Tori Paitan ramen and added an egg. As expected it was a thick and delicious broth with tons of flavor. Enjoyed every bite and every slurp. I can see how some people may find it a bit too much since it is very thick and many will not be used to it. I thoroughly enjoyed it and thought it was delicious.

Now, is it worth the wait....again? Possibly, yes. BUT...you'll have to catch me on patient day and when I'm not that hungry because of the line.
author: Ruben P.

description:
Ehhh. I've had ramen that tasted on par with this for so much cheaper. $18 for a bowl of ramen is ridiculous especially when you add on a mandatory 15% gratuity. 

Seating: I'm fine with community seating, but this place is ridiculous. You have to eat like you have damn T-Rex arms because of how closely seated you are so you aren't just hitting your neighbor every time you move. 

Beer selection: pff. Joke. Get out of here with that. Get some actual good Japanese beers. 

Price: like I already said, not worth the price. 

Wait time: I got there when they opened So I didn't have to wait but have heard that it can be around an hour wait. 

Taste: it by means did not taste bad. But it's definitely overhyped.  

Would I come back? I wouldn't go out of my way for it so maybe not
author: Julio N.

description: I want to love any place with a vegan option but this really wasn't worth the wait. The line always seems to be long and moves so slowly. Once you do make it inside, it's very crowded and you definitely feel pressured to rush through your meal by all the people in line watching you eat through the window. The food itself was okay but definitely not the best ramen I've ever had so I would not do that line again.
author: Jessica H.

description:
3.5 stars if you have never had this type ramen you will be in for a surprize, I will probably get flack for writing this review but hey if you don't like it don't read it.

The wait for this place has always been fairly long, the night we tried it was about 20min wait for 2 people late night around 9:30pm

So let me get down to the why it fell short in my book. It was not the service, it was not the ambiance, it was not the price, it was the ramen. If you are expecting a full face broth with sinus cleansing and pore cleaning attributes this is not one of the places you go if you order the Tori Paitan or the Spicy Lamb that is, I was told the vegetarian ramen is very good,

Here is the description of what we sampled and how each item faired
