There was a large line out the door of people waiting but I got lucky since I was solo - made it faster to get in.  

Bright, cheery ambiance -  look forward to coming back here when I am in the area needing a ramen fix.
author: Anna P.

description:
After being at the bar across the street, birthday girl wanted Mensho ramen, so off to Mensho we went. We waited in line, and with a fun group, the line goes decently fast. We went in as groups of two to get seated faster and it just lucked out for us that we got to sit next to each other anyways!

Upon sitting down, we asked the server for recommendations. Both servers working there suggested the Vegan Tantanmen! Shocked but intrigued, I ordered it and added chashu. It was amazing. I tried a bit of the Tori Paitan (their signature dish), but it was too rich for me. I'm glad I got the vegan option!
author: Leana L.

description: 1.5 hour wait.  The appetizers were mediocre.  Ramen broth were thick.  Egg was done correctly.  Ramen is closer to udon texture than ramen.  Glad we tried but not likely to go back.
author: Y O.

description:
About a 45 minute wait on a Friday night. Beers from the convenience store down the street can help pass the time. Can't comment on the other ramens because I am vegetarian, but the vegan ramen was great and very filling. One of the best vegetarian ramens I have ever had. Super rich broth - surprising for a vegan dish.

Quick in and out. Not the most amazing ramen I have ever had - will have to reserve that designation for some tiny noodle place in Tokyo that I forgot the name of - but this was pretty solid. Would go again.
author: Casey L.

description:
In short: Food didn't live up to the hype. Highlights go to the speedy service, noodle texture, and unique interior. 

I was so excited to finally try this place because I heard it was popular. There is always a long line outside the place well before they open for dinner. We went on a Friday night and got in line around 5:15 and got seated an hour after, which I consider it to be a decent wait time. Seats are tight because it's basically family style on the four long tables inside. They have baskets on the ground for you to put your bags but since the seats are high, you'll have to get out of your stool to reach for your purse. The food came out fast and this is where the disappointment sets in. We got the ume shio chasu and double chasu and boy, was it salty. I liked the texture of the noodles but just couldn't get past how salty the broth was. When I got to the bottom of the bowl, it got even saltier and was so relieved I was done with it. My friend said he liked the pork but I didn't have any comment on that. 

This was such a letdown. I guess my expectations were too high having had ramen in Japan and orenchi in Santa Clara. But I would give it another chance and come to try something else on the menu. I'll just have to come with lower standards and surely won't be going near the ume shio again.
author: Ying Z.

description: Vegan ramen here is amazing. It's very flavorful and quite nutty. Definitely  one of the best ramen places with vegetarian/vegan options. Pro-tip - go early or late to avoid long lines.
author: Vaishali P.

description: Nice atmosphere! Small shop with a cozy feeling. Had the Tori Paitan Ramen, was very flavorful and the noodles were perfect. Wish it had a bit more protein considering the price.
author: Russ K.

description:
太喜欢了 I love it
we waited for an hour, but it was well worth!!!!!!!
This restaurant gave me a really good time with my friends. 
It's not so big, but the style is good, noodles are the best I tried since I came to San Francisco.
I'll come again!!!!!!!!!
author: Tiffany X.

description:
Waited till the hype dies down a bit and so happy I did. Only a 15 min wait for a party of two on a Thursday night around 7pm. So Awesome! Mensho is probably one of the better ramen places in the bay area. The broth was creamy and flavorful. The NOODLE was prefect! I got the Tori Taipan Ramen with chashu, $18. Pricer than most places but it was delicious. I can't give it a five star because I don't think it was amazing. I love ramen and I'm such a sob when it comes to ramen. Feels like no matter what the bay area does, it's never comparable to LA, for its price and taste. 

FYI, don't get the oysters. It's the dry ones.
author: Sandy B.

description: The wait here is pretty long but it is worth it. The noodles are thicker and has a creamy pasta sauce like taste to it. Its vastly different than Marufuku, and I prefer this style more. I wish the seating was more comfortable or at least spaced out a bit. It's awkward eating so close to random people.
author: Nick Y.

description:
I've been wanting to try Mensho for some time, but the line always deterred me. Finally, on Thursday, July 28th, my group of three decided to brave the line around 10:30pm. It honestly didn't take too long. I think about 20 mins.

*Tori Paitan Ramen: Rich and Creamy Chicken Soup, Pork Chashu, Duck Chashu, Menma, Kale, Burdock, Katsuobushi Sauce ($18 double chashu)
*Organic Shoyu Ramen: Clear Organic Chicken and Pork Soup, Shoyu Dare, Pork Chashu, Duck Chashu, Kale, Kale Sprouts,Chives, Menma, Nori ($16 double chashu)
*Shio Ramen: Clear Chicken and Pork Soup, Shio Dare, Pork Chashu, Kale, Menma, Fried Garlic, Chives, Nori ($9)

My favorite, hands down, was the Tori Paitan. The noodles were the right consistency and the broth was rich and flavorful. I wasn't the one who ended up with this bowl, but I was wishing I had ordered it. My Shio ramen was okay. A light flavorful broth. But the noodles were the flat kind and I preferred the thicker noodles from the Tori Paitan better. They had a much better chew. I only tried a spoonful of the broth from the Shoyu Ramen which was fine.

We all know I can't have a meal without alcohol! Two of us got the Sapporo Premium: 355ml/12.0oz ($4.75) and one of us tried the Ozenoyukidoke IPA 12.75: 330ml/11.5oz ($12.75). Pricey for a beer, but a better choice if you like IPAs. I, myself prefer the lighter beers, so the sapporo was perfect for me.

Glad I was finally able to check Mensho Tokyo off my list. Was it worth the 20 min wait? Yes, I would say so. But if I had to wait 1+ hours in the SF cold, I don't know. I'm just happy I'll never have to find out.
author: Elena N.

description:
We got in line at 4:35pm on a Wednesday with 8 ppl ahead of us.

The staff starting seating customers just after 5pm.

Seating was communal and extra cozy. There are baskets on the floor to place your belongings inside.

Service was courteous and the staff stay on top of everything. Upon getting seated, we placed our order pretty quickly. We wanted to try the Ozenoyukidoke IPA but our waitress said they didn't have it. While waiting for our order, I counted 24 seats in the restaurant. 

I had the oysters in shoyu dare oil and while these weren't quite what I was expecting, I enjoyed them. The oysters were flavorful and firm with a texture similar to liver.

I also had the Tori Paitan ramen with double chashu. I tasted the broth first and immediately picked up on its intense chicken flavor and richness. When I cook chicken thighs in a pan, and that skin is browning and the fat renders, I could smell the same aroma in the Tori Paitan broth. It was very delicious and for sure unlike any ramen broth I've had before. I loved the thick springy noodles and the tender chashu. The pork was excellent but the standout for me was the duck which had a really nice floral flavor. I have to say I didn't enjoy the menma as they didn't taste like they had enough TLC since they still had that mustiness. I did find that as I finished up the broth, it began to feel grainy and my body was feeling that salt so water was much needed.

We were out the door by 5:52pm.
author: Maya S.

description:
Being vegetarian, I feel like I'm almost on an endless quest to find good vegetarian broth that has both flavor and substance. Mensho Tokyo delivers on both accounts with its vegan tantanmen. Rich, deep flavors in the broth suit the noodles perfectly and offer vegetarians and vegans a substantial dish that can go up against its meat counterparts any day. I do have to admit that the vegan option is somewhat pricey, but considering I've been back roughly 5 times, I'd say that it's worth it.

The reviews about the lines are completely true. I would get there around 4:30 pm to line up if you want to avoid the dinner rush. If you don't mind a long wait (1-2 hrs) past 5:00 pm, you can definitely go later.
author: Lakshmi M.

description:
Expect to spend a few $$ more than most Ramen in the city. Expect to get Ramen equal is not even freaking greater to that in Tokyo, Japan.
I make it a point to eat Ramen in every city I travel to as well as in every neighborhood in San Francisco, and this place is the best. What really confuses me, though, is how the heck is their vegan Ramen even amazing?
author: Iris C.

description:
I wanted to come here for awhile after reading and hearing about this place since day one. Finally gave in and waited for 50 minutes in line. I got the Shio Ramen while my partner in crime got the Tori Paitan. I was pretty disappointed. 
Shio Ramen
 - broth was ok. Nothing incredible about it
 - noodles were interesting but not amazing
 - Chashu was pretty good but so thin
 - green onions were pretty bitter

Tori Paitan
 - broth was incredibly creamy and frothy. 
 - noodles were better

Overall, the experience was okay at best. At the very least I'm glad I tried it and don't understand the hype over it. My gf went to Japan recently and tried so many different ramen spots and according to her, it was far from authentic, it was a complete letdown. For SF ramen it is ok. When comparing this to the rest in the Bay Area, it doesn't even come close to Top 5. But compared to other Ramen in the LA or Japan it's like night and day.
author: Jae C.

description:
What I appreciate about Mensho is that they use real stock (including clam dashi...at least for the organic shoyu). You can't call yourself a serious ramen maker without having a good soup base! 

That said, was a tiny bit disappointed to find out they still use MSG, but maybe that's an industry standard for this fast-paced, mass-consumption world. 

Was it worth the hour + wait? Maybe just once. 

I had the organic shoyu ramen and it was packed with flavor. The noodles were perfectly cooked and I appreciated the chewiness. 

Communal seating with high stools with baskets on the floor to store your bags. 

If you come alone, you'll get seated faster!

The friend I was with said she preferred Mensho to the ramen shop in Rockridge across the bay!
author: Lisa K.

description:
Not worth waiting more than an hour for. When it first opened, the line used to be three hours! Now that it has been more than a year, the line is still long but not so bad. I came here on a Friday night around 6:30PM and waited about 30-40 minutes before being seated. It's a small and cramped restaurant. No to-go orders allowed, and also no taking home leftovers. 

I came here with high expectations. Especially since the guy in front of me said this was the best ramen he ever had. We decided to try the Tori Paitan (single chashu) at $16 and the organic shoyu ramen (single chashu again) at $14, and enoki chips $5. The enoki chips were super oily, and I would not get those again. I definitely liked the tori paitan more than the organic shoyu ramen. The noodles in the shoyu ramen were flatter and less yellow. The tori paitan had a creamy, oily broth that tasted pretty good. There was no half boiled egg included :( which I feel is a standard topping to have in my ramen. Overall, it was okay, but not blown away nor worth the wait and the high price.
author: Christina G.

description:
Oh where to start with this place.... So we stopped in here last night, for my birthday. It was bitter cold outside. We walked inside at first to wait to be seated. We were promptly told to go back outside and wait in front of the door, so we did. We waited a bit. A lady had told us it would be 2 minutes for a table. We were first in line. Other people began lining up behind us. 

   A young gentleman came out and said he was going to take our order, while we were waiting, outside. He assured us our table we be available soon. About 15 minutes later after we had already waited at least 10, of not 15... He came out and pulled 2 different couples from behind us in line! Mind you, we were a party of 4, having already waited outside the front door for almost a half an hour. They sat them all at one long table that had 4 spots available. A table that would have suited us, a party of 4, just fine.

   They seated 2 parties of 2 before us that arrived much later than us and were waiting in line behind us. This ruffled my feathers a bit. I still kept my cool. I really wanted ramen for my birthday. My husband, on the other hand, was a bit upset, but I told him to relax. 

   They again assured us our table would be ready soon. After 10 or 15 MORE minutes, we watched them clearing off empty tables etc. We were growing more and more impatient as we were waiting, outside in the cold STILL. The people that were behind us in line that got seated before us were being served. 

   We FINALLY, after just about 40-45 minutes of waiting outside at the front door, freezing, were brought inside and seated. We then waited. A few minutes later they came and informed us, they had ran out the items we had ordered nearly 40 minutes ago! From then on, most of the items we attempted order from their menu, they came back and informed us they were out of for the night. 

   You know, when I finally got my food, it was very good. However, the experience I endured to get a bowl of ramen from this place made me NEVER want to come here again. I wanted to love this place, it had great reviews.
author: Krista B.

description:
Let me preface this by saying that this was a decent bowl of ramen. It had a lot of elements that differed from what I usually expect from ramen but that doesn't mean it was bad. Just not my preference.
Tori Paitan
-the noodles are thick.
-when they say rich and creamy, they're not kidding. But it also tasted very frothy. Really a type of broth for flavoring all your ingredients rather than drinking directly.
-2 slices of duck chashu (interesting but tasted too uncooked fatty for me) and 2 slices of pork chashu (really good)
-some bamboo, garlic, kale, all solid
-I added a miso egg which was delicious. The egg is cooked to this super gelatinous phase that I don't often see in my soft boiled egg but it worked for me and the miso left it with a tinge of sweetness.

I didn't give this place 5 stars because it was a 50 minute wait late Friday night and the cost of two bowls of tori paitan + two eggs came out about $40 (which is pretty steep for me). Also, I probably won't be coming back just because I prefer a different kind of ramen. That doesn't mean you shouldn't give this place a shot though!
author: Christine L.

description:
Fantastic food, exceptional service!

I had to try the ramen here, despite the rumored hour long wait. As a fellow Yelper suggested, I arrived a little after 5PM to avoid the hour long wait. I got here around 5:30PM and found parking right around the block. When I got in line at around 5:30PM, there were approximately 5-6 groups ahead of us in line. As I studied the restaurant through their window, I realized they only had 3 large tables that seated roughly 6-10 people and a counter in the back facing the kitchen, which seated around 4. The walls had descriptions of the growing popularity of the cuisine and its origin. There were TV screens displaying clips of ramen chefs, ramen eaters and soft music playing in the background. The lamps that hung down from the ceiling was also interesting as the brightness changed throughout the night. 

My friend and I both got the tori paitan and shared the enoki chips. The tori paitan was on top of the menu and a great selection for first timers. With the tori paitan, you can really taste the essence and quality of their signature features. The tori paitan consisted of a rich, creamy and smooth chicken flavored broth with duck cha siu, pork cha siu, kale, menma (bamboo shoots), burdock (herb) and katsuobushi sauce. The combination was super satisfying. The noodles resembled the shape of Maruchan ramen, but the noodles are way better in quality, thickness and consistency. 

The enoki chips were one of a kind because I have never seen it on any other menu in San Francisco. Comes with a side of chili powder and black sesame seeds. The taste reminded me of crispy hash browns. I definitely enjoyed the odd associations that came with ordering the enoki chips, because it also reminded me eating enoki mushrooms during hot pot too. xD

I think Mensho Tokyo absolutely deserves 4-5 stars, but there is always room for improvement. The slight anticipation you get from the wait is always something you can complain about. :P
author: Jennifer Z.

description: I had the spicy noodle. It was good but to be waiting for hours? I don't get it. It fits in with a lot of the SF trend that I'll never understand. There are so many restaurants in the city that taste as good but people choose to come here and wait for hours does not make any sense to me. Luckily, I did not wait that long.
author: Doan T.

description:
It's not my favorite place in San Francisco. But it's good. 

I came on a weekday at 6 pm, waited for about 70 minutes lining up outside of the restaurants. Good thing it wasn't too cold, or else I would have left. 

After looking through the photos on Yelp and the whole menu, I ordered Paitan with chili oil on the side. And also the fried enoki chips as appetizer. The broth was thick and flavored. The noodle was thick and el dente. Overall, it was a good bowl of ramen if you like thick broth. However, I would like to note they did not add a lot of side flavors to their broth (Which could be a good thing for some). To me, it was lacking a kick in ramen. Also notice that I had to ask for chili oil on the side as the paitan did not have a spicy option. It was a subtle broth, but its rich enough to hold the ramen. 

I'm not too impressed given the long wait and the hype of this place. However, It's good and I'm willing to come back and try other ramen. As for the wait, it's San Francisco, so I'll suck it. But keeping fans wait outside under a cold weather would be very cruel! Please keep this in mind!
author: Wing C.

description:
Unreal. Absolutely delicious ramen! I spent a month in Japan and the best ramen I had (maybe I didn't hit the best places) didn't match this level of delicious! 

It is on the pricey side!! Around $20 a person without any drinks or appetizers. 

Wait time is about 30-45 minutes. Restaurant seats 26 people, if you are there for opening and not the first in, expect to wait about 45 minutes. If you're starving be sure to grab a snack before you go.
author: Patrik B.

description: I had their chicken-base ramen (paitan) about 30min before they closed. Place is clean and comfortable. Service people were great. And of course, the ramen was delicious! Although, in my opinion, it is not worth more than a 30min wait. If wait is long, you can easily take the 38 bus to Japan Town and find comparable options.
author: Adan A.

description:
Ramen shops tend to have long waiting lines and most, if not all, are usually made up of small dining.  No reservations may be made.  This was of the norm.  Had to wait a good 45 minutes even prior before it opened.  There were people in the agonizing line already and the turnover for a tiny place, isn't appealing either. 

Communal seating on high chairs.  Definitely different from what I'm use to on seatings at ramen shops.  There were a few side seatings, but very limited.  I would opt for that and not be open for side conversation if topics are required to be discussed more in depth in between 2 people.  It's a hassle to bring a party of 6!  A group of 4 would be nice on the communal table.  You can't be choosy, unless you want to wait even longer.  I felt packed like sardines and quite claustrophobic.

It was an uncomfortable dining experience.

The snowflake sake was much needed after the wait and as a way to relieve the weekday workflow on a Friday!  When we asked which sake to order, the waitress recommended an unexpected different one that I have not tried before in sake.  It was like a creamy, smooth yogurt mixed in drink with a sake shot. It was wonderful.

Ordered up the organic ramen with chashu. It was the homely broth, stringy noodles, spot on chashu with flavor and right tenderness, and a surprisingly big metal spoon.  Nothing to me, was spazzing or to rave over about.  They give you a tiny scooping spoon for the hot sauce.  I mind as well pour the entire hot sauce container into my bowl or use the huge metal spoon for that hot sauce!  I was thinking about it and how to proceed at that time.  I love hot sauce with my ramen, but I didn't need to flame the fire in me on a Friday.  Cooling it with that snowflake sake was rather nice. 

Aye okay ramen bowl, but not worth the wait and my needed space to whine down and simply enjoy good company without worrying to be gestured out with the bill and seeing through the transparent window of that endless line.  

It's one of those days where you just don't want to deal with it, but your dining partner set up that time and place to do so.  In my case, I guess I dealt with it and not wanting to be that flaker. 

So, if you're a foodie and love ramen testing, this would be a perfect spot to try out.  However, you deal with the wait, tightly squeezed ambiance and given limited time to dine.
author: Tiffany D.

description: Easily one of the best Ramens I have ever had; and this includes Ramen in Japan. I had Tori Paitan and my wife who is vegetarian l, had the Vegan Tantanmen. Both were extremely good, very rich and flavorful broth, and tender pork chashu in the Paitan. We waited for an hour in line, but forgot about that the moment we had the first taste of the ramen. Definitely going back for my next Ramen craving :)
author: Rohit N.

description: This is the first ramen place I have ever been to the vegan tantanmen albeit expensive is worth every penny. If you are vegan, vegetarian or even an omnivore you will enjoy this dish. Wait might be a bit long and there is always a line outside, service is good and fast. The enoki mushroom chips are a must have! Don't forget to squeeze the lemon juice on it (it makes a huge difference).
author: Raymond H.

description:
For all the hype that is Mensho, it just doesn't hit the mark.  

I ordered their signature Tori paitan ramen with extra chashu, which is a chicken white broth ramen.  It came their fresh ramen noodles, 2 pieces of pork (which were quite thin), topped with some veggies, bonito flakes. Overall, i just found it quite lacking.

The three criteria which I usually judge quality ramen are:

1. Noodles - cooked with a bit of bite to it, similar to al dente
2. The broth - flavorful and compliments the noodles and toppings
3. The soft boil egg - a staple to most ramen, and shows how well the place cooks their food.

Now, to put these criteria to the test.

1. Mensho have some great ramen noodles. It was perfectly cooked and quite delicious 5/5.
2. The tori paitan broth was quite unfamiliar to me. Maybe it is just wasn't my style, because a chicken broth tends to be a lighter base compared to the typical tonkatsu broth you find elsewhere.  But the "light" broth with the heaviness of the creamy base just seemed to be unbalanced and just not as appealing to the palate. This is just my opinion, but seeing as how this is their most popular dish, they must be appealing to others  2/5
3. Soft boil egg.... There was none.  This is the first popular ramen place I have been to which did not serve an egg with their ramen.  This baffled me. Maybe their are trying to appeal to the "vegan" sensibility which makes no sense since ramen usually has an animal based broth.  0/5

For a $18 dollar bowl of ramen ( it was $2 extra for a thin slice of pork), it did not meet my expectation.  The broth was dull and unbalanced, the toppings lacking, and even the noodles couldn't save the dish.  It is quite a shame. Maybe this place is more of a hype since the long lines and small location make it seem like an amazing ramen parlor.

The long lines and mediocre broth just push this place to the wayside, but I guess if you are willing to wait for average food, and have the money to spend, try it out.
author: Jacky C.

description: Came here on a weekday night after seeing it was near top in regards to Yelp ratings & had a lot of hype. Had to wait in line for 20 minutes, but I heard from locals the wait can get up to 2 hours ... ouch. That being said, once I was seated, I ordered my ramen. In regards to offerings available here, this joint serves up different broths with modified tiers in each section along with appetizers, sake, and alcohol. As for how I found the ramen, it was quite good. The broth was more creamy than I imagined, but not so much to be overpowering. The egg was runny and warm, which is just the way I like it, and the noodles were perfect consistency - not too soft that it fell apart before you ate it but also not too chewy either. The chili pepper powder was a nice addition & the fixings only served to make this bowl a delight to eat. Now, would I say it lives up to the hype? ... Maybe. Reason why I say that is that there are plenty of comparable ramen places around this area that you can go to that don't require a 2-hr wait during peak hours. Overall, still a most stellar joint & worth dropping in for a visit when it's not so busy (weekday nights are best).
author: Jack M.

description:
I've only been here on 3 different occasions and I will make sure I make a visit each and every time I'm in SF.  
The one and only bad thing about this place is that we had to wait about an hour every time we've been here but that's given when you show up for dinner during its peak hours.  The chairs can get a bit uncomfortable but i mean it's a ramen spot, you're not going to be there for that long so... SUCK IT UP!!!  

When people used to tell me "oh their noodles are extra good bc it's handmade noodles", I would just smile but think to myself like "YOU CAN'T TELL IF IT'S HANDMADE NOODLES OR NOT!!!"  Well, I thought that until I had Mensho.  The noodles are nice & thick but very soft AND chewy.  You can tell tell they're handmade noodles!!!  The texture is great but I think the best thing about these noddles is the fact that the broth flavor sticks to the noodles very well, making your bite that much more flavorful.  Most ramen places I go to, I'm that guy eating the noddles with chopsticks AND spoon like I'm eating a bowl of pho, trying to eat the noodles while enjoying the flavor of the broth.  Well, you don't need to do that here.  The broth flavor sticks very well to the nice thick noodles so you can enjoy your bowl how you're supposed to.

What's also amazing about this place is that the broth is not overly salty like other places where you have to drink a gallon of water to keep yourself hydrated from all that salt.  I can't quite put my finger on what it is about the broth but it's very flavorful without being overly salty.

I'm not going to act like this is my regular ramen place I've been eating at for the past 5 years but I highly recommend the Tori Paitan which comes with pork & duck meat!  I am not a big fan of duck meat but TRUST ME!!!  You have to try it!  The lamb ramen was really good also.  Again, I'm not a big fan of lamb but you really have to try it!!!  Shoyu chasu ramen is probably the best I've had in its category.  

PLEASE NOTE:  15% gratuity is already added to your tab.  You will most likely end up sitting at a community table next to strangers but that's part of the experience.
author: Jang N.

description:
I had been wanting to try this ramen for quite some time and I finally got a chance to and oh boy, was I disappointed! The ramen is not good. And the service is pretty terrible too.

We waited over an hour to eat here and I am sorry that we wasted our time and money. 

In my first sip of ramen broth, I typically want another sip and another sip before I get to the noodles. However, the broth here was super bland and had no flavor. And the consistency was weird. Much more thicker than other ramen places I have been to.

My husband ordered a different ramen than I did and it was supposed to come with duck chashu but when it came out, it didn't have it in. He waved down our server and asked about it and she told him that he was wrong and that it doesn't come with the duck. We had to point it out to her on the menu and wait for her to go and double check. First off, know your menu. And second, check things before giving out information that isn't accurate.

They also add a 15% tip on your bill, which I'm not OK with. Granted I usually tip more than 15% but with the food and service I received, it just didn't feel good that they just added it into the bill with the expectation.
author: E C.

description:
Craving for ramen? More like...YAH...man. Bad joke/pun aside, Mensho Tokyo is anything but cringe worthy. 

The Tori Paitan Ramen ($16) is the chicken soup with pork and duck chashu, menma, kale, burdock, and katsuobushi sauce. My boyfriend and I both ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen with DOUBLE chashu ($18) for extra meat. 

After our first taste, my boyfriend and I both looked at each other with amazed faces. The chicken broth was rich, creamy, and super flavorful -- it made my insides feel warm and fuzzy. My boyfriend usually doesn't care about finishing the soup in ramen, but he finished this one (I did too). The meat was also tender and the noodles were chewy and thick. I'm currently drooling as I reminisce about this magical bowl. 

Service is polite and attentive. Wait time can range from 30 minutes to 2 hours. My boyfriend and I went on a Friday at 6:00 PM and waited in line for about an hour. Not sure if a 2 hour wait is worth it; an hour and a half is cutting it close. I highly recommend you go in small groups (1-3 people). 

The restaurant is also quite tiny and seems to accommodate about 28 to 30 people. There are only three communal tables: one long table and two smaller tables. Be ready to sit next to strangers elbow to elbow.

Despite the wait and tiny space, I will definitely come back!
author: Kristal D.

description:
Mensho Tokyo lives up to the hype! Let me start by saying I do not go to the TL. Call it TenderNob, call it "up and coming", I don't care. Not boujie just 5'2 and 110lb. The TL is scary and I'm not about about that life. 
That being said, I would 10/10 go again for Mensho Tokyo. It lives up to the hype. 
I know I know.. we all know "the best ramen" place in town... And waiting in line in the cold for a tiny restaurant is SO 2015. But this place is worth the try and worth the wait. You can taste the thoughtfulness of the ingredients and the space is communal and cool. 
I tried a couple different dishes and they were all so different but equally great. 
Thanks for helping me get over my fear of the TL with the only motivation my heart needs-- food. 


+1 I've interacted with the owner a couple times and he's super passionate and welcoming. Love supporting businesses like these! 

Xo
author: Pamela S.

description:
Worried about the line? Come early on a weekday! I went on a Wednesday at 6pm and there was no line and quite a few seats available. However, by 7pm when we left, there was a line out the door with ~15 people. Not too bad. 

Highly recommend the Tori Paitan Ramen. The soup is AWESOME, super flavorful but not too salty like a lot of ramen places. The noodles were also the kind I like - chewy and al dente. (So, if you like very soft noodles, this probably isn't the place for you.) 

We also ordered the vegan tantan noodles. Can't believe it was VEGAN! Tasted as if it had meat. If you're not a soup noodle type person, go with the tan tan noodles. 

The Shoyu or Salt flavored ramens are just not as flavorful or umami like the Tori Paitan or the tan tan noodles. So I would recommend sticking to what they're known for!
author: Rohenne L.

description: As usual in San Francisco, popular places requires a line (30 minutes in this case) before getting a seat in this small 24 to 30 seat establishment.  We went with the fried mushrooms as an appetizer followed with the tori ramen.  The app was not very tasty to me, however my guest enjoyed the taste.  It seemed to me as if it is mostly batter less mushrooms.  I decided to skip the lamb ramen as it was ground meat. The tori seemed unique from what ive had in Chicago or Minneapolis.  The rich and creamy chicken broth was great and unlike any other. The ramen texture was just cheey enough.  Price wise, it was a bit high, imo, however it very may be average cost of things in SF.  The place is located on the edge of tenderlion, which is supposed to be shady but I didnt get that feeling that night. I supposed if no one was in line or walking arounding after dark, the experience might be a bit different.  In conclusion, its a nice eatablish with fast service.  It's a place to try but given the numerous options in the city, I would likely not retry this place again for the sake of trying something new.  Based on a few I met while in line, there are a bit of repeat customers from all over the city.
author: Andrew C.

description:
4 stars for the double Tori Chashyu ramen ($18), 3 stars for the organic ramen ($14). 

The Tori Chashyu ramen was really good - creamy and not too salty. The organic ramen was plain and simple. It tasted clean, but not worth $14. I wouldn't recommend this. 

- Over priced food that isn't amazing. 
- Too loud in such a small restaurant. 
- The owner was way too rushed, which came off a bit rude. They literally want you in then out immediately after you finish your bowl. 

Note:
- This place is ideal for 1-2 people. It's not as convenient for groups of more than 3-4 people. 
- Line builds up outside, but it also goes fast because they rush you in and out.

This place is definitely over-hyped. Not worth coming back for!
author: Miranda T.

description:
The vegan ramen, I have now been told by the staff at this establishment, is actually NOT vegan. It contains egg noodles, according to the waitstaff.

I had this last night, and although delicious, when I order "vegan" food, it should ALWAYS live up to that.

Edit: I've been told by someone on yelp who claims to help run the establishment that the noodles are in fact vegan..

Then I was messaged privately and also responded to publicly here by someone who used to work for Mensho Tokyo and saw that the box of noodles used for the vegan ramen did in fact contain egg. Just as the waitress confirmed in-house.

Do you guys really want a troop of angry vegans with pitchforks descending upon your stoop? I didn't think so.
author: Nikki O.

description: This is my second time coming here. I got the Spicy Lamb Double Chasu w/ Ajitama. It was creamy and heavy but not too fatty (like their paitan) and i felt like a sphere after finishing the bowl but it was so good i didnt want to stop. The lamb was good and reminded me of dan dan noodles. There was a good balance of veggies, though they are diced very finely which generally means to enjoy them you will need to use the spoon. On that note the spoon is v big, which I thought was a tad unnecessary. I added an extra egg which had a unique flavor. It was well cooked, a tad overpowering in a bite though. I did notice that halfway through pieces got too small to use chopsticks. Finally there was a good level of spiciness, hitting you with a kick but not overpowering / did not detract from the rest of the ramen flavors. Overall along with Nojo they have won me as a repeat customer.
author: Vikram S.

description:
Line out the door but only waited 10-15 minutes.  Long bench tables, so you sit next to strangers.  For me it was normal, for my girlfriend, she was surprised since it was her first time at a legit noodle house.  

Noodles were chewy, freshly made, excellent.  Broth was perfectly salty.  

Appetizers small, very flavorful, and exactly what I expected in a good noodle house.
author: Cobra K.

description: Best ramen hands down. The wait will kill you but if you brace yourself for it (1. A good friend you can talk with for hours 2. If you're eating by yourself Netflix on your phone). Tori Paitan is super thick and delicious. Pretty pricey but being the best ramen, can't complain.
author: June L.

description:
Wait time is about an hour to an hour and a half (pending) There is no reservations so prepare to have some time on your hands.  

Fortunately this is San Francisco and the people outside are nice, and the weather is pretty good.  

I tried 3 different ramen's when I entered.  The lamb / / chicken (Tori Paitan) / / Organic Shoyu

Noodle Firmness:  All similar firmness from what I recall.  Very good noodle texture.  Perfectly al dente.  

Broth:  Lamb broth was way too thick, and I usually like my broth pretty thick.  It was almost like a paste- I do not recommend this one.  Chicken broth had a very strong flavor too it.  I recommend the Tori Paitan for anyone who likes thick broth.  The Organic Shoyu was a good light ramen.  

Price:  It's an expensive ramen ($15-$20) but will definitely fill you up simply because the broth is so thick.  I think it's ok if factor in the price of rent for San Francisco and the demand they're in.  

Overall it was a good experience from start to finish.  I would recommend they allow noodle refills for a lower cost.
author: Justin L.

description: 2 hour line on a weekend at 5pm but UNBELIEVABLY delicious. Worth the wait. Just bring a jacket and comfy shoes. Their other noodle dishes are just as delicious as their classic ramen dishes, so try to go with multiple people so you can all try out various things on the menu.
author: Olivia T.

description:
OMG! Required eating in San Francisco for VEGAN ramen lovers - for any lovers!
Do this - order the vegan ramen and add burdock, cabbage, and roasted garlic. Done.
You have to wait outside and it can take 15min early or late, and 30min when busy (on the weekdays).
Solution - walk across the street to the corner liquor store and drink a Sapporo in line - right out of the brown bag. . . Perfection.
author: Lee M.

description: Very thick both ramen, horrendous line. The ramen is probably one of the best in the bay area. I'm ok with thick broth but this is extremely thick and pretty creamy. The pork chashu is so thin than I barely felt that I just had a bite. I added the soya sauced egg. The yolk is creamy, so good but the outer egg white absorbed the soya so it's really salty. I would recommend the miso egg instead. Worth the 1.30hr wait? Probably not.
author: Vy T.

description:
My friend and I got there at 5:04pm on a Sunday night.  We waited for about 1.5 hours to be seated.  The restaurant is kind of small, It has around 28 seats in case you want to gage the waiting time.  ;)

The ramen soup was really rich.  You can absolutely taste the chicken favor.  That was very interesting to have duck meat in the ramen.  I really liked it.  

Honestly,  I won't wait for 1.5 hours again for the same ramen.  But it is worth it for a first timer. =)
author: Rachael C.

description:
Ordered a shoyo and a shio. A bit disappointed. Ramen were good, but no where near "michillen guide" standard. Forget about Japan, any decent ramen joint in Vancouver, Toronto, or NYC is just going to be so much better. 

Hand pulled noodles were unique, but not sure it worked that well with the broth. And there's a mandatory 15% tip added to the bill when we barely got any service?
author: David Z.

description: My favorite ramen shop in the city (and possibly in the country).  Given that the wait is usually around an hour and the prices are around $15-20/ bowl, I surprise myself by how often I return.  The Tori Paitan ramen is my favorite off the menu and I dream about it when I'm not in the city.  The soup is really rich and creamy, and all of the flavors worked really well together.  The noodles can be really hot though, so be careful about that.  If your group is looking for an appetizer, the enoki mushroom chips are also really good and satisfying!
author: Tim L.

description:
Got here at 530 on a gloomy, rainy Saturday and stood outside glaring at the patrons who were done eating and chatting it up. Eat and go people! 

Ate for 20 min and left! It's cramped inside with bar seating (4 ppl) and then 2 long tables that can seat ~15 or so. 

Got the ramen tori ramen $16 everyone gets and it was good! It's a thick broth and yes, the noodles were good. 

Also, the mushrooms... enochi chips in a chile lime dip. I would not get these again for $5 since it tastes like any other fried thing. It was partly that 1 hr wait!

We saw some ppl who came in a group and alternated waiting in line and going to a bar. What a fantastic idea. 

Would I wait an hour to eat here again? No. no no no. Liked it, but I think dining is a lot about experience, and I can't say that the packed restaurant and 1 hour wait outside is worth it.
author: Anmy V.

description: I came here on a Tuesday night at 7 PM and had to wait an hour to get seated. Despite the wait, the food was alright. It is a flavorful ramen but it's definitely on the pricier side. I got a double meat of the Tori Paitan Ramen. It was very heavy and a little too salty for my taste. This place is worth a try, but I would go elsewhere for ramen because I have found better places. I would recommend trying Marufuku Ramen instead. I have tried this place twice now, and I feel that it isn't worth the wait or the price.
author: Lynn T.

description:
MATCHA RAMEN. 
Never had this combination but Mensho changed my life forreal. It was so good.... especially with their soft pork cha shu slices. The broth is a bit thick and different compared to a regular soup base. Pricey but this bowl of noodles is so rare in SF. 
Soy sauce oysters were way salty but ramen was my main goal anyway. Will be back!
author: Gloria L.

description:
True Rating 3.5 stars.

Came here around 10PM and there was a line, however my boyfriend and I only waited for 5 minutes since we were a small party (yay!)

The place is pretty small, but I like how bright it was. Staff is efficient and friendly, they were definitely all Japanese! 

Ordered:
Tori Paitan: OK...it was too creamy for me and i felt the soup was grainy. Noodles were decent, the duck meat was delicious! I have had this ramen in Japan before so I kind of have an idea what they are trying to make here. The soup came be more smooth and not as heavy 
Oysters: OK...too salty, nothing too special, small little oysters, I wouldn't recommend

I wouldn't say this is worth a 2 hour wait, but no wait, it can be a decent place. I prefer Ramen Dojo.
author: Natalie L.

description:
Over-hyped. Over-salty. Over it.

There must be something buried deep in our Americanized taste buds that confuses "tasty" with "an abundance of sodium". There must be something that makes us stand in line for hours to drool over the newest, coolest thing, to brag about it to our friends, to blab on Instagram about this beautiful, postable, tasty thing that landed in this tech-infested, brunch-addicted, 5-star-inflated city. Ramen in America has become such a dining experience. Something that was made to be fast, cheap and good has metamorphosed into long waits, double-priced, and salty to the point of unbearable, but somehow still receives raving reviews, even Michelin-recommended. 

"Just over a century ago, two French tire manufacturers created the Michelin guide. According to the author, it has blighted the lives of chefs from Brooklyn to Bombay, while spawning legions of checklist gourmands." -Vanity Fair

We got there at 430pm, 30 minutes before opening, and the line was already 40 people deep. After waiting an hour, we ordered the Tori paitan and spicy lamb ramen. Don't get the Spicy lamb ramen. It's like someone poured a cup of salt in a bowl of meat and noodles and water. no matter how good the pics look.  Maybe that day they spilled a gallon of salt in the pot. The Tori Paitan was okay, but still makes you want to pass out immediately from the heaviness. Maybe I'm just crazy. Or maybe theres a reason why there's so much obesity and diabetes in this country. I really hope the Japan Tokyo Mensho is better. If it's anything like this, Tabelog would not be kind.
author: Kris W.

description:
I'm not feeling it. My organic shoyu had way too much bonito and was greasy. I ate like 1/4 of it before being turned off. The meat was skimpy and the noodles forgettable. 

Hubby liked the spicy lamb and the enoki chips coming out of the kitchen looked good. 

Got on line at 4:15 on a Sunday and made the first seating. Glad we didn't wait long.
author: Tara W.

description:
So much hype. Such a long wait. And yet... Such amazing food!!

We waited over an hour as a party of 4 for a weeknight dinner; the line was consistently pretty huge. Service is quick, and the place is small, but cute and clean. The tables are communal so you're in pretty close quarters with your neighbors.

Most of us ordered the tori paitan, and one of my friends ordered the tantanmen, which she enjoyed. The broth for the tori paitan was amazing - probably the richest soup I've ever tasted! Noodles were a great consistency; everything about the dish was great overall. 

I would absolutely come back. I just need to brace myself for the always significant wait...
author: Delia Z.

description:
Mensho is by far my favorite ramen spot in San Francisco (my #1 used to be Orenchi in Santa Clara but I haven't been there for years). I've visited Mensho for 3 times and I had great dining experiences each time. The waiting time during weekdays is manageable, I waited 30 mins the most and got seated right after (around 7:30pm). Weekend is tricky, like other popular restaurants, at least an hour if you are lucky.

I got the Ume Shio Ramen twice (was trying to get something else but I really like Ume Shio, plus you can't find this anywhere), Tori Paitan Ramen once and they were both amazing. When a bowl ramen has the perfect cooked noodles and flavorful broth, it's hard not to come back for it. It's a bit pricy, but it's definitely worth it!

2017007
author: Leslie C.

description:
I was stuck between two ramen shops and decided to see what the hype is about here. I got to Mensho 30 minutes before their opening and there was already a line outside. So if you come...come early!! 
I came alone so I got to sit at the bar and I could watch the ramen chefs at their work. The place itself it pretty aesthetically pleasing, but it's also super cramped. Four people is honestly the max. The bigger tables are all connected, so you're also essentially going to be sitting with strangers. 
As for the ramen, I was slightly disappointed. I went with the Tori Patan ramen instead of the matcha. Matcha in ramen sounds so strange, but I think I'd come back to try the matcha. 
For $16, I got to have pretty good ramen noodles. The noodles weren't hard or soft, for lack of a better word..they were bouncy. But the soup killed my vibe. Perhaps I'm just not used to thick ramen soup, but it was strange. First sip, I thought I was drinking a fatty cream. The chashu did not melt. I had to chew a bit. I did prefer the duck chashu over the pork, just because it was more bite-sized and with chashu that doesn't melt in your mouth..easier to chew. The dried burdock root was super tasty though.  I couldn't get enough of it. I had to add an egg because ramen isn't ramen without an egg. The egg was delicious except it was a bit over done. But I'm not complaining because making a perfect ramen egg is extremely difficult. 
So, for a spontaneous trip to SF I got to eat $22 ramen. It is overpriced, but if you consider SF rent, I'll take it. I would come again just to try the matcha ramen, but this is not going to be on my ramen must have list. Fun for the experience, not fun for taste and price.
author: Michelle W.

description: I lined up for an hour to check this place out and it did not disappoint. The shoyu double charsiu ramen hit the spot.  Also highly, highly recommend the mushroom fries.  Just a great meal.
author: Andrew S.

description:
Enoki Chips: 6.5/10 Tasted mostly of batter, wouldn't order again.
Spicy Tori Ramen w/ Duck Sub: 9/10 Goddamn was this good. Super thick creamy soup packed full of flavor with tender duck pieces and a variety of toppings. Only thing that could be better would be the amount of veggies given.
author: Anthony L.

description:
Good things happen to those to wait. A phrase that fits my experience at Mensho Tokyo. I mean the complexity of flavors you are getting from any great ramen broth takes time and love...hours of it. Trust me.. I've seen documentaries on it??..pause. hahahah ¯\_(ツ)_/¯ . Well, try to pay some damn respect to the art! An hour wait for amazing ramen such as mensho is a small price to pay so get to scrolling through your social media feeds or better yet talk to others who are waiting alongside you. You guys are all in line for some the same bowl of ramen so you must share interests. Sheesh. 

Tori Paitan Double Chashu...must get, would order again and again. The broth was nothing short of excellent. It was unlike any ramen broth I've ever had considering I've never had chicken based broth. Real thick in consistency but it clinged onto each and every bite of noodles as I almost slurped my face off.  The noodles had the perfect balance of resilience to it. Not too chewy, not too soft. Absorbant enough to pick up the broth's flavor. I loved that. The egg though...I was not expecting it to be flavored. I believe we got the soy sauce flavored egg which was something new and different to me. Don't get me started with the combination of pork&duck chashu. I've never had duck in my ramen but now I can't imagine my bowls of ramen without it. First world problems smh. The enoki mushroom chips were also a great idea... so light and crisp. I ended up using these mushroom chips as a garnish to my ramen. Next level... 

No complaints about their quick and great service. Gratuity is automatically applied to the your bill though. I wish the shop was larger but I wouldn't complain if my shop had a line out the door on a daily basis. The decor and ambiance is a nice touch. The nerd within me can't hate on the organic compounds related to umami drawn out and explained on the walls. 

I'm coming back to try their tsukemen whenever I get the chance. Leeeeeessss get it.
author: David N.

description:
Pretty amazing I must say, although the bill didn't look too appealing for two people. Went a little overboard with one of my buds and we spent more than we had anticipated for two bowls of ramen, oysters, beer and sake (woops!). Money well spent at the end of the day (to justify the hole in my wallet).

Was in the mood for ramen and just so happened to be in the area as well... hey... why not give Mensho a shot? Line was not too long and table for two was seated in 45 minutes (it was 10:00 pm on Friday at the time though). This place is also very tiny, so not such a good place to dine at if you're with a party larger than 4 folks.

My bud and I were feeling adventurous so we went ahead and ordered the Oysters in Shoyu Dare Oil and I think our experience would have been better off if we didn't order it (personal preference of ours, it might be amazing to someone else). 

Japanese IPA and Sake made for an awesome double-fist combo as we downed the oysters.

I tried their Tori Paitan Ramen with double ChaShu - after my first bite, I knew I was in for something special for the entire meal. Broth was loaded with flavor, very thick and creamy and it was nothing I have ever tried before... definitely the highlight of Mensho.

Overall lovely experience, it is a shame that this place is so small. I'd love to keep coming back, but the wait is absurdly long during peak hours. You'd have to start lining up for at least 30 minutes before they open in order to dodge the epic-long wait.
author: Sam K.

description:
This place truly does have good ramen. I had the tori paitan ramen. Soup was very rich in  flavors. It's kinda like a soy sauce based soup which is a bit too strong for me. I prefer the shio ramen more. But the noodles were fantastic! And the chasu meat was so good....very soft and flavorful. Was not impressed with the options for the sides. They did not have corn!! So used to eating my ramen with corn..and no chili flakes either! But I guess those ingredients would taken away the flavors of the broth. 

I also got the oysters in shoyu oil. It's 5 dollars for 4 pieces but they gave us 6 instead! Yes! We definitely came up with that so wooot! This was surpsingly very goood...it was oysters in soy sauce. Never had it that way before but it was amazing. Definitely worth the 5 bucks.

Update:
The vegan broth is so good. Think I'm gonna get vegan broth with a side of chasu next time I'm here. 

Come early if you  wanna eat here. Come an hour before it opens. We came at 4 last sat and to our surprise, some one was already in line when we got there. By the time it was 430, the line was  insanely long already !! Just do yourself a favor and come early. There's only enough seat for like 25 people there so wait can be long.
author: Caitlin P.

description: Small place with the potential for long waits, but the ramen is very tasty.  The broth comes in either creamy or not, and it seemed like the thickness of the ramen depends on the broth.  For additions, the soft boiled egg and ground lamb were my favorites.
author: Simon G.

description:
I crave ramen pretty frequently and regularly. Ever since my visit to Mensho Tokyo, now I just crave Tori Paitan Ramen. It's so deliciously perfect in every way. The broth is wonderfully flavorful and creamy, and the noodles are the perfect texture and chewiness. It's like they took all my disappointments with other ramen bowls, fixed them, and added their own special mix. It's absolutely fantastic!

At first glance, it's one of the more pricey bowls of ramen that I've had and I had my doubts about eating there or ordering the Tori Paitan. However, it's worth every penny. This is one bowl of ramen I'd gladly wait for, and shell out the $$$ for. 

Apparently it's usually a long wait, but I went on a weekday close to opening, and there wasn't too long of a wait (~20 min)

Service is nice, the atmosphere is bright and the decorations are modern. The restaurant is very small, and from what I could see, all the seats were high chairs. So maybe not optimal for a large group or kids.

Regardless, go get that Tori Paitan! You will not regret it!
author: Tsyria T.

description:
There's so many ramen joints around the Bay Area and they're all good in their own way but none has ever stood out to me until I came to Mensho. Prior to trying Mensho, Ippudo Ramen in NY was my favorite ramen spot ever. Unfortunately Mensho has stolen Ippudo's spotlight and is seriously the best ramen that I've ever had.

Had an impromptu day with some friends in the city and kinda winged it as to where to get food. My friend was browsing through Yelp for awhile and he picked very wisely. He asked if we were down for some ramen and off we went. Luckily when we got there, the line was starting to form so it wasn't too bad. We got in line while my friend tried to find parking. We waited in line for about 1.5 hour which honestly isn't that bad since Mensho is pretty small inside. So keep in mind it's not friendly for groups. As the line started to move once their doors opened and people were filling up the tables, my friends and I were so close to getting in and we were close to making the cut.

While anxiously waiting we browsed through their menu and as people were leaving, we asked what they got which made the decision process a lot easier. Finally we got seated by this counter seating which was fine. We got to see the chefs in action and it was interesting to see the process of it all. I had ordered the Clam Butter Chashu Ramen since I've never seen anywhere serve clams with ramen. My friends got the Tori Paitan Ramen with Duck Chashu and the Spicy Lamb Chashu Ramen. We ordered the Oysters in Shoyu Dare Oil, which was really yummy. There was enough pieces for the 3 of us to try and to hold off our appetite as we patiently waited for our ramen.

Once our ramen had arrived, we tried each other's broths. The ones that my friends ordered had a creamy broth and it was so savory and delicious. My broth was lighter but still delicious. At first when I tried the broth for my ramen, it had a strong seafood taste but after mixing that whipped butter and all the other ingredients in my bowl together, there was a huge shift in the taste of my broth. It was much more flavorful and that strong seafood taste was masked...probably by the butter but I'm not complaining. The noodles in my ramen were a bit different from my friends but they were so fresh and tasty. So delicious!

The service was alright. Had to flag down a server a few times to get more water. They were busy and it was packed so I understand. The decor was very simple and minimal.

When my friend had told me it was Michelin star rated I wasn't sure how I felt but after trying the food, it definitely proved me wrong. The quality of the ingredients was amazing. As mentioned earlier, it's one of the best ramen that I've ever had. I was craving for more the next day because it was so good. We had met some tourists in line and they told us it was their second time going during their trip in SF. That speaks volume.

Highly suggest trying this place and try to come as early as possible to wait in line. There was already a line at 4PM and they don't open until 5PM. Be patient and you'll have some of the best ramen ever!
author: Connie C.

description:
Had high hopes for this place. Maybe too high.

As with most ramen places, you expect to wait in line. You can either wait in line later, or you can wait in line before it opens. We chose the latter. We got there at 430pm, expecting to wait 30 minutes for the 5pm opening. Luckily, there was only 1 person ahead of us. Was able to walk down the street grab a cup of coffee from Starbucks and return without any problems.

Come 5 pm, window shades open. Pristine, small, clean dining room with the kitchen in the back. You could just anticipate a good ramen experience. Appeared it was well-staffed. Unfortunately, no one opened the door, as everyone just peered through the window, watching the staff working on the computer system.... Wait 5 minutes, nothing. Wait 10 minutes, nothing. Wait 30 minutes, finally, the head hostess comes out.

"Sorry, but our system is not accepting credit card. We can only accept cash. Please go to an ATM." Are you kidding me? I think cash-only establishments are OK, and I have no problem with this. But really? It took you 30 minutes to let us know this? Of course, all of us in line have been waiting and waiting, so we all make a dash to the nearest ATM. I think it makes more sense to let us know at the very beginning there was issues, so while we inevitably wait more in line, we can go get some cash......... amiright?

Further insult to injury. we didn't get seated for another 15 minutes... So really, 45 minutes after "opening." It doesn't make common sense.

Anyway, had the Tori Paitan ramen and the Vegan Tantanmen.
-Tori Paitan: Deep chicken broth flavor. Very creamy and filling. I think I heard it described as a chicken soup for rich people. I may be able to buy into this description. For our patience in line, we got an extra chashu (which is not the best anyway). Noodles were very enjoyable, al dente, and on point. However, the broth just didn't do it for me.
-Vegan tantanmen: Surprisingly, I will have to rate this above the tori paitan. The flavor is fuller and more complex. It has almost a nutty quality to it, so if you don't like nuts, would not suggest this one. But it was always very creamy and filly of a broth. Noodles the same. 

Unfortunately, given the late start and unreasonable wait without explanation (and even with an explanation, still does not explain make us wait beyond the opening time), I have to rate an overall 2 stars. Service while seated is great, but the compilation of average ramen and initial impression once we got there, has left a bad taste in my mouth.
author: Edward L.

description:
5/5 on ramen its up there. I had the regular pork and duck ramen. The broth was very thick and flavorful! Alot of dashi and bonito flakes? From what I read on the wall theres not alot of sodium since the dashi enhances umami it also has a salty taste without alot of sodium? Correct me if i'm wrong.

2/5 parking looks horrible idk when its not all busy but its sf so what do you expect. There was a long line when we got here and took about at least 30 mins. But people eat and go.

3/5 atmosphere. Great place if you are an extrovert and like being surrounded by others sharing tables but alot just mind their own business. 

3/5 facility. Very small. Long tables used to share.

Overall i gave 4 just because of the food alone. I have yet to try the clear broth. Looks just as tasty as the thick one
author: Gerald L.

description:
Talk about hype. Here's where you get it all; amazing & mouth watering pictures on social media, hour long wait almost on the daily and great food to leave satisfied, hungry for me. 

I now frequent Mensho Tokyo as my go to Ramen place given it's deliciousness and the fact that my girlfriend knows a couple of the waitresses. It is indeed the best Ramen in the city and worth the time, wait and money. Bring a friend, phone, or meet someone new while standing in line. If you're solo, easy seating. 2 or more, stay a while. In my 3 trips I've spent at least 1 hour 30 mins in line. 

My go to is the Tori Paitain Ramen, Double Chasu ($~20). The broth was great, so rich, so creamy. Every single piece of chashu was incredibly and tastefully mind blowing. Enoki chips on the side. Be sure to grab some sliced habanero on the side to spice things up a bit. Fuego
author: John M.

description:
Tasty ramen and fast service (once you are inside), but in my opinion this place is overhyped! 

I've heard so many great things about this place, that it's one of the best ramen shops in SF.

I came with a friend on a Friday night around 5pm. We waited in line for 20 minutes, which was a short wait compare to how long my friends had to wait (about 1-1.5hr).

The shop is very small, and can seat 25 people MAX. There are 2 long tables, and you will have to share space with strangers. There is very little wiggle room, and with everyone talking, it's hard to hear each other even across the table. 

I ordered the vegan tantanmen, which seems like the most popular choice. It was also the most expensive one too - $18. The soup is made with many exotic ingredients and nuts. I think the flavor was there but not the substance. I felt like there were so many other things going on - with the konbu, mushrooms, kale sprouts, etc, etc, but not enough ramen!! It's suppose to be a ramen shop. 

Also again, with there being so little personal space and loud background noise, it was hard to really enjoy something tasty. I also think I paid too much for this.
author: Wendy F.

description: This place always hit the spot when I am craving for some good old ramen. Their tori paitan is a bit heavy but it is so good. Not the traditional type of Japanese ramen. Their ingredients are fresh and blends well together. The only thing I dread is the wait and the parking. Also the seatings are not that comfortable. Other than that, I would come here for a late night dinner.
author: Amy T.

description:
Mensho is amazing. Don't even read the reviews, just go. Wait is usually ~1 hour. If you go alone, it's possible that you may be able to skip the line sometimes when one seat opens up. I love Mensho so much, it's now the only experience I am willing to wait this long for.

Review:

Now having gone to Mensho about once a week, I know that the ramen is consistently made and every item is excellent. 

Mensho is ALL ABOUT RAMEN. Your snack options are the fried enoki mushrooms and oyster appetizer. But you come here to be taught how ramen can be transcendental and get an experience closer to what you might have in Japan.

The tori paitan broth is unlike any I have had. Thick and rich, but not chunky. Full of umami. In fact, the tori paitan is the best chicken based broth you can find in San Francisco. Toppings were extremely complementing and portioned perfectly. The chasu is especially notable. Have not had better chasu at any ramen house. Noodles were thicker, bouncy, chewy, and oozing with flavor from the broth. The balance between the ramen noodles and broth was absolutely perfect such that the broth clung to the noodles to give your every bite flavor. 

If you would like a lighter meal, try the shoyu broth. This is my usual go to :) The noodles a little flatter and the broth is absolutely rich, but not heavy at all. My other favorite is the arubasoba -- a soupless ramen made with a soyu, garlic, and pork base. 

Between eating ramen in Tokyo and here, Mensho is the only spot that satisfies.
author: Kathy Z.

description:
I almost want to give 3.5 stars, but the handmade noodles and the quality of the pork and duck slices was too prime to lower. This was my first time at Mensho, and I was immediately astonished by the line on an early Saturday evening. After waiting in line for about an hour and finally being ushered into the small restaurant space, I decided to order the Tori Paitan Ramen, containing Rich and Creamy Chicken Soup, Pork Chashu, Duck Chashu, Menma, Kale, Burdock, Katsuobushi Sauce. 

PROS: 
- delicious (!!) pork and duck chasu. I had never had duck in my ramen before, but it was so tender and juicy and a great addition.
- handmade noodles. They had that inconsistent size and shape characteristic of a handmade noodle and they weren't chewy and harder like the premade or packaged ramen at some other spots. 

CONS:
- the broth! This might be an unpopular opinion, but it was just too damn rich and creamy, almost as if they had poured cups and cups of cream and milk. I definitely wasn't able to consume much of the broth after getting through the ramen and for hours after my meal, I felt like I was going to be sick. If (IF!) I were to come back again (maybe when it's raining and there's no ridiculous line), I'd try the Shoyu broth instead. 
- so there's kale in your ramen...but no option to add an egg? What??
- that line. Sorry, there's no justifying it, and in my case, not sure it was worth it. 

In summary, I didn't have the most mindblowing experience here, and perhaps it was because I was let down given all the hype. But due to the quality of meat and the delicious handmade ramen, I didn't feel I could go lower than 4 stars here.
author: Sarah N.

description: Holy sh@t this place is out of this world! I'm picky about my food and this place blew it out of the water for me. We arrived at 6pm and had to wait about an hour, BUT IT WAS SOOOO WORTH IT! The flavor is spot on!!!
author: Lana S.

description:
I'm usually picky about ramen.
Ramen is a quick, and a simple meal.
Lot of ramen shops decorate it too much with their egotistical ideas of how to make it better.
Ramen is already good as is. I hate when people try to re-invent ramen. Please just don't ruin it. 
Instead, soup, noodle, pork, all the simple ingredients should be worked on. So you keep the original intention and integrity is kept but flavor takes you to another level. 

With that said, Mensho Ramen is by far the best ramen place I've eaten in United States
Their soup is so flavorful. It's not too thick or too salty, it's just right that you can keep eating without getting heavy. 
Noodle consistency is perfect. Just right amount of hardness that you can feel the waves of the noodles
And toppings just tops it off.

You definitely want to go with friends or loved ones since you have to sit close to other clients. 
Everytime I visit here, I am happy to know I have good company, because people who sat next to us didn't talk much and were on the phone  enjoy ramen and company instead! Anyway 

I highly recommend this place
author: Yuki K.

description:
I'll start off by saying I am in no way a fan of Ramen. at all. However, the hype around this place made it that much more intriguing to want to try this place out. And my goodness - probably the BEST ramen I have ever tasted in my life! 

I came here with a group of friends when we first heard wind of the restaurant's grand opening. We decided to be smart people and arrived here right when the restaurant opened. Boy, were we late. We waited an additional 2 hours in line after arriving at the restaurant right when it opened. The restaurant itself is fairly small and only had room for seating for a small amount of people. Majority of the people at the restaurant ended up sharing with another party when they sat down. Even so, by the time we got to the front of the line, we were greeted by one of the owners of the restaurants. With a smile on his face and thanking us for being so so patient, it made us less agitated and more excited to go in and try out the food! I decided to go with the Tori Paitan, since it looked the most appealing and my boyfriend suggested I add double chashu...and it was the best decision I ever made. The chashu was so tender and buttery that it literally melted in my mouth. The Tori Paitan was just as delicious with its flavorful broth and creamy texture. If this was how every ramen I ever tasted actually tasted like, I can say I love ramen. BUT, every ramen I have tried since this place has been a disappointment because the ramen here is THAT good. 

Despite the long wait and the small seating area, it is still absolutely worth it. You have to come and try this place out to really know what I'm talking about.
author: Victoria K.

description: Super delicious ramen, and one of the newest trends and fads in San Francisco. I came here around 11:30 on s Sunday night, and there was about a half hour wait in line, but it was well worth it. We met Yoshi, the manager, and he was extremely helpful and polite. I was super satisfied with the ramen I ordered, and the sake. I will be back for sure!!
author: Ross S.

description: Duck chashu is a must here! The wait is terrible, especially on a cold SF night, but the food was delicious. They make great use of the small space they have available, meaning that the tables are communal. While I'm not the biggest fan of that concept, we sat next to some nice folks and it made for good conversation with our meal.
author: Kimberly N.

description:
Soup is way too creamy. I like ramen that are creamy but this one's  too much.

I was throwing up in the middle of the night.. 
Sick all day the following day. 
Will I go back? No. I'll stick with my ramen parlor in san mateo.

Btw, $17 with not much topping?  Plus add the long wait coz the place is really small.
author: Yardley P.

description:
Let me start this off by saying, I'm not normally a ramen person so take my review as you wish...

I found this place on yelp as we were staying downtown for a few nights and my fiancé is a ramen fan so I figured we could check it out. 

We got in line at 7:05pm on a Thursday night and didn't get seated until 8:40pm which we were prepared for since it's a small space. The inside was nice and bright and the service was friendly and quick. 

2 people of our party ordered spicy lamb ramen, one of us ordered the soupless ramen and I got the original shoyu ramen. My fiancé said the pork in his spicy lamb ramen was the best he's ever had! Mine was pretty good. The broth was perfect for the cooler night. Slightly salty but so is shoyu ‍ some of my noodles were in a clump and not quite the texture I was imagining but ehh maybe I should try something else

One perk about the place is that they already add in the tip into your bill so it's nice and simple
author: Jealee A.

description:
We got 30 mins before opening time on Thursday at 4.30 pm and were the first in line.  People started to show up after us and we got in on the first seating, which is about 30 people.  This place can be quite cramped and baskets are provided on the floor for your belongings.  Just remember to pick them up when u leave.

Been meaning to try this place since my friends said it was so good.   The menu is very limited, only one appetizer offered, oysters for $5, which had a oily smoky taste.  We also had the Tori Paitan, which was really thick and creamy, garnished with thin slices of duck, chasrsiu, burdock and kale. For extra charsiu, there was an extra $2 charge. 

Would come back to try other items on the menu.  We sat on the counter facing the kitchen, so it was entertaining watching our order being made and served to us.  But I wasn't keen on that huge silver serving spoon to eat my ramen, too big and it retained heat and just weren't suitable to use...just wished I said something coz I noticed the yelp photos showed small wooden ones. Also, there are no boxes for take out or left overs, so bring ur own or finished everything up, which I'm sure would not be a prob!
author: Elaine Y.

description: Mensho Tokyo is a good place to have some Japanese flavor, I really love their noodles because the noodles are chewier and have a elasticity to them, the ramen at this place is just amazing starting from thr Maccha Tori Paitan, Spicy Lmb,Shio and Clam Butter. Though the wait is long due to the busy nature and too many customers, the wait is worth it eventually since the services are amazing and food comes very fast compared to other restaurants around. Every employee is super kind and very quick to respond. Even with the large crowds, I was able to take as long as we needed to eat without ever feeling rushed.
author: Brian M.

description:
I, like so many love Ramen, Mensho is the Real Deal, Tokyo Style, inventive, not super heavy and freaking delicious! 

The only gripe I have is that I can't take my left-overs home, they don't think the noodles are good the next day, but I paid for it and it should be up to me. 

Otherwise, I love it.
author: Cesar R.

description:
Horrible service form the waiter/waitress.
Idk the hype doesn't correlate with the expectation. I was very disappointed.
I've had better ramen form Tampa. 
Plus NO togo!, they give you a huge bowl for close to $20 and they throw it away if you don't finish it. Thats just wasteful, and bad for the environment. I think they have there heads up there ass, thinking they make are out of noodles and dead animals.
author: Alek C.

description: Ok this place is ok.. I didn't like the creamy ramen broth but the noodle was ok. It tasted powdery. It's almost like they took the well done boiled egg yolk and smashed it in the broth to make it powdery.  I've been to Japan and I can say it's not all that. I preferred the shoyu broth with the ramen noodle. The Shoyu broth is good. I really enjoy the lychee sake and fried mushroom. Service is ok. I didn't wait long for a table since we got here when they just open. I wouldn't wait or worth waiting for over 30 minutes. 3.5 star because the shoyu broth is good, lychee sake, and fried mushroom.
author: Christy V.

description: One of my favorite ramen restaurants here in SF. The servers are amazing and respectful, service is always on point and the food is amazing. Try the Enoki chips with one of their daily limited ramen. My favorite to date is still the clam butter bowl with tasty scallops pictured.
author: Ruben G.

description:
Eating at Mensho is like eating brunch in San Francisco: the wait is RIDICULOUS.

They open at 5pm, but David C. and Allen C. were there at 4pm to be the first ones in line. (Yay friends!) By 4:30pm, there was a pretty decent line going on. The restaurant only seats 28 people, so do the math to see if you will be part of the first wave that gets seated! If not, you're looking at (at least) a 30 minute wait.

The Tori Paitan ($16, $18 if you want to add extra chashu) is the chicken soup with pork and duck chashu, kale, burdock, and katsobushi sauce. The broth was rich, creamy, and very flavorful. But the shining star of this bowl of ramen was definitely the noodles. They were thick and perfectly QQ! 

They have two communal tables and a few bar seats. So not the best place for a first date unless you want other people to overhear your awkward conversations!
author: Christine S.

description: The quality and price are not worth the wait. The broth was thick but bland. I had to add salt to get any flavor. I just came back from a trip to Tokyo and it made me realize how overhyped this place is and that most of the customers have never had a good bowl of ramen in their lives.
author: J D.

description:
Different than the regular ramen parlors I've been to. The soup was creamy and thicker than your average ramen. The Cha Shu style duck was delicious! 

Service is hit or miss. I ordered with one waiter and a different waitress brought me my food. Me not knowing starting eating and the gentlemen came back and said I was eating the wrong dish. -___-
The gentlemen dining next to me was waiting for his food and a different waitress came by and dropped his check before he even received his food or received his $11 beer he ordered. Lol
author: Liz N.

description:
OK, its a great place, but man it really makes me feel like I'm at one of those conveyor belt restaurants, except in this case, I am one of the many people on that conveyor belt.
That made me feel a little bit disgusting, on the inside...
That said, the food is very good.
author: Steve S.

description:
Steep price point for ramen due to inflated SF food scene and rent, sadly yes
So ridiculously hyped up that it has led to outrageous wait times, a frustrating yes
Super tight awkward seating arrangements, YUP! 

With all that being said and done

Is it one of the most delicious bowls of ramen you will have in SF and thank yourself for enduring the wait and price?

For me, this was a definitive YES! 

Overall Thoughts

Good god, what an amazing bowl of ramen, so much so that it makes you question every other place you have been and now hold a much higher standard of excellence!
author: Eddie W.

description:
Hands down best ramen in SF. We came here as part of our ramen 2K17 run. Le bf and I came on a weekday and waited in line 20 minutes before the restaurant opened. We were the second group to be seated that day. Between the 2 of us, we ordered 3 bowls, definitely worth it. We both left stuffed. 

We ordered the shoyu (which I always tend to go for), the tori paitan, and the limited clam butter ramen. All the soups were very rich and the noodles were cooked perfectly. Once they put the tori paitan in front of the bf, he didn't want to let me have any of it, and totally fair. The shoyu ramen was the best shoyu ramen I've had. I've been going to Japan for many years, and I eat ramen at least once a day when I'm there. The clam ramen was on a whole other level. They only serve 10 bowls a day. It had a ton of shaved butter that melted into the broth making it so very creamy. 

Pro tip: get double chashu for $2 extra in the tori paitan. You will not regret it.
