5 star service and 5 star food. We will definitely be back.
author: Carolyn Z.

description: Absolutely worth the wait. We were first in line so we got to try the special Wagyu Ramen, we also got the traditional spicy pork ramen. The broth is very good, better than most other ramen places, but only by a little. The thing that really sets Mensho apart is the noodles. They are incredible. Handmade, perfect texture. Go now, but expect to wait 30-45 mins in line.
author: Hari S.

description:
I've eaten ramen in a lot of places in the Bay Area (Ramen Dojo, Orenchi, etc), in LA, Vancouver, NYC, and Tokyo, so I've definitely eaten my share of ramen. This is definitely up there in the top 5 ramens that I've had. 

This place is tiny, so brace yourself for a wait. I came at 7:30 pm on a Friday evening with just one other person, and waited about 30-45 min. I probably wouldn't wait more than an hour for the ramen. It's good, but there are other things to eat that are good that don't warrant just standing in line outside in the Tenderloin. Because the place is tiny and communal seating, don't come with more than one other person. Maybe a max of 4 people.

There are 3 different types of broth you can order but I got the Tori Paitan which is a rich, creamy chicken broth. I haven't really seen this kind of broth in other places, but it's so delicious and indulgent. It's definitely not healthy, and I don't want to see what this broth looks like when it is cold and starts to solidify. The chashu was tender and almost fell apart, and the other toppings were delicious. The noodles were al dente and just perfect. It was really filling - I don't think I could have done extra noodles or extra chashu.

We also shared enoki chips which were deep fried enoki with a slightly spiced batter. They were definitely unique and delicious and would recommend this. The serving size was pretty decent on this.

I can't wait to come back here again - everything was delicious and I felt like I could have been transported to Japan. If you like a good bowl of ramen and have the patience to wait 30 min - 1 hour, go here.  The service, ambiance and food were all on pointe. The only downside is that it's a bit expensive for ramen - one bowl is ~$16-18 but I'd rather pay $5 more for good ramen than for mediocre ramen.
author: Christina L.

description:
I dont write many reviews on Yelp, much less give 5 stars, but if you only have one night to eat in SF, you MUST experience the Ramen at Mensho Tokyo!  I was in town for 5 days and had a lot of great food but Mensho took the cake on my favorite meal.  I fully expected a wait based on Yelp reviews and true to the comments ended up standing in line about an hour (watching Dave Chappelle on Netflix to pass the time).

Once seated I ordered the Spicy Lamb along with some kind of Japanese beer (no, it wasn't a Kiran Ichiban, it was something I've never heard of but cant remember).

Food was out in about 5 minutes and true to Ramen custom I dug right in, slurping and enjoying every last sip/bite.  I didn't find the broth too heavy as others have mentioned but maybe I was just that hungry after waiting in line for an hour. It was *totally* worth it, don't even hesitate to turn away based on the wait. I'm so glad I stuck it out.  

Do yourself a favor and eat at Mensho, you will not regret it!  Might be tough for big groups due to community seating.

NOTE: They do NOT do takeout/to-go orders!
author: Jeff F.

description:
The line was big. Broth is definitely thick and gelatinous. I would definitely prefer it to be pork based than chicken based. Warning very salty! 
Overall it was good but I enjoy Oh baby sushi ramen better. I guess it's because tonkotsu ramen is my favorite. Anyways its worth it. 
Really nice decor and stuff.
author: Anna C.

description:
4.5 Stars.

Finally after weeks of walking by this place everyday on my way home from work decided to give it a try. The hype, the line, the expensive menu - worth it.

Came here a little after 5 on a Sunday, the line was already down the street but my bf and I hopped in and anxiously awaited.  SF people are all about their lines, brunch, pastries, dinners, coffee, the Mensho Tokyo line just never seemed to move. We made the most of it by chatting with near by starving foodies about the absurdity of the long line all wondering if this place would live up to the hype. Thankfully, with a party of 2 we were able to skip some larger parties in line and got seats right at the bar looking into the kitchen. 

The restaurant is small but simple and clean.  Service was quick, we were immediately greeted by a waitress and placed the order right away.  One great thing about this place is the menu is so simple and straight forward,  no need to take time and decide what to get, only one appetizer and a few noodle options. I choose the Vegan Tantanman. 

My food came out way before my boyfriends dish so he did have to sit and salivate for a while watching me enjoy my big noodle bowl of goodness before he was able to dive in.  The flavor of the broth was incredible, rich in flavor a bit spicy, perfectly salty.  Typically with vegan/vegetarian noodle dishes the broth is lacking in flavor, but this one tasted like it had been simmering for days and I could drink it all day.  The noodles were perfectly al dente, a bit thicker than I am used to but nice for soaking up all the broth. 

My only issue with this spot was the fact that you could not take leftovers home.  I was so full from slurping up these delicious noodles and wanted to enjoy them the next day for lunch but the server told me it was owners policy that food couldn't be taken to go.  I hate to see food go to waste, especially after spending $20 on a bowl of noodles I wanted the chance to split this huge portion up into two meals. Hopefully they will either rethink this or next time we will go and share a dish as we were both left with a lot of food leftover. Otherwise, this place does live up to the hype and worth the wait.
author: Kelsey B.

description:
This has been on my to-try list for a while, and I put it off mainly so I wouldn't have to wait in some ridiculous line. Fortunately, we didn't have to wait too long to be seated when we came here a couple days ago, and the Tori Paitan Ramen was pretty good!

Broth - Rich, creamy, and super chickeny. I kinda wish they made a thick pork based broth, but the tori paitan was still delicious. Some people have mentioned that it's too salty, but I thought it was the right degree of saltiness. If I had to suggest anything, they could add more green onions or something else to offset the heaviness of the broth and meat toppings. While I enjoyed the rich profile of the ramen, having some sort of contrast would make it even better. Also, those weird metals spoons have got to go!

Noodles - Firm and springy. The noodles were great!

Toppings - I didn't care too much about the duck chashu, burdock, or kale. The pork chashu was very well made. It had a very earthy sweet flavor kinda like a Hakka style braised pork belly. 

Overall, it was pretty good, and I'd return when the line isn't super long.
author: Nei N.

description:
Just flew in last night at around 10 and I was madly craving ramen. All the local ramen spots around me were already closed or nearly closing til I found this gem. Let me tell you, PLEASE TRY THIS PLACE OUT. Although it's a fairly small space (I would say atleast 30 people max can be seated & its bar seating) the wait is not that long. People little sit, eat & drink, and pay their tab and leave. I spent about 30 minutes max in there eating (I was solo). 
Great customer service. Honestly don't remember the gal's name but she was very tentative and took my order rather quickly. I honestly did not know what to order so I ordered the first thing I saw- the Tori Paitan Ramen. My order came out quickly (within 10-15 mins max) and it was the most amazing ramen I have ever had. The broth is SO flavorful and thick.. there was no way I left anything in that bowl. Seriously, 10/10 would recommend.
author: Esther M.

description:
Definitely worth the wait, though don't know if it's worth the price. 

Once you order, the food comes out super fast, probably within 5-10 minutes, making up for the waiting you do outside of the restaurant.

My friend and I got the most popular ramen option on the menu, the tori paitan. I don't remember much about the noodles, but the broth was amazing! It was super rich and and flavorful. The texture is almost foamy, reminding us of a latte or hot chocolate..but savory.  Having visited shisengumi, daikokuya, and tsujita back in socal, I would still say Mensho still stands out, offering a great bowl of hot soup and noodles especially in the cold SF weather!! 

Will definitely be back to try other options on the menu..when I am in a patient and generous mood for a long wait and $20 ramen.
author: Shelly L.

description: This place is amazing. Totally worth the wait. Perfect for a cold Fall SF night. The restaurant opens at 5pm. We got there around 515, got seated at 630 and food didn't take long to come out. There was 5 of us. We got the fried enoki mushroom, spicy tori paitan, spicy lamb, and soba noodles. All were really good, though the lamb was a little gamey. They do give you a lot, but meat to noodle ratio was lacking. I would definitely come back.
author: Theresa N.

description:
Finally, got around to checking this ramen shop out. I have walked by it several times, only to see a huge line outside the door. This past weekend, I decided to wait in this line with a couple of buddies and we waited...and waited..and waited. I stood in line longer here, than I did at Rokurinsha in Tokyo!! Finally we made it to the front and got seated. As they do in Japan, Mensho will take your order while you are in line, so that your ramen is ready as soon as you get seated. 

The Tori Paitan is the move if you like thicker broth. Toppings include Rich and Creamy Chicken Soup, Pork Chashu, Duck Chashu, Menma, Kale, Burdock, and Katsuobushi Sauce. Double chasu is recommended. Read back those ingredients and tell me what is missing....I'll give you a second....That's right--NO SOFT BOILED EGG. Make sure you don't forget to order that as an extra topping ;)

Pros:
-HUGE portions. The way ramen should be (and is in Japan). 
-Lots of meat and high-quality meat.

Cons:
-Long line
-Space is space and seating is limited. Sometimes you have to share a table with someone you don't know. Ramen is supposed to be an intimate experience :(
-Why do they use chicken broth? It adds nothing to the taste and flavor :/
-There's an enormous latern hanging in the window that says "Tsukemen." Great, except for they don't serve tsukemen ramen -___-
author: Vasiliy M.

description:
TLDR: Tori Paitan was freaking awesome, spicy lamb is good but very heavy on the spice (gave me major heartburn and I didn't even finish the whole thing, wouldn't order again), enoki chips were too oily and dense (wouldn't order again), wait was 1 h 15 m, glad I waited this first time, not sure it's worth waiting that long for a meal that took less than 30 m to eat and pay other than on occasions where we feel like coming to eat at this specific restaurant. 

The wait: Came on a Saturday night and arrived to line up at 6:40 PM, knowing it would be a loooong wait. Ended up waiting 1 h 15 m, which is both far longer than we ever like to wait on a normal basis but also shorter than we expected for a clear and cold weekend evening. I was, however, already fairly hungry when we got in line, so waiting really kicked my hunger up even further, and I basically inhaled my food when I got in. I would suggest going when you're just getting hungry, or otherwise have a light snack before you head out, because if not, you'll end up scarfing your meal down without taking a moment to enjoy it!

The food: we ordered the tori paitan with double chashu, spicy lamb, and enoki chips. 

The 'chips' were more like an oily pile of mushrooms, and although interesting in theory, way too oily and heavy - would have loved something a little lighter. The portion size was actually larger than we expected, so we probably could have gone without them knowing we were ordering two bowls of ramen. 

The tori paitan was deeeeelish, albeit heavy, since it's a 'creamy' ramen. The duck chashu was a nice change from the typical ramen we go out for, and the pork was unbelievably tender.

The spicy lamb was not too spicy in the heat sense, but rather overly spiced for my taste, which detracted significantly from my experience. The spices used were ones I've eaten before with no trouble, but usually far less in amounts, so I ended up with a severely sour stomach. Quality is still there, so my dislike of it is more a matter of preference - and the fact that I apparently have a slightly more sensitive stomach.

Overall, quality and quantity is definitely more than a few notches above other ramen places I've eaten at in SF, and I would recommend going at least once to try it for yourself. Whether or not you end up going back to wait in that line subsequent times is really up to how amazing you think the ramen is.
author: Kristen T.

description:
Some context, I'm a foodie from LA visiting SF over winter vacation. Mensho Tokyo was one of my top restaurants to check out after reading a yelp review ranking this place over other LA places this particular yelper had tried. I've scoured the LA ramen scene and rank Tsujita Annex above all else, which is the bar to which all other ramens are judged for me.

Broth: To me, broth in ramen is most important followed by the noodles. I ordered the Spicy Tori Paitan and tasted the base soup before mixing in the red peppers and miso that make this the spicy version. The base soup was thick, creamy, and frothy but paradoxically tasted both rich and bland (flavors didn't pop) at same time. Something was missing. After mixing in spices the soup started to taste like Korean doenjang jjigae, which was kinda weird because I've never had doenjang jjigae with noodles.

Compared to Tsujita Annex's broth which I just want to keep drinking against my better judgment (i.e., heart attack), the broth at Mensho lost my interest after a few spoonfuls.

Also, the thickness of broth made all the other ingredients sink into it, which made my bowl of ramen looked like a primordial soup halfway through.

Overall, although the broth had layers of different flavors, but it didn't grab me. Perhaps I just didn't get the complexity. I had high expectations coming in given all the signage of its unique umami flavor and special nori that they use. IMO, the soup lacked  that "yummy" quality that makes my mouth water, which happens when I just think about the broth from Tsujita Annex or other places like Hakata Ikkousha or even the humble Santouka in Mitsuwa food court.

Noodles: Thick, chewy, bouncy, nice texture and cooked a bit al dente. The noodles in themselves were great, and on par with Tsujita Annex.  Broth clung to the noodles well, however because I wasn't that big a fan of the broth, I didn't feel a desire to finish the noodles.

Chashu: I ordered single portion and didn't get to try the duck chashu. The pork chashu was mediocre and served thin, lukewarm, and on lean side compared to other places. It was tender but did not melt in my mouth.

Extras: Surprisingly, my favorite part of the bowl was the bamboo shoots. They were flavored very well and had a nice crunch to them.

Venue: Venue is small with about four communal tables and a few seats at bar facing kitchen. I came alone and had fun watching the chefs do their magic.

Wait: It is what it is. There wasn't a sign in sheet which required everyone to stay in line. I waited 35 minutes at around 9pm Friday, but if longer, it would be great to have option of putting name down and wander streets a bit to pass time. 

Service: Given how busy they are, it is understandable that waiting staff are inattentive, but they were also not very cordial. Back in my hometown of Torrance, I'm used to mom and pop japanese places where there is a loud greeting and farewell regardless of how busy the place is. At Mensho, the waitress didn't give any acknowledgement (verbal or nonverbal) after I thanked her for the meal as I walked out. Not a big deal but I left with an unwelcome feeling. Also worth noting is that they included a service charge to bill. Total came out to $22 for one bowl of ramen (ouch). I've had really really good service at other busy SF eateries so my experience here may not just be a stranger effect ("people are strange when you're a stranger").

Atmosphere: Decor is a bit generic and did not feel like a Japanese place in a traditional sense. I don't think I heard one word of japanese my entire time there.
author: Yong P.

description:
The advance hype on this place was off the charts, and the breathless texting and taxing anticipation from the hipsterati of self-proclaimed ramen connoisseurs has been quite deafening. A two-plus-hour wait for an $18 bowl of ramen sounds like a Louis C.K. joke about San Francisco millennials with no punchline. I got exhausted thinking about the hoops I'd have to jump through to get a taste of the broth here. However, now that at least six weeks have elapsed since the grand opening in February, I had an opening that I couldn't bypass, the Thursday before Good Friday when I got off work early.

Everyone says to be there at 4PM even though they don't open until an hour later, and so I did. If you don't count the screeching homeless woman who kept sauntering by, no one else showed up until around 4:35PM. That's not to say the staff was indifferent to my presence as they thanked me for coming and waiting patiently. Eventually a line did start to form and rather quickly. I got seated at the front counter promptly at 5PM where I had a nice view of the kitchen where activity was bustling behind he coffee beakers with the broth at full boil and the pork and duck chashu being meticulously sliced. I was sitting with a Filipino family who could barely contain their enthusiasm over the forthcoming noodlefest.

I was feeling the same way and knew what to order since I had well over an hour to decide. I started with their one and only appetizer, the $5 Oysters in Shoyu Dare Oil. There were four of them completely shelled and marinated (photo: http://bit.ly/1Vp0sEV). Tasty freshness gone too soon, but the main event was about to occur. It was the $18 Tori Paitan Ramen with Double Pork Chashu, and I had them add an extra couple of Duck Chashu slices for $1.50 extra because why not go to town? The noodles were perfectly al dente, and the chashu was meaty without being overwhelming. Slices of menma, kale and burdock floated on top with a katsuobushi (bonito) sauce spooned on top (photo: http://bit.ly/224L6pv).

However, for all the fresh ingredients, it was that rich paitan chicken broth that lingers not only on the palate but in my sense-memory. Just the natural creaminess of it was amazing, and what really makes this bowl of ramen stand out against the others. There are three other ramen bowls on the menu - organic shoyu, shio, and vegan tantanmen, as well as a selection of mazesoba bowls. I was timid and just had a $4.75 bottle of Sapporo Premium to wash it all down (photo: http://bit.ly/1RTN9dq), but they have pricier Japanese artisan beers which they strongly recommended to me for the next time. And there will be a next time even as I saw the line go down the block as I departed.

FOOD - 5 stars...best paitan ramen broth ever, period
AMBIANCE - 4.5 stars...clean, white and you only wish it was triple the size to make the line move faster
SERVICE - 5 stars...lovely people work here
TOTAL - 5 stars...not just for self-proclaimed ramen connoisseurs...be patient or come near closing
author: Ed U.

description:
I know pretty much nothing about ramen, but holy crap, best japanese pot o' noodles I have ever eaten. The tori paitan ramen was incredibly creamy, and I had a hard time finishing all the broth, it was that rich. Twenty bucks is a little steep, but I would highly recommend this bowl.

Long line at 4:55, but we were seated by 6pm. When we left at about 6:50, the line was pretty short. I definitely think the wait is worth it, for currently the "best" ramen in SF. I definitely would recommend coming with a smaller party, though.
author: Steph D.

description: I really enjoyed my tori paitan ramen, and I must say it was a unique dish. First, as someone who generally does not like getting too close to strangers, I thought the close seating arrangement was tolerable. Since the wait is so long, the literature on the walls was enough to educate/entertain me, and the specialty of their kombu broth does seem authentic after tasting it. However, I think this particular broth needed time getting adjusted with because it was much earthier than what I've had at typical American ramen places. I would even suggest nixing the bamboo shoots because for the first half of my meal, I could not taste anything but that strong pickly bamboo taste which took away from the broth flavor. The egg was seasoned to the T--rich, pungent, and oversalted even. I had to be careful eating that egg. Overall, not worth the wait or the price tag for me as someone who has affordable ramen options back home, and not unique enough for me to come back.
author: Hong L.

description:
There's always a huge line to this place but this time it was a bit short and even then we were still debating on leaving and going somewhere else.  We stuck it out and very glad we did.  The place is super small and if you are going in as a couple you'll most likely share a table with someone else.  Also if you have a big party (6 or 8) it's gonna take ages for you to get seated.  Single diners get seated pretty much immediately.

Ok now for the food.  We didn't get a starter but I got the Tori Paitan (single not double) cause I didn't want to pay that much for ramen, but it was amazing!  So much flavor and the duck and pork were so tender and just melted in my mouth.  The broth was filled with all this flavoring and was a bit thick but I slurrrrped it all down.  I could've drank the whole broth but decided against that lol.  This is a must get, definitely, for real for real.  Get this one!

My bf got the clear soup, Shoya ramen, and tbh I didn't like it.  The broth was a big tangy and kinda salty and mine was wayyy better.  Kinda felt bad cause I know he wanted to switch with me, but sorry buddy you just get a taste! Lol

Also, they give you this huge silver spoon to slurp up your broth.  Never seen that before!
author: Nyla K.

description:
An hour wait in line and we got our ramen. Can't say if it worth it or not but after 15 min waiting it becomes principal not to leave.
My hubby got Tori Paitan and he couldn't finish because it was too thick. I got Shoyu and it was good. Light and tasty. Not thick and not too salty as I like. 

So if you are ok with waiting it could be nice experience:)
author: Maria M.

description:
Above average ramen, but 2hrs in line and $20 a bowl doesn't give you a bowl of gold.

Tori Paitan
- Thick broth but subtly flavored, tastes like chinese porridge infused with some fat
- Awkwardly thick noodles that don't soak up any flavors, but I can see how some of the same people who like to chew on dough like this simply because it's "al dente"
- Best two pieces of pork chashu I've had in a ramen bowl (duck chashu tasted weak AF however)

Tantanmen
- Equally thick broth mixed with a ton of nuts that looks like a bowl of fodder you stole from some pigs' trough, but pretty solid flavors

Friendly service after you spend 2hrs in line smelling sun dried hobo piss outside.

Tip: Come 20 min before they open on weekdays for generally guaranteed first seating
author: Tian Q.

description:
Unfortunately for me this place didn't live up to the hype or the 40 minute wait...

Food: While the noodles were fantastic and obviously made fresh the creamy broth (while nicely flavorful) was just too creamy for me. I got the the Tori Paitan and my friend got the Spicy Lamb. The meat was great in both, but we ended up not being able to finish our bowls because the cream was so heavy, even more so in the spicy lamb. Next time I would definitely try the clear broth. 

Ambiance: the seating area is decorated nicely and customers are sat at communal tables which is nice. What I couldn't stand was the very loud dubstep music that was playing. I could barely hear my friend while he was talking to me and it made me feel a little irritated during the meal. 

Service: our servers were awesome! We were asked if we were ready to order 3 times in the first 5 minutes we were there which made me worried that the meal would be rushed, but once we ordered and food came I didn't feel rushed at all. 

I'm not sure if I will be back or not, but if so I hope the music is quieter and I'd try a clear broth for sure.
author: Anna M.

description:
My friend and I were shopping at Union Square and craved for Japanese ramen. Went there at 7 and found a long line. When we were struggling to figure out whether to leave, the line only got longer.

Decided to stay on the line before we were seated one hour later. The ramen was definitely worth the wait. We had the signature Torri and shio Ramen. I added duck slices, ground lamb, bamboo shoots and hot spring egg. The food almost overflowed out of the bowl  haha. The soup was tasty and rich. Pork and duck chasu tender and fresh. I love the egg the most. 

Definitely a good choice for food in cold San Francisco evening!
author: Andy Juzheng Z.

description: Best. Ramen. In SF. Better than Marufuku, Orenchi, and Ippudo. Where Mensho Tokyo really differentiates itself is in the noodle quality. The noodles are the right amount of chewy and the pork belly is spot on. Lines can be a bit long but do not worry, the ramen is worth it.
author: Kenzan T.

description:
I don't want to mention about Clam Butter Chashu Ramen because it's limited and it might be more difficult for me to get it next time but it's so good!!! The soup is tasty and i can feel an ocean taste in this bowl  

And as you know, the waiting line is crazy! Sometime it takes like forever but it's worth to the wait !! 

Staffs is nice and kind. 

My favorite ramen restaurant in Bay Area!! 
You guys deserve 5 stars!
author: Nuii N.

description: Mensho is my favorite ramen spot in the city by using far. Concise menu, focused on what they do great. There can be a wait upon arrival, but once in, anticipate super carrier, a kick back communal environment, and delicious, milky broth with lots of flavor. extraordinarily recommended.
author: Jeremy N.

description:
First things first, the line is worth. This is my go to place when taking my family or friends that are not from the city. I first came here during the open week in 2016 and have gone at least twice a month ever since.

The Tori Paitan is hands down my favorite one. I have tried Shoyo based one, the Vegan, and the spicy Tori Paitan, but I always go back to my roots. The oysters are also pretty amazing.

Forever my favorite ramen place in San Francisco.
author: Nicole N.

description:
The ramen was too salty for me to eat and was definitely not worth to wait more than 30 minutes outside in cold/hot. We were waited for 1.5 hours to get in. However, the mushroom fries were great! The appetizer was much better than the main menu we ordered. Other than the taste, their service was pro and served great.
We were pleased with their service but don't want to go back for that long line.
author: Hyesun K.

description:
Not necessarily the best bowl of ramen I've ever had but the broth in their Tori Paitan (TP) ramen is INSANE. It's super thick, almost gravy like, yet still remains pretty light. I haven't had anything like it before. You can tell the broths quality with it's texture and deep flavor, definitely been cooking for HOURS.Add in some super tender chashu (both pork AND duck), menma, springy and squiggly noodles, kale, and some katsuoboshi (bonito shavings) and you got yourself their TP ramen. Hella flavor! 

Normally, it's $16 for a bowl but you only get one piece of meat so I'd recommend getting a double chashu for $18. Personally, I got the double and got an extra piece of chashu (since that's how I roll) and boom, baller bowl of ramen for $20. 

Perfect comfort food for those cold SF summer nights. I ain't spending hours making a ramen broth so it wasn't bad waiting an hour in line (Arrived on a Thursday @8:30pm, seated at 9:30pm). My tip - It's better to go later, wait times are shorter. 

Other bites. 
*SHIO RAMEN $11 - very clean, deep, clear. The noodles were fettucine like.
*OYSTERS IN SHOYU DARE OIL - 4 for $5. Like little chewy umami bombs. Reminded me of smoked oysters from the can. 

Can't wait to check out more flavors of ramen when they bring them over.
author: Earl G.

description: We came here at 6pm on a Friday and got very lucky with parking right in front and less than a 20 min wait. It's a tight space in there and the food is just okay. My ramen was actually very salty and too thick for my liking. My fiancé didn't love his ramen either :( which is unfortunate because we've heard so many good things about Mensho. The fried enoki mushrooms were good though! Perhaps we should try something else next time...?
author: Michelle L.

description:
Mensho is so worth the wait!

I've heard from many people that this place is like THE best ramen ever. That's impossible right? Well, I'm not easy to please in terms of ramen, but the fact that I actually drank the entire chicken broth is saying something! The restaurant opens at 5pm, but a huge line already started forming before it even opened. My friends got a spot in line at about 4:45pm, and I met up with them 30 minutes later. Total wait for us was about 1.5 hours, but I heard people have waited at least 2 hours for this. There is no sign up sheet for waiting, just an old fashioned wait your turn in line kinda deal. There's also not a lot of seating inside, so the wait makes more sense. Once you're inside, you still have to wait about 30 minutes from being seated to having your ramen come out.

TIP: If you're comfortable and brave enough to eat alone, single seats are most likely available for you to skip the line if there are groups with odd numbers.

Parking in this area is kind of difficult, especially with all the one way streets and meter parking. If you wait till about 5:45pm on weekdays, rush over to take the parking right across the street. Parking is free and allowed at 6pm along this part of Geary. 

The menu is pretty simple too, with your choice of Ramen, Tsukemen, and Mazesoba. The most popular one is the Tori Paitan Ramen, but I hear the Tsukemen is bomb as well (chilled ramen separated from the broth). There's not too many choices for additional toppings like soft boiled eggs or corn, but hey if the ramen tastes amazing by itself, who needs it? Just kidding I still want my soft boiled egg and corn.

We ordered oysters in shoyu dare oil for appetizers, and it was tasty. 4-5 pieces for $5 so not a bad deal. Once my Tori Paitan Double Chashu ($18) came out, I just stared at my ramen for a good 10 seconds. IT LOOKS SO GOOD. Okay looks are one thing, but let's taste the broth. DROOLS. A rich, thick, & creamy broth packed with a lot of flavor. It doesn't taste overly saturated with sodium at all. Double Chashu is so worth. Most of the flavors from the ramen came from the pork, and the chashu just melts in your mouth. The duck was good too, but it had a subtle lemon taste to it. Crispy bamboo shoots were a nice touch.

The hype couldn't be more real.
author: Kevin S.

description:
Expect a long wait but it's worth it to try this place. We came at 5 pm on Sunday right when the restaurant opened and the line was already an hour long. There aren't too many seats inside most of which are communal tables. The service was quick and friendly.

Get the Tori Paitan ($18 for double chashu)! That was by far my favorite dish here and one of the best ramen bowls I have ever had. The broth was super thick almost like gravy and very rich. The noodles were springy and had a generous serving size. The pork was extremely tender and flavorful. I thought the slices of duck were just okay. Only wish was they had an egg inside!

My boyfriend got the shoyu which he really liked. The broth is a lot lighter and clearer. I thought it was good but not nearly as delicious as the Tori Paitan.

Overall this place stood up to its hype for me!
author: Linda X.

description: This restaurant has got balance! I loved the food as it came out hot and fresh and the seasoning is just in it's right proportion. Check them out!
author: Maxxi M.

description:
Well, that was the meatiest and nuttiest vegan ramen I've ever had. It's nutty to the point that bits get stuck between your teeth and you're occasionally chewing on larger pieces that you sip up. Reviewers and even other customers raved about how good the vegan ramen was and that may possibly be better than its meat-based brethren.

While I liked it, it's definitely a once-in-a-while ramen because of how heavy and sodium laden it was. I'm parched as I'm writing this. 

The best thing about the Tori Paitan Ramen was how tender the cha shu was. I don't know how they cook it so there's still a pink hue but it's amazing. The regular portion is pretty generous but if you love pork, you might want to pay extra for the double portion.

With both ramen types, the broths were super heavy in flavor so how much you like this place may depend on how you like your ramen. I actually prefer the milky, creamy broth but this place still does an excellent job making what they specialize in. 

The place looks bigger in pictures but it's a pretty tight space. They have a coat rack for you to hang up your belongings and also bins underneath the tables for purses and backpacks. I went at 5:30pm on a Friday and the wait was a little less than an hour. They took our order a few minutes after we sat and the food came out in 10 minutes.
author: Shannon L.

description:
Seinfeldians: THIS is San Francisco's soup nazi. 

+ They don't do carry-out of doggy bags so finish all your food and don't even think about asking

+ If you don't get there at least an hour before they open and wait outside then you'll likely be waiting in the 2-4 hour range

+ There's room for just 20-something seats and It's all ass-to-ankles communal seating that isn't comfortable and there's a real good chance you'll slurp on your neighbor and your neighbor's slurp sauce will get on you

+ Before they open, they'll pass out the menu and you need to be ready with your entire order when your server comes

+ If you order an appetizer and a ramen, you don't get to pick the order of how it comes out 

+ Service is around to take your order, drop your food, and get you the f*ck out so the next hoard of people can be corralled in

+ A single bowl of vegan ramen starts at $18 (tip is included, though)

+++ Most important, it is the best vegan ramen/ ramen you'll find in the Bay Area. Just incredible and worth every second of your time and every penny of its price.
author: Candice G.

description: Crazy busy place. The urine soaked sidewalk on the approach was no deterrent. Made it in for the second seating on a Wednesday. Very efficient and friendly staff. Had the Tori Patan Ramen which was  rich and creamy. The star for me was the enoki chips.  It looked like a deep fried sea urchin arrived instead of mushroom chips. The first bite was a sublime combo of crunch and meaty chew that melted into Umami.
author: Doug M.

description:
One of the best ramen joints in the city... BUT be prepared to wait in line cuz everyone else knows it too. Also, they're kind of pricey, some bowls at $18. 

The broth is a little thicker as well. If you like thin broth, this might be way too thick for you.

Oh and egg is over cooked. I just cannot find a soft-boiled egg here... What's a girl gotta do????????
author: Mandi W.

description: Customer service is really on point and great when you're inside.... if you're outside then good luck.... this place is always packed... that's no exaggeration. 1 hr wait is the minimum.... be aware...  the food is good, it's almost perfect. We all have different taste buds and we all have different preferences as well. I do think when it comes to ramen, this place is above average for sure. I still haven't found my 5 star ramen review yet for any restaurant. So 4 star for this place is kind of a big deal. Lol FYI the thick ramen broth is really thick and a bit on the salty side.
author: Dang D.

description:
I came to this place completely unaware that the line would be this ridiculous. I was so shocked at the length of this line on a Tuesday evening - I definitely should've read the reviews and tips beforehand. Nonetheless, my friends and I decided to wait 1.5 hours in line to try the ramen. I mean there has to be a reason why everyone else is also waiting in line. This place just opened around 3 weeks ago, and the chain is straight from Tokyo. Honestly, they should really expand their venue considering how amazingly popular they are! They only have about 4 bar tables that seat 6 people and a small area that seats about 3-4 people. If you come here alone, you could probably skip most of the line!

The service here is really great. The host was really friendly and even remembered our names! He also brought the chef out to meet us and the chef was so adorable and sweet. The staff honestly believes the vegan ramen is the best one, and if you really love meat you can add meat to the ramen. Both my friends went for the vegan ramen, but once I saw that it contained 7 types of nuts, I didn't order it considering I'm allergic to a couple types of nuts. I went with the most popular Tori Paitan Ramen with double chashu. WOW this was definitely the creamiest ramen I've ever had, and the noodles themselves were the best tasting ramen noodles I've ever eaten. They were very thick and chewy and the broth was very very rich and creamy. This was definitely one-of-a-kind ramen!

If ramen is like this in Tokyo, I'm definitely going to have to pay a visit to Japan soon! Although the line here was quite painful, I will try come back here again hopefully when the line isn't as terrible. It is pretty pricey but definitely worth. They're also adding eggs to the ramen in 2 days for all you egg-lovers!
author: Catherine S.

description:
Since I wasn't too hungry for dinner I decided I would walk from 1 Embarcadero Center after watching City of Gold (which is really good by the way) on Sat 3/26/16.  It's a good 1.4 mile walk.  I stood in line with about 20+ people in front of me.  Place opens at 5pm.

It was about a 1 hr wait because I showed up around 4:35pm and people must have been there 4pm or even earlier.  Once in one of the waitress took my order and then had to wait maybe 5-10 minutes to get my ramen.

I picked: Tori Paitan: Rich, creamy chicken soup, pork chashu, duck chashu, menma, kale, burdock, katsuobushi sauce, chashu $16.  It was really creamy & rich broth, noodles were chewy, good amount of meat, kale was a few pieces that was ok, other stuff ok.  

There is red salt w/ grinder, whole black pepper with grinder, and lemon and salted plum seasoning on the table.

One unisex bathroom on the side.  Charge cards accepted.

Hrs: 5pm-11:30pm I think daily, no sign posted.

PS: Bring your own small folding chair so you don't have to stand while in line!
author: Ann L.

description: After failing the first time from waiting in line I came back a second time close to closing with my girlfriends and we made it in! It was a cold night so it was nice to end our evening with ramen. It's worth the wait! My friend said it you wait that long then just order 2 bowls for yourself lol. It's so true! Enjoy!
author: Stephanie J.

description: Wow!!! This place is a great find. A quaint "hole in the wall" type noodle shop. I took a friend of mine there and notice the line to enter. We waited for about 30 minutes before getting to our seats. It was an unexpected surprise to me because I didn't imagine it to be such a small place to dine. I've heard great things about this place. For starters, we ordered the oyster appetizer and Sake. Then onto the main entree. I ordered the spicy lamb ramen and my friend ordered the pork ramen. The spicy lamb was absolutely delicious. The noodles were very filling. I look forward to trying more of the noodle entree in the near future.
author: Arthur M.

description:
Mmmm, one of the best ramen spots in the city. 

Went on a Friday around 5:30 pm and there was a line forming already. For about 15 people in front of us, the wait wasn't too bad. We got seated around 6 pm and I ordered the Tori Paitan. 

Priced at $18, I thought it was a bit steep but I was willing to pay the extra to see what the rave was about. Oh. My. Goodness. I finally knew why people loved it once I ate a spoonful. The texture of the ramen is exactly how I like it - al dente - and the broth was packed with creamy goodness! The chasu is also very tender! I devoured my bowl and wanted more. I wish they offered extra noodles. 

Would come back some day for another bowl.
author: Emily M.

description:
It's true. Here you will find the best bowl ramen bay area has to offer. Their Tori Paitan is out of the world. The broth is insanely murky with an almost viscous consistency and hits all the right marks on your tastebuds. The souyu broth is just as good if you prefer something relatively lighter. 

Was it really worth over an hour wait and $18? That's debatable. Bring your friends and hang out while you wait. Don't come here hungry and grumpy. No matter how good it is, it's still just a bowl of ramen.
author: Mona W.

description:
Tori Paitan Ramen (Double Chashu) was way too creamy and rich for me. Felt a tad bit of nausea afterwards. I finished the noodles but left most of the sauce/broth untouched. And unfortunately, the ground lamb was so ground up that it got lost in the sauce. #rip 

I'd try another dish next time but future me would not wait such a long line for ramen in such a small shop. There are 3 tables total so you'll definitely have to share--fun but not fun if you need to tolerate annoying neighbors.
author: Lydia Z.

description:
I tried to disregard the hype, but I'm sure I had my own biases coming into Mensho expecting it to be amazing. Here is my attempt to be objective. I ordered the Tori Paitan ramen with double chasu, an egg, and fried garlic aka full AF. 

Broth: This broth is THICK. First impression when sipping it was that it was very rich and almost even gritty since it was so thick. I warmed up to it after several bites and having it together with the noodles and the other ingredients. At the end, it made me feel pretty gross though. 

Noodles: Springy, my favorite type. 

Chasu: Two types of chasu, pork and duck, both thinly sliced, both had great flavor. 

Egg: Shoyu egg, flavorful where you can actually taste the soy sauce marinade. Perfectly soft-boiled

Other: Bamboo shoots tasted a bit more fermented than what I was used to but still good. The fried onions, kale, and cabbage were good additions as it added different complimenting textures and flavors to the dish. Fried garlic was a waste of an add for 2 dollars more as I felt it didn't add that much to the dish. 

Wait time: 10 minutes; Came 10 minutes before opening on a Tuesday and there was already a small line in front but was able to get in with the first wave of people. 

Service: Waitresses were friendly and knowledgeable about the ramen. Had sound suggestions regarding which egg to get (miso or shoyu), which ramen to try as a first timer, and what I should try in the future. 

Price: Steep for ramen. Ingredients seem high quality and the place is pretty hyped up so I guess its understandable. 

Overall, the Tori Paiten ramen was good but may be too rich and thick for my taste. I'd come back to try the other ramens here (the lamb miso ramen, the clam ramen, and the soup-less ramen) since they have the potential to be really good.
author: Danny L.

description: Broth is bold and rich. You can taste the quality of the ingredients. Noodles is perfectly cooked.
author: gi e.

description:
The short: organic shoyu ramen hits the spot

If you're not one of the first in line, be prepared to wait about an hour. This place seats about 30 people max, with 2 very long tables, and some seats facing the kitchen. Also be prepared for sitting at a communal table. Some people don't like this...? I don't mind, as long as I have elbow room and have good food!

While in line, we checked out the menu and had a face palm moment when I realized that the description described the items below. Basically, the items below the header start with the basic bowl, and increase in price for additional items. So the four categories are: tori paitan (most ordered based on pictures and reviews), shoyu (what I ordered), shio, and vegan tantanmen.

When the shoyu ramen arrived, I quickly dug in because I was so hungry. The duck chasu and pork chasu was tender, perfectly cooked, and enhanced the broth (wishing there were doubles of each!). Even the kale was an unusual, but nice addition. The broth was perfect, not salty or oily. And the noodles were chewy! At first, it doesn't look like there's a lot of noodles, but the bowl is shaped quite deeply at the bottom, so all the noodles are hidden there. There was so much I liked about this ramen. 

I couldn't figure out what the seasonings on the table were, though there was pink himalayan salt, and maybe some other seasonings to personally enhance the broth to the right taste. I didn't need to as I liked it the way it was.

The waiter was very kind and smiling, which is something I don't see too often. All the seating is on stools, and there are baskets on the ground for bags. The whole inside has a clean and modern aesthetic, with a living wall at the entrance, descriptions of the different types of ramen, and a view into the kitchen. So exciting!

One downside is that this isn't a place to sit and chat after you've eaten the food. Somebody will kindly let you know that there are other patrons outside who are waiting.

It's hard to say if I would wait in line for another hour, but I would come back to arrive right around opening so I don't have to wait so long. Thanks for the experience Mensho!
author: Catherine W.

description:
Pencil in an hour or two of waiting. But it's worth it. 

Mensho Tokyo opens at 5pm and so my friend and I came here at exactly 5pm. There was already a long line waiting outside the restaurant. Were they there since 4pm or just five minutes ago? I have no clue but 5 minutes later, half of the line went in so my heart skipped a beat at the possibility of having my wait time reduced in half. Even then, we waited for at least another hour and 15 minutes until we were finally seated. At reaching the top of the line, there was still a good thirty people behind us. 

There is no wait list to put your name down or reservations. You do it the good old fashioned stand and wait your turn. Finding parking in this area can be a hassle but there is parking across the street that is free and available after 6pm assuming you can snag the spot (it is a no stopping zone before 6pm). The restaurant is quite small and there's two rows of tables. The front row was one long table and the back row near the windows was sectioned off into two separate tables. It's communal seating so you may be sitting with other parties if you are a small group. I was sitting in the back row near the windows and our table seated 7 so our party of 3 was seated with two other parties of 2. If you're eating by yourself, you may be lucky enough to move up in line since you can sit with the odd number groups. 

We ordered the oysters in shoyu dare oil to share and for myself, I got the tori paitan ramen with double chashu (because dammit, I waited too long in line to limit myself). 

Oysters: For $5, you get four pieces although I counted five unless one oyster cloned itself. They're really tiny pieces and the Yelp photos are a lie when you see the close-up and think it's bigger than it really is (so sorry, my photo is now a lie). It's a little salty but still kind of tasty if you're into oysters. I'm definitely used to raw oysters with the lemon and marinara so it was a bit strange to taste cooked oysters in soy sauce. A good starting appetizer as you wait for your ramen. 

Tori Paitan Ramen (Double Chashu) $18: WOW! The chicken broth was so rich and creamy. I would expect it to be salty judging from the look of it but it wasn't although it was SUPER FLAVORFUL. In fact, most of the salty taste came from the pork chashu. The pork chashu broke apart easily with my chopsticks and melts in my mouth with each bite. Duck chashu was interesting since it had a slight lemon-y flavor. I definitely enjoyed the pork more. The noodles were thick (chow mein thick) and chewy. You get a big silver ladle spoon so you can spoon up both the delicious broth along with your thick noodles.

Be prepared to open up your wallet and drop almost $20 a person. With three bowls of ramen and oysters, we paid about $75 with tax and tips. Thankfully it's not cash only and they do take card. To the side of the restaurant, they have a single unisex bathroom that is quite spacious for such a small restaurant.
author: Diana C.

description:
New ramen place that has a long line, but worth the wait:

I originally tried to check out this place but people were lining up hours in advance. I finally had a time to check out this place with a friend on a Thursday night. The wait still took almost an hour long, but I think the hype is worth it. Plus, the line seems to be getting shorter and shorter every time I walk by. 

When you get in, there isn't a ton of seating, but the lighting makes you feel welcome and comfortable. We got seated as a party of two, and were our drinks were immediately ordered followed shortly by our food orders. With a line so long, they are definitely quick here ready to get you in and your food ready to be made.

I ordered the shoyu, and was very impressed. Serving sizing were perfect; I felt extremely content with the portions after eating. The pork and duck chashu were cooked great, I enjoyed the savory broth, and the noodles were pretty good. I hear that they will soon be making the noodles in house.

Service was really fast and friendly once we got in. I didn't feel rushed, but at the same time they were ready to check up on us when needed. Overall, one of the best ramen I've had. If you like ramen, you already know that this place has been gaining popularity, and even if you're not a big ramen eater, I'd definitely recommend you to check it out if you don't mind waiting In line. It goes pretty quick. 5 out 5!
author: Kenny L.

description:
Waited until now to try out this ramen shop with the hope the hype will be slowing down. Finally was able to try it and was not impress up to my expectation. To be fair, I have tried almost all of the popular ramen shops around Bay Area and few locations in Asia (including Ippudo in Kyoto). 

I tried the Tori Paitan and Spicy Lamb broth. The noodle was impressively fresh and the meat were soft and delicious. My only complaint was the soup flavor. Tori Paitan broth was flavorful and smell perfect, but the taste was too salty for me (this is coming from someone who dip my fries with salt). It would be nice if i can ask for 3/4 salt or something. Spicy lamb was creamy and not very spicy, but you def had the curry like smell.

For $18 per bowl, I don't think its something I would rave about. 

I would stick going down to San Mateo or Sunnyvale for my ramen crave..
author: Ivana L.

description: Their ramen is awesome! Loved it! It's so tasty and delicious. The queue outside is really long even if it's almost their closing time. But it's worth the wait. They serve it hot but quick. And the rest is history, you'll wanna go back and try other flavors. The price is not cheap, nor expensive. I think it's just right but it's really really worth it!
author: Willie C.

description:
The line was ridiculously long for such an expensive bowl of ramen. I got the taipan ramen since it was so highly recommended. 
1. I wish it was spicy
2. it was so creamy/fatty that it was too hard to eat. 
3. when you moved the bowl, the soup didn't splash, it jiggled like jello
4. kale in ramen is weird. 

Conclusion: I wish I tried something else.
author: Dolly D.

description: It's the best I really enjoyed it's really one of those places u bring your gal and have a great time
author: Oso O.

description:
I came at 830pm on a Saturday night and surprisingly only waited around 30-35 minutes. I'd recommend trying the Tori Paitan ramen with extra chashu the first time you're here.

The duck chashu was so tender and fatty and it surpassed all my expectations! The pork chashu was also quite fatty and delicious. The chicken soup base was surprisingly heavy and rich and the noodles were of average chewiness. I also had a chance to try my friend's vegan ramen and it was surprisingly delicious! The soup base is the perfect mixture of soy and peanut. Plenty of peanut flavor that doesn't overpower the rest of the flavors. 

The communal seating makes it a bit difficult to hear across the table because the restaurant is quite small and the voices echo. I love that the restaurant provides boxes underneath the table to store your bulkier items. The table also has space inbetween for smaller items like a phone or purse.

Service was quick and efficient.
author: Edward W.

description: Best ramen I've ever had. The broth is so creamy and flavorful, but it gets really thick by the time you get to the bottom and bowl and cools down! I recommend getting the extra chashu, it's so worth it. But be warned, this is a  pretty big bowl of ramen so come hungry! I got the Tori Paitan ramen. :) Definitely will come back here again even if I have to stand outside for over an hour. Lol. But it's that good. ;)
author: Joelle L.

description:
This line is only for the patient and determined. Got there 15 min before opening on a weekday and the wait was 80 minutes. Right in the "TenderNob", there were we a few beggars hassling the line but Mensho Tokyo was trying the best they could to ask them politely not bother the customers in line. I don't know if there's any way to really get around this with all the hype! 

Oysters: Tiny little oysters in shoyu dare oil. They were served cold and not quite appetizing. Dark brown in color from the oil ost likely, oddly very shriveled and almost chewy. Flavor was okay but not what i was hoping.

We ordered the Tori Paitan, Organic Shoyu and Shio. Favorite of the three? Tie between Tori Paitan and Shoyu. They both have the DELICIOUS DUCK CHASHU but otherwise very different bowls of ramen. Tori Paitan's rich creamy broth is hard to compare to the lightness of the shoyu. Compared to other shoyu broths at other restaurants, Mensho's is definitely one of the better bowls. Great noodles all around.
author: Samantha L.

description:
Authentic ramen from Japan? Count me in!!! 

My friends and I lined up at 4 pm and we were 2nd in line. By 4:30 pm, the line was growing. We only waited an hour compared to some of the crazy 3 hours that other people have waited. All 4 of us ordered the tori paitan ramen ($16), which was seemingly the most popular! We were all really excited especially just to be some of the first people in the restaurant. 

The tori paitan was incredibly flavorful, creamy, and THICK! Like others have said, the tori paitan broth has more of a sauce or gravy-like consistency rather than your normal thinner broth. If you don't like heavy meals... don't get the tori paitan. You're probably better off with the lighter shoyu or shio ramen (both look delicious!). The tori paitan broth got a bit too rich as I was finishing the bowl. However, I enjoyed it! I normally order tonkotsu at ramen places, so the chicken flavor was definitely something different to try out. 

The noodles are round and thicker than your average (think chow mein noodle size), but perfectly cooked and chewy. As for the toppings, the chasu was melt in your mouth delicious, but the duck was subpar for me. My friends and I also thought there should be a little more veggies just to lighten up the heavy bowl. I liked the bonito flakes, but the small amounts of kale and bamboo shoots did not cut it for us. But we did really like the toppings on the tables! The red salt was something we'd never seen before, and the other brown seasoning (smells like bonito flakes) was pretty tasty.

By the time we left at 6 pm, the line outside was crazy! If you don't like waiting, definitely don't come around that time. You're better off coming anywhere from 4-4:30 pm. The restaurant seats less than 30 people at one time, and it seems like there's a slow turnover rate. Mensho was good, but I probably wouldn't wait 2-3 hours for it.
author: Tara A.

description:
Even though Mensho's been open for a while now, there's always a wait when I go. There's a trick to minimize your wait time though - on weekends, I've been there at 4:30 to wait for the first seating, and at weeknights things tend to calm down after 6PM. The service is impeccable and fast (they automatically add a 15% tip to all bills) and all of the servers want to make sure you have a good experience while getting everyone in and out of the small space. 

I've ordered the tori paitan and spicy miso lamb ramen here. The tori paitan is a solid ramen, rich broth (a little on the salty side), chewy noodles, fall-apart-chashu pieces and some garnish. It's definitely not worth $20 (incl. tip & tax) though. I just don't think it's special enough to warrant the wait and price. The spicy miso lamb ramen is more unique - it's definitely spicy enough to make you sweat, and the lamb is cooked really well. Haven't tried any of the special seasonal ramens, but I would come back to try those next. Also, if you're with 1-2 others, definitely order the fried enoki! It's a great starter and a unique dish.
author: Ada C.

description: Best ramen I've ever had. As an avid fan of Japanese ramen, I've tried ramen from places in SoCal, Boston, and New York; Mensho ramen just simply the best I've had so far. The broth is divinely creamy and tasty. The noodles are thick and you can tell that those were handmade. Highly recommended!
author: Ho N.

description: Line is long, ramen is pretty expensive, but I think it's well worth a try (or a few tries!). It really is different from alot of other ramen I've tried, and it's definitely up there in quality of broth and noodles. I've tried the paitan, shoyu, and the spicy lamb. All are very delicious, full of umami, and noodles just the right texture. I find all of the really salty, and the chasu tastes like cured ham. The most unique is the spicy lamb, and I 100% would recommend! The broth is very thick, creamy texture with ground lamb pieces and crunchy bean sprouts. It is faintly game-y as lamb dishes are, has a spicy kick, a bit of curry and honestly resembles Mongolian hot pot. I'm a huge fan though! So worth trying if you're in for ramen that's a bit different.
author: Ke C.

description:
Bookmarked this place for months because I had to visit San Francisco for a concert. So I attempted to look for the best ramen shop in SF. And Mensho seems to be the one!
I expected a long line right for hours right when they open at 5pm. Me and my friends arrived at the place around 10:30pm on saturday. But there was still a 10-12 people line outside, crazy! Luckily, it was only about 25 mins wait.

Authentic tori-paitan ramen is a very difficult type of ramen to find in U.S. So no hesitation for me, I ordered it right away.
My ramen came out pretty quickly, piping hot. The creamy chicken soup blew me away. Very complex, flavorful, savory, rich and light at the same time, which is crazy!  
Thick noodles were perfectly cooked, slightly al dente and matches marvelously well with creamy soup.

Pork chashu has delicate flavor and literally melted in my mouth. Duck chashu was great also, but pork was way better. So glad I ordered double chashu, totally worth extra $2!

Bamboo shoots, kale and burdock were so pretty on the bowl. But also taste great as it looks.

This creamy chicken soup ramen has to be the best ramen I ever had. And I ate plenty of authentic ramen throughout my life. 
$18 sounds crazy right ? But it's definitely worth even pennies.

For anyone who visits San Francisco and never been to this place. Please, please visit Mensho Tokyo. Then you may have a new favorite ramen place.

I'm satisfied that I finally get to eat at Mensho even though my trip in SF was real short, only 2 days. And I'm glad to invited good friends of mine as well. All of them couldn't stop talking about how good their Mensho experience was lol.
author: Cafe S.

description:
TL;DR - Hype worthy? You betcha. Personally, I'm just not that into ramen anymore. (I kinda consider it a sick-day kinda craving)

Wait time. Honestly, not terrible. Showed up at 7:30 and only took us about 20 minutes. 

Inside, clean and compact. I love that they have the baskets on the floor for your stuff. -Ahem- Us ladies and our purses.

Finally, food. I got the Tori Paitan Ramen. IMO, way greasy. I know, I know, its like eating fried chicken and wanting it to be healthy. Blah blah. I did actually like the flavor and consistency of the broth; quite viscous and oily (perfect for coating ramen!). The duck was actually very well cooked and so was the chasu. We also got the shoyu ramen. I love the noodles of this bowl. Thin and wavy. The broth was also a lot less greasy, but still flavorful. My friend just got back from Japan and said that he actually preferred the ramen here to some that he had on holidays. Haha.

Side note, this is the only ramen place I've ever seen that charges more for a vegetarian dish than a meat dish. What a shame. Not sure if I would be willing to drop $20 for veggie ramen, ya dig?

Overall, yes, the 4-star rating of Mensho is pretty accurate. But if ramen isn't your thing, I'd pass on Mensho as there are plenty of other places to dine in SF.
author: Crystal Z.

description:
There's been a lot of large hype around this place, so the SO and I decided to finally investigate whether or not it was any good. We arrived around 8:30 pm on a Sunday evening, and the wait was most definitely real. It took us an hour to get into the restaurant, but only about ten minutes between getting seated and getting our bowl of delicious ramen served to us.

Anyways, while I wanted so badly to believe that Mensho was going to be the bomb.com, I found myself enjoying the bowl of ramen greatly, though unlikely to ever return back (well, maybe if the lines die down).

The current Mensho menu that everyone posts on the wall is actually an aspirational menu--we chatted with the waitresses and apparently they won't really be serving tsukemen until at least May/June. I was bummed out because the Bay Area has a real shortage of good tsukemen (besides Iza); they currently are serving a Vegan tsukemen if you're into that, but relative to their more popular dishes, I feel like most people are more inclined to try their more popular dishes. We got the following dishes -- I'll do broth and overall reviews and then noodle and content reviews since both bowls basically served the same thing:

Chicken paitan -- the must have for everyone who comes here. I really was not a fan of the chicken paitan. If you love your broths thick and creamy, this is the ramen for you. SO described it like a creamy chicken noodle soup -- flavor was rich, but not particularly nuanced or complex. Overall, easy to have a couple bites of, but you better have a high tolerance for creaminess, otherwise this dish is going to be hard to finish.

Organic shoyu -- I enjoyed this and actually found it be a good ramen. The broth is very light, perhaps salty, but I have a high tolerance for saltiness so I'm not a great judge of that. I thought the flavor was quite delicious, though the soup itself was definitely quite oily. Overall, I enjoyed it, and would have again. The noodles were interesting because they were flat noodles with speckles on it.... never seen that before, but they worked well with the soup.

Overall, noodles for both dishes were good -- they were appropriate complements to their soup base. The contents of the dish were interesting -- the chasu is good, but what I particularly enjoyed was the duck chasu, which I've never had before. I like duck to start with, so it was a nice textural shift to what people are normally used to in ramen. 

I was impressed with the careful attention to detail -- they served the chicken paitan with a wooden spoon and the organic shoyu with a flat metal one, perhaps because the flat metal one wouldn't have been quite as appropriate for the creamy paitan, but maybe we were overthinking it. 

Final price was $40, so definitely on the higher end, but given how expensive everything in the city is, I was pretty happy to have a $40 meal.

Overall, I found the ramen to be fairly good here, maybe not the best ever, but given the ridiculous wait times, it's hard to want to come back because it's not good enough to wait an hour for. Ippudo is also opening in Berkeley within the year, so will be interesting to see how these two big Japanese ramen stores do when they're all situated.

tldr; certainly good ramen with a higher price, but you will likely have to wait an hour for it -- I wouldn't do it again, but I did like the ramen. just didn't like it THAT much.
author: Jasmine X.

description:
As a Bay Area native I'm used to waiting in line for good food but lining up like you did in grade school, single file is another thing! The question is whether or not Mensho Tokyo is worth this process, well is it? The answer is YES. 

The long awaited Mesho Tokyo has lived up to the hype - the ramen is hella good. I ordered the Tori Paitan - rich, creamy chicken broth which is more like gravy. Thick, savory and packed with flavor. The noodles are thick and just the right texture. The chashu....ahhh, yes, PORK AND DUCK! So tender it melts in your mouth. Their ramen is a little bit hipster with substituting kale instead of seaweed which works but (insert sad face) NO EGG!! Nonetheless the ramen is one of the better joints in the Bay. I can't wait to try the vegan tantanmen, thats if I can ever find time to wait in that damn line.

ps Don't bother with the oyster appetizer, it was meh. Save your appetite for the ramen.
author: Caye Q.

description:
4.5 STARS

San Franciscans love shiny new places (and things). 

When it comes to the hottest new restaurant and food trends, many of us spare no expense with our paycheck (and time).

Last year, it was $8 for toast. Ok, not just "toast" but phuckin' bougie, tweezified toast. 

This year, it's $15 coffee (for one cup!) and $18 ramen.

Because, San Francisco! 

Next year, I'm bracing myself for $100 pizza. Oh wait, we already had that during the super bowl (well, I didn't but it was available at Tony's Pizza Napoletana). 

Seriously, what's next? 

Kindly let me know so I can start harvesting my eggs to sell! 

$18 ramen may sound crazy but people waited 3+ hours for this ramen on opening night! 

$18 for a taste of Tokyo? Why not! 

Mensho's first U.S. location is one of the most, if not the most highly anticipated restaurant opening this year in SF! 

Tip: Come at 4 pm (earlier on the weekends) or after 10 pm to avoid long wait times. 

Currently, Mensho has 4 ramen options available ($9-$18) with a single or double chashu option. When the owner returns from Japan in March, their menu will expand. No housemade noodles yet. They have a noodle machine but are awaiting permit(s) to use it (same for the tonkotsu equipment). Disappointingly no marinated soft boiled egg is available but maybe in the future? Beer only; no sake, soda, or juice.

My friend and I ordered three bowls of ramen to share:

(1) Tori Paitan: Rich, creamy chicken soup, pork chashu, duck chashu, menma, kale, burdock, katsuobushi sauce | double chashu $18
http://bit.ly/1XrzETT

Our favorite of the three, the kotteri broth was deliciously creamy (gravy-like) and richly satisfying. It had great depth of umami flavor but did get a bit gritty mid-way. The al-dente noodles were thick, springy, and had a fantastic toothsome chew. 

The chashu is sublime so pony up the extra $ and double up on it! The pork chashu is melt-in-your-mouth tender, like pork butter. It's so ridiculously tender, it falls apart when you pick it up. The duck chashu is silky smooth and chews effortlessly.

The only other ramen shop that offers Tori Paitan is Nojo Ramen Tavern (that I'm aware of). I tried Nojo's last night and there's absolutely no comparison. Mensho's is infinitely superior. 

(2) Organic Shoyu: Organic chicken + pork soup, shoyu dare, pork chashu, duck chashu, kale, kale sprouts, chives, menma, nori | double chashu $16
http://bit.ly/1QfmuKm

A much lighter assari broth but saltier with a slight sweetness since it's a soy sauce based. The duo of chashu were perfection just like in the Tori Paitan ramen. I didn't like the noodles which were overcooked, flat, and lacked chew. 

(3) Shio: Organic chicken + pork soup, shio dare, pork chashu, kale, menma, chives, fried garlic, nori | double chashu $11
http://bit.ly/1Loeijq

The most affordable bowl available, the shio ramen was simple and pure. The assari broth was light and salty but still had depth. Same delicious chashu as the other bowls but the noodles were disappointing like the shoyu ramen. In this bowl, not only were the noodles overcooked, there were two clumps. *sad pouty lip*

(4) Vegan Tantanmen | $18
I'm kicking myself for NOT ordering this too because I love nuts! The broth contains soy cream and 7 kinds of nuts, producing a creamy kotteri broth that looked similar to the Tori Paitan.

I washed everything down with a Sansho beer ($11.75): http://bit.ly/1Px6vnx. Beer usually tastes like carbonated piss to me but this one was refreshing with a gingery lemon spice. Loved it but not the price. 

Service is a work in progress which is understandable since this is Mensho's first foray in the U.S.. They only let 8 or so customers in at a time to not overwhelm the kitchen. They don't fire up orders by tickets, instead they prepare the ramen by type (they really should do the former). We received our order at different times and after people who ordered after us. If your companion(s) orders different ramen than yourself, be prepared to start eating first before the noodles get soggy. 

When I was line I met one of the restaurant partners, Abram aka Ramen Beast. He was uber nice and offered to answer any questions I had. Really cool guy! 

The space is small and only seats 28 - two communal tables and four seats at the counter. We choose to sit at the counter. There's more privacy (if you're on a date) and you can watch the chefs in action.

Read all signs before parking. Do NOT park on Geary from 4-6 pm (tow-away zone) on the weekdays, otherwise your $18 bowl of ramen will turn into a $618+ bowl of ramen. 

Because, San Francisco!
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
Best ramen ever! 
We are from London where we eat ramen once a week and although before SFO had some most delicious ramen with friends in San Diego, Mensho's ramen were by far the best ramen ever! 
Generous portions, rich broth, al dente noodles, and an explosion of wonderful flavours all together. 

Be prepared to cue up though, although we went there on a Tuesday we had to wait for over 30 minutes to be seated. But once served, totally worth the wait.
author: CatAlina A.

description:
Solid five-star ramen place in San Francisco. To be honest, I never heard about MENSHO TOKYO until they came to the Bay Area, but decided to check it out based on the hype.

**Side announcement: The wait staff was super friendly and informative. I definitely loved their customer experience, especially when they work at such a fast-pace and crowded restaurant like this one**

Our party of 2 waited for about an hour or so after 10 pm, which wasn't too bad! The only thing that was a bit concerning was the neighborhood and constant loiters. Parking was tricky too, so I'd definitely recommend taking an Uber here. *PRO TIP: Send one of your friends to wait in line if you need to find parking. There's no list, but just a straight up old school line.*

Once we got in, we both ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen (Double Chashu) $18. Best decision ever. It was filled with mouthwatering noodles, tender Duck and Pork Chashu, Kale, Menma, Burdock and Katsuobushi Sauce. The broth itself was rich, creamy and just overall yummy. It was piping hot too, which was a plus. Unfortunately, there wasn't an option to add a soft boiled egg yet. Bummer, but the staff said it was coming soon!

The noodles themselves were thicker than usual, which was unique and different. I actually enjoyed them. They were perfectly cooked and chewy. The Chasu was so amazing that they melted in my mouth. I was indifferent about the Duck Chashu and leaned more towards the Pork Chashu.

Overall, this a great ramen place. It's probably in the the top 5 Bay Area ramen places by far. I was hesitant at first, but this place was definitely delicious beyond disbelief! I'm a MENSHO TOKYO fan.
author: Chinsin S.

description:
Our group had just finished up at Wilson & Wilson. After splurging on drinks there it was pretty difficult for me to dive right into some pricey ramen! But we were all ready for some drunchies.

We got here at 11 and asked for a seat for 4. Another customer came up behind us and said with a surprised tone, 'There's no line!?' I just told him that we're the line. I was confused too because I thought, why would there be? But now that I've actually seen the reviews and pictures... I now get it. Didn't realize this spot was THAT poppin' lol. I'm always wary about restaurants that have crazy lines - usually it doesn't meet the hype... not for me at least.

We were seated in no time. I love the communal tables! And I actually really like the small space haha, reminds me of a lot of shops I've been in throughout Asia.

Since I had just burned through my wallet on drinks, I opted for the lower priced Shio Ramen w/ Chasiu ($9 something, ~$11 w/ tip and tax). Food came out surprisingly fast. I was kinda sad that there wasn't much in my bowl. Everything was delicious but I want a lot more for the price! Everything definitely tasted top quality but when you only get one piece of meat, it kinda has you scratching your head. Broth was great. Looks like I should have gotten the Tori Paitan since everyone on here is raving about that one's broth.

I'll stick to my cheap, hefty ramen shops for now. I like quality and quantity - but, this was definitely a nice treat for one splurge-y night!
author: Shanise M.

description:
*** In Short ***

One of the best ramen joints in the city? The hours-long waits certainly suggest as much!

*** In Depth ***

I have a deep seated dislike for long waits when it comes to food, with a rage that starts to simmer around the 30-60 minute mark, depending on the quality of the company I'm with. For this reason, despite hearing all the wild raving about how amazing Mensho was, I refused to come during prime dinner time, what with the purported 2-3 hour waits.

But, it so happened that on one chilly night several weeks ago, after a date that ended earlier than expected, and that I hadn't eaten prior to, Mensho was still open, and screaming my name. So along I came, waiting for a meager 20 minutes* before being seated, having my order taken, and my toripaitan served, all within the span of another 10 minutes.

And, I mean, what else is there to say? It was amazing: a rich, creamy, tasty chicken broth, and one of the only I've actually felt compelled to finish drinking; ramen noodles that were cooked to just the right springy consistency; and overall, a perfect combination of amazing flavors.

Definitely plan to be back, schedule permitting, because, amazing as this may be, I still refuse to wait with the masses.

* See venue accessibility for additional notes on this

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - The place itself is pretty small, with some lower counter seating that fits four, and two long high top townhall style tables. Because of this, if you're in need of accessible seating, waits may be even longer: while I reached the front in 20 minutes, it was another 20 before a counter seat opened up.

Bathroom - Didn't try them.
author: Johnny W.

description: This is probably in the top 10 of all the favorite places I have ever eaten! Highly impressed with the food and the all around experience! I will be coming here again!
author: Dana B.

description:
Arrived here at 430PM and there was a line already. SOOO HYPED!! We got seated for 2 at 5:05. There's ~28 seating total. Not too bad 30minute wait if you get there early. 

I would recommend coming here before it opens to get the first seating instead of later. They do not take names down as that's traditionally how it is in Japan.  There was a longg line after I got there and when we were done eating. 

Ordered the Tori Paltan with double chasu $18. I can probably go without the double chasu next time. 

- Broth was very rich (nothing compared to the ones I had in Japan like Ichiran and I thought their broth was rich but this beats it). I wish it was less rich tbh. 
- Noodles were delicious. Thick noodles with a nice bite to it. I believe they make their own but not 100% sure about that. Either way I would come back just for their noodles!! They should have the option to add extra noodles! Although I was pretty full after this prob bc of the broth lol 
- Chasu was good with the right amount of fat.
- Duck - good, flavorful 
- Bamboo - comes with bamboo! Feel like most places you need to pay extra for this but glad it comes with it here! 

Service was great and very friendly! 

Highly recommend to give this a try if you haven't been!
author: Sherry Y.

description: Decent ramen, but creamy soup base with a little too much salt. Too much hype and price with a long wait time to be worth it.
author: Vincent D.

description: Believe me when I say that this is by far the best ramen spot in SF. They've focused on one thing and have done it very well. I really wish there were more places like this here. The line is typically pretty long, about a 1 hour wait though.
author: Nate T.

description:
I can't say I've ever had a ramen that would make me want to wait in a line that goes out the door but Mensho Tokyo comes close. Their Tori Paitan is so incredibly luxurious and rich it's almost too much goodness in a bowl. Not going to lie, you will probably feel like crap after a while but at least you get some joy before the regret.

Came on a weekend for dinner with a friend. I arrived about 30 minutes early and was able to get in after about 50 minutes of waiting (including the early half hour). The shop itself is very small and has very few seats. The seats that are there are honestly very uncomfortable. The tables are communal style and since they're high chairs I kept feeling like I was going to fall off and knock someone over. However, the product may be worth at least some of the suffering.
