Mensho offers some of the best ramen I've ever had. It is seldom that I have high expectations for a place and am blown away when I get there. The restaurant seems to always have a line outside, since there is limited seating, but the ramen is well worth the wait.

I came to Mensho with a few other members of my architecture fraternity. We were in San Fransisco for a photography day, and my friend was interested in seeling out the best ramen places in the city. While walking to Mensho, we walked hurriedly up a super sketchy street (I would not want to be there without the light of day). 

We got a good place in line and waited for the restaurant to open. While waiting we looked at our phones, and a Korean man waiting behind us loomed over our shoulders to look at our screens. He seemed genuinely interested in our Facebook news feeds. I took a photo of him undescreatly and he didn't seem to care. 

The inside of the restaurant is designed beautifully. We all felt very cozy at our tabel. We took the opportunity to take more photographs with my DSLR. The menu has several different ramen options, including a vegan one for my vegetarian friend. The service is friendly and the wait time is normal. I can't remember what exactly I ordered, but it was a clear broth. The ramen was delicious.

Overall, it's a bit pricy for ramen, and I would only go on special occassions. However, I love this restaurant and look forward to coming back.
author: Bryce P.

description:
Everytime i am here theres at least 1 hr wait. I understand that we are in America, but please people, be considerate of others, finish your ramen then leave. If you wanna chat, theres a bar across the street. In tokyo, theres never a wait for mensho ramen. It takes people 5 min to be done and walk out. I averaged out the time it takes people to eat and walk out of this place is 30 min. Oh well, i guess the universe just revolves around these people...
One of the best ramen in the Bay Area. And of course, ramen traditions are preferential, people might like other types of noodles and other thickness of soup base. But this one, is a plain transverse from Mensho in Tokyo. Simply put, i will comment the ramen in this shop by its components.
Soup: 
paitan soup base is thick and tasty, they put the real ingredients into making them and enough hours were  used in cooking the brooth. No chemical additives were tasted in these.
Lamb brooth gives a hint of lamb flavoring but its mostly covered by the spicyness of the soup, might be a little weak for lamb fanatics.
Shoyou brooth is as plain as you can get. Its a good choice if you dont feel like ingesting a heavy load for the night.
Noodle:
Thick, wavy, medium softness. Wish they have different choices to choose for different brooth.
Meat:
Chasiu was made from fine pig belly, not too distinctive between the fat and muscular layers, therefore its not too saturated for the taste. Thin cuts also made it easier for your stomach too, or else you will be needing Tums after dinner.
Oyster appetizer was great with the beer!!! Must try this original japanese izakaya appetizer.

This place is also a little pricey for ramen, but oh well this is sf.

Will come back again if theres no wait... or maybe once a year...
author: Jason C.

description: Good place, but I've had better. Not worth the hour wait in line to have little space to yourself when you sit. Felt super rushed and for those prices the experience wasn't worth it.
author: Sarah W.

description:
Ever eye a bowl of gravy and wish you could just eat it with a spoonful of mashed potatoes, instead of the other way around? Well, the tori patain gives you that chance except it's chicken gravy and you get some noodles to sop up the goop. Glorious, condensed chicken soup. And, and if your vegetarian, the vegan one is an umami rich thick bowl of sesame-y gravy..Crazy delicious!

I generally hate lines but I've stood in Mensho's more than 8 times now. WORTH IT!
author: Jean L.

description:
I braved the 1.5 hour wait on Saturday evening to see if this place would live up to the hype. My thoughts are mixed. I really wanted to like it but I'm not 100% sold.

On to the review, the service was excellent and once we were in the restaurant we were seated and given menus but not rushed even though it was jam packed.

The menu is spartan and focuses on the ramen. I would love to return here once they have some more of what I consider necessary side staples such as karaage or takowasa. 

First, we had the tori paitan with extra chashu. The broth is very hearty and fatty (creamy taste always equals high fat content). The ramen was firm and held up well. However, where was my ajitsuke tamari!? This is Japanese for soft boiled egg and I am not sure why they don't also serve this as an option. My guess is this will be added later but it was sorely missed.

Second, we had shoyu ramen. I actually liked this better than the first bowl because the broth was lighter. Now, I did know what I was getting into by trying the fattier broth; however, if you are watching your figure or want something light stick to shoyu.

Finally, we tried the appetizer oysters in shoyu dare oil because it was option one of two. The oysters were ok to me not bad but not amazing.

In sum, I was a bit disappointed because things that I consider fundamental to a good ramen experience and ramen dining experience were missing. Admittedly, the appetizers do not make the ramen but the ajitsuke surely does.

I will have to return and give this place another after they introduce the full menu. 頑張ってね！
author: Corey H.

description: Love love love. Had the shoyu ramen on a foggy evening after a forty minute wait. The ramen was perfection. The noodle to broth ratio was perfect. The chashu was juicy and there was also some duck. I didn't love the duck in the ramen but I'm guessing you can ask them to take it out. The tables are communal style so get ready to make some friends. The staff is super nice and it's one of those few gems that don't force you to tip as they pay their staff well. Love it
author: Ashmita V.

description:
Been several times now. Amazing stuff. Just like japan. The sour plum spice on the table is magic.

It's different ramen than what many are used to in that it's thickened with burdock (root vegetable...sort of like potato...). Definitely heartier. 

It's a great space, great service, fast, efficient, delicious.
author: Ryan B.

description:
Solid 4 stars! Have only tried Tori Paitan but the rest are definitely on my list. Small place which explains the long line. Also small menu but BIG on flavor. 
The dish itself is the best I've had in the city. Noodles are perfect, not skinny or too thick and cooked just right. All the accompaniments paired well; fried gobo, chives, cabbage, bamboo shoots (although my partner felt it was overwhelming, I thought it was fine) and meat (pork and duck).  Pork and duck was so tender and juicy.  I personally love the use of kale instead of the usual leafy greens in ramen. I thought I was the only one that did that. 
If you have the patience to wait (at least an hour if you come before they open) and love ramen as much as I do it's worth the almost $20 for a bowl of noodles.  I wish it was more $15
author: Naty D.

description:
I've been here far too many times for my own good. 

Let's just say, Tori Paitan with double meat never fails to hit the spot. The thick, indulgent broth is just a whole another world. Have you seen that gif of Drake sitting in a bowl of ramen?* That. That is exactly how I feel with each slurp. 

The Mazesoba is also amazing. (Note: If you get spicy, you will absolutely start feeling the heat) Their spicy mazesoba was actually spicy! You know when you really want a kick but most of the time only get a poke of spice instead? This is not the case. The flavor is rich and with the combination of the multiple dimensions in this dish leaves you wanting more after each bite, even if your mouth is burning up like a volcano.

My go-to when I'm feeling ramen in the city! Beware, people are not exaggerating when they proclaim the wait is at least one hour. Get there early and be hungry. 

*https://media3.giphy.com/media/l0HlJHK6QjMxzMKGc/giphy.gif - The infamous gif.
author: Winnie I.

description:
I'm not sure what's wrong with this place or it could be something wrong with me. I just can't stand their modernist interpretation of ramen. Looking at the descriptions on the walls, looks like this place has been around for a while, adapting their flavors always. 

I ordered a Shoyu ramen with a stewed apricot as an add on at the suggestion of the waiter as well as a duck chashu. The bowl of ramen was like no Shoyu ramen I've had. You can tell right away that each ingredient was quality and painstakingly prepared. But the broth was odd. The used good soy sauce but all that quality didn't amount to anything. The noodles were the worst part. They were a flat type, akin to instant noodles in the bland consistency.

Obviously, a lot of people like it and the service was. Wry good but not for me.
author: Anthony W.

description: This place opens at 5PM. We came at 5:07PM and there was already a wait!! We were probably 10th in line and it took us an hour to get seated :(. The restaurant is really small... I didn't like the seatings and the wait time. But the ramen was definitely worth it. I ordered the Tori Paitan. It was really creamy! The broth was perfect and the flavor was on point. Definitely hit the spot especially since I was starving!
author: Nhu N.

description: Waited in line a little over an hour so come with someone if you've got lots to catch up on or major life updates. But we ordered four ramens to share amongst our party. Both the reg and spicy paitan , the vegetarian tantan and the spicy lamb. The broths are incredibly creamy and flavorful. The most unique was the veggie ramen with a distinct smoky and full flavor!
author: Phoebe F.

description: I showed up and the first thing I thought was, "oh great, a huge line." This may discourage some people, but it is worth the wait. I got the spicy lamb ramen and was blown away. The flavors were very strong and unique. I look forward to my next visit and trying something new.
author: Conrad S.

description: 2 hour waiting line  i don't get it !!! For food 2 hours waiting line !! Stupid !! And The Ramen taste like a normal Ramen !!???
author: Noel L.

description: One of the best ramen I've had yet.  From the broth to the noodles absolutely delicious! Wait wasn't too long either looked worse than it was. Waited approx about 45 minutes and scored the awesome seats in the back facing the kitchen.
author: Cynthia A.

description:
long line but really good food. yum vegetarian and vegan options. they focus on really thick creamy blended broths. the meat options are katsuobushi heavy and i think there might even be katsuobushi in the noodles??? the menu is huge and fun and the community style eating is tight too. there's even katsuobushi on the tables that you can add to your broth if you're into it (i'm into it)
anyways bring a board game or something to do while you're in line because there is NEVER not a wait, almost always close to an hour
author: Brooke M.

description:
Based on the high reviews on Mensho Tokyo, I walked in with high expectations. Personally, I think this place is  overrated. The service is really friendly and the atmosphere is designed beautifully, but that's not why I came in. I ordered tori paitan noodles, which is probably one of the safer items to pick. To me, if a restaurant cannot get the basics down, they cannot do much. The broth was really creamy (and oily), but the flavor was not there. The noodles are were actually really good, the texture is almost perfect. I wouldn't recommend this noodle shop to my friends, but if someone was visiting SF then I would point them here.

P.S. This place is saturated with techies looking for a quick bite after work so expect a long wait.
author: Nicholas H.

description: Get the lamb ramen! It's out of this world good, full of flavor and I literally ate until my stomach hurt, I couldn't stop. The ramen is just spicy enough and the ground lamb is the perfect size to eat with the soup. We got in line at 4:20 on a Sunday and were the last people to get in for the first sitting, phew! The resto opens at 5.
author: Casie M.

description: We had the vegan ramen. It was smokey and delightful. The wait on a Saturday at 6:30 was a little under and hour. Worth it for vegan ramen.
author: Meridith G.

description:
Probably the best ramen in sf. 

One of the few Tori paitan ramen in the Bay Area. 
Ramen is definitely a preference thing. Some prefer miso, shoyu, tonkotsu, etc

Oh btw it is not tonkatsu. It's tonkotsu. Tonkatsu is pork cutlet. Tonkotsu is pork bone. Get it right.

The tori paitan is very flavorful and on the lighter side. 
I'm not a fan of the very heavy "kotteri" soup that is very popular in the Bay Area.

They also have great noodles. I prefer the thicker noodles  "chijiri" rather than the thin noodles. 

Since we have not gotten Ichiran, ippudo, or afuri ramen yet in the Bay Area, this is probably the best place at the moment.
author: tsubasa m.

description: We came here on the first night of our trip to SF and stood in line in very cold weather (staring intently at the people inside to hurry up) and it DID NOT DISAPPOINT! This was a unique bowl of ramen. The duck breast was perfectly cooked and added an unexpected sweetness to the bowl. The long, crunchy toppings were ridiculously delicious (my first bite tasted a bit like plantain chips although I know they were not plantains). It was delicious and filling and my favorite meal in SF so far. Will definitely come back for more next time!
author: Olivia G.

description: 3.5 ~ On a Thursday night we arrived at 5:30PM. We waited 2 hours, which is one reason for my low rating. I'm not really a fan of the tables because I couldn't really communicate with my friend. We both ordered the Tori Paitan since it was the most popular. I've read that many people enjoyed the thick and rich broth, but we weren't loving it after the first few bites. I would be back, but I'm only willing to wait an hour and try something else. All in all, it was alright and is still hyped up. Also, probably the most expensive ramen I've had.
author: Maggie W.

description: Delicious, rich broth. A bit thick for me, but the depth of flavor made it easy to overlook.
author: Mary T.

description: I was able to visit this place after a busy day in a biz trip. And waited in the line from 8 to 9pm before I can sit down and have my bowl of ramen fix. The soup is easily 10, noodle is 8, chashu is 8, didn't have egg but they look 8+. So yes definitely added to my favorite.
author: John L.

description:
I have mix feelings about writing this review and about this restaurant. First of all, its really awesome that Mensho branched out from Japan and into the heart of SF. I love it when amazing food is shared around the world and I would love to thank Mensho's owner/team for this. Unfortunately, this type of ramen is just not my favorite. The noodles are really great--chewy and thick. The broth is on the thicker side, which I do not mind, but the taste of the broth is only alright to me. Not the kind of broth I would drink all of. Hence, the four star rating, but I recommend everyone to try this place at least once.

I once ordered the spicy lamb ramen and I would never ever order it again. There is ground lamb and once piece of chasu... not impressed. A few of my friends have tried the same dish and did not like it.

The staff is attentive and nice. The interior is nice and I am so glad they have baskets for diners to store their personal items in as they enjoy the meal.

A tip for those who would like to beat the wait for this place, I recommend lining up at least 30 minutes before they open.
author: Karina N.

description:
Finally came by to try this place today! We got here around 5:45, and for 2 seats, the wait was not too bad, maybe 30minutes max.

For those driving, there's restrictions on parking in the area from 4-6pm, which means if you come at 5:45, it's perfect, because there's plenty of free street parking. Have a friend wait in line, while you sit in the car for a few more min until close to 6pm to avoid any parking violations. 

Ramen was great, tried the taipan as suggested by everyone else on Yelp. The chicken broth flavor hits upon first taste, but then soon blends in upon subsequent bites. I personally don't like thick broth, but I didn't mind this one. It was a bit grainy, which was weird, but other than that, no complaints.
author: Cynthia X.

description: Best Ramen in town! Best noodles! One of my favs! Worth the wait in line. I love this place and will weather the cold or warm for a bowl of their amazing ramen.
author: Jorge C.

description:
Oh Mensho... so this is my #71 ramen review in my ramen list (can you believe that?!). Yes, I'm a bit obsessed with ramen and friends nicknamed me "Ramen Sheriff." Check out my ramen list attached :) 

So when the talk of the town was that Mensho was everyone's new favorite ramen spot, I had to try it for myself. I tried 2 of their bowls at 2 different occasions: 

[May 2016]
I ordered the Tori Paitan while my friend ordered the Shio. I got Tori Paitan because everyone raved about it - for me, it was very rich and flavorful, however too creamy and heavy for me. It didn't even taste like broth anymore, it was like a gravy sauce, which I was not a fan of. I was jealous of my friend's Shio because it was so flavorful and light. I gave my Tori Paitan 2.5 stars and he gave his 5. I do agree that the noodles are really good here though. Perfect texture and taste. 

[Oct 2016]
Decided to give Mensho another chance. This time I ordered the Shio and my friend ordered the Organic Shoyu. Shio was much better than the Tori Paitan I ordered before, but I thought my bowl was a little bit salty. I tried the Shoyu which tasted similar to the Shio but with a kick of light soy sauce. Noodles were great again, pork was not bad, but flawed in the broth again. I was hoping second time around would have me agree with everyone else, but with the amount of ramen bowls I've had, I can't help but compare.

OVERALL: Mensho has great texture and taste for their noodles and decent pork, however although their broths are unique and somewhat similar to Japan, it still does not quite hit the spot. If you really want authentic ramen, hit up Clint at Noodle in Haystack and reserve one of his pop up ramen dinners! It's the closest thing you'll get to Japan :)
author: Raquel Y.

description: The food was okay. I waited in line for about an hour, because this is apparently some of the best ramen in San Francisco. The food was so-so. If it's cold outside, and I find myself wanting to drop $20 for soup, I might come inside. Unless there's a line...can't say that it's worth waiting for.
author: Richard K.

description:
Came here on a rainy Tuesday evening with a couple of friends. This place opens at 5pm and had a line at 6pm with about 5 groups of 2 and one group of 4 ahead of us. There is no waiting list, everyone just lines up outside and the staff lets each group enter in order. The wait was about 20 minutes, which isn't bad minus the downpour.

The restaurant is small, only seating about 20 people at a time. It almost felt like a cafeteria but with nicer atmosphere and furniture because you share a long, high table with other people. The staff are very nice and attentive.

I chose the spicy lamb double chashu ramen:
   -the double chashu option comes with two slices of chashu. 
   -the lamb was ground and formed into almost like an oval-shaped meatball, it was interesting.
    -the noodles were chewy but a little hard.
    -the broth was very heavy, fatty, and rich.
    -it was moderately spicy and seemed to get spicier as you eat more.

I was disappointed that the lamb meatball and chashu were cold, as if it's been sitting out in room temperature for a while. It was obvious like the meat in this ramen dish were not even heated up with the rest of the dish. Towards the end of the meal, I see clumps of white fat float to the surface. I've had other rich broth that were just as flavorful without being so fatty.

My rating is probably closer to a 3.5 but honestly I am not a fan based on my experience with this dish. $22 total for this meal.
author: Amy T.

description:
I'm going to go ahead and say this was the best ramen I've ever had. However I will be going to Japan next spring, so I reserve the right to revoke this statement in the future. But Mensho is certainly my new favorite ramen joint in SF!

I overheard some skeptics in the restaurant saying the ramen lacked traditional staples like corn and hard boiled egg, but I could care less. The Tori Paitan Double Chasu had some of the richest, flavorful broth I've ever tasted. The ramen noodles were equally as impressive, not at all overcooked and had a great texture and chew to them. The pork was succulent and fatty, just how I like it. It was decadent and filling, and rightly so for $18.

My sister and I arrived at 4:40pm just before they opened on a Thursday and there were less than 10 people lined up outside. Come early and come hungry!
author: Chelsea P.

description: Great ramen but they need to increase prices, I rather pay more than wait for an hr.
author: Lex R.

description:
We came on a sunday night around 9 & waited about 30 mins, the place Isnt very big so they definitely want you to eat fast because theres usually a long line outside of the place. They only have a few items on the menu but everything is pretty go id quality and taste great! 
The ingredients in the ramen overall here is some of the best, as they balance all the key components of ramen very well. I got the vegan tantamen ramen which was one of the best ramen ive ever had vegan or not. I love the ramen spots in so val like hakata sen gumi yen, kita kata, Kopan (Orange county) Tsujita and daikokuya in LA and MENSHO is up there with those places for me =D
The creaminess was amazing with so much flavorful taste from the broth, we also had the most popular tori paitan with pork and chicken broth, which was also amazing very creamy though if you prefer less creamy go for the shio or shoyu.
 Definetly expect to wait in line so the earlier you come to the better ;)
author: Cheryl P.

description:
Now, I understand the hype - the long line - the mystique.  This place is special.  I could use a bunch of colorful adjectives to try and describe the meal, but I'm not in the mood to test the character limits of a Yelp review.  The best way I could describe it is like...  its like if the joy of Christmas morning had a flavor, this is it.  It is truly an adventure for your taste buds.  Here are the particulars:

Noodles:  Perfect al dente

Broth: paitan was perfect, I added the fried garlic (I tasted the vegitarian one too - it was excellent)

Ambiance:  pretty cramped, but not claustrophobic

Price:  Around $24 per bowl (with the 'fixins'); thats totally fair for SF

Charge your phone and go wait in that line!
author: Kendall B.

description:
after the hyped news of this new ramen shop in SF...i finally got to try it on my visit home.

I went on a Thursday night around 7pm and the wait wasnt too bad for 2.

It appears that they have the classic 3, the tori, the shoyu and the vegan...but i think they rotate a few other ones too.

I got the tori one since its the classic and it seem to be the favorite to try.  My person tried the Spicy Lamb, which appears to be new.

In a decent side bowl...my ramen came and i couldnt be more excited!  the first thing i always do...BROTH!!

TASTE THE BROTH...

man o man...is this baby FULL OF FATTY RICHNESS...full of fatty porky chickeny richness....then it hit me...this shh*t is also HELLLAAA salty....like whoa...hella salt.  BUt it was delicious afterall... i do love the full body in the broth.  The noodles were cooked just right and the chasu were good (the duck was okay...i felt like it got lost from the flavors of the broth)

After halfway in, the saltiness and the heaviness didnt leave, although i can deal with the salty food...this may be a bit too much for most people.  The good thing about this ramen is that it stays hot through the whole time i was eating it.  Kudos

I also tried the spicy lamb broth...and THAT SH*T was way too salty...even saltier than mine...so salty that my person was even tempted to ask for hot water to dilute down the flavor.  It wasnt bad though but it was just way too salty.
author: Laurie W.

description:
I don't get the hype. I waited an hour in line for a warm bowl of $16 ramen that tasted like murky white bean paste. Why do all of you monkeys like this place? You're San Francisco foodies for god sakes. You should have higher standards. Shame on you. 

The oysters (we got 8 of them compared to the photos that show 4) were actually pretty good but it doesn't offset the disappointing ramen. In a few months the hype will die down and all of you who don't want to wait in line will try this place and get what I'm talking about. 

Man...I just read what I wrote and I sound hella salty. But trust me. This is nothing compared to the lukewarmness, lack of spice and saltiness that you'll experience with your bowl of Mensho ramen.
author: Joshua F.

description:
EDIT: They've heard my prayers; you can now get egg with your ramen! It's not on the menu yet but you can choose between miso or soy sauce. Now my ramen is complete.

The second time we went we decided to get the Extra Spicy Maze Soba as well. This is actually now my favorite dish at that place. They add habanero for that spicy kick; I drowned myself in water afterwards.
author: Mandy C.

description: This is my 1st time here. I'm in town for business-and decided to go find one of the area's best Ramen places and I was pleasantly surprised to find this wonderful establishment. It's a very small and popular restaurant so naturally there was going to be a wait.  I went alone and found the place because of the line... I actually waited in line for an hour, maybe even an hour and 10 minutes.   The food was great!  The food was brought out quickly and the service was excellent.  Very upbeat atmosphere too!  Seriously, the Ramen was just delicious.
author: Janelle G.

description:
The white girl who served us tonight is unbelievably rude. She took the wrong order and tried to pin it on us. After that she just gave us the very mean look. If the restaurant decided to charge its customers with 15% mandatory tip, at least try to teach the staff to get rid of the attitude.
Ramen tastes amazing as always. Just bad customer experience.
author: Liz Z.

description:
I've had both the TOKUSHIMA RAMEN and the TONKOTSU RAMEN. Hard to choose a favorite.
They are both exquisite.  Each is so creamy & flavorful that you disappear into the moment and can almost forget about the shitty music that is playing so needlessly loud.

It makes you appreciate the Ramen all that much more: IT provides the tranquility.  Very nuanced.

The Pork Bone soup, is cooked for 16 hours and you actually feel like you are there for all 16 hours as one crap song dissolves into another.
The artisanal craftsmanship of the Ramen is accentuated by the contrast with the music that sounds like was made in a lab by cyborg rats that that run on battery acid.

But seriously- the food is outstanding.  Bring earplugs or noise-cancelling headphones for your own audio experience.
author: Michael C.

description:
This restaurant was located in San Francisco and was recommended to me by my baby brother and friends. As a group, we decided to go check it out. We came with a group of seven and we decided to come early at 4:30pm before door was open. We took Uber there and as soon as we got out of the car, to our surprise, the line was already halfway long! When the door was finally opened at exactly 5:00pm sharp, the first wave of people in the line came in to be seated and unfortunately, we had to wait for our turn. Keep in mind that we have seven people in our group. Now the challenge was that my girlfriend and I needed to go back to LA and we only had an hour to eat as we also needed to Uber to the Oakland airport, which was cutting it very close. We decided to risk it and waited for our turn as we broke the group into two and five instead of seven people in a group. 

As soon as a couple was leaving, my girlfriend and I was seated. It was kind of awkward at first because the seating distance between me and my neighbors between me were too close. However, we came there to eat and that's what we wanted to focus on, the food! As soon as we finished ordering, the workers there were kind enough to wait for the five people that were sitting around us to finish eating altogether and offered them seats to my brothers and friends! So we ended up sitting together as a group and I was very grateful! 

Phew that was a long backstory, but it was necessary to be told because I wanted to focus on how delicious these ramen were although we were in a rush! My girlfriend and I ordered Tan Tan Ramen and Tori Paitan Ramen. When i first tried the Tan Tan Ramen, which was a vegetarian ramen, I was in shocked on how delicious that soup was! In addition, the texture of the noodles were just right. Not too raw, and not to cooked either. It was just right! Tan Tan Ramen didn't even taste like vegetables, I felt like I've eaten some type of meat there. I believe that's because this ramen was genuinely made for vegetarian as if they were eating meat! Which was brilliant! As for Tor Paitan Ramen, it was also yummy! the meat was great and the vegetables and fried onions made the taste even better! We finished them ramen in just 25 min, paid, said goodbye to everyone, and left! Even in the Uber's car, we kept on reminiscing on how great those ramens were.
author: Aldo H.

description: Mmmmmmmmmm best ramen I've had in my lifetime so far. The spicy one is good. Get it. I love it
author: Ian J.

description:
I used to live in Japan, and my childhood memories of ramen was not like this.

Over $50 for two bowls of ramen and two beers was a bit out of bounds for me, but now I know what Tori Paitan is, and it's my new go to meal before my cocktails and cigar up the street at Rye.
author: Ron L.

description: Pretty fast service once you're in. The wait is pretty long and the line starts around 4:30. Overall good friendly service. Got in line around 4:50 and got in at around 5:30ish maybe on a Saturday night.
author: Mayee L.

description:
Three stars for the noodles themselves. The soups I tried left much to be desired. Neither ramen that I tried would bring me back. I feel like I'm supposed to like this place because it's so hot right now. and new. and from tokyo. but, it's just okay. 

gomenaisai not gomenasai.

++1/2 Oysters in Shoyu Dare Oil. (3 pieces) $5

This was good; a nice, simple appetizer. the oysters aren't large, and seems like something that came out of a can, frankly, but still, I liked it and would order it again. It just works.

++ Tori Paitan Ramen (Double Chashu) $18
(Rich and Creamy Chicken Soup, Pork Chashu, Duck Chashu, Menma, Kale, Burdock, Katsuobushi Sauce)

Ahhh... I can't eat this. It sounds good, smells good, looks good as food porn, but it is SO RICH. It's just short of being a gravy. I ordered this on my first visit and made a mental note not to order it again. On my second visit, I didn't order it, but when I smelled it and saw it, I doubted my decision. Then I had a sip of the soup and I was like nope. The noodles are really chewy, and the soup flavor is good, but after the first few bites it already feels like too much. 


++ Organic Shoyu Ramen (Double Chashu) $16
(Clear Organic Chicken and Pork Soup, Shoyu Dare, Pork Chashu, Duck Chashu, Kale, Kale Sprouts,Chives, Menma, Nori)

The duck was okay; chashu was better but it was nice to have another meat choice in the ramen. I think it was hard to notice the chashu in the tori paitan, due to the decadence of the soup, but in the shoyu, the chashu is a fatty standout. probably the best chashu in a ramen that i've had. the noodles in the shoyu are good, but different - thinner and lighter than it's tori paitan counterpart. it paired well w/ the shoyu broth. The broth itself tasted like bonito more than shoyu. 


I would not come back for these two ramen dishes, but I still want to come back to try the other options. As for the wait, we waited about 30 minutes the first time, and maybe 20 minutes the second time. Not bad at all. Once you're in, though, the seats and ambiance are not intended to have patrons stay and shoot the shit. They want you in and out -- in that sense, it's a traditional ramen experience.
author: Erika C.

description: THE best ramen I've ever personally had! (Given I've only had ramen in Seattle, Las Vegas, New York, Durham) The wait was way over an hour long, but it was worth it. The broth was smooth silky and flavorful. The meet tasted perfect. Everything was just so so amazing.
author: Vicky T.

description: Came here with my boyfriend on Valentine's Day, around 8:45pm. There wasn't a long line when we got here, and only waited for about 20 mins before we got seated. We ordered the Enoki Mushroom Chips as an appetizer (which were amazing). I ordered the  Maccha Tori Paitan Ramen and my boyfriend ordered the Organic Shoyu Ramen. If you love matcha, I definitely recommend trying their Maccha ramen. I was expecting the Maccha ramen to only have a light coat of matcha powder on it, but I was wrong! There was so much matcha that it was also covering the rim on the bowl! The broth was thick, creamy and silky, and the noodles and chashu were cooked perfectly. I'd personally say that this is one of the best ramen I've ever had and I'll definitely be coming back for more! I would have rated this place 5 stars, but I knocked off one because we needed a little more time to look at the menu and ordered the Enoki Mushroom Chips to start. Our Enoki Mushroom Chips came out and we finished it, but no one ever came back to take the rest of our order.  We were were waiting for about 15 minutes for someone to take our order, and ended up having to flag down one of the waitresses who was taking the order for the couple who came in after us.
author: Britney R.

description: Love this place. They don't take reservations but the line moves fairly quickly. You won't have to wait long for your tasty ramen either. They serve both tonkatsu and vegetarian ramen.
author: Mimi J.

description: The shoyu ramen was really good the broth just a bit too fishy for my taste but still delicious. The chashu was thick and tasty and I really liked the duck chashu too. It was a long wait but the staff was super nice and friendly
author: Kenny R.

description:
Came here on a Wednesday night around 6pm expecting a long wait. To my surprise, we only had to wait no more than 10 minutes for a party of 2! I have to agree with other reviews saying the fewer people you come with the better. My only complaint is the space is cramped and on the louder side, making it slightly difficult to have a conversation. 

I was able to try the oysters in shoyu dare oil, tori paitan,  and shio ramen. The oysters were tasty, but nothing too special. The tori paitan had a richer and thicker broth than any other ramen I've eaten. The new consistency was initially overwhelming, but I loved the flavor and finished more of it than I should have by the end of the meal. The shio was much lighter and more similar to ramen broth you can get at other Japanese restaurants. The meat was perfectly tender and the texture of the noodles were on point for both bowls. 

Mensho is a very unique ramen experience that you should definitely check out. Hopefully you will be as lucky with your wait time as I was!
author: Sean W.

description: The line moved fast, the ramen was delicious.  Just the right texture and the vegan broth was tasty.  Don't forget to add an egg for some protein, two types to choose from.  No kae dama :-(
author: Sean K.

description:
fantastic ramen spot, line out the door at 445 pm, they open at 5pm. The broth was so frothy and rich that it was almost hard to drink. 

The flavors were great, the pork was tender and tasty, the egg perfectly prepared, the spicy lamb is a great touch and add in. 

Definitely want to go back to try the other dishes like Clam and Spicy Lamb. I sat next to a guy who said he went once a week. 

Highly recommend it.
author: Phillip T.

description:
Yes. The wait is crazy long. I waited an hour, and the last 30 minutes was filled with me watching other people consume what I could only image to be the most amazing ramen dish ever poured into porcelain. Not to mention the big screen TV that also taunts you with recordings of others eating ramen at an alarming rate. 

Even with everything working against me, I continued to wait and it was worth it. I got the Shio Ramen and Yuki Nigori Lychee Saki. Both were better than I had imagined and honestly the best dish you may find in San Francisco for the price. The duck was exquisite and the wait staff are attentive without making you feel in a rush.
author: Jeremy B.

description: Ramen was good but not sure I would say it's life-changing like the hype would suggests. The broth for the Tori Paitan is thick which is not everyone's preference but it does make the ramen more filling. Maybe the soy broth is better but I overhead another couple saying it was very salty. Overall, I was expecting more flavour in the broth and a more "wow" experience but the noodles were good. Solid bowl of ramen, but I feel like you can probably get the equivalent somewhere else for a shorter wait time and for cheaper.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
The vegan ramen is art.

I am not a vegan, but why does that matter. I did a little contrast-and-compare with the flavor of the other ramens around me, and they are ALL good, but I was SO PROUD of my choice of vegan ramen. So proud. So choice. The price is pretty gnar-gnar, but it psychologically helps boost the flavor (see "When Prophecy Fails"), and THAT I "believe" (jaja). The [owner/manager/cook?] personally delivered a local [homeless?] person some soup, on the sly. I saw it, and I was very stoked. The hypocrisy of 20 dollar soup in the Tenderloin only makes sense when good people like that [owner/manager/cook?] throw down for the whole community. Anyway, back to the soup, the soup is good. The soup is very good, and the vegan ramen is art.
author: Seo L.

description: Line is long but moves pretty quick. I wouldn't go here in a group any larger than 2, since all the tables are communal. Soup is good, a little fishier than most ramen in SF. The noodles are chewy and filling.
author: Nate H.

description: It's ok / decent but definitely not worth to wait in line. The creamy soup is too creamy and made me feel full for next couple of hours
author: Why-Tie Z.

description:
1) got there 15 mins before opening on a Tuesday. Already a good line, but luckily we were seated immediately. Score!
2) cute interior. Tight space. Baskets at your feet for your belongings. 
3) ordered the tori paitan. Came pretty quick, even though the servers took orders in a weird order. The people behind us in line (but also got seated) ordered before us. 
4) Tori Paitan was pretty good. But I didn't like the wilted greens and the creaminess of the broth made me a bit nauseous mid-meal. Very heavy. 
5) no tipping. But 15% is automatically added. 
6) don't come with a large group. Duh.
author: Whitney M.

description: Anybody who doesn't like this place probably just hates waiting in line, hates flavorful food, or loves to hate popular things.
author: Jewelle B.

description: Long line (70-mins on a Tuesday after arriving at 6:15) but worth the wait.  The Tori Paitan is very creamy and savory and the noodles were chewy and satisfying.  The starters were great and the beer was extremely cold.  Give yourself enough time to wait so that you can enjoy the place.  If you get really hungry send one of your party down the block to buy the fava-bean falafel at Pharaohs Mediterranean Sandwiches at 608 Geary.
author: J E.

description:
I came here yesterday with my boyfriend after shopping in Union Square. It wasn't too bad of a wait for a Sunday night at 7pm, but I was a bit confused that they didn't seat us when there were multiple seats opened and ready. It makes me believe that they seat people in waves, which is fine. 

I ordered the Shoyu ramen and oysters in dare oil, while my boyfriend ordered the Tori Paitan ramen and the enoki fries. The reason I rate this restaurant a 2/5 is because both the oysters and the Shoyu ramen were INCREDIBLY salty and UNEDIBLE. Furthermore, the Shoyu broth, made from chicken and pork broth, tasted so strongly of just fish - bonito flakes to be exact. I had to ask them for a bowl of broth to mix in to reduce the saltiness, but even that was not enough to counteract the saltiness. I've never had any ramen this salty before, which is a shame. I feel like they need to constantly check the flavor of their broth, which I'm sure became more concentrated due to evaporation. Furthermore, their Shoyu ramen has strange noodles that were slightly soft and overcooked. I much prefer the thicker, al dente cooked noodles that my boyfriend had in his Tori Paitan noodles.Also, duck chashu is just not that great. This is quite a shame because I couldn't enjoy the meal - which is already quite expensive and includes a 15% service charge.

The Tori Paitan was really thick which I don't enjoy much, but the broth tasted fine. The enoki fries weren't very impressive because it's difficult to taste the actual mushroom since they're quite tiny. 

I would not come back to this place and do not recommend it, unfortunately.
author: Ashley T.

description:
Sunday night lined up at 445pm, got seated after an hour. 

Gratuity free but 15% service fee is included in every bill. 

Service was good, they were nice and attentive. Ramen came out quickly. 

I got the vegan tantanmen and my boyfriend got the tori paitan. The tantanmen was very good! Hearty and creamy. Flavorful broth and you won't miss the meat. The tori paitan was very heavy. Very creamy. I can't imagine finishing the whole bowl and I am a person who loves creamy stuff. Broth was good and was very chickeny, the pork was good too.

4 stars for the tantanmen and 3 stars for the tori paitan. Rounded down to 3 stars because of the wait and price point. 

All in all, good experience and I'm glad I came. But I still prefer Ichiran and Ippudo.
author: Rae C.

description: The vegan was exceptional. You would not believe that it is vegan- the soup is unctuous and rich with a nutty undertone. The whole thing was a umami bomb!
author: Mary H.

description:
One of the BEST ramen I have ever had in my life! The broth was so frothy and rich (how I love it). There was SO much flavor! I got the Tori Paitan and I was NOT disappointed. It doesn't come with a soft-boiled egg, so if you want it - make sure to add it. The egg is one of my favorite parts so I was a bit disappointed for not reading that part closer. My friend had the spicy lamb and I had a taste of it. I think it was as good as the Tori Paitan, if not better!

Came and ate here on a Thursday. Got there probably 5-10 minutes before 5PM. There were already people in line, but my group of 9 was seated in the first round. I would have given this place 5 stars if they could split checks better. I understand we were a group of 9, but the way the place is set up, you're sharing a long table with other guests. We didn't have one dedicated waiter/waitress to our party. We actually had two different waitresses take our order even though we were in the same party. When I mentioned that we were all together, she said it didn't matter. If that didn't matter, then why couldn't our checks be split individually? I guess they don't care since they charge you a service fee regardless of your party size.
author: Alan N.

description: there's a lot of hype over this little ramen shop. I waited outside for one hour for one person! Was it worth it? I think so. the broth is rich and creamy; enjoy it with a cold sapporo! tables are mostly communal and space is very well lit and bright. not a place to sit and mingle, but ramen is legit!
author: Tiffany L.

description: Solid ramen but Ippudo is moving in soon. it's different from the other ramen places. A little thicker broth consistency. Long wait. Show up at 5pm to avoid the wait. Eat here instead of Katana-Ya, which is no good.
author: Karl K.

description: After passing by a line of waiting people numerous times and hearing a raving recommendation (especially about the vegan option) from a friend, I had to try Mensho Tokyo. And yes, the wait was for about an hour but the communal dining and view of the kitchen team in action made it worthwhile. The Vegan Tantanmen is an exceptional journey into comfortable textures, tasty broth, and happiness!! Also love the concept of no leftover packaging or to-go orders, an environmentally responsible measure that minimizes and reduces waste. Perfectly portioned, the meal left me well nourished and very satisfied!!
author: Milton W.

description: Best food I had so far in San Francisco. There's always a line here but so much worth the wait. We were lucky, we only waited 45 min but by the time we went in, the line almost doubled. I had the vegan ramen but also wanted the soft boiled soy egg in there. My god it was soooo good! All the flavours together, it's amazing. The vegan ramen are a little spicy but I loved it. The herbs and nuts in there really bring everything together.
author: Romy M.

description:
Went here last Saturday for the 3rd time and I'm pleased to report that the wait at 7pm for a party of 4 was only 25 mins! Now's your chance folks! 

This is the best ramen place in SF, the bay area, and most likely in California. The Tori Paitan ramen is on par wtih some of the NY greats like Ippudo and Totto, and the vegan ramen was a revelation for me. I came in really skeptical mumbling things about mouthfeel and "depth of flavor," but I actually ended up liking it more than the Tori Paitan. 

And on to the dish that makes me dream about this place -- the spicy mazesoba. It's a dry noodle dish kind of similar to Zha Jiang Mian (black bean noodles) that comes with bbq pork, chashu, and diced habanero. Yes, you read that right, HABANERO. It's hands down the best noodle dish I've ever had, I'm not even joking right now. I tried to order the extra spicy, but the waitress advised against it, as it contains a full 2 diced habanero. Next time! 

Finally, they have a super delicious IPA called Ozeno Yukidoke for $13 a bottle. Yes, that's super duper expensive for an ipa, but it's really really good and you should at least try it once if you're into IPAs. 

The dishes here range from $13 for shio ramen, and up to around $18 for the extra spicy mazesoba.
author: Eric W.

description:
Life has been busy, and it's been a while since my last review. As such, what better way to get back into than start with the absolutely most mindblowing culinary experience I've had locally in years? That's right, this humble little ramen shop in the Tenderloin was exactly that.

I'd been hearing about this shop for a while since it opened to great fanfare and long lines. Many of my friends went on at least a weekly basis. Since I don't live in SF, it's never been very convenient for me to go there. One time I was in SF for a Johnnie Walker event, and my friends and I thought it would be an awesome idea to check out Mensho afterwards. It was around 8:30 or 9 pm and we were starving and needed something to soak up the alcohol. We got to Mensho, but the line was ridiculously long, and starving stomachs couldn't wait. Mensho would have to wait for another day.

Fast forward a few months, and finally, I heard lines were starting to become more manageable. I was in SF to meet a few visitors from the mid-West, and my friends and I suggested that we check out Mensho. Again, it was around 8:30 pm. We walked over from Union Square, and there was a line, but it looked bearable. We had 6 people. Maybe waited 20 min in line, not bad at all given how small the shop is and how big our group was. We perused the menu during our wait.

Once we were seated, we were ready to order. I ordered the Tori Paitan.

When it came, I dipped into the broth and my mind was blown. I hadn't had broth like this in a long time, and it's been a long time since I last went to Ramen Dojo, so I can't really compare except that I recall having a similar reaction. I don't even know how to describe the rich creamy flavor (but not disgustingly fatty like Orenchi), except that perhaps this is what they invented the word "umami" for.

The hype was not blown out of proportion. It really is as amazing as everyone hyped it up to me. Normally, I try to temper hype and go somewhere with low expectations for fear of ruining the experience. I didn't really try to come here with low expectations. No, I came with high expectations, and the culinary experience exceeded my expectations. I've had many delicious ramen experiences, but this was truly an AWESOME, in all senses of the word, experience -- awe-inspiring.

I highly recommend that you check it out, and I'm not even going to tell you to temper your expectations. You'll see why.
author: Esther Y.

description:
the wait in the cold was not so fun. we were about 10 parties back in queue, and waited about 1 hour on a saturday evening around 9pm. it's communal tables with decently quick service. 

our party of 4 all got different dishes. my vegan tantanmen was DELECTABLE. super rich, peanut-y base, perfectly alkaline aldente ramen. i tried the broth for shio, organic shoyu, and tori paitan. all very good, but the vegan tantanmen was my favorite of the meal.

also try the oysters!!!
author: Judy L.

description: Man this place is really good. I've lived in Japan for a couple of years and I really miss the food there. This place gets my cravings satisfied. I really wished the venue was bigger so we don't have to wait so long though.
author: Han F.

description: I went here last year when it just opened, and checked it out again last week. The chasu pork is made to perfection--just dissolves in your mouth. The broth is thicker than other places, which I like but my friend didn't.
author: Catherine W.

description:
Came for dinner last night before seeing a play down the street. At 6pm on a Wed we only had to wait about 20 minutes for a table for 4 and an additional 10 minutes for the food to arrive after we ordered while waiting in line. 

Most of us ordered the Tori Paitan ($16 rich and creamy chicken soup, pork chashu, duck chashu, menma, kale, burdock, katsuobushi sauce) with one lone Organic Shoyu ($14 clear organic chicken and pork Soup, shoyu dare, pork chashu, duck chashu, kale, kale sprouts, chives, menma, nori).

The Tori Paitan was rich and creamy as described. The ramen came out piping hot so I was unable to really slurp and go as intended. The noodles were slightly thicker but not thick, and nice and chewy. The broth was a little too rich to drink on it's own but really good with noodles and meat and bits. 

I didn't try the Shoyu but the friend who ordered it and his date tried both and declared the Tori Paitan much better.

Not sure I would wait an hour but would make an effort to get in for an early dinner.
author: Jean K.

description:
One of the best Ramen's I have had. Yes, there is a reason why there is a line outside this store on weekdays. They are masters of their craft. 

It takes a lot of talent to get such a clear, well balanced broth like this. The broth was perfect. In fact, it was dreamy. Check out all the glass filtering utensils that they use to clear the broth. I love how much care and precision Japanese have when cooking.  

I went for the Shiro Ramen. It had beautiful flat soba style noodles and very tender slices of pork. So tender, they kept shape in the bowl, but easily fell apart when picking it up to eat with chopsticks. How do they keep this shape when slicing it for the soup? 

The restaurant itself is not that big. Only four groups of tables that sit around six people. So I would suggest that this restaurant suits no more than four people in a group. The service is quick, polite and attentive. I can see they do well with turning over the diners. 

I will easily come back here next time I am in SF. I really enjoyed my meal here.
author: Anita D.

description:
Ah, we had no idea what we were getting ourselves into. We waited in line for a good 45 minutes (maybe an hour). I counted the seats inside... 24 seats?! That's it?! No wonder it's taking so long. I started to  look this place up on my phone to see what the big deal was, ohhh, I get it now (I guess?). After waiting for 30 minutes, we were too invested and couldn't leave. The bowls of ramen being served looked too good to walk away from. I was looking forward to a diet coke (how amateur of me) but came to find out they didn't have any diet coke...

This place is traditional, that's what the word on the street is. But I'll take it. The flavors are very unique and unlike anything you've ever experienced (or unlike anything I had ever experienced). I ordered the vegetarian option, and it was crazy delicious. The broth was complex and rich (for veggie, that's impressive). The noodle were perfect. We ordered the one appetizer they have, I believe it was some mushroom thing (really tasty and different). Long story boring, this place is worth the wait. I am so glad we waited and I would do it again. I get the hype and I want more of it. More Mensho please!
author: Nikki R.

description:
I don't know where to begin... but I will start with their ramen.

I ordered the Tori paitan double chasu ramen, my hubby ordered their spicy lamb double chasu ramen, and my daughter ordered just the regular tori paitan ramen, which she shared with her grandma and I shared mine with my youngest daughter.

We waited for almost an hour in the rain just to get in and have a ramen. Now, the food was good but really overpriced for a ramen that is not even going to blow your mind. Just an FYI, my hubby and I lived in Japan for two years and we had never been given any grief by any staff at a ramen place for sharing our bowl to our family and some of the ramen places we've been in Japan are really good, plus the staff are very polite and respectful.

One of the staff literally came to our table and told us that we are not supposed to share our food because if there is 5 people in our table, we should order 5 bowls of ramen, her reason was because there are people waiting for seats. I mean seriously?? Does she want my mom and youngest daughter to wait outside in the rain because we didn't order them separate bowl of ramen???! 

I was shocked and felt humiliated because people that seating really close to our table heard all what she said to us, it felt like we could not afford to pay for five bowls and we should not eat out if we are just sharing it to the rest of our family. The fact that my youngest daughter only eat tiny amount of food and my mom is also the same, why would I waste 2 bowls of ramen that we can't even take home if we can't finish it?!! Yes, they don't have a to go container so how would they expect us to order more food if it will just end up into waste. 

The hype for getting a good ramen is just not right. Yes the food is good but not going back there again just because their staff have no respect for their paying customer. Hence the one star.
author: Lyn W.

description:
Definitely get here early, someone wrote to get here around 4:15. We arrived at 5:10 and had to wait about 1 hour and 40 minutes to be seated. 

Tori-paitan is supposedly the famous/most popular dish here. If you tend to in general not really like chicken due to occasionally getting a "death"/fecal taste despite the chicken being cleaned very thouroughly then I would recommend you skip the tori-paitan and go for something like the shio ramen. I ordered the tori-paitan despite my general dislike for chicken because I wanted to give it a try (I'm open the trying new things). Despite not really liking the broth I wasn't mad at all at my order. I REALLY liked the fried gobo and the duck chashu is sooooo good!!!

If I get the chance to come back I'll definitely try out the shio ramen.
author: E H.

description:
A very different style of ramen. Tried shoyu, tan tan, and chicken paitan. 

Must say I loved the deep fried enoki as appetiser. The ramen is a little pricier than normal and you cannot order extra serves of noodle which is unusual. 

If you like shoyu then this is very similar to what you have in quite a few other ramen places, the chicken paitan is very thick and can be a bit too much if you don't like thick broths. 

The duck charshu was very good as according to my wife and I did enjoy the pork charshu.
author: Brad B.

description: I was in SF visiting and was shocked by the long line. Prepare to wait a good 30-40 min but it was well worth it ! I got the Vegan dish. It was seriously amazing ! If you go later in the night just make sure they have enough vegan dishes as they make a certain amount for the day. Highly recommended!!!
author: Ingrid G.

description:
I finally got enough patience to wait in line for Mensho and I'm sad I didn't earlier!! It's a small spot but the line moves quick..given we got there around 9PM, with about 10 people ahead of us, we waited for about 30 minutes. 
I tried their Tori Paitan Ramen and the thick creamy broth is almost like gravy! Super flavorful and rich; not like your typical soup and ramen where you can sip on... it's soo rich that it feels like you're going to have some arteries clogged if you finished the broth. The ramen is also wider than the average--which is perfect for the gravy to latch onto. Definitely a unique bowl of ramen from all the others in the city and worth the wait!!
author: Athena L.

description:
Food was the same as last time. Read previous review for food review.

This review is more towards how the service impacted my food eating experience.

It was only half an hour wait on a Saturday around 6/7PM which is a great difference from the hour wait or more in rain. Service has gone significantly down though and almost at the point of rude. As soon as my friend and I sat down, we were approached to order. As soon as I set my spoon down from finishing my meal, they asked if they could remove my bowl. Even though my friend was still eating, they gave us the bill. And they kept checking on us to pay.

Considering I paid $18 for my bowl of ramen, I'd like to take my time and enjoy it. It was disappointing especially since I had brunch at aina that morning in Potrero Hill with similar price range and their service was significantly better.
author: Mimi T.

description:
Beforehand, I expected a wait and came early and still had a 2 hour wait. For those who aren't willing to wait, beware! My review is on the food though. 
The food was interesting. The ramen soup has a seafood flavor to it for some reason. Thought this was strange but my crew agreed that there was something fishy. The place does its noodles a little undercooked(the way most ramen shops offer when the shop doesn't let you choose your style) so it'll be a little hard in the middle. My gf likes the noodles like this. The soup, though strange, had a great taste, didn't leave a dirty taste in your mouth, and definitely high quality. The egg is slight sweetened here which fits well with the soup and a great tasting, different egg one should try. The flavor was a little strange too off for me though and isn't what I think when I think of ramen.
author: Frank V.

description:
I was skeptical, but the first few bites made me feel like I've never had ramen before!  The flavor packs quite a punch.  After about half a bowl though I think I started not enjoying it as much, I probably should have changed the broth a bit at that point w/ the spicy seasoning but I was afraid to ruin it already.  I'd definitely go back again, but maybe share w/ another person and try something else!

We also had the fried mushrooms which is quite fun and tasty!
author: Soo Jin M.

description:
Best ramen I have ever had (so far in my life). 

This restaurant was recommended by friends who have been and had ramen in Tokyo. My friends recommended that the best way to not have to wait an hour to eat ramen was to get there 30 minutes before the restaurant opened. The restaurant opens at 5pm and my friends and I arrived at 4:30pm on a Saturday. There was already a line, but we were still in the first group of people to be served.

The restaurant isn't huge. There are three tables: one long table that seats ~15 and two other tables that seat ~6 each. Though on the smaller side, the place didn't feel cramped, I felt that they used the space efficiently.

The menu wasn't extensive and didn't need to be for a ramen shop. I mean, what else are you going to get at a ramen shop? (I actually don't think there were any other entrees besides ramen.) We started with the oyster appetizer and the bamboo shoots. The oysters were very different from what I expected oysters, salty and firm. I really enjoyed them. The bamboo shoots were just bamboo shoots, nothing too special. For ramen, I ended up ordering the Tori Paitan with double chashu (double meat), which is their signature ramen. The soup base was.... amazing... It's a chicken based soup broth, which isn't typical. The broth was super rich and on the thicker side of broths I've had. The meat was sliced nice and thin, and the noodles were cooked to perfection. Everything came together so perfectly. It was like a miniature orchestra in my mouth. One of those meal experiences you wish would never end.

Definitely worth the 30 minute wait, even an hour+ wait. This place will definitely be hard to beat, unless I end up going to Tokyo for ramen.
author: Kevin W.

description:
The wait is definitely real.  We waited around 45 minutes late on a Sunday night, after hearing rumors from friends about how great this place.  I have to be honest though and although I liked it, I don't think it's my favorite from the Bay area.

I ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen and the broth was delicious.  Creamy, thick, and rich.  It was super flavorful but almost chalky in texture--like there was so much stuff that it became "sediment".  The broth was delicious but it just seemed a bit heavy and overwhelming to slurp up after a whole bowl of ramen.  The noodles, however, were cooked perfectly and the cha shu was on point--tender and delicious.  Also, I wish that they served soft-boiled eggs which are offered at most other ramen places around.
author: Jess Y.

description:
Satisfaction level 1-5 (5=highest) 
Food: 1 
Booking: 1 (waiting in line)
Atmosphere: 2 
Service: 2 
Note : waste my time!!! taste is not qualified to wait for 1hr30m 
P.S my bf gave minus 10 (-10) LOL+
P.S 2 ladle for eating soup!!! So ridiculous
author: Madame S.

description: Mensho Tokyo is a pretty solid ramen joint that tends to have a line coming out of its doorway at all times. The lines are pretty justified as the food is good, and the lines move relatively quickly as it is a relatively quick serving ramen joint. I don't feel as though it is the best ramen I've had, and if this place weren't so hyped up, I would probably give it another star, but the four star rating comes from the cons of eating at a v hyped up restaurant (i.e. longer lines and more waiting for ramen that other ramen restaurants might be on par with).
author: Patrick L.

description:
I devoured two bowls of ramen in a single visit.  One at 5:20 and another at 7:10.  The long and short of the hiccup is due a combination of hunger pains and anticipated lines and arrival time of friends.  

I tried the Tori Paitan and Shio ramen.  The latter is more similar to the typical ramen around town where as the prior was unique with a thicker broth.  Every slurp took me to umami heaven.  Broth, texture of the ramen, charsu and vegetables were perfect.  I licked both bowls clean, down to the very last drop of broth.  It was that amazing.  It was also painful to move afterwards but I got the full experience (pun intended).  Check it out.  The hype is real.  

Also, the service was unexpectedly good.  They bent over backwards in trying to accommodate my party of 1 which grew to 7.
author: Amy J.

description:
I came around 5:30 on a Saturday and the line was already crazy. My friend and I waited about an hour, maybe hour and half for a spot. We both ordered the Tori Paitan based on everyones reviews and fell in love. The noodles were thicker than usual and the chasu was super tender. And as for the most important part, the broth - it was really flavorful. I read some reviews about it being too heavy, but I guess it's just different from what we're used to. 

While I don't think I'm wiling to wait in that crazy line again, will definitely be back when the hype dies down (hopefully soon!).
author: Carrie L.

description: The soup was saltier than what I normally expected but the overall ramen is pretty good. It's a small place so there's always a line but depending on what time you come in, you wouldn't have to wait too long.
author: Angel N.

description: Worth the wait! I've been here a few times and the food is great. Only wish reservations were taken or there was more inside space for people to wait. Also wished they were open for lunch. Anyways the food is so good they can obviously have these restrictions.
author: Katie F.

description: YUM! I finally got to go here. Came right after evening opening on a Thursday and it was already full, Luckily we were only 2 people so we got seated right away. Communal seating so you will most likely sit with strangers if you are a small group.  I tried the tori paitan and it was soo good! I was afraid that it would be too milky when I first saw it but it wasn't at all, nor was it overly rich which happens with most ramen I try. The single chasu serving was enough for me and the meat was so tender. The noodles were cooked perfectly. Worth the 16$, I just wish my serving was a bit bigger, but I left not overly full which was good I guess. Also wish there was a bit more veges, but overall it was great!  Will definitely come back and can't wait to try other items on the menu!
author: Vivian D.

description: I never had a ramen where I could close my eyes and hold back tears of joy. Don't care what others say, but I know my body and my feelings. Problem is, I also want to keep my eyes open so I can visually take in all of its beauty too. The duck chashu is fabulous, the creamy broth shakes me, and the giant spoon allows me to shovel it all in, even if I take my time slowly slurping it all in. The wait does not bother me. The oysters were different yet incredibly savory and delicious.
author: Janelle H.

description: I can see why Mensho is all the ramen hype in San Francisco right now. My friend and I were really lucky when it came to waiting in line- we arrived ten minutes before 6:00pm on a rainy day, waited close to the front of the line, and were ready to be seated half an hour later. However, we still had to wait for our husbands to arrive for the full party of 4. Luckily the staff was gracious and allowed us to keep waiting in line and have the people behind us go ahead until our full party was there. We were all seated by 6:35pm and ready to eat! The restaurant is really small so I can see why the line is always down the block. I got the Tori Paitan Ramen, Double Chashu- the broth was pretty heavy but it was quite tasty. The noodles were chewy and perfectly cooked- I wish I could have had another handful of it. The meats were also tender and fatty. The ramen is on the pricier side but definitely worth a try!
author: Grace L.

description:
Delicious broth, melt-in-your-mouth chasu.

The waiters were super friendly, despite working in the "hottest" ramen place in town.

Order the appetizers! The oysters were so tasty and the fried enoki mushroom was very light and tasty as well.

Will come back!

-1 star for the wait.
author: Novalina N.

description:
Be ready to wait outside. But yes, completely worth it. I would go back and wait the line all over again.

I'm from Miami. My friend was here a few weeks back and came here with her husband to eat and told me exactly in these words "I don't care how long the line is or how cold you are, you get your butt in that line and wait."

I ate the Tori Paitan and my boyfriend had the Organic Shoyu. We shared the mushroom chips for the appetizer and had some sake and 2 Sapporos.

The staff is friendly and your food is served rather quick. The warm broth is the perfect comfort food for this San Fran weather. Especially us, since we're from Miami and FREEZING! Highly recommend!!!
author: Samantha M.

description:
It was 11:15 PM on the Friday after Outsidelands, and my friends and I were STARVING. Enter Mensho Tokyo.

We weren't expecting a wait, since it was so late, but unfortunately plenty of other people wanted to get their ramen fix as well. Ended up waiting 30 minutes - and were seated at 11:45 PM  (if you're in line before 11:30 PM, they'll most likely seat you!).

The three of us ordered the Tori Paitan. The soup was super creamy and heavy, and the noodles thick and chewy. This ramen is really unique... different from any other ramen joint I've tasted in the US. The soup was little too heavy for my liking, but the chashu and duck chashu were amazing!

At $16 per bowl, this place is a little steep too... but definitely worth checking out once! I'll probably stick to Orenchi and Ramen Parlor instead!
author: Michelle L.

description:
Mensho is one of those places where there will always be a line.  However, the line is justified, as they are able to offer ramen that is quite delicious.  I have had the pleasure of being able to dine here several times.  I have tried the shio ramen and the vegan tantanmen.  My favorite is definitely the vegan tantanmen, despite it costing double in price.  The soup is uber rich, and packs huge flavor.  I think most people would prefer the traditional soy sauce/ pork style broth, but I like this one more.  Portions are generous, even though the ramen is quite pricey.  

There aren't any seats that are private, so be very aware that everyone will be eyeing you and your food.  Service is decent, but they do rush you to eat, pay, and leave.
author: Victor L.

description:
The line is crazy long - you have to get there before it opens to get in the first round. 

Definitely overhyped. The ramen itself was okay. The broth was pretty good, but it was pretty heavy. The pork was fatty too, so I didn't feel like I was getting enough of the meat. 

We also tried the oyster appetizer, but the value for the price wasn't very good. There weren't too many oysters, and they didn't taste super fresh either.
author: Julianna K.

description:
Another hype I don't get. It wasn't bad... but it wasn't the "best ramen ever" either.  Place is super tiny. I came here at 4:45pm on a Saturday and waited about 1 hr to get seated. Let's get to why we're here:
I got the tori paitan with miso egg and it was really interesting flavor to me.  The broth has both pork and chicken flavor so it didn't taste like typical tonkatsu broth. Toppings were out of the ordinary, there was both sliced pork and duck meat as well as kale. Some mentioned how tender the duck meat were, but that wasn't the case for me. It was chewy and hard to chew, the pork on the other hand, was literally melt in your mouth tender. That was the best part of the ramen.  Hated the kale (shouldn't be anywhere near a ramen bowl imo). Miso egg is the one with the runny yolk but was extremely salty on its own. Noodles were thick and al dente, no problem with that. Meal came out to be ~22, with 15% Tip Included. First time I've seen mandatory tip for less than 5 people.
author: Yenn T.

description:
Closer to a 3.5-star rating, but I'll give it the bump.

After all the hype (aka ridiculous long lines) died down, I finally decided to give Mensho a try with my friend. Gone are the mile-long lines - I arrived around 6 and there were about 5 people in line. By 6:30-7, there was still no significant line (maybe 30 minute wait max?). 

The menu is short and sweet. I had the Tori Paitan and my friend had the vegan Tantanmen. As soon as you sit down, they come and take your order so better decide while you're waiting in line!

***First thing to note***: This is nothing close to the ramen I had in Japan. I don't know if Mensho is authentic or not, but it's definitely not the same as stuff you hear about like Ichiran, Ippudo, etc. I think my hopes of Mensho being legit ramen from Japan killed it a bit for me =X Or maybe I just didn't run into any ramen shops that served ramen like this? *shrugs*

The Tori Paitan was very interesting. The broth was VERY creamy and rich, almost like a sauce instead of a broth. If tonkotsu had a creamier poultry-based broth cousin, it would be this. You could definitely taste the katsuo in the broth, which I normally don't like but it was okay here. The slices of duck were SO tender, it was quite amazing. The noodles aren't the traditional ramen noodles, but a bit more thick, wide and flat. I found it odd that there was kale in my ramen o_o But overall, I enjoyed it. 

I had a sip of my friends Tantanmen, and I think it was good? Haha

While I don't think Mensho lives up to ramen in Japan, it's pretty good. The limited menu is a turn-off, since I don't see myself coming back for the Tantanmen or the Tori Paitan one again anytime soon. Oh, and the price tag. $18, not including tax and tip, for ramen? Yikes. I'd def pay $23 for Ichiran or Ippudo, but Mensho? Eeeeeh.
author: Doris K.

description: One vegan option, which was extremely rich (thick, nut based sauce) with hearty noodles, mushrooms, soy curls and micro greens. Tasty and layered flavors but again SO RICH. My stomach didn't so so well with it as it's extremely heavy. Maybe the average carnivore can handle it. The ingredients seemed to be really high quality and I appreciate that. Noisy doesn't cover this packed out tiny dining area (in which they play techno club music to top it off). But if you're used to all that I'm sure it's would be a bigger hit
author: Katie R.

description: I give this place A++++++. One of our friends found this place as we were walking around the city. It was a bit an hour wait but it's totally a worth it. So many flavors, options, and the ramen is incredible. We all had different ramens and we all loved each other's aswell. I recommend adding the soy egg to the ramen, it makes it extra special
author: Sara Z.

description: Very good Ramen. 4.7 stars different not your typical Ramen shop! Limited menu. Specialize on what they serve. Dashu oysters require an acquired taste. Their tori Paitan duck and pork chasu is their top biller. Highly recommend. Their shio and vegetable tantanmwn rocks too. The lamb is unique all though tasty and filling. The broth is makes them unique. And that's what makes this place different from the rest.
author: Miguel Y.

description: I don't usually give reviews but I had for this one. My partner and I came to visit SF for the first time and stayed at the Herbert Hotel which is only a 10 min walk to here. This place was recommended by a friend (who usually has great taste in food). We waited for two hours in the blistering cold (we are from socal, we don't like the cold) for a spot at this ramen spot. We looked at the menu, 20 bucks for a bowl of ramen!Most we had ever spent on ramen-- it must be good, we thought. We were seated at the counter where you could see the chefs working to make the ramen. We were put off when we saw some chefs microwaving the ramen noodles.... Yes, you read right. Don't get me wrong, the ramen was tasty. They added duck confeit for flavoring which is really unique. But just know, the ramen noodles are microwaved.
author: Donna T.

description: Waited forever but was delicious. Totally accommodated my veggie broth request. Ingredients are fresh and high quality.
author: Danielle P.

description: Ramen was great, no doubt about it. Had double chasiu and it was nicely done. Rich soup base was memorable. However, it was not worth an hour wait..
author: Dex Y.

description:
Get the Tori Paiten Ramen with double chasu. Sets you back $18.

The chashu is so fatty and well-selected that it literally falls apart when your chopstick touches it. I could almost drink it with the creamy broth. And that broth is just so creamy and thick like tsukemen broth but not nearly as salty. It is excellent. 

The duck chashu is a nice addition since the texture is different than the pork. This might also be the first ramen I've ever had with Kale-- I didn't not like it. Menma (bamboo shoots) Katsuobushi (fermented fish flakes) are all thrown in there but noodles and the chashu are the stars of this bowl.

The oyster appetizers are just okay-- I could do without. To me, it tastes like jarred oysters soaked in soy sauce. The line is a little off putting but like all good things in Japan, there is a line. The line doesn't move as fast as you'd imagine since waiting for the bowl of ramen after ordering isn't as fast as you'd think. It is well worth it though and if you're ever a single diner, they usually call out for single seat availability which allows solo patrons to cut the line. Maybe I'll try that next time I'm flying solo dolo near this ramen dojo.
author: Jerry Y.

description:
I have been waiting to go to Mensho for a while now because I've heard horror stories about the line. I finally gathered up the courage one Wednesday evening to brave the line and get what's considered to be the best ramen in SF! We arrived around 7:30 (peak dinner time) and with our party of 2 we waited in line for about 45 mins; not too bad considering I've heard of people having to wait for 2+ hours. 

We tried the vegan ramen and it was so different than any other ramen I've tried. The broth was not clear; instead, it was a cloudy brown color with a thick texture. The description said it had 9 different nuts in it so that made the broth more crunchy than smooth. I really liked that the ramen had edamame and bamboo shoots as toppings! The spice level was also perfect for me (not too bland and not too spicy), it had just the right amount of kick. 

They try to get you in and out of there as fast as possible, probably because they always have a line outside. One odd thing was that they didn't have to-go boxes to take your leftover ramen home (I've never heard of that before). All in all, the ramen was very good and I would come back here again! The price is a little much and I do prefer clear broth to Mensho's vegan ramen broth but it was definitely different and worth the visit!
author: Malika R.

description:
Although I'm not a ramen expert, the consistently long line and alluring smell made me do it. 

I did stand in line for maybe 20 min. But usually it's longer. However, it was a culinary experience unlike any other. 

I got the vegan one and there was soooo much flavor!! A tad spicy but not too much and the noodles were cooked to perfection. Totally worth all the hype. Go try it!
author: Megan F.

description:
