The ramen was soooooo good. Totally made me reminisce Japan but it's also culinarily unique and thoughtful. The broth has many different flavors that work together to create an exceptional umami hum. Very rich and smooth and the textures of the noodles were impeccable. The chashu and duck are both cooked perfectly; they're flavorful and tender. 

Yes the line is long. Come before they open so you can be in the first rotation of people that gets seated. If you're there by 4:30-4:40, you will only have to wait for half an hour. 

If you're a ramen snob or a weaboo, this place is for you.
author: Cherie Y.

description:
Third time's the charm! My friend and I tried to eat here three times. The first time we came here, the line was too long, so we ate somewhere else. Our second attempt was when it was raining on a weeknight, and I thought surely the line couldn't be that long... but it was long. Finally we came an hour before closing one night and we got seated after waiting ~30-45mins? Whoohoo~ Redford and some bars are nearby so some drunk guys caused a scene.
You don't get your own table; you're taken to the next available spot at one of the large tables they have inside... so not a good place to have a private heart to heart with someone lol. The ramen was pretty good and pricey but I come back here if I'm ever craving ramen and the line isn't too long.
author: Annie S.

description:
Wow, this unique bowl of ramen actually blew me away.  Didn't wait long (~15mins) at 7:15pm on a weeknight before getting seated at one of their 4 large communal tables.  It was a girls night out but the tables were wide enough to carry on a semi-private conversation without worrying that our neighbors were encroaching.  The service was adequate but rushed.  The point is to clear as many patrons as possible in the most efficient way.  I get it.  Don't linger.

We both opted for the Tori Paitan.  This is THE ramen to start with.  I've been to Japan twice and I've just never had anything like it.  Smooth. Creamy.  Oh so good.  Sure, my picture makes the ramen appear fatty, rich and dense but I didn't feel like a heavy greaseball afterwards.  The portion is just right and the perfectly marbled pieces of chashu pork and DUCK were absolute heaven in my mouth.  Meltingly tender.

The soup base does have a somewhat funky fishy aftertaste.  If that's not your thing, get the vegan ramen which I may try on my future visit.  It contains 7 types of nuts and was mentioned in several Yelp reviews that I read while waiting in line.

Oh, in case you're wondering, there's no need to "add" any of the standard ramen toppings - like egg, corn, mushrooms.  You won't miss it.  In fact, it's not even offered.  The broth is rich and flavorful on its own.  Restraint is key.  If you want standard ramen with all the usual fixins' go elsewhere.  This isn't why you spent $16 on a bowl of ramen.
author: Cin P.

description: Best vegan ramen I've had to date. Very long lines at this place. We waited for over an hour, but it was totally worth it. Highly recommend adding a soy egg to any ramen you get. The broth had incredible depth of flavor and was deliciously smokey. Defintely get the fried inoki mushrooms as a starter too. Looking forward to coming here again. Wow.
author: Shivu S.

description:
I was coming from up north but I knew what my plan was if I didnt want to wait 2+ hours. I arrived on Sunday at 4pm and I could have waited until 4:20 if I wanted to be the first group in still. However, I am super glad I got there as early as I did because even tho everyone gets seated, they stagger when they take orders and hand out the food. They didnt let people in until 5:10 or so and I was getting cranky waiting to enter cuz I hungers. I was one of the first 6 so we ordered first but our food took like 20-25 minutes. The people who actually got their food first were the ones you got the limited supply dipping noodles. They took those orders while we waited outside in line since it takes 15 minutes to prep. One by one, people got those dipping dishes and the rest who ordered broth ramen had to wait in agony. Le sigh. By the time I finished my bowl, the next group of 6 started to slowly get their food. Cant imagine how long the other tables had to wait for their food. 

I got the Tori paiten ramen, the one everyone gets cuz there is pork and duck. for $2 more I got double meat. The duck was somewhat raw tasting to me and I didnt like it. The pork was fatty but I had better meat than this. I do admit that the noodles were quite good and the broth was a good thick texture. Too bad they didnt have an egg bloop. I dont think this ramen is the best but because I am a yelper, I just had to try it once and experience the line.
author: Amy H.

description:
Wayyy over rated,over hyped.
What is wrong with the texture of their broth? It was... grainy. Wasn't smooth or creamy AS A tonkotsu should. The  broth is supposed to be white. The one I got was more brown. So I'm not sure if there are inconsistency or what. Another downfall is... THE meat wasn't fully cooked! YOU can see the color for yourself!

Worth the hour wait and the $18?
(Which is way too much for a single bowl of ramen).

NO
author: Satoru K.

description: I loved my Shio Ramen! Really really tasty broth... light and not salty at all. I slurped up every last bite! I only wish they serve eggs here,, its not ramen without a poached egg! Only gripe is they don't really have a system for the line outside. You just line up and it could be an endless wait since the waitress is the one who comes out to get the next party. You don't even check in, there's no texting, you just wait and wait and wait.... lol I would definitely come back though, definitely one of the best ramen I've had!
author: Irene C.

description: Long wait but worth the wait. Look for baskets under your feet when seated to place your items. I didn't know this until I finished eating. ‍
author: Millie H.

description: Came here on their anniversary date and had their Duck & Truffle Ramen special. Seriously a life experience, it was absolutely amazing. They came around and shaved truffles onto your bowl like a block of parmesean cheese. Broth was super rich and the duck tasted fantastic.
author: Faye C.

description: Duck ramen FTW! Come with 1 other person 30 minutes before close to avoid the long wait. They have good Japanese IPAs as well.
author: Mary N.

description: Delicious. We happened in at the end of a late night and it was amazing from the service to the food to the ambience. Must stop in.
author: Rachel S.

description: I came here in the beginning of April and arrived around 7:30ish and the wait was about 30 minutes which was not bad considering the wait for this place is usually longer. The service is pretty fast once you're seated. They have a pretty simple menu and only one vegetarian option  so I just ordered the Vegan tantanmen which was amazing. It was the best vegetarian ramen I have ever had. The ingredients were so fresh and the broth was to die for. In addition to the amazing ramen, they also had a small selection of different Japanese beers which included a Japanese IPA that was pretty good. 5 stars for authenticity and best vegan ramen!!!
author: Cynthia L.

description: The place maybe a lil small but the ramen has it power. I ordered the Tori Paitan which broth was rich and creamy in a good way. Also I got chance to try my friend's order which is Spicy Lamb pretty tasty as well. Definitely come back again to finish up the menu.
author: Hien H.

description:
Another testament to how I do not trust Yelp reviews in SF whatsoever. Come here if you want to wait 1+ hour for $18 bowl of subpar ramen or if you like to drink kool aid. I'd think I have some credibility as a veteran ramen eater in LA & NY:

1. Extremely heavy creamy broth that tasted like I was eating mac and cheese powder. Are you sure this is ~authentic?
2. Noodles were chewy and thick though +1
3. No egg. Wtf?!
4. Two slices of meat that literally tasted like ham or spam
5. Got the oyster appetizer for $5 and it was so gross we couldn't even finish the 5 pieces
6. Two hours later my stomach hurt like hell

Way better ramen in Japantown.
author: Connie W.

description:
Hands down, one of the best ramen I've had in California. 

Mensho Tokyo is a tiny place, with a light ambience and cozy feel. Due to the lack of space, all of the dining tables are communal and you'll often find yourself next to a new face. The idea might scream claustrophobia but MT managed to make it pleasant; and honestly, the clean lines and light wood work of the interior is really easy on the eyes. 

My friend warned me about the line prior to coming so we made sure to arrive a half hour before opening. At 4:30 pm there was already five people ahead of us and we all stared at the window in hunger. 

Once inside, we quickly ordered the Tori Paitan (the hype on this dish is unreal) and the first bite had my taste buds singing. 

The broth had depth, was extremely creamy and thick. Every spoonful was flavorful and I burned my tongue in my haste to finish it. The noodles were cooked really well and had a nice chewy texture. 

My friends and I didn't speak throughout the entire meal. We looked at each other with silent appreciation after each bite and once we finished, the only thing we could was stare at our empty bowls in longing. 

For half a second, I seriously debated on moving to SF just so I could have this ramen joint near me at all times haha. 

The people sitting next to our left had the Maze Soba, which looked amazing. The girl to my right had the Tori Paitan AND the Maze Soba (god, I was so jealous of her ability to eat more).
Safe to say, that soba is next on my list.
author: Esther B.

description:
Well, that was a letdown.

We arrived at 5:45 pm on a Friday and the wait was about an hour long. I don't really like creamy broths so I opted for their shio ramen instead of the popular tori paitan, but it was underwhelming. Just a word of caution, the shio broth is very fishy. I was ok with that, but if you're not a fan of heavy bonito flavor, I'd skip on the shio. The noodles were the crumply kind, but they weren't al dente but rather soft instead. Toppings consisted of kale (how fitting...of SF?), nori, bamboo, green onions and one piece of chashu. Comes with a giant silver spoon.

2 stars for the cute, wood minimalist interior with handy places to store your personal belongings, the friendly servers and relatively quick service once seated. As for the ramen itself, I'd look elsewhere.

If you aren't up for the long wait but want to try it out, just come as a solo diner! You'll get in much faster. There were open seats for "party of one" like 3 times over the course of our hour long wait.
author: Jen P.

description:
Quite different from other ramen I've had (Ippudo, Totto, etc). Came in with very high expectations, given people say it's the best ramen in town and there was quite a line. 

Overall, quite tasty. Soup was very creamy and rich, though a little heavy. Noodles were springy, though much thicker than typical ramen ones. The duck/chicken was a little weird, in my opinion. 

Will try other ramen joints in SF before coming back again.
author: David Y.

description:
Long story short - ramen wasn't bad but it was still overpriced/overhyped. 

Went here around 5pm on a Tuesday and there was no wait! We got seated almost immediately. Even though I was happy we didn't have to wait, I was slightly annoyed because the waitress still rushed us. Not even 30 seconds after we sat down with our menus, the waitress asked us what we wanted to order. I told her that I was still looking at the menu, and she seemed impatient/annoyed. She came back 1 minute later to see if I was ready ... I ordered the Tori Paitan, since there's not many items on the menu anyways.

The food came out very quickly. The servings are a pretty decent size, but I still don't think it's worth $16. I really liked the noodles because they were thick and the texture was very good (not too soft, I prefer my noodles to be on the hard side). The broth was also the creamiest, richest, most flavorful broth I've ever tasted. I enjoyed the taste initially, but it was a bit overwhelming to have so much of it. Even their motto on the wall says, "indispensable to Mensho ramen is the wealth of glutamic acid..." so I'm not surprised the broth would be so flavorful. 

Also, the place is very small. It's a communal dining space, so you'll be sitting at a long bar table alongside many others. I went with one other person so it wasn't a problem at all, but I wouldn't recommend trying to go here with a large group of people. 

Overall, try this place if you like really flavorful, rich ramen. It's worth a shot, but I probably wouldn't come here again due to the high prices.
author: Aye K.

description:
Arrived at 4:50 and there was already a line forming out the door...

Boyfriend and I found this place on yelp and although there were mixed reviews, we decided it was worth a try.  Honestly, for a $16 bowl of ramen, you'd expect more. It was very mediocre. I've had way better ramen for much less. 

Everything about this place kinda of turned me off. The whole community seating thing takes away from the dining experience IMO. I understand the place being small and all but it was so crammed. The woman sitting next to me kept smacking my face with her ponytail every time she turned her head. That's how crammed it was. And by having people so close, I can barely hear the person in front of me speak and can hear everyone's conversation next to me. 

The service was beyond terrible. The group that came 15 minutes after us received their food before us and the other group beside us who ordered at the same time, finished eating before our food even came out. Like what the hell is up with that? The woman who was probably the manager/owner was pretty rude and impatient. She sat a group down next to us and immediately demanded their order. I know your menu is like basic and all but damn give them a few minutes to decide. She also told them that they can't share a bowl. I don't understand what the big deal about sharing is. Maybe they can't finish an entire bowl by themselves. Although, I don't really see how someone can't finish a bowl as their bowls are narrow at the bottom and portions are extremely small. 

To be honest, this is probably the worse bowl of ramen I've ever had. It was beyond oily and too salty for my taste. I had to ask for some chili oil to make the flavor a little more interesting and because I enjoy eating everything spicy. The ramen was already hella oily before the chili oil but trust me, it made the ramen much more eatable. I wouldn't drink the soup unless you want to drink oil. 

I honestly don't understand what all the hype is about. The place is too damn small, service was terrible, way too expensive, and food was basic. Save yourself the wait in line and eat elsewhere. For a few dollars more, you can have all-you-can-eat hotpot or korean bbq. I haven't tried many ramen places in SF but if you want really good ramen, check out Hayward or Sacramento. They are much better than this so-called ramen place.
author: Phuong T.

description: One of the best ramen spots I've been to ever ! Did not like the wait. It was almost 2 hrs long. I'm not sure if I could do the wait again. Noodles were amazing. broth was amazing! The people in line were cool and had some friendly conversations. Really wish the wait was not so long. I would recommend for a bigger location since it is so good !
author: Jeffrey A.

description:
I live near this place, and my fiancé always says no- not waiting in that line. Well, I decided that eff it- I'd go by myself, especially since I had this intense craving for ramen. I am a nerd, so I read all about Mensho, as well as the Yelp reviews. I went 25 minutes before they opened, stood in line, and was seated when they opened. I have a disability and use a walker, so they had accessible seating at a bar where you could watch the cooks prepare the food.

Ok, the hype is real for a reason. I've never had ramen like this, and now I don't think I can go back to regular ramen. Since it was my first time, I wasn't too adventurous. I got the standard chicken broth based ramen, with char su pork. I literally moaned out loud, after eating a couple of bites. I wish I had purchased the double portion of pork, since the few pieces I had disappeared in my mouth, quickly.  

There are no to-go boxes, so the guy sitting next to me went to the store next door, and bought some disposable food storage containers, and shared with me and another patron. We all took our leftovers home, and several people praised our decision! Next time I go, I'm bringing a container from home. If I pay that much for food, I want to be able to take home what I can't eat.  

I took the leftovers home to my man...and I have never seen his face transform from skepticism to sheer pleasure like that, ever. He agreed- this was worth the wait!!!
author: Robin W.

description:
I'm from Japan. I do love to eat ramen in Japan. I'm going to write honesty review.

================
1. Best ramen restaurant in city.

2. Toripai-tan is most famous, I recommend MAZESOBA !

3. It takes time to go inside if you are more than two people.
==============

First of all.
" This is the BEST ramen restaurant in this city".
Mainly all of the ramen is pretty good.
The taste is almost similar to Japanese famous ramen restaurant taste.
I ate some ramen in BayArea, but this one is the best.

The best one is Toripai-tan. If you want to eat the best taste traditional famous Japanese ramen, Tori-paitan is the best choice.
Personally I recommend "MAZESOBA" without spicy.(Spicy one is so spicy. Be careful)
MAZESOBA is ramen without soup. 
The taste is so strong. Once you eat Mazesoba, you cannot forget this taste. I'm sure. 

BUT, there is actually one terrible thing.
It is that because this restaurant is so good and famous around here, every time there is line infront of the restaurant. It takes around 30 minutes to go into the restaurant.
If you are alone, you can pass the line and go inside quickly, but if you are group which is more than two people, it takes time...
author: Junshu O.

description: Best ramen I've ever had (disclaimer: I've never been to Japan yet lol) but seriously best ramen I've ever had! My husband and I were in town from socal and this was one of the restaurants that were highly recommend to us.  We got here at 4:40pm on Wednesday and thank gosh the line wasn't long yet! We only had about 6 people ahead of us. We were part of the first batch of people in the restaurant. Service was quick and friendly! We ordered the tori paitan ramen and it was so rich and creamy but not heavy! The noodles were cooked to perfection too! My mouth is watering just typing about my experience haha. I wish we had one in the OC! I highly recommend coming here and get in line about 20 mins before opening to avoid any huge wait times!
author: Alina P.

description:
Tori Paitan Ramen 3.5/5

Noodle: 4/5 - the noodle was thick noodle in order to match the Paitan broth. Was cook to katame per my order.

Broth: 4/5 - the broth is solid chicken white soup (Paitan) while I don't complain too much, it was quite plain and there is no much layer of tastes from the veggie. In the default set, there is no menma or bamboo shoots but one thing provided different texture is kyle. (Secret: ask for the spicy sauce to add some in. It's not that spicy, but will totally change your view to the broth)

Chashu: 2/5 - probably the least thing I enjoyed about tonight. It all went into small pieces after my first mix the noodle with the soup. Meanwhile, it's not very flavorful and just totally blended into the soup.

Overall: Service is good. The bill is unfortunate a little bit pricy that comes out to ~$20 per person possibly due to the unaffordable rent in SF. With the same price, I could get me a bowl of good ramen and chicken kara-age in San Mateo or South Bay.

Secret: if you go by yourself and they have one person seat open up, they will accommodate single party first for the empty seat. See there you go the power of being single. I waited only for ~15 minutes in line today.

Baseline: I will go to check it out if I haven't been to this place. I might go back again if I am in SF and I want ramen badly.
author: Even C.

description:
I visit this place almost weekly! My favorite ramen shop in San Francisco, it's the closest thing to Japan I have yet to find. Definitely try the Maze Soba, I think it's the most under rated item on the menu. It's super heavy, but delicious. 

Of the soups, the Shoyu is my favorite ramen. Everyone loves the Tori Paitan, but it's just a bit too rich for my palate. My preference is for the lighter broths. 

The service is fast friendly and efficient, just like Japan, and I love how gratuity is already built in to the total.
author: Joseph C.

description: Waited 20 mins in line before the restaurant opened and managed to snag the last two seats at the counter - there's about 28 seats available.  The sweet owner is very friendly and will gladly take photos with you.  =)  I think he only speaks Japanese.   Like everyone else mentioned, you must get the Tori Paitan Ramen with double meat if you come here- $18!  Thi comes with two pieces of Duck and Pork Chashu each. The creamy rich broth goes very well with the noodles.  My friend tried to order a soda but this was not available.  They only offer beer or water.  I could only finish half of my Ramen and was super stuffed.  I wanted to take the rest to go but couldn't since they did not have any To-Go Containers.  Such a waste of food and for the amount I paid.  Slightly disappointed.
author: Melanie N.

description:
Yummy, authentic and decently priced ramen. Just be prepared to wait.

== FOOD ==
Ordered a Tori Paitan Ramen (4/5) and a Shoyu Ramen (4/5).

Tori Paitan broth was thick and full of flavor. The meat that came with it was super soft and tasty, it soaked up all the essence of the soup that makes the meat taste so heavenly. Only wish would be if the noodles could have been more cooked.

The Shoyu Ramen broth was delicious! They had a different type of noodles from the Tori Paitan Ramen, it was pretty good. 

== AMBIENCE / SERVERS / WAIT ==
Street parking available right in front of the shop but only after 6pm. We were there approx. 5.30pm with the plan to beat the crowd, we had to park 2 blocks down. 

There was a line outside, thankfully the weather was good so waiting in line was bearable and considerably comfortable. We waited approx 20mins to get in. The line moved pretty quickly which was great. 

It is a pretty small shop that seats around 30 pax, not advisable for big group outings. Once you are seated, they are prompt to serve you water/tea and take your orders. We waited for 5-8 mins before our food arrived. 

Servers were great, prompt and move like ninja through the narrowly spaced area. Everyone was seated very closely to one another and kinda awkward to have conversations as your neighbours can pretty much hear everything you say!

Waiting for 20mins in a nice weather was fine. If it was any longer, i do not think it would be worth the time/wait.
author: Cindee T.

description:
Small ramen shop on Geary St, a few blocks away from Union Square. Arrived around 8:30pm on a Saturday, and waited about 30-45min in line. They have long table countertops, so you'll likely sit next to other customers. Waitstaff was friendly and the food arrived pretty quickly. Very clean and bright in the restaurant. It has a slight hipster vibe in there. Street parking can be tough, but you can park in an expensive garage a few blocks away, or take the bus. 

They list out some menu items on the wall, but they're not available yet. They currently offer a limited menu with just 4 ramen options. I had the Tori Paitan Ramen. It was delicious. The broth was thick, creamy, very rich and flavorful, but had a slight grittiness. The noodles were chewy and cooked to perfection. Toppings were unique, which I really liked. I had pork chasu and duck, which were both very tender. Since coming back from Japan, a bunch of ramen shops seem a bit mediocre to me. So I'm really glad to say that this was legit.
author: Katherine C.

description:
Arrived at 6:30 on a Saturday evening and waited a little under and hour. Not awful considering what I've heard about this place, and the fact that the line was moving made it less of a terrible experience. Still, the wait and all of the hype surrounding Mensho definitely built up expectations.

I can't say that the ramen completely met those expectations. I got the Tori Peitan, because it seems to be the specialty and the obvious choice for a first meal there. It was definitely a unique flavor but overwhelmingly rich (even for me, and I thought I only liked super rich ramen). The duck chashu was pretty incredible, but there wasn't enough of it. I see why people buy the upgrade. The noodles were very thick and cooked to perfection - probably the best component of the ramen. Overall I liked my bowl and finished it all, but it wasn't the best I've had or even the best I've had in SF. 

We also shares the oyster appetizer which was small but tasty and interesting.

I like the layout of the place, the communal tables, and the general ambiance. While the ramen wasn't the best ever, it was a fun experience.
author: Sara M.

description:
I would say I am a Ramen connoisseur so I know what is good ramen.  All four of us ordered the Tori Paitan, which is their signature ramen.  We were all disappointed.  The soup was too thick, almost like gravy consistency.  Although I do prefer thick noodles over thin, their noodles were too thick- similar to Shanghaiese noodle. The noodles were bland and not chewy.  The hour and a half wait was definitely not worth it.  

The service and atmosphere were the only thing I would rave about.
author: Beatrice L.

description: Delicious, rich and savory! I had the vegan ramen and it was so good. It had a smoky flavor with bits of nuts, mushrooms, cilantro, and edamame. It was creamy with a soy base. Beware that it has a bit of heat to it. I like a little heat and it had just the right amount without being overwhelming.
author: Jennifer J.

description:
Came here at a 4.30pm on Subday and there were already 3 groups in line. Luckily we were seated right away at opening. Most people in our group ordered the Double Chasu Tori Paitan ($18). Although a couple people get the vegan ramen ($18). 

The tori paitan had good flavor, but was a bit thick for my liking. That's a lot coming from someone who loves thick, deep flavored ramen.

The vegan ramen was my favorite. It had a peanut-satay spicy flavor. It is a little less thick than the tori paitan. It's hard to believe this ramen is vegan, it's so good.

With that being said, I can still only rate this 3*. The price is a little outrageous, and the lines are way too long. While the ramen was good, I would never wait more than 20mi s for this place. If this ramen is your jam, try Izakaya Goku in the Mission - slightly less thick ramen broth but equal flavor, cheaper,much shorter wait.

I did appreciate how you can order more broth or noodles here. This is definitely the true Japanese way to eat ramen.
author: Amanda R.

description:
Mensho has a special take on ramen and delivers a solid bowl of flavor & perfectly cooked ramen noodles.  I tried the spicy lamb ramen, and it was light on the spiciness, packed with meaty, cumin lamb flavor. I'd recommend it for someone who loves lamb, especially grilled cumin lamb skewers. 

I love drinking ramen broth. Mensho's soup is deep and rich, filled with those free amino acids that are advertised on their walls. Every bite of ramen noodles is packed with flavor and meaty richness but the trade off is that the broth is a little too rich to drink out of the bowl after finishing all the noodles and toppings.

The chasu was melt in your mouth deliciousness. It wound be wrong to write a review about ramen and not mention the quality of the soft boiled egg. Their egg yolk was soft and perfect and somehow it's been cooked such that the white has been infused with their broth's flavor.

Wait: I showed up at 8:30pm on a Thursday and waited 30 minutes.
author: Nancy W.

description: This might be my favorite ramen in SF. I had just eaten a fairly big meal but I was literally walking past Mensho when I remembered this place had huge lines. It was only 20 minutes away from opening so I decided to stick it out. One of the employees kindly gave me a stool to sit on as I waited. Soon thereafter a healthy line started to form.
author: Asphand B.

description: I came here with my bf when this location first opened up. There was a wait and we waited about 1.5 hours outside. The location is pretty small so there is not a lot of seats inside. There is one huge bar table and everyone is sitting together. The ramen texture was great, the soup was a bit too heavy for me, and the service was very very mediocre. We came in, got seated, ordered, ate, and left. Nothing special in terms of the service from the people working here. We got seated at the bar, with the tall stools. I didn't think this place was that great given the wait time we had. I suggest kaju eats for a better option.
author: Amy Y.

description: Came during the opening time, didn't have to wait. I ordered the chicken broth ramen, it had really thick pasty chicken soup base. Ramen is thicker then most of the ramen restaurant. Will definitely try again.
author: Tim C.

description:
One thing i would like to say this place ramen requires a minimum of 1 hr waiting. 

I knew better and came here around 410pm and i thought i was early, but guess what already 8 pple was in line already. The spot i was in, wasnt too shabby and i got in within the first round. As each 10 min pass by the line doubles up, by 430pm. To 445 pm you basically ran out of luck and gotta wait until the second round. 

When i sat down i ordered right away due to not want to wait for a while. I ordered the tori with double chashu, i requested to add an egg but they couldnt do it. 

Tori with double chashu ramen - this was served in about 10 to 15 mins of waiting. The bowl looked big and was beautifully presented. Of course i had to photo bless it before chowing down. The broth was really thick and you can totally see a layer of chicken fat since it was made with chicken. The broth was very rich in flavor with chicken flavor. Its kind of cloudy as well, it paired well with the fresh do it yourself ground your own black pepper. 

I tried sprinkling different spices that was offered on. The table as condiments, it was great and gave me a zing here and there. The chashu is very rich and strong on the first bite. As well the chashu is like bone fall off texture where it was just melt when you try to pick it up with your chopstick. The other 2 slices of duck is tender and a bit chewy. I do like the duck better than the pork. 

One of my favorite veggies was the kale, and i couldnt believe how good kale is inside the ramen soup. It also had bamboo shoots, and bits of cabbage as well. 

Price is steep for 18 dollar a bowl with 2 pc of pork, 2 pieces of duck, and bamboo shoots, kale, and bits of cabbage. The portion is like just right wont be stuffed but wont leave you too hungry. 

Overall i am glad i waited 45 mins before open time to avoid the long crowd and man if you dont have time to wait, i just say go elsewhere. If you do have the time try it once and you can say you been here and cross it off your bucketlist. So the question is will i do it again? Maybe not, i wasnt impressed with it, and it is different from what i had in tokyo japan. But why 4 stars? Its great and one of the better ones i have had in SF, until i can find better. In the stars it includes service, food, vibe, and environment. Thanks for reading and enjoy your wait in line.
author: Alex T.

description:
I came here off a suggestion from a SF native.  The wait was about an hour for 3 people around 6:30PM on a chilly March night, so you might want to have a snack before dinner.
There is no take out here, so dont even think about it.

The setting is quite small, but clean. Its what comes to mind when I think of a contemporary ramen shop. There are high top stools and bench tables with boxes underneath that you can put your stuff in (I was wondering why the random boxes were there).  You will share a table and sit closely with whoever youre next to, be it a random person or not.  This allows you to eavesdrop easily so you can sit there and silently judge while eating your ramen.  The staff is super friendly and once youre inside, service is fast.

I got recommended the Tori Paitan, which is their rich & creamy chicken soup.  I enjoyed all of the meats included, especially the chashu.  I read the ingredients but had no idea that "menma" was bamboo.  Now I dont necessarily hate bamboo, I'd just rather not eat it.  I would describe to you what I think bamboo tastes like, but it might spoil your appetite.  This broth has an extremely strong bamboo flavor. I wish I had ordered the shoyu instead, so next time I'll do just that.
author: Kenneth L.

description:
Tip 1: Show up EARLY. 
Tip 2: Don't bring a huge party. 
Tip 3: Expect a wait if you don't follow tips 1 & 2. 
Tip 4: Enjoy some of the best ramen in the city. 

4/5 stars because the wait is a nightmare even if you show early on the weekends. Have been a few times (first time, wait was 2.5 hours, 2nd time wait was only 20 minutes but I was in line 20 minutes early to get a seat).
author: Mima G.

description: Good Ramen but not worth the hour long line. Matcha ramen very novel but bit salty for my taste.  The enoki mushroom apertizer was good.  Oysters not as good.
author: Simon T.

description:
First of all, the line for this place is insane. You want a tip on when to come? Probably even at weird times, the line is better but it's still long. We came on a Thursday night around 9:15p. Maybe it was because of the NBA finals, with a game that just recently ended and people still at the bar, or maybe it was just because we caught the lull in between the dinner rush and the late dinner crowd. We ended up waiting for about 20 minutes. I would also recommend you come in a smaller group of like 2 people. You are likely to get seated faster with a small party because the shop is very small. Bigger parties just have to wait for more tables to open up. 

Ok, on to the ramen. You want to know if it's worth the wait? I don't think any food is really worth a two-hour wait, so that's where I'm coming from. But it is very good ramen. We got three bowls to share between the two of us so that we could try more things.  My friend who had been there before said that her favorite is vegan tantanmen, and we are both partial to spicy ramen. However, they ran out by the time we got there. At least that's what our server said - but I think she must have gotten false information from the kitchen.  The dude next to us who came after got a bowl, which made us very sad. Note that if you get more food than you can eat, they do NOT do to-go orders. Meaning they won't give you a to-go box. I'm not sure I like this policy. You shouldn't make delicious food and then not let people bring it home with them to enjoy if they can't finish it all. I will also say that I still like Ramen Dojo better than this place because I'm partial to spicy broth and they didn't have the spicy one when we were here. 

So here are the bowls of ramen we tried: 

(1) Tori Paitan: I think this is their specialty. I don't really like chicken broth ramen, but this place has the best chicken ramen I've ever had. The broth is frothy and creamy and satisfying. Also the noodles here are some of the best ramen noodles I've ever had. They're thicker than normal and really yummy. Still, I love spicy ramen and this was delicious but a little too bland for me. The toppings are good too - duck chashu and pork chashu are both yummy. 

(2) Shoyu: If you like shoyu ramen, this is probably the best one I've ever had. If you like lighter broths this is the one for you. I'm not as big a fan of lighter broths, but I could tell this ramen was done really well. The noodles are really good in this one too, still chewy but a little thinner than the ones that come in the tori paitan. 

(3) Spicy Mazesoba: Originally, we were going to get the vegan tantanmen as our third bowl but they ran out. Then we wanted to get the tsukemen, but they said they run out at 7p. So we decided on the spicy mazesoba. I have never had this before, so I had no idea what it is. Basically, it's like noodles with sauce but no soup. It comes in a bowl (see attached pic) with an egg yolk and various toppings. Note that the spicy one also comes with a side of what I think are habanero peppers, but not super sure. We thought these were carrots and put the entire thing in - it was wayyyyy too spicy this way - like wasabi style spicy. Do not do what we did! I think this noodle dish would have been really yummy to try and share if we didn't accidentally make it so darn spicy, it came with thick and chewy delicious noodles. Good alternative to the soup ramens, and interesting to try if you come with a group. 

All in all, I'd give this place five stars for the food. But docking it one star because of the to-go policy and because they didn't explain how to eat the mazesoba to us. It's not really intuitive! Just don't go in expecting great service either because it's a little too crowded and busy to give great service. 

I will definitely be back to try to get my hands on bowls of tsukemen and the vegan tantanmen!
author: Lin Z.

description:
Waited an hour in line, totally worth it.

I got the single Tori Paitan which it seems this place is known for. The broth is really thick with a kind of foamy texture that I found pretty unique and very flavorful. Noodles were on the thicker side which I like, and the vegetables (kale and bamboo mostly) went really well with it. The highlight of the ramen was the two type of chashu (duck and pork) that came with it. Super tender and flavorful, especially the duck.

I also tried a bit of my friend's Shio broth which was nice and light with a really nice seaweed-y flavor to it. Very nice!

All in all, this place is 100% worth the wait, especially if it's your first time. The ramen tastes unlike any others I've had in the Bay Area. Highly recommend a visit!
author: Quan N.

description:
Honestly, this place seems a little bit overrated. My friend and I came here around 5:45 on a weekday and there was already a line. Luckily, they had a spot open for 2 people and we actually didn't end up waiting.

The place is really small. At most, you can probably seat 25 or so people so don't come here in large groups unless you're willing to wait. 

As for the food itself, I got the Tori Paitan ramen. The broth was much thicker than I thought. It was sticking to my spoon so I thought that it would be difficult to drink much of it. Surprisingly, it goes down surprisingly easily although it is heavy. There was a good balance between the amount of broth, noodles and meat/vegetables. Overall, for how hyped this place is, it was actually kind of disappointing. If there is not line and I happened to be nearby, I may come back but I can't see myself going out of my way to come here again.
author: Cassie Z.

description: *** review based on first experience when they first opened***Not the best i've had but i do not think it was worth the wait and their menu was limited back when they first opened. Im 50/50 about giving this place another try again. But i am huge on 2nd chances so i will update this review once i try it again.
author: Jan H.

description: Waited in line for about 1.5-2 hours. Super stoked to try this place but when I got my food was extremely disappointed. I love ramen, but there's certain things I can't eat and when broth is made with a fish oil base, I can't eat it. We called the waitress over and explained the situation and called out that the menu didn't mention anything about a fish base. She told us we were required to pay for the one we weren't satisfied with as well as a replacement (if we wanted one). So, I ordered rice, my ate it and we left. Will never return or recommend this place to ahyone
author: Ashlie L.

description: The vegan tantanmen was so delicious. I highly recommend ordering this dish, even if you're not vegan!
author: Kirsten M.

description:
Horrible!!!!
If possible, I would like to give no star.
Doesn't even deserve a star.
Not sure why there is a long line for wait.
Not worth it.

I had shio ramen and it was just eating noodles dipped in oil.
No taste in the soup.
Kept adding salt but still no taste AT ALL.
Not Japanese quality at all!
So disappointing!!!!
日本人の恥だ！！
author: Mike C.

description:
I had the Tori Paytan. Awesome chicken broth. Does have flour in it to thicken it up so eat it while it's hot. I got extra veggies, extra duck, no pork. The noodles were firm and springy. 

Super delicious and we ended up having an amazing chat with friends we made sitting next to us who had been in line with us. 

Also, the smoked oysters and enoki fried mushrooms were a great way to start with a beer. Super delicious and different. Everything was well prepared. 

This is a great spot to take friends!

Our servers were very nice to us. We were the last people there and they accommodated a friend who had just flown in and was very hungry and 10 minutes away. This was a slower night, mind you, but a great time to try the place.
author: Priya S.

description:
Best Ramen ever. 
Long wait as always and can smell urine all over.
But believe me its worth it. 
I had the Tori Paitan with extra egg and habanero.
Do not even think of driving unless ur willing to pay for it. The location is in the Tenderloin area but I felt safe.
author: Allen A.

description:
Came here this last Tuesday (~5:45) and there was only one couple in line. 

S-C-O-R-E! 

Thank you Ramen Gods, for blessing my friend and I with these coveted seats at Mensho within 10 minutes of a wait-time. We both ordered the ramen with the creamy duck broth, which we thought was the "signature dish." It was great, the soup definitely had a creamy consistency, which is unlike any other type of ramen broth I've had. A good comparison I can think of would be clam chowder. Yup, it's thick and some might say it's hard to drink, but I'm a drinker of stews and chowders so I can live with it. I had two slices of duck which were cooked medium-rare, the center of the slices were pinkish which made the meal really interesting. I also had a slice of way overcooked char-siu which was tough and not fatty enough for my liking. BUT, CAN WE PLEASE TALK ABOUT THE TEXTURE OF THESE NOODLES? They are so amazing and chewy and just a gift to the glutenous girl in me--they absorb the flavors of the broth really well and the texture is really cool. Overall this was delicious but without any additions, with gratuity and Uncle Sam's portion, the total come out to a little over $20. Not bad, but not sure if I'd want to frequent this ramen joint considering you can probably add HEAPS of toppings at other places. #RamenToppingPalooza anyone?
author: Denise L.

description: It's good - good that we only waited a bit over half hour. More than half hour I would say it's too overrated. Would only come back if wait is not that long.
author: Gloria T.

description:
Mmm, definitely coming back here. This place is in my top 3 for ramen in the Bay Area. Had a great first time here with coworkers. I went with their specialty, Tori Paitan. When can you go to a ramen place serving both pork AND duck? What can make this better? The broth is very creamy, and the noodles are the perfect texture without being overcooked. It tasted like heaven.

The place is very packed, but in my opinion worth it. I waited 20 minutes to sit down, and my party arrived around 5:30PM. The weekday is probably your best bet for less waiting time, and I would expect the weekend to be the most crowded.
author: Alyssa C.

description:
My friend got here around 4:50pm and the line was already super long on a Thursday. I got there to meet with him and a couple other friends around 6:15 and we weren't seated until close to 7pm! The space only has enough seating for maybe...30-35 people max? So definitely be prepared to wait if you don't come super early before they open.

Service was pretty on point, food didn't take too long to come out and if you know what you want they usually take down your order when you're at the front of the line. 

I got the miso spicy ramen and got to try my friends' Tori Paitan ramen which was pretty on point. 

1) Miso spicy ramen with chashu: comes in a huge bowl and was actually pretty spicy (I like spicy food so it was tolerable but the broth definitely had a kick to it). Afterward my stomach kinda burned...was not expecting the spice to still be so prominent after eating! The chashu was super fatty but in a good way--tender and flavorful. Loved the addition of corn in the dish as well.

2) tori paitan: the broth is soooo thick and creamy but so good! I'd probably get this if I were to go again.

The noodles--super yummy, right amount of chewiness and the broth coated every inch of the noodles. 

Since the place is so small, they definitely try and get you in and out ASAP so they can seat the people waiting in line. Overall, I think the ramen was super good, but not mindblowing. I don't think I'd wait in line for 2 hours for a bowl here--maybe just come here once in a while.
author: Shannon N.

description:
This place was really authentic!
But the line is too long unless you come when the store opens:( 
I will definitely come back again!
author: Katie T.

description:
I'll say this place has the best ramen food in SF. Mensho Tokyo is location on Geary near Jones street in SF. My favorite Ramen was The Tonkotsu Ramen I always get the Ramen every time I come here. There's One thing is not good about is you gotta wait outside in line for a table & it's a small restaurant the Max capacity for this place is round 20-25 people per table. 

I wish they can build this restaurant in the East Bay at Hayward, Union City, Dublin, Fremont, San Leandro, & San Jose so it's easier for me to travel there. Also I wish they can open all day instead of the Evenings their hours should be Lunchtime 11-2pm & dinner 5-11pm.
author: Mychael H.

description: Officially my favorite ramen place in sf. Long line. Very long line. That's the worst part of this place. Their second failing is that they don't have ramen eggs. Other than that, their Paitan is super thick and flavorful without being too salty. Noodles are nice and thick too. I ordered the plum wine, which was delicious, but came in a very small amount buried in ice chips and was kind of challenging to drink. Enoki chips sounded more interesting than they actually tasted. They were a tad too oily, but had good crunch.
author: Kris F.

description: My boyfriend and I decided to bite the bullet and wait in the line at Mensho! We arrived at 7:30pm on a Saturday and as expected, waited over an hour. 1 hour 15 mins to be exact. The restaurant is very small, only a few tables and is community seating. If possible, I would recommend going alone since you can get seated faster! I highly recommend the Tori Paitan ramen for its rich and creamy broth! I LOVED the creamy broth! Definitely one of the best broths I've had. Overall, amazing ramen, long wait and pricey but worth the try!
author: Lynn T.

description:
If you're questioning whether it's worth the wait. I say yes. Is it the best ramen I've had in the bay area? It comes close. Overall, I'd give it 4.5 stars.

Small seating area, so expect a line out the door. We came towards the end of the night, so we waited around 20 mins. The staff sat us down quickly once there was seating open. 

I ordered the organic ramen just to try something different from my friends. I can assure you, I was expecting the noodles to taste grainy and the overall broth to be bland. Boy was I wrong. The ramen was cooked perfectly, slightly undercooked to give it that al dente texture. The broth had great flavor as did the other ramens. 

I do recommend this to anyone and will certainly be back in the future to try the other ramens.
author: Kyle B.

description:
Wow that was an interesting experience...

Got in line around 4:45pm on a Friday - my boyfriend and I both got off work early to stand in line before 5. The line wasn't bad at all. We were maybe the 6th to 8th party in line? After we sat down, there were only a couple parties left standing outside so I would say early Friday isn't a bad time to go! 

How did I not see any reviews about really HOW SMALL this place is?! Honestly, it seems like the size of a boba, ice cream, or froyo place... It's so small, you don't even get your own table. You sit very closely next to strangers on the same table, unless you get one of the four seats at the bar. It was a little...too cozy for my liking. Definitely not a place to spill juicy secrets with a friend if you don't want your table neighbors potentially listening in also. I'm quite a small person but I still would've preferred to have more space. I sat at the table closest to the bar and I kept getting bumped into by people walking toward or serving the people at the bar. Also, you're sitting on bar stools and have to put your coats and bags in baskets underneath the tall table. I like having my stuff a little closer to me but oh well. They also played their music really loudly so it was a little harder to have a conversation - and it was already hard because people were talking right next to us.

Alright, onto the food. My boyfriend and I both got the Tori Paitan Ramen. Wow that was the creamiest, thickest, richest ramen broth I've ever tried. I can't even really compare it to others - it's just on a whole other level. It comes with one slice of chashu and two small slices of duck. It was good but I don't think it was truly worth $16. Honestly, I did get tired of the creaminess halfway through my bowl. It just started to become too much - and out of my boyfriend and I, I typically like the creamy, tonkatsu flavored broths so that says something. Maybe this type of rich ramen just isn't for me? 

I think because of its authenticity and taste, we give it 4 stars. It's not 5 stars because the overall experience was only okay and we didn't think it was worth $16. It was definitely cool to try but might not make the effort to come again.
author: Amanda L.

description: This place is talked up a bit too much. Not only is it in a seedy location, but once you get in you won't even have the elbow space to eat your food. There's a much better ramen place just a couple blocks down that is as good, if not better. Look for the restaurant with bunnies on Market Street. You'll thank me later.
author: Peter B.

description: I understand the hype now! Got in line around 5:10 and there was already a line, missed the first seating. Because the place is so small, if you line up early then you can be the first wave of diners. We got seated around 5:50 pm as the second wave. Got the Tori Paittan (spelling? first item on the menu) $16. You can get double cha-siu for $18 a bowl. The meat was so tender it literally melted in your mouth. The noodles were comparable to other good ramen places I've had, definitely not the best but pretty solid. The BROTH is the star of the show - this is rich, creamy chicken broth that had so much flavor and umami to it! Whenever I crave ramen now, this will be at the top of my list.
author: Wendy L.

description: I usually don't care for ramen but this place is capital L LEGIT. Worth the wait. Just do it.
author: Michelle K.

description:
I was on a mission to find the best Ramen in San Francisco and my quest ends here. 

So pure and clean flavors, the broth was rich and creamy, the noodles were cooked to perfection even if I had to be in the queue for longer than I expected I would have done that to get this bowl of pure umami!
author: Sahil S.

description:
CONDENSED VERSION: I waited a long time. Food is DELICIOUS. SO FREAKIN GOOD. Service could be better. Come here if you don't mind the long wait.

Read on if you dare:

I stood in line for 2.5 hours for this. Wow. I can't believe I did that LOL. Thankfully my friend and I were just chatting and catching up the whole time, so it really didn't feel like that long -- we didn't realize we had been in line for that long until we got in and looked at the time actually LOL. We got in line around 4:30 PM on Sunday evening and it was already pretty long. It started raining a bit while we were in line and by the time we were inside, it was POURING. But the line was just as long at 8 PM as it was at 4:30.

+ DECOR/AMBIANCE
The decor is very interesting and trendy. It's a hip, modern spin on a Japanese restaurant -- tons of writing on the walls, which are very fun to read! It explains what ramen is, what umami is, etc. There's a coat rack towards the front. It's very cozy and homey feeling. The restaurant itself is INSANELY small. There's three longish communal tables, and the restaurant can probably seat about 25-30 people. You will be in close quarters with everyone sitting around you. However, it's easy to ignore the conversations next to you because it is CRAZY LOUD. It was so hard to hear anything my friend said and he was sitting right across from me. It was even harder to hear/comprehend the waitresses since they all seemed to talk very quietly and softly. They play some loud pop music in the back and with the constant yelling from people trying to hear each other, I definitely wouldn't describe it as a calming atmosphere LOL. Probably not good for a date. Good for friends and small groups. 

+ SERVICE
Well aside from the insanely long line, our waitresses were very attentive. There were a lot of them too. They were all girls that spoke very quietly so it made it hard to hear/understand what they were saying. I wanted to order the Tori Paitan with double cha siu but I guess our waitress was confused as to how I could eat so much because she tried to clarify the difference between the regular and the double and I kept saying I wanted the double but she was very confused. I eventually was just like yes I want the regular DOUBLE cha siu not DOUBLE DOUBLE, but the $18 one. I ended up with the normal Tori Paitain, $16 one not the $18. Sad. But oh well. They also didn't seem to know the items on the menu that well. The group next to us would ask which ramen was which once she brought it out to the table, and she'd have to run back and ask. I ordered the Tori Paitan and my friend ordered the Shoyu, and they swapped it accidentally. This made me very sad. LOL. But I will say they were very nice and apologetic about it. They randomly gave us green tea LOL. We didn't ask for it but they were just like HERE TAKE THIS TEA, so we did and we were very grateful LOL. 

+ THE RAMEN
SO FREAKING GOOD. YUM. As I said, I had the Tori Paitan. It was a great portion size. They did not skimp on the noodles, which I appreciated. Sadly I did not get to eat the ramen how I usually do since they gave my friend my ramen at first and when we realized, it was already all stirred up. I like to leave it as is and eat all the vegetables first, and then eat the noodles and meat without like...disturbing the presentation of any of it LOL if that makes sense. I'm weird I know. I just like my food to look nice while I eat it. I didn't get the double cha siu like I wanted but the meat was very delicious and flavorful. Perfectly cooked, and just melted in your mouth. The vegetables were also SO GOOD. Strangely, to me it tasted very meaty. And it seemed to melt in your mouth also. The Tori Paitain comes with a thicker noodle than the Shoyu, which I loved since I'm all for the fat noodles. The broth was VERY thick, and sort of gritty...not in a bad way. It was creamy and very flavorful. It's not for the faint of heart. I tried some of the Shoyu broth, and it's noticeably lighter. Very salty. I definitely preferred the Tori Paitan more. 

Overall, delicious ramen. VERY LONG WAIT. Maybe the wait will die down in a few months. And by then, hopefully the service will be better. I think they just needed to work on speaking more clearly, and knowing the orders better. Obviously this place just opened recently, so I'll let the slightly less than satisfactory service slide for now. The waitresses were all very nice and the complimentary tea was a nice gesture. If you aren't dedicated to the foodie life, wait a few months because the line is insane. If you are dedicated and willing to wait for hours in line, GO FOR IT. TRY THIS PLACE. IT'S GREAT.
author: Amy T.

description:
First off:  the lines to get in. Yes, they're long. And those on line will talk about the long line, what they read about the line, will take pix of the line -- line, line. Ours was also long but timed well on a Sunday by getting their at 3:50 and were seated within minutes of their 5pm opening. 

So, again: Lines = Long. You have been warned. And hopefully you'll be lucky like us and won't be behind an individual who holds spots for large parties who, as witnessed and reported in other reviews, show up minutes before opening. 

Was Mensho worth it? For our trio, absolutely. Again, partly due to luck and good timing. But mostly, for the ramen. We each opted for the Tori Paitan, with a double chashu order for the gents. While it's doubtful any new opinions can be offered, it was easily one of the best bowls of ramen I've experienced. The broth, very thick -- even moreso than most tonkotsu, and coaxed mostly from chicken vs. pork bone, yielding softer but more nuanced flavor than its porcine counterpart. Its texture: were I the photo editor of a dictionary, this is what I'd use for the word "mouthfeel." https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/mensho-tokyo-san-francisco-2?select=qqf4OrsRY0VRa3VVJ7fV6Q The noodles -- the best I've had, a bit thicker and more full-bodied than Oakland's Ramen Shop. The toppings, from the dash of chives to the menma, each adding to what makes eating a great bowl of ramen a true experience.  And last but no means least, both chashu, especially the duck, beautifully subtle in its individuality and synergy. 

Portions larger than Ramen Shop too. Speaking of R.S., they've gotta be a little worried about the competition, particularly since they practically stopped serving tonkotsu broth ... but that's another story. 

We also had the oysters, which weren't a personal fave, but I'm not a fan of fishy fish. If you are, might be worth your indulgence. 

Beyond the food, the interior is clean and lovely and fun. And, despite their efficiency, all the staff, particularly the host and our waitress, demonstrated uncommon courtesy and conviviality. They deserve big props for their friendliness and customer service. 

Next visit, I'm going for the vegan, with the option of chashu toppings. It's a very accommodating place. And, despite all the hype, IMHO worth it.  Just don't forget: lines.
author: John Z.

description: Great ramen restaurant in SF. I waited for 45 min to be seated, but I am glad that I didn't go home without trying it. I absolutely loved the ramen. I tried Shoyo and Tori. Both were amazingly good but I personally liked Atori better since it had more complicated flavors. I highly recommend this place.
author: Erika L.

description:
Tried tori, vegan, and shio. I like spicy so vegan was my fav. Tori and vegan noodles are delicious and crisper than the noodles in shio. In shio they are more wavy.

I heard the staff do a chant before they opened. I drink a lot of water and had to ask for refills everytime but the waitresses were nice enough. Service isn't the best but the vegan ramen is the best ramen I've had in my life. Broth is really thick in tori and vegan.
author: Allison W.

description:
Dare I say the best ramen in SF? This is not a statement to be taken lightly!

The line is long but it's definitely worth it. It was about an hour wait at 5:30pm on a Friday. Could be worse I suppose (ahem Orenchi in South Bay). 

Hubby and I had the Tori Paitan - but he made the wise decision of going with the double. I stuck to the original because of my history of chashu at other ramen places being too dry but MAN I wish I had gotten the double. The pork chashu was so freaking good! The duck chashu was even better. I for sure had ramen envy with the hubby that night. 

Only comment was that the noodles were more on the al dente side than I like but otherwise it was really really delicious ramen.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
Imagine Wal-Mart during Black Friday, that's exactly what Mensho Tokyo was like. 
If you walk in the TL and see a long line out the door, it's most likely Mensho. 

Authentic ramen from JAPAN?! Count me in to join in on the hype! Gave it a couple days to let the crowd simmer down a bit... Not that it really has.... 

Did my research and realized that in order to get in first seating you have to be there around 4-4:20pm. On a Tuesday, my friend and I came at 4:10pm and were the 3rd ones in line. Around 4:20pm the line was pretty long. I hear that if you come at 5pm (their opening time it would be a TWO hr wait) anything after that is 3-4 hr. HELL NAH. Lol. 

::Parking/Service/Ambiance::
Parking. Ha. Don't even think about it especially after 6pm. Luckily we got there around 4pm and there was parking 5-6 blocks away from the restaurant. Paid $2.25/hr because it was meters. 
It's kind of ironic that a restaurant from Japan opened up in the most ghetto part of SF, in the tenderloins. I felt super scared at night, good thing I was with a guy. 
Service was amazing. While we were in line I think the manager of some sort came out and thanked us for waiting and asked if we have any questions at all. The staff were all friendly too from start to end. 
They fit about 28 people for max capacity says the manager. There were 3 separate benches: one long bench that fits 12, two short bench that fit 6 each, and 4 chairs near the chef window. The place was definitely small but very clean and simple. Below each table were cubbies that reminded me of elementary school where we could fit our small purses or jackets. 
Came at 4:10pm so we were seated immediately and got to order before the large groups came in. 

::BLACK FRIDAY DEALS::
If you want something creamy and thick, go with vegan tantanmen or tori paitan ramen. If you want a lighter base, shio or shoyu.

Tori Paitan ramen 16.00: thick creamy rich chicken soup with BOTH pork chashu and duck chashu topped with menma, kale, burdock, and katsuobushi sauce. The sauce was SO rich and creamy. It wasn't too salty despite the creaminess. However half way through it got too heavy for me. Nonetheless the meat were all melt in your mouth perfection and the noodles were thick and cooked to amazing "bounciness" level.
author: Chena N.

description:
If you like creamy savory ramen you should get the Tori Paitan, it's a combination of duck a beef. It comes with 2 pieces of duck meat but it's definitely better to double the meat for $2 dollars more (18 total). The ramen noodles were cooked to perfection. Broth flavor was a bit too creamy. It lost its savory awesomeness after 3 bite. The duck meat broke apart cause it was so tender!! I definitely prefer Himawari in San Mateo.

Service is awesome, place it small so get use to sharing tables! You'll wait outside in a line we got there at 7:10 on Thursday and waited about 35-40 minutes. I heard the wait was insane so it might not be worth it if you're waiting 1+ hour for it.

Maybe it's cause I'm new here but street parking only (difficult). Enjoy!
author: Ben N.

description:
Goods:
Very tasty broth (with Dashi/ bonito flakes) after taste
Nicely firm noodles (Very enjoyable to eat)
They have tsukemen (Didn't try it this time as they ran out)
The chashu pork flavorful and soft

CON: 
$18 a bowl of Pricey
Smaller portion than most ramen places now
no egg :(
$11 Japanese beer with herbs (Like Whoa)


ADVICE: 
GO late or go early, if you don't want to wait then don't complain while waiting for a long time to enter the establishment. 


I would love to come back to try the tsukemen ramen.
author: kent c.

description: This is the best ramen available in San Francisco. Try the tori paitan. You will thank me later
author: Paul M.

description:
My Oh My! My belly is full and mouth has a satisfied pallette from the luxury creamy Tori Paitan Ramen with double Chasu. So creamy that you think its made with milk. Wrong! Its a mixture of chicken broth and rice but no sight of either. 

Slightly disappointed with a selection of only 2 appetizers to choose from. 

Believe me after one bowl of ramen you wont walk away with any regrets. 

I didnt see a selection for Miso, Shoyu or spicy broth. Their broth their signature broth.  Good! You can ask for their signature chili oil if you need spice. 

Be prepared for seating arrangements. There are only 4 tables, one of which seats 13. Seating arrangements are all shared so prepare to get cozy. On a warm day like today powder up cuz you can get wet!  

This is a place that you sit eat and leave. It moves fast so dont be discouraged by the line. Fast eating. 

I will consider it for individuals or small parties cuz you have to share the table.
author: Michelle P.

description:
Service and Quality at its best! I love the Paitan: the broth is one of a kind, super rich and creamy. I'm sure all the fat and juice in the broth is über nutritious as well! 

The Duck Chashu is amazeballs!!! Extra order of that fashizzles fashizzles! 


The waitress confused my order and gave my ramen to the guy next to me, since we all ordered the same thing. She profusely apologized and the manager comp-ed my bowl. We tipped them extra for the excellent service and customer care. Shout out to the chef for tossing in perfectly cooked eggs in my Paitan. 

The wait is crazyyy as all the reviews mention. Is it worth.. 

2 hours wait? Not really. 
1 hour wait? Perhaps
30 mins? Definitely 

It's better to come late than early. I say after 8pm, the wait should not be too crazy. We came on a rainy Sunday night at 8:30pm and --- No wait. Literally only 4 people in line ahead of us and we got seated in less than 10 minutes. I know, right?? Plus the free Paitan and perfect eggs. #blessed #winning #5starexperience
author: Ellen W.

description:
Oh my god. I can't even describe how great the ramen is here. I haven't had anything like it until now.

The wait can be crazy, but hey it's SF. People wait over an hour for good brunch; I'm down to wait over an hour for some delicious ramen (and because I just love noodles). It was cute seeing people play games in line to kill time and made friends with other groups in line.

Was it worth it? YES. My boyfriend and I got the Tori Paitan double chashu ramen, oyster appetizer and the premium malt beer. One of his other friends got the shoyu ramen and that was okay/something you could get something similar elsewhere, but the tori paitan is where it's at. The broth was SO creamy, rich, and something I wasn't normally used to. It was surprisingly not salty at all yet VERY flavorful. The noodles were cooked perfectly, nice and thick. Out of the pork and duck chashu, I loved the duck. It didn't fall apart like the pork, but it was melt-in-your-mouth/to-die-for perfect. Everything about it was like heaven in a bowl.

The oysters were good to try once; marinaded heavily in shoyu dare oil that not everyone would like but worth a try if you're feeling adventurous. It usually comes with three pieces but because they brought out our ramen before the appetizer, they gave us an extra piece. Our beer was one of the Suntory malts that was one of the best Japanese beers I've had. 

This place is great. Bring some good company or try your luck by yourself in hopes that you could skip the line. I'm definitely looking forward to when they start making their own noodles & the tsukemen! Hopefully some decent tsukemen in SF!!
author: Kathleen S.

description:
So this restaurant isn't very huge and it's set up where customers share tables. They have 4 bar-height community tables, which I assume makes it difficult to sit bigger groups. 

The boyfriend and I came here one weekend and had a hard time finding parking. By the time we got there, there weren't a ridiculous amount of people in front of us, but still took about an hour to be seated. They need to take note of what Ramen Parlor in San Mateo does where they take your order and prepared shortly before you get seated so that by the time you are, your meal is ready. This might help in getting the wait time shorter. Because it takes some time to get your meal after you've ordered here.

Once you are seated, the space felt slightly cramped and you had to decide whether to sit across or next to whoever you went with. There are also bins underneath the table for your belongings, because there's nowhere else to put anything. 

We both got the tori paitan ramen. The noodles are great and the broth was creamier than any other ramen restaurants I've been to. My only gripe about the food here is that there's not much options. I love spice and from looking at what they have to offer, I can only get that by ordering the veggie ramen. If there's another way to do so, I could not find it. & adding spices is just not the same. Overall, the ramen was delicious and if my boyfriend was writing this review, he would've given them a 5. I'm sure we'll be visiting here again.
author: Trina V.

description:
Tori Paitan is their claim to fame. It is rich but oh so decadent. The duck chasu is what dreams are made of. 

Mazesoba: is my secret, so here it is. MazeSoba is similar to Dan Dan Mein, but better. If one were to Google Maze Soba, it is described as ramen without the broth. The base of the sauce is almost a concentrated version of the Tori Paitan broth, with TONS of toppings, including the beloved duck chasu (treat yo self and get the double chasu). 

They also have my beloved Coedo beers.

The staff is incredibly friendly and they move fast. So be ready. 

Pro Tips: 
-Ramen etiquette, order your ramen, eat your ramen and leave. If you want to hangout with your friends, go across the street to the bar. You are the reason why the line is 2+hrs at any given time. 
-order the MazeSoba or coerce someone else in your party to.
author: Virginia Q.

description:
Shout-out to my friend Berta for waiting in line at 4:15pm so that we can get seated at opening time. If she had gotten there 5 minutes later, it would've been too late for the first seating.

The restaurant is small and lots of people are crammed into a few tables. I liked that the tables have a little cubby to put your stuff but the opening is too narrow for most women's purses. Given the lack of purse hooks combined with tall stools, there was no good place to put my bag. I also found the stools to be about 2 inches too high for the height of the table. If you have big legs, you may not fit.

Onto the food. I love tsukemen but apparently that is not being served yet. All three of us ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen. The broth was way too rich and fatty. I did like the texture of the noodles. For $18 and a long wait, it's not worth the hype.
author: Yi Z.

description: Hmm...ramen is a very personal dish, I think. Personally I thought this place was solid and is loved by many but I like Ippudo better. The broth is just more satisfying and rich, the noodles here were thicker and more al dente, which is good but not in the comforting way I like my ramen to be!
author: Claire L.

description: If I can wait 2 hours to get on the Cars ride in Disneyland .. I know I have the stamina to wait out for a hot bowl of ramen   . Worth the wait .
author: Samantha P.

description:
After waiting in the rain and cold, my food NEVER came!! Yes your read it right: NEVER came. My husband and I ordered the same thing at the same time. While he almost finished his bowl of ramen, mine was still not served. I called one of the waitress who was not our original waitress who took our order. She said she was going to double check with the kitchen. Five minutes later and still no food. I was so disappointed and decided to just cancel the order. All they could do was just apologizing. Yeah sure...

Totally NOT worth it. Not sure what the hype is all about. The food is below par (I got to taste the broth from my husband's bowl). If you're really looking for good ramen in the bay and want to make your trip worth it, Ramen Dojo in San Mateo or drive down more south to Orenchi in Santa Clara. 

Definitely NOT coming back. Bad experience with the service and food is disappointing.
author: Kunti T.

description:
Historically, SF has had mediocore ramen at best, and shit-tier ramen at worst.  Meanwhile, the Peninsula hosts the remarkable Ramen Dojo/Parlor duo, while in the South Bay, solid ramen establishments seem to popup every year.  With Mensho Tokyo, SF can finally compete with all the other titans in the Bay Area.  And they're bringing more than just ramen--their mazesoba is delicious too!

My first impression of their tori paitan ramen was the flawless execution of its individual components.  The noodles were a perfect al dente with some satisfying give to them on every bite; the pork chashu melted away with just right amount of fat and pork flavor; the chicken broth--very creamy and rich, maybe overpoweringly so, but still complex and enjoyable enough to have with every slurp; and the duck chashu...just wow...it's DUCK chashu god dammit, something to die for.  

The whole bowl of ramen, with all of these components, was quite heavy, and might not be for everyone--but if extreme savoriness is your jam, then this might just be the best ramen in the Bay Area for you.

Also of interest is their mazesoba!  It's apparently a recent food trend in Japan, so Mensho Tokyo might currently be one of the only places to offer this dish in the United States.  Regardless, it's absolutely delicious and totally worth trying.  It's essentially a dry bowl of noodles (not quite soba though, a bit thicker and similar in consistency to their ramen) with some vegetable (green onions, chives, watercress, seaweed, garlic, etc.) and meat toppings (ground pork)--somewhat of a cross between bibimbap (it has the raw egg too) and zha jiang mian.  

Mixing it all together is when the magic happens.  Every bite of noodles was accompanied with a saucy mixture of meat, fragant herbs, and crunch from the vegetables.  Why hasn't anyone thought about doing this before?  It's worth mentioning that we got the extra spicy version, and it certainly did pack quite a kick!

The wait on a random Tuesday night was about 2 hours, and when we finished eating at 9ish, the line was still just as long!  Whether or not Mensho Tokyo is worth the steep prices (actually, probably normal pricing for SF) or absurd waiting times is really up to you, but the quality and meticulous execution of their dishes is undeniable.
author: Derrek C.

description:
Came to try this place out due to the crazy hype and a couple of friends saying it's the 'best ramen they had'. I got there Sunday around 8 something for dinner, didn't get seated until 9ish. 

Ordered the tori paitan and I wasn't impressed (esp how they are charging $16 for a bowl). There's nothing really special about the ramen, more on the thicker side for noodles and the broth is more on the rich and creamy side. Toppings were lacking (u have the option to add more kale/chasu for extra $). 

For $16 you'd expect that it comes with an egg or corn or something special.  However, it does come with a small piece of kale with the stem on (very unusual).  Definitely not worth the wait if you do decide to come try this place out and not worth $16 either.
author: Jessica L.

description:
I hate waiting in lines, but like half of the Asian population in SF I just couldn't resist coming here to test my luck on a Saturday afternoon. I recommend coming 40 mins before opening in order to avoid a 1.5+ hour wait. We almost made it to the first round of seating by coming 20 mins before opening, but clearly there were people out there more determined than we were. The line only got worse after we were done eating around 7pm. 

Following the footsteps of fellow Yelpers, we each ordered the Double Chasu Tori Paitan Ramen at $18. I thought it was a little steep considering that the ramen didn't come with an egg, and double meat really just meant two thin slices of pork chasu and two thin slices of duck chasu. The duck was definitely the highlight of meal. The pork was on the salty side. Noodles were chewy and el dente just the way I like it. Broth was creamy but so loaded with chicken fat that it was deemed too unhealthy and rich to be drinkable by my friends...but I did it anyways! 

The organic shoyu ramen was too salty with strong a undercurrent of bonito and seaweed. The Tori Paitan was the clear winner here, but if you're not into thick broths, don't even bother coming here.

Customer service was efficient, and the greeter at the door was friendly. 

The restaurant seats around 25 people and is pretty tiny. Expect to squeeze with strangers at your table. Decor was clean and modern. I like that they have personal baskets below the table for you to store your purse and jacket. 

Overall worth a try for the duck chasu and delightfully chewy noodles, but not worth repeat visits because of the line.
author: Catherine C.

description: Thankfully I did not have to wait too long. Overall the service was wonderful but the food was so-so. The broth was not flavorful and tasted cheap. Also quite expensive for what it is. Worth the hype? Try it for yourself.
author: Jaushua R.

description:
This is one of the best ramen places (if not THE best) I've never been to. As stated by other reviewers, you want to come early because I came maybe 5 minutes after opening and grabbed the last two available seats.

The restaurant seats about 20-30 patrons with communal seating (get ready to get real intimate.) Service is speedy and 15% tip is automatically added to your bill. Some people might not like that, but I didn't mind; made the in-and-out process that much easier.

I got the vegan ramen which is cooked in 7 different nuts and it was DELICIOUS! I'm not a vegan, but it was so rich and flavorful that you wouldn't even notice there weren't any meat. The noodle was chewy and fresh. Yum yum.

Side note: I actually came back a couple of hours later on the same night, but the line by then was way out the door.

Second side note: It's 2 blocks down fro Katana-ya, same price point, but 100x better so GO TO THIS ONE!
author: Julia N.

description:
The BEST ramen you will ever have. I got the tori paitan because I prefer the thicker, creamy broth. The noodles have a little bite to them which I love. And the duck and pork chashu just melts in your mouth. It's like a dream. 

Me and my boyfriend always come around 10:30-11:00 to avoid the long line. Even then it's still about a 20 to 30 minute wait which I really don't mind because the food and service is sooo worth it. They always have a door man at the front who happily answers any questions you may have about the menu and fills you in on what the owner has planned for for the restaurant.
