I recommend coming in small groups or even by yourself because there is no way a large party can sit together without waiting for hours and hours. They only have Japanese style communal tables so you're always going to be sitting with strangers. I actually enjoy that because every time we go we get seated next to some really fun people :) 

5 stars for the whole experience.
author: Christine L.

description:
Da hype is real
The ramen at this restaurant is noticeably different from all other places I've been to. If you like your noodles and broth thicc, then you MUST endure the wait and try it here.
The first thing I noticed was the lack of an egg. I know, I too felt cheated.. I usually always finish my bowls of ramen, but the ones here are particularly rich and creamy that I couldn't bring myself to eat the last spoonfuls. The broth definitely didn't need the added thickness of the traditional egg after all.

The restaurant is tiny with communal tables so wait times can be overwhelming. But if you want to try something a little more unique try the toripaitan ramen!

Overall my boyfriend and I agreed this is some of the best ramen we've had, and I've been to Japan!
author: Jacqueline N.

description:
So, the hype is definitely not real. The line was longggg for a Thursday night. I had my friend wait while I drove around for 15 minutes looking for parking. Line went pretty quickly for how long it was. I may not have picked the right ramen, because I was extremely underwhelmed when it came out. The menu's print was so tiny I kind of said eff it and picked one that seemed popular. It was the double charsu ramen that was $18. The broth was too salty for me, and I love salt. The noodles looked fresh but were a little too soft for my preference. Maybe it's being picky, but the spoons they give you to eat with were ridiculously huge and hard to use to eat. There's no eggs, nothing too special. Didn't really even remind me of ramen - if it's as authentic as people say it is to Japanese ramen, maybe I shouldn't visit Japan. 

The place is TINY. Only 2 long tables really that you share and a tiny little bar where people can sit as well. Pretty sure the single stalled restroom is bigger than the restaurant (exaggerating of course but proportionally to how many people, it's pretty true). 

Id rather drive out of the city to my favorite ramen spot.
author: Erika C.

description:
When you're planning a first date, Mensho is a good choice because you have to stand with them in line for about 45 minutes on a cold SF Tuesday evening. If you're introverted or shy or socially awkward, tell your date to meet you there and show up a little later to minimize the waiting and awkward small talk and homeless approaching you for money.  

Come here when you're hungry, borderline starving. I inhaled an açaí bowl as I was leaving work, right before I came here. So my tummy was already a bit too occupied for the super thick broth and chashu and delicious noodles of the Tori Paitan Ramen. The broth is creamy and tastes great, definitely, but it was super thick. The friendly people sitting next to us suggested the vegan ramen for next time. 

Did I mention the restaurant is small and cozy? The plus side is you get to listen to your neighbors talk about girls they like and their game plan to dating them. Interesting. 

I felt ashamed looking at the leftover food. I usually kill my ramen. But I couldn't handle it. On top of that, Mensho does not have take out containers. So like I said.. come here when you're hungry. 

Next time I'll come back after a leg day for the Tori Paitan. Then the vegan ramen for the third time.
author: Sheila D.

description:
I came here after a few drinks with my friends and we needed something to fill our bellies (well, I probably needed it more after 3 cocktails, hahahaha). Through the mighty power of Yelp, I found this place just a block away and it have a bunc++h of nice reviews. I figured, why not try this place out. Mensho was definitely smaller than I expected it to be and the place was pretty crowded. I learned through my friend that this place was actually a place where people would line up to eat at this place because it was really good. For us though, we waited around 5 min before we were seated.

Service here was really quick, as they gave us our ramen in a few minutes. For me, I had the Shio Double Chashu Ramen ($11), which had 2 slices of pork. I was a little suurprised though as to how small the bowls were comparing to other ramen places that I've been to. The food itself was pretty good and filled me up. 

Although the service was quick and the food was good, would I come back specifically to this place again for some ramen? Probably not. For the price, it was kinda expensive and I feel like you can get a better deal elsewhere. Maybe if I was drinking again and needed something in my stomach. Would I recommend this place? Sure! Just expect that you'll be paying a little more than usual for ramen.
author: Tito G.

description:
I might have to come back, but here's my take on my first meal here: Not worth the wait. We ordered the oysters first and they came last. Btw, they are not fresh oysters so if you're into that, do NOT get them. Personally, I actually didn't mind them. They're very hearty, not at all refreshing as you would expect if you were expecting fresh oysters. They almost taste like marinated oysters out of a can. Again, I liked them enough to eat 2, but they're pretty overwhelming so I couldn't do anymore.
But most importantly, the ramen: we all ordered the Shoyu ramen (btw, I typically like the Tonkotsu which they do not have on the menu) and it was way too fishy tasting and yet kinda bland. I needed chili oil and a garlic spicy chili paste kind of thing to help the broth taste better. The noodles were also not my favorite. They reminded me of fettuccini, not like the ramen noodles I usually like (full disclosure, I like the ramen noodles at Nojo in Hayes Valley or Shin Sen Gumi in LA). 
For more than an hour wait, I really would have rather gone to Slurp in FiDi... Just saying.
author: Mariecar M.

description: If I consider the line and the waiting time for what you are getting, I would not give more than one star (45 mins of waiting in the line). But I think the experience should start right after you place your order. The ramen bowl with creamy broth was delicious but never ever order the mushrooms for the side ( my apologies but I found them disgusting). Slightly pricey or maybe not. I might come back.
author: Fikret D.

description: Worth the wait in line, if you need to catch up with a friend, like I did, it wouldn't bother you. Once you are seated service is efficient. Delicious ramen, we had the Tori Paitan and fried mushrooms. What I like the most about the ramen were the noodles, thick but perfectly cooked.
author: Lorely G.

description:
Came in at 8pm, got in 915pm, weekend. Overrated by the wait but I'll try to be super objective. 

Got the oyster app: unique flavour, strong soy taste, bit salty, but for sure worth a try. Why not, you waited for so long already.

Got the Tori Paitan: I'm a bit conservative so I get thrown off when they have kale in my ramen (it's SF, duh!). Despite being open-minded, I prefer my spinach. Another point that I'm extremely disappointed: they don't have the soft-boiled eggs. Great al-dente noodles, flavourful broth but nothing out of this world that you should wait for 1.5hrs.

Part of the reason why the line is so long, is the restaurant can only house up to 25seats. Overall: I'll pass.
author: Connie T.

description:
I've had a lot of ramen in my life especially being from Hawaii where great ramen is all over. So when I hear about people rave about a ramen spot I'm hesitant to jump at it right away. I went to Mensho for late dinner mid week around 10pm. There was a little line but it moved very quickly. I've seen long ass lines out this place even in the rain so I decided if I was gonna try this place I'd go when it's not a peak time. My friend and I each ordered the tori paitain, shared enoki chips, and lychee nigori. It was the most beautiful and tasty ramen I've ever had. The rich broth was complex and had so much flavor to it. Noodles tasted handmade. It was so good and so filling I almost couldn't finish it but did just because I couldn't stop eating it haha. The enoki chips were brilliant and a nice snack. The lychee nigori was so refreshing I've never had a lychee nigori before and I've had a lot of sake when I used to work in the industry. 

While we were eating I couldn't help but notice the manager looked had a friendly familiar face. Turns out he used to manage Katanaya back in the day (katanaya is now under new ownership) 

Anyway I would definitely be back but plan to go on off-peak times! Tori paitain, enoki chips, lychee nigori!!
author: Natassia S.

description: Worth the wait unless you're starving! Authentic broth and homemade noodles. Service is quick.
author: Kim O.

description: Great place for Ramen. Went on Wednesday night on a rainy day, so Ramen was a good choice. Even though you have to wait in a long line sometimes, the wait is good. They have a good selection of ramen. I recommend this place to anybody who is a ramen lover!
author: Stephen W.

description:
Excellent ramen, the Tori Paitan Ramen is by far the best ramen I've had in the US, 
I remove one start because the other ramens are just not in par with the Tori Paitan Ramen. I would not get any other ramen. 
-For people complaining about the richness of the soup, you never had real ramen, and are probably comparing to all the other shitty ramen shop around cali. 
-About the line and the price, well it's simply the best around and they have a lot of return customers for a reason. 
-Also the service kinna sucks but I don't really care, the ramen totally makes up for it
author: Jonathan F.

description:
Food was really good but the whole experience is exhausting. I ended up waiting outside in line for 90 minutes. You can get some beers across the street. If you're in a group, you can at least hope that the time will pass faster this way.
Once you get in, the light is so bright that after spending whole this time in the dark outside, it actually hurts looking at the menu. The service what awful, rushed and on top of that one of my friends at the table had to wait an extra 20 minutes to get his food. The reason: his plate was given to another table by accident so the chef had to make one from scratch. To apologize for the confusion the waiting staff kindly offered my friend a small plate. The place was loud so we didn't understand what it was and someone at the table shouts, oh I think they said oyster mushroom (looking at the brown tasty dish that was just placed on the table). My friend who is a vegetarian, and ordered a VEGETARIAN DISH, believe what he hears and starts eating. You should have seen his face.... Anyways, probably gonna skip this place from now on. It sucks because the Ramen Noodles were delicious.
author: Alex W.

description: Waited for over an hour to get in but the spicy Tori Paitan is EVERYTHING, the vegan ramen was surprisingly not bad either but def get the spicy tori paitan. 4 stars because i can never finish all my ramen and they don't let you take any to go :((
author: Pratika M.

description:
Finally a worthy ramen shop in the Bay Area!

I happened to stumble upon Mensho Tokyo by pure coincidence on Instagram of all places. My plan of attack was to come straight here right after the halftime Super Bowl show. Line was about 30 people stacked already, but it took us only 45 minutes of waiting. Not bad, considering I overheard people waiting 2-3 hours grand opening night on Saturday. Plan worked! 

Totally digging the interior design and details of this place. There's coat hooks on the wall to hang your jacket, woven baskets underneath the table to stash your purse, and even a storage space under the table to keep your phone ready for some picture action. I totally geeked out on the molecular structures and science blurb of umami on the wall. Even the wooden spoon and chopsticks neatly laying on top of the ceramic plate was just perfect.

Me and boyfriend ended up sharing a total of 3 bowls:
- Tori Paitan ($18): The most decadent of them all, a creamy and rich chicken based broth with pork + duck chashu. The broth was good, however I couldn't get over the slight grittiness of the broth. That duck chashu though! Served with round thick chewy noodles.
- Oraganic Ramen ($14): A blend of chicken + pork clear broth seasoned with shoyu and comes with pork + duck chasu. Served with flat thick chewy noodles. My boyfriend's favorite of the 3.
- Shio Ramen ($9): The cheapest bowl and also my favorite. Similar to Organic Ramen, but with a salt (not shoyu). Simple fixings with pork chashu and some fried garlic bits. Served with flat thick chewy noodles.

I loved the clear broths of both the organic and shio ramen. It was flavorfu and not overly salty. Can really taste the complex flavors of seaweed and seafood notes. I like the Shio Ramen just a bit more because of its simplicity, allowing the broth to shine. The broth comes out HOT (the way it should be). I won't lie, I slurped that bowl clean!

The pork chashu was melt in your mouth delicious. Duck chashu was completely new to my tastebuds and is as amazing as it sounds. Their in-house made ramen noodles are the thicker kind and the shape depends on which bowl you get. The toppings were different, such as fried burdock, kale, or sprouts, but the novelty works.

There's 28 seats in this joint, but turn over seems fast. I dined in and out in 30 minutes.

Since they just opened, they have a very limited menu, hopefully to expand next month with tonkotsu and tsukemen. The vegan ramen sounds intriguing as well. Can't wait to try more!
author: Minh N.

description:
This place is like a hidden gem. 

The shop itself is quite small so be prepared to wait to be seated. I arrived at the shop around 6ish and ended up waiting for an hour before we got seated. Luckily it was a nice warm day in San Francisco. 

Once you are seated, they are very prompt and quick with their service as their line is never ending. I had the opportunity to try the Tori Paitan Double Chashu and the Organic Shoyu Ramen Double Chasu.

Tori Paitan - This isn't your typical ramen you'll get at Santouka or Orenchi; it is a must try. The broth is thicker, heavier, and I would say a little bit creamy. The noodles here are definitely hand made. The broth stuck to the noodles so well that it was like eating soup and noodles at the same time! It was a very harmonious dish. If you're looking for something with a powerful flavor you should get this dish.

Organic Shoyu - The soup for this ramen isn't as heavy as the Tori Paitan. It is lighter but came across super oily in my opinion. Noodles in my Ramen were in the softer side. So if you like stiff noodles, then don't expect that here. Also the chashu is so soft, flavorful, and tender. It falls apart easily and makes it easy to eat. 

This place definitely has nailed the umami taste.
author: Stefanie W.

description: For a person who is not a huge fan of Ramen, I loved it. We stood about an one in the line but it was worth it. We ordered the veg ramen. Loved their creamy texture.
author: Amruta K.

description:
I'm glad my friend got in line early because I didn't think this experience was worth standing outside waiting for more than an hour. Well, let me rephrase that. Yes, the ramen was lovely. Very unusual and delicious.

However, the kitchen timing was off - way off. The food is brought out by type, not by when it was ordered, which may leave you nearly finished with your dinner before your companion receives theirs. Also, seating people 12 at a time to not overwhelm the kitchen when only 7 different dishes and one appetizer are served seems odd to me.  

Also, details were off - cheap paper napkins, tables too wide for normal conversation (they make you sit across from your companion), empty appetizer plates left on the table until the end of the meal. 

Finally, $20 for a bowl of ramen and a glass of water seems excessive, especially with the other issues. Maybe I'm just not hip enough for this place.
author: Kim C.

description:
The ramen wasn't bad, but it wasn't great. Honestly feel like Mensho is way overhyped. 

We waited in line for almost 2 hours (service is slow and the shop is tiny), so we were really excited to finally sit down and try the ramen. We had the Shoyu and Tori Paitan ramen, and the Tori Paitan was much better than the Shoyu (it was too salty). The broths did taste much more deluxe than other ramen places, but the bowl as a whole didn't impress me with the lack of ingredients and saltiness.
author: Claudia C.

description:
Honestly hands down the best ramen i have ever eaten. 

My friends and I decided to eat here after my job interview and when we drove past the place while trying to find parking I saw the long line and was very skeptical about it being worth the wait. It was pouring rain and yet there was a long line, that should have been an indication of what good was to come. 

After our 1+ hour long wait we finally were seated at a really large family style dinner along with other diners as well. I ordered the first broth they offered on the menu with double meat. 

When the food came it was amazeballs. 

Noodles were thick and chewy just like I like it. The broth was thick as well which was a nice surprise and it was hella fucking flavorful. 

Only complaint I would have is that there wasn't a soft boiled egg!!!!! Was hella hoping there was but the flavorful chasu was so fucking flavorful and despite not looking so colorful like the ones I'm used to, it packed a great punch of taste. 


Overall this IS a place I would love to try again despite my bowl being $18. I do wish they had other things besides seafood as apps but I ain't tripping cz the bowl of ramen filled me up pretty good.
author: Michael C.

description:
When I first heard about Mensho and subsequently read about the art of ramen, I was very excited to come here. By now, surely you must have heard about the potentially monumental wait times. My friends and I arrived at around 4:30 and the six of us were the last to get first seating at 5:00 and it was a pretty good feeling to make it into the door, especially after we turned around and looked at the line that grew behind us. 

Our group ordered mostly the Tori Paitan ramen which appears to be their signature "house" dish. But I have heard great things about the vegan ramen and I would want to try that the next time I come back. The quality of the ramen soup is extremely thick, less like a broth and more like a sauce. Although the quantity does not look like much, it will be very filling because of how dense the soup is. Someone also ordered the mazesoba, which is known for a spicy kick and is very delicious. You can get it at a variety of spice levels, but even the medium was pretty hot. Their spicy doesn't "linger" the way chili paste sometimes can, but I don't know if I would be able to handle an entire dish of that. We also asked for a recommendation of sake and got the Dassai, which was so good it got me reading a bunch of articles about sake making.

My recommendation would be to go with people you like because you should just expect a wait of some substance, know that you will be dropping about $20 for a bowl of ramen, and just enjoy the experience without getting hung up on that other stuff.
author: Maureen C.

description:
Came here on the grand opening on the first day and waited for LONG LONG time to get inside even though I was one of the first 20 people. 

The restaurant opened at 5PM, but I probably didn't get in until like 6:30PM. It was the first day on grand opening and it was superbowl weekend. It was pretty cool to see Chef Shono come out and greet everybody and also Abram AKA Ramen Beast. They took photos, some of us got interviewed. 

They didn't want to overwhelm the staff and chefs in the back so they only seated a few people at once. Everybody waiting in line was a little angry because we've been waiting for so long, but they just want to make sure everything goes well for the first day. 

Because me and my friend waited for so long we ordered 3 bowls of ramen. We got two orders of the Tori Paitan and one order of the Shio ramen. The Tori Paitan is basically a chicken based Tonkotsu ramen and the Shio is salt based. 

The Tori Paitan was freaking amazing. It was just packed with flavor. The broth was thick and there was heaps of meat inside. The chashu was very delicious and quite possibly the best chashu I had in a bowl of ramen. Well, actually, this is probably the best ramen I've had in my life. I've been to Japan and eaten plenty of too. This was definitely on that japan-level. 

The Shio ramen was very light in comparison to the Tori Paitan. It was very delicious as well. It had a nice clean flavor and was very beautiful. It was very very very good as well, I just preferred the Tori Paitan because I'm a fan of thicker broths. It was paired with flat noodles.

Tip, if you order two bowls of ramen start off with the lighter bowl first (not Tori Paitan) because once you go light to thick broth you can really taste and notice the difference of thickness. 

This is by far the best ramen shop in the Bay Area. The wait is incredibly long right now, so I'd advise you to wait till the hype dies down. Shono-san will be coming back to Mensho in March and will be added new items to the Menu. I cant wait!
author: Allen C.

description:
Meh.
Tried the shoyu ramen. A bit on the salty side for shoyu. Also the noodles, while obviously house made, were flat and not typical ramen noodles. The shio was bland. No flavor in the broth. The mazesoba was good. Better than the ramen. Not exactly soba noodles. Better! 

Probably wouldn't bother coming back. Not easy to park. About a 15 min wait. Not bad but not good enough to bring us back. So many other better ramen places.
author: Karen N.

description:
Edit: Nevermind, the hype is real. I went once, then twice, then three times, and eventually it grew on me. I've easily gone a dozen times this year. It could also be that I've gotten used to the lines and find it sort of fun, now. Weird. 

It's good, but it's not so good to justify the hype / wait.
author: Tuan V.

description:
Unfortunately I do not know what the buzz was about.  It's definitely on the pricey side, but it's SF.  

I felt the tori paitan's broth texture seemed a bit too powdery.  It's like when you cook broth and  the all that remained was the powdery portion.  The meats weren't bad.

The shio ramen was better, though not by much.  The broth was light and flavorful.  For both dishes I didn't like the ramen noodles themselves, not your typical noodles, they were of the flat wavy style.

We waited about 1 hr on a Thursday night.
author: Kent H.

description:
I believe they did their science right. Ramen is typically oily and salty, but when I had their ramen I came out wanting more. I've frequented tons of ramen joints all around, all of which where I had to keep reaching for water every couple gulps of broth or wiping my face covered in oil. In Mensho, I was completely satisfied not needing to touch the glass of water until only after my meal nor dab my face with towel. Sure it's not as flavorful as Orenchi or Daikokuya, but the bowl was completely balanced. Totally worth the wait. And as I'm writing this review, I'm thinking about coming back again this weekend.

Ps, get the extra duck chashu. You'll really want to.
author: Owie P.

description:
Location: Minimal street parking available and inside seating is very very limited. There are 3 long tables that can sit around 6-8 people at each. We got there at 4:30 PM and were the second party in. It's worth it to stand in line early - you get to be one of the first seated !

Service: Food comes out very quickly, and the ladies are very helpful and quick even though they are so busy. We were in and out within 35 minutes! 

Food: I got the organic shoyu ramen with no duck, just 2 pork charshu. The broth was rich, but not too heavy or salty. The noodles were thick - different from any other ramen I've had. This was worth the wait.
author: Shelley K.

description:
Have you ever had ramen that was SO amazing, it absolutely ruins all other ramen for you?

Unfortunately, that was not my experience at Mensho Tokyo.  While the ramen is undeniably good and I am by no means a ramen connoisseur, I think I would have been similarly satisfied with a bowl at Waraku or Men Oh.  Maybe this was a dangerous product of high expectations combined with over-hype, but my meal last Friday night did not blow me away as much as I had hoped.

My boyfriend and I got in line at 4:40PM last Friday night, and we missed the first seating by 1 party of two.  The wait didn't feel too terrible--we were seated at 5:36PM--and I was excited to try the much raved-about $18 Tori Paitan (Double Chashu), as well as the $18 Clam Butter Ramen (currently limited to 10 bowls daily).  We also ordered the $5 Oysters in Shoyu Dare Oil for appetizer, as well as a $18.55 bottle of Kikusui "Perfect Snow" Sake.  Service was fast and we did not have to wait long for our food to come out.

The Tori Paitan was definitely the highlight of the night.  As many other reviews have noted, the broth is thick and almost gravy-like.  The noodles were hot and just the right amount of chewy, and the the only thing missing from the bowl was a soft-boiled egg.  It was my first time having duck chashu, and I LOVE duck, but I can't say I prefer it any more or less to the standard pork chashu.

The Clam Butter Ramen was a little more of a miss, and we probably should have ordered something more traditional like the Shio or Shoyu Ramen.  The broth started off tasting light and delicious, but over time the taste of raw seafood ("like the ocean") permeated the entire bowl.  My boyfriend noted the noodles were not hot as in the Tori Paitain; perhaps that was to prevent overcooking of the clams and scallops in the dish?  I was expecting the broth to taste a little more "cooked," so I would not recommend this dish if you are adverse to an overly "raw" seafood taste.

The Oysters in Shoyu Dare Oil were similarly raw tasting; I love oysters, but from the pictures I did not expect it to taste this much like the ocean.  Some pieces had sand/gravel in them, so at least you know it's fresh?

The waitresses are prompt in cleaning up your bowls after you are done, which I appreciated; however, they took away my napkin before I was done drinking my sake. :(

Overall, I am not in a rush to return, but on the off-chance I walk by and there is no line, I'd give this place another shot.  Finally, note that they do not offer to-go or take-out containers, but you won't be needing any since the portions run on the small side for the price.
author: Amanda W.

description:
Their vegan tantanmen is some of the best vegan alternatives I've had. They make a roasted nut based broth with chili oil, and it has a similar fat content and depth as their non-vegan broths. The vegan noodles were springy and thick and were similar in texture and taste as ramen noodles, despite not containing egg. 

We arrived at 5:20pm on a Thursday and waited about an hour before we got seated. Line seemed to move regularly, even though the restaurant could only seat around 20 people. Bowls of ramen typically are more than $15 (except the shio ramen), so it's definitely on the higher end of the spectrum. But despite the wait and cost, it's worth going at least once.
author: Charlotte H.

description:
stumbled upon this place on Yelp and arrived 10 minutes before they opened and there was a line of at least 6 groups ahead of me. So I thought, hey this place must be good. 

First off the place is very small. The placing of tables and chairs is cramped so much that the waiter kept bumping my back every time she had pass by. Very limited seating so if you come here with a group of 4 or more, good luck trying to get a seat. You will probably have to wait for hours until a table opens up. Since its so cramped here you can hear other peoples conversations so clearly. 

The customer service was little but there. The server who looked like the manager was too into getting customers in n out of the restaurant it felt like I was in a food competition where I had to eat as fast as I could. I felt so rushed I could barely enjoy what I was eating. I get that the place is very small and you have a line outside the door but if I am going to pay for over priced ramen I would want to enjoy it. Not only did I feel so rushed trying to finish my food the server denied a customer because they wanted to share a bowl of ramen. I thought this was ridiculous and honestly felt bad for the 2 people who had to leave. 

The food was mediocre at best. To be honest, I would not wait outside to eat at this place. I ordered the Shio Ramen and was very oily. Besides the broth the pork was soft and tender. They add a lot of bamboo to your ramen which I thought was a plus. I really do not understand why this place has so much hype. I have tried better ramen places around here in the bay area that had much more flavor and spices. 

I will not come here again.
author: Joey V.

description:
There's a new ramen wave hitting the bay and I can't say I'm mad at this. The latest addition is Mensho Tokyo and there's already lines out the door even before it opens for dinner. Had to wait 2 hours (worth it!)

The Tori Paitan is pretty rich, stew like (similar to tonkotsu) and perfectly seasoned. The star of the dish was the duck chashu, so tender and thin. The shoyu is the lighter choice, although it was a tad bit oily 

The restaurant seems to be still working out kinks. The menu is currently limited to four main items. The creator is supposed to be back by the end of the month to roll out more items and homemade noodles are also expected later this year. I can't wait to try this place out again in the near future.
author: Jeff T.

description:
I feel strongly and shake my head when I read the other reviews when they docked this place for a couple of stars because of the long wait or the ramen is too salty. Ramen is my JAM. These amateurs obviously don't know ramen. Ramen is always salty. It's not mean to be a bland soup. Also, good food is worth the wait if you have the time to wait and if you want to eat the good food enough. I must admit in SF, many people love to wait BUT there are very few places that I am willing to wait long for the food. This is one of them. 

On a Sunday night around 9:15pm, I waited 45 minutes to eat so I already had high expectations for the food since this is more than the average amount of time I am willing to wait for the food. 

I had the tori paitan. I was surprised to hear that they don't have the tonkatsu ramen yet. Should I dock them a star for not having that ready yet? Uh, no. The soup for tori paitan is VERY rich. To the point where it's almost like a gravy. So drink sparingly if you can't handle the richness. I'm used to having tonkatsu ramen hakata style, so while tonkatsu is rich, it's less thick than this variation of tori paitan. So basically I am saying the tori paitan was a bit too rich and thick for my liking. 

But why am I giving this place 5 stars even though I think the broth is too rich and thick? Because it was freaking tasty and the ingredients are fantastic. The ramen goes for $16 which is on the higher end but the ingredients are high quality so you get what you pay for. For those people who gripe over the price probably are those who like bang for buck over quality...not my type of food philosophy. If you want the best ramen in SF and willing to pay on the higher side for it then this is your place. The lines will be long because everyone else wants in on this greatness. Come when you have the time to spare. I certainly don't have much time to spare so I probably won't be coming more than once a month or every other month. But I will look forward to it when I do.
author: Kai C.

description:
I give this place 3.5 stars ( yelp does not have .5s) Long wait! 30-40 mins. Overpriced for what it is. I used to go to Katanaya which had more variety at a better price. 
It is too creamy and rich. Reminded me of Thai curry. 
The meat was good, I asked for extra meat.
author: Francisco S.

description:
I get it. They're new. Grand opening jitters from some staff along with confusion about how to use certain equipment. They most likely didn't anticipate the high flux of people since anything and everything is going on in the Bay Area this weekend. (SB50). That line was HUGE. I don't blame the people waiting in that line for being upset for how slow it was going. Hopefully they adjust and step up their speed in the coming days.

The bay area is full of foodie snobs everywhere that LIVE for ramen shops. If you've had ramen in San Mateo you know what I mean.

That being said, it was pretty damn delicious. Broth....good....ramen....good....meat....GOOD! The staff was incredibly friendly and professional.

We were lucky enough to be the first table making it a very fun experience. I'll definitely make my way back when they mature a little more and add the spicy menu. 

Chef Tomoharu Shono is the Ra-MAN!
author: Jeff M.

description:
If you haven't lived in San Francisco you'll probably make the assumption that there are a lot of great ramen places there - it's a major city after all. Sadly the locals will disappoint you immediately by dissuading you of this myth and telling you to trek south to the far remote lands of San Mateo and San Jose to seek what you crave. If you're like me and the thought of ever leaving downtown is off the table you've just kind of accepted that you'll never have ramen quite as good as you would in Tokyo or even Los Angeles.

And then, Mensho Tokyo opened its doors. Since that day it's been really clear that the inhabitants of San Francisco are suffering from a severe ramen shortage because the lines to eat at this tiny place haven't let up. Part of the reason is that there are only around twenty spots to eat in this place but still, I would have expected the demand to let up a bit after a few months; your best bet is to show up around 4:30pm before the restaurant opens if you want to be seated in less than an hour.

There is good reason for the demand: the ramen is unquestionably the best in the city. The Tori Paitan has one of the most flavorful broths I've ever tasted and every sip is like having pure concentrated chicken. The Vegan Tantanmen is shockingly savory and meat-like for a dish that is meat-free - I know some of you are likely skeptical of this one but I guarantee you will not be disappointed and go out on a limb here.

I would say that despite how good everything I've eaten here has been I still wouldn't put it up there with my favorite ramens. For truly satisfying comfort food ecstasy you're still going to have to heed the advice of your local friends and travel south on the peninsula to the likes of Ramen Dojo and Santouka.
author: Matt M.

description: Probably one of the best ramen places I've ever been, the Shio Ramen is amazing. BUT be sure to get the DOUBLE CHASHU trust me, the meat is soft and melts in your mouth, would even recommend adding more chashu from the menu.
author: David Jonathan T.

description:
Up before trying this restaurant, my all time favorite was Totto Ramen in NYC, and after trying Mensho, my favorite is... still Totto Ramen. Still, Mensho Tokyo deserves the 2nd spot on my Ramen list together with Dojo Ramen in San Mateo.

We came on a Sunday night at 7:30 and only got a table at 8:30 pm, so the wait was that bad. What's more, we had to split into 2 groups (we had 6 people in our group). 

As for the food, I had the Tori Taipan double Chashu, I liked the kale and the broth the most. I don't remember having any ramen with kale. the green onion and the bamboo shoots were also pretty good. The broth was thick, nutty, but not greasy, I could keep eating the broth without getting tired of it even though it was quite fat, which made me kinda surprised. The duck chashu tasted like ham to me, and the pork chashu was not very special. .I still prefer the broiled chashu like at Totto or Dojo.

Anyways, still a good eat. The price was a little expensive comparing to other ramen places though ($20.77 incld. tax)

TIPS: Come after 9pm, the line was significantly shorter after 9pm.
author: Tung D.

description:
2 stars for creamy soup
1 star for green tea
2 stars for oyster
2 stars for service

-1 star for long queue
-1 star for no boiling egg 

5 stars in total

Quick tip: only order Tori Paitan when you're extremely hungry (you're hungry for sure after 1+ hour waiting), cause it is heavily creamy.
author: Dingding Sherry W.

description:
The line seems to be very long on the weekends but weekday evenings are a lot better. I only had to wait for 20 minutes. The menu is small and features almost exclusively ramen - which is a good thing. They have writing on the wall that informs you about the history of ramen. I was amazed that the service was fast but not in an intrusive way.

The broth was a bit sour but very rich. The pork was extremely tender and melts in your mouth. The noodles were thick and short. The ramen here is definitely better than other SF ramen establishments that I have been to.
author: James S.

description: The best vegan ramen I have had!  Well worth the wait.  It was a great experience all around. Found a parking spot right in front of the restaurant, waited only 30-40 mins in line (we were expecting much longer) and the ramen did not dissappoint.
author: James E.

description:
Let's get this out of the way:

This place is good. Not wait 3 hours in line good. At ~$18 dollars a bowl, this place is a bit steep for ramen. The noodles are a little bit thicker than usual and the broth is much creamier. Cha-shu melts in your mouth and the flavoring is there. 

Luckily, I got there 30 minutes before opening and still managed to get in on the first seating. I would say this place is definitely worth trying, but be weary of the waits and the pricing.
author: Andrew C.

description:
Came here with a friend on Wednesday night around 6:30pm. Waited in line for about 30 minutes. Heard it was worth the hype. Well not so much. We got seated amongst some "who was in line first" confusion. The place is shared tables, thank goodnees we got seated next to some cool kids. Anywho, we order the vegan ramen. So not what the Yelper hype stated. We were both bummed. The noodles were more udon thick, the broth was unventful, and it was a whole cream mess of nothing. We also got the oyster appetizer, just some salty unflavorful waste of money, food and time in my belly ;p Also, our server barely spoke english, so that was a fail, and I had to ask her three times to bring my tea I ordered, or get more water to wash down the salty mess of a bowl I eat. 

Bottom line Yelpers. Don't bother, you aren't missing out, it is all hype. Go to Izakaya Sozai or somewhere else cool that has been in the SF woods for a bit and has earned it's ramen cred. I promise you, you will thank me.
author: Sonia A.

description:
I went to Mensho Tokyo at 6:15 and was seated around 8:00. Yes, the line was long, but the real question: was it worth it?

I ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen with extra Chashu. The broth was everything I wanted it to be: thick, creamy, fully seasoned, with a hearty feel. The pork chashu was amazing, and did not disappoint to melt in my mouth. The duck was a little less memorable, but still really nice. 

If I had extra time to devote to standing in line every day, I would definitely be a regular! This place is a great addition to the neighborhood, and I love having a remarkable ramen shop right up the street!
author: Sarah B.

description:
I came here because I've been looking for a good ramen place in the city & my friend recommended me Mensho. And let me tell you guys, this place is the real deal. I came here on a Wednesday night and I waited maybe 5 minutes before getting seated. The place is super super small, but still comfortable. The service was decent. 

My boyfriend & I both got the tori paitan and it was so good! The broth was extremely creamy and thick and the noodles were cooked to perfection. The pork and duck chasu were delicious and everything about the dish had a great flavor balance. 

They also do an automatic 15% gratuity/service charge just fyi.

All in all, I would definitely come back here again! Looking forward to trying other dishes on their menu :-)
author: Lina T.

description:
Best ramen in SF!

We tried our luck on Saturday to see if the hype was legit. Be warned: the restaurant only seats 28 people at a time and the line gets BANANAS. The wait for people end of the line at 5 pm (opening time) was about 2 hours. It was twice as long by the time we left. The host mentioned that 10 or 10:30pm was a good time to come if you didn't mind waiting until after the regular dinner rush.

Be aware that they are not currently serving Tonkotsu Ramen or White Truffle Shio ramen.

We shared two orders of the oysters in shoyu dare oil. They were good but nothing to really write home about. Definitely don't get them if you're planning on getting the shoyu ramen (unless you really, really like shoyu) because they taste pretty much the same. 

Our group tried the Tori Paitan, the Shoyu Ramen, and the Shio Ramen. I had the Shoyu and it was super flavorful. The broth was pretty strong on the bonito flavor, so if that's something you dislike you should try the Tori Paitan instead.

The chashu was A+ and practically fell apart when I picked it up. The noodles were excellent as well.

Service could have been better. I understand that they're working out the kinks and that the demand is super crazy, but with only 28 seats and a constant feeling of "we need to turn these tables over quickly" I don't think we should have needed to flag someone down for water and our check.

Overall, the food was pretty great and is definitely bringing the SF Ramen scene in the right direction. I'd love to come back later on when they have a fuller menu.
author: Kelly L.

description:
Definitely the best ramen I've ever had. Their vegan ramen is surprisingly good even for a meat eater like me. I even get the pork on the side of the vegan to take advantage of the amazing broth. 

The other favorite of mine is the maze soba. It's a dry noddle and it's amazing

I go almost every week since it's close by.
author: Jimmy W.

description:
I came here at 3:50pm on a Saturday to secure a first seating seat. People start showing up after 4pm, so the line increased rapidly after that. They open right at 5pm and you're greeted by Abram, who is super welcoming, nice and willing to answer all questions you may have.

They make the most of the small space so there are three communal tables and four seats at the bar. Supposedly, there's 28 seats total but I didn't bother to count -- I was too excited. 

The menu is also posted on the wall. It's currently a tease of things to come since there are only 4 items listed as of Saturday. The chef is coming back this week (2/29/16) and they plan on putting more items on the menu. 

We got the one appetizer listed on the menu - oysters in dare oil. Beware, it doesn't taste like an oyster. It's this creamy and rich oyster that tastes borderline like monkfish liver. It was surprisingly yummy. 

I ordered the Tori Paitan, double chashu. From the yelp reviews I read prior, I expected the creamy, slightly heavy, rich broth. It's definitely something I haven't had before. There's a lot of hype around this bowl of ramen and it's justified. It was delicious. The noodles were spot on; the chashu was incredible -- melt in your mouth. Order double, no question about it. 

The only reason this doesn't get 5 stars in my book is that my flavor profile gears towards a thinner broth, which is why I'll be back once there are additional items on the menu. I can't wait! I can imagine that with the different broths, this will be a spot I will highly recommend. 

You have to come to this spot expecting two things 1) a wait and 2) the price tag. I understand both and still will gladly return. There are just some things that just are worth my money and this is one of them. And to everyone saying, you could make this at home with a package of top ramen -- you're delusional.
author: Jeannie L.

description:
I really wanna give this place a bad review and make people stop going, so I can skip the long wait at their door.

This place ain't gonna be a typical ramen shop that you may find near the bay, the ramen is close to a traditional Japanese ramen.

You should be there before they open, like 4:30 is a good time to be there, and sometimes that even won't make you in the top 3. If you be there at 5, expect at least half an hour wait. By 5:30, it is going to be at least 1.5 hour wait.

The place didn't even have a sign outside, and the address on Yelp is wrong(672 is the right one.) Inside is pretty small that only have around 30 settings. Interior is good, lets get to the food.

Tori Paitan Ramen has a full body and very dense broth. Very flavorful, every sip is a surprise, and it won't get me bored. Some people might found it a bit too oily or creamy, but I think it is thick yet not too much. The ramen noodle itself is one of the best noodle I had in the Bay. All other ingredients are pretty good. The Shoyu broth is very good, too. It is saltier than the Tori Paitan, which it should be. I have not yet tried the shio base yet, will try it next time.

over all very good, service may not be the best because they are not very good at English, but I am very happy with my visit.
author: Zack Y.

description:
Liked: Quality of ramen I ordered and service overall was exceptional
Not so much: Smaller space, so expect to wait in line for a little bit, somewhat on a higher price side. 
PS: Though I had to wait in line, the time went fast, so I didn't regret. I would come again
author: Eugene D.

description:
Really great ramen that's worth the wait. I had the double ume ship ramen which had lighter flatter noodles then the Tori paitan. Noodles were cooked to perfection I don't think you'll go wrong with whatever ramen. I tried my friend's Tori paitan and it was super delicious as well with the creamiest taken broth I've ever had. Next time I think I'll try the maze spicy ramen because I love spice. This place doesn't do any Togo, even with leftovers, so keep that in mind! 

Waiting experience: Went there yesterday with my group of 8 people. I started lining up at 4 and my group formed by 4:30. We were asked for orders while in line and were promptly seated at 5. So yes, about an hour wait, but it was with friends so I didn't mind much. I really love the little baskets they provide underneath the tables, great for storing your things. Although, the chairs were high and wobbly which made me a bit concerned. Atmosphere was overall very nice. Place is very cramped though, if you don't like dining so close with strangers this place may not be for you. It's also an extremely busy and tiny restaurant so they expect you to leave right after. My whole group left by 5:30. All in all, I really enjoyed the food and experience.
author: Thao T.

description:
Mensho has taken my stomach by storm and edged itself very securely into my top 3 favorite ramen restaurants in the Bay Area. I had no idea what to expect walking in and was blown away by the ramen I experienced in Mensho. 

I ordered the tori paitan ramen, easily one of the most unique bowls of ramen I've had in years. It's a chicken-based broth so thick that it almost tastes like gravy. The deliciously soft pieces of pork chashu are complimented by pieces of duck chasu (you have to order these on top of your ramen), both of which basically melt in your mouth. Within this concoction of broth and chashu sits strands upon strands of the most delicious noodles in San Francisco. 

I've always considered good ramen to be art in food form. Sometimes it looks beautiful, sometimes it tastes beautiful, and in rare situations it's both. Mensho is such a case. The way the chasu floats in the rich broth is gorgeous but the way everything tastes is even better. Everything has a different consistency here that tastes just right, from the melt-in-your-mouth chasu to the gravy-thick broth to the sturdy noodles. I had a great time eating here.
author: Philip W.

description: Long line, but super high quality ramen...don't think I've had it this good outside of Japan. Not good if you want to hang out and socialize with friends as the long line outside the window makes you want to speed it up for others to enjoy
author: Travis M.

description: Ahhhh....such wonderful flavors, depth of umami flavor and aroma.  Wow.    Long lines but so worth it.  Truly differentiated flavors, above the pack, even compared to other authentic Japanese ramen places.
author: Stan G.

description: The best vegan ramen in the city in my opinion. The wait in the cold was about an hour, but it was worth it! All of it. The broth was extremely flavorful, creamy, and satiating. Their service is also pretty quick, efficient and hence the line (which is always long, weekday/weekend) moves at a pretty decent rate. Highly recommended and I will definitely come here again and again!!
author: Puja I.

description: Of course I have had ramen before but wow this was delicious. Honestly worth the wait. My cousin and I got there at 4:25 and we were the 15th and 16th person in line. We were seated and they got to us right away. We didn't have to wait long for our food thankfully. When it came out, my mouth started watering and the smell was delicious. You know food is good when you eat it fast. I happened to finish the Tori Paitan in under 10 minutes. That is how good it was. I highly recommend this place.
author: Allyson L.

description: Really good ramen only regret was not getting the 'vegan tantanmen'. Since it was my first time I decided to go with the 'tori  paitan ramen'. It was really good don't get me wrong but once I tried the vegan ramen I was disappointed in myself for not going with my gut instinct. The vegan one had a spice to it that just pulled together the ramen. Thank goodness my sister was nice enough to share :)
author: Stephanie A.

description:
Got here around 4:30pm on a weekday, so I just had to wait for them to open, but there was already a line when I got there. This small ramen joint only seats 24, so wait times can obviously get long. I opted to get their fancy tori paitan for my first visit, juuuust in case I decided it would also be my last. The broth was SUPER rich, almost thick enough for what you would expect to find with tsukemen. The tori paitan comes with pork and duck chashu, both of which were really good - but I have to admit the duck threw me off. It was kind of weird to have it in my ramen, even if it was super tasty. Where I think Mensho really shines are their noodles - they were thick, chewy, and al dente - SO GOOD. I'm coming back purely based on how much I liked their noodles, but I'll definitely opt for one of the lighter broths (which are a more reasonable $9-$12 range). They also don't have their full menu up yet, so I'd love to see what else is on offer.

Service was really nice, friendly, and quick. We all slurped up our noodles and we were in and outta there in 35 mins. Def ranks in my top 5 ramen places in the city.
author: Lily C.

description:
Arriving one hour early to be ahead of the line, we had pretty high expectations going into the restaurant. My friends ordered the Tori Paitan ramen while I ordered the Organic Shoyu Ramen. 

The Tori Paitan seemed like it was a thicker and creamier broth compared to the Organic Shoyu but had very good noodles. 

The Organic Shoyu Ramen had a much lighter taste but still retaining the taste of shoyu that other restaurants. I recommend this for those that like lighter tastes or are in a mood for something not too creamy. The chashu was very tasteful and would be considered one of the better chashu that I've had. The noodles however for the Organic Shoyu Ramen was the flatter noodles which I don't like as much as the normal ramen noodles. 

Overall, despite the lack of egg, I was plenty pleased with the Organic Shoyu Ramen but I would be more pleased if I could have the other noodles with it.
author: Howard J.

description:
I had dinner here last night with a friend. Came around 9:40 PM and was seated at about 10:25 PM. I heard the wait is longer if you come around dinner time so we opted for a later time. We ordered the one that everyone else on Yelp ordered and recommended which was the Tori Paitan. 

Wow, that was literally the best bowl of ramen I have ever had. Up until now I wasn't such a huge fan of ramen because none really stuck out to me. They all pretty much tasted the same to me to be quite honest. 

The broth was probably my favorite part, it was creamy, thick, and loaded with tons of flavor. I think the noodles resembled garlic noodles but that's just my opinion. Pretty much everything in that bowl of ramen was delicious and all gone at the end. We devoured that bowl.

This new ramen addition in SF is worth the hype and the wait!
author: Dara S.

description:
In my humble opinion this is the best ramen I've had in SF.  As far as overall experience it's pretty cut and dry there. You pretty much go there for one thing and one thing only, slurp down a delicious bowl of ramen. I stress it is a delicious bowl. I am admitted Ramen Shop (Oakland) disciple and most of what I know of ramen I learned from my experiences there. Mensho is an extension of everything I've learned when it comes to ramen from Japan. The broth was rich and flavorful as one would expect. The prices are higher than your standard bowl of ramen but this is not your standard bowl of ramen. The nori, chasu, and in my case duck complimented the noodles and broth with perfect harmony. 

The room is bright and open but the seating can feel a little tightly packed at times. Not really great for larger groups so keep that in mind. The food comes out quick and fast. Service is pretty much no frills and ready to turn the place over for the next guest. Though it doesn't feel rushed. We were allowed to sit and chat for a bit before we made our way to our next spot. Don't go by the ramen advertised on the wall. The menu is what you need to go by. All in all it was a great meal and worth the wait.
author: Joco F.

description: Came here on a Friday evening at around 8pm knowing full well that there would be a line. I usually never wait in line to eat a restaurant and to be honest, really wanted to bounce after 30 minutes but my friend was adamant on eating here. Anyways, we waited for exactly 1 hour before being seated. The restaurant is tiny and must seat around ~20 people. I had the spicy lamb chasu ramen ($18) and it was really good - the soup was super thick and rich and the lamb and chasu melts in your mouth. I can understand the hype but wouldn't wait an hour in line again for a bowl of noodles.
author: Valerie L.

description: My husband took me here for my pre birthday dinner. He knows I need to have my soups . We stayed at the Canterbury, so we were walking distance from here!! The broths are so flavorful ! They have a lighter version with is still flavorful but not as rich....Noodles are perfectly made. My husband had the vegetarian ramen and his broth was still very flavorful!! Although it was a tad spicy for him .... So you might wana let them know...the lychee sake was light and freshing!!
author: Cici L.

description:
Lined up at 5:15pm on a Friday and waited about 2 hours. Tried the tori paitan, vegan tantan, and shio ramens -- LOVED ALL OF THEM. You really can't go wrong with any of these. Going in, I definitely had my usual pessimistic doubts about the place. Mensho is truly worth the wait though! 

+ Tori Paitan - Richest broth of them all. This was my top pick at the start. Got through half the bowl and just couldn't do it anymore.
+ Vegan tantan - Upon first taste, was a bit sweet but a lovely complexity and spice/heat comes out as you eat it. A bit of a creamy peanut-y taste. I would probably get this over the tori paitan next time.
+ Shio - The true favorite. A true broth rather than a creamy soup, it was rich in flavor profile. I could finish this whole bowl by myself, unlike with the other two.

Duck 'chashu' in ramen is new to me... but ended up being a good thing as I love duck and it is served at a perfect medium rare! Noodles are nicely chewy and pick up the soup perfectly. Noodles are flatter in the shio.
author: Jennifer M.

description:
I was initially hesitant looking at the line outside the restaurant and their prices. Paying $18 for a bowl of vegetarian ramen is pricey even for San Francisco. Decided to bite the bullet and stood in line for 30 mins or so with a friend. looking inside from the window, there were 3 long tables with 6-8 people on each table. that explained the long lines. Finally our turn came and we sat in our seats. As soon as we sat, the lady came and asked if we were ready to order. We just sat down. we politely told her no but in 2 seconds another Lady came to take our order. seeing the trend, we went ahead and ordered our food and lychee sake for our drink (amazing)!

the ramen came out pretty fast and what came out looked like a work of art. I have uploaded a picture and I had to try really hard to hold myself from eating it already. The vegan ramen promises nutty flavor and boy is the broth Nuttily awesome. Never had edammame in ramen but it works. It is an experience! My only complaints will be the uncomfortable seats and making the customer feel rushed to finish their meal by keep coming and glancing at us. But would definitely visit again  soon! one of the best bowls of ramen I've had in a long long time!
author: Prashray D.

description:
Just AMAZING!! I've heard a lot about this place so it was time to give it a shot! A really good Ramen. I went there with my friends. A pretty long line,  maybe 20 min at 10:30PM, my friend told me that's usually longer!! 

From outside we could see that the place was very crowded, but pretty small too. Cool. After 20min we ordered our Ramen a Tori Paitan and an Organic Short with an extra pork, OMG it was just delicious! Our waiting just paid off, the taste, the meat, well everything was great.

How about the place? Maybe too small, noisy, with only 1 restrooms. Otherwise, the service was great, the servers really polite. $14, yeah that's a good deal!
author: Lino M.

description:
Arrived at 5PM on a Saturday and waited 50m for a table for 2.

+ The chicken paitan broth is delicious. Suuuuper creamy soup but not overwhelming
+ Noodles are perfect. Great texture and chew
~ Chashu is solid, but you're really here for the soup and noodles
+ The vegan tantanmen was also great. Very nutty, rich broth and excellent balance of flavors.
author: Dustin H.

description: Love the tori paitan ramen. Broth was so creamy and yummy! Worth the 20-30 min wait. Food came out really quick and service was great too!
author: Shay B.

description:
The hype is real. Seriously the best ramen I've had in the bay area. I loved their tori paitan - really rich and flavorful, perfect for all tonkatsu lovers like me. The chashu was soooo good and practically melts in your mouth. Order the DOUBLE portion!!

Lines were long, as expected. I definitely wouldn't wait over an hour. It was also pricy for a bowl of ramen ($16-18), but worth it. Definitely can't wait to come back!
author: Vivian H.

description:
Ah, the long awaited Mensho... literally.

If you haven't heard already, Mensho is the new ramen shop in the Tenderloin where you'll always see a long line of people. Luckily, my friend waited in line for ~40 minutes so I ended up only waiting around 15 minutes. 

Mensho ramen is really unique. The broth is creamy and its ramen in general is on the heavy side. The pork is super fatty and they use duck to top the ramen. 

Overall, really good, but keep in mind the ramen is really rich. Maybe a little too rich in my opinion. Be sure to come at off peak hours to have a reasonable wait!
author: Janet H.

description:
HOLY SHIT WAS THIS PLACE DEELISH. 

Tori Paitan Ramen was oh so rich rich rich rich rich RIIIICHHH and creamy. That broth was pretty close to a chowder! And the noodles had the nicest thick texture along with it. MMMmm. The duck chashu was definitely a nice, flavor changing bonus! I enjoyed that addition into the ramen very much, and usually, I'm not a big fan of duck! 

Little sister got the Shoyu Ramen. It comes with a different textured noodle - a flatter styled noodle. And heol, definitely complimented the clean, soothing broth it was served with. 

GODDAMMNN. How did this place perfect both the fatty, rich tonkotsu broth ANNNND clean, clearer broths?! I could eat either of them all daaay loooong.

Setup was supah hip and rad. There's a bar-ish seating and like two long high, communal tables. They play clubbing-esque/edm music inside. Haha, threw me off for a second.

Overall, the hype lived up to my standards. Definitely worth that one hour wait.
author: Kim N.

description:
I've gone back here twice since my first time.

I got the soy sauce-based (shoyu) broth once, which was disappointing. Lacked any sort of a real flavor profile and was far too salty. They forgot some toppings (the duck) and the noodles tasted off. They were flatter and definitely did not have the same mouth-feel. The waitress assured me that all of their noodles are the same, but we could see a difference. Maybe they used noodles that had gotten a little crushed for my bowl?

I most recently revisited their famous tori taipan. This time, it was much nicer. The broth was creamy and flavorful without being overwhelming. That ramen was some of the best that I've had in a long time.

The inconsistency of the restaurant is troubling. My most recent experience was definitely five star worthy. Is this a trend of improvement? I hope so.

Still waiting for them to get eggs.
author: Yan F.

description:
Kinda harsh to give it 2 stars just on taste alone, but it's what i'd give the place considering the long wait, and the let down after believing the hype.

If you're Japanese or have had really authentic ramen in Japan, this place might disappoint. 

The ingredients are very unique, and the broth is nice and powerful, but i think they try too hard to make it a one of a kind experience. Just saying it was just a little too fancy and too complicated for my taste. It might be good for some, but not for those who believe authentic simplicity is best for a dish like ramen.

We had the tonkotsu and the abura soba (soupless ramen), and both were a challenge for us to finish....
author: K Y.

description:
Each time come here, I taste the heaven. Place is tiny,  but whoever did the interior design of the restaurant is the megamind. It doesnt feel so tight, even though entire restaurant size is no more than 1 bedroom. Service is always good, fast, and efficient.
Ok now, most importantly the food is awesome. We always get oyster appetizer. Although its tiny mini bunny size of dish, u ll definitely enjoy it. My all time favorite is vegan (soup?ramen?) Bowl and add slice of chasu. Soup is thick but flavorful,  noodle is prepared amazingly. 
Beware one thing, they do have long waiting.
author: Stacy U.

description:
When I arrived at the restaurant (9.30 on a Friday night), the line was pretty long so I was kind of skeptical if it was worth the wait. Surprisingly, the wait was only 30 minutes and I only had to wait 10 minutes for the food. The overview of the food:

Tori Paitan - the broth was very good the first few bites but the broth became too overwhelming and creamy for my taste (I don't favor creamy food so if you enjoy creamy food then you would probably like this). The chashu pork was delicious, though!

Vegan Tantanmen - despite the consensus, I prefer this one over the Tori Paitan. The broth was a little spicy but it wasn't too creamy. For those who think that the Tori Paitan might be too creamy should try this one! It kind of reminds me of a Thai dish called Kao Soi (which is also delicious). 

Oysters - this is not your typical oyster in a shell which I expected but turns out to be oyster dipped in shoyu. The taste wasn't bad but I was hoping for something else.

The overall experience was good. I would definitely come again if I didn't have to wait in line.
author: Whan T.

description: I'm sorry. Everyone throwing down 5 stars have not had the pleasure of experiencing Totto, Ippudo, or even Marufuku. This is okay ramen, at best. For the price point and portions, it's just mediocre. If you take away the handmade noodles, it's a two-star joint at best, and those two stars would be for their stellar service and system. Otherwise, the hour-long wait for this ramen is not deserved. Maybe it was too hyped up to begin with, the overpowering bamboo quantity and flavor just overwhelmed any sense of the ramen itself. The broth was a hearty chicken stock, but you could only taste the bamboo after the initial. The ramen itself is the perfect amount of springiness, but the kale is for decoration, and the tori paitan (duck breast and pork) could be anything because of the overwhelming flavor of the bamboo. While the quality of the meat was solid, and the texture was tender, $18 for a bowl of this was not worth the wait. Nice touch with the burdock, but I can't slurp another bowl of bamboo-flavored noodles.
author: Danny C.

description:
One of the best ramen places in the city! After having recently moved from the east coast to SF, it was hard to find an abundance of good ramen here, but I'm so glad I found this place. We came here late on a Sunday night, around 9pm, but had to wait at least an hour to get seats, so be prepared to spend some time here. They usually close when the broth runs out. 

We got two items here: 

Tori paitan: 5/5. Dangerously rich and delicious, with every bit of that melt-in-your-mouth flavor 
Organic shoyu: 4/5. Highly enjoyable also, but just not as good as the tori paitan, and I thought it was a little too salty 

Can't wait to come again. This is definitely a place I'd revisit and even bring people to.
author: Anna C.

description:
Amazingly frothy and creamy tori paitan (chicken bone broth). Duck chasu that tastes like it was marinated in something sweet and citrusy. Crispy burdock root. Extra large soup spoons. 

All these things make me respect Mensho as a ramen shop that has perfected their craft. 

Note that this style of ramen does not currently include soft-boiled egg...but everything else was perfection.
author: Audrey L.

description:
My wife and I landed in SF late last night, craving for some delicious ramen. We found Mensho to be the only thing open at the time. There was a little line outside, but only took like 20 mins to get through it. It's a pretty small restaurant and can only fit like 20 ppl at the max? We were sat down at the table nearest to the kitchen, so we're able to see the cooks working their magic.

As we were ordering the ramen they said they ran out of the 2 that we had just selected...sad panda...so we went with the Shio and Vegan Tantanmen. We also ordered the enoki chips for apps and some sake. GUYS...the enoki chips were sooo good. I'm a huge fan of mushrooms so when I saw these were fried up? That's a must for me. Dip it in the spices that they give you and what a treat. I wish I could talk to you about the Sake, but unfortunately the waitress never brought it to us. The service here was pretty bad (idk if it's because it was later in the night) as we had to ask them for utensils and no one came to refill our water. 

The waitress brought the ramen and we finally got to eat after a long flight from DC. First of all when I saw the Tantanmen, it looked like noodles in peanut butter broth haha. If you order it you'll know what I'm talking about, but nonetheless it was pretty good. The noodles were cooked great, but something was lacking in the bowl itself. Some bean sprouts or some crunch of something. We ordered some chili sauce to put into our ramen too, as we're both spicy food lovers! The big disappointment was the Shio ramen. It just wasn't anything special. I feel like I could've went to the Korean market and picked up a pack of Shin ramen and it would've easily satisfied as well as this bowl did. It didn't have any veggies ( you can order veggies to be added) and it was just so....plain. I guess I'm use to having some veggies in there or some other stuff in there besides the couple piieces of meat, noodles, and broth.

Overall...just a meh meal. Hope to try other ramen spots while in SF.
author: Richard C.

description:
The hype for this ramen shop right now is extremely real. The best friend and I decided we had to come to see if it was really THAT good. We waited an hour and a half just to be seated. And although the host was very friendly all of the waitresses made me feel as though I was doing a disservice to them by requesting water or the bill.

I ordered the tori paitan ramen and my bestie ordered the shoyu. It was actually quite comical as I ended up enjoying hers more so we switched. But the tori paitan was ridiculously rich and the "soup" was definitely more of a gravy than an actual soup. I couldn't take a few bites without feeling completely overwhelmed by fat and salt. The shoyu was much lighter although still just as salty. It did however have an amazing mushroom / umami flavor that I was willing to drink a few glasses of water to enjoy. The noodles in the shoyu were more of an egg type noodle than the ramen I am used to. The tori however had more traditional noodles.

Although I did not care for the broths I do feel that the meats included in the two ramens were perfectly, delicately cooked and very delicious. I've never had duck chashu and I was pleasantly surprised to say the least. The regular pork chashu was also thinly sliced and amazingly tender. They both just melt in your mouth.

The bits of kale and seaweed unfortunately did not help enough to combat the overwhelming fat that lingers on your palate which is ultimately what led to my 3 stars.  I honestly feel like this ramen was not to type to be enjoyed on a continuous basis. The flavors were great for that of a tasting menu, but for a full bowl of ramen it was much too salty and heavy to enjoy for more than a few bites. Overall I could not get over the overwhelming soup bases which clouded my ability to really enjoy this ramen.
author: Megan W.

description: waited til everyone in the city left for christmas to brave the line - showed up at 4:55 and i grabbed the second to last seat at the bar. ordered the spicy ground lamb ramen and ate every last noodle, and every last drop of soup. im sold. wouldn't wait 3 hours for a bowl, but definitely scheming as to when i can come back.  good job, mensho!
author: Christina L.

description:
finally went to check out mensho last tuesday for dinner. 45 minute wait around 7pm, which personally i think is still a tad bit too long to wait for food. but turned out to be worth the wait. after all, there aren't too many impressive ramen shops in sf, so figured i had to get around to trying this at some point.

i ordered the spicy lamb miso (single chashu) -- the broth was very heavy and thick with flavor. it was extremely filling to eat, despite the deceptively small appearance of the bowl. i can honestly say i've never had another bowl of ramen even remotely similar to this, and i've tried my fair share of miso-based ramens across both coasts. my favorite part was how al dente the noodles were. mensho does a much better job than most at preventing the existence of soggy noodles. the chashu was also nice and fatty -- mmm just the way it should be.

we also got the oysters in oil which i didn't end up liking. the texture and consistency reminded me too much of intestines but with the flavor of liver. my bf loved it though, so maybe it's a hit or miss thing depending on your taste preferences.
author: Yiwen S.

description:
This is an authentic Japanese ramen house - as in this is the first US location of this Japanese restaurant. We were told by many to go as soon as it opened to avoid waiting forever, so we made sure we were there right at opening time at 5:30pm. This allowed us to get in the first wave of seating - now, don't think you're going to have an intimate meal as you are literally sitting next to strangers. Ramen was great but what wasn't great was waiting over an hour for our food.  Pretty sure they forgot our order while continually talking to the Japanese couple next to us (who happened to be the first to get their food). I'm all for connecting like that, but don't ignore your other paying customers please. We didn't even get our food until the NEXT couple seated next to us had ordered and gotten THEIR food. 

Since these reviews encompass all aspects of a visit, I have to consider that. Hope it doesn't happen to you!
author: Ling X.

description: Mensho was recommended to me by a friend as the best ramen in SF, but I was also warned about how heavy the paitan broth is. I ended up getting the paitan anyway, since it seems the most unique to this shop and my server recommended it, and because I tend to prefer heavy broths anyway. But actually, it really was extremely extremely heavy and creamy. Not so much that I would say I regret ordering it, because it was pretty delicious (also the slices of meat were heavenly, love that they had both pork + duck!), but next time I'd probably opt for another kind of ramen. However, it's weird that they don't have soft-boiled egg as a topping! And also while the ramen was really good, I wouldn't wait an hour for it. It's absolutely crazy that my friend and I went at 10pm on a Sunday night and there was still a line! Luckily not a long one, so we only waited for 5 minutes, but still.
author: Christine Y.

description: Finally made it here and I didn't wait very long. Broth was thick, frothy (which was odd) and very flavorable. The noodles were thick and slightly chewy. The perfect consistency. But the best was the duck chasu. So tender and delicious. The only disappointment was the soy egg was too underdone and slightly cold. Overall really good ramen. Not sure I'd wait and hour for it. Much better than Ipuddo but not as good as Orenchi in Santa Clara. Would definitely come back.
author: Deborah H.

description:
2 hours of waiting and one trip all the way to Chinatown for boba and back later, our party of 3 finally got seated at the communal table they had. If you don't mind eating alone, come alone and you definitely won't have to wait as long. We had so much time in line looking at the menu, I already knew what I wanted - Tori Paitan with double meat! I was so excited when I got my bowl of ramen! I always think that if others are willing to wait in line that long as well, it must be pretty damn good. I dug in and the noodles were good. I like to let them soak in the broth so that they get a little softer. The broth is made with chicken and it was thick and creamy - perfect for a cold day. All the toppings were good as well. The pork chashu was tender and delicious and the duck chashu was melting in my mouth. So good!
 
Overall, was it worth the 2 hour wait and $18 bowl of ramen? I think you should definitely try it at least once, but it's pretty pricey (even though the quality is really good) and I'd only go back if the line was shorter.
author: Sophia Y.

description:
I came here on a Friday, and I was lucky because I only had to wait 20 minutes for a table for 2. I'm happy with is. This restaurant is very large, so if you want to eat to long lines outside. I looked over the menu, but they only have a few dishes true to say that their food is quality, tasty and people are willing to pay to eat them. 
I ate ramen here and they are very good because they create them by the finest raw materials
author: Kevin S.

description:
Going to assert that this is best ramen place in the city. 

Wait time on a Friday night at 8:30PM-- 1 hr 15 minutes to seating. 

Food: I got the Tori Paitan, which was ultra rich. I believe the broth is chicken based. Pork chashu melts in your mouth like butter. The sliced duck is also a savory spin on things. Also, I because Mensho is an international entity, they try to 'theme' ingredients based on the city. Guess what SF's is? You may have/will notice the kale in the soup. 

My buddy got the organic shoyu ramen, and let me tell you, it was as if I instantly transported to a dark alleyway ramen shop in Osaka, only frequented by the locals and salarymen. The subtle katsuobushi flavoring reminded me of the fresh bonito flakes sourced from the local booths of the Nishiki farmer's market straight from Kyoto.  

I heard they also import local Japanese craft beer but I didn't have a chance to try that. 

Service: Great service, can't complain. 

Final prognosis? This place is bomb. If you eat here PLEASE do your fellow patrons a service and clear out shortly after finishing your meal :)
author: Justin S.

description:
Note: 4 stars rather than 3 (3.5) because for what it is, it deserves 4. For my personal taste, it's a 3.5.

Food:

TORI PAITAN. Pricey $16. This seems to be one of their #1 dishes. I've never had it thus did not expect it to be so thick. 
- Soup. To me it was as thick as tsukemen (dipping noodles) which I believe is not meant to be consumed like soup. After 1/3 of the bowl, I had to call it quits... too heavy. For those who love that heavy creamy texture, I could see it being 4+ stars.
- Noodles. These were fantastic. Slightly al-dente and chewy. The way I think it should be.
- Additives. The meat served in the bowl included duck and pork, both delicious and good proportioning of fat. Plus some veggies but no egg :(

SHOYU. Less pricey but not by that much $14. This I would come back for. I however can only speak for the soup; I only tasted my friend's order. The broth was delicious and as my friend put it "has complex layers of flavors". My only issue is that the soup had a thick layer of grease sitting on top of the soup; I'm sure this can be easily remedied by the kitchen prior to serving. Otherwise, fantastic! Same or very similar meats and toppings as above.

TSUKEMEN. These dipping noodles were on the menu but have not come to their kitchen yet. Apparently the founder/head chef is still in Japan and will return in a couple weeks to teach the chefs how to make. I will have to come back to try.

Other:
- Friendly staff. Host is very helpful explaining each dish if asked or with identifying ingredients for those with allergies.
- Waited close to 2hrs (lined up at 4:50pm on a Friday). Note that restaurant only opened a couple months ago so people are still hyped about it. If you're eating on your own, you'll be seated sooner. The host walked by 3x asking if there were any parties of one.
- Food comes out within a reasonable time after ordering.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
We got super lucky last Thursday- we waited 20 mins for a table for 2; we arrived at 5.25p.

The tori paitan is amazing- super creamy and thick, flavorful broth. The noodles are thick and al dente, just the way I love it. The duck charsiu is to die for/ tender and full of flavor.

I didn't want my bowl of ramen to end.
