Would come back here again if the line was just 20 mins
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
Loved it!  Luckily waited only 10 min tonight to get in.  1-2 hour wait may make me hangry and would result in a lower star rating.  But that would be for any where. 
Karai Chasyu Mazesoba was incredible. Thick shanghai style noodles as their soba. Perfectly done egg topping.  Accompanied by a flavorful combination of bamboo, pork, habanero peppers, seaweed, green onions, and fresh garlic. 

My wife ordered the Chasyu Ramen. Tried a little, was really clean and well done. 

My only con is that the bowls are a bit on the pricy end.   $16-$19 a bowl.  Depends on what extra toppings you add.
author: Chase F.

description:
Thanks for my bestie for taking me here. It has been a while since I've hung out in SF and I felt a bit out of the foodie scene. This place is relatively new and can only fit 25 people commune style with three large tables. The design is quite nice with high stools and a little basket at our feet to hold your purse/jackets. The ladies that work here is really efficient although it appears they do not have enough menus for all 25 people at one time. 

The ramen noodles were definitely different from what I am used to. My Tori Paitan had a really thick fatty broth (not sure if I would get this again due to fatty broth) with thick noodles that look like hand made noodles. Very good. This fed me but if you can eat then this would not be enough. 

My friend ordered the organic ramen with extra chasu. Hers looked like Chinese thick egg noodle soup. She enjoyed it. 

I definitely would like to come back and try their other ramen.
author: Sarah C.

description:
I am a vegetarian ramen fiend.  I seek it out in every major city I visit, trying 2 or so restaurants even on a short trip.

Momofuku Noodle in New York is superb.  Totto Ramen was my first favorite.  Others (shall remain unmentioned) were decent.

Mensho Tantanmen blows all of them away. Veeg-Umami is my new memory of it.  The texture of the bamboo shoots (menma) is crucial to the experience.

Vegetarians like me don't often have meat-eaters gawking at my food -- three diners noticed how rich the broth in mine was.  If only they could have tasted it.
author: Mark O.

description:
You know you and your friends are addicted to ramen when they send you messages about a new place opening up!

Just to note, I would say it's more like a 3.5 star for me. 

A lot of people must have known about the opening since the lines were super long. I went on the Wednesday after the weekend opening. I know you expect lines for food in San Francisco but this is first time I've waited this long for a ramen place in the city. Expect to wait 1.5 hours for the dinner rush. I do hear that the lines die down around 10pm (it closes at 12).

As for the food, my friends and I all ordered the Tori Paitan which was a rich creamy chicken broth with pork chasiu and duck. The broth is very heavy and flavorful. I like the flavor but I felt that it was a too salty for my preferences. The noodles were a perfect texture and the meat was delicious. The burdock added a contrast in texture as well as the kale, but I could do without these two. 

The Tori Paitan is a little more expensive for ramen at $16. I'm interested in trying the other ramen dishes and perhaps going for a less creamy broth. However, I don't feel that it's worth it to wait nearly 90 minutes for it.
author: Jonathan C.

description:
Things you can do while you wait for a seat at Mensho Tokyo:
- Tailgate: The people behind us may or may not have been brown bagging. We were told that there have been people who will break out six packs cause they DGAF.
- Get yur hur did: leave a designated wait person and get a haircut from across the street. Trust me, you have enough time.
- Meditate: You probably won't do this, but I'm not going to lie, my hangryness was taking over my body real quick. If every crevice of SF wasn't covered in piss, I'd be sitting in a corner collecting myself.

So we arrived at about 5:15 on a Sunday and had to wait for a good 2 hours before we were able to enter the door. Abram was really nice and thanked us for waiting. We shared an oyster appetizer, SO ordered the Shoyu Ramen, I ordered the Tori Paitan.

The oysters were nice but forgettable. I wouldn't order them again. The Tori Paitan ramen on the other hand, was delicious. The chashu and duck melted in your mouth, the noodles were perfect, and the broth was so very rich and creamy. Sadly, the Shoyu Ramen was too salty. Each bite was followed by a gulp of water.

I can't wait for the rest of the menu to come, we'll definitely be back. I want to try the Vegan Tantanmen. OH, just a suggestion, if you want to get in quick, come alone, there were some lucky ducks who got to skip the line for that.
author: Jenny Y.

description: Long wait, but worth it , the ramen reminded me of the flavors texture of being in Tokyo ramen restaurant. Service is fast and attentive. Not a place to dine and sit and talk. Order enjoy your ramen pay and leave . Reminiscent of the ramen shops in Tokyo subways . Great ramen worth the wait !
author: Warren Y.

description:
I don't know why it has taken me so long to write this review, but I can assure you the experience and taste of the ramen left a lasting impression on my palate (1 month and counting).
A friend and I read about this spot and HAD to give it a go. We arrived at 9:30 and had ordered around 10:20. Definitely not bad considering other reviews of up to 2 hour wait times. We both ordered the single Tori Paitan $18, which is the most popular here. Took a taste of that broth and DIED! I never really understood the concept of umami until that hit my taste buds. It is an indescribable taste that comes in a thicker than normal broth and the most perfectly cooked noodles. The broth tastes almost oily/fatty and buttery at the same time, but the taste you get is just insane. I didn't care much for the chashu, but they were excellently cooked. 
Currently saving up my quarters for my next visit because that broth is something I need again. It's addicting I promise you. 

***Communal Tables Only***
- This isn't the type of place where you can sit and gossip about your friend and her new boyfriend after you finish your ramen. People are hungry and waiting to taste this ramen so please, GET IN AND GET OUT.
author: Brie R.

description:
I was fortunate enough to be seated at the inaugural table (of 6) during the grand opening. The other patrons were a blast to be around - we agreed that it was strange to have only 6 seated until the food arrived but it was thrilling to be part of the exhibit. This is the nature of grand openings so I imagine Mensho will have it sussed out very soon. 

I opted for the tori paitan ramen with two slices of chashu. The handmade noodles were stellar with the appropriate texture and chewiness. The noodles perfectly absorbed the rich and balanced broth. I would have been able to finish it had I not camped out for happy hour at the friendly Resolute next door. My objectivity for this review is compromised because I had a relaxing time lined up an hour and a half before opening. In my mind, it was guaranteed to be a great experience.

Abram was a delightful host. His enthusiasm and engagement with the crowd were appropriately uplifting for the public opening. Chef Shono's spirits were high and he personally delivered my bowl with a smile and a handshake. I'll never forget the connection when he reciprocated my emphatic thumbs up through the kitchen window. 

Miscellany:
- The beer selection is stellar. the Suntory malt and the Sansho may not have been the best standalone beers but they paired so well with the tori paitan. It was nice to see a change in roster for the typical ramen house beverages.
- They use Square payment and were able to quickly rectify an erroneous bill.
- The music selection was hilariously comforting. It was what seemed to be a wedding covers playlist during the first hour - including hits like a diluted acoustic version of Peter Cetera's "Glory of Love"
- There's a clipboard. The sequence of names was honored for at least the first 6 people (mild gloating). 

The per bowl pricing is higher than average but it was worth it to be part of the spectacle. Cheers to Mensho! I'll be back.
author: Joseph V.

description: Came here for the first time at 5:30 on a Sunday, the line was too long and it was raining so didn't bother to wait. That same week on Tuesday, me and my friends wanted to try again and this time the line was short around 6:45. For a table of 6, we got in thirty to forty minutes after we arrived and were immediately given our drinks and had our orders taken. I got the Clam Butter Ramen since I love seafood. It turned out to be so amazing that I almost teared up a little... best ramen I've had in SF. The noodles are perfect in texture, the clams, oysters, and scallops were super soft and delicious, and the broth was to die for. Definitely will come again!!
author: Mika T.

description: Love the space, not to big not to small. It's  modern and classic. The ramen is tasty, broth is creamy and rich, I feel little bit salty. But over all is good ! Thumbs up!
author: Faye L.

description: Best ramen in sf. There's only three communal tables and a small bar for seating so expect a wait to be seated at most times of the day. This means don't come starving and be forced to watch people eat their yummy ramen through the window just begging them to get up. And don't be that jerk taking their time long after your meal is finished either! Probably not the best idea to come here on the weekend or with large groups if you can avoid it! Also no take out or to-go boxes for leftovers. I still think the ramen is worth it despite this (:
author: Brianna N.

description:
Waited about 45 minutes on a Thursday night. There needs to be a sign or something about vacating your seat once you're done. The only reason the wait is so long is because people love to sit and chit chat after eating despite being 3 feet away from the window where everyone is waiting. No i'm not saying you can't have a relaxed dining experience but be aware of other patrons who are standing outside. A group of 5 kept dawdling for about 30 minutes after the waitress put the check down and everyone in line was just WTF.

Anyways, the food was great. The broths are flavorful and noodles are cooked just right. Bowls look small but they are deceiving. My friend and I ordered three bowls between the 2 of us and we were stuffed beyond the brim.
author: edward k.

description:
Have to be mentally prepared to wait. Lined up at 5:30 on a Tues for 5 ppl and got seated 2 hrs later.

Ordered the tori paitan. First bite was heaven. Best ramen in SF imo. But because of the creamy broth, it does get pretty heavy by the end. The shoyu/shio ones are probably lighter. Noodle's thick and cooked really well.
author: Dana C.

description:
There comes a time in a cats life where as much as he wants to avoid the "in" restaurants of the world, he cant help but give in to try something new with some friends. That is what happened to me, in my journey over to Mensho Tokyo.

Mensho Tokyo is a little place on geary that I learned has a very high reputation. Due to this, diners line up long before the place opens to try to get a seat. With the restaurant opening at 5, I was surprised to see customers already forming a line at 4:15! 

Luckily, my group was able to be seated in the first round of diners, and we were greeted warmly and happily. 

Menu here is smaller, but each dish had a high reputation. I decided to go for the Tori Paitan, which sounded delicious and was recommended to me.

We were first served an oyster appetizer which was very flavorful and delicious! Being a cat, I have had lots of oyster before, but this was super special to me.

My ramen arrived and I took the first bites with the broth. This broth is phenomenal. There is so much flavor in it, and it feels so smooth and creamy. The meat cuts were superb and tender, and the noodles were cooked perfectly. I instantly could see why people line up for so long to get a taste of the ramen here, I can honestly say that this ramen is the best I have ever had. 

Service is fast and pleasant, and the intimate and close setting meant that you could get to know those dining with you as well!

Ill definitely try to make it back here one day. Its definitely on the pricier side, but I firmly believe and can say that paw's down, it was worth every penny.

Line up early, and give this place a try!

*chirp!*
author: Jei C.

description: SUCH A LONG WAIT BUT IT WAS WORTH IT. Go and get the ramen with the double chashu pork. It is hands down the best ramen I've ever had (although to be fair, I've never been to Japan).
author: Liz C.

description:
Can't express how conflicted I am writing this review. I want to give it 5 stars, I know it deserves 5 stars, but I can't give it based on my experience. Here's my reason why: 

Be expected to wait a while. The hope of getting inside rests on how close you can see the front of the line, and your fellow food-lovers inside taking their quick, or sweet time devouring their delectable ramen. Parking for me came at an ease, but be sure you take all your valuables and leave nothing exposed. Wait time? 2 hours for me. Granted it was a Saturday night at 6:30 so it was to be expected. Now for the star of the night, which didn't shine as bright as I expected. Tori paitan, rich, creamy, broth paired with perfectly cooked ramen and tender, melt in your mouth chasiu. Sounds perfect right? Unfortunately for me, it didn't pan out that way. You know when you get to the bottom of a carton of OJ that's settled and you get all the pulp (no offense to pulp)? My broth tasted like it's equivalent. It came out extremely frothy and with crystalized salty bits, which made me think it was the very end of a pot. Not entirely sure if this was true, but that's my assumption, esp after tasting another party member's order. Like I said, I want to give it 5 stars, but I can't based off of my experience. 4 stars is still plenty good in my book for ramen though.
author: Ryan C.

description: Best Ramen in SF forever! Had the spicy lamb it was super spicy and tasted. I will back soon, wants try all ramen there!
author: Yu R.

description:
Five of us started lining up 5:40pm on a Friday and got seated exactly two hours later. The ramen shop is tiny, like 20 seats, so we waited a bit longer than smaller parties.

I didn't really mind the wait, it's just not for me. Four of us got the tori paitan (chicken white soup - creamy and rich), and the other friend got shoyu ramen. The broth was very dense, the guys loved it but it was too heavy for me and even slightly upset my stomach for the rest of the night. Veggie toppings (bamboo shoots and greens) were tiny portions, I wish there could be more to balance the heavy broth. Duck chashu was unconventional, but I personally preferred traditional pork chashu.

Overall, the ramen was unique but I wouldn't wait for more than half an hour again. I'd also try other lighter ramen/soba options. Worth trying it, just grab some friends to chat over the wait or go alone for high chance of skipping the line.
author: Jaclyn C.

description:
Creamiest ramen ever. Go later in the day (9pm) on a Sunday and you'll have a short wait. I love the bins at your feet for all your stuff. Very practical. 

There weren't too many ramen options, but they are newly opened and will offer more choices soon. I'll be back for sure.
author: Wayne Y.

description:
Arrived 10pm and there was a line. Luckily the wait was short. 

Be ready to order as soon as your sit down. 

I tried the tori taipan double ramen. 

Broth two thumbs up (it's full of flavor but not overwhelming)
Noodles two thumbs up
Meat. Two thumbs up

Most places leave you dehydrated afterwards. I left throughly satisfied. 

Looking forward to trying other items on their menu.
author: Lyman C.

description:
Delicious!!! Mensho Tokyo is such a delicious stop for ramen. We went on a weekday evening and there was already a line before opening time. We ended up waiting probably 30 mins, so not too bad. It was well worth it! 

The ramen itself - AMAZING! From the flavorful broth, to the noodles texture and consistency, to the toppings, to the cha su meat. Everything just worked. My favorite ramen in the city. 

The service was good - nothing outstanding but nothing to complain about. Our waters were refilled regularly, food came out in a timely manner.
author: Mary N.

description:
Long wait: 1 hour and 20 minutes on a Saturday night.  This restaurant is tiny and does not seat very many people.  We probably would've shaved off 20 minutes of waiting had our party not been a group of 5 and was a group of 2 instead.  Not a good place for large parties.

In terms of the food:

Tori Paitan (Double Chashu--$18):
---The broth was the richest ramen broth I have ever had.  It was very unique in that it tasted like chicken pâté broth.  I literally had chicken pâté the week before at another popular restaurant in SF and the flavor profile was very similar.  It tasted good, but I don't think I could eat it on a regular basis.  There were two types of chashu in the dish, pork and duck.  I have never had duck chashu before, but it was very tender and succulent and did not taste fatty or oily compared to Chinese roast duck.  The accoutrements with the food were pretty decent with the bamboo shoots, bonito flakes, etc.  The burdock root was a nice surprise with the katsuobushi sauce as it made it taste like there was bacon in the dish almost (or like bacon + brussel sprouts taste).  In terms of the noodles themselves, they were not as firm/springy as I would have liked, and it seemed as though I got all really short/cut up noodles and not the long strands of noodles where you can "slurp" the noodles as a sign of respect that you like the dish.  This could have just been my particular bowl as I noticed others in my party had longer noodles.

Overall, worth a try, I probably wouldn't wait another hour for the bowl if I was really craving ramen as there are other places to get my ramen fix, but a solid choice/restaurant to visit.
author: Lawrence E.

description: It's not worth the 2 hour wait. I've had better Ramen with less wait time. The wait time is ridiculous. I went because I saw so many good reviews about how good it is, but it's nothing special. I had the Matcha ramen and I don't recommend it, smells and tastes bad.
author: Jaylou V.

description: Omg the best ramen ever. I was walking past and saw this line and got curious. I waited 30 mins and sat down. So delicious... I hear the wait can be much longer though
author: Zaineb D.

description:
We came here at 4:45pm and got seat at 5pm immediately. 
We got chicken paitan and shoyu ramen which both are tasty. 
We noticed that the seats are high stool and little uncomfortable. Also they had strict seating assignments and we had to obey. At the end of our meal they had totaled service tip which was 15% which just surprised us is all. Overall it's tasty ramen when you need eat quickly and go. However if you really want to enjoy your meal at your leisure, go NoJo ramen!
author: Misha O.

description: I have tried most ramen places in the Bay and I have to say this is the BEST!! Pork and duck so tender it falls apart; you do not even need to bite. Very flavorful and rich broths. Try the habanero side if you like spicy!
author: Andrea R.

description:
Best ramen I have had in SF, no question. The broth is just incredible, definitely worth it.

Hopefully they open another location or start allowing take out because the wait time is quite long.
author: Justin J.

description:
This was amazingly good! We got there before they opened and made it into the first seating. (The second seating was about an hour later.) Its a small place, but worth the wait.

The spicy lamb ramen was awesome and rich and not too spicy. The miso egg was my favorite, the shoyu egg was good too. The creamy chicken ramen was also great. We didn't try any of the clear broth ramens.

I'm not really a ramen connoisseur, but I don't know that I've ever had a better bowl of ramen anywhere. The Ramen Shop in Rockridge is close but not quite there.
author: L B.

description: Handmade noodles with good texture. Felt miso soup was a bit too thick. Server required each patron to get their own, so no plate splitting allowed. Small interior with decor akin to something a non-Japanese may mistake as authentic Japanese. Not sure how the pepper and salt fit in either, and the TV with Japanese girls eating ramen felt a bit hipster lame. Definitely sure about one thing - decent ramen not worth an hour or more wait... and no egg ;(
author: Kimberly H.

description: Absolutely loved this place! Just a warning you do wait in line for about 45 minutes before you get seated (so don't go too hungry). Once your seated, service is fast and friendly. I got the vegan ramen and the lychee sake! Delicious!! I was visiting from Philadelphia and will definitely come back here the next time I visit San Fran.
author: Evie B.

description: Been here twice, once shortly after opening and again this past week. Latest trip was much better in terms of wait time and ramen choices. I prefer Shoyu and liked this version (added habanero, fried garlic, extra kale). BF loves spicy thick ramen and the spicy lamb was amazing. It was almost curry-like with the spices used on the ground lamb. Our fave ramen places remain in Manhattan but this place is solid!
author: Whitney S.

description: HOOOOLLLYYYYYY mother of God. Help me, Jesus. The broth of the tori paitan was creamy AF. Definitely not my cup of tea. It was less of a broth and more of a creamy, grainy gravy sauce. It reminded me of eating the foam that forms at the top of your shabu pot after you've cooked so much meat in it. However, I will say that both the noodles and the chasu were good. But when it comes ramen, the broth is everything for me. Not worth the wait in line or the hype. Hard pass.
author: Kristina D.

description:
Finally had a chance to check out what the hype was about and the verdict was - yes, totally worth the wait!

Wait time: 2 hrs on a Friday night (arrived at 6:05pm, got in at 8)

Space: Roughly 24 seats. Easier to get seated right away if you go by yourself or as a couple than parties of 3+. They let my friend and I come in before two large groups ahead of us.

What we ordered:

Tori Paitan double chashu ramen, $16 + $2 for the chashu [http://bit.ly/1VsPPBt]
Rich, creamy chicken soup, pork chashu, duck chashu, menma (condiment made from dried bamboo shoots), kale, etc.
---The server gave me the option of single or double chashu, but **ORDER DOUBLE CHASHU!!!!**  ...trust me one won't be enough!! All my friends who made the mistake of ordering just one walked out the door day dreaming about that other chashu... Also, about the broth, as many Yelpers say here, it is definitely on the thicker side but has a flavorful and creamy twist. Noodles were chewy and perfectly cooked.

Vegan Tantanmen, $18 [http://bit.ly/22xt7tY]
Vegetable soup with konbu and mushrooms, Japanese soy cream, sesame, cilantro, chili oil, green onion, menma, etc.
---My friend ordered this one but I was able to try some of the broth and noodles. The broth was very creamy as well - think tonkotsu without meat. It's sprinkled with seven kinds of nuts and a bit spicy because of the chili oil. 

Bill ended up to be $39.15 sans tip.

No doubt, if you're craving authentic ramen from Japan, you cannot go wrong with this one!
author: Jasmin H.

description:
I love Mensho, Everything about it, except the line!
Best Ramen in western hemisphere!
author: Kevin H.

description:
This place is extremely unprofessional and I'll let you know why in a second. Came here in August 2016 if it matters. Honestly, the ramen was decent but absurdly overpriced. $18 for basic ramen that was average at best. Ramen places in Southern California offer more at a simple $10 a bowl. 

To preface, I usually always tip. A tip is to be earned and that's usually pretty easy if you provide basic manners etc etc. I rarely do not tip and when I don't it is because I really feel that the service was not up to standard.

What really ruined the experience was the fact that I chose not to tip because I felt the service was subpar(had to ask for ice water multiple times and they were acting rude). They then charged my card for a generous tip when I specifically wrote no tip on the receipt.

No matter how you stand on the social norm of tipping employees.. no business has the right to charge you for more money than the goods and services they provided. No business or restaurant is entitled to a tip. 

Incredibly unprofessional and I urge people not to come here on that principle alone.
author: Jordan W.

description: Good ramen with a thick soup base.  We waited almost 2 hours to line up and get seated, not sure that I would do it again (in the fog and cold!).  The bowl looked really small, though we were both full after eating our noodles (no appetizers).  Would be better if the line ups were not as long!!!
author: Carolyn L.

description:
Ramen is oh so good.

I was so excited to finally try this place! I came here with 3 other friends on a Saturday night at 4:30 and we were able to get seated the first round.

I'm definitely not vegan but I ordered the vegan tantanmen and  honestly, you wouldn't be able to tell it's vegan! The broth is so rich and creamy, but doesn't leave you feeling heavy or greasy. It has so much depth of flavor and a good spicy kick. Also the nuts added a nice texture and crunch. The ramen noodles are thicker than your typical ramen noodle, but are perfectly al dente. 

Overall, the waits are long and the prices are pretty steep for ramen, but worth it once in a while for their unique and delicious ramen.
author: Karissa Y.

description:
Small restaurant on the border of downtown SF and tenderloin. I wouldn't recommend coming here with anymore more than 4 people; 2 is best. Their signature ramen, the tori paitan is excellent.; Very rich and flavorful broth with thicker textured noodles. The chasu melts in your mouth, but was quite a small piece. The Shio ramen was ok. The broth was good, but this noodle was flat and smooth, similar to egg noodles. 

The wait was one hour long on a Sat night. I'd say worth it to try once.
author: Ali F.

description:
The place is definitely over hyped, and the Ramen is just slightly above average.

We got there at 9:15 and only waited for 25 minutes.  I ordered the Tori Paitan, which had a thick and rich but still tasted one dimensional as though it lacked umami or salt.  

The service was good in that they were very attentive and took care of the line well.

Conclusion: I wouldn't come back.  The price, overhype, and lack of flavor wasn't worth the experience
author: Craig V.

description:
Honestly one of the best ramen spots I've been to.
The broth: so flavorful!  
The noodles:on point
And the chashu was literally falling off my chopsticks because it was so soft and tender! 
Not only was the ramen amazing, but the service was very good also!
Definitely worth standing in the long line!
author: Isabella A.

description: Came here on a rainy weeknight and didn't have to wait too long to grab a seat. Ordered the Tori Paitan and was really impressed. The soup broth is really rich, like "thick creamy" rich. Plus the chashu and duck is a really tasty addition. The noodles are spot on too, you can tell their fresh and have a light texture to them. Not going to lie, it's probably one of the priciest bowl of ramen I've ordered and don't know if I would pay that much again for the same bowl. If you're in the area and have never been, it's worth a try!
author: Nick C.

description:
My wife and I came here for the first time due to the great review and hype. We came on a Friday afternoon around 4:45pm. They open at 5pm. There was a line outside already. We were able to get in the first group of people getting a seat. It's a tiny restaurant with about 30 seats. Seating was a bit crowded and you would be sitting right next to a stranger. Here's how we rated our experience. We ordered Tori Paitan and Vegan Ramen.

(5 = best.    1 = worst). 

Restaurant setting: 4. 
Service: 4. 
Time duration from order to getting the food: 3. 
Tastiness of Ramen: 2. 
Portion of Ramen: 3. 
Price: 2 ($$$). 
Overall experience: 3. 

After we ate, we felt thirsty. So I guess the broth might have MSG in it. Of course, everyone's taste buds are different. Give it a try and you will know whether or not you like it yourself.
author: Jonathan X.

description: The hype is real! The ramen is made to perfection with chewy noodles and broth that is not overly oily and salty. The only downside is the wait. We arrived ten minutes before opening and there was already a line of 20 people. Go early and make sure you bring something to do!
author: Eunice Y.

description: The waiting time varies so try and make it before it opens. Otherwise, the wait can be up to 45min, but is always worth it! Shio Ramen with duck is amazing!
author: Nestor C.

description: Awesome noodles and ramen! Although there is only one vegetarian/vegan option, it's a really good dish. The portion is perfect and very satisfying. There is usually a line out the door and down the block, but don't let this discourage you! They have a great system that keeps it moving fast and effective. The service was excellent, and people at the shared tables were mostly friendly. Should definitely be on your list if you're ever in the mood for authentic ramen.
author: Eimanne Z.

description: Mensho Tokyo takes ramen to another level. If you get there at 4 pm and wait you can probably make it in the first wave of diners. I got the shio broth which had excellent kombudashi flavor, with two slices of pork. Wish there was an option to add an egg. The noodles were chewy and the best part. Tried some of their chicken paitan ramen but their broth was too rich and creamy that it was almost like tsukumen sauce. The duck chashu was pretty amazing. Like the flavor of the vegan broth ramen. Overall high quality ramen but higher priced than your average ramen place.
author: Ellin C.

description:
I've been hearing all this hype about Mensho from a few friends so decided to check it out. Come early because the wait is pretty long. Waited a little over an hour for a party of 5. 

What we ordered:

Appetizer: Oysters in shoyu dare oil

This reminded me of the Chinese canned dace you would have for breakfast with congee. Texture and saltiness were about the same. Would've never guessed it was oysters. 

The Ramen:

When I arrived at Mensho, I saw signs everywhere that said Tsukemen. I was extremely happy and anxious because not a lot of places serves it. I've been on a search of Tsukemen for quite awhile after my trip to Tokyo in 2011. We I saw their menu, no Tsukemen . It's plastered everywhere on their wall but no go. So I opted for their Tori Paitan double order of chashu. 

Interesting take on ramen. Their broth is extremely thick and one note. Noodles were cooked perfectly and had the right amount of chewiness and texture. Duck chashu was pretty good but their pork chashu was the highlight of the dish. 

Overall, nothing impressive about their ramen. I'm just glad it wasn't bland. Their shoyu ramen may be the better option.
author: Vince L.

description: Best ramen in the city. I've spent time in Japan and this place actually tastes like it whenever I'm longing to go back. They also have rotating special ramen dishes which are unorthodox but always creative and delicious. Worth the wait especially on a chilly day.
author: Amber L.

description:
4.5 stars

Tori Paitan Ramen $18 - perfect broth, duck was good. My noodles were a lil too al dente. 

Organic Ramen $16 - a bit on the salty side, noodles were a tiny bit flatter but more cooked than the Tori.

Sapporo beer $4.75

Portion size is good. Overall it was good, authentic. Service is excellent. 

Had about 20-25 people in front of us, was about 45 min wait. Friday night (10:30ish).
author: T H.

description:
I finally get to try this place after hearing all the good reviews about this place! I came with the BFF on a Friday around 5:40ish and the line was getting longer by the minute. They do NOT do to-gos nor do they have to-go boxes! 

We were seated around 6:15ish at one of their community tables. If you are looking for a romantic date night followed by 1hr+ conversations--this is NOT the place for that. People come and go rather quickly and you are most likely going to be seated ACROSS from the other person in a big tall table along with 8 other people. I already knew what I wanted once we sat down. We went for the Tori Paitan ramen w/ double cha siu. The fat of the duck meat just melts in your mouth! And the big metal spoon is given so you can drink all the broth! YUM YUM YUM. Best ramen in my book so far! I want to come back and try their tonkatsu next time!
author: Alice Z.

description: Standing in line is worth it for this ramen. Perfectly cooked, delicious broth, and add-ons to customize it to your taste. No take out containers provided as they are purists about their ramen consumption experience, but for good reason. Eating ramen is hard to do for a vegetarian, but the vegan tantanmen does not disappoint. Creamy, spicy, and served at an amazingly perfect temperature, this broth was everything. The noodles were also perfectly cooked - just a little al dente and very flavorful. Worth the wait and a gem of a find for vegetarians looking for ramen!
author: Vina C.

description: Ramen was excellent, the small area with limited seating was not. We got there within 10 minutes of opening, and ended up waiting for an hour to get seated. If you like your privacy while eating, you also won't like the possibility of sharing a table with multiple parties. Other than that, the ramen was authentic and filling, perfect for a cold windy night in the city.
author: Alvin B.

description: We came here on a Friday night and left work early just to try to get here by opening, but damn line was still kind of long even when we went early.  We waited for about a good 30 minutes or so and it wasn't too bad.  Got in and ordered some beer and some noodles and it was actually pretty pricey, 2 beers and 2 noodles and it was about $80. but it was so good!! and different so I actually didn't really mind the price!!! definitely will be back :)
author: Ben Z.

description: Got there about 30 minutes before the place opened and we were seated promptly. So if you want to get seated promptly, GET THERE EARLY! I got the shoyu ramen and that did take a bit longer to come out since I guess the orders were all coming out in batches for a specific dish, I understand that. The wait was worth it! The noodles were amazing and the broth was unlike anything else I had before, it was very flavorful and full of taste. The chashu was very tender and melts in your mouth. This place was definitely worth it!
author: Anthony K.

description:
Be prepared for a long wait. We reached there at 10pm and it was half hour to get in.
Has only two benchs and I really wasn't sure if I will like it or what I should order. 
I ordered the creamy lamb soup. Sorry, can't remember the Japanese name. Was delicious. Will some day come and eat the exact same thing.
Portions are huge. The men finished their meals and I was only able to eat 1/4 of the portion.
If you are skeptical, don't be. You will LOVE it!
author: Saima P.

description: Very good and I don't like ramen. One of the best ramens I've had and I have the spicy one.
author: Nick J.

description:
Long story short: Not worth the hype/ wait
I love trying new ramen places and was super excited to try this place out while I was in SF.
Waited 30 min+ at 8:30pm, which was the minimum wait time for this establishment. I Tried the Tori Paitain ramen. The rich broth and tangy noodles were interesting enough, but the toppings were far from a traditional japanese ramen. I'm not a great fan of duck but they only had duck chashu. Not so many choices as they only offer few apps and ramens offered. Seating is uncomfortable as space is limited. Cool place to try out, but I wouldn't go again even there wasn't a line.
author: Loe Y.

description:
As the reviews have mentioned, it's a small place with no reservations so it can take a long time to get a table.  Luckily for us, we arrived at a good time and only waited 20 minutes for a table for 4.  But I heard it can take up to 1-2 hours.

The place looks really clean and well maintained.  I ordered the vegan ramen and my friends ordered the pork ramen.  Generally, I have avoided the vegan ramen since it's usually flavorless and doesn't have a good salt/unami ratio.  But at this place, holy heaven, it was amazing!

The vegan ramen has an awesome balance of saltiness and flavor.  It has 7 nuts in it to make sure it has the right amount of sweetness and fat to complement the salt.  As for spice level, it was not spicy for me, but I had the option of getting the hot sauce and add it to the side.  There was some menma (fermented banboo) but I was not a fan of that.  Overall, spicy, salty and the fat perfectly complemented the tantanmen noodles.  I can say this is the best vegan ramen I tasted so far!

My friends who ordered the pork ramen loved it, but did complain that there was a little too much fat in it, but loved the flavor.  

For alcohol, I ordered some sake and they presented different from what I am accustomed.  They gave you the small glass and a wood saucer and filled it with sake until both the glass and saucer was filled.  I didn't complain, more sake for me.  Staff was friendly and food came out pretty fast (less than 10 minutes).  It can be expensive since we spent about $25 per person and only half of us ordered alcohol.

Overall, I highly recommend if you want ramen and have a vegetarian/vegan friend.

Side note not affecting review:  They have two compounds painted high in the wall (see pictures).  As a chemist, I am familiar with some food additives especially Mono-Sodium Glutamate, aka as MSG or Unami flavor, all which is natural in yeast extract.  I first thought that it would be MSG, but actually it's not.  You see, glutamate is a natural amino acid and it is in the "top" part of the compound pictured.  However, there's a bottom part attached to the nitrogen "N-H" that's whole benzene group with an amino group.  I investigated it during dinner (my friends know I would do something like that), and found out that the compound they have pictured is actually N-(4-Aminobenzoyl)-L-glutamic acid which is commonly used as UV absorbing tag for starches (used in analytical chemistry to detect compounds).  I am pretty sure they're not giving us that, so I would recommend to the owner to fix the image since it's just plainly wrong.
The other compound they have featured is Inosinic acid which is a non-canonical nucleotide in RNA but totally natural.  If it were me, I would delete the phosphate part (i.e. the "P=O" part) in the picture, but it's fine.
author: Bryan A.

description: Came in Saturday and had delicious vegan ramen! I've been a ramen addict my whole life and my mind is forever blown. I can't get it off my mind!! It was creamy, nutty and full of so much awesome flavor. Can't wait to have it again. Too bad I live in Oregon..
author: Elex O.

description:
Need more stars. Some places are on a different level.

Turtle Tower and Mensho are by far the best soups in the city. 

Mensho very obviously uses different noodles for its different broths for desired effect. The beers are priced quite well. An ample sake selection, an excellent staff. Duck chashu omg. More more more. 

I heard there may be another location opening, I hope so. I would love to be able to eat here regularly but I do not always have the time for the wait. Its worth waiting. 

The best part, when you go inside here it smells like Japan. They use intensely flavored kombu in the broth and tell you all about it on the walls. No other ramen spot that I have been into in America has smelled like you are in Japan.
author: Peter M.

description: Atmosphere was great. Servers were nice. We made a special trip to this place because of its high rating but were very disappointed. It's over rated to an extreme and half through eating my ramen I found not 1 BUT 2 hairs in the soup. For a restaurant with a Michelin star I had higher exceptions and cleanliness.
author: Hannah B.

description:
Okay, maybe I am not a fan. This place seems To be a bit overrated. 

1. It tasted like any ramen 
2. Broth is light and satisfying, maybe they added less oil? 
3. Place is way too small, I can't even stretch my arm.
4. Expensive for a bowl of ramen

I'll probably give this place another try, for now... naw
author: Yuri Y.

description:
ramen is good, not as good as I expected.
Wait for 60 mins line is okay but please at least let me finish my soup.

we order the 酱油 shoyu ramen and chicken broth ramen.
The broth of shoyu is nice~ 
The chicken one is too thick for me.
Duck and pork Chashu are the best I've ever had. 
Also the spoon is the biggest I ve ever used. 

The space is narrow , 22 sits in two big shared table.

I can take it .
Is it worth the wait?
Umm
author: Yuanren P.

description:
If you don't like needles stop reading and go on with your life; I'm not here to convert nonbelievers and malcontents. This little place gets busy quick like all the best noodle bars with a line forming around 30 minutes before opening. The staff is curt and eager to get you served and out the door to make way for more patrons. There's a cool view into the kitchen if you're the curious type. 
The food, the broth was hot AF, a delicious mouthful of noodles and pork. I expected things to be so so but the bowl was totally satisfying! I can't complain about anything I put in my mouth. $13-$16 for soup is a little high but such is the world of ramen.
author: Tommy W.

description:
Literally the best ramen you'll probably ever have! Very small/intimate place with a modern ambiance. The waiters are extremely attentive as well as helpful. They advised me that their popular ramen may be too thick for most so I always order the vegan. Their homemade noodles and broth was absolutely to die for I'll definitely be back soon.

This spot usually has a line and a waiting time of at least 20-30 minutes. I don't recommend this place for big groups or impatient hungry people.
author: Elisza T.

description: Tried the Shio Chashu Ramen after waiting in line for 30 minutes. I read about the hype so was really excited until I tasted the bowl. Not the most flavorful especially the broth. It was underwheming.
author: B H.

description:
1+ HOUR WAIT?! WTF!!! 

Giving this place 1 star for the overwhelming wait and hype San Franciscans have created and the utterly underwhelming experience at mensho. Is everyone high or brainwashed by the latest trend on social media that I'm not aware of? Oh wait, they're probably all starving by the time they're seated, so anything consumed would automatically be amazing.

The flavor was mediocre for the first 3 broths on the menu. All I could remember was that they were salty and fatty. I'd rather eat bacon for that flavor package. The chashu was plain and I have to pay for an egg! Why?!There was not much complexity in the broth except for the tori, which has a thick rich texture. However, there was really nothing spectacular deserving of a 1+ hour wait here. If you've got nothing better to do than stand in the smelly tenderloin waiting to eat mediocre ramen in your free time, then be my guest.
author: Kim P.

description:
Not my cup of ramen.  

Had Tori Paitan and Spicy Lamb with miso and soy eggs. Both broth was dense, slushy consistency and extremely rich, but lacks acidity balance which pickled vegetables or sprinkling of yuzu would have fixed.  Prefer Tatsu Ya or Kata Robata (both are in Texas), or even Orenchi down in Santa Clara.
author: Pete N.

description: Really felt this place was a letdown. We were lucky and only waited about 10 minutes. If I'd waited over an hour I would have been even more let down.  The tori paitan was way too rich. And I don't know if I've ever said that before about a food. I love strong flavors and rich foods but it was just so thick and flavors so potent . . . and not in a good way. My partner ordered a clear ramen and had the same feeling. First two bites were good but no desire for more after that.
author: Ryan W.

description: Average. The place is way to small. Not worth the hour wait outside in line. Service was just okay, forgot to take our order after us waiting an hour to get inside.
author: Abe R.

description:
The ramen is good... different, but I probably wouldn't return. 

I've been on a search for ramen in SF for a while. I would have to say most place I've been to is a disappointment compared to ramen in LA. Mensho Tokyo, although better than most places I've been in SF, I wasn't impressed. 

Mensho Tokyo is different from other ramen places because they have duck in their ramen. The broth is creamy, really fatty, and flavorful. The noodles were cooked al dente. I thought it was good, but nothing special. Different? Sure. But great? No. It's good if you want to try something different. But I didn't think it was worth the wait or the money.
author: Anny T.

description:
Two bowls of Ramen and one small sake the bill was close to $56 with tip.

Wow!!! That had to be the most expensive Ramen I've ever had. I'm not sure if it's for the location or for the hype, but I couldn't even breathe when I saw the final bill. I suppose I should us scan the menu before hand but I never knew Ramen could be that expensive.
author: Emily L.

description: The place is tiny so expect to wait. The beer was great and the ramen good. I had the soy sauce based more traditional ramen. My friend had the matcha ramen. It was good but disnt remind me of ramen. It seemed too much. All in all a fun place to go.
author: Bla B.

description:
Worth the hype? I think so. A little pricey for ramen ($16), but delicious nonetheless!

I came on a Saturday night at around 10:30 pm and waited roughly 30 minutes (for a group of 4). Two parties behind us in line were able to skip ahead of us because they had smaller parties of 1 or 2! So yes, DO go in small groups! 
 
We all ordered the Tori Paitan. I loved the chasu so much, I wished I got double meat for an extra $2. The meat was perfectly marinated, and it was "fall-apart" tender. The noodles aren't your typical ramen noodles. It's wide and flat with the perfect bounciness. The noodles interact harmoniously with the creamy, grainy broth while capturing the flavors of the broth.  I can see why some may think the broth is too heavy! If you want to change up/balance out the flavors, ask for a side of the chili paste with chili oil. It adds a kick to the ramen and makes it less heavy and salty (in my opinion). 

I would definitely go to Mensho more often if the lines weren't always so long. No ramen is worth waiting 2+ hours for.. lol
author: Fanny H.

description: It's ok. The soup is too creamy and rich, too over. The noodle is too hard. Seats are so limited. People stay long even after they finish, that's why the wait is always so long outside. I personally don't like this style of ramen. Is real Japanese ramen taste like this? Why it's so different? Is it American customized style? Why the soup can be so thick. Idk. Will not go back again.
author: Vivian F.

description:
I dropped by on a rainy Saturday night, missed the first wave, waited 30 minutes for a seat, not so bad. Ordered
- draft beer - good but pricy for the portion
- oyster appetizer - love it!
- tori paitan double with pork and duck - love the noodle; soup is too thick for my taste; pork and duck are okay, nothing specially; not a big fan of the giant metal spoon.
author: Helen L.

description: I have no idea why this store can be michelin. I try two times and why everthing is too salty. I will never try this store again.
author: Yuyan M.

description: I've been wanting to eat at Mensho since they've opened but was deterred by the long lines. I thought I'd try the Mensho in Tokyo but ended up trying other ramen shops there. Finally my partner and I happened to be in the area late on a weeknight and stopped by. There were about 6 people ahead of us in line. We saw a lot of parties finish their meals and leave, but we had to wait for the servers to seat everyone in line at once. They didn't have the tsukemen noodles today. They also don't have the tonkotsu broth yet which is what the shop in Tokyo is known for. I got the tori paitan broth and my partner got the shio one. Noodles are homemade and thicker/fatter than your normal ramen noodles. They were still good and so were both of the broths. I liked the thick, creamy tori paitan broth and was tempted to take it home for later (but resisted). I was worried that the shio (salt) broth would be too salty but it wasn't, it surprisingly had a fish taste that I liked. They said that they do not offer egg with their ramen because it detracts from the flavor.
author: Diana B.

description: The ramen was great! But not worth the hour wait. It's a odd mix inside of genuine ramen and being "hip" as far as the atmosphere inside. The portion servings are quite large. Wouldn't be a great place to go if you're hoping to have private conversations because of the table setup. You're gonna be elbow to elbow with a stranger. But at least you'll have good food.
author: Kelsey W.

description: I thought I wrote my review about this place! I think it's better to go way early or way late to avoid waiting in too long of a line (has the hype died down a little by now? Probably not!). I had the Tori Paitan ramen, and I went in a little overboard ordering double pork (the original amount is just fine). I enjoyed it as it (especially the broth, pork was delicious) was so flavorful, and it was well worth the wait! They have their system down, nice and simple: sit, take your order, eat, go. Two people normally sit across from each other at the long communal table, and if you're by yourself, you might get seated with another person across from you to be space- and time-efficient. I did that once at another place, and we ended up having an ok conversation. So why not? I hope to go back again!
author: Maile N.

description: I had the shio ramen after an hour wait in the rain. It was just okay. The soup was super salty. The noodle was flat which was unexpected. And there's was no egg in the ramen! Disappointed... will not come back
author: Connie C.

description:
I personally think it's way too overrated. I have no concept of having to pay $16 on a bowl of ramen. ( over $20 after tax and tip) It's basically drunken food that you get for like $4-5 in Japan. If you are charging $16-18/bowl, please LEAVE me the F alone for 3 min while I sit down and take a look at the menu, all the Japanese waitresses. So annoying. This is why I don't go to Japanese places like this ever.
I understand it's a fast paced grub and go kinda place but still. When you are paying $20 on a bowl of ramen, I think you deserve more than 5 minutes to decide what the hell you are eating there.  This girl came back 3 times in 5 minutes to get our order. People around us were annoyed too when this one waitress was trying to explain something with bad English, she was just basically telling them to leave because they were still enjoying their soup lol this place is a joke.

 
I am def NOT going back.
author: C M.

description:
Food is 5 star. I ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen. It was delicious and broth is super thick and yummy. 

But, the overall experience is just... tiring and disappointing. I would never come here again. 

Ramen costs $20 a bowl. Which is super expensive. It would be okay if I don't have to stand in line outside waiting for 30-40 minutes to finally be seated. Not only that, after getting seated, the experience gets more and more terrible. The space is really really small and it was super uncomfortable.

The seats are really small and it's very hard to squish in and sit comfortably. I was trapped between the wall and a person beside me. The whole dining experience was simply terrible.

Honestly, if there's more space in the restaurant and I can sit comfortably, I would come back here again despite having to stand outside in the cold. But at its current state, there's no chance that I'd put myself through that experience again.

Try it as a once in a lifetime experience to see what the hype is about. After that, judge for yourself.
author: Erni L.

description:
Chilly and a bit of a wait. They sit you with other strangers, which my date did not like too much as he said they were obnoxious. I was ok with the arrangement.

Veggie ramen with yummy base. Oysters were slick and slipped down quickly. Worth the wait and quality of food was good and hot both on cold day is what we needed.
author: Mary C.

description:
This is the best ramen place in the city! 
I've been to Mensho a total of three times. The first time I waited an hour and a half to get seated and served. It was well worth the wait. 
The broth is so flavorful and creamy with the handmade chewy noodles. It was overall perfect. I will continue coming back and will always recommend this ramen spot.
author: Diane Z.

description: Queued for one full hour for a bowl of ramen, but totally worth it! Good ramen are rare in bay area, but I'm really glad to see decent ramen places like Mensho Tokyo started popping up.
author: Chen P.

description: Decent ramen place in Tenderloin. I'm not sure why this place ranks so high and why there are lines out the door, maybe because it just opened and there aren't many other ramen places around. Not the best ramen. Anyone who really enjoys ramen and has tried many ramen places would not rank this place very high. It's all modern, trendy, and very westernized and unauthentic. Not a great soup base and no egg option? Not enough pork flavor. Portion sizes kinda small.
author: Peter K.

description: If you are a first timer here- try out the tori paitan ramen. It has a creamy broth and the serving is enough for one.
author: Manish K.

description:
I was expecting SO much when I came here. I thought it was going to change my life because of how good the ramen is.
I ordered the organic shio and my friend ordered the Tori Paitan.
The Shio was SO salty, at the end of my meal I had to drink a couple cups of water just to get the saltiness out of my mouth. The noodles were good but it really failed me with the broth.
I tried my friends Tori Paitan, I was better than my Shio. But it also was super salty and I think the creaminess was overpowering. 
Also I was put on the edge in the most uncomfortable chair, 
Will not be coming back, this place is just a hype!!!
author: Ariunaa B.

description: One of the best ramen places I have been to! I had the vegan tantanmen (the vegetarian ramen on the menu). It was very flavorful - the broth was spicy but nice; the cilantro and chili oil were a great touch. The noodles were thicker than usual and was quite filling. We went on a Friday night and there was a 20 minute wait outside but once we were in, service was quick. Seating seemed limited with space for about 16 people (2 tables with 8 chairs each).
author: Roshan H.

description:
I came here for the first time maybe about 2 weeks ago and it was still a pretty long line at around 9PM. However, they seem to always have spots for people who are eating alone so I was lucky enough to come on my own and not have any wait.

I ordered the Tori Paitan Double Chashu ramen with a side of fried enoki mushrooms. Given that this is a Paitan ramen, I knew that the broth was going to be very thick and heavy bordering on a gravy-like consistency. It's not particularly common so I understand how some people might not be particular fans of this style.  

The fried enoki were very crispy and delicious but if you let them sit for a bit, they start to really develop that oily feel in your mouth which is a no-go for me. The ramen was very good. I was a little hesitant when they told me there was kale in it (This kale phenomenon in SF is getting ridiculously out of hand) but it was surprisingly good and didn't have the strong bitter taste of kale. I also think you need to order the double chashu since the meat was extremely tender and good but a double portion felt just right and not too much.

All in all, this was a great experience and I would like to come back but at $18 for a bowl, I think that's just ridiculous. Maybe it's because SF is so expensive but even the Tokyo branch is almost half the price of SF. Given that most other ramen places in this vicinity have yet to come close to what I've had here, it's probably the only place I could recommend for good ramen if you're in the city and want some place that's not too difficult or will take too long to get to.
author: Ray L.

description: My first time here I tried the tori paitan and that was way too salty. But I was determined to give this place another go. The second here, I tried their mazesoba and that... will go on my list of "best things I ever ate".
author: Claire D.

description: I'll admit that I haven't tried all that many ramen spots. That being said, this is by far the best ramen I've ever had. I had the vegan with an egg, added spicy sauce. Delicious!
author: Ryan H.

description: Ok... so I went from 3 stars to 4.5 stars and now to 2 stars. I have been to this place more than 5 times now and though I thought the first ramen I tried here was too thick and fatty, I opted for a vegan one in all my next visits. It was good the first  couple of times and I told everyone about it. I brought my friends with me this time and we all got vegan ramen. It was nothing like I've tried the previous times- too spicy (I handle 5 star spicy), too salty, and lacked flavor. I could only eat because I stayed in line for 1.5hrs and was super hungry. I am not sure if the chef cook changed, but the vegan ramen I tried today was not good to cost $18 and 1.5 he's in line... not cool. I did tell the server about it and all she said was: "I'm sorry, but when I eat vegan ramen it is always spicy like that"... "I'll let the cook know". That's all? She could've offered to make the less spicy one instead? Or maybe a discount for all this hassle waiting in line for something that did not turn out well?! Nothing.
author: Aya J.

description: Aaaaaah! This is the closest I've gotten to REAL Ramen outside of Japan. It's good. Worth an hour wait? Ugh... yes, it is.  Lines suck. And I hate adding to them. But this one I'll gladly do again (I'll bring snacks next time). Tip: the Tori Paitan is way less fishy than the shiyo organic ramen. Paitan all the way.
author: Christina R.

description:
Tori Paintan: Bouncy noodles with tender, tender duck + pork in a rich and creamy broth. Solid bowl of ramen. Add chili oil to this and it would be *slightly* better than the vegan option.

Vegan Tantanmen: Nutty, chili oil deliciousness. Rivals Izakaya Goku's vegan ramen... which is saying a lot.

Since it's so small, I love how they crank you out. Super efficient and great service. Worth noting because of the tight space and quick turn around, not a great date spot.
author: Britt M.

description:
I had the Tori Paitan, which I believe is their signature menu item.  It was quite good!  I've had ramen from a number of top ramen restaurants on the west coast, as well as quite a few authentic ramen shops in Tokyo.  There are many types of ramen, so it's important to frame my review with the kind I prefer, which is hakata ramen, which has very thick broth.  This definitely delivers.  Additionally, it's different, unique, and it's clear they try new things that really work, all while still delivering an authentic taste.  That being said, I don't think it quite lives up to the hype I've heard.  There are many comparable ramen shops.  Come here if you want something that's very good as well as unique, but don't expect it to outclass other top-tier places, either.

One real complaint: I found that the dregs of the broth are a bit gritty, like there is a fine silt which sinks to the bottom.  This makes drinking the remainder impossible to enjoy, something I've never encountered at a ramen shop before.  Ramen aficionados always slurp the broth remaining, right?  You won't want to do that here.
author: Ryan H.

description: This is the one my favorite noodles (ramen), and I enjoy to eat it! and very delicious.
author: Team M S.

description: Go when it rains! I only had to wait 30 minutes for the 3 times I visited. I first tried the Tori Paitan and I was in creamy heaven! I've been to Japan and while of course the ramen is good everywhere there, nothing I tried was mind blowing and this Tori Paitan was mind blowing! I also tried the clam ramen which was very good if you love seafood. It's very rich is clam buttery flavor. And lastly I had the Vegan ramen which was good, but my favorite by far was Tori Paitan with a side of Lamb :)
author: Stacey P.

description: We waited for about 45 minutes, but it is worth every single bit. Officially the best ramen I've had in a long time. A must do if you are ever visiting San Francisco !
author: Andrea S.

description: I got the mushroom chips and the vegan ramen. The mushroom chips were delicious-- perfectly crispy and just the right amount of oil so that they weren't too greasy. However, I was disappointed by the vegan ramen. The broth was very flavorful. It tasted nutty and was grainy. The noodles were thick and quite al dente, which I personally enjoyed because I felt like they weren't soft and soggy like noodles sometimes are in ramen. The ramen was too rich, however, and it gave me a stomach ache right after eating it. We went on a Friday night at about 8:30 PM and the wait was 45min-1 hour. In my opinion, not worth it!
author: Rebecca L.

description: I love this place. It is one of the best ramen experiences I've had. The broth for my ramen was thick and hearty and is what sets their ramen apart. There is often a line--and I complained to my friend about this the first time I visited. It is worth the wait. The staff is friendly and fast. I have no complaints whatsoever.
author: Justin H.

description:
Being Singaporeans and having tried a lot of ramen before, we think that this ramen is unique. The Tori Paitan was thick and creamy. It was a refreshing taste for the first few bites but it got slightly too overwhelming towards the end. The organic shoyu ramen had a fragrant and tasty broth. We bought fried enoki mushrooms that were fried to perfection. 

The most exciting thing of the meal was the Japanese ramune soda. It was sealed with a marble ball and we had to pop the marble out to open the drink. 

Overall, it was a pretty interesting experience but we doubt we could be back again.
author: Rachel T.

description: Hands down best ramen I've ever had. Had some tori paitan with double chashu. Got there around 15 mins before closing, had about 4 groups in front of us and the wait was about 20-30 mins, so no complaints.
author: Ross B.

description: The food was good overall. I would've added some more spicy sauce or something to it or at least have it available on the side. The wait time was pretty long, like 35-40 min. I hated the fact that they add gratuity for every check, I felt like it was a bit unfair. I get that you want to keep your staff happy, but I want to decide whether to give the tips for the service I got or not. If you want to keep workers happy at your restaurant simply pay them more, but don't make me pay for service when you don't know  if I liked it or not. Sitting at the counter I've noticed that you guys slice the duck and the park using the same slicer without even cleaning it. Please do for those who don't eat either of the two meats.
author: Sergey S.

description: Outstanding. The noodles and broths were wonderful but what got me was how much care is taken with all of the ingredients. We also got the  chicken broth one but it was definitely on the thick side.
author: Dustin B.

description:
In town for business and wanted to find something near my hotel. Boy, did I hit the jackpot. It a little pricey but SO worth it. The Vegan Tantanmen has the perfect balance of creaminess and heat with ingredients I don't usually see in ramen. 

If you want a soft drink, the Ramune is fun (you have to pop a marble into the bottle to drink it) but I'd skip it if you're don't like the taste of Juicy Fruit gum. 

There will definitely be a line but it moves faster than you think and the food is worth the wait.
author: Cora A.

description:
+ THE FOOD
Definitely one of the best ramen's I've ever had. I had the shio double chashu ramen and my friend tried the tori paitan ramen. My shio ramen was very flavorful. The broth was amazing, but it got pretty salty near the end of my meal. The pork was so soft and delicious. There was a perfect amount of noodles to satisfy me. My friend also really enjoyed his duck ramen. The pieces of duck are rather small so he suggested getting double meat. The duck ramen's broth is more frothy but it still tastes amazing. 

+ THE SERVICE
Service is friendly and fast! Although you wait at least an hour in line, they serve you really quickly once you order. Everything seems very efficient there, from the way you are seated to how you are served!
author: Cindy C.

description:
My friend and I decided to take advantage of the Warriors game being on and hit up Mensho Tokyo. We figured that with the game being on, the line would at least be slightly shorter than their infamous 1.5+ hour-long lines. Thankfully it was a lovely evening out and we only waited about 35 minutes before we were sat. They run a VERY tight ship; seats are turned incredibly quickly and efficiently. We were sat at the bar, which allowed us to look into the kitchen. The kitchen, along with the dining space, looked incredibly clean and everyone was operating very efficiently. The dining area, although packed quite tight, doesn't feel too crowded, and I thought I had a lot of personal space at the bar. 

Our server was very friendly and helpful when it came to ordering; she actually recommended the Vegan Tantanmen, but said that the Tori Paitan was the most popular item. We ordered one of each, although surprisingly I ended up preferring the vegan ramen. It truly was some of the best ramen I've EVER had (and I've had quite a lot in my lifetime). Everything was perfect, from the al dente noodles, to the level of spice in the broth. There's no way you could tell it's vegan, and the broth had a great earthy, nutty flavor. Even the chopsticks and spoon were fantastic (you'll see what I mean what you go there). The chicken ramen was unlike anything I had tried before - super creamy but also light at the same time. It was such a delicious culinary experience, and while I would not wait over an hour for it, I am SO happy I had the chance to try it. The ramen is so good that perhaps I might even start walking by after work just to see if there happens to be a short line...
author: Regina L.

description: This ramen shop serves novelty ramen. Their flavor and broth are pretty unique. I tried the Tori Paitan and it was delicious. The broth was super creamy and the texture of the noodle was amazing. It came with two types of chashu, pork and duck. I could eat the duck chashu all day every day. A bowl of ramen here is quite pricey but it really fills you up and you leave full and satisfied. If you're looking for traditional ramen though, this might not be your style. Overall, a very unique and enjoyable experience.
author: Catherine T.

description: Well worth the wait. Most delicious ramen ever. The line outside is intimidating but moves fairly quickly.
author: Jimi B.

description:
We went on a Wednesday evening and had to wait about 30 minutes.  When we got inside we were seated at the end of one of the long tables near the door so every time someone entered/exited you could feel a blast of cold air.  I had the shio ramen and was a bit disappointed by it after all of the hype I've heard. To me it was a bit salty and I wasn't able to distinguish it from other ramen that I've had before. 

Overall, I'm not sure the food here justifies the long wait to get seated. If you also need to use the restroom be prepared to wait as there is only one which is shared between the ~30 people in the restaurant (all of whom had had a long wait to get in) and the staff.
author: Mark S.

description:
3.75 stars, haha but I decided to round up to 4.

PARKING: It's street parking so you just have to circle around until you find something.

WAIT: We came on a Sunday night at 5:30 pm and had to wait 1.5 hours.  The line was about 60 people deep. Unfortunately the inside is very small (seats about 28 people or so) and people seem to take a while to eat their ramen so the line moves but isn't that quick.  When you get to the front of the line the waiter takes your order so you get your food quicker, but even then it does take about 7 minutes to get your food.  

ATMOSPHERE: The inside is small with 2 sets of long communal high tables.  If you're with a weird number expect to sit with or close to strangers.  There is also a small counter/bar area that is regular height and seats 4.  If you come here alone they will come out and ask for "party of 1?" so you can take advantage.  Inside is pretty modern with information about their ramen on the walls, a TV that plays ramen videos and modern Japanese music.  The kitchen is open so you can see them making the ramen.

FOOD:

TORI PAITAN - my first time having this kind of ramen.  I was drawn to this place because the pictures made the noodles look really thick and curly - my favorite! When the ramen first came out, it was very frothy on top because they whisk it before serving.  The broth was a bit of a disappointment because it was so thick it was almost like a gravy.  The taste was decent, not quite as tasty as other broths I've had (Orenchi, Tsujita) but pretty "intense."  The noodles were also a disappointment, they looked so good but they fell flat! They weren't chewy.  They had a different color and texture to them than normal ramen noodles like at Tsujita or Orenchi, and they weren't yellow.  This leads me to believe that they have a different type of flour in them that don't give them as much bounce as I was hoping.  They definitely were thick though, which was good.  As for the toppings, the pork was cold and a little gelatin-like.  The actual meat part almost had the same consistency as the fatty parts.  I did enjoy the duck meat though, very flavorful and good.  The kale was interesting but kind of hard to eat.  I did notice that they do not offer an egg, which is interesting.

I'm starting to think that Tsukemen noodles tend to be the chewiest because they are not cooked in soup.  Next time, I would get the Tsukemen.  The problem is that they only have a certain number of bowls.  

Overall, it wasn't worth the 1.5 hour wait in my opinion.  I could definitely see why people would like this ramen because of the unique flavor and noodles but overall, I would rather go to Orenchi Beyond if I was in SF.
author: Brittany T.

description: Staffs are friendly no matter how crazy-busy they are. This would be different from the ramen you can commonly taste--I loved it but my friend didn't. If you are expecting some kind of traditional flavor, this may not the right one for you.
author: Isabella K.

description: Just simply amazing, so good I had two bowls of Ramen!
author: David S.

description: My friend wanted to go to this place for his birthday. We came early before the store is opened.we waitedfor 45-50 min before we were seated. My friends and i ordered few things including tori peitan, spicy ramen, and clear both ramen chicken. I had tori peitan myself with double chascu for 2 dollar extra. The noodle was perfectly cooked. The soup or the broth was very right,but not too oily.  The portion is on medium side- i thought it was just enough to fill my hungry stomach. The meat is on the smaller portion size.
author: Bibi B.

description:
I have to say my bar for Ramen is a bit high since I lived in Japan.
When asked myself, "Is this restaurant worth waiting 1 hour?" Answer is probably not.
author: Yuma K.

description:
I live basically next door to this place. The lines are absurd, everyday on my walk home from work I maneuver my way through a long line of people. So i finally decided to try it. 
After a 30 minute wait in line (not that long seeing as i've noticed when is the best time to go to avoid the line), another 20 for the ramen, i was surprised to find the food to be pretty mediocre. Thick, creamy, and flavorful, but nothing to rave about. Other notes; The service was great. The restaurant is very cramped and is poorly lit. The small space probably works to make this place seem more exclusive to people. The broth lacks flavor.
I'm not saying it was bad, but i definitely wouldn't stand in line again when there is so much food elsewhere in the loin, saigon, etc. Hopefully the hype train will die down and let us walk in peace at least.
author: Ernie B.

description: Ok. I know I'll get some heat for saying this but I'm really not picky about my ramen and almost prefer more simple traditional broths. We waited an hour and 10 mins after we arrived at 5:20.  We both ordered the Tori Paitan. The noodles were thick and unlike any ramen noodles I've had before. The broth was very thick and probably incredibly fatty. The flavors of the ramen were perhaps too advanced for my palette.
author: Jackie G.

description: Super shocked at how they handled our experience. Although the staff was friendly, I did not appreciate paying $40 for ONE bowl of Ramen and a $6 appetizer. We asked the server to help us order, letting him know what we usually get it at other Ramen places. When our food arrived to the table, my fiancé loved his bowl, but mine was lacking in flavor, and I did not enjoy it at all. I tasted my fiancé's ramen and loved his. I pushed mine aside, and my fiancé and I started sharing his bowl. When the server came by and asked if everything was OK, we informed him that I did not like my Ramen. I told him that I enjoyed the texture of the creamy broth, and that the noodles were awesome, but I found it to be lacking in flavor. I made it a point to let him know that I really enjoyed my fiancé's choice, it was spicy, savory, and delicious. As a courtesy they gave us our $6 appetizer for free. Personally, as a manager for a restaurant in a five-star resort on the Las Vegas strip for 5 last years, I feel like this was not the appropriate course of action. To charge us for a $20 bowl of Ramen that I didn't even touch was uncalled for. I left the place upset and still hungry, and that's not how you ever want to guest leaving your establishment. I'm not saying they should have taken the Ramen off of the bill, but they could have offered to take it away and remake it like my fiancé's, or when I mentioned how I liked how spicy his was, they could've offered to bring out some kind of spicy sauce or seasoning. All in all the experience left a bad taste in my mouth, and we will not be returning.
author: Shanell A.

description: a big ol yes to this spot, worth every minute second and penny. what more can i say? someone's grandma definitely made this shit from scratch. fuck wit the lychee sake and fried oyster shrooms. i've yet to try the veggie ramen because i can't get enough of dat spicy paitan.
author: Yves D.

description:
I don't like it. The ramen is different for sure, but different does not mean good. 

$50+ for two people, we left unsatisfied. Japanese IPA for $12.75 and it's flat. Tori Paitan soup base is creamy but too thick and lack umami (in my opinion). We liked the shio ramen with plum paste, but not enough to return. Servers were nice.
author: Michael L.

description:
finally tried the ramen here at 9:30pm on a wednesday and there is always a line.

the tori paitan has such a rich and thick broth but it is very obivous that it was made well because the flavor was not too overly rich or salty. by the end of the bowl though, it was a little too much for me however because it was so thick. i was also very full from the broth the whole night. everything else in the ramen was also made well.

i would definitely come back to try the other flavors.
author: Alex H.

description:
Pretty delicious ramen! Small space but clean and the line wasn't terribly long (Thursday night at like 9pm). 

My boyfriend got the double charsu shio ramen and I got the shoyu ramen! The duck charsu in my ramen was melt-in-your-mouth delicious! The other charsu pieces were well done as well! My broth was a wee bit salty towards the end so I might try another next time-but still tasty!
author: Van N.

description: This was absolutely the best ramen place I've ever been too. However you must be ready to stand in line but it's worth it.
author: Madison G.

description:
Just got back from dinner at Mensho, Day 2 of opening. It was an hour and a half wait arriving in line 30 minutes before opening, which is not surprising given the limited number of seats (around 24 bar seats) and the fan following (people in line raving about the quality of the Japan site).  

Due to the recent opening, there was a limited offering, with the promise of further options in the future, i.e. Tsukemen, soba, others. We had the Tori paitan, which is a creamy chicken broth ramen with pork and duck chashu, along with their draft beer.

The broth was rich, flavorful, umami goodness (despite being fully chicken, no pork), and the noodles were a thicker variety with nice chewiness. The pork and duck chashu were nicely salty, tender, and tasty. I didn't care for the odd texture of the vegetable toppings, and would've preferred something a little more crisp, maybe with something pickled.  The service was friendly and efficient, especially considering they are still early in their rollout.  Once we were seated, we ordered immediately and were served and finished in about 30 minutes. 

The final tally for two ramens, extra chashu, and two draft beers was $56 without tip. Not cheap, but certainly this was a definitely a higher quality ramen.  I would definitely go back in a month or two when they expand their menu and some of the initial excitement dies down.
author: Christine L.

description: Very good Ramen. Small restaurant but open till pretty late. We went at around 9 pm and waited in line for like 20 mins. Nice service.
author: Hannah L.

description:
Mensho has become a obligatory thing now when I visit sf. It really makes every other ramen place you've ever been to seem mediocre. They've mastered hand made ramen noodles, perfect texture and taste, not too chewy not too soft just right. I order the organic shoyu every time the broth is so deeply flavorful I wouldn't want anything else. 

End note: just try this place out you won't be disappointed. Prepare to wait 45 mins especially on the weekend. Their service is super efficient and friendly so 5 stars for that too.
Cheers.
author: Rj S.

description: There's a 45min wait even if you are only one person! There are two seats open on two different tables. But they won't seat you. Because the host has to go in order. Get a better system! One person doesn't take as long as two people!
