author: Ardy F.

description:
Best Ramen I ever had. Coming at least once a week, concern the line can be up to 2 hours waiting better come early or late.
Definetly worth it though!!!
author: Stav F.

description:
They got THE best spices for their broths...

I have been to lot of Indian cuisine or Chinese cuisine restaurants, famously known for their spicy-ness. But nothing comes close to the flavor of the condiments right here.
The noodles are my favourite. Will 100% come here again next weekend.
author: Shubhra R.

description: Ugh, it's been about a month and I can't stop dreaming about the vegan ramen!! My boyfriend and I came on Easter around 8:00 pm and ended up waiting around an hour and a half, as to be expected. There isn't really much to say that hasn't been said before, I just wish I could eat this creamy, delicious ramen every day of my life. I sadly have yet to find another soy cream ramen here in NYC but my search will go on! Highly recommend for vegans and meat eaters alike!
author: Laurel H.

description:
Got here at about 4:30pm on a wednesday.  There were already 15 people ahead of us!  Luckily, we got in for the first sitting.

I tried the tori paitan with double chashu.  Really rich with complex flavors.  The chashu was so tender that it almost melted in your mouth.  It was really good ramen.  

Our server didn't speak english very well, so I think she had a hard time taking our order.  In the end, I corrected her on what I wanted to order, but I was left wondering if she actually understood what I wanted.  Thankfully it all worked out in the end and I got my correct order.  The server was very nice, though, and came back often to check up on us.

For the first sitting, I believe they make each of the different types of ramen in series.  For us, all of the tori paitans in the restaurant came out at the same time.  Then the next type, followed by a different type. This means that some folks might be halfway finished before others get their ramen.  (I don't recommend waiting since the ramen will get cold!)  This was true for our first sitting, so I'm not sure if that happens every day.  Just be prepared.

Overall, the food was great and I'd like to come back to try their different varieties.  The difficulties with the ordering and the staggered serving times knock off a half star for me.  4.5 stars.
author: Philbert W.

description: Yum! "Mensho" was realy good. This ramen is genuine. Everybody should try it too. I would recommend "Sho-yu ramen" to anyone!
author: Shogo N.

description: The is by far the best ramen I've every had specifically the Tori Paitan. I've been to all the best ramen places in the Bay Area. Go there and order either the Tori Paitan or the Vegan. Do not get anything else.
author: Rico S.

description: To be fair, food is good on your first few bites. Diminishing marginal utility comes to mind thereafter.
author: Monica M.

description: Not mind blowing in any sense, but the food was very well prepared. The Unami flavor was unique, the noodles were great, and the service was spot on.  Our two hour long wait in a line outside was not the business's problem, but raised the level of expectation walking in.  The price of $58 for what amounts to a pretty good soup with a draft beer and appetizer was slightly high.  Also, the elbow to elbow communal dining somewhat impeded a pleasurable experience. I am glad I tried it, but I would not recommend the wait in the long line unless you have nothing better to do.
author: John S.

description: The best ramen we've tried in the Bay Area! Broth is delicious and full of that hyped up umami flavor! Tori Paitan bowl with extra chasu, topped with fried garlic~ that's gonna be my regular order. To get a guaranteed seat, we were told to get there ~ 4-4:45pm to be one of the first 24 seated at 5pm. We got there at 4:40 pm and got seated when they opened on a Sunday. So happy we finally got to try!
author: judy l.

description: It is all its been hyped up to be. And yet it is not as great as the ones that I've had in Japan. Can't articulate it well enough. The pork belly and noodles are identical to the ones at Shiba Ramen in Emeryville. Only the soup base is better - it reminded me of my mom's duck soup/broth. I did see them using a wire whisk to froth up the broth so that it looks different. Very good, but you can still get better ones on a lay-over at Narita Airport.
author: Nancy T.

description:
I was told Mensho was the place to go while visiting SF.
I waited 30 minutes outside on a chilly day in SF before being seated by the kitchen. The restaurant is quite small but it didn't bother me. However, I do wish there was more than communal seating. I've had ramen in Japan and throughout the states and I do prefer a thick pork based soup. 

I ordered the Tori Paitan and something just seemed to be off about the flavors. I'd definitely say the flavors are Americanized. It's not a bad thing but it's not what I like to eat. There was kale used for the veggies which was kind of a letdown. The duck chasu however was pleasantly delicious. Chashu was mediocre. We also ordered the oysters in shoyu dare oil appetizer. They were just OK. Think pickled oysters. 

You leave with sticky lips which I love after eating ramen but the flavor profile isn't your traditional flavor so just know that going in. Service was excellent but you do feel rushed when there are 20 pairs of eyes watching you slurp through the big window. 

I wouldn't go back a second time but if you want something slightly different from your ramen you can give it a shot.
author: David C.

description:
Sigh, what crazy people would wait outside a ramen shop at 10pm on a Tuesday night? Yes, me. And many others apparently... because this wait still took 45 min!

Totally worth it. I've had ramen up and down California and with all the hype going around, Mensho reigns supreme (next to Orenchi). How do you make a pork broth taste so thick yet light at the same time?! Noodles were actually al dente. A lot of ramen places claim to have good noodles but theirs were perfectly chewy. The vegan tantanmen was a close second favorite. I think I almost enjoyed the broth more.

I would love to come back for the tsukemen and oysters.
author: Sally C.

description: Toripaitan ramen, super creamy broth with thick noodles, just a little bit salty to me.This is a super super narrow and crowd place, be here as early as possible.(**)
author: Welcome Z.

description:
The wait is SO NOT worth it. 

My friends and I (party of 5) came to try the hype and because it's pretty unusual for a ramen place to have vegetarian or vegan options since the broth is usually made with meat. We came here around 7:15pm and stood about 5 feet from the Alcatraz theatre sign. A waitress came to take down our name, and we asked how long the wait was. She said from the sign, it would be about an hour. We decided to wait, but her estimate was far from what the actual wait turned out to be. It took us almost an hour to get to the sign, and in total, we waited 2.5 hours. 

What turned my friends off the most was the service. Their seating system is the most inefficient that we have ever seen. It was baffling. Granted, our party is on the bigger side, and there are only 4 tables and a bar to sit at so approximately 35 seats in the restaurant. Their seating system really puts people with more than 2 or 3 people at a disadvantage because they won't seat you unless a party with the same number of people leaves. Once we reached the front and there were only 2 more parties in front of us, the waitress told us that we would take the table of the group of 5 that just sat down even though there was a group of 3 that was leaving. We asked if we could split up because the people next to the group of 3 on their way out would probably finish within 15 minutes. She said no because then the time of serving the food to our party would be  vary and that's not allowed. We were so confused as to why that should be a problem if we were okay with it. And if that were really a problem, since the party next to the group of 3 was close to done, it would have been practical for her to save those three seats until the other party finished so that we would all be seated at the same time. Instead, she gave it to another party behind us and multiple parties behind us went before we even got in. In total, it was a 2.5 hour wait. By the end of the wait, we were fuming at the inefficiency because it was extremely unfair that we couldn't be seated even if we agreed to split up. As we were making our way out, the same waitress, an older woman who seemed to be the manager, stopped my friend and yelled at her for not giving enough tip and demanded more. We were all in shock because we have never been put in a situation like this before. My friend said no because she explained her to how she thought the seating system was inefficient and the wait wasn't worth it. The lady then proceeded to tell her, "If you don't want to wait, don't come back." We waited because we thought it would only be an hour because that's what we were told, and a lot of people would be seated faster and the line would move faster had their system been more efficient. She has our WORD that we will not be returning. 

Finally, onto the food. I ordered the chicken paitan ramen because that's what everyone was raving about. Upon being seated, they took our order pretty quickly and the food came pretty fast (~10-15min). Upon tasting the soup, my friends and I looked at each other with furrowed eyebrows, and said, "it's so salty." This was not just the case with the chicken paitan, but my friend who had the vegan tantanmen also said hers was really salty too. You could definitely tell that the chicken broth was cooked for a long time because the natural flavors of the chicken were prominent, but I thought the broth was too heavy, salty and creamy in a bad way. I drank SO much water while eating the bowl of ramen, and 3 hours later, I'm still thirsty and my mouth is super dry. I appreciated the innovation of incorporating different ingredients that aren't traditionally seen in ramen such as kale. I am willing to accept kale because it offered a change in texture within the different types of vegetables, but I was NOT a fan of the duck. I thought that having a chicken broth with pork and duck chashu was WAY too much. 3 different types of meat in one dish and it felt like all the flavors were clashing. I liked the pork chashu though; it just melted in your mouth. The noodles were also cooked al dente and chewy. My friends and I were disappointed that there wasn't even a soft boiled egg in a bowl of ramen that costed $18. There were a lot of noodles and I was full, but I definitely will not be back.
author: Sharon C.

description: We came here late night on a weekday so the wait wasn't too long. Decor is cute, informative, modern. Clean inside. Service was okay. They expect you to know your ramen. A suburbian girl with limited frequent access to ramen, I felt a bit stunted and needed to ask a few questions about menu items, and the server was kinda not helpful. Very in & out type of setting. I suppose it's to get people in & purchase that $20 bowl of soup & then out so that the Line can move accordingly. Way to dine, America. Then, they don't allow you to share. So if you're not hungry. Don't line up. After all my princess thoughts (lol), our orders came & it was like they slapped me silly.. With deliciousness. I ordered the vegetarian. When I tell you, I wasn't hungry.. But dammit it was too good. Ramen was fresh. Broth had this delightful heaviness (like a coconut cream curry) but they added a sesame oil with some spice to add heat to my soup of flavor. The cilantro & peanuts were a great dimension. My taste buds were dancing to the salsa music playing overhead while I ate Japanese food. Lol. Anyhow, it was the best vegetarian ramen I've had. Great baseline. I get why this place is popular. & despite my thoughts about their speed/service, I'd probably come back.
author: Stephanie A.

description:
Very good ramen. Wish they had egg/soft boiled egg as an option in their ramen dishes. Also wish they had desserts.
Worth the wait -- if the line is under 15mins long. Also fine with family style eating in this setting.
author: John G.

description:
Finally decided to stay in line to try the best Ramen from JP, but I got really disappointed:( I hope you are not seated in the front of the kitchen , otherwise you might can't enjoy your meal anymore. What I saw what really disgusting. The guy with white headband took the meat out from a leftover ramen and put into someone else's bow... How could you even have this thought ? I hope I really didn't see this happening....

I got the tori paitan ramen. It's difficult to cater for all taste, but the noodles are very hard to me. Dunno if anyone else feel the same. The broth is creamy, a bit too tasty and oily. A piece of 70% fats chasu pork cost 2 bucks... Smh... I'm not a meat person but seriously, if you are more expensive then all the other places, at least make it worth the money and waiting time. 

The service was great. The lady who delivered the ramen was very sweet. She came back twice to check on us if everything is ok. 

Overall a nice place w great service. Just a heads-up for Mensho. You might want to improve the sanitary part since its an open kitchen. We see everything!
author: Lyn Z.

description: After waiting for one hour. I finally got to enter this place. They recently put Spicy Lamb Ramen on the menu and I ordered one with Double Chashu. The first impression of it was the soup was super thickand creamy! It's like miso flavor chowder. The lamb smelled strong while the chashu was soft as marshmallows. I couldn't stop for a single second until I swallowed the last inch of the noodles. Finishing that, I realized I sweated a little, and the smell of lamb and menma was still here.
author: Zhetao W.

description:
I finally got off work early on a Friday and was driving in the area with my partner in crime at 5:10pm. I told him I've been wanting to try this ramen restaurant that makes their noodles in house. So what do we do? We drove by to see how bad the line was. We saw two people in line, which meant we would catch the second seating.

I dropped the hubby off to stand in line while I circled for parking, which was atrocious at the time. Make sure you don't park in a spot that's a tow away zone from 4-6pm! When I finally got parking, hubby was 5th in line. Not too bad. We were seated within 20 minutes of my dropping him off.

When we were at the front of the line, the server asked us what we wanted to order. This way our food would be served to us shortly after we were seated. As others have mentioned, this is communal type seating in a small space. I couldn't quite carry a conversation with my husband because it was so loud.

We ordered (1) enoki chips (2) tori paitan chashu ramen (3) organic shoyu double chashu ramen (3) sansho beer. We received the organic shoyu ramen first which was slightly fishy and caught me off guard. It wasn't bad just very different. The noodle were also flat noodles, which was also different from other ramen places I've tried. Next we receive the tori pain tan which came with noodles similar to chow mein. We both preferred the tori paitan broth. It was much richer and, for lack of a better word, the texture of the soup was "fluffy." We then received our appetizer, which was fried enoki. We never had a dish like it and would order it again.

Service at the establishment needs work. The communal tables have these weird cubbies that the workers place setting in them. Without an excuse me, the workers would reach into the cubbies and startle patrons. I would never expect for someone to reach for something in front of my stomach. They should either (1) learn to say excuse me (2) place these setting elsewhere. I'm not one that dings an establishment for service but more of an FYI.

Would I go back? Only if the wait didn't exceed the one we experienced. Considering the price point (our tab was over $60 with tip), I can't justify waiting 1+ hours for ramen with mediocre service. Was it good? Hard to say but it was definitely different.
author: Remus L.

description:
I don't get the hype. We came on Sunday at 10:30 pm and got seated at 11:00 pm. I was super excited because I've seen so many people posting about this place and the Yelp reviews were saying how it's the best ramen in SF. Well coming from LA, I have to say this was so disappointing. Daikokuya and Shinsengumi and Tsujita Ramen in LA are all better than this place. 

I had the Tsumen ramen with double chashu. Duck chashu is just whatever. The broth was super fatty... But not flavorful?? The noodles were so thick, more like udon noodles. And kale?? Kale belongs in green juice, not in my ramen.

I wouldn't come back... Overhyped.
author: Christina C.

description:
Unfortunately they didn't have tsukemen when I went but the tori paitan really is great. Full flavor, deep, and delicious.

Worth the wait!
author: Josh C.

description:
Okay, this place is wayyyy over hyped. It was not worth the hour wait I had to endure. I got the shoyu ramen, I think, and it was literally soy sauce soup. The noodles were good and I liked the incorporation of the bambu, but wheres the egg?! I feel like the soft boiled egg is what makes Japanese ramen so much better than cooking your own at home. My boyfriend had the creamy broth which was much better because the broth tasted so much like egg lol 

It was a good try but I dont think I'd bother coming back, especially for the price we paid for it. Sorry =\
author: Dalena T.

description:
3.5 Stars. It was fine but nothing exciting.

Waited for an hour at 6pm but it seemed to go faster since the line moved consistently.

Had the tori paitan ramen (double chashu). The tables have pink salt, pepper, ume (dried plum) and bonito (dried fish) powder which I tasted but didn't add to my ramen.

The ramen was a rich thick chicken broth. It came with two large pieces of pork charshu, duck charshu, burdock, menma (marinated bamboo shoot), kale and cabbage.

The broth was creamy with a strong stewed flavor which was good quality but one dimensional. It was a little too thick for me. The noodles were thick which I dont prefer, chewy and slightly curly (you can ask for the noodles to be cooked a little longer if you don't prefer your noodles al dente). The pork chashu was flavorful but a little over stewed. The duck chashu had good texture but had an herbal flavor that I couldn't pinpoint. Why is there kale and random cabbage in the broth? Is it to cater to San Francisco clientele? Why isn't there a soft boiled egg option? Why can you get Michelin star ramen in Tokyo for under $10 when a bowl of ramen here is $16-$18?

Haven't tried a lot of paitan ramen so it might just be that I dont prefer this style.

I'd rather go to the other ramen places in the city instead of here especially because of the line (Waraku will fulfill my ramen cravings). Compared to Orenchi, Santouka etc. in the Bay Area and places I've tried in LA, NY and Japan, it's only okay. Other people seemed to like it so I would give it a try.
author: Amy H.

description: OMG addicting like crack! Yes, it's that good!  The tori paitan is amazing. The broth is rich and milky, and so good that I forget that the dish is missing a soft boiled egg that I'm usually obsessed with.  I've also had the shoyu ramen, but the tori paitan is so much richer it's hard to go to the shoyu. However, it is really good and probably worth ordering if you feel like something lighter.  Seriously, the ramen here is better than some ramen we had in Japan.  Yes, the line is always long, and the TL is ghetto, and sometimes they pull a party of 1 to be seated right away even though you're way further up the line...but really it's worth the wait.  Just wish they would add more options for appetizers though (but I guess that would just increase the table turn over times).
author: Tiffany C.

description:
Me and my friend got there by 9:15p on Thursday, waited in line for 45' so we were very excited to try their thick creamy broth. I ordered a spicy dried ramen. Nothing special. All the components in the bowl goes well together to enhance the flavor. However, under-seasoned. 
My friend ordered a tori paitan ramen. The broth was runny, AH-Nah. Flavor: salty. It felt like they were running low on broth and try to dilute the original one with water than try to make up for it with more salt. Also, this is the big turn-off for me. There didn't discard of the white bubble on top of the broth. These makes the whole broth smelled like I just bite a real-life pork instead of a well-developed elegant bowl of ramen. 
Their spicy miso ramen caught my eyes but they ran out. I might come back to try this, but others thing, nah.
author: Thanh N.

description:
Those long lines but best ramen I've had in the United States! I think I'm in love. If you don't agree with me, either your tastebuds are dead, or you don't understand Asian noodles. 

Great selection of different types of ramen/noodles - most ramen joints in America usually focus on just 1 type of ramen so I'm in awe if the fact that this little shop can provide such high quality noodle dish variety.

Everyone goes for the Tori Paitan - that's what people are used to eating in SF - but their tantan noodles and soba are really special. You can't find those two dishes anywhere else in the Bay, not even close.

Patiently awaiting their Tsukemen. Bay Area, we're getting Tsukemen!!!!!!!!!!!!! (I know Iza has Tsukemen, but....)

The 6th time I went, the quality was slightly lower than the first 5 times. Not sure why, maybe they were having an off day.

Pro-tip, for the shortest lines, go Friday at 9:30PM, when everyone else about to go to the bars!
author: Tiffany L.

description: The wait can be a little long...but once you get inside, it is totally worth it!  The ambiance, trendy decor, and attentive service, not to mention the aromas of deliciousness everywhere make for satisfying experience.  Be prepared, however, to eat at communal tables.  I enjoy making new friends, so that wasn't really an issue for me.  But, it can feel cramped and noisy.  Probably not a good first date spot as was evident from the couple sitting right next to my boyfriend and me...but I thought it was a lot of fun, great food, and definitely check it out if you're in the area!
author: Phan ..

description: Wow. Unbelievable Vegan Tantanmen. Expect long lines. Service is quick b/c they want u in and outta there. Even the omnivores around me wanted the vegan ramen I had. Get in line at 4:25 b4 they open at 5 or go after 6:30 pm.
author: Susan C.

description:
While in SF, I found mensho on a whim. I was craving ramen given the evening weather was chilly and we had walked around all day and needed something to comfort the soul. I saw that mensho was a less than 10 minute drive from our hotel and so it was meant to be. After some quick review checking, I noticed a trend that the vegan ramen was quite popular. I'm not vegan, but given the lack of decent vegan/veg options back in Texas, I had to jump on the opportunity to try this! To start, the wait to get inside really wasn't that bad (sunday night). We waited (for 2) for just about 30 minutes (got inside around 9p). The efficiency of this restaurant is impeccable! I'm not used to tiny restaurants, but the way they prioritize parties to maximize the number of seats that will be filled is just brilliant. So once we're in, everything is pretty quick. The minimalist vibe of the place, both the menu and decor, enhances the eating experience. You don't feel rushed or overwhelmed. You don't need lots of time to decide on something. And it's quite intimate and friendly since you're seated right next to complete strangers. 

We ordered the oysters to start.They were very bold--strong flavor and good texture. The ramen. Oh, the ramen. I still dream about the ramen from time to time, particularly on cloudy or rainy days. The cream based broth totally elevates the whole dish by adding extra texture and a richness you may not find in a clear broth. There are 7 types of nuts in there, which add depth and crunch. The addition of chili oil balances the richness of it and the fresh cilantro and edamame round it all together. 

It is seriously addictive.
author: Nazia H.

description:
I've only had Mensho ramen three times, and each time, I've found that it's only okay. Maybe waiting in line for over an hour while being hangry makes me bitter, but I don't think it's worth the wait. There are plenty of other Japanese ramen establishments that have the same or better quality of ramen and service.

Service here is great though. Don't get me wrong, the ramen is just okay IMO, but the servers are fantastic and really nice.
author: J L.

description:
This is the best ramen I've had in all the (U.S) land... the best in California.  so why not 5 stars?  why the low-ball 4?

because i'm like all the other low-life yelp reviewers... i'm a cheap bastard.  this place is expensive.  holy crap even my 11 ounces of beer was 12 bucks!!! (goddamn it was good beer though)
author: Paul H.

description:
Food: 5 Stars
Costumer Service (particular to one lady): 1 Stars

Really enjoy the tori paitan ramen here, the soup is creamy and thick why very heavy chicken favor; the noodle cooked on point with the right amount of chewiness; and the duck chashu is also very delicious. The only thing I complain is their stuff, one of the ladies there (older lady with shoulder length black hair) is super rude, she was literally yelling at people when they don't sit according to her direction (she wants everyone to sit opposite of each other, rather than sitting next to each other).
author: Hunter S.

description:
Arrived at 4:40 on a Sunday and got into the first seating with a party of two.  I would not recommend waiting more than 30 minutes.  The tone of our meal was set by our ungracious hostess/waitress as she yelled at customers who didn't know they were supposed to wait outside, "Not yet!!!"  Even though it wasn't directed at me, I didn't think that rudeness bode well for anyone else.  

Little did I know that I would incur the hostess' wrath next.  She brought my order and said "toripaitan!" so fast that I couldn't understand what she said.  This clearly annoyed her; she yelled at me again and shoved the bowl towards me.  I got some sympathetic looks from the communal table for that.

The hostess seemed to get her s*** together a little better and didn't yell at anyone else except the kitchen staff for the rest of the time.  Still, her bad attitude didn't help me swallow the $16 price tag on a bowl of so-so ramen.  I'd been warned by other reviewers about the unusually thick soup, but you have to try it to believe it.  It's not thick in a good way, but how I imagine soggy, hot Jello might feel.

If you do go, stick with the vegan ramen, which my husband had and was much better than mine.  Just watch out for the ramen Nazi.
author: Jorge M.

description: The quality of the ingredients were superb but their broth was very salty and everything ended up very expensive. I ordered the spicy lamb, as a result of them running out of the shoyu broth. Overall I would say it is average and the oyster appetizer was okay.
author: Jessica L.

description: Overhyped? Yes. I went there at 4:15  pm there was still a line! Waited 45 mins just to get in, and there only about 16 seats. The place has nice vibe but it was tiny. I order the tori Pantian and the broth was so creamy.. I asked the waiter , what makes it so creamy? She said it's blend with rice and chicken broth... Interesting. The total bill came out to be around $20 including gratuity and tax. Will I ever go again? No, it was a one time thing only.
author: Julie M.

description:
I've driven past here on multiple occasions and wondered what the big deal was. The line is always super long. So, when my coworkers were deciding on an early dinner one night, we stopped by to see if there would be a line and lo and behold (despite the restaurant being full) we were the first in line outside. 

I learned why there is always this line, that makes it appear to be deceptively popular. The restaurant itself is rather tiny, only seating maybe 20 or so people at once. 

SEATING: You get seated at these long, communal tables so seating can get a little complicated if you have a big party. 

BROTH: If you enjoy super rich, creamy, thick broth then this is your place. I have to be honest, I really enjoyed the broth. It was unique, savory, and really really hit the spot. 

NOODLES: The Ume broth and Tori Paitan broths were delicious, but the noodles themselves were different from what I was used to (not bad, just not what I was expecting from a bowl of ramen).

PRICE: I would've given this place maybe 4/5... Unfortunately, I think the priciness of each bowl kind of put me off. It was about $16-18 per bowl, and the bowls weren't particularly large nor did it come with a lot of toppings. That was disappointing. I just can't justify paying that much for ramen, when I've had ramen that has tasted just as great (or even better) over in San Mateo for less. 

SERVICE: Because of the table arrangement, it was really difficult for the servers to get around us without reaching around / over you which was kind of uncomfortable. We also felt super rushed - they asked us MULTIPLE times whether we were done (and we're not even slow eaters), and tried to bus our bowls away on several occasions while we were still working on drinking the broth. I used to be a waitress, so I understand the importance of turning over tables, but definitely not at the expense of your customers' dining experience.

All in all, would I come back? Maybe.. if I was in the area and there's no line. The broth is definitely unique enough that I might come back, and it's worth a try if you've never had it. 

Maybe next time will be better!
author: Jessica J.

description:
I came here solo and still waited like 20 minutes. I'd recommend coming 30 minutes before they open. Would I wait more than an hour for this place? Probably not. If I am with friends who are fun and willing to wait, probably yes. I'm all about the foodie adventure! 

Compared to other ramen places, the broth is what made this place stand out. I got the Tori Paitan. The broth is rich and creamy. I loved the duck cashu. I've never had that before and it went very well with the broth. The noodles are thick the way I like. Everything just meshed together. I just wish you could add a marinated soft boiled egg.

 I also ordered the Oysters in Shoyu Dare Oil. They were interesting... not what you expect when you think of oysters. Tasted like oysters from a can drenched in soy sauce. I wasn't a fan. Also, I wanted to try a spicy ramen but they didn't have it yet. It was on the wall menu but I'd like to come back and try it.

This place is super small and you will probably end up at a communal table. Interesting fact I learned from someone I met at my communal table: the ramen broth making process in Japan would not meet food safety requirements here in the US. And I heard the owner is an expert Ramen creator from Japan, I trust that this could be the closest we can get to authentic Japanese ramen!
author: Julie S.

description:
OMG, the almost two hour wait was so worth it! The kind of ramen offered at Mensho is so unique that it's hard to find in the big cities (West Coast). The duck, pork, chicken were all extremely tender which melts in your mouth once in there, and the broth was out of this creamy world, and super delicious. 

Would I wait 2-5 hours to try Mensho Tokyo's ramen again...Yes, in a heartbeat!

Open one in LA, please!!!
author: Monica S.

description:
Solid ramen. 

I tried the Tori Paitan - it was rich, creamy, and chewy, just as I imagined.

I would definitely come back and try the vegan and shoyu ones.

Waited for an hour and half to get in, but it's expected for a popular ramen place. The taste is one of the best I've had in the U.S., similar level as Totto Ramen and Ippudo in New York
author: Lucy W.

description:
2 visits. Have had 3 (out of their 4?) types of ramen (did not get the vegan one). Some with double pork chasu. 5 total bowls. 

I don't care if it's "authentic". Authentic doesn't always mean "good". 

The tall bald man that runs the door the times we went was super helpful on the style of ramen each was. We appreciated his descriptions and personable demeanor. The waitresses inside I felt were poor. More because of their lack of command of the English language than anything else though.

All their ramen is great I thought. I highly recommend adding more pork chasu to it.

Tori Paitan is more like thick gravy than what I would think as soup 'broth'. So be it. It was very flavorful, I may just add some water to it from  my glass next time.._

The other 2 we had were lighter in style but all had distinct flavors.

3 Japanese beers with only 1 under$10. The IPA was solid, I've had Sansho and the lager before. Probably gonna stick to crushing a beer or 2 in line.

With tip, expect around  $20 a bowl. Its 2016 in SF. Just the way it is.
author: Monsieur_Meursault _.

description:
waited 40 min in line starting at 520pm on a Thursday with the hubby. looking at the window, it looks like everyone seated on the first seating were not served any food until at least 6pm. If you open at 5pm, can't you presume that folks would get to eat at the minimum by 530pm? 

Looking inside the busy small kitchen, the chefs needs to pick up the pace. there was one guy diligently placing some spring onion onto the bowls using his fancy chopsticks like he were administering eyelashes on princess kate. WTF, hurry up, there are hungry people and pregnant hungry people like MOI waiting in line to eat. I deducted one star for complete lack of urgency for guests waiting so long.

No onto the food

I am not a die hard fan of ramen, but having eaten delicious bowls from Japan to Ny TO LA, I can gauge quality when I taste it.

My hubby and I both got the go to toripaitan and then also tried their new item, tsuekemen, The Tseukemen came first (Chasu) ..having had a very good tsekukemen in LA, i thought this bowl was VERY GOOD. I actually liked it even better than toripaitan. The dipping noodles were cooked perfectly, while the dipping sauce had a very savory umami taste to it. Perfect for the summer. note they only 30 bowls of this daily.

the toripaitan is as expected, rich, creamy broth, quality ingrediants, very good.

at $16/17 for a bowl of ramen, they better be good, otherwise no one would wait that long and pay that much for a bowl.

I will come back for sure to have the tsuekmen again but not wait any longer than I did. Just not worth it. Come off peak hours and then head over to shakedown around the corner for their DELICIOUS Strawberry shake for dessert. OMG
author: Petri Y.

description:
$16 to eat ramen in the TL!??!?! What the hell was I thinking?!??!

Definitely disappointed by the experience and the quality.  Do yourself a favor, if you love ramen, go to Himawari in San Mateo and get the Tan Tan Men Deluxe:
https://www.yelp.com/biz/himawari-san-mateo

Being a fan of thick, creamy broth, I decided to get the Tori Paitan.  The stock was definitely thick, but it had this grainy texture that was not appealing.  The noodles were definitely thick and good.  The ramen includes a paltry slice of pork, duck and a few pieces of bamboo to supplement the soup and noodles.  Having eaten at Himawari and Orenchi, by far this is not a value.

I have tried to go to this place numerous times but the line and waiting system is just ridiculous.  Standing like cattle, tethered to a line might be a psychological factor for attracting customers and a form of free advertisement, but it's completely intolerable.  There are name lists, pagers and call back options the business could have implemented to make better use of your time.  

For you city folk, do yourself a favor.  Hop on a caltrain southbound to Downtown San Mateo, enjoy excrement free streets and a scenic tranquil landscape and experience ramen nirvana at Himawari.
author: eric w.

description:
The vegan ramen was soooooo good! Worth the wait! Huge portions.

They really need a bigger location as the lines tend to get long.
author: Madelyn T.

description: Hands down the best ramen I've ever had! I would definitely recommend the appetizers too! I had the Takayuki fries and it was oh so good! I also got the chicken karaage and the sauce they used was nice and spicy. When I first looked at the menu, I was confused because there was only chicken option. I am used to the typical shoyu and chashu options but don't fret. The chicken ramen was by far the best ramen I've had. I definitely recommend the spicy tan tan ramen or the dried noodle option. Anyways, I had a good experience here. The service was friendly and efficient. I am definitely coming back!
author: Peter N.

description: I got the Tori Paitan and it was delicious. The broth was thick and very creamy. My boyfriend got the Spicy Lamb and he felt that the broth was very rich in flavor and a perfect amount of spice. We went on a Wednesday and got there fifteen minutes before it opened to beat the 'line' everyone talks about. Luckily I was first in line and everyone else started to trickle behind me. Highly recommend going early and getting the Tory Paitan!
author: Lan T.

description:
My boss had told me about this new ramen shop opening up months ago, and I decided it was about time to brave the line and try it out. I started standing in line at 5:30, and wasn't in the restaurant until 7:15. Service was immediate, seating is communal which is smart for a ramen shop, and overall the atmosphere was positive. 

We started off with the oyster appetizer which was outstanding! The oysters (4 on a plate) came prepared in a semi-dried treatment, yet still oozed with texture and flavour of the soy sauce. It was a surprising burst of flavour, sweet and salty, with a slight tang of nut and acidity. 

The tori paitan with double chasu came in the perfect size, with the right soup to noodle ratio; however, the ratio of toppings to the noodle+ soup was underwhelming and disappointing. While I thoroughly enjoyed the menma and burdock, which provided a punch of saltiness and texture to the ramen, the kale was the odd one out, arriving in a sad lump of overly cooked green mess. I do love my noodles and soup, I just wish there were more toppings to accommodate the carby goodness. I feel like the lack of egg is a good thing, as the soup itself is already very rich. I first tasted the broth, which was lacking in flavour and almost seemed like a thick and creamy gravy, as another yelp reviewer pointed out. Granted, this is the second paitan I've ever tried, but it just seemed like the thickness of the broth should have been remedied with more spices or whatnot. By the end of the ramen, I had no desire to continue drinking (eating?) the broth. It is true that the broth is slightly grainier towards the bottom of the bowl.  

The strangest thing was that everything in the bowl was fairly lukewarm which was alarming when I first tried it, however the noodles were steaming hot in contrast! Once you mix the bowl up, the broth becomes steamier and the temperature is more balanced out. Unfortunately the meat is still not hot, something I prefer my meat to be in all of my ramens. The duck was the winner compared to the pork chasu, which I've had better pork chasu's at Parlor or other places. I tried the broth of the soyu ramen which was delicious, just a tad bit too salty. The noodles for the paitain were thick and Al Dente, for the shoyu they were flatter but still consistent in springiness and chewiness.

Overall, I enjoyed the food here. You can tell that it's high quality, and made with a lot of thought and love. I would come here after the chef arrives back from Japan and the other dishes are in stock--very eager to try the tonkotsu and the umi miso ramen (miso ramen is my favourite!! Go to Ramen Parlor for a bomb miso ramen). There are also tsukemen ramen and soba that are in the works. I don't think I would get the tori paitan often, just once in a while when I'm craving a whole lot of richness and comfort food in the form of japanese cuisine. I prefer the chicken paitan at Nojo's which is impeccable and much tastier in my opinion in terms of broth and overall balance.
author: Jennifer S.

description: We waited 10 minutes in the rain, but well worth the wait as we were treated to a delicious bowl of ramen. I ordered the Vegan Tantanmen and my friend ordered the Shoyu ramen. The broth and noodles were so good with so much flavor. The kale sprouts and mushroom tasted good. The last time I was here I had their Organic Shoyu ramen with Chashu and that was equally tasty! The staff is friendly, but they also remind you to move along as there others waiting for your seat. It's not a bad thing if you're waiting.
author: Allie L.

description: Not worth the line n price. Service was great but the kitchen staff are just not clean and doesnt know what's the importance of being clean in the kitchen. On the picture below, this guy, not only he took something out of his mouth and started touching foods without washing his hand, he checked his phone and back to work without washing his hand. Sanitize much huh?
author: Olivia J.

description: There's a new ramen shop in town and it's already my favorite in the Bay Area. Ramen creator Shono Tomoharu is bringing authentic ramen culture to SF and I can't be more excited!! The dashi is made with two high quality kelps from Hokkaido and a specially sourced katsuobushi. The shio is my favorite so far, but I absolutely loved the vegan tantanmen too - it's distinctly rich and flavorful, you wouldn't believe it's vegan! As for the long queues, go at night ~10-11pm. :)
author: Grace C.

description: Creamy chicken broth with thick ramen noodle which is nice and yummy!!! Also the duck Shachu is very good. Only one thing is the spoon is too big and heavy! I sore my left hand after finish the ramen lol.
author: Orange S.

description:
It's like a movie where all the parts are well-acted, but it doesn't come together. You find yourself praising the quality of the each ingredient because you're not ready to admit you're not as happy with the dish.

Waiting in line seems silly when they could just take names. 

As for the Tori Paitan: is it broth or is it gravy? It's tasty, but it gets a little gritty towards the bottom.

The shoyu is fishy.

Both the duck and pork chashu are excellent. 

The noodles are good.

There is no soft boiled egg. Apparently this will be fixed once Shono finds some eggs here he likes, but this still needs to be mentioned.
author: Huey K.

description:
I had been very excited about Mensho since (a) I'm a fiend for Japanese noodles and (b) their restaurant is literally two blocks from my home.  So on the night of the grand opening, we left about 20 minutes early and walked to Geary near Leavenworth to find . . . about 70 people already lined up.  We went to the back of the line and prepared to wait a while.  Six o'clock came and went.  I walked up and looked at the entrance and saw that the door was still closed and there were no signs of activity inside.  Another 15 minutes passed and my wife walked up to check on the progress.  Still no one going in.  Fifteen minutes later, there were SIX patrons in the place and by now, more than 100 waiting in line.  By 6:45, 45 minutes after Mensho was supposed to open, we had moved forward about 8 feet.  

Not being gluttons for punishment, we gave up and walked past the entrance to Mensho to Osha Thai.  Pausing, we took a look inside.  Of the restaurant's two long tables (yes, they really only have 2 tables), only one was in use.  And most disturbingly, NO ONE HAD ANY FOOD.  Forty-five minutes later, after an excellent dinner at Osha, we wandered back down to see how much the line had moved.  The girl who had been waiting just in front of us had moved forward no more than 15 feet; there were still at least 60 people in front of her.  There's just no excuse for a restaurant's grand opening moving at such a glacial pace.  

I've worked in restaurant service in San Francisco before and know the mechanics of getting patrons in, getting their orders, getting their food and getting them on their way.  These people seemed clueless.  San Francisco is a foodie town, but we're not masochists and we don't like having to accommodate unprofessionalism.  There are a hundred ways to avoid this kind of debacle.  Do a soft opening for a week or two, and limit your patrons for that time to reservation-only, to get your staff up to speed and iron out the kinks.  Open just for weekday lunches for a couple of weeks, for the same reason.  And don't advertise the hell out of a grand opening but then choke when 100 people line up outside.  You only get one chance to make a first impression, and Mensho blew it for us.

Also, we glanced at the menu: the items that we had hoped to be able to order -- their vegan ramen -- were $18 a bowl.  I've eaten a LOT of noodles all over Japan and even in the priciest neighborhoods of Tokyo, where rent is much higher than in the Tender-Nob, it's never been more than $10 for a bowl of veggie ramen in a place like Mensho.  $18 for a bowl of ramen noodles and a few vegetables and some dashi?  Ridiculous.  And why does their vegan ramen cost MORE than their ramen that has meat in it?!  The late Kare-Ken, which was a block closer to Union Square, served up an excellent bowl of veggie curry udon for $8.  Is Mensho's ramen somehow worth more than twice as much?

I have to wonder how long this place is going to last.
author: Curran H.

description:
The ramen was delicious, albeit slightly on the salty side. However, this place gave me mild food poisoning.

I came home after eating here around 11pm and went to bed a little bit around 1am. Nothing was unusual other than how incredibly thirsty I felt even hours after having the broth, so I guzzled some water and went to sleep. Around 3am, the puking began and lasted until 6am.  It's about noon right now and I'm finally able to keep sips of water down and write this review, but unfortunately, my boyfriend had just started puking up last nights dinner too.

I browsed Mensho Tokyo's reviews on Yelp and I noticed that out of 32 reviews, one other person noted that they got mild food poisoning from this place (with the same exact symptoms as mine). I think that's a statistically significant figure considering that this place just opened. 

Please note, I have *never* had food poisoning before and I eat out a lot, so diner beware.
author: winnie t.

description:
This place needs to open up some outdoor seating to accommodate how popular they are. We waited in line for about 45 minutes which might be considered short by some. Due to the lack of space inside you share a long table with other customers which might be awkward if you are eating alone. One of the servers spilled some of the ramen broth of the person sitting next to me on my pants because the seating is so tight. 

Despite all this I'm giving it 4 stars because the ramen, broth, and meat was bomb.
author: Simon C.

description:
The Ramen is great.  It's a supposedly famous ramen chef from Tokyo.  But the ramen aint worth an hour wait standing in a line outside in the cold - I don't care how good it is no ramen is worth this.  I'm guessing this is a common way to handle guests in Tokyo but this aint Tokyo yo!  We like to sit somewhere warm indoors while we wait for our table!  How about having a wait list so we can go to the bar on the corner and get a cocktail?  We'll be happier so you'll be happier.  NOPE!  They would rather we stand in a ridiculous Q like were waiting for a ride at an amusement park.  From now on I'm sticking to The Ramen Shop in Oakland which is owned by two chefs that used to work for Alice Waters at the renowned Chez Panisse in Berkeley.  The broth is just as sublime as Mensho, the cocktails are great, the other foods are delicious and they have a large INDOOR WAITING AREA with a bar!!! 
Soyonara!
author: Theo R.

description: The ramen is phenomenal!! Maybe the best I have ever had. I'd heard that the vegan ramen was exceptional so I ordered that and my boyfriend ordered the Tori Paitan which was a chicken broth base. Both were divine. We ordered the oyster in shoyu dare oil. It came with maybe 6 or 8 of them for $5-cheap. We could not decide if liked them. The oysters tasted WIERD but we also kinda liked the flavor. The only down side to this place is they have no reservation service meaning you half to wait in a line of people, outside. Last night when we went it was raining and we stood in the rain. Kinda sucked. Also the music is kinda strange; they were playing techno adventure pop music. It was a little overwhelming. But the food! I'll be back.
author: Angel B.

description:
I had the Tori Paitan with extra chashu. It was very flavorful, and except for a few times when it was unexpectedly temperature hot it was very good. My friend has never had ramen before as he's never figured the cuisine as being friendly to vegetarians. He had the vegan tantanman. Once I explained that you eat ramen with the spoon in your left hand and chopsticks in your right he really enjoyed the meal.

The main worry here is the line. Setting up a restaurant like this with no reservations in the tenderloin is a little ridiculous. Fortunately, there wasn't much of a line at 5:45pm on a Thursday evening, we were inside within 10 minutes. But I wouldn't want to go back on a busy evening and have to wait outside this area for more than that. They really ought to start taking reservations.

We split a 300ml bottle of sake. Only after I ordered it did I remember that this was not a sake I particularly liked. 

The waitresses speak only the most basic english. My friend had a question as to what some things on his food were and she answered "vegan!" as if he was only concerned with whether or not he was eating meat.

Overall the ramen was quite good. I'll come back when times work out for it being convenient. But their location and average long waiting time makes it hard to just decide to go here.
author: Jeff L.

description:
From the time Mensho opens, there is a line out the door.  I joined the crowd at 5:30pm and was grateful that I had a short wait (around 30 minutes).

There are four seats by the bar or four large communal tables.  They fill the tables as soon as seats are available, this means your larger party may get skipped for a single or double.

There are limited types of ramen on the menu, and each come with different noodles (and spoons).  I was happy with tori paitan and my guy enjoyed his shoyu.  The price for both (without sides or drinks) was more expensive than typical ramen ($30), but was worth trying.

The place is packed and they don't take reservations.  Get there early or wait in the long line.  While it was delicious, I think I'll stick with my less crowded spots when I need a ramen fix.
author: Michelle K.

description:
Hallelujah!! Ultra Ramen descend on earth. Complex, wide range of Umami gently wrap up on your tongue, and sparkling flavour go through your nose. It's unbelievable to eat this ramen in the US. I'm seriously worry about the line... I will believe that start from Union Square.(^o^)
ネ申。アメリカでこのレベルは信じられません。どのラーメンも本物の美味さです。ベイエリア住民に対する、全米の羨望が聞こえて来そうです。
ユニオンスクエアから歩ける距離で、アクセスも良いので、噂が広がったらどれだけ待つのか、想像もつきません。。
どれも美味しいので、一杯を選ぶのは究極の選択です。が、間違いなくここのVEGANは全米に衝撃を与えると思います。
author: Masayoshi Y.

description: I got the tori paitan ramen double chasu. Very flavorful rich broth, chewy noodles, and tender meat. I devoured the entire bowl. I've had ramen all over Japan and the U.S., this ramen ranks among the best. Definitely my new favorite ramen in SF. Can't wait to go back.
author: Kevin B.

description:
Fantastic addition to San Francisco. Grant them the operational roughness during the first week, and you'll have no disappointments. Recommended.

1-hour wait at 6:30pm on a Wednesday, 20 people in queue. Would not normally do this. Crowd thankfully knows to eat quickly, and turn the table for the next diners. Ramen is not food to linger over, folks.

4 kinds of noodles available at opening, ordered 3:

* Organic Shoyu - Excellent baseline. Good flavor extraction without excessive salt. Noodle bit on the soft side.
* Shio - Also for baseline. Same as above, satisfyingly light. Kale works well here.
* Vegan Tantanmen - Quite the standout, and I'm not regularly a tantanmen fan. Probably the most delicious vegan dish I've had in my life. Piping hot noodle, visually rich but each-to-eat soymilk base, many dimensions to flavor, all of the elements balanced well.

Our entire group finished the soups, to the last drop. It's a beautiful thing when this happens.

Suntory Premium Mait's not available. Boo-hoo!

Table check came out wrong (missing multiple items), sent back so we can properly pay for everything we ate.

The original Menya Shono (http://menya-shono.com/tokyo) in Shinjuku is a regular stop for me, and their Mensho Tokyo (http://menya-shono.com/tokyo/shop) overseas expansion pilot near Tokyo Dome has been reviewing well in Japan, with a wild range of noodles created. I'll vouch for the quality of the people behind this very welcome addition to San Francisco, I hope they continue to execute well!
author: Richard C.

description:
I tried both the shio and the shoyu ramen. The broth for both are delicious. May be on the salty side for some, but I love my ramen broth rich. The meat is the perfect amount of tenderness. The noodles weren't the best I've had, but still very good. Portions leave you wanting a bit more. I'd recommending splitting an appetizer and getting a bowl for yourself.

The restaurant is tiny, so if you are going with a group more than 2, expect to wait even longer. 

Overall, one of my favorite spots in the Bay Area. It's definitely not worth more than an hour wait though. I'd attempt to show up maybe 20 minutes before they open to avoid a 1.5+ hour wait.
author: Tri N.

description: Waited over 1.5 hours. Worth it? Maybe... Someone was asking if he could pay for peoples meals to skip the line. Its not that serious. But the tori pitan ramen was definitely different. The broth was very creamy and thick. The taste was good but I wasnt a fan of the kale addition really, it seemed like they tried to Californiaize it. I wouldnt mind going back to try the spicy duck ramen but the line was ridiculous.
author: Prima Z.

description: Friend was craving ramen and we were in downtown shopping. Found Mensho Tokyo on yelp! It was around a 10 minute walk from union square and an hour wait (5:35-6:35pm) for seats at the table. We ordered the oysters for appetizers and two orders of the Tori Paitan (based on recommendations on yelp!). The broth was thick & creamy! The atmosphere of the place was great as well. Total bill (before tips) was $40.24. I personally thought the ramen was okay, but my friend loved it..would recommend to definitely try, but a bit pricey to be an often dining spot.
author: Joanne H.

description: The ramen was amazing. The creamy chicken broth was absolutely delicious.  Reviews that talk about the wait are not kidding.
author: Kamron W.

description:
They say people like to wait in lines in San Francisco. That may be true, but I'm definitely not one of those people. That said, the 2+ hours I waited in line at Mensho's grand opening were definitely worth it.

I went with the Tori Paitan Gyokai Tsukemen, which was by far the best bowl of ramen I've ever had. The broth was creamy and rich, but not too much so. The pork was excellent and the noodles were the perfect texture. Every ingredient tasted fresh and you can tell that they pay close attention to every detail.

I definitely look forward to coming back and trying some of the other options. It also sounds like they are going to expand the menu in the near future, once they get the hang of things.
author: Jeremy S.

description: This is by far the best Ramen that I've ever tasted! It's a long wait, around 50 minutes, and they add the 15% of gratitude, but it worth every penny
author: David D.

description:
Decent, but my girlfriend got a mild food poisoning afterwards.

Waited in line for 1h (which was not bad considering we expected a 2h wait). The menu itself is not very friendly for Ramen-noobies like us so we decided to get 1 of each (so we ended up sampling 3/4 ramens, everything except the veggie).

I particularly enjoyed the extra-fat one and she liked the mor clear one. Service was not good for SF standards but I guess thats to be expected when theres soo much traffic.

The really bad part was that she got sick the night after (in 6-7h) and had a minor case of food poisoning. Only lasted until noon the next day, but not really what you'd expect from such a hyped place.
author: Mihnea G.

description: Waited in line on Friday for 1.5 hr. Ended up sitting by the bar and ordered the Tori paitan. Soup was definitely creamy and thick but a bit salty and the noodles were thicker than my liking. The meats were decent and I did like the addition of kale as my veggie consumption for the day. Overall bit overrated and not worth the wait.
author: Stacy L.

description: Seriously worth the wait! Came around 5:15 on a Sunday with 2 friends. Wait was approximately an hour. Once we got in we ordered immediately and beautiful bowls of ramen came out about 15 minutes later. I can't begin to describe how incredible the vegan ramen was. I am not vegetarian but wanted to try this unique dish. The broth was so rich and delicious. So much umami! Also the nuts and edamame were a stunning addition. I would wait in this line over and over to eat this incredible bowl of ramen again!
author: Anise N.

description:
A few sips of the Tori paitan, and I thought, Yum! After that, it was just the heaviest, thickest broth I'd ever had. The noodles clumped together. A good sign that it's store made, but that's not how you want to know it's not mass produced. The shoyu was really good, but I usually like lighter noodles with the lighter broth.

Waiting minimum 45 minutes for $18 ramen that is not the best that you've ever had (or even the best in SF) is just ludicrous.

The shio ramen did look pretty good, but I don't know if I want to put in the time to try it.
author: masa s.

description:
Waited for more than 3 hours in line for my perfect bowl of happiness but went home feeling a little let down, and woke up still w/ that damn curly leave of kale in my bowl haunting me this am.  Let me explain - I grew up in restaurants, worked in both small & large-scale operations, lived in Japan & LOVE ramen.  Please pardon the long review as I'm about to share...

WAIT - I get it's the long anticipated grand opening, and over SB50 weekend no less but you should know there's such thing as a soft opening to work out all the kinks before your highly-anticipated US debut.  Never mind the 3hr+ wait, train your staff to know the mechanics of seating & managing a hungry mob outside.  I came by myself & waited in line patiently before the door opened but noticed how they failed to move the line (you see a LOT when you had to go thru a long wait like mine).  There were plenty of single seats available throughout the evening but they never seated solo diners to ease the line...guess they wanted to be fair to others who waited (which I get) but this only added to the angry crowd.  Either 1) designate a few chairs for solo diners to ease the line or 2) insert them where there's already a single diner seating across from an EMPTY chair or 3) seat them where there's a party of 3 or 5.  This is a ramen joint not a fancy sit-down, so operate like one...in, out & no one gets hurt!

MENU - Once inside, waited yet again patiently for a menu, any menu...at this point, I was weak from enduring the cold and just sat in silence getting warm-up but quickly found out how hectic the place was w/ no server in sight, so as soon as a waitress showed up I had to flag her down for a menu.  What amazed me was the moment she handed me the menu, she asked whether I was ready to order!  I told her you just gave me the menu so please give me a sec, so she stood there expecting for an order, instantly.  Menu was limited during grand opening, no Mensho "welcome ramen", no chicken karaage, etc...just ramen for now.

FOOD - I'm a Tonkatsu Ramen lover, was shocked to see there's none offered out of the 7 types of ramen on the menu.  I ordered the $18 Tori Paitan Chashu Ramen, got served w/o too long of a wait (yay but $18??!!).  But wait...my spoon was missing from my setting...BIG no-no!  I came so close to happiness thinking they got 1 thing right - prompt food delivery.  At this point, my ramen is just mocking me.  Such a slap in the face since I couldn't properly enjoy it like the next guy who got his food just before me but he's happily slurping away tasting the broth w/ his SPOON!  I waited yet again for my waitress to reappear and asked for spoons for me & others at my table who were also missing theirs as I observed spoons were all missing from our settings.  Finally, I just dived in, too hungry to wait around for a silly spoon while my ramen's getting cold (another no-no)...who cares if I had to hold the bowl up like I was in Japan just to taste that rich, creamy broth full of yummy umami.  

Forget the traditional toppings of a sexy ramen 1/2 egg, nori, menma (bamboo shoot) etc...you get fried gobo (burdock root), a few chives mixed in, an odd curly leaf of kale which haunts me like an unnecessary garnish of a curly parsley in any bad dishes I've seen (let alone in a Mensho ramen).  The broth tasted incredible and lived up to the Mensho name.  I can just see how much time & effort that went into it, but the noodles was just too thick for the already thick broth.  I couldn't help but envy others who had a different flat noodle in their ramen.  Guess I'll have to come back when their ramen machine is up & running to taste it again, but for now the thick noodles just don't really belong in that rich broth...I can see it being an incredible ramen dish served cold as the noodles were perfectly chewy & got a great bite!  

CUSTOMER SERVICE - I was so hungry, I finished my bowl under 10min vs. my 3hr+ wait outside but at least tummy got fed.  Waited patiently for my check which never came since my waitress whom I finally had to flag down for a check said they had lost my check after some investigating.  She later came back w/ a manual check but never came back to gather my cc.  I sat & observed how hectic the place was still at 9:40pm and realized how green the staff must had been w/o much training as to offer proper customer service.  Finally, I had to flag down another waitress who was nice enough to run back w/ my cc.

OVERALL - 3.5 stars and will wait for them to work out the kinks & all the hype before returning.  Lots of ideas for improvement.  It will be interesting to see if anything improved then.  I really wanted to try another bowl of ramen (that tells you how much I wanted to like Mensho) but didn't want to wait & go home at midnight due to the sheer chaos.

P.S. our table (long table closet to kitchen against the wall) kept collapsing a bit on us any time someone puts their elbow down.  Worth looking into...
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Mensho is my new favorite ramen place in SF and they deserve the hype!  The Tori Paitan is rich with a delicious broth that must have simmered for hours.  Pricey but they source high quality ingredients.

The wait is long but fun to chat with people in line who loves ramen as much as much as I do.
author: Lis A.

description:
Finally tried Mensho Tokyo ramen this weekend... I've been avoiding it like the plague because of the line BUT I was surprised at how fast the line went! The line was down the block but we only waited 40 mins max for 4 people.

Once you're seated the restaurant itself is tiny so please be respectful of the other waiting ramen lovers... just eat and go! Redford is across the street if you wanna drink and chit chat ;) 

As soon as we were in front and waiting to get seated the waitress took our order, then within 5 minutes we were seated. The tables are interestingly shaped they have these like slots for extra plating and napkins, then baskets underneath for your belongings. Stools so no leaning back and you'll most likely be sharing the table with other ramen goers. I loved the big ass spoons they give you... it's RIDICULOUSLY HUGE! :P

Probably another 5-10 minutes and our ramens came out! We got the following items:
Oysters in Shoyu Dare Oil - Livery texture and the Dare Oil is almost like a soy sauce/ponzu mixture. It's cold but a great burst of flavor if you love oysters and salty/sweet sauces
Shio Chashu Ramen - OMG... The broth is clear and super flavorful for a clear broth. I'm usually a tonkotsu kinda of gal. The noodles are not your typical kind and the Korean kalguksu kind, so chewy and perfectly al dente. The chashu just falls apart as you try to grab and eat... Only sad thing is that they don't do marinated eggs :(
Tori Paitan - The broth was more sweet than savory, but SUPER CREAMY! The noodles were different from the Shio and I wasn't a huge fan of this dish, but the best part was the duck... it was like pinkish and fatty but man. It melted in your mouth!

Service was phenomenal!
author: Jackie O.

description:
Had the greatest dining experience here! Everything was so delicious and I was pleasantly surprised by the vegan ramen! The taste was so perfect, creamy, sweet, salty and reminded me of tonkatsu broth without the meat! I am not vegan so I was seriously shocked with how amazing it was. I will be ordering it again and have already recommended it to my vegan/vegetarian friends.

The organic ramen was also incredible. Very traditional and simple taste. The broth was very balanced, both savory and sweet and the pork was perfectly tender. Mmm, my mouth is watering now! 

We should be honored to have Shono-San & Mensho Tokyo here in San Francisco. 


Can't wait to go back!
author: Kie H.

description:
Reposting my prior review -- this was taken down by Yelp because it was posted prior to the restaurant opening, but after having revisited several times since, my opinion hasn't changed:

I was lucky enough to get a chance to taste the organic shoyu ramen before the grand opening, and I'm happy to report that Mensho Tokyo is as good as it gets for those of us that love our ramen as authentic as possible -- noodles with a good chew, a beautiful slick of fat ladled over the soup, and the whole thing served properly hot (temperature-wise). The soup was a great change of pace from the same old tepid, weak tonkotsu broth with curly pre-frozen noodles that you can get elsewhere in the area. The chashu was generous and delicious: a soft and fatty round of simmered pork, with two juicy slices of duck meat on the side. The tori paitan is thick and rich, for those of you who like a ramen with more body, and the noodles are appropriately matched. Agreed with others that the sprig of kale isn't much to my liking, and I miss having some of my Japanese ramen favorites (menma is a big one for me), but the fried gobo is excellent and adds a flavor that a lot of Americans aren't familiar with. The shio ramen at $9 is the single best value bowl of ramen I've had in the US: the shoyu just edges it out, but for those looking for something delicious that won't weigh you down, it's a proper shio ramen with a strong chicken flavor. The garlic tends to settle on the bottom, which leads to an interesting shift in flavor as you make your way through the bowl and the garlic sits longer in the remaining soup.

This feels like a shop transplanted from Tokyo (which it is), and beats out every one of the other 36 ramen shops I've tried across the US to take the title of #1. It competes handily with the best shops in Tokyo as well. The interior is beautifully appointed, clean, and modern, and I love that they've turned the entire restaurant into counter seating (albeit with the concession of counter-height tables for groups) for a more Japanese dining experience.

They're not launching with everything on the menu, and they're waiting on the go-ahead from the health department before they can start making their own noodles with the machine that they imported from Japan, but Mensho Tokyo is already far and away better than anything else available in the area. Can't wait until they finish sourcing ingredients and start serving additional items from the menu! When that happens, we'll finally be able to have proper tsukemen in the Bay Area. Crossing my fingers that the tori paitan gyokai will be reminiscent of Fuunji in Tokyo!

SF is in for a real treat. This place is worth the wait.
author: Kevin L.

description: Not my favorite ramen place and the service is pretty mediocre.
author: Clare L.

description:
4.5. That -0.5 down bump is for the price. But don't let that get to you.

I frequent Tokyo a lot due to travel routes and I DAMN VOUCH for this place. This is what Ramen is suppose to be. Its thick, because its suppose to be. Why do y'all think Ramen is like chinese clear soup noodles anyway? (for YF who said they over rely on creaminess: D'UH. Thats what its suppose to be.)

Anyways, please stay like this, dear Mensho Ramen people, don't water anything down. Don't listen to those ignorant people. Let them go away somewhere else. YOU have a crowd of your own.

Also, understandable slow service and long lines considering the size of the place and the amount of people working. And maybe because its new and the hype is still strong.

Also Tori Paitan is good.
author: Wiryan T.

description: I have been to Mensho twice and I already know that I will not try to go back again just because it is not worth the time and I did not like to be rushed through my dinner. It could be a good spot if you just want a bowl of ramen in the shortest amount of time (assuming you arrive before they open so you don't have to wait for 1 - 2 hours in line). I also didn't like their paitan (chicken broth) ramen as it is too rich and it has a powdery texture to the broth (it could be because they put in chicken liver in the broth). I personally like Nojo Ramen a lot better if I were to get chicken broth ramen.
author: Kally C.

description:
The line was super long. Had to wait over 2.5 hours before I got my bowl of ramen.
It is really good. Soup is really thick, very milky but not too salty. Unlike some other places, it gives pretty good portion of meat too. If the wait is less than 1 hour, I would go back.

Right now they got their ramen from another place. They installed the noodle making machine in the basement but don't have a permit to use it yet. They said within a month.

Soon they said will be open between 5pm-2am. Hopefully, the line will get thinner then.
author: YueStudio Y.

description: Very tasty ramen I should say, granted being a ramen lover. I ordered the vegan tantan, the most expensive ramen on the menu $18 but granted I love tantan and it is vegan, I had to try it. The flavors and veggies were delicious and had a spicy peanut taste as a tantan ramen would. Presentation was nice, the service could have been better and more organized, granted the size of the place is very small. I did get confused with another menu that was on the walls of the restaurant but had nothing to do with the menu we could order from. When I travel I like to enjoy and find the best ramen around. My search in San Francisco continues... ;)
author: Mo B.

description:
My eyelids droop slowly as I type this review and I feel myself sinking lower and lower into my seat. I am a blob. A round, floppy blob. If this is death by food, then this is the way I want to go. 

I stopped by here with a friend after work. At 6:10pm on a Tuesday, the line was already at 30-40 people and it took us over 1.5 hours to get seated. Luckily, the long line offered us ample opportunity to stare wistfully through the window. Making patrons uncomfortable? My specialty. Besides, that just means they'll eat faster.

After consulting Yelp (cause food fomo is a real thing),  we both settled on the Tori Paitan Ramen. I ambitiously opted for the double chashu- spoiler: there were no regrets.

The Ramen itself came out fairly quickly (maybe about 10-15 min?) and looked absolutely gorgeous. One sip of the broth and we both swooned. The Paitan broth is incredibly savory and creamy, the texture like a mix of soup and gravy. The Ramen comes with both duck and pork chashu (1 slice of each in the regular Ramen and two slices of each in the double). The duck chashu was an interesting addition. As my friend commented, you could definitely taste the lemon. To me, it felt a little out of place in the creamy broth, but whatever floats your boat. The PORK chashu though. Omigod. I'm already a sucker for pork, so this absolutely stole my heart. 

About a third of the way through the meal, however, I could definitely feel some regret. It was sooo rich, maybe a little too rich for my personal taste. I think if I had to do it over, I'd personally try one of the lighter broths but hey- maybe you'll like it more!

Overall, really delicious Ramen and a place I'd definitely recommend trying. Was it worth 1.5 hours of waiting? Not so much. I've heard that lines tend to be better if you come 30+ minutes before opening, so maybe try that!
author: Lucy C.

description: This place was absolutely amazing. All of the hype is real. Was a little concerned at first about the line, but after about 21 minutes it started to flow quickly. Got the tori paitan and was blown away..
author: Nagger M.

description:
Getting sick of all the tongotsu soup places in the bay area so finally a place with good shoyu Broth.  Having travelled through Japan the past two years, I miss the umami depth of good shoyu broth the likes that only until now that Tokyo and Asahikawa in my travels provided me.  Shoyu broth, seems simple but takes a master to create something deep and complex.  Missing an egg and maybe some scallions and fried shallots as Ramen Honda in tokyo does this and blew me away. But otherwise the noodles and were are perfect, and liked the kamo (duck) slices and burdoct shavings were a unique touch.

Also tried their shio (salt) which was good but I've been spoiled Hakodate's shio ramen as over there the broth is clearer from cooking under low heat of bones and salt, but it's still better than any other shio broth in the bay area. 

Finally, tried the tori paitain from my son.  It was good emulsified chicken stock goodness, but i like the clearer broth options.

Overall, we're lucky to have mensho open in SF.
author: Vien C.

description:
Waited 45 minutes in line yesterday evening for dinner and it was worth it. NOM. We both ordered the Tori Paitan - which had Rich and Creamy Chicken Soup, Pork Chashu, Duck Chashu, Menma, Kale, Burdock, Katsuobushi Sauce. I requested a spicy broth, - they didn't have it but they did have some hot chili oil / paste that she gave me and I dumped the entire thing into my ramen - so good. 

He also ordered the Oysters in Shoyu Dare Oil. (3 pieces) $5 - really good and super tasty. 

My favorite part: the NOODLES... omg. So good. Definitely recommend coming by for ramen. Staff is super friendly and tables turn pretty fast.
author: Cat G.

description:
The line is pretty absurd, but at least the food is delicious.  Up to the person if you think the long wait is worth it.


Oyster App - Delicious, but probably depends on a person's taste.  It is marinated in a sauce with the texture that reminded me of Ankimo (Monk Fish Liver).


Tori Paiten Ramen:  Very rich and thick broth.  I loved it, but i definitely heard people next to me complaining it was too rich for them.  I think people are trying to contrasting it to more common and watery pork broth.  However personally I would get this again no doubt,  no complaints from me.  It is a little pricey tho,  starts at $16 and is $18 for double meat.


Ramen Meat Toppings:
    Duck char Siu: Awesome, definitely would get an extra side of this.

    Pork Char Siu: Very Soft, falls apart soft as you pick it up with chopsticks.  Good, but i thought the duck was better.
author: Steven F.

description: I was a bit skeptical but this place lived up to the hype. We got the tori paitan and it was delicious. The broth was creamy and flavorful and the thicker noodles were amazing. The pork was super fatty and the duck was great too. I thought the food was worth the wait - which can be up to an hour (outside w/ no seating, so dress warm and be prepared to stand for a while). I can't imagine going through the waiting frequently but I'll definitely be back every now and then.
author: Adt S.

description: Delicious ramen!!! A bit of a wait, but so worth it.
author: Arthur M.

description: At this point it looks like I have found my favorite Bay Area' Ramen house. The line is what it is so if you intend on making a wise decision by enjoying the wonderment of Mensho Tokyo come prepared. I did not find the line to be too terrible - it is no different than what you can to get for an average Sunday brunch wait. For this visit I had the Vegan Tantanmen and there isn't anything I would change about this dish. Also I would recommend trying the crispy, fried mushrooms appetizer with a little lemon on top for a pleasant intro to your meal.
author: Lauren S.

description: One of my regular ramen shops when I am in the bay.  First of all I give it 4 stars because the lines to get in the shop is pretty long during dinner time.   The place is pretty small and the menu is pretty limited and you have to share tables with strangers.   The ramen is on the pricey side but well worth it.   The noodles and the broth is so filling.  Make sure to get the Tori Paitan well worth the money.
author: Jimi Y.

description:
Once thing for me. Waited in line for an hour (slow night). But it was worth it.  But not something I would do often. If you're on the fence about this place just keep that in mind. Go it tastes awesome and the wait is worth it for a one time thing. 

If.... Wait we shorter. I would be back often
author: S F.

description:
Excellent! The broth... so good and rich! This place is busy - best to go early. Or with just a friend/date - instead of a big group. The seats by the kitchen were the best - more intimate - in my opinion.
Wish they had more vegan options - but can't complain. Make sure to try the Ramune soda!
author: Charles Montgomery B.

description: Anyone giving this place less than 5 stars is probably just scorning the line - the food is absolutely perfect, and well worth the wait.  I say this as an extreme skeptic and someone who walked many nights past the 40-50 person crowd, laughing about the line of sheep (sorry).  Little did I know what I was missing out on, and I soon converted... When I finally tried, the first spoonful was just an explosion of umami on my tongue. One taste, and I was hooked.  Also, my little recommendation is to arrive at around 4:15.  Check if there are approximately less than 20 people ahead of you in line (The restaurant seats about 25 at a time- someone can correct me if i'm wrong).  This will ensure you get in on the first batch of customers when it opens at 5pm.
