If you're not in the first ~20 waiting in line, then expect an extra 45 minutes beyond that, which crosses the line of how long I personally wait for food.  One annoying thing that happens is that people hold spots for their friends, and this can often be the difference between your 45 min or 1.5 hour wait.  This is frustrating but understandable, so I started double checking with people in front of me whether or not they were holding spots.  Bottom line - must try!  (I should add my estimates are based on weekend wait times).
author: Evelyn T.

description:
Best ramen I've had outside of Japan. (Have yet to try Iza Ramen though) Went with a ramen connoisseur friend who ranked this place in his top 2 ramen places in all of California.

FOOD:
We ordered two classic Tori Paitan Ramen's with double chashu, one with the miso egg and another with the soy egg. The broth is thick, flavorful, full of umami, but *not too salty* (!). For me, the broth is the most important part. I don't think I've ever had a thick broth ramen where I could drink the soup without a bowl of rice. The duck and chashu were cooked exquisitely, and the noodles were thick and yummy. The eggs were both tasty and cooked to runny perfection; I preferred the miso egg (sweeter) to the soy egg (more fermented flavor). You can't order a side of rice here, and I'm not a huge eater, but the double chashu + whole egg was the perfect amount of food for me (maybe sliiiightly too much, but no regerts). My friend who can eat more than me finished all his food and the broth, whereas I wasn't able to finish the broth. We almost ordered one Maccha Ramen instead, but looking at others, the amount of matcha they add was a lot and we overheard people discussing the graininess of it, so decided to stick to the classic for a first time.

SERVICE etc.:
We waited in line for ~one hour on Sunday at 6pm for two people. Waiters were all very nice and responsive. They forgot our double chashu and were a little quick to blame us for not ordering correctly rather than taking the blame for not taking down our orders correctly in the first place (we made sure to double check that it was double chashu when ordering). There are baskets under the table for your things, and coat hooks by the door. Decor was slick and urban -- big glass windows, communal wood tables, stool seating -- but still somewhat cozy because of the small space. If you're on a date, get ready to sit across from the other person, because they won't let you sit side by side (the table width is pretty wide). We were lucky enough to be able to trade with another couple to sit side by side. (Personally, I prefer this because I don't like to watch people eat, you're closer to the other person, and it makes sharing food easier, but I understand why they make this rule since there's high customer turnover.) Bathrooms were clean, which is a good sign to me of the level of kitchen cleanliness.

We will definitely be coming back! Also plan to update my review once I've tried Iza Ramen and Marufuku for comparison.
author: A T.

description:
Probably the best ramen spot in SF right now. Don't go here if you are going to complain about a 20$ bowl of ramen. The quality is excellent.

Tori Paitan: If you want to try something different, this is it. Broth is extremely rich (much different from the tori paitan i had in Japan at Kagari which is by far one of the best ramen bowls i've had) but good. They use very fatty duck and regular chashu although not much.

If you want a more balanced bowl, get the organic shoyu. Definitely enjoyed the lightness but still delicious broth of the shoyu. Noodles are a bit thicker than you'd expect but that is just how they do it. If you want to pick at it for their choice of noodles, don't go.

Just make sure to double your chashu order if you go.

Line: Gets kind of crazy because of the hype so expect at least 30 mins. Shorter if you go before 5 or after 9.
author: Dylan T.

description: That tori paitan is legit. Thick, creamy chicken and pork-based broth -- almost thick enough to be used as a tsukemen (and thick ass noodles to match). Extremely flavorful, and absolutely delicious. It's so great to see a ramen joint in the Bay Area serve something other than tonkotsu, and to do it so well!
author: Kazu O.

description: Just came here for dinner today. Be prepared to wait at least half an hour as the place is really small. I ordered the shio ramen. The broth was super tasty and not ok oily. Perfect for those who don't like creamy broth. However I was a lifts disappointed with their noodles as they were sticking together. Did not ever expect that from ramen. My friends ordered the paitan Tori which is chicken broth. It was super good though! High recommend that over anything else! And the noodles were different and super chewy.
author: Qianqi L.

description:
Finally a ramen that is equally as good as Ippudo NY or Minca in NY...and a tad better than ShinSen Gumi Hakata in SoCal- Tori Paitan double charsu and duck is absolutely perfect. 
The wait can be brutal at times - but you won't be disappointed. Best in San Francisco...best on the West coast. 
Oh..and all you complaining about the price, you spend 1/2 that on your favorite coffee drink every morning.
author: Grover G.

description:
Hoping to shorten the two hour wait that many yelpers have mentioned, I came here on Wednesday before the restaurant opened. Did I mention it was one of those days where SF hit the high 70s. I arrived at 4:28 being the third party in line with 4 people ahead. Although it was only a 32min wait, I was dying from the heat outside. I can't express how happy I was for those doors to open. 

Service **
Although we were the 3rd party to enter and order, our food did not come until 20-30 mins later. The ramen was made in about 7-8 mins, but I believe some kind of mistake was made by the chef or server. The first two parties ahead of us have already received their order, but the waitress did not notice that we did not have our ramen until 4-5 parties that ordered later was already half way done with their ramen. After asking about our ramen, the answer was oh you guys did not receive your ramen yet. 

*****
Tori Paitan 
This is definitely worth the wait. The broth is rich and flavorful, where you could taste the meats boiled for hours. I have to agree with what the customers across mentioned, "this broth is too good to waste." 

Thicker ramen is paired with this broth. 

***
Shio 
This is on the lighter side when it comes to the broth. The taste of the broth did not stand out. 

Soft Ramen
author: Sylvia C.

description:
The Tenderloin is finally the it place! The streets still smell like piss but now the venues are dotted with wine bars, swanky cocktails, proper ice cream shop and now possibly the best ramen in SF.

The inner Asian in me is fighting itself but if you can stomach $18 for a bowl of ramen Mensho has placed itself as #1. Mind you the steep price tag does not come with the hailed soft boiled egg and trimmings. Please adjust expectations accordingly.

//Quick & Dirty Tips//

1. NOT Dinner Time
Why would anyone wait 3 hours if you can wait 30 minutes? The shop closes at midnight. You have to physically wait in line. Let's make it less painful for everyone by not eating at dinner time. I went Sunday night, 8:30 pm and waited for 30 minutes. Easy peasy.

2. Order the Vegan Ramen
You read that right. Never in my pursuit of hating on vegans have I been an advocate for vegan food. Vegan ramen might just be sacrilegious to the very essence and being of ramen but make no mistake the chef solved it. The vegan ramen rivals the pork fat broth in creaminess and flavor. The blend of nuts mixed into adds a depth of flavor and texture. If all vegan food tastes like this, sign me up!
author: Tiffany L.

description:
Arrived around 4:45 and waited in line for them to open.
Not too fond of the crowded communion tables. The establishment is small, so they must make do. We were the last group seated and right at the edge of the table, so we were able to get their attention and order first. Lucky!
The Organic Shoyu Ramen ($14) was pretty good. Not sure if the oil was drizzled on or just part of the broth. The broth was tasty but not feeling the oil. The Tori Paitan ($16) was good. Our party member who ordered the Shio Ramen ($9) thought it was a bit bland and didn't finish it.
Glad we tried it but not a spot we would frequent.
author: D V.

description: Been here twice, and I am not impressed. Even dining here alone takes forever to get seated. The ramen isn't even that great. I would much rather go to Nojo or anywhere else to get a bowl of ramen without the wait.
author: H. L.

description:
We came on a Saturday night when they were supposed to close at 11:30. Got in line by 10pm and sat down by 11pm

Tea was more matcha green tea rather than standard green tea .

Broth was thick and tasty. I have never had a broth that really had all the flavor a of the ingridienta embedded into it. I had the Tori. It was quite good. Definitely worth trying out this place at least once. In terms of me going again? It's questionable whether I would want to wait again in line but if a bunch of my friends wanted to go again I wouldn't mind waiting. If there was no line I would go a lot.
author: Derrick C.

description: Finally! Great #ramen has finally come to SF. #MenshoRamen. Every single ramen shop in SF is blah, but Mensho brings its famous thick and creamy (almost gravy like) #ToriPaitan broth, w duck and pork chashu, really thick noodles, and gingered veggies, to America. It's $16 for their special, and worth it. The grand opening lines are 2-4 hours, but luckily I knew a friend and bypassed it. Definitely check it out. They are adding their famous #Tsukemen dipping ramen and Tonkatsu options soon. Also pictures are science like tubes where the broth is made slowly, their decent and unique duck and pork tangy broth, and their very fishy marinated oysters. All unique, try it. 4.5 stars.
author: Chuck N.

description: I can honestly say that this is the best bowl of ramen I've ever had in my entire life. This place completely outshines Orenchi's in terms of flavor and quality of noodles. The broth is out of this world & the cha siu is so tender that right as you pick it up it begins to fall apart. I highly recommend you come out to SF & give this a try, the wait is worth it.
author: Patrick L.

description:
Don't get me wrong. 

I'm not the kind of guy who derogates everyone's favorite for the heck of it. 
I don't have anything against Tokyo or local ramen business either. 

I am giving my one star because this is a One-star restaurant. Pretty horrible bland ramen sold at premier pho prices. Both noodles/soup were nowhere near satisfactory grade. I almost wanted to sing national anthem of Japan for protest (like shameless Chinese travelers from main land China do when they think they are mistreated in a foreign country). 

If you question my judgement, my rating on Santoka, San Jose is 3. Yes. Santoka is the Bay Area's "M"adison"S"quare"G"arden of ramen and one of the few ramen places in the region that deserves to be considered normal (3 stars). Mensho is not even boom boom room, they would prolley be Mission City Swing for cougarly social meetings. 

The only saving grace is the chef will be arriving from Tokyo next month. Might give them a second chance after proper quality control has been in action. 

My reviews are written for food affectionado and ratings reflect tastabilities of the food more than anything else. I thought the place was very clean and staff were very professional. I hope they will start serving great ramen too.
author: yota L.

description:
What can I say? You have to be incredibly hyped up to wait one and a half hours for ramen. I'm sure most of you, just like myself, read these glowing Yelp reviews biting your tongue in anticipation for this "delicious" ramen but unfortunately I was let down again. It's from Japan, it's legitimate Japanese ramen and such. It is and it's better than most of the fake ramen around but that isn't saying a whole lot. 

With that being said, you can probably guess I wasn't impressed with it and it worsens the blow to have waited so long for it. We tried their oyster appetizer and it tasted like sardines. A friend and I ordered the Shoyu and Paitan ramen to share but it was underwhelming. The Paitan had flavor but was overly thick and had a grainy texture to it. The noodles for this ramen had clumped up so it was hard to enjoy it.

Shoyu ramen was good but the more you eat it, the saltier it gets. Noodles kind of reminded me of linguini too. I feel like the price you pay for the amount you get is too much. 

Just came here to satisfy my curiosity and that's it.
author: Grace G.

description: Hands down favorite ramen place in San Francisco- I recommend the shio ramen with a side of duck chashu.
author: Tracy Y.

description:
Holey smokes...  Cooking is an art...  But these guys take it to scientific level also (read the walls)   very very cool concept and great attention to detail.  

Broth was simple to the point.  The goal is umami in a bowl..  And mission accomplished.  Only downside is the wait...  Had to wait 2.5 hours to get in.   Great stuff
author: bill b.

description:
The Tori Paitan Ramen (chicken broth) is amazing. Creamiest, thickest ramen broth I've had since being in Tokyo. Noodles were thick and chewy. Each topping had its own distinct flavor - no ingredient was a "filler." You could really taste the quality and care. Kitchen staff far outnumbered wait staff.

Not cheap - $16 before tax for Tori Paitan Ramen. Other options are cheaper. Shoyu (soy sauce) ramen is $14 before tax, Shio (salt) ramen is $9 before tax.

They do not yet have tsukemen and tonkotsu - those are coming in a couple months. So if you enjoy creamy ramen then Tori Paitan is your only option, but you won't regret trying it.

For seating, they only have communal high tables and a few bar seats.

Mensho Tokyo is well acclaimed in Tokyo and this is their first US location. The co-owner is from the Bay Area and is a ramen critic in Japan. He's the host and is super knowledgeable.

They do not have a waiting list, so you have to wait in line. I was in a party of 2 and we had to wait an hour after arriving at 8pm.
author: Jeffrey Z.

description:
Was walking around Westfield Mall on Market when I felt like ramen. Saw positive reviews and thought I would try Mensho. When I arrived at 7:10pm, there were about 20 people in line. As a single, I sat a little more quickly - in about twenty minutes.  The group of four immediately behind me sat down about twenty minutes after me (I just noticed that there sure we're a lot of twenties in this first paragraph) at which time I was finishing up my noodles and getting ready to pay. 

I ordered the Organic Shoyu Ramen and a draft Sapporo. I only later saw that they had tsukemen which I will try next time. The guy sitting across from me had it.  It wasn't like the tsukemen I get in Tokyo. The noodles are served dry but there is no dip sauce.  Nevertheless, they looked good and the noodles were mixed with a large number of toppings. The bowl of tsukemen looked like it had about twice the amount of noodles when compared to my ramen. 

My ramen took about 10 minutes to arrive.  The came with both duck and chashu. The noodles were flat as pictured by many in this review. The soup was clean and pretty tasty. The noodles were a little bit softer than I normally like but overall pretty good. Both the duck and the pork were cooked well and quite soft. There was a lot of fat with both which I appreciated.

Overall, the ramen was good. I would probably try to come earlier next time so that I might have a shorter line.
author: Douglas E.

description:
Pretty good. Not really worth the 1.5 hours in line we spent though. I had mazesoba in Japan and was excited it was on the menu here. It's similar in the sense that they're both noodles, but miles away from the wonderfulness I tasted in Japan. 
I guess I can't expect the exact same taste, but at least serve the vinegar pourer together with the dish. The first girl I asked about vinegar wasn't surprised and immediately brought it out. The soup (more like a sauce in the case of mazesoba) was extremely rich and way too heavy, so I needed more vinegar. The second girl I asked was so confused and kept making sure that I was asking for vinegar lol. If you're going to serve mazesoba, please be familiar with it.
I pushed myself to finish everything because I waited 1.5 hours, but as soon as I was done, I regretted it. I felt like throwing up.
On the bright side, the bottled sansho beer they have on the menu is amazing. No one should pay $11 for it though. Find it elsewhere.
author: Tracy S.

description: We only waited about 20 minutes. We had the oysters and enoki to start. I didn't care for the oysters because they tasted like they came from a can. The mushrooms were delicious! was more than enough for 4 people. I had the spicy lamb without pork. The broth was very rich and a large portion. Since I couldn't take it with me, I had to finish it all! True comfort food and the best ramen I've had outside of Japan. I can wait to go back!
author: Mia G.

description:
For those counting the people going in and coming out, the there are 28 seats total in Mensho (including the four facing the kitchen wall).

I tried the Tori Paitan ramen and the soup was very thick and creamy, way thicker if you compare it to even the extra fatty version of Daikokuya's tonkatsu ramen.  I was expecting something more flavorful, but perhaps this type of broth is meant to be mild? I've never tried Tori Paitan anywhere else. The noodles themselves were excellent. It's pretty pricey too, Tori Paitan was $16, so be prepared.

The service staff is still trying to figure things out but I think that just comes with being a new restaurant. For example, the pepper mill cap was not screwed on tightly and we saw peppercorns fly everywhere when someone tried to pick up the container. I also noticed there was no soap in the bathroom an hour into service. Hopefully these things will get sorted out with time. 

I hope the expand to the full menu soon. The choices on the wall (but not on the limited menu) like the ebi miso sound so good.
author: Angella A.

description: Can't believe this. Use to go here all the time for my ramen craving and recommended this to my friends... No more. Brought my friends here for his birthday celebration and our server was great. However, the one server really ruined it. Our guest was not even finished with our meal and she gives us our check. After I made the complaint to her that my guest is still eating, she acted like she didn't understand and walked away. We were at the window side and can see her snickering to her coworker. If this is how you treat your customer, I am taking my business elsewhere. Really sad that this happened on my friend's birthday...
author: J H.

description:
3 star because .... 
- the wait is not worth it
- the price is not worth it ($16 for ramen?!)

We had the taipan and the shio (which was a big fishy). Both were ok, but definitely overpriced. The ramen itself was great. Also, the folks behind us in  line both got their food before us which was strange (same dish).
author: E T.

description:
I've been to Orenchi, Ramen dojo, kotetsu, and a few other ramen places around the Bay Area, and I think I can tell a good bowl of ramen from the rest. When this place opened up and got the hype it was even better than Orenchi (although I personally think it was arguable it was THE best, but certainly very good), I had to go.

I came here today 35 before opening time, ordered tori paitan... And boy, did it blow me away. The creamy, buttery broth combined with melting chashu and perfectly made noodles took the whole package to a whole another dimension from the other ramen in the Bay Area. This is the best ramen in the Bay Area without question. It cost $18, pricy, but heck, I would've paid $30 if I had to. 

The restaurant is run by a mostly fully Japanese staff, with a really modern design-y look inside. However it can sit 25 ish people inside, with no reservations or even a list to write your name down. As such, I recommend you to come at least 30 min before opening and physically wait - even earlier if you want to get in on the first wave!
author: Kuan P.

description:
I visited Mensho Tokyo with some friends, and had their organic shoyu ramen. It was hands-down the best ramen I've had. The broth was exceptionally balanced and the meat was super tender - the portion was quite large too. 

To improve, the restaurant could definitely offer better seating options; the highchairs are not that comfortable. I was fortunate to have friends bear the line for me (upwards of a 30+ minute wait, though I've heard it is commonly 45-1hr+), but it'd also seem worthwhile for them to offer reservations or a better line management system.

TLDR: The ramen is exceptional - the wait and seating options are not.
author: Robert M.

description: No muss, no fuss ramen. Love the experience, service and of course, the quality of the food!
author: Y L.

description:
Logistics:
- Went with a friend at 5:10 PM on a Sunday and waited about 40 minutes, not too bad. 
- You have to actually stand in line; there isn't a waiting list or anything. 
- All community tables, didn't see any groups bigger than 4, most were pairs.
- No sharing food, no take out available for leftovers.

Food:
- Ordered the Tori Paitan and the first few bites were really good. The soup was hot, noodles were al dente, but mostly, it was just so novel and I've never had anything similar, despite having been to Japan twice. I probably should've just stopped there.
- The soup was SO heavy and creamy that everything else just kind of melted into it. After that, the flavor profile instantly became salty and flat. The toppings that would have offered a contrast in texture and taste basically got drowned out by the broth. However, the chicken flavor did stand out. 
- The broth had a strange grainy texture...
- The duck was interesting and had a hint of acidity. Interesting isn't always good. Also do you really need chicken, duck, and pork in the same bowl?
- The pork was amazing, I'll give them that. Soft and melted in my mouth. Unfortunately, once it got mixed in with everything else, I could hardly differentiate the pieces of chashu from the soup, since the textures were equally fatty.
- The noodles clumped together a bit but were thick enough to hold the flavor of the soup.
- I really wanted to love this place, but a broth that thick and creamy probably just isn't my thing. I guess I thought it'd be okay since I absolutely adore Ichiran's fatty broth. I really regretted finishing it. Felt nauseated after. I've felt less gross after eating 20 McNuggets and fries.
author: Erica Y.

description:
Mensho Toyko is among the best ramen I've ever had in my life.  I had the Tori Paitan with Duck Chashu and it was simply divine. The rich creamy broth paired with the succulent duck, and kale among other vegetable delights I cant seem to remember were wonderful. The noodles were just the right texture and chewiness everything was harmonious and beautiful and Im hungry now just writing about it. 

It is worth the potential hour plus wait if you are in the mood for some fantastic ramen.
author: Max J.

description: I'm glad my husband and I only waited about 15 minutes. I had the renowned tori paitan and it was just so so. Yes the soup tastes like chicken skin...but I didn't get the umami flavoring I was hoping for. My husband ordered the lamb ramen and it was almost inedible there was so much salt and salt and more salt and also way too many spices to make it enjoyable. His broth was actually thick and viscous. Sad...I really wanted to like this place. I'm going to stick to Orenchi.
author: Jennifer A.

description: Oh me who I love you!! Every time I go to San Francisco I need to go here. I don't care about the line, best ramen ever! Service is great, food is great. Everything is good about mensho!
author: Roxanna Gisell R.

description:
Great little place that has most of your standard japanese bento stuff. Very authentic and very tranditionurrrrr. It won't win awards and it is not amazing like other specialized Ramen only places but Mensho Tokyo will fill you up in the right way.  

The place is very tiny and gets packed very easily. Especially around lunch time so be prepared. The menu is expansive and covers most of what the typical person will want to eat.
author: Dennis C.

description: Really great ramen! I recommend the one with duck in it. It was so creamy and full of flavor, which was great. The space was small, which is what made the wait long. Other than that i loved it! I would definitely stop by again for a different bowl of ramen.
author: Diana L.

description:
My bf and I came here at around 930pm on a weekday and there was a line with 10-15 people. The wait was about 35-40 mins which wasn't too bad... We got seated by the glass window in front of the kitchen. The servers were super friendly and gave great customer service.

I ordered the organic Shoyu ramen and my bf ordered the Tori Paitan ramen. The Shoyu soup base tasted amazing but the noodles in the Tori Paitan were better. I wish people would eat a little faster though, considering the fact that there is always a long line... Eat like the people in Japan do!
author: Jamie T.

description:
Decent food; awful service. This place certainly does not offer much respect to its customers. First of all, most popular places that do not accept reservation allows customers to put their name on a sheet and come back after 20 minutes or so. This place forces you to line up on the street, in a dodgy part of the city. In addition, it is extremely crammed, with customers and waitresses constantly bumping into you while you eat. They missed an order for us and at the end, spilled soup all over my pants (a result of them trying to fit too many people in such a tiny space, and inattentiveness of the waitresses) and barely apologized. 

Unfortunately for the kitchen, their carefully crafted noodles are matched with a sub-par front house.
author: Vivien S.

description:
Very small place, there is always a line outside but the wait is well worth it.

Best ramen I have ever had at a fair price.
author: Rob R.

description:
Certainly everyone says that the line gets crazy long but there are certain ways to avoid it. Either you come earlier or come later after avoiding the first seating. I chose the latter cause I didn't want to wait for 1.5 hour+

Regardless, I really enjoyed eating here. Ive been to all the majority ramen places in SF and Bay Area but I definitely love the ramen in Mensho Tokyo. I am such a fan of the Paitan ramen broth because its so creamy, salty and rich in flavor. The cha shu was also really good, its comparable to the ones I've had in the east coast. True that the price is expensive, and I certainly won't come every week, but I would def come again to try different ramen and of course Tsukemen broth. 

I wanted my bf to get the Tonkotsu, but it was not available, even though it was put in as the type of ramen on the wall display (was a little bit disappointed on that). Other than that, i was pretty satisfied with my visit here.
author: Cavin T.

description: Omg!! The best ramen ever!! I'm not a vegan but it sounded good so I tried Vegan Tantanmen which was soooo good and one hour waiting outside in cold weather was worth it! I would love to go again when we return to SF.
author: YM E.

description:
I love ramen and have tried a lot of it.  Came here with high expectations and perhaps that was the problem and my disclaimer.  

The broth taste was heavy and thick.  The Shio tasted better but as another reviewer mentioned, I kinda grew tired of the taste. (sorry).  Definitely worth to try but I wouldn't wait for 30 min though.
author: Hoyman H.

description: Waited almost 2 hours to get seated, but staff was efficient about getting people in as quick as possible. Ordered the Tori Paitin Ramen and it was delicious. Noodles were tender, soup was thick and full of complex umami flavor, and the meat was as tender as it gets. Definitely would go back again.
author: Michael W.

description: Came back a second time. Tori Paitan much better. Shorter wait time and the egg was good.
author: Nam N.

description:
Arrived at 4:15pm on 2/14 with my girlfriend and we found ourselves at the 30+ mark in line. We decided to wait despite the fact that they had run out of the noodles for the Shio and Shoyu ramen. I even went across the street to get Hot Cheetos because I was so hungry. We entered the restaurant around 5:50 or so and sat at the "bar" which is really just 4 chairs looking into the kitchen. Given that our only options were the Tori Paitan, which is written about very favorably here, and the vegan ramen due to the limited menu during Mensho's early operations, we both went with the Paitan.

When the reviews say the Paitan is really creamy, they mean it. It is almost too overwhelming with meat flavor and we could not even finish our whole bowl because we got a bit grossed out. It was just a lot of the same flavor. If you've never had Paitan, think Tonkotsu, but WAY creamier. 

I could tell that the ramen was really high quality, which is why I am giving 4 stars and perhaps if I would've tried the Shoyu or Shio, I would give 5 stars. I've had ramen at the best places in New York (Ippudo, Totto) so I have some idea of what good ramen should taste like. There's just no way I see myself waiting that long again for ramen, especially in San Francisco, where there must be a dozen places to get at least a decent bowl without the hassle of waiting. 

For Mensho: You guys need to start recording people's cell phone numbers and texting them when their table is ready. There are two bars across the street I would have much rather sat at for 90 minutes. Also, the servers seemed confused about which seats they were covering, as I ordered with 3 different servers. I'm sure this kink will be worked out as the weeks go by, however. 

TL;DR - if the wait is over 1 hour, go somewhere else, especially in the first few months of the restaurant being open. They told me they are expanding the menu in the next 2 months. The ramen is really good but not worth the wait and countless people walking and driving by thinking you're crazy
author: Adam G.

description: Delicious, rich ramen. Hate the line, but so worth it! Highly recommended over other ramen places in the city. I have some fave spots in the city, but this place will wow you.
author: Patricia L.

description: Hmmm first of all this place is extrememly tiny, only sits about 24 people max. Secondly, it's quite expensive. My friends and I waited about an hour in line and ordered the most popular ramen. I forget the name but I think it was paitan ramen. It has duck and chasiu. The broth is very thick compared to your regular ramen and at first its good but it gets real salty real quick. I did not like the burdock in the ramen and didnt really care for the kale. However the noodles were really thick and chewy which was yummy and the meat was good as well. I think people should give this place a try but its definitely not worth a 2 hour wait.
author: Jane K.

description: Tori Paitan is the way to go!!! Although I waited 40 minutes on a Tuesday, it was still worthwhile! It was super creamy and the broth was delicious! I also got an order of the soy sauce oysters which were pretty good too. My only complain is they don't have appetizers besides those oysters! I would love some Takoyaki on the side please...
author: Alice K.

description: This is really solid ramen. Wait was 1 hour on a Sunday at 7:30 pm. Hitting the corner store for a special beverage certainly aided the wait. The noodles are particularly delicious, great flavor and texture. Ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen (with double chashu) and wow, the flavor of the broth is incredible, but it is a little rich. Next time we would probably order just one of those and another type of ramen and share. A little annoyed with service because 2 groups of people got served ten minutes before we did (and we were only a party of 2), but ultimately you shouldn't be expecting much in terms of service at a ramen shop. The point of a true ramen shop is to provide delicious ramen and Mensho does just that.
author: Alana C.

description: I waited for a whole hour to sit inside and waited for my order, but one waiter was so impatient that when I hesitated during my ordering, he showed an obvious grouchy face and walked away without saying anything! I would have left the restaurant if had not been waited that long before. The ramen was not surprising at all, kind of too greasy that my stomach still feel uncomfortable after an hour. For those who have never been to Japan or Japan town, this could be a try when not so many people are waiting. But for those who have already tried good ramen before, the price and the long line to wait definitely don't worth a shot at all!!!!!!!!!
author: Bibo W.

description:
Downtown folks don't really have a handful of good ramen places to go huh? Usually I will never line up in a cold night for 50 minutes and only for food. But given my wife has been waiting for 20 minutes and it's only one block away I just dropped my delicious chicken wing order at another restaurant and went there. And ahead of me is another 30 minutes waiting. 

The first sip of the broth did give me the right feeling though, but not as good as the good ramen place in Japan town, which is cheaper, less crowded and has better service. The "creamy" chicken broth tired my tongue soon after, and the only thing left is the greasy feeling after I finished the whole thing. I guess the flavor of their  ramen is just like their place: noisy, crowded, fancy but not very enduring.
author: Hanzhou S.

description:
I went with my boyfriend around 9pm and the wait was an hour. While I stood in line I watched the tv which was some Japanese variety show of some girl eating a variety of food, weird but I guess entertaining. The restaurant had limited space but was cute in design. 

Food: We both got the tori paitan. When I eat ramen I care mostly about the flavor of the soup and the texture of the noodles. The broth was better than the other ramen restaurants I've been to where I'm from, very creamy and not extremely salty. However the noodles were kind of hard and the meat was alright, not amazing but still pretty good. 

Service: We saw our waiter three times in total. We were out of water ten minutes into our meal and it was never refilled. There weren't very many waiters available for us to flag down. The food took awhile to come out as well. 

So was it worth the one hour wait in the cold? Probably not, but if you've never had good ramen this is a pretty good place to try.
author: Beth H.

description:
Without a doubt the best ramen I've had in San Francisco.  I'll be coming back again.

Food
First, the Tori Paitan Ramen, with double chasu.  The broth was incredibly thick, almost gravy like!  An immense amount of flavor in each spoonful and incredibly satisfying in both flavor and fullness.  Both the duck and the pork chashu melt in the mouth; the slow cooking of the meats allows the flavor to concentrate it and it stands out despite the incredibly flavorful broth.  The noodles themselves are thick and take on the flavors of the other ingredients, all while having a firm but easy to eat consistency.

Second, the Shio Ramen.  Being a shio ramen, the broth is much lighter, but with a much more intense salty flavor.  The initial taste of the soup can definitely taste a bit *too* salty, but it quickly passes by eating more.  The noodles here are much thinner, but it definitely compliments the lighter but more flavorful soup.  The chashu is once again fantastic, and the flavors of the meat stands out in the broth.

The other vegetables were incredibly fresh, which really adds to the complexity to the overall dish.  It's incredible how they packed so many different flavors into a single dish!  And as a personal preference, I hate when food gets cold too quickly, but the choice of dishware and freshness of the food kept everything hot!

Environment
It's very intimate seating, so bring a party or a friend!  The food is the main attraction of the restaurant, not the decor! Clean, average loudness, and the service was fantastic.

In short, if you like ramen, you'll love Mensho Tokyo!
author: Chen L.

description:
4.5 stars. Only tried the Tori Paitan and Organic Shoyu so far. The Tori Paitan has a really creamy and heavy broth with chewy noodles. The toppings are plentiful and everything blended together really well. It is heavy though, so I couldn't finish my bowl. 

Second time I tried the Organic Shoyu and it was ridiculously good. Very well balanced and just the right amount of saltiness. Some of my ramen noodles were clumped together into a ball, so I spent some time pulling them apart. 

Easily the best ramen in town. They will expand the menu to include Tonkotsu and Spicy Miso ramen in the near future. 

Get ready to line up for an hour or two any time of the day.
author: Lynn C.

description:
This review is just for the service. My friends and I (party of 5) got there at 4:30pm. We were seated right away when they opened at 5. However we had not even finished climbing onto the bar stools when they were asking us for our order. Mind you there were 5 of us and we only had 2 menus. After my cousin finally had seated herself they made her get off so they could squeeze another person in, I get it the place is small. Over all the staff was rude and I felt rushed the entire meal not an enjoyable experience. The place is definitely over hyped. 

Side Note: The ramen was decent compared to other places, maybe I'll come back when the hype dies down.
author: Karla B.

description:
We came all the way from London to San Francisco to try out the ramen here in SF. Actually, no, we just happened to be in town visiting and my cousin had recommended this place. It was 9:00pm sharp, and we waited in line for about 45 minutes. However, the line is totally worth the wait. We both ordered the Tori Paitan and loved it. The soup is creamy and the noodles delicious on their own. The meat is a little fatty but we were really enamoured with how good the soup was that we didn't really care. However, it was hard to tell which was the duck and which was the pork. 

Slurptastic, service was much like it is in Tokyo, save the little coin vending machine at the entrance and J-pop blaring through the speakers. Man, I'm glad we had the chance to come here whilst we were on holiday.
author: Tim L.

description: Delicious Tori Paitan, attentive and fast service. The line can get long so either join the line before opening time or come prepared to wait.
author: Jackeline D.

description:
YUM - welcome Tokyo to SF!  Yes, this is the crazy thick broth ramen place that will change your life.  So do it.  Now I know you're going to order the tori paitan ramen which is their deservedly famous meaty dish with a chicken-ish broth, but let me also encourage you to order a couple other things:
- The vegan tantamen, which the chef recommended as his second choice, and which is an awesome, slightly nutty contrast with the tori paitan.  In fact, we kept alternating between the two because each one seemed to make the other one taste awesomer and each was awesome by itself.
- The oysters!  These had "shiyo oil" on them, which gave me flashback to the first time I had truffle oil: the first bite is a bit "unusual" or foreign, the second bite affirms that this foreign taste is actually good and fits in with other savory aromatic foods, and by the third bite you are ready to pay double the price just to have a little more.  Don't tell anyone but I actually licked the oil off the mini plate after the oysters were gone.  
- The Sansho beer, which is perhaps my favorite "herbal" beer ever - with a hint of Japanese peppercorn.  Disclosure: this beer is expensive as f*ck at over $1 per ounce.  Splurge and get two.

Out of curiosity we also ordered the $14 Shiyo ramen, which is listed on the receipt as "organic ramen."  OK to be honest, actually I wrote down "shiyo" based on phonetics but now that I look at their menu online, they have $14 "organic shoyu ramen" and $9 "shio ramen" so I'm not totally sure what we ordered.  Anyway, it was what thinner and what most people would probably recognize as "ramen."  Not as good as the others.  Still need to try the Shio... or Shoyu.
author: Aaron M.

description:
Heard that this place was new and had a long wait, so we came here around 9PM on a Wednesday. We still had to wait about an hour and 15 mins to get seated. Get ready to wait if you're coming here! There's a Redford bar and a liquor store across the street if you want to help make time go by faster. Someone would need to wait in line at the restaurant though.

The inside is pretty small. There were a few long tables and a table in the back that looked into the kitchen. The tables had baskets below them so you can put your bags. My huge Mission Workshop bag was able to fit in one of them.

Now about the food: I got the Tori Paitan with double chasu, which is the bowl that most people get and the most talked about. It's pretty different from all the other ramen bowls that I've had. The broth is really creamy, like creamy enough that my friends thought it was weird that I was drinking a lot of it once I finished the noodles. It's a pretty unique taste and I would definitely suggest trying it out, especially if you wait that long in line. 

Overall, the ramen here is unique and tasty but the long line may or may not be worth it, depending on how much you like ramen. 

Pros:
-Unique creamy ramen

Cons:
-Long wait to get seated
-Limited seating inside
author: Paul U.

description:
Broth is tasty. And duck chashu is delicious. They have vegan ramen which is great because I can go with my partner who is vegetarian. But they use thick noodles.  My preference is medium to thin noodles. I wish we could choose thickness of noodles when we order. 

Their wait is awful for regular dinner hours like 7-8 pm. Unlike other ramen joints in Mission, Mensho doesn't have a bar or space for customers to drink while they wait their turns. So we just have to standing in line outside. I would add another star if I didn't have to keep standing cold outside so long for dinner time. 

A bowl of ramen at Mensho can end up about $20 if you add a topping. Ramen is quite tasty, but to me total experience doesn't worth $20. Definitely not worth wait over an hour outside.
author: Akiko O.

description: Amazing ramen. I walked by this place on my way to meet colleagues - long line caught my attention. On my way back there was no line so I jumped in. I got the Double Spicy Lamb - full of flavor, creamy, and spicy. By the time I left the line was back. Wow, can't wait to come back.
author: John B.

description: Disappointed and the most terrible service ever... Not gonna go back again.
author: Jean L.

description:
ramen ramen so good. veggie ramen good for vegetarians. 

ramen just like the food in tokyo! 

always go early b/c there will be a line. 

my favorite is the Tori Paitan with a lot a lot of chasu! my friend also likes it, we went for round 2! yummie!
author: Zoe H.

description:
Best I've had in SF, Santa Clara, LA, NY, and Tokyo. Staff is great and the ramen exudes quality and care. It really is distinct from any other bowl I've had (Tori Paitan and Shoyu).

In case you're keeping track of the wait times....

3/2/2016 Wednesday @~7pm was 65 minutes (for 2)
author: John S.

description:
Really good ramen. The broth a bit thicker than you might find elsewhere, but it sticks to the noodle well and has a great flavor. The duck chashu accompanying the ramen is phenomenal.

Skip the oyster app though.
author: George T.

description:
Food: the ramen with chicken broth - eh. Not as flavorful as I would have thought. A little too thick of a broth for me. For the price. Not worth it to me.  Especially if you had to wait an hr in line. I didn't, so ok with it. I wouldn't get this again. The vegan ramen though is awesome. Add
Chashu in it and you are set. I know. It's odd thing to recommend. But seriously it's good. The broth is flavorful. 

Place: if the wait is more than 15 minute. Don't bother. Seriously. It's a waste of time. It ain't that good.
author: P L.

description: I am from Jersey and would fly all the way back to San Fran just for their Tori Paitan. No other ramen is going to compare I fear. We went on a Sunday night so the line wasn't bad. It moved fast. They were closed on our last night in the city and it broke my heart.
author: Sarah W.

description: We saw the long line...we knew we had to come back. After going to Rye we went back and stood in line. The ramen was awesome. I ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen, it was flavorful, lots of noodles just delicious. The other order was Tukemen. It's limited on their menu but delicious too. Then pair it with Ozeno Yukidoke IPA you have a perfect meal. Next time I'll get the oysters, I'll be back soon.
author: Sharon B.

description: I thought the line would be much shorter around 9pm in Sunday night because everyone is watching Leo wining the Oscar in front of TV. But I was wrong(maybe I'm right)! The waiting time is still like 15min or so(maybe it shoulda been 1 hr or so). I ordered tori chashyu ramen. The broth is super rich and creamy. It tastes really good if you like rich broth. Kale in ramen broth does sound weird to me but it turned out to be great fortunately.  Overall this is the best ramen shop I can find in downtown. No kidding, ramen is much better(and more expensive) than takanaya.  Expect a long line during any hours.don't expect sushi rolls and sashimi.
author: Jeremy S.

description:
I got tantanmen ramen (veggie) and added chasu and duck.  It was amazing.  I was expecting the broth to be a bit thicker since it had to sesame and peanuts, but it was still rich.

I also tried the oysters and it was good!  But, if I had to do it all over again, I'd rather add more pork to my bowl than a small bowl of oysters.

The oysters tasted great.  It had lots of flavors and were very concentrated.  The texture was on the crumbly/dry side, but it's what I expected in cooked/dried/fried oysters.  The marinade was awesome.  I would get it again if I went with several people... 1-2 pieces per person is a good amount.

I like how they automatically add gratuity to the check and don't leave an amount for tip.  But, I like the idea to increase each item on the menu another 15% and not have gratuity in there at all.  Either way it works out the same way.  I just like the concept of no gratuity.

Other tips:
There's no signage
No to go or take out
Look for it on a map before you head out
Be prepared to wait or go early
Don't use the neighbor's restroom while you wait.  Use Mensho's.

Keep up the great work!
author: Anon y.

description:
Best Ramen I've had on the west coast.  I had the Tori Paitan and it was thick and full of flavor.  The broth had no issues sticking to the noodle so every slurp was delicious.  After the first taste of the broth, I was wondering if I was going to feel heavy and sleepy afterward, however, I didn't get that feeling.  Also, the noodles were thick, chewy, and perfect texture for the broth.  
Lastly, if you don't want to wait 1+ hour in line on Saturdays get there by 4:20 and you should be the first set of group to get seated.  
Definitely worth going to. Will be back many times even though I have to drive 1 hour.
author: Paul K.

description: I came here with some high expectations. There was a pretty short line for us (25 minute wait for 2 people). There isn't much choice on what to order if you want ramen. Either get fatty broth or not fatty. The fatty broth is 16 vs non fatty at 9. Needless to say, I still got the fatty one. #1 they have duck slices in it, I'm a huge fan of duck but was not a fan of the duck there. The pork pieces were really good and you get one long strip. The amount of noodles is not enough, if you come empty, you will need to eat everything and drink everything to be content. As for the broth, I kept thinking it could use more flavor. It was pretty grainy and not so much smooth and just didn't really hit the spot with me. If you like ramen spicy, definitely not the place to go. I might try the less fatty one next time at half the price
author: Victor D.

description: Came in on a Tuesday evening right after work because right around 6:15 or so, there is already a long line outside. The sweet waitress recommended the Tori Paitan Ramen, which consist of sliced duck meat, cabbage, kale, bamboo shoots and some chives as garnish. The broth was very rich and creamy which I thoroughly enjoyed. I also added some chili oil for the extra kick. Restaurant is quite small but the food came out fast. Definitely check this place out if you're craving ramen.
author: Diana L.

description: I don't mind waiting in line for great food and Mensho did not disappoint. This Ramen is ridiculously good.
author: Theda S.

description: We arrived around 8:15 and were seated by 9.  Good idea to bring a drink with you as the line is no joke. Very intimate space inside, so be prepared for small talk with neighbors.  We had the oysters appetizer and Shio ramen.  Both were superb!  I recommend getting the double pork cashu as the regular only comes with one piece.  We were still full though.  Definitely worth the weight in the end.
author: Jason K.

description:
The vegan ramen is amazing! Not what you typically think ramen to be with such a rich broth but the flavor is amazing! 
That wait really isn't bad and they take your order in line so our food is basically severed once you sit down.
author: Rachel M.

description: I came here with two other people on a Friday night around 6:30ish and waited about 2 hours in line which was pretty ridiculous. It's a small restaurant that seats maybe 26 people inside. The ramen was good but not wait in line for two hours good. My boyfriend is Japanese and used to live in Japan and he said it tastes pretty similar to the ramen in Japan so that's good to know. I got the shio with double chasu and that went for $11. I'd come back but probably not on a Friday or the weekend.
author: Tori M.

description: This place has a LONG wait especially during the hours of 7-8 PM! There is no sheet to sign in so be prepared to stand in line for at least 45 min. before getting seated. They also don't take reservations. I had the Tori ramen and it was good, but I wasn't that excited about the creamy broth or the kale that came along with the broth. The noodles were firm and the broth was flavorful. The chashu was as expected and the duck chashu was a little fatty. I think I'll stick to the clear broth next time. Unfortunately, there was no egg with the ramen considering it's $16 a bowl of ramen. :( The ramen shop has 3-4 tables with limited seating and it can get pretty loud. Overall, it was an interesting experience. I'm hoping they will expand their menu and maybe add a few more seats to accommodate more guests.
author: Maria V.

description:
Had a really high expectation, but it was pretty disappointed. 

The soup was rich but it's not tasty as traditional pork broth. The noodle was kind of hard. I love the traditional Ramen noodle texture than this noodle. Everyone highly recommended the duck chashu, but it had sour flavor which was pretty weird. Chashu was the only thing I liked, very tender.

$16 for the Ramen +$1.5 extra Duck Chashu=$17.5/bowl. It's totally overpriced for something that is not tasty. Definitely not for me. We will not go back for sure. We really wanna love it, but it's not for us.
author: Che K.

description: Had the Tori Paitan...this place gets it right..rich broth...perfect noodle texture...good reason wait is so long
author: Craig S.

description:
Finally made it out to Mensho. We wandered over Saturday night around 10ish - and were surprised that the line wasn't very long (probably around 20 minute wait). The noodles were very fresh-tasting and chewy. The broth (we ordered the tori paitan and the vegan) was thick and creamy. Tori paitan tasted full and meaty (even porky tasting) and vegan was very nutty with some spicy kick. 

Qualms are that the broth is a bit too over-the-top creamy (more of a noodly chowder than a ramen) and there's no egg option. Oh man an egg would have been awesome. Also, maybe I should get the shoyu (clear broth) option instead next time.

To be quite honest, I really enjoyed the meal but don't see myself coming back often. The wait in line isn't worth it to me and $18/bowl of ramen (I think our bill for two ramens and a tea was around $40) is a bit ludicrous, even for San Francisco.
author: Sylvia L.

description:
This place is still getting a lot of popular buzz, so there's usually a line, but it's not so bad on a weeknight.

They serve more clear broth than cloudy and I'm a creamy ramen fan, so it's the Tori Paitan all the way and I was not disappointed. Velvety and umami-laden broth makes a home for slices of pork and duck. There's no eggs in this Ramen, but I hardly missed them.

All in all, a great place to have down the street!
author: Miles L.

description: I try pretty much good to better Ramen place in LA. i must say this place has a fight! Lolz! My sister and I looked for a place to have some diner, and heard of this place is awesome and worth a wait in line. Damn ryt! I ordered Vegan Ramen $18.00, even though I am not a Vegan eater! Guys! Taste ryt as I wanted! Their crew are all helpful! Suggested what else can we get or put on our Ramen"nice". A pricy ramen but a must try when you are in SF town! Organic and their house special taste great too! We also try oyster appetizer for $5.00. A little salty but had a nice taste! With beer!
author: Ampie E.

description:
This place is great for a bowl of ramen. I felt like it was a spot that you sit down, eat your bowl and move on. Owing to the line outside, you want to help keep it moving. 

The ramen itself is outstanding. The tori paitan is outstanding. The maze soba is one of my favorite dishes as it has an egg on it. My vegetarian friends are pleased with the vegan option. 

All in all, super yummy ramen if you're ok with standing in line.
author: Vijay A.

description: Came here on Saturday at 7:19 pm and waited for about 50 mins . The place seem pretty small with limit amount of seatings. I ordered a organic shoyu, which was small in portion and overpriced. The soup base tasted normal to me and the meat did not taste as well as I expected. However, the noodles had a distinct taste to me and the service was good.
author: Melanie N.

description:
Had way too much high hope for this place. I live just across the street, so everyday I see a lot of people standing outside of this place in line. Last Friday, from the window I saw only 2 people outside, I immediately ran down and went inside. I did not wait one single minute and got inside. But there are quite a few things I don't like

1. The place is small as hell. You can rarely move around or talk to your friend about some juicy stuff without being heard. It is really uncomfortable to sit 2 feet away to other customers.

2. The noodle is very very very salty and heavy. Seriously, it is like 3 days' salt intake in one meal.

Anyway I have had much better ramen than this one. Pricey and just not worth it.
author: Zhang R.

description: The Vegan ramen is so good! Depending on the day the line can be rather long but you'll be seated within an hour. Eat solo and you'll be bumped to the front of the line!
author: Amanda J.

description:
I had the tori paiton ramen with double chashu and the oyster side dish. They are only using their grand opening menu which consists of 4 types of ramen and some oyster side dish 3/1 when the head chef comes back to San Francisco to expand the menu. This restaurant is showcasing their tori paiton ramen since there are not many other places that are good at making it. 

Oyster side dish:
Very worth. $5 for 4 cooked oysters in their special sauce. It's very difficult to describe the taste, but I loved it. One dish is enough for one person as the oysters are pretty small.

Soup - 3/5 (or 5/5 taking into account that it is chicken based)
I thought for a chicken based stock, the soup was incredibly flavorful. However, when comparing to other pork based broths that I have, it was lackluster. It was very thick and gave a bit of that powdery feeling in your mouth after eating a spoonful. That didn't stop me from spooning up the last of the soup, though. 

Noodles - 4/5
Pretty standard noodles for a high end/popular ramen restaurant. They're above average compared to the generic ramen place, but nothing game changing. I think they're a bit on harder side, which is my preference for ramen dishes.

Toppings - 4/5
This is where I'm a bit conflicted. Maybe it is this style of ramen traditionally doesn't have an egg, but I was pretty disappointed when I found out no soft boiled egg was included in the ramen. However, the duck chashu was the best chashu I've ever had. The texture of the duck was like a rare steak without the blood and iron-y taste. I could eat just that chashu for days, which is why I'm giving the toppings a 4/5. They also had what I think was kale and cabbage in the ramen which provided a nice break from the heavy and salty flavors of everything else.

The two hour wait for this place was pretty absurd and I'm sure it's just because of the current hype. The first time you go might be worth the wait, but after that, most definitely not. I'll be back to try their tsukemen when they start serving it.
author: Michael D.

description: Got lucky last night, after a Sketchfest event with Mike Judge and the King of the Hill cast at the Marines Memorial Theater, we walked over to check the line and it was only 2 parties deep.  Hopped in line, and before long we were seated.  Efficient service, we were slurping within ten minutes of sitting down.  The ramen was exquisite--I had the Tori Paitan, SO had the Shio.  She loved hers, the clear, flavorful broth won her over.  The Tori Paitan hit all the marks I have been reading about, creamy broth and excellent flavors.  Will be back.
author: Colin S.

description: My friend and I went to check out the hype about Mensho's ramen and it did not disappoint! We went on a Sunday at 4:45 because they open at 5 and the line was already 40 people long. We were seated after about 1.5 hours. The vegan ramen was amazing and the best ramen I've had so far. The noodles were thick and chewy, the broth was thick and very flavorful. The portion wasn't oversized but we were definitely full. I'll be back for sure!
author: Jocelyn L.

description: Man oh man. Came here last night on a Wednesday to check out the hype and this place gets packed real fast. My boyfriend and I waited about 1 hour and 15 minutes or so. If you're a party of 1 you can probably get seated within minutes. The place is tiny and it gets hot so be prepared to take off your jackets and other accessories lol. Parking is difficult in the tenderloin area and make sure to lock your cars and hide your valuables. The waitresses are super nice and they speak Japanese which is plus for me lol since i speak that language. The menu is simple. They only have few things on the menu which was like 4 different ramen, one appetizer, some beers and drinks. I like the ramen here. The soup is thick and favorable, noodles are thicker than most ramen places, they put kale in there (a plus for me!) and some other veggies. Unfortunately they don't come with the half boiled egg. I don't remember if you can order that as an extra. Anyways this place is overpriced for a bowl of ramen. I wouldn't spend $16 a bowl for a ramen or extra $2 for more meat. I'll only be back here if my boyfriend pays haha.
author: Monica W.

description:
After going to a show, we ended up here on a Friday night around 10 PM. The line wasn't terribly long - but there was still about a 30 minute wait. Pro tip: If you're willing to dine alone, you can get a seat pretty quickly (I've noticed within 5-10 minutes tops). 

The Venue - 4/5
Definitely small, and communal. There aren't any individual tables, rather, you'll end up at a communal table that seats about 6 guests. I noticed that most people kept to themselves/the people they came with - but some people (generally the individual diners) would have a great conversation with the complete strangers that they sat next to. There isn't much wiggle room, but there's enough to not bump elbows with your neighbor. They provide a little basket under each pair of seats, meant for putting any belongings (bags/jackets etc) during your dining experience. The servers and staff seemed friendly, although when ordering, I felt that we were slightly rushed. 

The Food - 3/5
I wasn't a huge fan of the food. The ramen noodles seemed slightly undercooked (and different bowls had different types). I ended up with the Tori Paitan, but for me it wasn't "blow me out of the water" amazing. The broth was decent, definitely different, but didn't shock me (I didn't end up finishing all the soup). I felt that it was a little too rich for my tastes, so maybe next time I'll try a different one. The meat was so-so: I didn't enjoy the regular pork chasau (it had a wine or alcoholic taste to it that didn't quite sit right with me), but I LOVED the duck chasau. For my companion, it was the opposite, he loved the pork and hated the duck. The one thing that made me really sad was the lack of soft-boiled egg. For me, I love ramen for the soft-boiled egg, and was sad to see that they didn't have it :[ I also think that the variety of the menu was a little disappointing. I would like to see additional add on options, such as extra corn, extra broth, etc. Currently, they only have add extra types of chasau.

Overall - 3/5
I think this was definitely a place to try once, for the experience. Perhaps it's my particular taste preference, but I didn't love the ramen. It's very  bare minimum and focuses more on the particular broths. I would say try it to see if you like it, but I think it's more of a taste preference type of place. I would love to see more explanation of the different menu items (since they didn't really explain much), and more options for additional add-ons. I think this place definitely has potential, but still needs to work out the kinks before they get a higher rating for me. I'll probably try this place again in a few months or so, to see if they've improved.
author: Li S.

description:
Had the Paiten ramen. It was very thick and creamy coming out somewhat between hot and lukewarm. 

The noodle inside were on the other hand very hot which was an amazing experience. The noodles warmed up the soup as well and ya overall it was a fantastic dish. I will certainly bring my closest friends and family here for a nice one on one dinner.

Besides that seating is small, but that's just the environment and you can't really change that. But if you come with a group don't plan on sitting all together.

I usually judge a place by the following criteria:
Price-Portion-Quality-Taste (PPQT).
I would come here again alone if the line wasn't long. I don't care about the price in this case, the ramen is unique! I would certainly bring a date here (if she liked ramen). Portion, quality, taste, price, ya it was all great, certainly a 5 star meal here. And I rarely say that about expensive dishes.
author: Anthony N.

description: Came here with a friend of mine one evening because I been wanting to try this place since it opened but never understood why there's such a long line, now I see that it's people like me who will only try this place once and never go back. This place is made for baka gaijin. $16 Tori Paitan Ramen with super stingy toppings and super small portion noodles which I finished in less than 3mins, faster than it takes to make instant noodles. $11.75 for Sansho "highway robbery" beer. My total comes to $31.90 or $32 for noodles that are nothing special, especially for those who comes from East Asian countries. The owner must be laughing all the way to the bank. Ingredients cost $5 at most and was charged $32USD for a bowl of noodles and beer. Only the dumbest people buy into the ramen hype. This stuff is fast food in Japan and all over Asia, it's nothing special but somehow there's a ramen craze in the West and fast food chefs from East Asia are flocking over here like it's a gold rush to capitalize on the craze. I feel like the biggest sucker for playing $32 for something that easily passes for $10 tops. Ramen Yamadaya is still the best in SF, Ramen Dojo/Ramen Parlor (same owner) if you're in San Mateo. Stay away from this place unless you're someone who likes hype, getting ripped off or being the best ramen sucker in the West.
author: Panchali S.

description: I could see how people would not love the place on their first visit, but after three times.. I've got it down. Vegan tantanmen ramen with pork is the absolute best. Not a fan of the little egg noodles they use in the shoyu and shio, and the Tori paitan broth  is way too much like gravy for me to slurp down to the last drop. Vegan ramen all the way here.
author: Michio F.

description: I really wanted to like this place, but I was not use to the thick broth.  We waited here for an hr in the stormy wet weather with my friend. I love how the inside looks, simple, and clean. It is expensive for a bowl so I probably wouldn't make trips often here for my ramen craving. The place is small so there will be a long wait. I am willing to come back and try the other flavors, but not anytime soon.
author: Matthew L.

description: Best vegan ramen I've had in SF. Rich broth, amazing flavor, optional kale and cabbage, delicious
author: Sarah F.

description: Amazing craftsmanship -- I had the shoyu ramen with duck charsu. The duck with broiled to perfection. The noodles were passably al dente. The broth was flavorful. Unfortunately, I find all of their broths too tsukemen-like and thick and salty. I know their Tokyo headquarters are known for tsukemen, but even their non-dip noodles swim in gravy-like extra salty sauce. Otherwise, it's a supremely well-crafted bowl of noodles they serve.
author: Ken H.

description:
Mensho Tokyo has the very best ramen that I have ever had in my entire fucking life -- so why only 4 stars? They also have some of the very worst wait service I have ever had in my entire fucking life. It would be one thing if the service was generally mediocre, and one time it was BAD, but it's not even like that. The service is just REALLY BAD pretty much all of the time; except for one really sweet young lady, the entire staff is rude, as far as I can tell. Maybe that's the entitlement that comes with serving the best ramen in San Francisco? I dunno. As others have said, show up and be prepared to WAIT and then keep waiting. No to-go boxes, no doggie bags, you can't take anything with you, and no substitutions. If you don't like what's on the menu, eat at your house. 

All of that being said, the $18 (!!!) bowl of vegetarian tantanamen with bunches of nuts and soy beans and mushrooms and cilantro and chili oil is heavenly. Worth every penny. Slurp the last drops from your bowl!
author: Najla A.

description: True ramen straight from Japan. A valiant effort to educate non-ramen literate population on the science and method of ramen. From the alkalinity of the noodles to the proper smoking and fermentation of the other ingredients, the video and wall lexicons provide ample education. They had 3 ramen choices. The tori was good, creamy chicken broth. I am used to the kinktau, thus was a nice surprise. Bowl was left empty.
author: Susan S.

description: I can find no reason to deduct a star from the five I can give this hipster Noberloin hole in the wall. Had the tori paitan ramen ($16) and small Sapporo ($5). While a tad more expensive than your average ramen bowl in he city, the quality of the rich duck/pork/chicken broth, and the fresh noodles make it a good value. Also, there are less expensive bowls on the menu. Cute decor, friendly staff, I'll be back to try the other broths. Time will tell if they can keep the quality up.
author: Nick C.

description:
I came here more than a dozen times already and I wanted to update my review.  

Their ramens, though expensive, is one of the best in the city.  Their soup base tends to be on the richer side, especially Tori Paitan.  If you want a lighter soup, go for the Shio Ramen.  Their noodles are pretty fresh and chewy, so no matter what you order, you can't go wrong.

Lines are usually pretty long especially during the weekends so the best time to go is before 7pm earlier during the work week where the lines tend to be the shortest.  If you are by yourself, your chances of jumping the lines are pretty high should they have a single spot open up.

Why 4 instead of 5 stars?  Sometimes service can be bad, but it has been steadily improving.  Also, $17.50-20+ is just a lot to pay for a ramen, even one as good as Mensho.
author: Alex T.

description: This is the only ramen in the US that serves a good Abura Soba. This is officially my goto ramen restaurant in the bay area.
author: Katsumi C.

description: Outstanding Ramen.  A little expensive and you have to wait in line but Mensho delivers.  Original style and flavors.  Even better than the ramen I had in Japan.  Hinawari in JTown is  also excellent if you like a lighter style ramen.
author: Matt F.

description:
Quality and wait that is well worth it.  
The big points for me are the noodles and the soup.
Soup: Tori Paitan was the choice.  Thick and full of flavor.  The right amount of abura.
Noodle: Usually in the USA you'll see the thin noodle more akin to Hakata style noodles.  Mensho uses thicker noodles more like ones you'll find in the Kanto region.  Makes for more al dente and it soaks up some of the soup.  
Well worth a wait in my opinion!  Looking forward to their fuller menu to become available!
author: John M.

description: I was in SF for the weekend and heard about this fantastic, highly rated, new ramen restaurant. Being from Socal, I've had a lot of ramen in my lifetime (from Gardena/Torrance, Downtown Little Tokyo, to Costa Mesa). It took my 3rd attempt in line to finally get into this place (the first two times I was too hungry for a 1.5hr wait). Needless to say, I was extremely happy to have gotten a seat after only an hour wait (I also had a smaller meal prior to coming here). I got the vegan ramen. For $18, it's definitely on the HIGH end of the menu (well, not even that, high by any ramen standard). The soup base flavoring was really good the first 3 spoonfuls, but the saltiness quickly became overwhelming. The noodle itself was thick (I think it depends on preference, but I prefer the thinner more springy noodles). They include tip into your bill at 15% so I think the service can slack a bit because we were nearly done with our ramen when they remembered our marinated oyster order. We could have easily skipped it.  It looked nothing like other Yelp reviewers' photos. It was definitely overlooked. Not sure it's worth the wait, but given the novelty of the restaurant and the high ratings, you'd have to try it just for curiosity's sake. But, I think if I ever go back, I would order the regular pork ramen (hold the pork of course).
author: Linda W.

description: Perfectly tucked in Lower Nob Hill to satisfy round one of your drunchies. The line after 10pm is relatively short so my +1 and I were seated within 10 minutes.
author: Celia W.

description: Broth is thick like gravy and noodles tasted slightly over cooked. I'd pass given the strong presence of other ramen shops in the Bay Area. I'm not sure what the hype is about.
author: Molly W.

description:
This review has nothing to do with their food or staff. More to do with the way this business is run and how food is wasted at this restaurant that is in the Tenderloin neighborhood of SF. I have posted my email thread with the manager of the restaurant who never addressed my concerns with the establishment. In fact, he mansplained about ramen. Dine at Mensho at your own risk. Just know YOU HAVE to order food there (even if you're just dining out with friends and might want to share food) and YOU CAN NOT take any food to go even if you're purchasing it. Enjoy. 

Good afternoon,

I am writing to let you know that my boyfriend and I had a bad experience at your San Francisco-based restaurant last night. After patiently waiting in line for 30 minutes (which I have done before at your establishment), we were told after being seated that my boyfriend had to order food even though he had ordered a beer and I ordered an appetizer and a bowl of ramen. Since he knew I was hungry (but he was not), he graciously ordered another bowl of ramen for himself.  When we were done with our ramen, we asked to get my boyfriend's bowl of ramen to go, but we were told he couldn't take it home even though we were forced to order a second bowl. The second bowl of ramen, which I paid for, was wasted. 

Being a resident of San Francisco for 10 years, I know that owning a business in this city is expensive, but not being able to take a meal home that I paid for is ridiculous. My boyfriend and I are very cost-conscience, so paying $11 for a bowl of ramen and not being able to enjoy it later is a waste of your ingredients and time as well as our money.

I was incredibly disappointed by what happened at your restaurant and will never go back again. At the very least, let your customers take home what they don't finish since they are paying for it. Your food is going to waste in a city that has a lot of homeless individuals as well as people who are just trying to survive here. 


Dear ------,

I am very sorry to hear about your negative experience at Mensho Tokyo SF.  It is our goal and purpose at Mensho to serve authentic Japanese ramen.  Ramen is based on the balance and harmony of five main elements, and is meant to be enjoyed immediately upon being prepared by the chef.  To let the ramen sit or take it away would allow the noodles to soften, the soup and fat to separate, and in essence would ruin the magical harmony which is what makes ramen great.  In Japan there is no ramen take-out and no to-go, period.  We strive to create this authentic experience and it is why we have our current policies.  I want to sincerely apologize for our lack of communicating this to you before you patronized our restaurant.  I agree that wasting food is a terrible thing, and better communication on our end can hopefully help us avoid this situation in the future.  I apologize once again, and hope you can understand.

Sincerely,
Abram Plaut

Mensho Tokyo
author: Erin L.

description: I wish I could give more than 5 stars. I waited for like an hour in the rain but it was so worth it. Their vegan ramen is on my list of top 3 foods I've consumed in my entire life, and I've eaten some good food.
author: Lucas M.

description: Incredibly good ramen. Line could possibly get you one hour but its definitely worth it. If you go alone it could take you less. There is a long table inside (communal style). The bowls are going to be around 16$ but they are huge so you definitely getting your money worth.  Ramen soups are very good here.
author: Gus N.

description:
I'm always on the look out for great ramen, so when I heard about Mensho Tokyo from a friend, I had to give it a try! 

Mensho opens at 5pm. When I arrived at 5:10pm, there was already a line of about 15 people! What is going on?! So it turns out according to the host.. that the chefs have requested to let in a few guests when the restaurant first opens so they can get the first orders out without it backing up orders in the kitchen. Anyway, my friend and I waited for about 30 mins and then were seated. It's a pretty small spot, so be prepared to wait now and in the foreseeable future. 

We ordered tori paitan and the shoyu ramen with extra chasu for both. The tori paitan was a really creamy, heavy broth.. perhaps, a bit too heavy for my liking. It also had a duck flavor to it, which wasn't my favorite. The shoyu ramen, on the other hand, was great. Loved the lighter taste. Plus, it was just the right amount of seasoning. For both bowls of ramen, the noodle was pretty good and actually kind of reminded me of Chinese noodles a little. The chasu was on point - pretty much melted in your mouth.

As for service, everyone was friendly and great. Pretty quick about getting the ramen out as well. Kudos and shoutout to the host, who was really friendly and cared about our dining experience.

I look forward to their full menu and would love to try their tonkotsu ramen. Until next time, Mensho!

(10/100)
author: Cassy H.

description:
If you've ever been to Totto Ramen in NYC, this place will definitely ring some bells. The name of the game is thick, THICK, rich broth if you get the classic Tori Paitan. It's by far richer than Totto's, which kind of overdid it for me personally, but there's no denying that the ramen is still delicious. Just be warned that this is a very rich meal, and trying to drink all the broth along with your noodles is more ambitious than your average bowl of soup. 

My boyfriend has been here before when this place first opened, and he commented on how the slices of duck always seem raw and undercooked. This time, they were also a noticeably pink color, but we figured it was on purpose. Neither of us came down with any illnesses except the sheer distension of our very full stomachs afterwards.
author: Hope X.

description:
The broth for the ramen is very unique. I've never had it before. But it is definitely too salty for me. Maybe it's my own preference but I think the soup for ramen should be less salty with a lot of flavor. Mensho Ramen has a lot of flavor but just too salty. I would give it a 4 because of its uniqueness and the texture of the ramen if there was no waiting.

I waited for about 1.5 hours until I got in. A bit overhyped. 3 stars
author: Curtis T.

description: Caveat -  I don't eat pork, so this rating is based on the vegan ramen. I've heard great things about this restaurant and came around 8:30 pm on a Tuesday. The line was about an hour long. I loved the vibe of the restaurant and the communal tables, but I didn't love the ramen. It was delicious and had a unique flavor, but after a small amount of it, I just felt like I was drinking peanuts. I ordered a side of duck as well and it was such a tiny piece. For over $20 for dinner (no drinks, just ramen), I could go somewhere else.
author: Lauren G.

description: waited 30 mins but it was nothing special.... noodles were good but didn't really like the broth and soup was really salty. Service is fast and friendly. But I prefer Ramen Underground
author: Carmen L.

description:
I was hella grumpy from a long day at work, a tough workout, and a sloppy walk through the tenderloin, so when my wife made me wait in a long line for a new ramen place, I was not feeling it. I ended up walking across the street for a large can of Sapporo, which I nursed for the next hour while smelling people walking by us in line.
