The ramen was worth it. Friendly host and waitresses. Looking forward to coming back less sloppy and for the other ramen bowls.
author: Stephen H.

description: Vancouverite here. I came here with 2 girlfriends as we were craving ramen and Mensho had rave reviews on Yelp. We got there around 6:30pm on Sunday night and waited for an hour in line before being seated. We all ordered the same which was their popular one. It was definitely a different kind of broth - very creamy indeed. We all thought it OK as the ones we've had in Vancouver were much better. If you're a fan of ramen egg, they don't have that there. Perhaps we were not used to the creaminess...it was just not worth the hype for all 3 of us girls.
author: Brenda T.

description:
Great food, everyone knows that. Interestingly enough, to me the highlight of the experience was the line. 

I used to balk at waiting in long lines for restaurants and bars. Yet, I had a blast talking to like minded individuals in this line. It made the wait much more fun, and ironically, I was a bit sad when I left the line to eat. 

Pro tip: Come here starving. They don't let you bring leftovers home. That's why this is 4 stars instead of 5 stars to me.
author: Robert F.

description: The spicy lamb ramen was amazing. The soup-less noodles were great too. Duck chasu was unique and fantastic. Suntory premium on draft and sake pour was generous. Would expect a line but great ramen as a reward.
author: Elir I.

description:
Had the Tori Paitan.  The broth was flavorful and thicker than normal.  The noodles were also thicker than normal.  Overall the taste was good.

There are tables which seat six people and since it's a popular place, strangers are forced to sit with each other.  This isn't a bad thing, but personally I think it makes a lot of people more guarded in their conversations.
author: Chris S.

description:
Even though I got there before 5pm. I still waited about one and half hour to get my ramen. 
Once you got the ramen, sip some soups, everything worth for the wait. That's how good the Mensho Tokyo Ramen is!
author: Blair Z.

description:
Tried the Tori paitan, super thick broth, creamy and filling.
Best dense and creamy broth I've had so far.

Also tried the oyster app, it's good but have had something similar before. Best way to describe it's kinda like pickled oysters...tastes better than my description.

The owner/partner(?) suggested the vegan option and after tonight's dinner i am definitely coming back to try it.

I loved loved LOVED the duck chashu, wish I tripled ordered just that.

Totally worth going. We got there around 4:15 Wed. Got in first round. Worth the 45-60 min wait.

Very small space, seats about 20-25 people.
author: YaYa S.

description:
Wow what a wait! Visited SF for the weekend from LA and just had to try this place out. 

Let me just get it out of the way, 2 hour wait for ramen is a long ass time. Was it worth it? Yes. Would I do it again? No. It was worth it for the experience of trying "authentic" Japanese ramen, but the food didn't wow me enough to wait again. Maybe when he tonkatsu ramen eventually makes its way over. 

I got the tori ramen with double chashu. This is beyond creamy. It was practically a gravy, and actually tasted similarly to it. It was still good, and the noodles were fantastic, but I would prefer for it to have been a tad thinner. The pork chashu was perfect. Amazing stuff there. I should have asked for the duck to be replaced with the pork, because I wasn't a fan of the duck. 

Overall I enjoyed the food, but the line makes it really hard to want to go back. I would suggest trying it at least once though.
author: Andrew H.

description:
We arrived to a line and waited one hour. The shop is small, but the line moves pretty quick. Once seated we ordered the oysters, shio chashyu and tori paitan. The oysters were good and helped ease our hunger pains while waiting for the ramen. The ramen was amazing! Shio was light and sharp with a flatter noodle. The tori was creamy, rich and had a round thicker noodle. They were both delicious and a nice compliment to each other. I would recommend getting both if you come with a friend. 

We have had ramen from coast to coast in the US and this is hands down the best we've had so far! We will be back next time we are in the Bay Area.
author: L L.

description: Mensho serves some of the best ramen I've had in the Bay. My friend and I arrived around 10 on a Saturday, and the line actually moved pretty quickly. Once we got in, we were not disappointed. I got the vegan tantanmen and she got the tori paitan. Both were amazing! The noodles had the right amount of density and chew  and the broth was rich and layered with flavor. I particularly loved my vegan broth, which had some nice peanut and spicy notes. The only warning I have is to come hungry so that you can finish the entire bowl. The type I got was pretty rich and filling. I can't wait to come back and try some of the other broths.
author: Bethany D.

description: I'm from Tokyo and I've never heard about this place....It was very average despite the hype
author: Nikki U.

description: The best ramen I've ever had. I was a die-hard Santa Ramen fan since it first opened, then a Ramen Dojo loyalist, and now I'm a Mensho Tokyo raver. Only go to Mensho if you don't mind saying "meh, Mensho is better" for the rest of your life to all other ramen joints.
author: Samantha F.

description: There's one vegan option but is it ever good.  We came on super bowl Sunday so the queue at dinner time was a reasonable half hour long.  The first time my friend and I intended to dine here we already had movie plans with another friend and just kept walking past the unbelievably long line.  Getting back to that vegan ramen, it is not your run of the mill, afterthought flavorless meatless option that many other ramen places offer.  The broth is incredibly rich and full of flavors.   I can't really describe the taste other than had I not read that it was vegan, I would've been convinced that it was meat based.  Again, it's hard to explain the flavor profile except that it was delicious.  This is a rare instance where it required effort to finish my bowl.  My friends and I left feeling really full.  Another friend who had eaten here previously commented that the broth was too rich and heavy for her taste.  At over $18 for one bowl Mensho will be just a treat and not a frequent haunt.
author: Robert W.

description:
...I think this may be the most delicious bowl of ramen I have ever had..and I will try my best, but I don't think my review will do it justice.

The wait: I got to Mensho around 6:30pm on a Wednesday night, and waited about 40 mins before getting a seat. I expect the wait for Fridays and weekends to be much longer, but I swear it is worth it. 

Inside: Mensho is a super small ramen shop, with a simple, clean cut themed interior design. Everything looked super clean and new. All white everything. 

Staff: Service was not extraordinary, but its more or less like a service you get at most authentic asian restaurants. The staff's priority is to get the line rolling but rotating people in an out as fast as possible. 

The Ramen: WAS UNBELIEVABLY AMAZING.

 I ordered the Tori Paitan, which was $16, a bit on the pricey end that I am used to paying for ramen. As soon as I took a sip of the broth, I couldn't help but smile. I was absolutely stunned by the richness and intense flavor of the ramen. 

It came with 2 small slivers of duck chashu and 1 ginormous sliver of pork chashu. The duck chashu was seasoned perfectly and tasted unique but delicious. The pork chashu was a bit fatty, but still flavorful. There was also a small bushel of kale and bamboo shoots. The noodles were thicker than most ramen shops I have been too (which I personally prefer) and had a little bounce to them. It was the perfect combination of chewiness and tenderness- perfect for slurping. Best of all was the broth- it was creamy, rich but not too heavy, and EXTREMELY flavorful. It tasted as if a chicken was used to make the first batch of broth, which was then boiled again with a fresh new chicken, but 10 times. Everything in the bowl came together perfectly. Although the portions may seem a bit small, the richness of the broth will make up for it. By the time I finished 3/4 of the ramen, the broth was getting a little bit overwhelming, but nevertheless I could not stop until I finished every last noodle in the bowl. So if you are worried that this bowl of ramen won't fill you, I promise that you will be A-OK. 

If you are looking to get your mind blown by a bowl of ramen, Mensho is the closest you will get to authentic Japanese ramen in the city.

JUST DO IT. NO REGRETS.
author: Shirley L.

description: The best ramen I've ever had! Got in line about 10pm and sat down around 45-50 minutes. Well worth the wait! It's a small restaurant but staff and patrons know to keep your stay enjoyable but revolving. The food was delicious and my girlfriend and I were done in about 20 minutes. So satisfied and can't wait to come back!
author: sam f.

description:
It wasn't worth the 1 1/2 hour wait to me; it was good ramen. The oysters were not in a half shell. They were marinated in something that made it the color black and it was firm and chewy - It wasn't what I expected and I didn't enjoy it.  

The server talked me into getting the $9 beer, saying it tastes better than Sapporo (which was half the price).  I fell for it and tried their small glass of $9 beer and it was just ok.  

Service was pretty good.  We were 4 people and we spent $100, which includes a $15 tip.  

Looong wait for just good ramen, and expensive = I can say I've been here once.
author: Jeneal V.

description: Well, we waited almost 3 hours, I ordered organic shoyu ramen, but I really recommend tori paitan. Seriously!
author: Tony S.

description:
We got here on a rainy Saturday at 4:30 thinking that we would be the only ones crazy enough to dare outside on such a day. Completely wrong! There were at least 30-40 others ahead of us already at 4:30! Waited in line for about 2 hrs to get in. This is the worse part.

Moving on to the ramen, one of the best I have had. I got the tori paitan and boy it did not disappoint! Be warned it is all creamy goodness and the noodles are super thick but that is exactly  what makes a good bowl of ramen on a cold, rainy day! 

In short this place is the new ramen heaven in sf if you can stand the wait!
author: Mo S.

description: So rich and creamy! Damn this white soup of ramen is good... My only gripe is that their Tsukemen still has not made the menu! Also best time to get here for little to no wait is between 5pm-6pm. After that, good luck (in "Taken" voice).
author: Charles L.

description:
As much as I hate waiting, I don't want to be the type who pays a TaskRabbit to stand in line on their behalf. Oh no, I've done [insert name of any place vaguely hipsterish in The Mission] the hard way. And probably complained about it, except on the rare occasion I thought it really worth the wait...

Step forward Mensho. Or rather, step forward imperceptibly slowly along a somewhat gritty stretch of Geary. I couldn't get Google Maps Popular Times to work for this place - probably because it's so new - but my suspicion is the chart would be solid blue lines i.e. constantly busy. Fortunately my friend lives right across the street and has been carefully monitoring the line on an almost constant basis. She should really set up a pay-per-view MenshoCam (TM) that integrates seamlessly with the Eater app. That'd help fund the $18 ramen addiction.

Utilizing our insider knowledge of line dynamics we seized our opportunity and the wait - thankfully - was only around 35-40 minutes. The weather wasn't terrible and we even made new acquaintances and exchanged ramen recos as we inched toward our supper. The space itself is tiny yet minimalist chic and, given the hype combined with limited capacity, it's easy to understand the long lines. The confusing thing was that the menu written on the wall doesn't correspond to what they actually sell so best not to pay attention to that.

My go-to in most noodle shops is the Tonkotsu Ramen which unfortunately Mensho doesn't yet offer, apparently they're still in the process of setting up the necessary equipment. Instead I went with the Tori Paitan, a recommendation from our line buddy, which was decent but not really my cup of soup. I kind of regretted not going with the Shoyu Ramen.

Overall I liked the experience and didn't so much mind the wait but can only really give 3 stars based on the food, which admittedly was largely down to my own rash selection. I'd like to come back and try the Shoyu Ramen, or ideally the Tonkotsu once they finally have that available, and will rate again. The only thing I would say is that there was no hot sauce or hot pepper available, and frankly I like a bit of heat in my ramen - I get that this is a purist type of place though. If you like that you might want to bring your own. Just saying.

As to whether it was worth the wait, I'd say yes in this case as a new experience but wouldn't want to wait close to 1 hour even once the menu is updated. I did try to come back a few weeks after my initial visit but the line was much longer than before so ended up elsewhere. I'm sure many devotees will continue to endure the long waits but, for those who love the ramen places down there, you'd probably be eating sooner if you drove all the way to Santa Clara. Or, you know, just have your TaskRabbit bring it to The Marina.
author: Danny G.

description:
We ordered the most popular item: tori paitan, which is a gravy-like broth made from boiled down chicken bones (wings, feet, carcass, etc) so in that way it was different but also a little gritty. The first couple slurps were pretty good, didn't taste very salty nor heavy but as you get to the bottom of the bowl, it starts getting really heavy. The best part were the noodles, al-dente and so yummy. The toppings were also a nice touch and added great texture and a different note to the ramen. Overall pretty good, worth a try but weighing the peak wait time of 2+ hours and the soup, I would say it takes the rating to a 3 star. For a 30min wait time, well worth that wait. 

Don't get the oysters, they have a very mushy texture and an okay flavor profile. They're also $5 for 4, not worth it. 

The restaurant is also very small which is the main culprit to the line, 3 long family style tables.
author: Qui T.

description: I was taken to Mensho Tokyo almost by chance, as I was staying in the tenderloin. The queue was long but I was told the locals know this place as one of the best in the area, so we decided to stick it out and boy was it worth it. The inner decor is clean, well ventilated and spacious enough to have waiters walk between tables without obstructing your eating experience. Having been to Japan solely for the purpose of eating ramen, my palette was used to good thick broths and freshly made noodles. But this place deserves extra mention and credit. I tried the tori paitan and my companion the spicy lamb ramen. The wait wasn't long - our ramen arrived promptly. Once I mixed my tori paitan I knew instantly the pork had been well prepared (it is extremely soft and melts in the mouth) the ramen fresh and the broth evenly thick without using too much oil. All conversations stopped and we both dug in to the dish. Prices are reasonable for what one gets (you will be quite full after one ramen) and waiters are polite. 5/5 and would highly recommend this ramen novices and experts alike.
author: Hong N.

description: Surprisingly, this place is worth the wait. The Ramen is smooth, packed with flavor, and delightful. Every ramen shop is different, but all seem to follow a structure, or guideline. This just can not be said about mensho. It was truly an unique experience. The broth was very thick, yet holding form, no separation of fat, with a creaminess of a just starting to peak whipped cream. Noodles were thick and chewy, held broth well, yet offered a good neutral after taste. The wait is generally worth it on certain nights, as the umami balance on the broths is both satisfying and savory.
author: Aaron T.

description:
Excellent flavor and quality. Their different ramen types are great (vegan included) and appetizers are good too. Service is quick and friendly.

This place is tiny and has a line out the door that can be 1+hour wait on Friday night. I recommend going at a less busy time (Mon-Thu) and having 1 person show up a little early.
author: Brennan K.

description: I didn't wait for too long. The soup is rich, presentation are nice, but it is just too oily and too salty compared with other Ramen I had before.
author: Chia C.

description: Don't know what this kunti t. Broad is babbling about but this is the best ramen in Northern California. Worth the wait and lives up to the hype.
author: Jarrod P.

description:
went on a Friday and waited almost two hours but after trying the ramen we could see why!
the inside was small but the atmosphere was super warm and welcoming, the staff was also very friendly! 
we got the Tori Paitan Ramen , the broth was super rich & creamy and tastes awesome, the chashu pork was super soft & tender and literally melts in your mouth, it made me regret not getting extra! the noodles were thick and cooked to perfection and they even sell Japanese beer which was fun to try. 
overall all if you have time to spare or if you love ramen and are willing to wait in line Mensho is definitely a great place to try! 

will definitely be coming back some time in the future !
author: Inthia T.

description:
We ordered vegan tantanmen and the clam butter, enoki chips. My vegetarian friend really likes the tantanmen. I liked the think ramen noodle in tantanmen and the way it is cooked but it's too salty for my taste. the clam butter uses a thinner and flatter noodle, which works well with the lighter and clearer soup. the clam and scallop are both fresh and tasty, the lemon slice helps by giving it a fresher taste and also adds variation to the bowl. We are happy with the enoki chips. I had enoki tempura before but these are different. They don't seem to be using any flour batter  (at least I didn't taste any in our batch), which makes it very flaky and less greasy than enoki tempura. Definitely give it a try if you like enoki like we do.

Overall we enjoyed the food quite a lot. But we probably won't be back when the line is long. The food is good but not worth an hour of wait. 

I do think the restaurant could serve their customers better with some lining policies

We went there on a friday evening around 5:50. There were about 28 ppl in front of us. There are also about 28 seats in the restaurant so we decided to stay. After 15 minutes, we didn't move forward too much, mostly because ppl lining in front of us had friends joining them - one person even had 5 people joining him! I would like to think restaurants line their customers up not just to give themselves good advertisement but also to help people decide if they are dining there based on the length of the line. Allowing too many people to cut into the line because they have sent a friend waiting does a disservice for that purpose. If the restaurant lets people line up before the whole group is there, It is better to also keep a written waiting list of names with the number in each party, so that people would not have the wrong expectation regarding the waiting time. 

I also noticed that mensho does not seem to seat smaller groups first. They left 4 empty seats open for sometime until 2 more people at that table left so that they can accommodate the 6-ppl group. To be honest, that's a nice thing for the restaurant to do, and I would prefer going to that kind of restaurant when I have a larger party. But it sucks if 5 people of that party cut into the line in front of you and you ended up having to wait 10-15 minutes longer.
author: s c.

description: If you like creamy base ramen, try their Tori Paitan Ramen! There may be a wait and limited menu since they openned a week ago but it's well worth it.
author: Rose T.

description: We ordered the tori paitan, my boyfriend got double chashu. We both LOVED it. Some have mentioned the broth being too creamy, we personally both enjoyed it but it certainly is rich. The line was very long-we waited 45 minutes (in the rain) but I think they will probably get better with turnover in time. If you are more than 2 you will probably have difficulty getting seated-the group of 3 in front of us was passed over twice before getting a seat. I rated this 4 stars because only half the menu was available for now and they don't have eggs yet-I will update my review when I feel I can fully evaluate this place.
author: Amber F.

description:
Came here on grand opening day and they have very few options of ramen to choose from. I'm a HUGE FAN of ramen. I hunt for ramen whenever I go travel. I've had ramen in Tokyo, NY, Hong Kong, and some other popular Bay Area ramen places, and I definitely will NOT say this is the best ramen place in even just SF. 

I got the Tori Paitan Ramen on this visit.
Broth:
The broth is favorable yet waayy too thick. it's prob the thickest broth I've had in my life. Don't get me wrong, I love thick broth in ramen but this one is just too much. It also left a strong residue on my throat, which made me drink tons of water afterwards. 

Noodle: 
I kind of felt like there's a sand-ish like texture on the ramen(probably due to the thickness of the broth). The noodle itself was too thick as well, feeling more like udon. 

Chashu:
I dont know if it's day 1 and they're unprepared, but the chashu I got is more than 70% fat. I like chashu with a bit of fat, but def not something like this. 

Overall, I would not go back again. 

Just as a reference, I love Ichiran Ramen the most. They're perfect in terms of broth, ramen, and chashu.
author: Sharie H.

description: with such a crazy hype, we managed to hold on to our hungry stomach and waited for over an hour around 10pm to try this ramen. to my surprise, the broth was way too thick for me. i liked the deep flavor and the chewy texture of the noodle, but the broth was overkill and the overall quality of the ramen definitely didn't stand up to the long wait. we came out with somewhat uncomfortable and greased stomach. i just like the clean and natural broth that you can actually drink up. this is not my style but i can see it appealing to those who like the broth thick and gravy.
author: Chris L.

description:
This is the best ramen you can get in San Francisco, probably the best in the city and East Bay. $18 for the tori paitan ramen with double chashu is not a bad price for the city's dreadful prices. 

This is just what you want in a bowl of ramen. Thick, rich, and flavorful broth that's not overwhelming. The handmade noodles were thick, delicious, and cooked just right. The chashu melted apart. Everything is made with care. It is all quality. That's what you want. All grievances can be boiled down to personal preference. They are serious about their ramen and the quality reflects this.
author: Alex M.

description:
Arrived at 4:25 on Weds. Third party in line. Anyone after 4:35 prob didn't make first sitting. Seats 24 at 3 communal tables and 4 seats at the back counter.  Very limited menu. Just eat your ramen and go. Just a few minutes to order and served within 10 min but the last party seated had just been served when we were done. over 30 min wait. 

Noodles were excellent, rich broth and duck (med rare) were novel ideas but pork was almost mushy. No take out or doggie bags. $9 draft beer was prob 12 ounces for lite beer - way overpriced (-1/2 star) and ambience is nonexistent (-1/2 star)

All in all glad I checked it off my list.  but not worth 1-2 hour wait if not front of line.
author: Lena L.

description: Not sure how I feel about the lining up system, the ramen is good though. Big bowls of salty meaty eggy fun~
author: Mingmei N.

description: A original and unique broth.  Very good quality that does stand above most.  But...the sidekick said her meat just disintegrated and not memorable.  No egg.  Rating to other ramen hot spots I'd say: iza ramen, this place, Ippudo (from ny but opening here soon), ramen shop (oakland).  I'd come here more,  but a 1.5 hr wait is a never again...I'm so embarrassed to admit I waited in line.  Such a trendy douche I am.  But the worst part of the wait is that you're stuck in line! ...set up a list and call ppl please!   I could have shopped for some swanky attire or other stuff douches do.
author: A A.

description: Amazing!! Definitely recommend the lamb curry. You cannot go wrong with it.  I would recommend going right before they open or nearing the time they close. It's not worth the 2 hour wait.
author: Caroline H.

description: Super small place. The vegan ramen was $18 (twice as much as my cousins meat ramen) but sooo good. Not super spicy but they call it spicy. Big portions, no takeout or to-go. Go at 4:30 before it opens to avoid waiting in line.
author: Lelyn C.

description:
Good luck getting into Mensho Tokyo.

But if you do, I would highly recommend the Tori Paitan and the Tantanmen. Both are amazing and I would rate the risk of getting addicted as very high.
author: Loubna M.

description:
Here are the longest lines known to man: the DMV, Disneyland's Space Mountain, Immigration line at the international airports, and Mensho's 5PM opening line on a saturday night. Seriously, how the hell do you expect me to wait 2 hours? We get it supply and demand. But there's something wrong when potential customers are leaving frustrated and hungry after waiting in line for an hour and not having move at all (not even an exaggeration). How my girlfriend and I managed is beyond me. You guys must enjoy the free advertisement from having people see other people wait in a line for your food, especially in that part of town. Don't worry! They have no name list and they don't have reservations, and they are not friendly to groups bigger than 3/4 people! So you can slave away and wait in a line for 2 hours to try something that I sincerely believe does not cost $18 a bowl. Ramen isn't supposed to be this expensive. 

I got the Tori Paitan with extra meat for $18. It was OK. Just OK.

All in all, was it worth the wait? No.
Was it worth the price? No.
Was it worth the experience of waiting in line for 2 hours in anticipation for the "best" ramen in SF? For some people yes; for me, paying $16/$18 for a bowl of ramen is more or less daylight robbery. But I get it supply and demand. Well after this review, your business will have one less person demanding this kind of food.
author: Howard K.

description: It must've been our lucky night because we came here with a group of 3 on a Friday night and only waited about 15 minutes. I ordered the tori paitan and it was tasty! A bit rich for my taste as it got heavier and heavier as I ate and to the point where I just couldn't eat anymore of it. It's also a bit pricey compared to other ramen shops. I would definitely recommend though!
author: Irene V.

description: We were second in line 50 minutes before opening time. Was it worth the wait? I think so. It is not like any other ramen I've tried. Pretty unique and I tried the creamy broth and it was super rich. So next time I'll try the organic or shio ramen if muster enough patience to stand in line again.
author: Yen T.

description: No line when I arrived around 6pm. However, the food was not good. The duck had no flavor and the broth was way too thick.
author: Sonny V.

description:
I ate at Mensho Tokyo with my friend last Wednesday night near closing time. I had passed by it a few times and finally found a time with a semi-reasonable wait so we decided to give it a shot. 

I'm vegetarian but have developed a liking for ramen over the years. I was curious to try this place out based on the reviews and demand. 

We waited for about 30 minutes in line and got seats at the bench. I ordered the vegan option and got a side of kale. Normally I like to add eggs to my ramen but that option wasn't available. The ramen was tasty thanks especially to the creamier broth, though it was missing several of the vegetables I normally get. The service wasn't great and you could tell that some of the servers have developed an attitude given the popularity of the restaurant. Also, as expected, the ramen was pricey. We had one of the more expensive beers which was a nice addition. 

Although interesting, this ramen wasn't worth the wait, price, or attitude-y service. I prefer the style I get in most other ramen restaurants. To deal with 60 minute plus wait times and prices that are double that of other restaurants, I'm expecting some world class ramen - and this didn't measure up.
author: Ravi R.

description: This place is fantastic. I order the Lamb or the Pork double chashu and it is the best Ramen I've ever had. The line, however, is beyond insane. They open at 5 so my advice would be to get there at 430 and get in with the first group. Seating is limited an family style seating. The menu is very simplistic but they have the most amazing broth. My girlfriend is vegetarian and she loves the veggie ramen. Lots of non vegetarians come to eat that dish as well. Overall, amazing Ramen, good service, but a really long wait. In my opinion, the wait is worth it!
author: Abhi V.

description: A great ramen joint in SF, especially on a cold night.  We arrived on a Thursday at about 5:20pm and was seated by 6pm.  Not bad!  Highly recommend the shio or shoyu.  The shio is very garlicky if you are into that because I totally am.  The paitan is good too but gets a little heavy after a few slurps.
author: Michelle Y.

description:
It opened at 1750. I arrived at 1650. I ate at 1850.
Ramen is delicious, I could give 4~4.5 without line time.
But it's not delicious enough to spend over 1 hour line again for me.
author: 文廷

description: Wasn't a fan of the thick broth (Tori Paitan Ramen) and the looooong line was definitely not worth the wait. Presentation and plating however was beautiful. 2 stars for effort and presentation. Not much for the taste though..
author: Margarita L.

description:
Overall a solid Ramen experience. The line is understandable with so much hype. The Tori Paitan has solid flavors and umami. My girlfriend has the vegan option and she enjoyed it as well. It seemed like well informed customers also enjoyed the lamb ramen. The best part was definitely the duck slices which were tender, perfectly cooked and different twist from pork chasu.

We also ordered the mushroom appetizer which was unique and flavorful.
author: Aaron C.

description: The Shio Ramen was absolutely delicious. The pork was unlike anything I've ever had. One of the best meals in San Francisco without a doubt. The line was worth the wait and the staff was super friendly. I will definitely be back next time I'm in San Francisco.
author: Lina M.

description: Very bad experience! The waitress tells us they are out of the spicy lamb but after 30min of us ordering, people next to us order the lamb! Then while we were eating they came and asked us if we are finished 6 times and we had to keep saying NO we are still working on it, and at the end the bill came with the gratuity already added (for a party of 2!) I wouldn't recommend going and standing in line for an hour for a fatty Ramen that didn't even taste good :(
author: Kate M.

description: Well worth the wait. Excellent ramen and cheap Sapporo. The staff was so nice. A homeless woman barged in, touched my friend's bowl of ramen and wouldn't leave. The friendly staff brought her out a bowl of ramen but she refused it. She only wanted money. Finally she left. The staff apologized, brought out a new bowl of ramen and didn't charge us for the beer. Talk about customer service. My new favorite spot.
author: Blake S.

description: Wow! First time and I don't think I'll ever order something different after having the vegan ramen with soy egg and burdock root. Absolutely the best ramen I've ever had.
author: R. P.

description: Very displeased with the service here. Came in a group of 10 and was divided separately. Understandable considering the small space. Was not able share food amongst friends even though I wasn't super hungry so I ordered and figured I'd take it to go later on. However, I found out later on when I asked for a box, they state in *fine print* that we can't take any food to go. One of the waitresses was really rude and aggressive about everything we had to ask, will not be coming back.
author: Tiana P.

description: Totally doesn't worth the time to wait... Very crowded.. Soup is very salty and noodle is just enough for a girl. Never go there again! Don't try if u see the long line.
author: Ying S.

description: It is very different from Ramen Dojo and Ramen parlour in San Mateo. Tori Paitan with double chashu is the real deal. Standing in the line is totally worth it.
author: Ash M.

description: Meh I don't know what's the big deal is. The soup is too oily. They don't have spicy miso.  The noodle is good. Slightly too fat, consistency is good. Nothing special about the flavor. Place is too loud which is often used practice to kick you out quickly. Loud customers trying to talk over the loud music. I rather go other ok place that's solid and I can hear the person who is sitting across the table. I think ppl like it just cuz the loudness and hecticness amp their adrenaline or something.
author: A O.

description: I was right, I did end up craving their Tori Paitan ramen. So, I went back again and this time... it was SO MUCH better! It was still thick and creamy, but not as heavy as the first time I've had it. I also came another time and had their tsukemen. Probably the best tsukemen I've had in the bay area. Definitely get it if they're serving it when you're there. They have a limited serving of it.
author: Lina C.

description: So this place had a HUGE line which honestly was a good sign I don't mind a wait. I do mind a wait when it's not worth it though. I am here visiting friends and they told me how great this place was so I was pretty excited. We got in after an hour wait, still on board at this point, and we sit down and get our food pretty fast. Yes finally what I've been waiting for. It's pretty good too. Pork chashu was really good/tender and the lamb had spot on spice. Broth was pretty good and the duck chashu was also just alright, didn't really fall apart like the pork. So overall rather food was like 4-4.5 out of 5. Pretty good right? After eating we come to find out we can't take home any of the food I paid for. That makes no sense. Why can't I take my leftovers? Do I get to pay less since you are throwing away some of my food? So that made me upset, but then they refused to split our bill. I understand that splitting a bill can be annoying but I'm paying for service and food, and not getting the service. The vibe from the place also felt very pretentious and overrated the whole time. The service to me was a flat 0 out of 5. Not my waitress' fault but the businesses for making ridiculous rules.
author: Cameron K.

description: yum. Love ramen! Waited for about an hour for 2..  Got the Tori Paitan it is as described on the menu rich and creamy...the duck chashu was sooo juicy. The pork chashu just got lost in all the flavor. Wish there was a little more kale. All in all a good first impression just wish that the wait wasn't so long...maybe I'll try the Shio next time.
author: Fanny C.

description: For a small and busy restaurant, the wait time and turnover was fast. The was a line outside as the restaurant is very small but, the hostesses come out to survey the line and move the customers in quickly. The food is good, large portions. If you are not familiar with noodles, the pictures and description helps.
author: LaTisha T.

description: i refuse to stand in line anywhere but this place is so great that i would go back and i would spend time in line to get there
author: Hanna G.

description: I liked it. I got their limited broth thing a while ago. It was late at night and they still had some so i'm not sure if it's really limited lol
author: Francisco B.

description: The ramen is absolutely delicious.  A few twists you don't normally find, like kale and bamboo shoots, but the noodles were perfectly al dente and dense and the chicken broth was cooked so well it just coated the noodles perfectly and marinated your mouth  with every bite.  The lines are long but this was a normal occurrence with the ramen shops in Japan where I just visited (and after a 5-hour wait at the Tokyo Fish Market, this was a breeze).  The chicken broth and noodles reminded me of the famous Kagari Ramen in the Ginza district of Tokyo.  Prices are high but totally worth it.  My only disappointment was they don't include an egg.
author: Max G.

description: I'm not impressed. After waiting over an hour in line on a beautiful sunday afternoon, I ordered 3 bowls of ramen: Tori Paitan, Organic Shoyu, and Shio, with extra duck in each. The Tori was super rich and creamy. It reminded me of my favorite ramen place in the world, Yume Wo Katare in MA Cambridge, except the bowl is way smaller, the soup less complex, and the noodle lacking in texture. The organic shoyu was super one-dimensional and overwhelmingly salty. If that is all I got after all this hype and wait, I'm disappointed. The shio ramen was my favorite. The flavor was there, not too salty with a hint a zest in the mix, but again, nothing stood out, no surprises, no kick, just a pretty girl with no personality. I kept looking out the window looking at the beautiful sunset glow masking the dirty tenderloin street side, wishing I had made better use of my time.
author: Alvin D.

description:
Don't waste your money on this fake Ramen restaurant!
The ramen is horrible! Don't know why so many people went to this restaurant before, but today when I arrived, I understood, they serving just 4 table to make people have to wait~in downtown Geary Blvd, smart idea! But the ramen is sucks! I'm living in Tokyo for one year, never have Other wired stuff in the ramen, but Mensho! They put KALE in the soup instead of other vegetables!!! I never heard before! I understand California people like kale, but it is not professional to cooking and put ingredients like that. Please ask any Japanese who would put kale inside, and the Lamb Ramen I ordered was totally garbage! The soup is too thick which made the noodle all broken, the meat were all melted (I even ordered double chashu)even the restaurants located in Fillmore Japan town won't serve this kind of noodle. So, people who have seen the line outside the Mensho, don't be fooled by their trick to make them looks popular！
author: Kong D.

description:
1. Favorite: Organic Shoyu!  Duck AND pork in ramen?  Say no more.  Broth is lighter and clear compared to the Tori Paitan broth.
2. Others: Tori Paitan broth is thick and gritty, like a sauce (as if they blended the bones into the broth.  Who knows, they actually might. Saw blenders in the kitchen).  Vegan tantan is surprisingly heavy with tons of nuts.  Heads up: none of the sobas come with soup! 
3.  Expect to wait in line and leave with an unhappy stomach later. Yikes, TMI I know. Prob because the kitchen does not look very sanitary.
author: Brett C.

description: I hate writing bad reviews so lets just say that this isnt the place for me.
author: Portia P.

description: Delicious but they have one MAJOR flaw. No to go Tupperware? Because it wouldn't taste the same? That is outrageous, to throw away all of that food. I went with a couple of friends and no one was able to finish their ramen. Even though it is some of the best ramen I've had, I'm not sure I can support this business. If you're going to go, consider sharing.
author: Lourdes A.

description: Came here on a Friday night and waited about 40 minutes outside (group of 3). Wasn't too cold so didn't totally mind the wait but we got hangrier by the minute after awhile! When we finally got seated (at the bar which had really cool coffee glass jars display, we thought it was interesting for a ramen place) we were given the chance to order fairly quickly. We all knew exactly what we were getting: tori paitan double double (duck and pork). My two friends both got the lychee sake which they brought out and poured into a glass in a box so it wouldn't spill when you drank it and if you did spill, you wouldn't waste anything. First time I've seen this and it was pretty cool! Our ramen came out shortly after and oh. My. God. I've never really been a huge ramen lover but this was beyond amazing, can't describe the rich unique flavor of the broth and everything they put in it, knocked my socks off, YUM! I sadly burned my tongue earlier in the day on coffee, but it was just as delicious and makes me want to come back soon! I shall be back the next time I need my ramen fix
author: June L.

description: This place is overrated not worth the line. Got the popular Tori paitan was super thick and very salty. No umami flavoring. Maybe their regular ramen is better. Only highlight was the duck and the noodles were cooked perfectly and also the excellent service. I would definitely skip the line next time and eat ramen elsewhere but if there is no line or if I arrive before they open I will pop in and try a new dish.
author: Jay H.

description: Best Vegan thing I ever ate was the ramen at this place.  The perfect noodles in a creamy-peanut broth.  Eat it.
author: Rob S.

description: After planning for weeks about the best time to come here, we finally decided to come here on a Tuesday evening at 5:15. There was (of course) already a line outside (presumably before they even opened). We waited around 45 minutes before being seated (party of 4), which was actually a lot faster than we expected. My boyfriend originally wanted to order Tonkotsu Ramen as it was one of the dish written on the wall, but apparently they're still doing a limited opening and Tonkotsu wasn't one of the dish we can order. We all opted to then get the Tori Paitan, which was what they're famous for. IMO the Tori Paitan is even more rich than Tonkotsu (it's basically a white thick chicken broth). So if you're not really into rich broth, opt for the Shoyu or Shio ramen (Shoyu, imo, is less rich compared to Shio). It was super delicious, comes with both duck and pork chashu (my boyfriend opted to get double chashu), and the noodle is pretty thick with a nice chewiness. One thing I hope they will add in the future would be an option for extra noodle. Is it the best ramen place in the bay? I personally still like Orenchi and Ramen Dojo/Parlor better, but it's definitely in the top 5 (especially if the wait isn't as long and they have a more extensive menu). I would come back again if the wait is under an hour, but overall, 5/5 in terms of food quality!
author: Sharon L.

description: Mensho Tokyo is the newest ramen shop in SF, with lines out the door at least an hour before opening almost every night. My boyfriend and I got in line at around 4:45 PM on a Saturday, and waited almost an hour and half to get into the restaurant. We learned the story behind the store while talking to the owner, who is a Bay Area native and well-known ramen critic in Japan. For now, they only have a couple of their ramens on the menu and a oyster appetizer. I had the vegan tantanmen, which was one of the most flavorful vegan broths I've ever had. Made out of seven kinds of nuts, it had a hearty flavor and thick texture that was coated on each noodle just perfectly. The noodles themselves were some of the best I've had, both chewy and thick. I loved the additional toppings, from the menma to the edamame. My boyfriend had the tori paitan, their specialty ramen, which comes with both pork and duck chashu. Again, the broth had such well-developed flavor. I'm hoping the lines start to dissipate because I'm dying to go back for the ramen here as it's definitely some of the best you can find in San Francisco!
author: Ashley T.

description:
I ordered the tori paitan ramen and the broth was really good. It was a rich creamy chicken broth. It kinda reminded me of the instant creamy chicken flavor but not as salty lol. I ordered it with double chashu and it only came with 2 big pieces and 2 small thumb sized pieces...
Be ready for a long wait because the place is pretty small.
Overall it was good, but not $18 good lol
author: Daniel H.

description:
YUMMY! Came here on a Tuesday night at 8 and waited probably 40+ minutes to be seated. Definitely come early or be prepared to wait. Their turnover seems pretty fast, though. Once seated we were out the door within 30-40 minutes.

They mainly serve ramen, with a few additional snacks. I got the tori paitan ramen, which was amazing and well worth the wait. It was like drinking the most umami gravy, with perfectly cooked piping hot noodles and really flavorful toppings. 

I don't know if I would jump to wait in line again... but man that was some amazing ramen.
author: J L.

description: I came here when it first opened and waited maybe...15 minutes? I tried again in April 2017, and the wait was much longer. At like 6:30 pm in the pouring rain and gusting wind the wait was an hour. Still, I don't mind the wait. I always get the tori paitan and it's always delicious. What I like about this place is they seem to cook each ingredient in the ramen bowl separately so that each element is perfectly cooked. The noodles have just the right level of firmness and springy quality, the chashu slices and duck slices are also cooked perfectly so the meat is melt-in-your mouth tender, each vegetable is the right texture. If you need more spice, you can ask the wait staff for chili sauce or shichimi powder. You can also order extra meat, extra egg, extra vegetables etc., for extra $. The oysters are not worth ordering in my opinion. They are tiny and hard and covered in a sweet sauce and taste like the kind of oysters you get out of a Chinese can. Ambiance: you sit REALLY close to the people next to you and the seats are backless high stools. In other words, stay home if you want to be comfortable. Come to Mensho if you want to eat ridiculously good ramen!
author: Cat M.

description: Rating low so people will stop going and I can actually eat here again. SOOOO GOOOOD
author: Eric A.

description:
I like it. Do I love it? Nah.  We waited an hour in the line. I don't think this is worth a 2-3 hour wait. So for those of you thinking about it; just wait until the hype dies down and they've worked out the kinks. 

For two of us (we needed to make it worth our while to wait):

1.) tori paitan:  this was pretty tasty. Rich, without being too heavy. Garlic was yummy, but not overpowering. The pork and duck chasu were really good; not sure I would pay $2 or $1.50 for an small extra slice of either though. I liked the noodles in this one better than the other two.  I do think that overall, these aren't the best ramen noodles I've ever had. I like mine with more bite/chew to them. These noodles were maybe 1-2 mins too long. Also, towards the middle to the end of the bowl, I got a lot of residue/grit/something. I think they need to strain the broth a few more times to get rid of that stuff. It was a bad way to end the bowl. 

2.) shoyu: this was my favorite bowl of the three. It had a nice subtle sweetness and was flavorful. The soup gave my mouth a nice coat, but it wasn't fatty or greasy. But, as mentioned above, I didn't love the actual ramen noodles. Too soggy and they were different than the tori paitan noodles and not springy at all. 

3.) shio:  this was was also nice. Good, clean flavor. I like the garlic in this, also. I probably won't remember this one in a month. 

4.) oysters:  pass. I've had better smoked ones from Whole Foods. 

Service was good; they are trying really hard. 

I think they need to construct the table to be more stabilized. Every time some sat down and leaned on the table, it would knock the other end of the table. Could be hazardous with molten bowls of porky soup. 

The lines for this place tells me that SF is in dire need for some great, not good ramen.  Maybe we can send some of our good LA ramen juju up north.
author: Victoria S.

description:
Came here today (Friday night) at 7:40 & waited about 45 minutes to get seated, which I guess isn't too bad given this restaurant's reputation. The restaurant is small & not really the most comfortable. You sit on high stools which I personally am not a big fan of and are seated at communal tables so it's hard to have an intimate conversation. Also there doesn't seem to be any place to hang your purse aside from dropping it in the basket on the ground. 
I got the tori paitan & my bf got the shoyu ramen. I read reviews that said the tori ramen is too creamy & I didn't think I would mind because I tend to like creamy, fatty foods.. but it really was a bit too much for me. Still really delicious, rich, & flavorful, though! The pork was perfectly fatty & pretty much broke apart as soon as you touched it. The noodles are perfectly QQ! I think overall I liked the shoyu broth more because it's more clear/less heavy.
Was it worth the $16 & the wait? I would say yes, because I heard about this place for so long & didn't feel disappointed. If I lived nearby, it definitely wouldn't be my monthly or even bimonthly ramen place (who wants to wait that long all the time? then again, it is SF) but I'll definitely revisit when I'm craving some authentic ramen.
author: Jacqueline K.

description:
I was truly excited as I waited in line to try the ramen here, and got here with my friend a full 45 minutes to wait before the restaurant opened (we were not even the first party to arrive!). Luckily, we made the first seating though! 

Food: My rating for this place ultimately comes down to the food. I ordered the Tori Paitan ramen with double chashu. Long story short, I was just not impressed and this type of ramen is just not to my liking. The broth, while very flavorful, had an overly rich taste and was just a bit too salty to be enjoyable. It was also very opaque, so you couldn't quite see what else was in your bowl without having to fish around in it. The noodles though were actually tasty, and had a nice texture and bite...slightly reminiscent of an udon noodle, but not as thick. Overall, too much for me to handle after more than just a few bites. I was actually sad that they do not have to go boxes since this was way too much for me to handle in one sitting. 

Service: The people here are welcoming and friendly, especially since the location is quite small. I never found it difficult to let someone know if I needed anything like a water refill or the bill. The one issue that my party had was communicating with some of the people here when we had questions. I had a difficult time understanding them, so at some points I just nodded my head in agreement. 

Atmosphere: The restaurant is tiny on the inside and seating is done on communal tables (so you might not know who is across or to the left or right of you). I didn't mind so it was not too much of an issue. I do wish that there were other seating options besides stools, especially after waiting outside for so long. It would have been nice to have some back support to make the dining experience more comfortable (though I do understand the stools for aesthetic purposes). There are also baskets under each table for you to store your things, which are convenient too. This location also has just one bathroom, which had an unusual odor to it, but since it's located so close to the dining and kitchen area, there was not an opportunity to properly air it out. Better ventilation in the dining room would have also been appreciated because the aroma of the rich flavored food was a bit intense at times. 

If the hype ever dies down, I might come back here and try another noodle option, but based on my first experience I am in certainly no rush. I wish they took to-go orders (or at least a boxing option), but perhaps that's an area they can get into once their business starts to grow. I would also like to see them adopt a sign in system either manually or through an app instead of just having people wait in a long line. This would give people some mobility instead of having to wait outside until room clears up for dining.
author: Daniel H.

description: Ramen was decently priced for the quality (which was amazing) however the lamb ramen had a very thick based soup--thicker than curry, and was extremely salty. It was salty to the point where it muted and underwhelmed all the other flavors in the bowl. I really appreciated the service and portion sizes and liked the ambiance. The service was amazing! Waiters were attentive and accommodating for large parties! However $200 for 7 bowls of ramen and a couple of beers and three oyster appetizers, is not bad. I will go again, but this time I will try a lighter broth which I believe is the most popular here, because it was sold out by the time my party came.
author: Jennifer N.

description: Came here on a Sunday night around 8 and there was about 15 people ahead of me. Line moved fairly quick. There was a menu outside the restaurant for you to look out but there's also items listed on the wall inside the restaurant that they don't have on the menu! Ordered the Tori Paitan ramen and I really enjoyed it. Loved the creamy broth and thickness of the noodles that not many ramen places have. I would say that the ramen here is a bit overpriced and really sad that they don't have eggs (I saw that they had it before in some of the other review pics).
author: Jessica L.

description: In VietNam, can i eat camen? it is verry delicious
author: Hkc V.

description: HORRIBLE server. He asked my friend to leave in THE most rude way on a night that wasn't busy because two of my friends wanted to share a ramen. When they said that wasn't ok, one of my friends said he just wouldn't eat but would sit with us. To this the waiter demanded he left. When we asked for the manager (because none of this was noted anywhere in the restaurant or obviously we would have complied) our waiter never notified the manager. We had to ask a separate server to send the manager over because ours was trying to cover his tracks. Unbelievable.
author: Kassie M.

description: Pretty good! Not sure if the wait is worth it to come regularly, though. My friend was in line since around 4:45 and there were already a good number of 20+ people ahead of her. When they opened at 5, we were just 7-10 people behind and waited about 30-45 minutes to get in. We were served promptly and both ordered the original. My friend ordered the double menshu for $18 (my single was $16) and I wish I had! The meat was really tender and melted in your mouth and the fried onions and kale were well done compliments to the ramen. Noodles were big, too. I like creamy soup so I really enjoyed this one. I can see how it could be one of the best ramen places in SF (hopefully not the only was this good; it's not THE best I've ever had in my opinion but I guess it's hard to stand out). Polite and quick service :) they were working really hard.
author: Fabiha H.

description: Best ramen in town. There's always a line but it's worth the wait. Menu is limited but don't let it fool you, it's all good. Good price to portion ratio especially for eating in the city.
author: Ikaika F.

description: Considering the mediocre selection of ramen in SF, Mensho is probably the best place in the city. I liked everything about their Tori Paitan except the gritty broth. I just went to Ten Ten Yu in LA the other week and their tori paitan is super bland in comparison. However, waiting outside in a single file line in the cold of SF is just demeaning.
author: Shirley H.

description: I also had very high expectations of this place. I ordered the shio and thought it was pretty solid but also nothing to rave over, and a tad too salty. I am interested in trying the other options even though it's overpriced.  This isn't the kind of place you come expecting great service, but it was underwhelming to say the least. They had cleared my bowl when my friend was still eating her ramen. They brought the check at once, and literally three different waiters came by to check if we had put our credit cards down, where I had to point out to one that my friend was still eating. After we paid, we were drinking some water and the main lady literally kicked us out of the place. I didn't see them doing this to anyone else so I'm not sure why we were treated this way or if it was just a hectic night.
author: M C.

description: Hour wait so be prepared, food was amazing. I had the pork ramen, my girlfriends got the vegan and spicy lamb. All 3 were amazing but the spicy lamb was probably the best due to the spicy flavor. $15 a bowl or so, the lycee sale was only 1 large shot and served super weird but had a good taste. We would love to visit here again before we leave.
author: Kim G.

description: Came twice in one weekend while staying in SF because the ramen was so tasty! I was a little hesitant from some yelp reviews that said it was over priced or over hyped, but so glad we stuck it out and tried it. The first night around 6pm was a Friday and we waited about an hour, but we knew ahead of time based on reviews we would. Seating is a little awkward maybe depending on who your neighbor's are since you sit across from the person you are dinning with, but the food is totally worth it. My boyfriend and I came back on a Sunday around 10pm, got right in no wait, and sat at the little bar area facing the cooks. We loved it and enjoyed the atmosphere a little bit more than the first night since we could be closer. I got a double the second time and it was delicious once again. I thought the quality and amount of food was perfect for the price and the ramen noodles were perfect and broth soooo tasty. Not a place you go with a big group to sit and chat but if you want delicious ramen they deliver for sure! Can't wait to come back.
author: Devon S.

description:
Delicious Ramen! Great service as well 
Only drawback is the wait, an hour to hour and a half.
author: M D R 1.

description: Came here on a rainy day and the line was still an hour wait. Ordered the tori paitan and the broth was really thick like gravy. If you're into thick broths then I think you might like this place, but for me its a no go. I think this place is over hyped and I much rather go to ramen dojo for my ramen fix. There's also only one restroom, so don't block the waitress walking back and forth from the kitchen. She also gave us our bill when half of my party was still eating, but I get it there's a lot of people waiting. Maybe I'll give this place another try, but definitely not ordering that ramen again.
author: Helen C.

description: I ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen. The broth was intense and deep with flavor. The noodles were good with the right amount of chewy bite. The char siu melted in my mouth. Overall, best ramen I've had in SF.
author: Andrew T.

description:
Food poisoning.

The food itself - and I only had the pork ramen - was probably 3.5 to 4 stars. Just solid ramen with an unusually thick broth, but not out of the world.

The 1 star is driven by the severe - and this may be an understatement - case of food poisoning I got. I know it was here because I haven't had a meal during the day.

Apparently two others have gotten food poisoning in the past month too. I will be reporting this to the food safety agency and filing a credit chargeback as soon I'm in the physical condition to do so.
author: Jack W.

description: Visiting for a conference and found this place on Yelp and it does not disappoint.  Don't be discouraged by the line outside...it's worth it.  I had the Tori Paitan double and it was excellent.  Very authentic.  My wife had the Vegan and it was also very good but has a good amount of heat to it so be prepared.
author: Matt F.

description: Awesome ramen. Probably the best ramen I ever had in SF. Broth is truly amazing. Line is long and expect to wait more than an hour before getting in. You cannot really make a reservation for a table.
author: Kilim C.

description: Finally San Francisco has good ramen! Waited 40 minutes on Tuesday to try this much anticipated spot. The Shio is perfect. I'll be back often.
author: Jason W.

description: So a friend recommended this place because it was close by and always a line out the door, turns out, the line is because it's so small and can't accommodate groups of more than 3. The reason for my low rating is because they DO NOT let you share and they DO NOT let you take the food YOU PAID FOR to go. Just blew my mind because my husband and I are small eaters and wanted to share a large bowl, they refused.  So we ordered our own bowl ($18 each) and when we asked to take our left overs which was a LOT they refused to let us take it. Bullshit if you ask me since I was forced to order my own bowl. Go to Ramen Shop in Oakland instead. ABSOLUTELY worth the trip and AMAZING ramen that you can share and take home if you want.
author: Lolly M.

description:
Unfriendly service. Had to order at least one bowl per person. Server was very bossy so we left disappointed without ordering.

In addition to this horrible service the menu on the wall is valid in "the future". Of course you don't know this until your bossy server says it.
author: Freddy E.

description: Let's be honest, all the hype. Overpriced ramen, yes it's good but it's not life changing. I wouldn't crave it on a rainy day, especially for the price. I probably wouldn't come back either. The place is small and is not good for group restaurants. I would never go back. First of all she chased us outside for tip because she didn't think what we left her enough. So rude, very rude and we were shocked. Never again, if I can leave 0 stars I would.
author: Francis D.

description: I am a fan! Great Ramen! Happy that the wait was less than 15 minutes which made the ramen taste even better. But I would wait in line for thirty minutes just to get my ramen fix taken cared of. Although the sitting area is very tight, which I assumed it would be, it didn't matter to me. Dee~lish!
author: Zen W.

description: Was looking forward to trying the spicy miso, but they were out! I had something else instead. It was thick. Not the type of ramen I am used to, but still good. Will try again soon.
author: Jim R.

description:
Unbelievable! Went here at 10pm when there was no line on Sunday night. 
Got the Tori Paitan with green onions. WORTH THE HYPE! yum yum
Also, they overflow the Saki. Good luck ;)
author: Christina P.

description: Best ramen in the city, hands down. Has a very unique vibe. Their ramen is different from any other ramen I've ever had, from the thick noodles to the creamy broth. I had the tori paiten and it was amazing. It was rich but not overwhelming, and the noodles were think and crunchy but not to hard. Their duck chasu was delicious soft velvety texture and not overwhelming. Basically it's the best ramen you'll probably have for a while.
author: J Y.

description: Best vegan ramen of my life! Every component was delicious; the soup was nutty and full bodied, the ramen was perfect. I think people will always try to find something to complain about- these guys focus on the quality of the ingredients and it works. If you want a ton of stuff in your ramen like the "sushi" in the states, this isn't it. Simple food done right!
author: Gina N.

description: Line was so long even on a Thursday at 5pm but the ramen was pretty darn good. Extremely rich broth! I only didn't like that it seemed like the waitresses were watching us like vultures so that they could pick off our bowls as soon as they thought we were finished. (Do they not have enough bowls or something??) That kind of ruined the experience for me but I do understand, since there's a lot of people waiting in line.
author: Jannet H.

description:
It's fine. Did it match the hype and the hour wait in line? I can't say it did. Was it tasty? Sure, but I don't relate to / understand the zealous desire of many to repeatedly go back and waste a perfectly good evening in line for what is only a decent bowl of noodles with a large side of hyperbolic food conversations.

My wife and I are glad we tried it, and we agree that we've had much better at places with more menu options, shorter waits, and less insufferable fanboys. I likely won't be returning by my own will.
author: Patrick C.

description: I waited in line on the third day of their opening on a Tuesday night,  and waited for an hour around 7pm. The wait wasn't too bad. I ordered the Tori Taipan with charsui pork. The creamy broth was too much, too thick and creamy and a little on the salty side. The noodles itself was decent, thick and chewy. I'd come back here to give it another try, and I would try the lighter broths next time, but is it worth the wait? I'd say no, but I'd come back if there was no line or just a short wait. Definitely didn't have the Umami feeling with their tori taipan, as I hoped it would.
author: L V.

description: Worth the wait, period.  The depth of flavor and loads of umami elevates this Ramen to a whole new level.  Yes there can be a wait, but the service is very fast and seats rotate quickly.
author: Thor P.

description: I loved this place. After waiting so long in line, I sort of needed it to be *even* better than it was, but it was very tasty and a fun introduction to a cult import.
author: E G.

description:
I should have been more wary going into a restaurant with thumping club music at 5pm and a line forming up a half-hour prior, but c'est la vie. I found the whole mensho package to be a transparent exploitation of a hype driven food scene with little to back it up.

The walls were covered with text about umami and dashi and all the different types of ramen they had, except they didn't have those types of Ramen, a bit misleading to have a list on the wall that isn't relevant. I ordered the Tori Paitin Ramen, it was rich and creamy and perfectly decent, but for the first time in the history of Ramen I had no trouble finishing my portion. I was still hungry afterwards. I also was not the only person at the communal table who ordered it with double chasu only to find that meant two smallish slices instead of 1...
A TV on the wall was distracting, and just showed a medley of Ramen bowls and young Japanese ladies with their hands over their mouths laughing at the huge portions (about twice the size as the one in front of me....).

I ordered a Sapporo and after taking my menu the waitress asked if I wanted to try the premium malt, I did, but buyer beware; instead of a 5$ sapporo I got a small 10$ beer that tasted the same.

The 3 stars are for the Ramen, because it was legitimately good. Broth was rich, chasu was very tender. No egg, and kale added nothing to it. For 3$ less at any other joint you can get much more food without a line, or servers trying to up-sell you on a 10$ sapporo.
author: Rory K.

description: heavy drinkable broths with great satisfying rich flavor are hard to come by.  the creamy chicken broth stands for SF, and the pork mixed with duck chashu and burdock really stand out.  menma and kale make it a great SF bowl with thick wavy noodle, falls apart a bit though. wait still there at night, but not too bad like when it opened.  $20 doesn't go very far these days.
author: Rob C.

description: This place has great ramen. I had an order a few days ago and though I'd say it's not particularly value efficient, it is high quality.
author: Kevin W.

description: Super delicious. I got the tori paitan with extra kale. Definitely enough food. The broth was soupy heaven and the noodles were heavy and chewy. Excellent. A friend got the shoyu but I didn't enjoy it as much, the broth was too bonito-y for my taste. Also started with the oysters. Those were decent but nothing to write home about. Overall 5 stars
author: Christopher L.

description: Ok, Noodles and meat were good, broth too salty for my taste
author: Andee L.

description: Mensho is pretty legit in a town with a lot of choices for ramen. The noodles are chewy and the broth is complex and flavorful. I've only tried the shoyu and vegan ramen. I have tried friends' taipan, the signature dish, but I find the broth too thick for me. What's inside the taipan is good, but I don't suggest drinking all the broth unless you're really hungry or like creamy soups. It's communal counter seating, and I'm hoping to try other items on their menu soon.
author: Ellen S.

description: I got the tori paitan ramen and for 16 bucks a plate I was expecting my taste buds to be blown away by the taste. Once I took a sip of the broth I was disappointed.
author: Dani O.

description:
The Wait: Not nearly as bad as we thought it would be. Got in line about 9:15PM on a Saturday and we were seated shortly before 10PM. The staff is very efficient so tables flip quickly. 

The Dining Room: 28 seats, all community style tables. A little tight, but we didn't even notice once the food arrived because our faces were glued to our bowls the rest of the night. Simple and clean design with cool lighting. 

The Food: The Tori Paitan was incredibly rich, with thicker noodles. The chashu literally melts in your mouth, and combined with the creamy broth delivered a monster umami punch. The broth itself definitely rivals most tonkotsu's I've had in terms of richness. The fact that it was so robust without being very oily was a huge plus too. The chashu is literally the best I've ever had, and I'm definitely adding a few extra pieces next time I go. The duck was a bit cool and I probably would've preferred it a little more done, but the texture balanced with everything else in the bowl. No eggs available which I thought was a bit odd, but it was rich enough even without it.

Bottom Line: Best ramen I've had in the city. Totally worth the wait and price. If you're like me and were let down by the new Orenchi and Ramen Bar, you'll be relieved to know Mensho hit a home run here. My go to ramen place from now on!
author: Sebastian A.

description:
This was my very first ramen experience outside of Mr.Noodles... 
Amazing little spot. Waiting in line at 8pm on a Sunday night for about 20 minutes. The wait wasn't very bad, and definitely worth it. This location of Mensho as I understand is the first outside of Tokyo so that really added to the allure and why we waited. I was with a group of 3. 
I ordered the Tori Paitan Big fan, it was rich and creamy very easy to enjoy. Strong pork influence but they were open to modifications. My friend modified hers to be without the pork piece. 
Super happy with this spot.
author: Alana A.

description: The line was long. You're in SF long waits for good /new food is expected. Don't let that steer you away! Mensho is delicious!! I had the vegan option and oh my laaawd! I didn't want it to end. The servers were extremely sweet and the very experienced ramen critic (who's name is slipping at the moment) was extremely helpful and knowledgeable of the ramen. Overall great place , keep it up , I'll definitely be back !
author: Brenda E.

description: The wait wasn't as bad as expected for prime dinner time on a friday. Ramen was amazing. The European style seating was also kinda fun. Best ramen I've had in the bay.
author: Nick B.

description: Really loved their sushi's here ! Very clean and quick service. A little more flavor in the ramen and consider it a 5 star!
author: Jackie R.

description: Not bad food, but the sevice was utter crap......I wont be back.....dont know about you, but i dont like having people be rude to me when im supporting their business.......
author: Nathan A.

description: Tried Tori Paitan, Shio, oysters, the premium malt beer, and the Japanese IPA-- ramen and beers where excellent, the IPA is more like a traditional IPA than an American (more malt).  The oysters didn't really impress, reminded me too much of canned oysters to justify the price.  The wait isn't too bad (20-30 minutes) if you go on an off day, and later in the evening (after 8 or so).
author: Jason M.

description: Ramens are chewy and well made. Not quite impressed by the overall quality. Broth is a bit too salty. Service is fine. Long line even after 10PM.
author: S N.

description: Best ramen I have ever eaten. The long wait was well worth it. I ordered the Tori Pairan and it was So comforting and flavorful. The pork melts in ur mouth and the broth is creamy and rich.
author: Liz D.

description:
Overhyped. 
We felt a little rushed, as soon as we sat, the waitress came to take the order. The food was not bad but we expected much more.
save yourself some time and money.
author: K S.

description: I'm a person that doesn't really like Ramen but this place was delicious! I waited 40 minutes, but when we finally got a table it was so worth it. It will turn a non-ramen person into a ramen fanatic.
author: Kelly P.

description: Off the hook! Hands down, the best Ramen spot in SF! The IPA paired with the Organic Shoyu was nice! If you wanna flavor kick of rich & creamy the tori is for you!!!!
author: Issy V.

description: Let me save you from calling. No reservations. Best time to visit is on Tuesday between 10-11:30. And now, its a two hour wait.
author: Judy L.

description: the broth is excellent as are the noodles.  the meat and kale were ok.  Really great ramen overall, though there is a 30 minute stand in line wait.  unforgettable broth.  pass on the $13 bottle of Japanese beer, it is mediocre at best and ipa'ish.  Make sure you go to the corner store and brown bag a sapporo while you wait in line.  The ramen is very good as  I already said.  I was erect.
author: Tom P.

description: A+ food and service. Don't be fooled by the line outside the door. Once the wave of people are done eating their food, the whole line was pretty much gone. I think I waited 10 mins in total. This was on a Thursday night though. I got the Tori Paitan Ramen with double chashu. It was creamy rich but not as salty as the typical ramen and chashu that I've typically had. The double chashu is just an extra slice of chashu. I also got the oysters and it was refreshing. It was marinated and very salty and actually complimented my ramen very well. Highly recommended!
author: Laura Y.

description: Best ramen I've had in the city. Come here, you have to try it! But beware of the line that starts forming before the place even opens!
author: Petrea R.

description: Was super happy with the service. I liked the fact it wasn't some wannabe fancy over priced restaurant but still had the water front view and good service. drink menu was pretty unique lots of cool drinks and beers to try out. Overall I recommend going .
author: Rick K.

description: Great place to eat. Loved the authentic Ramen. I am a huge fan and would go back again
author: Michael F.

description:
(keeping this short)
Might bowl of tasty!
Looking forward to how the chef plans to expand the menu when he returns next month. 
I'll be back :)
author: Angel L.

description: Had to wait forever just to try this place. This was good, but not worth the 1 1/2 hour wait!  However, it is worth trying.You eat at a community table and they seat you were they can fit you. Don't expect to have privacy and to have a sit down where you can eat, have an intimate convo and take your jolly time. When you're done you gosta go. The portion is good, service is good and food is good. Glad I tried it, but not going again anytime soon unless there's not wait.
author: melinda v.

description: This is hands down the best ramen place in SF. It opened just a few weeks ago, and there are always super long lines in front of the restaurant. I live only a block away so I stood in line 45 minutes before they opened. I was still the 10th person in line...crazy! It was well worth the wait however. The ramen is definitely the best ramen in the city. I ordered the Tori Paitan ramen with double chashu. This is definitely the way to go...order the double chashu!!! The broth is creamier than other ramen places I've tried; the waiters told me it was because it is slow cooked in pork bone (yummy!!!). It is a bit pricier compared to other ramen places in the city. The Tori Paitan with double chashu costs $18 and a normal Tori Paitan is $16. I would pay the additional $2 for the double chashu; it's worth it. I like that they added a vegan option for the vegans/vegetarians in the Bay Area. I came here with my friend whos vegetarian and she got to enjoy the amazing ramen as well. All in all, a great experience at a new gem in the city.
author: Rebecca D.

description: This place definitely lived up to the hype. The ramen here is not too pricey, it's a pretty hefty portion so you can share with someone else. The wait is crazy long, but totally worth the wait.
author: Tracy V.

description: The wait was just too long for the food I was getting. It's good ramen but nothing like the real deal in Japan.
author: Jennifer L.

description: Very nice place for sushi downtown. We met for a business dinner, great food and people.
author: Kirk M.

description: Got the Tori Paitan. Bomb. I will try the other broths in the future and give yet another detailed review.
author: Gabriel G.

description:
I will preface my review by saying that I'm not a huge fan of ramen, so take what I say with a grain of salt (there are always too many grains of salt in ramen).

I came here with a ramen connoisseur who also knew a lot about the history and beginnings of this restaurant, so I probably appreciated it a little more. Apparently upon opening, there was always a 1+ hour wait. The restaurant only fits ~30, so definitely not a place for larger parties. We came here on a Sunday evening at around 7 PM and the wait was ~45 minutes for a party of 6. All the broths they currently offer are chicken based for now. They're planning to come out with a tonkatsu one and start making their own noodles soon. I had the spicy dry ramen with the habaneros on the side. The orange pickled habaneros were so delicious! Beware if your spicy threshold is not high b/c it'll definitely leave you gasping for air. Overall, I think the ingredients are very high quality and the ramen is tasty. However, the cons are $18 for a very small portion (they do not allow to-go boxes -_-) and extremely salty!
author: Chinh T.

description: I feel bad for giving an honest 3 stars, but look at all the 5 stars they got! Mine is just going to get lost in the pile. Anyway, lucky I work close by, I got in line by 4:45pm and was the 16th person in line (they can only seat around 25 people i believe). I was super excited to try this place as i'm searching for a new favorite ramen spot.  Of course I had to order the Tori Paitan Ramen.  At first glance at my bowl it looked a bit empty. A few strands of veggies here and there.  I took a sip of the soup and it was good. It was just good. The duck chasu on the otherhand was delicious. I was curious to try out whatever was in the little pots on the table. Those seasonings gave the broth a deeper flavor, but I did not want to ruin the natural flavors of the broth. I absolutely loved the noodles, chewy and delicious! just the way I like it.  I finished all of my broth, because I know how hard they work to achieve that consistency and flavor.
