Would I come here again? Maybe just to try the Vegan Ramen. I've heard great things.   I'll be back soon!
author: Emi K.

description: I heard about this place through a coworker so the BF and I decided to try it out since it is supposed to be "authentic" ramen straight from Japan. I'm not a ramen connoisseur but it was extremely good and flavorful. For drinks, we got 2 Sopporros ($4.75/bottle). For our ramen, we both got the Tori Paitan. A double basically has 2 pieces of pork ($18) and the regular only has 1 piece of pork ($16). Since I'm not a duck person, I replaced my duck with an extra piece of pork. The broth was definitely think and creamy. The pork was delicious and my BF said the duck melted in his mouth. My BF is VERY picky and he even said it was the best ramen he's had and he usually doesn't say that about restaurants often. The noodles were sooooo good!!! We got lucky because our wait to get inside was no more than 15-20 minutes. People in line were saying that it was the shortest it's ever been and usually is a minimum of an hour wait. I guess we got lucky. From waiting in line to paying our bill, I'd say we were in and out in about 1 hour and 15 minutes.
author: Cheryl V.

description: Lines are long but but the ramen is probably some of the best you'll ever taste in your life.
author: Mason W.

description:
Go! Now! Stand in Line and stay there until you get in and eat! It's worth the wait.
Had the Tori Paitan Ramen. The creamy chicken broth is magical, the ramen is think. It's filling but I ate all of it. I noticed people around me didn't finish their broth because they were either full or out of ramen. 
my friends had the other ramen dishes with clear chicken and pork broth and thinner ramen noodles, it didn't compare with the Tori Paitan Ramen. I'm still giving them five stars. 
FYI they have a Vegan Tantanmen for the vegg-es. 
so go, stand in line! Visit the web site, watch the videos about Mensho Tokyo while you're in line. http://mensho.tokyo/ 
go now before there is a three hour wait in line.
author: flashegirl e.

description: Best ramen in SF! My wife is japanese and pretty much cant stand ramen anywhere else.. this is the only place doing it right, and late night!
author: Raphael P.

description: Probably the best ramen I have had in the United States.  If you are are big ramen fan.  This place is worth the 3 hour wait.
author: Anupam D.

description: Quality was high all the ramen were delicious each one has its own flavor and I could switch around from one to the other. I am a boiled egg lover so that was a letdown that they show eggs but they are not serving . It's brand new so overall they did a great job it's small though that's why there is a long wait only seats like 22 people at a time so it's not a place where you have your own table you are sharing a long table with a group of other people
author: Adalia L.

description: Ramen is pretty decent. The tables are tall so definitely not a fancy sit down place like nojo but the communal tables are clean and organized. There is a longer wait than nojo due to smaller restaurant size.
author: Amie L.

description: Came here for my birthday with three friends. The restaurant is small so expect to wait outside or head over to the bar across the street for a drink. They also only seat when everyone in your party has arrived. Once inside, we sat at the bar and all had sapporos to drink and ordered the delicious duck broth ramen. It was heavenly! Every bite was decadent, hot, and perfectly seasoned. Worth the wait!
author: Patricia S.

description: The best ramen I have ever had, and I've had A LOT of ramen. Well worth the wait. My fav is the Spicy Lamb!
author: Sarah S.

description:
So, I thought I updated this review after my second trip there, but I guess not. now, I am not impressed. The first time I had something that wasn't on the menu when I came back about a month later, so I tried the tori paitan which seems to be their main thing. It is just too damn rich for my taste. Kinda of like a lard smoothie. The stuff I said about the place in the review that follows is still true, but the part about it being too much for me is emphasized massively. I can't even think about going back there without shuddering. 
Old review: So I am giving the place 5 because they do a really good job at what they do even though it isn't my new favorite ramen place. 
So, I sat a the "bar", four seats, 3 lefties? Solo, male, left-handed, "sit here so you can crowd each other and not knock elbows with the righties". The good thing was that I got to watch the "ramen magic" happen. For someone who spent many years working in restaurants, and had way too many opportunities too watch people cook, as well as the ongoing dreams of people cooking in slow motion, got to admit I still love to watch. Wow, are those chunks of lard they are adding? I guess so, that is pretty much what paitan is, tasty liquid lard. Slightly disconcerting, but then why boil those pig ankles for hours if not to extract delicious components. And, it is delicious, can't speak for the paitan since I had spicy miso ramen, but it was certainly delicious. Maybe a little too "kotteri" for my taste.
I used to get a magazine called "Lucky Peach", not sure if it still exists, but it was kind of interesting. The first issue was all about ramen, and they included some recipes (which had some major mistakes, still want to spit thinking about the alkali soap noodles I made). This cat Chang, I think his name is, has some hot ramen place in NYC, and was "sharing" his secrets, or trying to poison the unsuspecting. He used Benton bacon instead of katsuobushi, and if you have ever tried this stuff, the bacon I mean, it tastes like it was smoked over truck tires. It is industrial strength. So my point is....
Mensho is kinda an industrial strength ramen, lots of flavor, intense, delicious, perfectly prepared, just not my style. I think the phrase "it is the Mission Chinese of ramen" kind of sums it up. Or as an old "Was, Not Was" song said...
Love how hard the kitchen works to prepare a delicious and beautiful bowl.
author: James T.

description: Love this new take on ramen. The chefs are doing interesting spins on solid traditional broths, which are absolutely delicious. Noodles are spot on--not the instant noodles you get at a lot of fake ramen places. The chashu melts in your mouth and they have a no tipping policy. Perfection.
author: Will L.

description: I'll have to give them another shot when they have their ramen machine. It was disappointing to not be able to order from the menu painted on their wall. Ramen was ok, but not worth $20/bowl.
author: Alison Y.

description:
The noodle and broth were good.  But I just have had so many better ramen noodles that, it really just wasn't a 4-star and not a 5-star one.   
I wouldn't wait for an hour or 2 hours for it... , 

I know, I am speaking of personal experience here!

Anyways, everything was good.  If no line, or few minutes wait, I will come back.
(special thank to my friend who stood in line for 1.5 hours to get us in  ;)   )
author: Allison L.

description: Fairly long (~45 minute) line up but well worth it. The Tori Paitan was excellent, as were the oysters and sake. I definitely look forward to coming here again.
author: Amar D.

description: Good noodle soup and oysters as starters.The place gets organized after you are seated.Long queues served quite fast
author: Frank M.

description: First off, great ramen. Secondly, I loved the little eating area and the opportunities for socializing it created. Thirdly, do not order the Suntory premium malt beer - it is not worth the premium price!
author: Wes V.

description:
Not Worth a Long Wait In Line
You have something better to do, believe  me!!  I saw that this place didn't have a line tonight and decided to see what the line was ll about.   Usually there is a  a really long line and thank god there was no line because the food experience was meh at best.  Maybe cause I'm not into Ramen in general - but like almost twenty dollars for a bowl of Ramen? Really?  I was told the milky sauce would be tasty it was like some kind of icky gravy covering noodles, I'm not sure what kind of thing people are thinking there getting with noodles but you could go home, get some eggs, get some flower, mix em together roll em out, cut em boil em and have noodles and they would not be worse nor probably better than these "Ramen  is  really just a food that's gotten some popularity in the Asian community in my imagination  because it's something grandma used to make, let me tell you, your grandma made better noodles, you should spend more time visiting her and less time waiting in line.  My grandma made better noodles and she was a Scottish, Irish, German. Take her noodles put on some hot sauce and her noodles would be way better.  The sauce that was poured over the noodles was bland even after a lot, and I do mean a lot of hot sauce.  I can't tell you how over rated this place is, I know you probably won't believe me because of all the other reviews and you'll fritter your life away waiting but I tell it's not worth practically one hour of your non refundable lifetime waiting to eat at this place. 

Anyway so  I didn't like the food, it's a large portion and  they don't have a way for you to take half of it home, they also don't have small portions for people who don't like to eat that much,. they have some sustainable organic thing but it it's pointless as people can't take home food so a ton of food gets wasted.  All I know is it's late I have a stomach ache and I think I'm going to at any moment belch out half of the crappy soup from this place.  Don't mistake popularity for good food, it's a foolish.
author: Sara J.

description: Although the wait is ridiculously long during dinnertime, the wait is worth it. Every part of the ramen is of high quality, from the handmade noodles, the creamy broth, the fresh vegetables, and of course the great pork and duck that goes into making a perfect ramen.
author: Kevin S.

description: Rich flavored soup and noodle was thick, hand made. Dont have a lot  of ramen to choose from but ones on the menu definitely have unique taste.
author: Solongo B.

description: Just amazing. From the service, to the amazing ramen, to the friendly vibe of the place. I have never had ramen out a restaurant and I was thoroughly impressed. We're trying to find an excuse to cross the bridge soon to go back. The best part of the whole meal was the ham- OMG, amazing.
author: Kate H.

description: Good authentic ramen. A little pricey at ~$16 for a bowl of ramen, but I guess you are paying for the hype (very long lines!). Brought me back to being in tokyo. I'm hoping that this place inspires other authentic ramen places to pop up in SF (at more reasonable prices).
author: Hank K.

description: Best ra-men I've had in the USA in a long time.
author: Tramale T.

description: The wait wasn't as bad as it looks and the broth was on point! One of the best in the area without a doubt, and the price is really good for what you get.
author: Nicholas S.

description: Really good broth, this is definitely one of (if not the) best ramen places in San Francisco. Count on there being a line out the door.
author: Adam D.

description: Soooooo damnnnnn satisfying, fast and tastes good. You must try all of them!! I love it the workers, there are friendly!
author: Heidy S.

description:
The restaurant opens at 5pm but it doesn't receive customers till 5:30pm. The dishes are not served till 6pm. If you are the first 24 persons in line, add one more hour to your wait time. The 5pm opening time seems to be their staff meeting and food prep time. This part is quite a contrast to the traditional punctual Japanese style.

The inside is clean and modern looking. Staff is courteous. The food tastes precisely as what other reviewers described.
author: J Z.

description: nothing too special, I wouldn't recommend the small little oysters,too too too salty,if I can,I will give 3.5star.the soup is so creamy, I can't finish the noodle,I guess they use the dry noodles to make it, not handmade noodles, it is a little bite hard
author: Sarah B.

description: Waited approximately 45 minutes to be seated around 9pm on a weekend. First glance at the menu, I see ramen at the price of 18.00! I got the shio ramen because I enjoy light flavorful broths (didn't mind how inexpensive it was at $11 in comparison to 18). The other person in my party got the tori ramen and thought it was alright. We also tried the oysters and thought it tasted okay but not memorable. A little on the salty side but we all have different preferences. Because there was still a long line outside we felt kind of rushed to leave. Our time sitting was around 25 minutes and we left with a bill of around 70~ for two people. Id be hard to come back for that 18$ ramen when 18$ can almost give me AYCE shabu or KBBQ.
author: Melissa C.

description: Pretty good ramen! Had high expectations and it met them well. Something is missing for that last star
author: John C.

description:
We walked by late on a Friday night, and as we looked in the large windows, a passerby told us that it's the best ramen in SF, so we decided to check it out the next day. We got in line about 7 pm on a Saturday night, and the line seemed to move reasonably fast. For a party of 2, we waited about 40 minutes. 

The restaurant is clean and bright, with a semi-open kitchen. Unless you have a party of 6, you are going to be sharing a table, but it was spacious enough that it didn't feel crowded. If you want the miso ramen, show up early because they only have 30 bowls a day. We ended up with the shoyu and tori paitan, both had very flavorful broths and distinct flavors. The chasu was good, I preferred the pork over the duck. Overall, the ramen was good, but not so crave-worthy that I'd regularly wait in line for an hour.
author: Amy K.

description: Let me just start off by saying this place is honestly not really worth the wait. Don't get me wrong, their ramen is pretty damn good, but my friends and I waited TWO HOURS to get inside. And even when you finally make it inside, you can't enjoy your food/company because you have like 40 people staring at you through the window waiting for you to leave. So definitely not a spot to chill casually with friends. They open at 5:00 PM so unless you get there like an hour and a half before, you'll be waiting A LONG TIME!! Also, it's like $18.00 for a bowl... So if you're really into your ramen this is a pretty good spot, however if your whatever about your ramen don't even bother.
author: Priscila N.

description: Came here after a night of drinking and needing to some food. Man did this place hit the spot. Highly recommend.
author: Terence P.

description: Not worth the 1.5 hours in line, it was okay. We had the Tori, one single and a double. The meat was delicious but the broth was okay. Also had the oysters. They gave us more than 3 pieces which was great but tasted very fishy.
author: Cassie C.

description: The most popular tori paitan ramen was incredibly rich- so much so that it literally tasted like chicken gravy. For 2 at 6pm on a Friday we waited about 1.5 hours as there is seating only for 20 or so people. I would return hopefully when the hype dies down but I wouldn't order the chicken tori paitan again as it was so rich I couldn't finish it. The ingredients were complex and service was good.
author: Leily P.

description: I am no ramen expert but this was a delicious meal.  I ordered a single serving of the patian and that was more than enough.  The broth was thick and savory.  The noodles we're a little larger than usual for my taste but good. I especially enjoyed the charsu and kale!  Unfortunately, the place is small so the hour long wait is mostly outside and then you order, eat, and go.  No time for messing around or catching up with friends.  So be ready for the food and that's it.
author: Aileen L.

description: Yes, Tori Paitan broth is thick and like gravy. Yes, meat is delicious. Yes, noodles are perfect. Five stars for what it is. Not my preferred style of broth, but flavor on point. Would like to come back as they settle in and tweak the menu.
author: Sarah O.

description: Yup. This is the best Ramen in San Francisco. All their broths have amazing depth in flavor. Ramen noodles are authentic. Different types of noodles are used depending on which broth is being used. Long line when it opens. Waiting time reduces past 10pm. I still can't wrap my head around how their chicken broth is soooooo thick and creamy. It's a taste you don't forget.
author: Ken T.

description: A bit pricey but the Tori Paitan is the best ramen in the city hands down!
author: Yoichi N.

description: Best ramen in the city. Abram spearheaded the SF location and is straight out of Tokyo - incredible guy with an incredible story. Warning - we haven't been here yet without having to wait in line. There is also a strict no sharing rule in the sense that if you are sitting, you must order something. If you go by yourself, you often won't have to wait too long as there are often single seats open at the 'bar' or at the end of a table. It's a tight space, but hopefully they will expand soon! A can't miss for ramen lovers everywhere.
author: Danica W.

description: Fantastic vegan ramen. Ridiculously long wait during peak hours. Try going during the week for an early or late dinner.
author: Rob A.

description: Just tried this place for the first time tonight. Been dying to try it for weeks ever since a coworker recommended it to me. Mensho Tokyo did not disappoint! By far the BEST ramen I have ever had. My bf got the Tori Paitan Ramen and I got the Vegan Tantanmen. The broth was so rich and creamy with splashes of chili oil. It was the best tasting broth I've ever had. Absolutely DIVINE. And the noodles were cooked so perfect. I'm honestly at a loss for words right now because the ramen was THAT good. I can't wait to come back again and again. My only complaint is that it is a very small restaurant with only two long tables so you are seated very close to everyone else at the same communal table. I'm talking bumping elbows close to strangers but it's worth it. The food speaks for itself. What's great too is that they're open late til 11:30. I saw them seating people for dinner still even a few minutes after that. Come early because this place gets packed. I came at 11pm and there was a line outside. However, the service is very fast so the turn out on table space is quick. We waited less than 10 minutes. Definitely check this place out next time you're having a ramen craving. It's the best in SF!!
author: Amanda M.

description:
long wait. but have to give it a try in San Francisco, there arent a lot of good ramen in Las Vegas

Got to the restaruant at around 5:30pm, already a 20-people line waiting. parking is extremely limited, there is a parking next to the restaurant will charge $4 per hour, with that kind of wait it could be at least 2 hours.

Got a seat for party of 2 after 45mins wait. The oyster is very favorful but not my taste, i didnt like it very much. Ordered 2 bowls, the Tori paitan and organic shoyu. the tori paitan was good, a very creamy and strong broth, could fill up the stomach very quickly. The shoyu was not bad either, but the favor gets salty towards the end. 

Service was not bad for a ramen place, servers were polite and helpful. orders were taken correctly. Food come out pretty quick too.

Definitely recommend
author: Tommi N.

description: The broth of the Tori Paitan is so rich and creamy; the pork, specifically, was amazing and the noodles spot on. I've only been able to go once and after having had Ramen in NYC, Toronto, London, other locations in SF and home made this was by far my favorite. The four stars are for the wait to get in; hour and a half standing outside for a first seating. Yeah, the waiting is worth it but a downside. Awesome ramen that I will be eating again!
author: Red R.

description: The wait is long but It didn't bother me after I ate the super tasty ramen. The small fermented oysters were good too!
author: Ly N.

description: Everything about this ramen is great, but it gets 4 stars because the wait is so bad - we were there 15 minutes before opening and still waited an hour and 15 minutes.  Still worth it!
author: Alison D.

description:
Dont waste your time!!! Save your money! 
No Bento, No teriyaki, sushi dry, oily Katsu.
author: Chacha C.

description: I recommend not eating at the Golden Corral in Uniontown, PA.  They have been closed down by the health board for food poisoning.  Here is a link to the photo on their door on Facebook.  https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=10208146433171715&set=a.2421011657828.129358.1627534586&type=3&theater
author: Kevin B.

description: The ramen itself is great, but I think it's overrated. It's not worth 2 hour waiting and price is too high. Wouldn't hurt to try if you have plenty of time
author: Bubble C.

description:
Sooo I guess this place is good with there food.... But man when you come in the hostest told us to be quite......unmmmm excuse me!!!! I'm not in a library. Please!!!! 
So 2 stars on the service
author: Pam M.

description:
I hate to write review because it is waste of time but this place pisses mr off so much.  First, I live in tokyo for 3 years and before that I've beed traveling back and forth japan for years.   I've eaten ramen a lot and from North to South of japan.  Good and bad, from 500-1,500 yen ($4.5-$14) I had them all.

First, parking is hard in down town 40 mins to find a spot.   2nd the waiting line to this hole in the wall is long and moving slow.   Finally I got in... The music sux and loud.  I was offered a menu but within 30 seconds a rude lady stopped by.  "What do you want!"  Really? It was such a warm welcome...
Me: Tonkotsu please
she: not yet! 
Me: not yet about...?
She: not yet!  We don't have
Me: but it is in the menu?
She: we don't have it, not yet.
She was so rude but since i've wasted so much time and hungry then I ordered whatever chicken broth ramen.  The broth was salty and tons of MSG that made me dizzy.  Noodles were stuck together like just microwaved food.  Overall, this place is over rated and not recommended. 

PS Washed my hands before meal but the toilet smell like hell!
author: Cookie M.

description: Be ready for a line that forms before the place even opens. Also be ready for the best ramen you've ever had.
author: Zachary S.

description: I went here to have dinner with my husband, and was told if I didn't order ramen, I had to leave. I wasn't terribly hungry and only wanted the oyster appetizer and a beer. The food servers were pushy and rude and kept insisting "one person, one ramen!" I was willing to buy ramen, but they also have a no take-out policy. The food may have been amazing- but pretentiousness and service make this place not worth visiting.
author: Clark H.

description: I had the Tori Paitan ramen and really enjoyed it.  It was very creamy and flavorful, enjoyed every last bit.  The staff was really friendly and served us as soon as we got seated.  I learned that the chefs came straight from Japan so the ramen is as authentic as it gets.  The place is pretty small though, seats maybe 25 people max and we did wait for awhile to get seated but they're utilizing the resources they have the best they can.  I stood in line around 5pm, about the time that they open, and took us about 2.5 hours to seat our group of 5 people so expect to wait.  So if you don't mind waiting a long time and want to try a good ramen, this is the place!
author: Kevin A.

description:
I've been to most of the most highly regarded ramen places in the Bay Area and LA. This is easily one of the best ramen places I've ever been to. I tried the Tori Paitan Ramen and this broth is arguably the thickest, richest, creamiest non-tsukemen broth I've ever had. And it was delicious.

I also tried the Vegan Tantamen, which had so much rich flavor that I think it may have been the best Vegan food I've ever had. It was like a rainbow of flavor dancing around my taste buds. 

The only downside was they didn't have a tonkotsu ramen or tsukemen available yet. Waiting for that to happen. Oh, the line wasn't too bad when we got there, but I could see people waiting for a while. My fear is that this place gets too popular that the lines stretch forever. There isn't a lot of seating room.
author: Hamlet A.

description: meh~.... this place is okay.... soup is definitely wayyyyy too salty.. tho it taste good no egg in the ramen.. no add on items available.. noodle feels like those instant ramen...  most importantly... the line's wayyyy too long
author: Alexia L.

description: The best ramen in San Francisco for sure!  Probably the best ramen I've ever had in my life. And I don't even eat meat!  But their veggie ramen was fabulous. Great flavor.  The only draw back was that this place is so amazing that they had a line down the street to get inside!  But once you're in, it's worth every minute that you waited to get there!  I've been craving it ever since and the next time I'm in the city, I'll be paying them another visit for sure. Great service too.  Our food didn't take long at all considering how crazy busy they were. And they were playing Ramen TV the whole time, which was pretty entertaining.
author: Nikki L.

description: Food came out at different times, water from previous patrons wasn't cleared, preferencial treatment given to surrounding tables/no recommendations made on food or drink, older woman/hostess and young male host snubbed us throughout meal. For a place that seats 24ish people you would think they would have a full set of silverware and not a hodge podge of bowls/spoons. The place is small and seems very intentionally designed to maximize the use of the space. Servers were very nice, apologetic, and easy to flag down. Long wait time, but that's to be expected given the hype around this restaurant and the multiple delays in its initial open. Tori paitan broth was deliciously creamy, combined slow braised chashu/wonderfully tender rarer, wasn't too oily, but did lack a soft boiled egg.
author: Alex L.

description: Ramen was amazing, tried three different kinds and all were incredibly delicious. Definitely worth the wait.
author: Jorge G.

description:
My friends and I were here on a misty Friday evening. We arrived before 5:30 pm and there was already a long line. Be ready for a really long wait! If you're super hungry, you may want to bring snacks. The group behind us left to buy snacks at some point. Our party of four were finally seated a little after 7:30 pm. Thankfully our bowls of deliciousness were quick to arrive after we'd ordered.

Was it worth the wait? It certainly was! Two friends ordered the tori paitan, which is their richest, creamiest option. One friend ordered the vegan tantanmen, which I loved and attempted to switch with my own bowl of ramen. I ordered the organic shoyu ramen; it was slightly lighter but just as flavorful. They're all good; it just depends on personal preferences.

They currently don't serve eggs in their ramen. We asked the staff and they mentioned they're carefully selecting a type of egg that is equivalent to those in Japan. It's nice to know they're so particular about their ingredients.

I would definitely return but I wouldn't wait over two hours again.
author: Jules G.

description: First time at this Olive Garden, i went with my friend for early dinner... i have to say for a bill that was $50 i was so very disappointed! our endless salad for two had one olive two tomatoes and a few croûtons.... we had the fried lasagna and fried cheese sticks both were awful! tasteless..the meal no bette, .the whole visit was just terrible...will not go back to this one,
author: Debbie S.

description: solid bowl of ramen in the city. rich flavorful broth, thick handmade noodles cooked to perfection, chashu duck... yeah bruh, DUCK. and if you're vegetarian, don't even trip, the vegan ramen is bomb too! menu is limited, but ramen is the star here... well worth the 30min wait.
author: Marky E.

description: best Ramen I've had outside of Japan.  On Point
author: Kimo K.

description: Electrician for Hire Inc. Rick Sanchez in the Coachella Valley. Awesome pro and fixed the job in no time! 760-272-6115. This dude gets the job done!
author: Maarten D.

description:
By far the best ramen shop in San Francisco. Absolutely worth the 1-2 hour wait; the trick is to go at opening or at closing for shorter wait times. I would suggest getting the Tori Paitan ramen for first timers. The soup is extremely rich and creamy, and the pork + duck slices are among the best I've had.

The head chef and owners are extremely knowledgeable about their ramen (one of them has been to over 1,500 different ramen shops in Japan as a professional ramen taster). In fact, they have even refused to add eggs to their ramen until they've found a perfect source in California. Just goes to show how much they care about their craftsmanship. I hope they eventually expand to other locations in the Bay!
author: Andrew W.

description: Ordered a ramen, waited 40 minutes to watch them forget my order and panic to start cooking it.  I was sitting at the bar watching the whole thing.  Worst fucking service ever. I wish 0 stars existed, fuck yo mushroom soup
author: Michael K.

description: So after a 50 min wait in the sun. We are finally seated and they forget our order. And the waitress did not even know that she forgot our order or even knew what I was saying when I said, "hi, where is our food." I just don't understand how you can see a  table that has no food and the tables around them have food already.  So finally, she acknowledged that we didn't get the food and apologized. She gave us some oysters to compensate but now my gf gets the food. And I don't get the dish until ducking 15 mins later. How is this even ducking possible in sf? Worst fucking customer service. I get my food when the people behind me get all their food and finished eating.
author: Jeffrey T.

description:
Went here to try out some Japanese Cuisine.
Quite ok, ramen is really tasty but cleanliness and how it's prepared is somehow kind of OFF. the meat does not look like it's well cooked, although Japanese food are known for rare meat, but this one is not as alluring
author: Julia K.

description: My family is not exactly sure if ramen is actually authentic Japanese cuisine or not, but once you try Mensho Tokyo it won't really matter. The hubby always grabs some steak product here, and me and the kids share various ramen dishes. The waitress always greets you in Japanese and treats you really awesome. This is one of our family go-to's. Excellent!
author: Doris G.

description: Waited an hour and a half and couldn't possibly be happier the owner was very helpful with his descriptions and ramen knowledge it was hands down better than any ramen bowl I've ever eaten get the tori paitan it was honestly perfect
author: Dylan G.

description: I loved the homemade noodles.The lamb soba was terrific. Small but cozy. Expect long lines, but worth it. The vegan ramen was absolutely amazing as well. If you love ramen you must go to Mensho.
author: Mike S.

description: It's definitely one of those top x (be it 3 or 5) ramen in the bay area.  The chasau is very unique, and the soup is tasty.  While I can't say that it tops my list over Ramen Dojo, but it definitely has its place.   Minus one star for being a bit expensive and extremely hard to find parking at peak time in that ghetto neighborhood.
author: Steve J.

description: I came her with my friends around 945pm and waited just about 20 min for DELICIOUS RAMEN! I like this ramen more than any other Bay Area ramen shop and I would gladly come back (probably after 9:30pm so I wont have to wait 2hrs...) to try another bowl of ramen.
author: Nicoline B.

description: Broth was tasty and the ramen was chewy. It was delish. Went at 9pm but still had to wait for over 20 mins. Restaurant was small like most ramen shops in Tokyo. It had like 20 bar-like seats so be prepared to wait.
author: LA B.

description: Long line, long wait. But well worth it! I personally enjoy the tori and also the spicy lamb for when i want something with a kick!
author: Scott C.

description: After Ramen Underground got rid of their tomato ramen, this is my new favorite! It's much better - creamier broth and thick noodles. I had the vegan tantanmen and I liked it! Also tried the tori paitan ramen and highly recommend! Took us an hour to get seated on a Friday at 6:15 pm.
author: Sri S.

description: You deserve this negative rating. This is USA, not Japan. Stop playing tricks on customers! If the restaurant opens at 5pm, then do so! Stop telling us a stupid excuse like "you don't want to overwhelm the kitchen" so WE had to wait in line for an additional 30 minutes from 5pm to 5:30pm while you intentionally only served 1/3 of seats and kept the other 2/3 seats empty! Why did you open the business if it could not fully operate? Why would we help the owner to make a FREE advertisement by standing outside your restaurant in an ugly neighborhood? You chose this location to save money but we had to risk our lives to get in there. I don't mind to pay more for your unworthy expensive food but I wonder WHY I pay more to take a taxi or drive around to find a nice self-parking garage just for your crappy location and service? Also, the business mentality of the restaurant owner must be changed in order to improve aka learn to be a honest businessman because lots of smart ppl living in SF bay area.
author: Freya-Loki O.

description: Really tasty, and one of the richest veggie ramens I've tried. Can't wait for the line outside this place to calm down.
author: Brigitte B.

description: There isn't a word yet for how delicious this ramen is.  This ramen TAKES THE CAKE. Hands down & no way around it. I was eyeing this spot for a long time, and would always see a long line of people out in the front. So one gloomy sf day I braved the line, which ended up moving very quickly to my surprise. Super small spot, very cozy, cool interior, with high tables & stools with wooden boxes below for storing your purses/coats in which I really liked so nothing was hanging or bumping into your legs while you ate. Mensho Tokyo is not  traditional style ramen, it's a little more inventive and "cutting edge" in terms of the ingredients and the style...I THINK. I admit I'm basing this statement off of what I've seen at other ramen restaurants around the Bay Area and Mensho doesn't really have most of the usual items you'd expect. I got the tori paitan ramen and I was bummed that they didn't have a tonkotsu, but then this magical bowl was placed before me and it was truly the best thing that's ever happened to me. I've never had something so flavorful, thick and creamy as this ramen YOU GUYS! I cannot rave about this ramen a lot. Like I said, the vocabulary hasn't been invented yet. All I can say is, I'd wait in a 2 hour long line every day if I had to to get to taste this ramen again and again and again...
author: Shayan S.

description: used to be one of my fav ramen restaurant because of the spicy miso but they removed it from the menu, not coming back until the miso ramen menu is back
author: Felicia T.

description: Arrived at 5:10 P.M. to a line about 25 people big.  Got seated at about 6:00 so wasn't too bad.  The service is very nice and attentive and quickly got us our orders of the Tori Paitan Ramen.  Their soup is creamier and richer than most ramen broths I've experienced.  It not quite as thick and flavorful as Tsukeramen broths, however.  Noodles are spot-on though, and that's one of the most important factors. Chasu and duck is hands-down the best I've had anywhere.  It's a solid 4.5 / 5 stars on taste alone  and lacking that .5 because of its small dining space.  It's really the best ramen in San Francisco.
author: Dylan M.

description: Best Ramen by far in the Bay area. Totally worth the wait.
author: a a.

description: Pretty effing good. But I also only had this once when I was already starving. The broth was super hearty without being overwhelming and the noodles were good. Portions were medium sized, but I still felt sufficiently full when I finished the whole meal. The beer options are limited and rather expensive. Overall would come again.
author: Tianyu Y.

description:
Anyone who has lived in Japan knows that this is just your average, garden-variety, train station ramen with a steeper price tag. And yet, people wait in line for up to 2 hours to sample it - testament to the herd mentality of the current generation of San Franciscans. If you absolutely MUST try it, I suggest you wait until after 10pm when the salturated, (or is saltiated? When you've eaten a bowl of something that contains 500% of your recommended daily intake of sodium?) masses have turned in for the night.  I also advise not going alone, because despite the fact that the seating is shared counter-top, and they don't take reservations, they will seat large groups standing further back in the line, ahead of singles. Service is rushed. I paused for a breath and my server attempted to grab my bowl. Looks were exchanged. The bowl stayed. 
In short, don't believe the hype. The Chinese store across the road sells the same thing in a packet for $3.99. And the service is much friendlier.
author: Bernice C.

description: Authentic and great ramen. Lots of options and prices are reasonable.
author: Maria R.

description: Great Raman!   Its a small place and there always seems to be a line.  However, its worth it.
author: Mike T.

description: Vegan ramen is beyond great. Absurd line at times, but I can see why... maybe the best soup I've ever had.
author: Ian M.

description: Admittedly this was one of my first times having ramen, but it was so good, I'm still thinking about it a week later.  I had the Vegan Tantanmen and it was a whole new experience.
author: Marco G.

description:
has anybody been too mt. laurel animal hospital before they work on your animal they give you estimate of how much it cost there's little concern let me hear your responses.



angelo vitalone sr
author: ANGELO V.

description: walked out of Rye and this place was right next door.. my buddies were saying it was all the rage and super popular so we were about to go in and they said they were closing and we were like "aww" and they said... "ok fine you guys can come in.. last customers" in their endearing japanese way.  my friend said they were known for their Tori Paitan ramen so I ordered that and it came out quick.  Man that is some rich and creamy ramen.. it is like they pureed a whole chicken and it was half porridge half soup.... super chickeny and super tasty.  Duck and pork pieces were good, but the burdock wasn't my fav... would rather have more green... i really enjoyed it even though I was 6 drinks, a whole pizza and some fries deep at that point so I was struggling to keep everything down.  I probably would have enjoyed it even more on an empty stomach and a cold day.  We couldn't finish every drop so we asked for to go containers but they said they don't have to go containers b/c the flavor changes when you take it to go and eat it later... they explained it in their endearing japanese way... we were disappointed, but it made sense to me.
author: Easter E.

description: Simple menu, only one appetizer. Ramen was delicious! Ordered the standard Paitan broth with double chashu.  Was creamy and amazing. Someone next to us had a more clear broth and what looked like egg or rice noodles. Didn't look as good. I also had the smoked oyster appetizer which was great!!!
author: Nelly M.

description: Lives up to the hype, only downside is the wait. Looking forward to going back for more Ramen varieties!
author: Piers Y.

description: Loud music played in the a.m. hours.  The workers are not responsive to requests to turn the music down as it is quite intrusive.  I hope that the manager will take care of this problem and make the place more welcoming.
author: A A.

description: Good but definitely overrated. Not worth the long wait. Tori paitan broth was grainy, oily, and lacked depth.
author: Peachie Y.

description: I followed Mensho for six months before its opening. Checked their website and Facebook regularly, and read just about every article there was on their anticipated opening. When they finally opened and the lines were 2+ hours long, I decided to wait it out. Finally came here on a Sunday afternoon on a whim, got in line around 4:45pm and waited about 1.5 hours. I've had paitan ramen before and was familiar with the texture and the flavors. But I have to say, I was a bit disappointed with my bowl of ramen. Yes, the noodles were cooked to perfection but didn't enjoy the broth so much. It was definitely not worth the wait or the cost! I'm gonna give it a few more months and try his tonkotsu.
author: Q C.

description: The line is long, once inside it took 10 minutes to get our order taken , then another 30 minutes to get our ramen because one guy cooks while the other 3 stands and watches. Lastly the ramen doesn't even arrive together i finished my ramen by the time my friends arrived. Now I understand why the wait is long, what a failure or a restaurant... The vegan tantanmen does taste good and for that they get at least one star. Did i mention our server and manager fought that day and i think she was fired and that caused all the miscommunication.
author: Paul C.

description: One of the best ramen meals I've had in SF, a bit pricey for ramen but was great! Line seems like it's not too bad if you go on a weeknight and there's no more than two of you. Will definietly come back here.
author: Jordan L.

description: Best ramen I've ever had.  What more can I say?  I've been on a mission to come here since they opened several weeks ago, but the line is always far too long.  I lucked out last night and ended up on a short line.  Decided to try the vegan tantanmen.  Noodles: 5/5.  Broth: 5/5 (creamier than I'm used to, but super great), ingredient choices: 4/5.  Absolutely recommend giving this a try if you can stomach the long lines.  I'll definitely be back.
author: Zach S.

description: Ramen broth was good, I wasn't a fan of the noodles because they were slightly thicker then normal. it would be preference. Only thing I didn't like was the ramen was over priced.. we paid around $80 for 4 bowls of ramen and I was still hungry.
author: alex L.

description: I lived in Japan for 5 years as a translator and have eaten good ramen. This would not be among them. I know my ramen and don't make the mistake of referring to one of their styles tonkatsu when it should be tonkotsu FWIW. Their front staff seem as though they all speak Japanese fluently or close to it, so that can be a good sign for a ramen restaurant. But their Shio-Chashu ramen was not what I expected. The amount of katsuobushi (dried fish) in it was so great I doubted whether they gave me the correct dish. It was super-fishy, which isn't what I expect for the broth when it's supposed to be shio (salt). I watched as the cooks were microwaving the noodles in the back. Why? The pork was refrigerated and not only cool, but it was COLD in my ramen. The noodles themselves had very good mouthfeel. But when the soup isn't correct, it's a big problem. I walked by it the night before and I believe the stories of greater than 1 hour wait. I asked the people in line if they had been there before--not a single person had. This may be emblematic for them. I'm glad I went the next day near opening with no line. This is my experience--I'm sure lots of other people had radically different experiences, but to say I was underwhelmed would be an understatement and I ended up not eating more than half of it. It wasn't bad, but it wasn't good, nor was it expected. I don't know if there are better alternatives nearby, but I would have to assume there are.
author: Jason V.

description: Abe's of Maine is fantastic. I am a lawyer and photographer and saved $300 on a new camera. The salesman (Jeff) was honest, smart and cooperative. I have done business with other internet vendors but I won't consider using anyone else for future photographic purposes,
author: Howard R.

description: Ordered the tantanmen which was rich and salty enough that I couldn't finish it. When I asked to take the rest of my order home the server said it wasn't allowed because the chef said "the taste won't be the same." Her attitude was impersonal and dismissive. Mensho is obviously popular and will do business whether or not I return, but this experience made me feel wasteful and undervalued, especially with the location being in an underprivileged neighborhood. At $18 a bowl, Unsure if it merits giving it another try.
author: E P.

description: Simply amazing Ramen. It is a bit on the pricey side ($18 for a bowl of ramen) and they don't put the leftovers in a container (because it changes the flavor apparently) so be prepared to finish the huge bowl. About an hour wait time as well. But still worth it!
author: Basim B.

description: yes toaly all wennies should be fried
author: Charles B.

description: I come down to Bradenton FL twice a year and have always gone to Tandoor first on Clark Rd then they opened Tandoor on Cooper Creek Plaza always as delish as the first time, but today the buffet food/sauce was a little watery, and not up their normal standards . . .   different chief ?? don't know, but we might have to try a different Indian location for my next visit.
author: Sueboo D.

description: This nail salon do very good job , I come to do the gel mani and pedi for couple years. their  service is very good , you can have a snack and drink not like other salon have. They are friendly , when you come to do your nails it like a family. I will tell all my friends and family come to this shop , it is in Japan town.
author: Wendy T.

description: I was travelling back to Canada and heard a strange noise in my Jeep so I visited this dealership to find out the problem--the Service Rep told me he didn't hear anything strange even though I pointed out the noise. Well, a day later we were stuck, during our drive home, on a Saturday afternoon waiting until Monday for the local dealer ship to open so we could have the water pump replaced. When I arrived I asked them to also find out about the new noise and the answer was: 'It's your water pump" --- too bad this dealership doesn't train their people better.
author: Pete L.

description: I can tell that it is made very carefully and nicely, but the soup is just a little bit too heavy/thick for me. Someone who loves thick soup is gonna love it.
author: Dimin X.

description: Do yourself a favor and eat here. Suck it up and wait in line you losers this place is THAT GOOD. Also try the Chinese food place across the street. They don't have a yelp page so I'm adding their 5 star review here.
author: Briana I.

description: GAME CHANGER!! Hands down, the best ramen ever. Food nirvana! The tori paiten dashi was umami on steroids, appropriately rich and flavorful. The shio dashi was clean, with a perfect proportion of fat, and delicate noodles that were both toothsome and tender. I look forward to the menu expansion and monthly specials to come. Congratulations!!
author: Irene T.

description: We were impressed by the Tori Paitan Ramen - it has a very rich, balanced and full bodied flavor with super tender meat. This dish was very unique and having recently traveled to Japan have to say it is different (not spicy, has a thicker broth and no egg), however we were not disappointed and the the overall package was excellent. I would highly recommend this place for anyone looking to experience a unique form of ramen. We are looking forward to visiting more in the coming months when their currently limited menu is expected to expand.
author: Christine D.

description: I'm always looking for good ramen places around the Bay Area, and have tried a couple in San Mateo like Ramen Dojo and Ramen Parlor, as well as Sobo Ramen in Oakland.  Anyways, I got here on a Friday night for a party of 2 and waited a good 45 minutes to an hour, but then again that was expected, so just be prepared.  Inside it was tight, but also something that I expected.  They quickly take your order, as they are trying to get people in and out of the restaurant as quickly as possibly because of the high volume and customers and little room in the place.  Don't worry, there's usually plenty of time to figure out what you want in line.  After that, we got our food, and it was great.  Aside from the fact that their ramen was a little pricey, (almost at the Ramen Shop prices in Oakland) it was still really good and I'd say worth the wait.  I also recently got back from Japan, and had ramen there, and I'd say that this place is definitely competitive.
author: Stephanie F.

description: We tried Mensho for the first time tonight, a week after they opened in SF.  We arrived at the restaurant around 4:30, half hour before they opened and we waited for about 2hrs before we got seated.  I thought it was crazy but it was worth it after we tried their ramen.  They only had two kinds of ramen tonight: Tori Paltanf and Vegan Tantanmen.  I appreciate them for trying to make sure everything is as good as it is in Japan and that's why they rather serve only 2 ramens tonight.  We tried both tonight and I love meat but to my surprise, I liked the vegan tantanmen better.  I thoughtful it was very flavorful and complex and the noodles were cooked perfectly with the right texture and chewiness.  The broth was very thick but it wasn't oily at all.  We will definitely come back to try their shio and shoyu ramen.  By the way, the guy at the door, probably the owner and the staff were all very friendly and welcoming.  Good job!
author: winnie l.

description: warning. everyone has to order a bowl. no splitting. even if you cannot finish a bowl by yourself. you are not allowed to order only one bowl for 2 people. also, all that is advertised is not currently on the menu. they do not offer the tsukamen ramen that is plastered on their walls. will not be coming back.
author: Lee H.
